HEADLINE: Robert W. Ponte, 46, Urban Planner, Dies

 BODY:
Robert W. Ponte, an urban planner who helped design major developments in New York City and Tehran, Iran, died on Jan. 17 at St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan. He was 46 years old and lived in Manhattan.
He died of heart failure, his brother, Joseph, of Falls Church, Va., said.
Dr. Ponte was an expert on zoning regulations and the economic consequences of urban development projects. While with the planning firm of Cooper, Eckstut Associates in Manhattan he helped prepare master plans for Battery Park City and the 42d Street Redevelopment Project.
In the early 1970's he served in the Mayor's Office of Midtown Planning and Development. Later, he was part of a four-person team that created a master plan for the Shah of Iran for the redevelopment of the center of Tehran.
From 1984 until his death, he directed real-estate and market analysis for Buckhurst Fish Hutton Katz Inc., a Manhattan architectural firm. He also lectured on urban planning at Princeton University. He received his Ph.D. from Columbia University in 1971.
In addition to his brother, he is survived by his parents, Joseph and Grace Ponte of Cornwall, Pa., and a sister, Arlene Clanton of West Lynn, Ore.

HEADLINE: Lag Found in Kidney Transplants for Blacks

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Blacks receive fewer kidney transplants than whites, are less likely to donate kidneys and do not do as well as whites after transplants, a study by transplant doctors says.
At the same time, blacks are more likely than whites to suffer from serious kidney disease requiring either a lifetime of kidney dialysis or a transplant, said the study, which is being published today in The New England Journal of Medicine. 
 The relative lack of kidney donors who are black may be one reason blacks receive fewer kidneys, said Dr. Martin G. White, who directed the study for the American Society of Transplant Physicians. The society consists of kidney specialists and others who care for patients who have received organ transplants.
"Most of the organs are going to be coming from the white population, and fewer of them are going to be well matched for the black population," Dr. White said.
That may also be the reason that the survival of transplanted organs is about 10 percent lower in blacks than in whites, the study said.
 
Social and Economic Factors
 Dr. White and his colleagues speculated that social and economic factors also had a role in the transplant inequities between blacks and whites. For example, blacks who are poor may be less likely than whites to carry insurance that will cover the costs of transplants, Dr. White said.
Many of the problems noted in the study have been known for some time, but "this is the first time that a comprehensive review looking at all of the issues has been put together in one piece," Dr. White said.
Dr. David Sutherland, president of the American Society of Transplant Surgeons, said the inequities were not because of bad intentions on the part of surgeons involved in transplants.
"I don't know of any surgeon who would bypass a black to do a white," said Dr. Sutherland, who practices at the University of Minnesota Hospital. He attributed the problem to the difficulty of matching white donors' organs to blacks.
Dr. Clive Callender, director of the transplant center at Howard University Hospital in Washington, said his research found several reasons for the shortage of donations.
Among them, he said, are a lack of awareness of transplants among blacks, religious misgivings about donating organs and distrust of the medical system.
An experimental community education project has sharply increased knowledge of transplantation and organ donation among blacks in Washington, he said.

 BODY:

* Dade County Health Facilities Authority, in Florida, is offering $38.8 million in tax-exempt hospital revenue bonds for a Baptist Hospital of Miami project, through underwriters led by Paine Webber Inc. Interest rates range from 5.60 percent to 6.75 percent. Because the bonds are insured by the Municipal Bond Investor's Assurance Corp. they are rated Aaa by Moody's and AAA by S.& P.
 
* Limited Inc. is offering $150 million in 9 1/8 percent notes due in 2001 at 99.29, to yield 9.235 through Morgan Stanley & Co. The noncallable notes are rated A-1 by Moody's and A by S.& P.
 
* Warner-Lambert Co., Morris Plains, N.J., has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for up to $250 million in senior unsecured debt securities.
 
COMMON STOCK
 
* Microwave Laboratories Inc., Raleigh, N.C., has filed for a rights offering to buy 2.5 million common shares at 30 cents each.
 
RATINGS
 
* Goodyear Tire and Rubber Co.'s long-term debt and commercial paper ratings are being reviewed for possible downgrading by S.& P. The tire marker is based in Akron, Ohio.
 
* Horn & Hardart Co.'s senior subordinated debenture, convertible subordinated debenture and subordinated note rating has been lowered to B-3, from B-2, by Moody's.
 
* Scandinavian Airlines System's debt is under review for possible downgrading by Moody's. S.A.S., a consortium owned by private and government companies from Denmark, Norway and Sweden, is based in Stockholm.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Investors Bid Up Retailing Stocks

BYLINE: By Isadore Barmash

 BODY:
IN an odd offshoot of the Persian Gulf conflict, investors have been bidding up the stocks of retail companies, even though consumers seem so caught up in the war news that they are not doing much shopping.
Some analysts conclude that investors have already written off the fact that department stores and specialty clothing stores will fare badly in the first half of this year. They say these investors are counting on a surge in consumer confidence and retail sales in the second half and so are buying up these stocks now at what they consider to bargain prices. 
 Since the war started Jan. 16, the stocks of several leading American retailers rose fairly steadily. The Dayton Hudson Corporation rose to $61,50, from $56.50; the K Mart Corporation to $31, from $27; Wal-Mart Stores to $33, from $29.75; the J. C. Penney Company to $51.125, from $44.625; the May Department Stores Company to $46.25, from $40.50, and the Limited to $22.25, from $20.25.
An exception was Dillard Department Stores, which was about flat at $90, from $89.75.
Some of the reasons given for a possible recovery are expectations that interest rates will go lower; that inflation will be stablized at moderate levels, and that the Federal Reserve will take more agressive action to control credit costs. These moves, combined with an end to the war later this year, would inspire consumer buying, especially of big-ticket products.
Janet Mangano, vice president for research atJesup, Josephthal & Company, New York, added that large institutional investors were buying names to invest in, like Nordstrom Inc., the Limited and Tiffany. "Their short-term fundamentals may not be glowing, but their long-term fundamentals are," she said.
Other analysts remain skeptical.
"January has been a very slow month in retail business but it worsened after Jan. 16," said Robert F. Buchanan, retail analyst at Alex Brown & Sons, Baltimore. Meanwhile, he said: "Retail stocks largely are going the opposite way as though their investors anticipate a rise in the second half. But I, for one, still remain negative for a number of reasons."
He cited the seven-tenths of 1 percent decline in real disposable income in November, the last month reported. "It's not a big drop," he said, "but the trend is significant." He said real disposable income grew 4.6 percent in 1988 and 2.4 percent in 1989, "but the numbers in 1990 have steadily declined."
In other negative indicators, he cited high consumer debt levels and slippage in the savings rate. "As a result of these and other factors, we are not recommending the retail group," he said. "But the second half does have something tangible going for it. It will be up against a bad Christmas in 1990 so that the 1991 holiday period can be better and that would help the second half."
Since so many analysts and investors have virtually written off the first half, the only surprise that may emerge will be "the degree of the downward results," said Wayne Hood, retail analyst for Prudential-Bache Securities, New York. Since October, retail stocks have rallied in expectation of a second-half improvement, he said. The growth companies like Wal-Mart and Home Depot that do not have high debts have done among the best, Mr. Hood said.
Retail business is not good "and the war certainly hasn't helped, but the real problem is the economic uncertainty that so many people feel," said Ms. Mangano of Jesup, Josephthal. "Unemployment is rising in several fields, and this builds job insecurity."
Some experts say consumers are responding cautiously to the cautious stance of retailers.
"We have entered a year when most retailers are keeping tight control of their inventories and looking for opportunistic purchases to stimulate the apathetic consumers," said Walter F. Loeb, president of Loeb Associates, a New York consulting company.
Sensing an even greater public caution because of the Middle East war than before, he said, retail companies are not taking any flyers on new styling but are offering the public primarily basics or classic clothes. "Yet, it's likely that a good fashion message is just what is needed to get the customers in," he said.
Thomas Rauh, regional director of retail services for Ernst and Young, the accounting company, said: "There's an enormous amount of uncertainty today among consumers over the Mideast crisis. I don't see a return of consumer confidence for awhile. There are economic concerns, too. For the first time in the lives of many consumers, real estate values, particularly in the East, are going down. That has a chilling effect."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
The Dollar Is Mostly Lower; Gold Is Down in New York

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar weakened yesterday against most major currencies, particularly the German mark, after an unexpected increase in interest rates by Germany's central bank.
Gold prices continued to weaken in worldwide trading. On the New York Commodity Exchange, bullion for current delivery settled at $365.80 a troy ounce, down $3 from Wednesday. The Republic National Bank in New York quoted at late bid for gold of $365.80 an ounce, off $1.95. 
 Gold had fallen sharply on Wednesday largely on technical factors and amid rising hopes for peace in the Persian Gulf, analysts said.
Currency dealers attributed the dollar's decline yesterday mainly to the German Bundesbank's surprise decision to raise its key official lending rates by half a percentage point.
The German discount rate rose to 6.5 percent, while the Lombard rate was lifted to 9 percent.
"I think it generally was a surprise, given the slowing down of economies globally," said Ronald H. Holzer, a vice president and dealer at Harris Trust and Company in Chicago.
Higher interest rates in a foreign country make the country's currency more attractive, and the dollar less attractive, to investors.
Economists said higher German rates could force a realignment of the European Monetary System, which regulates currency exchange rates within the community.
In New York, the dollar fell to 1.47695 German marks, from 1.4880 marks on Wednesday. Earlier, in Europe, it traded at 1.4785 marks, down from 1.4920.
The dollar was weaker against the British pound. Sterling bought $1.9665 in New York, up from $1.9630 on Wednesday, and $1.9650 in London, up from $1.9600.
In Tokyo, where the global trading day begins, the dollar fell to 131.40 yen, from 131.70 yen on Wednesday. It traded at 131.45 yen late in London, and at 131.26 yen in New York, up from 131.10 yen.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late quotes on Wednesday, included: 1.2578 Swiss francs, down from 1.2625; 5.0245 French francs, down from 5.0490; 1,111.25 Italian lire, down from 1,115.50, and 1.16325 Canadian dollars, up from 1.16035.
Gold dealers said prices were volatile largely because of thin activity.
"The thinness makes the market too dangerous to get into any big exposure," one Zurich trader said.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
U.S. Securities Up; Trading Slow

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
As it had promised on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve yesterday added huge reserves to the banking system as a way of offsetting its rising cash balances. But that did little to excite participants in the credit market, who were more interested in the employment numbers for January that the Labor Department will release this morning.
Prices of Treasury securities inched higher in slow trading, as participants placed a modest bet that the unemployment numbers would show the economy remained weak. 
 Despite the optimism, analysts said today's Labor Department report would be difficult to decipher, largely because of seasonal adjustment factors that might overstate the number of workers employed in the retail sector.
As a result of the potential distortions, estimates vary widely on what the data will show, from a decline of 200,000 in non-farm payroll employment to a rise of 300,000. In December payroll employment fell by 76,000.
"Most observers will go to the retail trade category first, and try to determine what sort of influence it had on the overall number," said William V. Sullivan Jr., a senior vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds. "But most of the other employment categories are likely to show some weakness, and there is a general sense in the market that the report will be weak."
 
Market Participants Wary
 Most market participants were not willing to step in and buy securities, however.
"The day before employment numbers come out everybody usually stays pretty close to home," one government bond trader said. "This is no exception."
The Fed did not disclose how much it had added to the system. Joseph Liro, a senior vice president and money market economist at S. G. Warburg & Company, estimated that the central bank added between $10 billion and $12 billion to the system.
The action was taken to try and prevent the overnight rate for bank loans in the Federal funds rate from skyrocketing. Mr. Liro said that without the reserve addition yesterday the funds rate would have soared beyond 100 percent.
As it was, funds traded in a very wide range, and well above the Fed's perceived target rate of 6.75 percent. By late in the day, the funds rate was trading at around 11 percent, after being as low as 7 percent early in the session.
"Some of the pressures on funds are clearly due to tax flows into the Treasury that were of unexpectedly large dimensions," Mr. Sullivan said. "Beginning in February the pressures on the funds rate should ease as Treasury balances decline sharply. That should take a lot of volatility out of the funds rate, and allow us to see whether or not the Fed is of a mind to ease monetary policy."
Members of the Fed's policy-making Open Market Committee will meet in Washington for two days next week to consider any possible policy moves.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 3/4 percent 30-year bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 106 5/32 late yesterday, up 7/32, to yield 8.19 percent, down from 8.22 percent late Wednesday.
Among note issues, the 8 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 103 9/ 32, up 3/32, to yield 7.86 percent. And the 7 percent two-year notes were offered at 99 30/32, up 1/32, to yield 7.03 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates were narrowly mixed.
By late in the day, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 6.18 percent, up a basis point, or hundredth of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates fell by 3 basis points, to a late offered rate of 6.18 percent.
A number of new deals were priced in the investment-grade corporate bond market, including a $250 million offering of twelve-year notes for the Unocal Corporation.
The 9 1/4 percent notes, which mature Feb. 1, 2003, were priced at $99.214, to yield 9.36 percent, 1.33 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 1/2 percent 10-year notes at the time of pricing.
Merrill Lynch & Company acted as lead manager for the underwriting. The securities are rated Baa-1 by Moody's Investors Service and BBB by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
Morgan Stanley & Company acted as lead manager on an offering of $150 million worth of securities for the Limited Inc.
The 9 1/8 percent notes, which mature Feb. 1, 2002, were priced at $99.20, to yield 9.235 percent, 1.20 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 1/2 percent 10-year notes at the time of pricing.
The issue is rated A-1 by Moody's and A by Standard & Poor's.
In other developments, the Federal Reserve Board reported yesterday that all three measures of the nation's money supply posted strong gains in the week ended Jan. 22.
Most Wall Street analysts had been anticipating large increases in the aggregates. Consequently, the money report had no impact on prices in the credit markets.
In the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds, traders said prices of most issues rose by 1/4 point to 3/8 point in fairly active trading.
In the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds, prices of most widely quoted issues improved by about 1/4 point, dealers said.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Xerox's Earnings Rise 11% On Strong Sales for Copiers

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

 BODY:
The Xerox Corporation said yesterday that stronger-than-expected copier sales lifted fourth-quarter earnings 11 percent, overcoming a sharp decline in earnings from financial services.
Xerox shares rose sharply, gaining $5.375 yesterday, or more than 12 percent, to $48.75, on the New York Stock Exchange. 
 The company said it earned $235 million, or $2.27 a share, up from $212 million, or $2.01 a share, in the 1989 period, Revenues rose 10 percent, to $5.01 billion, from $4.55 billion in the last quarter of 1989.
 
Office Equipment Gains
 Xerox said that document processing income, which includes copiers, printers and related office equipment and supplies, jumped 36 percent, to $230 million, from the quarter a year earlier on a 15 percent revenue gain, to $3.91 billion. By contrast, income for the last three months of 1990 from the Stamford, Conn.-based company's Crum & Forster insurance subsidiary and its other financial businesses fell 37 percent, to $17 million, as revenues fell 6 percent, to $10.9 billion.
The earnings picture was complicated by a number of one-time charges and gains. The company gained $50 million, or 53 cents a share, after taxes from the sale of South Pacific copier operations to Fuji Xerox Company, its joint venture with Fuji of Japan. Xerox's financial arm had a $145 million pretax gain from the sale of Navco, an auto insurance subsidiary. That gain was partly offset by a $100 million addition to reserves to cover potential losses from policies that financially pressed reinsurance concerns may fail to honor. The company recorded a $12 million loss on discontinued operations in the quarter.
"I'm not sure why they had such strong copier sales in a recession or whether it's sustainable, but there's no way to look at the quarter as a negative one," said B. Alex Henderson, who follows Xerox for Prudential-Bache.
 
Yearly Net Off 65%
 For the year, Xerox's net income fell more than 65 percent, to $243 million, or $1.66 a share, from $704 million, or 6.56 a share, in 1989, largely because of $375 million writedown in the first quarter of 1990 of the company's investment in VMS Realty Partners and the steep fall in capital gains in Crum & Forster's investment portfolio to $53 million in 1990 from $379 million in 1989. Net income from Furman Selz, the company's investment banking subsidiary, fell to $12 million last year from $23 million in 1989.
Net income from all financial services plummeted to $6 million, from $165 million in 1989. Xerox's total revenues for the year rose more than 4 percent, to $17.97 billion from $17.23 billion.
"I am encouraged with our progress, recognizing that 1990 was a very challenging year, with deterioration of economic conditions in the United States, slow economic growth in much of Europe and economic disruptions in Latin America," said Paul A. Allaire, the company's president and chief executive since last August. "We are cautiously optimistic about our prospects in 1991."

HEADLINE: Home Sales Fall in Month; 1990 Total at 8-Year Low

BYLINE: REUTERS

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31

 BODY:
Sales of new homes plunged in December, ending 1990 on a sour note as total sales for the year fell to their lowest level since the recession of 1982, the Commerce Department said today.
Industry analysts said consumers were so shaken in the final weeks before the Persian Gulf war by concerns about the impending conflict and fears for their jobs that they stopped looking for new homes. 
 As a result, sales dropped by 6.7 percent, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 463,000 in December, the lowest since a 407,000-unit rate was recorded in August 1982 during the 1981-82 recession.
 
Weak Showing for Year
 For all of last year, actual sales of new homes fell by 17.5 percent, to 536,000, from 650,000 in 1989. The showing was also the weakest sales performance in eight years. Only 412,000 homes were sold in 1982.
Home sales have been falling since 1986, when they peaked at 750,000 at the midpoint of an eight-year boom that began in November 1982 and lasted until recession set in again late last year.
"These sales drops are not interest-rate or finance-driven because rates were lower in December," said David G. Seiders, the chief economist for the National Association of Home Builders, a Washington trade group.
"Nor is the credit crunch affecting the home buyers," he added. "So, we can pin this heavily, if not entirely, on a collapse in consumer confidence."
The Conference Board, a business research organization based in New York, said this week that its surveys showed that consumers were now more pessimistic about the future than they had been in a decade.
Since consumers fuel two-thirds of economic activity by buying goods and services, their low confidence suggests little likelihood the economy will be rescued soon from recession by a spending spree.
Mr. Seiders said he hoped the first quarter of this year would be the low point for new-home sales, but said he was forecasting sales for the year at only about 500,000.
 
Interest Rates Lower
 Tom Holloway, an economist with the Mortgage Bankers Association, also in Washington, noted that interest rates for 30-year mortgages dropped to an average 9.67 percent in December, from 10.01 percent in November, and fell even further in January, to around 9.5 percent.
Since the gulf conflict began on Jan. 17, oil prices have fallen and stock market prices have risen, which might encourage potential home buyers, Mr. Holloway said.
"It may be that December was the bottom or very close to the bottom of the home-sales market," he said. But he too forecast that 1991 sales would only be around 530,000, below last year's total.
Despite the weak sales last year, the average sale price of a new home for the year rose modestly, to $150,000 from $148,800. In December alone, the average was up significantly, to $163,500, from $145,700, a figure analysts said was affected by more sales of expensive homes in California.
In addition, the National Association of Realtors, a Chicago-based group representing sales agents, said that based on its monthly National Housing Affordability Index, homes were more affordable in December for the average American family than they had been since early 1977.
The index takes into account income, prices and interest rates and measures whether an average family can carry the monthly mortgage payments on a new home.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Barriers to Ending The Credit Crunch

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
IN his State of the Union Message, President Bush jawboned the banks and the Federal Reserve. "Sound banks should be making more sound loans," he said. "And interest rates should be lower, now."
And the stock market surged on expectations that the Administration would use its weight to break the credit crunch and bring rates down. 
 Indeed, in an interview, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve's chairman, appeared to follow the President's line in saying the credit crunch had been "as severe as any supply-induced constraint ever, other than from policy actions."
In fact, the United States now seems to have two monetary policies: one conducted by the Fed, the other by private banks. The Fed's policy is loosening, the banks tightening.
The Fed did hang tight until after Iraq invaded Kuwait in August. Mr. Greenspan blames the Persian Gulf crisis for causing the recession. Critics of the Fed blame him.
Despite earlier efforts to coax the banks to lend more money to fight the recession, the banks worry about their own survival and will not. Their complaint is that the regulators are making it too tough for them, marking many of their real estate loans down to zero and squeezing them for capital they do not have and cannot raise.
A result of the private monetary policy has been the credit crunch, which has cut money supply growth below the bottom of the Fed's target range. An increase in bank lending is the mechanism by which business and consumer spending would increase and the money supply and its velocity would grow, thereby ending the recession.
Mr. Greenspan said a "necessary condition" of recovery would be for banks to get over their own crisis of confidence. Action by the Fed to cut rates, though one means of lifting banks' profits, may notbe enough to break the credit crunch.
There are international forces, in any case, that could bar the way to a sharp fall in American rates now. "Investors may not have noticed that U.S. short-term interest rates have been the world's lowest since August," said Morris Offit, president of Offitbank, an investment management bank based in New York.
On Aug. 31, three-month Euro-deposits were yielding 8 percent for the dollar, 8.38 percent for the German mark and 8.13 percent for the Japanese yen. Since then, the yield on the dollar has fallen to 6.88 percent, while the yield on the mark has risen to 9.13 percent and the yen has held firm at 8.13 percent.
In fact, the spread between American and foreign rates still appears to be widening. Yesterday,, the German Bundesbank raised the rate at which it offers funds to the money market to 9 percent from 8.5 percent.
This is the first time that such an interest-rate environment, with foreign rates so far above American rates, has existed since 1973, when the dollar began to float -- and floated downward.
A basic cause for the current spread in interest rates is that the United States economy has slid into a recession while the economies of Germany,Japan and other countries are expanding. Germany and Japan are now facing internal capital requirements that will cause government spending to balloon, widening deficits and raising inflationary pressures that their central banks are seeking to check by tightening money and raising rates.
The widening spread in rates could cause billions of dollars in American assets to move overseas. That might worsen recessionary pressures at home and, at the same time, weaken the dollar.
Actions by Germany and Japan and other industrial countries to reduce their budget deficits, ease monetary policy and bring rates down -- the prescription that foreign governments have long urged on the United States -- would serve common interests and the global economy by promoting investment, more vigorous economic growth and international trade. The United States Treasury might push harder for coordinated economic policies within the Group of Seven industrial nations, consisting of the United States, Germany, Japan, Britain, France, Canada and Italy.
The war has made it more difficult to stay on the course toward a lower Federal budget deficit and easier money; that may be one reason why Mr. Greenspan warned that if the war lasted through April, the nation could face a long and deep recession. Another is that a prolonged war would be damaging to business, consumer and banking confidence, delaying any solution to the credit crunch.
Mr. Bush did not disclose any specifics of his proposals for shoring up the banking system this year. With the President preoccupied with the war and with the White House, Treasury, Fed and others tangled in controversy over banking changes, economic policy is being largely neglected.
The President turned to Mr. Greenspan, like a totemic figure, to head a commission that might help him in getting a cut in the capital gains tax through Congress. In itself, the call for such a commission is of scant interest. But it may signal Mr. Bush's decision to reappoint Mr. Greenspan as Fed chairman when his term expires in August. That move will also depend on whether Mr. Greenspan's Fed can extricate the President and the nation from a deepening recession if the war drags on.

HEADLINE: Reporter's Notebook;
Budget Numbers Are Cut and People Bleed

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 31

 BODY:
Easily obscured by the New York State budget's antiseptic ledger of numbers -- the $6 billion gap, the $4.5 billion in cuts -- were flesh-and-blood New Yorkers who felt real anguish today.
Loud wails could be heard from the public employees, up to 7,500 of whom may be laid off, and from the legion of lobbyists who are paid to denounce every threatened offense. But there also were quieter protests from people far from Albany, where a thick book of numbers can have a deeply personal effect. 
 They came from people like Dolores A. Mitcham of Chautauqua County, whose husband, Walter, is waging a recurring battle against mental illness.
In late 1989, Mr. Mitcham was hospitalized at Gowanda Psychiatric Center, a 300-bed hospital that serves a four-county area in the rural Southern Tier. His stay lasted only 30 days, but his condition, which is diagnosed as manic depression, makes a return trip possible at any time.
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's budget would close Gowanda by phasing it out over two or three years. The hospital has a $27 million operating budget that comes entirely from the state. If it closes, the nearest psychiatric hospital would be in Buffalo, nearly a two-hour drive from the Mitchams' home in Frewsburg.
"It's very disturbing to me," Mrs. Mitcham said. "Nobody likes to be hospitalized, but if they are they like to be as close to home as possible."
When her husband was hospitalized at Gowanda, it took Mrs. Mitcham almost an hour to drive there. She and other family members made two trips a week, and she said she thought that the visits had sped her husband's recovery. If he was hospitalized in Buffalo, she said, she would have to limit her visits to one a week at the most.
"I couldn't afford it, especially with the Governor talking about raising the gas tax by 10 cents a gallon," she said.
Frustration was also in the voice of Mark W. Jones, the planning and development director of the Glimmerglass Opera in Springfield Center, near Cooperstown. Because Mr. Cuomo proposed a 56 percent reduction in grants awarded by the state's Council on the Arts, Mr. Jones fears that one of his company's three summer productions could be imperiled.
Glimmerglass has already been promised a $35,000 state grant for the coming year. If much of it is cancelled, Mr. Jones said, it may be difficult to produce Gilbert and Sullivan's "Mikado" or Beethoven's "Fidelio."
"Imagine the "Mikado" being done with a piano rather than an orchestra," he said.
Glimmerglass, which has a $1.8 million budget, is one of thousands of arts agencies around the state that divided $56.4 million in grants last year from the Council on the Arts. For many of the smaller groups the grants are considered life's blood.
"I know that there are constantly new estimates of what the budget gap is going to be every month," Mr. Jones said. "But these things are devastating to the small nonprofit organizations."
 
Cuts Close to Home
While Mr. Cuomo did not formally unveil his budget until today, he has been laying the political groundwork for months. He spent much of the fall and winter warning of the hard times to come, thus lowering expectations. He allowed many of the most painful announcements to trickle out in advance, thus softening their impact over time.
And he carefully insulated himself from any accusation that he was not personally sharing in the pain. First he canceled his inauguration celebration, saving a symbolic $70,000. Then he formed a commission to study the possibility, among other things, of selling portions of the grounds of the Governor's Mansion.
Next he canceled a dinner that is traditionally given for news executives on budget day, replacing it with an afternoon briefing where coffee and cookies were served. And when the document was published today, it included a 10 percent cut of $873,800 in the Governor's office budget and the postponement of the Liberty Scholarship program, a centerpiece of the Governor's social agenda.
 
Lining Up for Bad News
Most people are not willing to pay for bad news.
But shortly after Mr. Cuomo proposed his budget today, hundreds of lobbyists lined up outside Room 117 of the State Capitol to await their chance to pay $10 for five pounds and four ounces of fiscal gloom.
The budget is always a hot-selling item in Albany, but it was easier to rationalize spending money on it back in the days of wine and roses.
The director of the New York State Motor Truck Association, Martin G. Carson, shook his head as he looked over his shoulder at the line snaking out of Room 117 and into the lobby of the Capitol. "It's amazing that anybody wants to read this thing this year," said Mr. Carson, whose organization quickly denounced the Governor's proposal to raise the tax on gasoline and diesel fuel by 10 cents a gallon. "It's nothing but bad news."
The thick budget books, which ran 618 pages this year, were distributed free until 1988. "Because they were free, everybody wanted them, and then we'd walk around and find them in trash cans," said Claudia Hutton, the spokeswoman for the state's Budget Division.
It was then that a $10 fee was imposed, recovering most of the cost of producing the book.
Many lobbyists standing in line today said they did not mind paying for the book, believing that they were making a small contribution toward reducing the state's $6 billion budget gap.
And the recession did not seem to have a chilling effect on sales. The state sold 429 copies of the budget book today, compared with 332 on budget day last year, perhaps showing that bad news travels faster than good.

HEADLINE: Bundesbank Lifts 2 Key Interest Rates

BYLINE: By FERDINAND PROTZMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BONN, Jan. 31

 BODY:
Germany's central bank raised two leading interest rates today in a surprise move that is likely to slow global economic growth and further strain the country's relations with its main European trading partners.
While higher interest rates were expected soon, no action was foreseen today. Karl Otto Pohl, the president of the central bank, the Bundesbank, said earlier this week that international political conditions were not right for such a move. 
 Economists said today that the higher German rates created a less favorable climate for the United States to lower interest rates in the face of its recession, but added that the war in the Persian Gulf clouded the situation so much that it was hard to predict the long-term effect of the Bundesbank's move.
 
Dollar to Remain Weak
 The higher German rates, however, do mean that the dollar is likely to remain relatively weak against the mark until at least the middle of the year, despite the support the American currency has received from investors seeking a safe harbor for their money because of the war.
More broadly, the economists said the move would aggravate the cool relations between Germany and some of its main trading partners. At the meeting of the Group of Seven leading industrial nations in New York earlier in the month, Germany was strongly criticized by the other nations for maintaining restrictive monetary policies while many countries were facing the prospect of economic recession.
While Germany's economy is growing robustly, thanks largely to pent-up consumer demand in eastern Germany, growth elsewhere in Europe has been slowing. French, Spanish and Italian officials had hoped to lower interest rates to improve their flagging economies, but the Bundesbank's move will put pressure on them to raise interest rates or accept an adjustment of currency exchange-rate parities to keep their economies somewhat competitive.
 
Dollar Declines
 The announcement that the Bundesbank's benchmark discount rate and its short-term Lombard rate would each be raised by a half a percentage point, to 6.50 percent and 9 percent, respectively, pushed the dollar lower in foreign-exchange trading and sent stock and bond prices on European exchanges slightly lower before recovering as trading closed.
The discount rate had been at 6 percent since October 1989. The Lombard rate was lifted by half a percentage point in November. The discount rate is what is paid on commercial banks' borrowing from the central bank against bills as collateral. The Lombard is the rate paid by the banks on short-term borrowing, using securities as collateral.
 
Others Follow Suit
 The rate increases were rapidly followed by similar rises by the Dutch and Austrian central banks.
At a news conference in Frankfurt today, Mr. Pohl defended the Bundesbank's actions, saying the central bank was obliged to prevent inflationary trends rather than react to them.
"I am concerned this decision will not be completely understood, especially abroad," he said. "But this is a technical move needed to adjust to money market rates. We are in a difficult period."
The interest rate rise was approved at today's regularly scheduled meeting of the Bundesbank's policy-setting body, the central bank council. It consists of the seven Bundesbank directors and the heads of the 11 western German state central banks.
 
Technical Problem Cited
 Economists agreed that a genuine technical problem had existed on the German money market. Eckhard Cornehl, the chief economist with Bank Julius Bear in Frankfurt, said the fact that some short-term money market rates had risen above the Lombard rate encouraged banks to borrow at the cheaper Lombard rate, which is intended for emergency lending. This shift made some action inevitable, he said.
"But I think Mr. Pohl was not for this increase," Mr. Cornehl said. "It looks like the state central bank governors pushed this through against the wishes of the Bundesbank directors. What they have done is created a big problem for other nations in the European Monetary System. If they don't follow the increase, then eventually the exchange rates will have to be realigned, with possibly a devaluation of the franc."
He added "No one really wants that, given all the turmoil in the world at the moment."
 
U.S. Has No Comment
 WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Bush Administration officials declined to comment for the record today on the German increase in its two leading interest rates. But a senior Administration official who spoke on condition that he not be identified said the increase was "obviously a concern because already high interest rates are starting to be a drag on growth around the world."
The official said that "it would be better if central banks were promoting growth rather than dealing with a transitory increase in inflation."
But a Treasury Department official played down the action, noting that it "reflects internal economic and financial considerations" and "appears to have been largely discounted by the markets."

HEADLINE: Bush Proposes More Anti-Drug Spending

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31

 BODY:
President Bush declared today that while the nation was making unmistakeable progress against illegal drugs, much more remained to be done, and he called for an 11 percent increase in Federal spending to expand the drug war.
Responding to criticism that his anti-drug program has emphasized law enforcement to the detriment of treatment and prevention, Mr. Bush said several new health initiatives were included in the new $11.65 billion spending proposal, up $1.13 billion from the current fiscal year. 
 But independent drug experts and Congressional critics asserted that while spending for treatment would rise by $260 million in the President's plan, the proportion of the total budget designated for health-related programs would decline, to 30.3 percent from 31.2 in the current fiscal year.
"Despite it's rhetoric to the contrary, the Administration continues to shortchange treatment and prevention programs that reduce the demand for drugs," said Senator Edward M. Kennedy, the Massachusetts Democrat who heads the Committee on Labor and Human Resources.
Mathea Falco, an Assistant Secretary of State for international narcotic matters in the Carter Administration and now a visiting fellow at the Cornell Medical Center in New York City, said Mr. Bush's drug strategy was "more of the same."
Ms. Falco said in a telephone interview from New York: "Its dominant focus is on keeping supplies from coming into the country and keeping them off the streets. It still does not recognize that reducing demand must be the first priority. We know that sealing the border is impossible, but the strategy continues to try to do it."
David Tell, deputy chief of staff of the Administration's Office of National Drug Control Policy, said the increased funds sought by Mr. Bush would be used "across the board in all the major functional areas." But the largest increase would go to domestic law enforcement, which would receive $5.2 billion, or 14 percent more than in the current fiscal year.
Speaking to a group of Administration officials and reporters at the Old Executive Office Building today, Mr. Bush drew attention to recently published studies financed by the Federal Government that indicated declining drug use around the country, most sharply among the middle class.
"The clear message of available data is that drug use is on the way down," he said. "Since I've come into office we've seen an important and encouraging shift in drug use trends."
 
Cyclical Patterns of Use
 Drug experts acknowledge the decrease but attribute the change as much to cyclical patterns of drug use and reports of public condemnation of cocaine as to Government programs.
"How many people have stopped using drugs in the last 18 months because of Federal dollars spent is hard to say," said John P. Walters, the acting director of the Office of National Drug Control Policy. "But I don't think there's any doubt that expanded Federal spending has contributed significantly."
With signs that the tide is turning, Mr. Bush said, "you might ask, 'Can we lessen our commitment to stopping the scourge of drugs, can we afford to look elsewhere, lose interest? Can we declare victory?'
"And of course, the answer is an emphatic 'no.' "
Representative Charles B. Rangel, the the Manhattan Democrat who heads the House Select Committee on Narcotics Abuse and Control, said the President's strategy was "so full of holes that it does not allow me to say that we are tackling the drug problem where it is most severe in our inner cities."
The drug strategy was the third presented by Mr. Bush since his appearance on television on Sept. 5, 1989, to declare war on what he said was "the toughest domestic challenge we've faced in decades." Cocaine and crack use were climbing and the people who refine and export cocaine from South America were threatening the governments in Colombia and Peru.
Now, while drug use appears to be falling, murder and robbery rates are soaring. The price of cocaine has sharply risen in most cities, but officials of the Drug Enforcement Administration say the drug is widely available. Some of the price fluctuation, they say, appears to be the result of manipulation by traffickers.
 
Change of Schedule
 The Colombian Government, driven by a desire to end a wave of violence, has embarked on informal negotiations with the traffickers, offering leniency in exchange for surrender. The fear in Washington is that drug violence in Colombia may end, while trafficking continues unabated.
Peru has refused more than $35 million in United States aid to help its military fight guerrillas who are encouraging small farmers to keep growing coca, the basic ingredient of cocaine. But Peru has proposed an economic plan to induce farmers to shift production to fruits and vegetables, a move it hopes the United States will endorse.
Officials in the Office of Drug Control Policy had intended to make public the Administration's strategy next Monday. But they hastily called reporters today because of a change in the President's schedule. He took the unusual step of personally announcing the results of a drug-use survey in December. Both moves were seen as an attempt to head off criticism that Mr. Bush was neglecting domestic issues because he was busy dealing with the war in the Persian Gulf.
"I expect some wonder whether I am totally preoccupied with events half way around the world," Mr. Bush said today.
The change in release date sent many members of Congress scrambling for copies of the report.
Mr. Bush said he was "particularly proud" that his proposal included $100 million to expand drug treatment.
He said the money would enable 200,000 more people to be treated; two million are now being aided in various centers. But Administration officials said that the $100 million would actually pay for treatment for an additional 40,000 people and that the remaining 160,000 treatment spaces would be created only if there were matching money from states, cities and private insurance companies.
Some Administration officials expressed anger at critics in Congress who say more should be spent on treatment and prevention. "We asked for this same amount for other treatment programs last year," said Mr. Tell, of the Drug Policy Office, "and they slashed us down to a third of the request."
The plan would increase spending for international drug programs by $132 million to a total of $779 million, with $499 million designated for Bolivia, Peru and Colombia, where most of the world's cocaine is grown and processed. Economic aid to those countries would rise from $202 million to $285 million. But Bolivia alone argues that it needs at least $500 million to reorder the farming habits of a peasant population that has grown dependent on the income from coca plants.

HEADLINE: Bailout Money Is Threatened

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31

 BODY:
Members of New England's Congressional delegation threatened today to block new spending for the savings and loan bailout until the Bush Administration comes forward with a plan to ease the credit crunch.
Massachusetts and other New England states were hit early and particularly hard by the recession, and the failure of Bank of New England and two associated banks this month has further shaken the region's already weak banking system.
The threat to link the credit issue to the bailout could further delay the new financing the Administration has said it will need by the end of February to continue seizing ailing savings and loans.
The Administrations wants $77 billion this year to dispose of 225 institutions.

HEADLINE: Atlanta Papers To Cut 255 Jobs

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Jan. 31

 BODY:
The Atlanta Journal and Constitution, the state's largest newspapers, said on Wednesday that they were laying off 133 people and leaving 122 other jobs unfilled, primarily because of a decline in advertising revenues.
The cuts were spread through every department, said Jay A. Smith, the publisher for both newspapers.
The reduction includes 17 of the 480 newsroom jobs, he said. Reductions were also made in the circulation, advertising, production, marketing and data-processing departments.
The Constitution publishes weekday mornings and The Journal weekday evenings. They jointly publish The Journal-Constitution on Saturdays and Sundays.
The economic slump has tightened ad revenues, although the newspapers' circulation has been increasing, Mr. Smith said. He would not release revenue figures.

HEADLINE: Two New Governors Offer Plans to Trim Deficits

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, Jan. 31

 BODY:
The new Governors of Massachusetts and Rhode Island presented their first budgets to the states' lawmakers today, taking painful steps that they said would eliminate projected deficits that are among the worst in the country.
Gov. William F. Weld of Massachusetts called for widespread cuts in state services, and Gov. Bruce G. Sundlun of Rhode Island urged a combination of tax increases and spending cuts. 
 Presenting a budget plan for the last six months of the 1991 fiscal year, which ends in June, and for the entire next fiscal year, Mr. Weld offered a complex program that included unpaid furloughs for state employees, tightened eligibility for Medicaid and the sale of state property, including recreational sites like zoos and skating rinks. He would also close a number of state hospitals and delay a state contribution to a public employees' pension plan.
Mr. Weld, the state's first Republican Governor in two decades, stood by a campaign pledge not to seek a tax increase to resolve Massachusetts's longstanding fiscal crisis. He also said he would not go to Wall Street to borrow money to cover the deficit, a step that had been taken by his predecessor, Michael S. Dukakis.
But the new Governor did seem to depart from two parts of his campaign platform, which proposed closing the deficit by decreasing the size of state government, when he called today for reducing state aid to cities and towns while increasing fees for a wide variety of state services.
 
Deficits of About 12 Percent
 Speaking serenely, almost casually, at a Statehouse news conference, Mr. Weld said that without his proposed cuts, the deficit for the last six months of the current fiscal year would be $850 million, in an annual budget that totals $13.9 billion. For the entire next fiscal year, the deficit will be $1.82 billion, in a budget of $15.1 billion, if his cuts are not made, he said.
On an annual basis, the deficit for each of those years would equal about 12 percent of the budget, one of the highest such proportions for any state budget in the nation.
In Rhode Island, which is facing a $200 million deficit, also equal to 12 percent, for the fiscal year that ends in June, Governor Sundlun proposed steps that included a 20 percent increase in the personal income tax, an 11 percent surcharge on corporate income taxes and a 5-cent-a-gallon increase in the gasoline tax.
Mr. Sundlun, a Democrat, also called for a sharp cut in state aid to education, the layoff of 1,000 state employees and requiring state employees to take one unpaid holiday every two weeks.
Both Massachusetts and Rhode Island are suffering from a severe recession that began in New England more than a year ago and has led to a continuing decline in state income and sales tax revenue. But residents in both states have blamed their governors for the trouble, heaping scorn on Mr. Dukakis, who chose not to run for re-election, and giving Mr. Sundlun a resounding victory in November over the incumbent Republican in Rhode Island, Edward D. DiPrete.
 
Laying Blame for Taxes
 Mr. Sundlun had pledged for months not to raise taxes, except as a last resort. In making his tax-increase proposals today, he blamed Mr. DiPrete, saying the earlier administration had overestimated revenue and consistently underestimated spending.
"We're paying for DiPrete mismanagement, pure and simple," Mr. Sundlun said at a news conference in Providence. Reminded by a reporter that he had once said that a governor who raises taxes never gets re-elected, Mr. Sundlun said, "There comes a time when you have to shift positions, and we've done that."
Mr. DiPrete did not return telephone calls to his home and office.
In Massachusetts, the early reaction to Mr. Weld's budget-cutting proposals from Democrats, who control both houses of the Legislature, was guarded but conciliatory. "Something has to pass -- we obviously have a deficit," said Speaker of the House Charles F. Flaherty of Cambridge.
"If we find any cuts in there we can't live with, we will have to find other cuts," Mr. Flaherty said. "We have to meet the bottom line."
Mr. Flaherty did suggest that Mr. Weld might be trying to achieve too much of his savings at the expense of state employees. Mr. Weld's budget calls for a reduction of 6,000 state workers, making them take 10 unpaid work days by June and requiring them to pay for a much larger share of their health insurance. The large sacrifices asked of state workers raises a question of fairness, Mr. Flaherty said.
 
Campaign Attacks on 'Hacks'
 In his campaign, one of Mr. Weld's major and most popular themes was constant attacks on state employees as "hacks" or "walruses" who were living high at the expense of the public.
By contrast with his treatment of state employees, Mr. Weld, a lawyer, today called for a repeal of a sales tax on services like lawyers and accountants, passed last year as part of Mr. Dukakis's budget-cutting effort.
Asked at his news conference whether it was fair to put a burden on state employees while repealing the sales tax on lawyers, Mr. Weld said, "My answer is jobs, jobs, jobs." The sales tax would lead to a loss of jobs in the state, he said.
Michael Widmer, senior vice president of the Massachusetts Taxpayers Foundation, a private, non-partisan group, said Mr. Weld deserved credit for formulating a plan that could balance the budget in 1992 without new taxes or borrowing in the bond market.
"The only way to reach some kind of stability here is to take some unprecedented steps," Mr. Widmer said. In particular, he pointed to the cuts being asked of state employees, the closing of state hospitals and mental hospitals and the shutdown of half of the offices of the Registry of Motor Vehicles.
"Given the dimensions of the problem, those are sound ideas," Mr. Widmer said. "But they are very difficult politically."
 
'Fees Are Not Taxes'
 Mr. Weld's proposal also calls for raising the fare on Boston's subway to $1 from 75 cents, to lessen the deficit of the Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority, much of which is picked up by the state. Asked today how he reconciled this and other new proposed state fees with his pledge not to raise taxes, Mr. Weld said, "Fees are not taxes."
In the campaign, Mr. Weld supported a ballot measure that would have greatly raised state aid to financially strapped towns and cities. But today he said state aid for programs like education, police and firefighters would have to be cut by $271 million next year, or 10 percent. He acknowledged this was "a violation of my intention," but dismissed it as being "less serious" than sticking to his promise not to raise taxes.
As part of what he has taken to calling "entrepreneurial government," Mr. Weld proposed to sell to private business Boston's two zoos, a series of state operated skating rinks, the state's largest reservoir and 26 other properties he declined to identify.

HEADLINE: UAL Posts Big Deficit In Quarter

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Jan. 31

 BODY:
The UAL Corporation, the parent company of United Airlines, today reported a fourth-quarter loss of $123.5 million and a record quarterly operating loss of $296.6 million.
"The alarming increase in the price of fuel and a significant softening in the economy took its toll," said Stephen M. Wolf, UAL's chairman. 
 United is one of the nation's strongest airlines, but like the rest of the industry, it was hit hard late last year by high fuel costs brought on by the Persian Gulf crisis, just as the economy was slipping into a recession.
The year-ago fourth-quarter had earnings of $6.8 million, or 31 cents a share, UAL said.
For the full year, UAL reported net earnings of $94.5 million, or $4.33 a share, down 70.9 percent, compared to net earnings of $324.2 million, or $14.96 a share, for 1989. The company reported an operating loss of $36.3 million in 1990, compared to an operating profit of $464.5 million in 1989.
Revenues in the 1990 fourth quarter were $2.8 billion, up from $2.37 billion for the same 1989 period. The fourth quarter's results included a one-time gain of $68.1 million in sales of property, including nine airplanes.
Annual revenues were $11.04 billion in 1990, up from $9.79 billion in 1989.
Sara Dornacker, United spokeswoman, said the fourth-quarter loss exceeded a previous record loss of $192 million in the second quarter of 1985, which came just after the carrier's pilots began a strike.
During 1990, the entire airline industry posted record losses, largely because of the high cost of jet fuel.
"For United, the average price per gallon of jet fuel in the fourth quarter rose to $1.12, versus 69.5 cents and 52.3 cents in the same quarters of 1989 and 1988 respectively," Mr. Wolf said in the statement.
On the New York Stock Exchange today, UAL's shares slipped 62.5 cents, to $128.75.

HEADLINE: CUOMO PROPOSING STEEP BUDGET CUTS AND TAX INCREASES

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 31

 BODY:
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo today proposed the largest package of spending cuts in New York State's history and a third consecutive year of sharp increases in taxes and fees.
Trying to fill a $6 billion hole in the budget for the next fiscal year, the Governor proposed slashing 10 percent -- or nearly $1 billion -- from aid to local school districts and halving the unrestricted aid the state shares with local governments. He also proposed abolishing dozens of state agencies and commissions and eliminating up to 18,000 jobs -- roughly a tenth of the state work force. 
 In Massachusetts and Rhode Island, two other states hit hard by the economic decline, new Governors presented their first budgets, taking painful steps they said would eliminate large projected deficits. [Page A12.]
 
Bad News for New York City
 For New York City, struggling with severe fiscal problems of its own, Mr. Cuomo's plan appears to offer not relief but even greater burdens. Over all, Cuomo administration officials projected, the city would lose about $400 million in state aid. It would absorb other cuts, including ones in Medicaid.
"These proposals will cripple our ability to provide even the most basic of services," Mayor David N. Dinkins said at a news conference.
City and state officials said they have been negotiating over how to offset some of the cuts, perhaps with funds from state authorities, including the Municipal Assistance Corporation, which issues bonds for the city and watches over its finances. But those talks have not yet produced an agreement, they said.
 
'Fiscal Anorexia'
 Seeking to prevent what he termed the "fiscal anorexia" that would result if he closed the gap through spending cuts alone, Mr. Cuomo proposed new taxes on gasoline, interstate telephone calls, tires, and other goods and services, and suggested deferring income-tax reductions again, which he said would save the state about $400 million.
He also called for a $500 tuition increase at the state's public universities. That would come on top of last month's increases of $200 to $300 and result in tuition increases of more than 50 percent at both the City University and State University of New York.
The Governor's $29.15 billion state spending plan drew cries of protest from educators, health officials and advocates for the poor. It also provoked a sharp rebuke from the state's Chief Judge, Sol Wachtler, who took issue with a recent comment by the Governor that his budget would generate "a lot of complaining and a lot of screaming," but would leave the state's basic strength intact.
"What you recommend will not leave this state strong -- it will leave it weakened and vulnerable in a very fundamental way," said Judge Wachtler, who presides over a judiciary that would take a cut of 10 percent.
Of the 18,000 jobs, up to 7,500 will be eliminated through layoffs, and the rest through attrition. Mr. Cuomo's proposal did not spell out which jobs would be lost, but indicated that prisons and mental health services would be the hardest hit.
Some Republicans, including the powerful Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, suggested that Mr. Cuomo ought to have proposed greater cuts in welfare programs.
Mr. Marino, of Oyster Bay, L.I., said he found it "troubling" that Mr. Cuomo had sought to "balance his budget on the backs of property tax-payers by making schools and local governments bear most of the cost."
In addition to the cuts and the new taxes, Mr. Cuomo's budget includes hundreds of other measures intended to close the $6 billion gap.
Among them is revision of the state law that requires prison sentences for all second-time felony offenders. Mr. Cuomo said that non-violent criminals should be eligible for alternatives less expensive than imprisonment.
Also, in contrast to New York City, Mr. Cuomo's budget includes no money for any wage increases.
 
Pistols and Nuclear Plants
 "I'm not going to lay off 7,500 people and then turn around and let everybody else get raises," Mr. Cuomo said. Public-employee unions denounced him for using both layoffs and salary freezes.
The new and higher state fees would cover a wide range of people, including pistol owners, drunken drivers, pesticide manufacturers and the operators of nuclear power plants.
While the Governor's austere approach to the budget drew immediate denunciations from many quarters, some who have frequently criticized his fiscal management said he had steered the right course today.
"The spending cuts are extremely painful and unfortunate, but from a fiscal perspective the Governor's approach is responsible," said Cynthia Green, a senior analyst with the Citizens Budget Commission.
The budget offered by the Governor today set off what has become a perennial ritual in Albany when he and lawmakers quarreled over just how large it was, and whether it represented any increase from the current year's plan.
Whatever number was used, there was wide agreement that the state Legislature would come under enormous pressure to restore at least some of the cuts sought by Mr. Cuomo.
But the Governor, constantly portraying himself as a fiscal pessimist during a nearly three-hour briefing on the budget today, warned that the state could not "wish away" cuts by increasing revenue estimates and thereby spending more. For the last three years, revenue projections sanctioned by both Mr. Cuomo and the Legislature turned out to be too high, and the state has wound up borrowing money to close the deficits.
If similar manipulations are not used to allow more spending in this budget, it may leave the lawmakers with a less palatable alternative: even higher taxes than Mr. Cuomo proposed.
Mr. Miller, the Assembly Speaker, said the state would have to ask itself to "unclog the arteries without removing the heart of government."
Meanwhile, even some of Mr. Cuomo's harshest critics seemed to agree that there was no painless way to rescue the state from fiscal distress.
"We know the days of wine and roses are long gone," said the Republican leader of the Assembly, C. D. Rappleyea, of Chenango County. "Now we must act decisively on this budget to stop New York from entering the days of bread and water."

HEADLINE: The 22% Rise in Postal Costs Upsets Magazine Publishers

BYLINE: By DEIRDRE CARMODY

 BODY:
Already suffering from a pervasive advertising recession, magazine publishers are now facing the more formidable problem of a 22 percent increase in second-class mail, which will go into effect Sunday.
"Coupled with the 18 percent increase that we had in 1988, our costs have gone up 40 percent in a three-year period," said D. Claeys Bahrenburg, the president and chief executive of Hearst Magazines, which publishes Good Housekeeping and Cosmopolitan. "We are basically appalled by it." 
 The increases have driven publishers to look for ways to defray or avoid the postal increases. In doing so, they are increasingly turning to private alternative delivery methods and banding with other publishers to ship magazines and share the mailing costs. Some even accelerated subscription mailings in the latter part of last year to beat the higher rates.
Thomas O. Ryder, the president of American Express Publishing, which publishes Travel & Leisure and Food & Wine magazines, called the increases a "gigantic hit, a shock to the system."
"The kind of cost increases that we are getting from the Postal Service are simply not sustainable," Mr. Ryder said. "Either we have to find an alternative to the Postal Service, they have to change their cost structure or we are going to close down our business."
Second-class mail includes magazines and newspapers. Hitting magazine publishers with almost as hard as the second-class increase is the 25 percent rise in third-class mail rates. Magazines use third-class mail, commonly known as junk mail, to solicit subscriptions and to conduct direct-mail tests before starting magazines. This category makes up 42 percent of the United States Postal Service's volume.
The new rates include a 4-cent rise in the price of a first-class stamp, to 29 cents. Initially, a 5-cent increase had been considered.
The rate increases follow 10 months of hearings by the Postal Rate Commission, the group that regulates postal rates and classifications while the Postal Service manages the system. The new rates have been anticipated since Jan. 4, when the commission unanimously recommended that they be put into effect. On Jan. 22 the Postal Service's board of governors gave approval "under protest" for the rates to go into effect Sunday at 12:01 A.M.
" 'Under protest' means that we aren't certain that the rates as recommended by the Postal Rate Commission are going to cover our costs," said Art Shealey, a spokesman for the Postal Service.
 
'Really Crazy' Move
 To magazine executives, the phrase simply means another probable increase next year.
"What was done with the 29-cent stamp is really crazy on its impact on other classes," said Reginald K. Brack Jr., the president of the Time Inc. Magazine Company, which publishes People and Sports Illustrated, along with Time and other magazines. "It put yet more burden on second and third class."
Some magazines are hit harder than others by the postal increase because their costs are based on differing factors like the discounts for presorting them by ZIP codes and the ratio of advertising to articles.
Mr. Brack, who is also the chairman of the Magazine Publishers of America, the industry's chief lobbying group, said the rate increases would bring the total postal costs for his parent company, Time Warner Inc., to almost $400 million a year, an increase of about 20 percent over current mailing costs.
 
Impact on a Small Magazine
 Jeffrey Dearth, the president of the New Republic, an opinion magazine with a relatively small circulation, said its costs would rise 25 percent.
"We're talking hundreds of thousands of dollars just to stand still," he said. "They are making it hard for us to stay in business."
Magazine publishers, as well as newspaper publishers, have been using more alternate private delivery services to circumvent the Postal Service.
Phillip Miller, president of Alternate Postal Delivery, and his partner, Stan Henry, drew up a business plan last year that foresaw expansion to 95 markets in five years. He said, however, that new clients were joining Alternate Postal Delivery, which is based in Grand Rapids, Mich., at such a rate that he thought the goal would be reached in four years.
Mr. Miller estimated that publishers could save an average of 15 to 18 percent in the costs of delivering their magazines.
"We probably have increased our interest in alternate delivery testing, but the jury will be out for several years at least," said William T. Kerr, president of The New York Times Magazine Group, which publishes Family Circle, McCall's, Golf Digest and other magazines.
 
'Cavalier Approach' Assailed
 The increase for third class, or junk mail, is also being greeted with outrage because publishers say this category is the engine that drives mail volume -- and revenue -- for the Postal Service.
When the new postal rates were announced, Robert Setrakian, the outgoing chairman of the Postal Service's board of governors, issued a dissent. He said that he was "incensed by the cavalier approach" of the Postal Rate Commission to third-class mail and that the commission was "attempting to kill off a whole industry, the third-class mail industry, by an exorbitant rate increase."
The publishers are also indignant over the Postal Service's refusal to give them a discount for stacking thousands of magazines on a board or pallet, somewhat like bales of hay, and placing them on trucks. This saves postal workers the job of lifting heavy sacks of mail filled with magazines, untying them and sorting through the magazines.
In 1985, the Postal Service asked publishers to use this process to stack magazines and promised them a discount. But earlier this month, the Postal Service's board of governors rejected the discount because it applied only to second-class mail and not to third-class mail. Since the current technology is not feasible for third-class mail, the discount was deferred.
Many magazine publishers who had made substantial capital investments in the stacking process felt they had been double-crossed. In the past, the Postal Service had given discounts to mailers who made the post office's work easier.

HEADLINE: Bleak Forecasts For the F.D.I.C. Are Challenged

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31

 BODY:
L. William Seidman, the nation's top banking regulator, today flatly contradicted forecasts that the bank insurance fund he manages would be insolvent within two years.
On the defensive against a growing chorus of criticism on Capitol Hill and mounting concern among Administration officials, Mr. Seidman disputed suggestions that a taxpayer bailout would be required to keep the fund that protects bank deposits afloat. 
 The bank insurance fund would be "weak but solvent" under the "most widely held view on expected economic conditions," Mr. Seidman said at a news conference this morning. "There is no crisis here. What we have is sufficient to handle what we foresee now."
 
Prediction Is Hedged
 But Mr. Seidman, who has been highly regarded in Congress both for his skill as a banking regulator and his candor about the size of the savings industry crisis, did hedge his prediction, saying that if the recession lasted longer than a year, a prospect he called unlikely, then the bank insurance fund might be insolvent by the end of the year.
As chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, the agency that insures accounts up to $100,000 in the nation's 12,399 banks, he is also chairman of the Resolution Trust Corporation, the body created by Congress in August 1989 to oversee the bailout of the savings and loan industry.
Within the last few days, the White House's Office of Management and Budget has predicted that the F.D.I.C.'s bank insurance fund, which now has a balance of about $8.5 billion, will have a deficit by 1992. And the Congressional Budget Office has predicted a deficit can develop by the end of this year, even if the recession is mild and recovery begins by summer.
If the fund does show a deficit at any point, depositors of up to $100,000 will continue to be protected fully in the event their bank collapses, but they may have to be paid from taxpayer funds.
Mr. Seidman also acknowledged, as he has before, that the fund, which is supported by premiums from member banks, would likely need some additional short-term funds for what he called liquidity purposes. While in the past he has not provided a precise figure on how much would be needed, he said today that at a minimum, the F.D.I.C. would need an additional $10 billion over two years.
He said the $10 billion could be borrowed from the Treasury Department, with the interest on such a loan paid through an increase in the bank premiums. The funds could also come from some form of increased contributions by the industry, he said.
 
Bigger Industry Contribution
 The forecasts by the Office of Management and Budget and Congressional Budget Office on the health of the bank fund were based on historical trends in the industry, and each assumed a specific increase in the size of the industry's contributions to the fund.
Mr. Seidman said that unlike those agencies, the F.D.I.C. based its conclusions on information provided by bank examiners. He said his short-term forecasts, using this method, had been highly reliable. He conceded that if the recession was more severe than currently expected and lasted for more than a year, then the fund would be insolvent by the end of this year.
Some members of Congress have criticized him this year for his frequent downward revisions of those forecasts. And the chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, Donald W. Riegle Jr., said earlier this week he was concerned that even the gloomier projections by the Congressional Budget Office might be understating the problem.
 
Count of Expected Failures
 Mr. Seidman predicted that if the recession is mild and lasts only six months, as he and many economists expect, then 180 banks with assets of $65 billion would fail this year and 160 banks with assets of $30 billion would collapse in 1992.
These failures would bring the bank insurance fund down to $3.9 billion by the end of this year and $2.4 billion in 1992.
If the recession is more severe, he said, then 230 banks with assets of $90 billion could fail this year and 210 banks with assets of $70 billion could require assistance in 1992. If that occurs, then the fund will be insolvent by the end of this year, he said, and be in the red next year by $5.8 billion.
 
Drain on the Fund So Far
 By comparison, the preliminary figures for 1990 show that 169 banks with $16.3 billion failed, costing the fund $4.7 billion.
The F.D.I.C. presented its latest forecasts minutes before a group of bankers from five banking associations met in Washington with senior Treasury officials and regulators to explore ways to reorganize the fund.
The group included Mr. Seidman; Treasury Under Secretary Robert R. Glauber; Thomas G. Labrecque, chairman and chief executive of Chase Manhattan Bank, and Walter V. Shipley, chairman of Chemical Bank. Administration officials have said they are prepared to go along with an industry solution to the fund's problems, provided it is a long-term solution and does not rely on taxpayers.
 
No Specific Plan
 The bankers emerged from the meeting late this afternoon without a specific plan, although participants at the meeting said the bankers and officials agreed that a private sector solution could be reached to bolster the fund. They also agreed to additional meetings in February.
No plan to reorganize the fund is expected before next week, when the Treasury Department has said it may present its report on overhauling the banking industry.
"This isn't something that has to be done today or tomorrow to prevent a calamity," Mr. Seidman said before the meeting. "But clearly something should be done by midyear."
The plans being considered involve either some form of lending by the banks to the fund, or increased contributions to the fund that would be offset by an ownership interest taken by the banks.
 
One Idea Lapses
 One idea now considered dead is a suggestion made in December by Mr. Seidman that the fund be financed through a onetime assessment on the industry of 1 percent of its deposits, a move he had said could raise $25 billion. Banking groups in Washington strongly opposed the suggestion, saying their members could not afford to pay it without leading to many more failures, and today Mr. Seidman dropped the idea.
The F.D.I.C. has the authority to borrow $5 billion from the Treasury. In addition, it may also borrow money based on a formula that relies on the net worth of the fund. Under the formula, and based on the present condition of the fund, the F.D.I.C. can now borrow $65 billion.
