HEADLINE: WAR IN THE GULF: The Bombers
SAUDIS RECAPTURE GHOST TOWN; ALLIES BOMB NEW IRAQI COLUMN;
NEW BASES FOR U.S.

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31

 BODY:
To increase the number of B-52 bombing raids against Iraqi ground forces, the United States has been secretly basing some of the bombers in Spain and has obtained permission to use a British airfield as well, Western officials said today.
The use of the base in Spain, which was disclosed by Administration officials, has been considered politically delicate because the Spanish Government, under public pressure, has been trying in recent years to reduce the presence of American forces. In addition, Spain pays close attention to Arab sentiment, particularly in the Muslim countries of North Africa, American analysts said. 
 The British Defense Secretary, Tom King, announced the agreement to base B-52's in Britain. In an operation that recalled long-distance bombing missions against North Vietnamese targets from Guam two decades ago, over about the same distance, the United States will reactivate a B-52 base at Fairford in Gloucestershire, Mr. King told the House of Commons today.
 
Expanded Use of B-52's
 In another unpublicized example of cooperation by Western European nations with the American war effort against Iraq, Germany has provided German-made shells for American M1-A1 tanks in Saudi Arabia as well as artillery shells for British forces there, Pentagon officials said. Germany's public contribution to the war effort, which has drawn large protest marches in Germany, has consisted primarily of economic assistance, some military equipment and the deployment of 18 Alpha jet fighters to Turkey as part of a NATO force to defend that nation.
Access to the European airfields allows the United States to expand the use of the giant bombers by providing additional bases for fueling, arming and maintaining the planes, which before the start of the war were permanently based only in North America and Guam.
In the days before the war started, some B-52's were flown to Diego Garcia, an Indian Ocean island about 3,000 miles south of the Persian Gulf. Since combat began on Jan. 17, B-52 attacks have been launched from Diego Garcia and Spain, and an airfield in the western part of Saudi Arabia.
The Pentagon has refused to disclose the precise number of B-52's being used in the war, but an American official who declined to be identified estimated that more than 50 of the planes would be part of the American arsenal. Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, the commander of American forces in the Persian Gulf, said that on Wednesday, 28 B-52's dropped 470 tons of explosives on Iraqi ground forces in southern Iraq and Kuwait.
Mr. King explained the American request by saying "it was necessary to increase the capacity," but did not say how many of the conventionally armed planes would be based at Fairford, which is not now being used by the Royal Air Force.
Officials in London said that other countries had agreed to provide support for B-52's, but declined to identify them, saying they would leave it to them to make their own announcements. Spain has sought to keep the basing of the B-52 bombers secret. But it has given limited support for the American military operation, such as allowing Washington bases for refueling stops and dispatching several ships to the Persian Gulf region.
The B-52 has been one of the most formidable weapons in the Air Force and has been used to launch punishing raids against Iraqi forces. Pentagon officials said the B-52s carrying conventional bombs were at first based only in Diego Garcia, where they were dispatched after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait.
But because the United States wanted to increased the number of bombers that could be used to attack Iraqi forces and because there is limited room at Diego Garcia for basing the planes, the United States has sought to expand the network of B-52 bases.
 
Egypt Declined to Base Bombers
 One reason the American military may have been forced to seek bases in Europe is that Egypt has opposed the stationing of the bombers on its territory. Saudi Arabia also showed an early reluctance to base the bombers, a senior military official said.
The hesitation of both countries might stem from the image of the B-52 as a weapon of indiscriminate bombing associated with its use in carpet-bombing North Vietnam during the Vietnam War, a reputation that the Air Force considers inaccurate and unfair. The B-52 is also associated by some with nuclear weapons. Although the planes being used against Iraq carry only conventional explosives, the bulk of the B-52 force based in the United States is armed with nuclear weapons to deter a once-feared Soviet nuclear attack.
In announcing Britain's decision to allow the stationing of B-52's on its soil, Mr. King emphasized that London had received "an absolute assurance that they will only use conventional munitions operating from that base."
Germany, which has been criticized by some lawmakers for not providing enough assistance, announced recently that it would provide an additional $5.5 billion. But some of Germany's contributions to the American and allied war effort have not been publicly discussed by German officials, who have been worried about criticism at home.
 
German Shells for U.S. Tanks
 A Pentagon official said the United States Army had quietly obtained 120-millimeter artillery shells from Germany for use in American M1-A1 tanks in Saudi Arabia. Germany made the shells for use in its Leopard tank.
The United States wants to have 60 days' worth of ammunition and other supplies on hand for its war with Iraq, and 25,000 of the German shells have been provided, according to a military expert, who suggested the the shells were being donated to the United States.
Germany is also said to have provided 155-millimeter artillery shells and Tornado spare parts to British forces there.
A Pentagon official also said Germany had been able to provide useful intelligence to the United States about the Soviet-made equipment in Iraq's arsenal. That is because the Government of the newly reunified Germany has obtained Soviet equipment made for the former East Germany military.
Prime Minister John Major's decision to let the B-52's operate from British soil is reminiscent of the agreement of his predecessor, Margaret Thatcher, to permit American FB-111 planes based in Britain to attack targets in Libya in 1986, to retaliate for a terrorist bombing in Berlin in 1986.

HEADLINE: Freed Rapist Seized in 5 Rapes

 BODY:
A man who was paroled four months ago after serving 10 years for rape and robbery has been arrested and charged with raping a 12-year-old girl and four women in a Bronx housing project, the housing police said yesterday.
They said the first attack occurred in October, shortly after the man was released from prison. The victims, who ranged from 12 to 71 years of age, lived at Patterson Houses on Morris Avenue at 143d Street in the South Bronx.
Detectives said the man, Larry Jones, 30, of 42 East 126th Street in East Harlem, approached his victims in the afternoons. He would strike up a conversation inside the building and either talk or force his way inside their apartments, the detectives said. Once inside, he threatened them with a knife, forced them into a bedroom and raped and sodomized them.
In two instances, he is said to have tied up his victims. He would also rob them of money and jewelry, said Chief Vincent Pizzo of the Housing Authority Police.
Mr. Jones, who is unemployed, was arrested by housing detectives Wednesday evening as he was walking at 140th Street and Morris Avenue, Chief Pizzo said. He was wearing a bracelet belonging to one of the victims and did not put up a struggle, detectives said.
The detectives said they had traced him from descriptions supplied by the victims and his record as a rapist. All five victims have identified him in police line-ups, the detectives said.
Mr. Jones was arrested in the Bronx in 1980 and convicted of rape, sodomy and robbery, Chief Pizzo said. He was paroled in September. He has been charged with rape, sodomy and robbery again, Chief Pizzo said.

HEADLINE: If Times Are Tough, It's A Job For The Funnies!

BYLINE: By STEVEN HELLER

 BODY:
IF you missed the "High and Low" show at the Museum of Modern Art, there is still time to catch Hi and Lois at the World Financial Center. These well-known comic marrieds are just 2 of more than 100 characters appearing in almost 50 original drawings and vintage printed pages representing some of America's greatest newspaper comic strips from 1896 to the present. They are on loan through Feb. 15 from the Museum of Cartoon Art in Rye, N.Y.
At first, the World Financial Center might seem an unlikely place for an exhibition of comic strips. But traditionally, in good times and bad -- bad, especially, like right now, in the widespread recession -- America's most popular native form of graphic humor has functioned as a kind of unrecognized economic indicator, reflecting, specifically, how much the nation needs a laugh. Remember how popular the funny pages were during the Great Depression, when they and their offshoots on the radio and in the movies helped keep people's spirits up. And then, of course, there was the celebrated newspaper strike in which the children of New York were suffering such miseries of comic-strip deprivation that Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia stepped in and read the funnies on his weekly radio show. 
 In recent years, the classic newspaper comics, acknowledged by historians as an indigenous American popular art form, have been included in exhibitions at the Modern, the Whitney Museum of American Art and other citadels of high art, and they have been the subjects of scholarly papers and books. Though "The Masters of Cartoon Art" is hardly a definitive exhibition -- it includes only some comic strips and no single-panel cartoonists -- it is nevertheless a worthwhile assortment of some superbly drawn original artwork and rare printed pages.
Displayed in chronological order are works representing the comics' nascent period, the late 1890's, through its golden age during the 1930's to the present. The range: from humor, to myth, to adventure, to suspense, to the wonderfully absurd.
 
Beginnings Amid Rivalry
 The newspaper comic strip was born in New York City. Its format -- a sequence of panels with speech in balloons -- evolved from the humorous single and serial drawings published in the early New York satiric weeklies, Puck and Judge, which between the 1870's and late 1890's served as a proving ground for many comic-strip pioneers.
The comics developed just before the turn of the century as a result of the intense rivalry between two competing newspaper czars, Joseph Pulitzer (owner of The New York World) and William Randolph Hearst (who had bought the failing New York Morning Journal). The first strips were an accidental offspring of both commerce and technology. Pulitzer believed he could increase circulation by publishing a Sunday color supplement. One of the earliest published features in his supplement was Richard Outcault's "Down Hogan's Alley," a tableau (not yet a strip) reporting on the fictional goings-on of the not-so-savory denizens of a New York slum, which featured as its signature character a bald, funny-looking imp who wore a nightshirt, named Mickey Dugan.
In 1896, Pulitzer decided to conduct an experiment with the strip by adding yellow, a color that had only recently been perfected on the press, to Dugan's night shirt. From this humble beginning was born "The Yellow Kid," which a year later moved in a different form to Hearst's New York Journal to become not only the first real comic strip in America, but also the basis for the term "yellow journalism" applied to Hearst's brand of muckraking.
New comics were developed to garner circulation, yet out of this commercial imperative came a remarkable diversity of styles and stories. Among the most successful were Rudolph Dirks's "Katzenjammer Kids," James Swinnerton's "Little Tiger," Bud Fisher's "Mr. A. Mutt" and Fredric Burr Opper's brilliant adventures of a sad clown, "Happy Holligan," prefiguring Emmett Kelly's woeful circus persona. The comics quickly took over a significant role in a growing American mass culture. The language in some of the most popular strips became part of the American vernacular.
 
Introducing 'Buster Brown'
 "Masters of Cartoon Art" offers visitors a chance to see many of these rare comics, including the first "Yellow Kid" in page form, and next to it an original drawing of a "Buster Brown" strip, also by Outcault. Though esthetically inferior to "The Yellow Kid," "Buster Brown" was decidedly more successful as an advertising and marketing tool because the public became fascinated with Buster's clothing.
Also on view is a printed page of "Little Nemo in Slumberland," by the prodigious Winsor McCay, whose adventures of a little boy experiencing the most phantasmagoric dreams (only to wake up breathless at the end of each strip) pushed the limits of content and design in the comic strip. Panels were elongated and compressed, depending on the flow of the surrealistic dream sequences. Unfortunately, another pioneer, George Herriman, is represented only by a lesser, later work from 1941. Mr. Herriman, whose minimalist drawings prefigured modernist tendencies, created "Krazy Kat and Ignatz" in 1911.
While "Masters of Cartoon Art" has one example each of most major newspaper strips (yes, "Dick Tracy," "Prince Valiant," "Beetle Bailey," "Dennis the Menace" and "Doonesbury" are there, too), it does have a few frustrating omissions. There is, for instance, no Lyonel Feininger, the Bauhaus master whose 1906 "Kin-der-Kids" and "Wee Winnie Winkie's World" were masterpieces of draftsmanship and storytelling. Nor is there an example by Jules Feiffer, who, more than 30 years ago, dismantled the traditional comic strip by eliminating balloons and panels, and added a psychological perspective ignored in comics created before him.
There is, however, one pleasant surprise in the form of Bill Griffith's "Zippy," a strip that began as "underground comix" in the 1970's and has earned a cult status in the mainstream press.
"Masters of Cartoon Art" is not the didactic or even critical history of newspaper comics that the subject ultimately deserves, but seeing this sampling of memorable and forgotten strips does whet the appetite for more.
 
When and Where
 "The Masters of Cartoon Art," an exhibition on the history of comic strips from the late 1800's to the present, will be on view through Feb. 15 at the World Financial Center, Courtyard Gallery, the Hudson River and West Street, between Vesey and Liberty Streets, in Manhattan. Hours are noon to 7 P.M. weekdays and noon to 6 P.M. weekends. Free admission. Information: (212) 945-0505.

HEADLINE: Revitalized Millrose Games Seek to Rescue Sport's Image

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY

 BODY:
A candy bar, of all things, is now the title sponsor of North America's most prestigious indoor track and field meet.
While that makes for quite a mouthful, the Snickers Millrose Games, the infusion of new energy and interest for their 84th running tonight in Madison Square Garden can only help so much as track and field struggles to return to a more healthy state. 
 The sport's decline is the hardest issue to avoid whenever American athletes gather for a competition, as an impressive array of them have for this one. So few of the indoor meets on the North American Grand Prix circuit retain a semblance of prestige. This year alone, 2 of the 12 meets were canceled, and the principal attraction in two others was the return of Ben Johnson, the sport's most celebrated cheater. Through yesterday, Millrose organizers still had tickets to sell.
 
A Call for More Heroes
 "We need more heroes and heroines," Howard Schmertz, the meet director, said yesterday, ruing some of the problems of the recent past -- athletes using drugs, a slumping economy and poor marketing -- that have dulled the attractiveness of the sport.
Other factors have hurt the sport, as well, like warming political relations, which have removed the drama of East-West showdowns; the reluctance of top athletes to race against each other, and increasing demands of athletes for higher appearance fees.
"We've had a lot of negative press the last few years, and I know there isn't as much interest now as there was in years past," Schmertz said. "But I think the sport will come back. Next year is an Olympic year, and that always means renewed interest. I think we can be healthy again."
 
Some Good Competition
 Tonight's meet could be a step in the right direction. With more foreign athletes than ever before and many of the better Americans, there are enough quality athletes in most events for good competition. Records are less likely. It's still early in the season, with most American athletes hoping to peak three weeks from now in the national indoor championships, the qualifying meet for the world indoor championships March 8-10 in Seville, Spain.
Among the foreigners competing are several from the Soviet Union, Cuba and what was once East Germany. Notable among them are Tatyana Samolenko of the Soviet Union, the world and Olympic champion at 1,500 meters and 3,000 meters who is running in the mile; Javier Sotomayor of Cuba, the world indoor and outdoor high jump record-holder; Christine Wachtel of Germany, the indoor world-record holder and Olympic silver medalist at 800 meters; and her teammate Thomas Schoenlebe, the world champion at 400 meters and the indoor world-record holder.
Samolenko may find most difficulty winning. Her race is virtually without a weak entry in a field that is strong and crowded with 10 runners. The others include Doina Melinte of Romania, the indoor world-recordholder; the two leading Americans, PattiSue Plumer and Suzy Favor; another impressive Soviet runner, Svetlana Kitova, and Yvonne Mai of Germany.
The men's 60-meter dash is equally unpredictable, with Lee McRae, the indoor world-record holder; two sprinters who have defeated Johnson over 55 meters this season, Daron Council and Andre Cason, and Cuba's best, Andres Simon.

HEADLINE: Auctions

BYLINE: By Rita Reif

 BODY:

The Wrists Have It
While Grandpa's pocket watch may still find its way to the auction house today, wristwatches have been dominating sales of timepieces in recent years. "Wristwatches eclipsed the sales of pocket watches in our auctions about 1984," said Daryn Schnipper, who heads the sales of timepieces at Sotheby's in New York. "In 1980, wristwatches represented about 1 percent of our sales. Today they account for 75 percent of our watch sales."
The popularity of all types of watches will be tested again next Friday at 10:15 A.M. and 2 P.M. in New York at Sotheby's first sale this year of watches and clocks. Ms. Schnipper said there was no indication of trouble in sales of watches last year. On the contrary, she said, many people claim watches fare well during recessions and in wartime "because they have intrinsic value and are small and portable." Last year, when the weakened economy resulted in lower prices and higher numbers of unsold offerings at auctions in other fields, Ms. Schnipper said, watches continued to sell for strong prices.
Usually, she said, watch sales attract bids from collectors and dealers in Europe, Hong Kong, Japan and the United States. Sotheby's estimates that next week's sale will bring $3.8 million to $4.5 million, about the same as its October auction, which totaled $4.4 million. 
 The most important watches in Sotheby's sale are by several of the most prestigious makers: Vacheron & Constantin, Patek Philippe, and Cartier. The offering with the highest presale estimate -- a Vacheron platinum wristwatch with diamond embellishments from 1955 -- is estimated to sell for $300,000 to $350,000. A round gold Cartier wristwatch from 1925 is expected to bring $125,000 to $150,000.
"Wristwatches -- Pateks, Rolexes, Cartiers -- are a form of male jewelry," Ms. Schnipper said. "Collecting has definitely changed in this field. The pocket-watch market did not recover until about two years ago, and then only on the most important pocket watches."
William Scolnik, a pocket-watch expert and consultant of Hawthorne, N.J., refuses to think of watches as fashion, and therefore continues to focus mostly on pocket watches, he said.
"Wristwatches have become very important in the business," Mr. Scolnik said. "They are bought and sold not because of technical precision but for the styling."
 
12-City Tour Planned
 What may be the most ambitious promotion ever devised for a watch auction is now under way to publicize the sale by Habsburg of Geneva of 204 Breguet timepieces on April 14. Describing the Geneva sale as "the most important horological sale in recent times," Habsburg is exhibiting in 12 cities the watches it estimates will sell for $11 million to $13 million. The tour, which began on Jan. 17 in Paris, is currently in Munich. After a viewing next week in London, the Breguets are to be flown to New York, to be shown from Feb. 12 to 16 at Tiffany & Company. The exhibition is also to visit Los Angeles, Tokyo, Hong Kong, Singapore, Doha in Qatar, Zurich and Geneva.
The most important of the Breguet offerings is a new gold wristwatch that doubles as a pocket watch and is automatically wound and set to the exact time when placed inside its master clock. The device to wind and reset the watch, developed 200 years ago by Abraham Louis Breguet, was employed in about 25 pocket watches. Completed three weeks ago at Breguet's workshops in Le Brassus, Switzerland, this is the first wristwatch incorporating the feature. Habsburg estimates it will sell for $680,000 to $850,000.
Breguet timepieces in the auction date from 1780 and include Breguet's first carriage clock from 1796, which Napoleon bought in 1798 and used as a traveling clock. "He took it with him to the Egyptian campaign," said Geza von Habsburg, chairman of the auction house, by telephone this week from Geneva. The presale estimate is $320,000 to $396,000.
Technically sophisticated pocket watches and wristwatches continued to bring high, even record prices, in auctions held during the last two years. The highest figure realized for any auctioned timepiece -- $2.97 million -- was paid in April 1989 at a sale in Geneva of a new watch by Patek Philippe: called the "Calibre '89," it tells what time it is in detail, giving the second, minute, hour, month, year, decade and century. The syndicate that bought the watch was not identified.
Organized by Habsburg, Feldman -- the name of the auction house changed when a co-founder, David Feldman, left last year -- the sale also comprised watches by one manufacturer, Patek Philippe. The watches in that sale, described then as the most valuable watch sale ever, were also widely exhibited, including at Tiffany's in New York. The total paid in the sale of 301 Patek Philippe timepieces was $15.2 million, a record for a watch sale.
Prices for Patek Philippe watches have held firm since that sale, and one watch brought a record price in an auction at Sotheby's in New York in October. At that sale, a massive gold 1920 pocket watch, equipped with bells, an alarm, minute repeater, split-second chronograph and perpetual calendar, brought $660,000, the highest price ever paid for a watch sold at auction in the United States. The buyer was the Patek Philippe Museum of Geneva.
 
A Table Sets a Record
 Last Saturday, Peter G. Terian, president of Rally Motors of Roslyn, L.I., bought a marble-topped, partly gilded Classical Revival pier table from 1815 for $704,000 at Christie's in New York. The price was a record for American 19th-century furniture, eclipsing the $594,000 Stuart P. Feld of Hirschl & Adler Galleries paid for its mate in a sale at Sotheby's in New York two years ago.
Both tables were made by Charles Honore Lannuier, and both were found in Europe in the collections of ancestors of the original New York owner.
"They are two of the finest pieces of Neo-Classical furniture in existence," Mr. Terian said. When his table is delivered to his apartment at the Dakota in Manhattan, it will be placed among other American classics in the Chippendale and Classical Revival styles, including four other pieces of furniture by Lannuier.
Two other records were rewritten last Saturday in Christie's Americana sale: a set of two gold-inlaid Colt revolvers from 1853 brought $352,000, a record at auction for an offering of American guns. An 1866 lithograph, "The American National Game of Baseball," was sold for $44,000, the highest price ever for a Currier & Ives print.

HEADLINE: Hard Times, Faced Squarely

 BODY:
Gov. Mario Cuomo always says his budgets are lean, but this year he's done more than say it. Faced with a deficit that could reach $6 billion, and an economy that has yet to hit bottom, he has put together a tough-minded spending plan. However painful, it could help New York through its worst economic trauma in decades, and in the process give Mr. Cuomo's national image a harder edge.
The $29 billion budget proposal calls for $4.5 billion in cuts and $1.5 billion in taxes and other revenues, and imposes a pay freeze on the state work force. It's too soon to say whether the Governor's plan will, as he contends, preserve New York's "mission" to help those most in need. It could prove so harsh that the Legislature would instead seek higher taxes to fulfill that mission. 
 But this much is clear: In a state with no money, the Cuomo budget is a responsible starting point, and a most welcome departure from the bloated spending and grandiose rhetoric of the past.
Washington's dwindling support for cities and states, and the weakened economy, bear most of the responsibility for New York's fiscal problems. The Governor and lawmakers did their share too, spending lavishly in good times.
Those days are over, as the Governor's budget starkly demonstrates. Its reductions are dramatic and deep. They include significant cuts in Medicaid, a 10 percent reduction in school aid, a deferral of a scheduled cut in personal income taxes, a 10-cent-a-gallon gas tax increase, the elimination of 18,000 state jobs and a 50 percent cut in revenue sharing.
After suggesting but then quickly withdrawing an unpopular proposal for a higher gas tax last year, the Governor now seems ready to fight for it. Compared with earlier years, there are far fewer one-shot revenue gimmicks. There's also a commitment to continuing the budget reforms enacted last spring, and a willingness to take heat from the state unions by insisting on a wage freeze.
Even as he proposed cuts, the Governor tried to preserve programs important to the poor -- including nutritional programs for babies, children and pregnant women. He has also asked the Legislature once again to help local governments save money by releasing them from costly and unduly restrictive mandates, like those governing the size and makeup of special education classes.
Still, Mayor David Dinkins of New York City and other elected officials are already complaining about the harshness of the proposed budget. Mr. Dinkins argues that despite the Governor's pledge to help the city as much as he can, the proposed cut of $400 million in direct state aid, on top of other reductions, would be crippling.
The cuts are harsh, and they are radical. What the next few months of budget negotiations will resolve is whether, in this weak economic climate, there is a better choice.

HEADLINE: Trials -- and Error -- in China

 BODY:
Nei jin, wai song, says China's Communist leadership, meaning that its policy of fierce domestic political repression can coexist with harmonious relations with the outside world. Not so is the outside world's only decent response.
Last week, Beijing convicted and sentenced eight student and intellectual leaders of the 1989 democracy movement, after trials that excluded family, journalists and independent observers. Government-appointed defense counsels readily conceded the defendants' guilt. 
 Wang Dan, one of the best-known student leaders, received a four-year prison sentence. Ren Wanding, a veteran of the 1978-79 Democracy Wall movement, drew seven years because of his continued intransigence.
Further political trials are expected soon, including those of Wang Juntao, editor of the reform journal Economic Studies Weekly, and Chen Zi ming, its publisher. Both risk death sentences on charges of plotting to overthrow the Government.
In 1991, flagrant abuse of human rights can no longer be treated as a purely domestic issue. International conventions require conformity with agreed minimal standards. Indeed, the laws of many democratic countries require more. And hard-headed statesmen and investors are recognizing the links between today's state violence and tomorrow's stability.
The State Department rightly expresses American outrage at China's latest imprisonment of people for "nonviolent expression of political views," and questions the fairness of the trials. It suggests that the convictions may violate the U.N. Universal Declaration of Human Rights.
That's a welcome surprise. The Bush Administration recently renewed its courtship of China's leaders to avoid open Chinese opposition to its Persian Gulf policies. For Washington now to insist on upholding U.N. human rights principles, even against a permanent member of the Security Council, demonstrates the evenhandedness required for a new world order based on law.
Remarkably, Beijing seems to believe that in these trials it has gone out of its way to be lenient. Workers involved in the 1989 democracy movement were shot in the back of the head. Wei Jingsheng, a young worker who wrote articles 12 years ago insisting that political democracy was essential to economic modernization, has been held in solitary confinement ever since.
Beijing's more modulated repression this time comes after Chinese officials were shocked at the human rights criticism they continue to draw in public in the West. China's response must be considered progress of a sort, encouragement to keep up the dialogue and the criticism; Beijing's behavior falls far short of what the world expects.

HEADLINE: Calendar Tricks Won't Fix N.Y. Budget

 BODY:
To the Editor:
If New York Assembly Speaker Mel Miller wants to avoid fiscal surprises ("Albany's Budget Timing Is Way Off," Op-Ed, Jan. 5), changing the start of the fiscal year from April to July in the name of access to more complete information on tax collections is not the way to do it.
The fiscal surprises Mr. Miller professes to fear are avoided by setting realistic budgetary limits based on known revenue sources. By doing so, you avoid springing a fiscal surprise on New York's citizens in the form of more and higher taxes.
A politician as savvy as Mr. Miller knows that taxes raised to fill budget gaps are regressive, discriminatory and ultimately insufficient. Unless spending is reduced, the money hemorrhage soon soaks through the Band-Aid of a tax increase. The accurate forecasting of budgets is an admirable goal that is best achieved by containing costs, not by changing the calendar.
 
JUNE SILVERBERG
New York, Jan. 15, 1991

HEADLINE: America's Purpose in Gulf Is to Fight Evil

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I am a proud 14-year-old American. The last couple of weeks have turned my life into a whirlwind of confusion as I watched my country go to war for the first time in my life. Endless nights watching CNN, hours spent reading the newspaper, and lectures in school did not help me to understand exactly why our world had fallen into the pits of war. Maybe I don't know much about politics or the price of oil, but I do know how I feel inside. 
 I feel that the American population is touching only the surface of the meaning of this war. Watching protesters burn our flag confuses me. Do these people, who claim to be "moral," think that waiting until the sanctions work is a peaceful solution? Is it really maintaining peace by starving Iraqi civilians? Is it more righteous to inflict hunger on a small child than to destroy Saddam Hussein's growing military monster? Will these protesters be content when Mr. Hussein threatens the lives of millions with nuclear weapons? When Americans shout "peace," do they think about what they're saying?
Amid all the rallies and protests, the real conflict at hand is lost. It is a moral conflict of how to deal with human aggression and evil. So instead of shouting "peace" when there is no realistic way to achieve it, we should deal with humanity. Everyone should reach out to someone in need. We should relate to each other on the basis of human kindness and love.
America is not in the Persian Gulf to serve economic interests. Our brave soldiers are on the Saudi border to show that America refuses to tolerate naked aggression. If we had only stood up for our beliefs 50 years ago, millions of people would have been saved. So let's consider the more profound aspect of this war. This war is not a matter of bombs or sanctions. It is a universal struggle against the evil of mankind. Let us not forget that we are together in this struggle. We must stand as a strong, united nation behind our troops, behind our President and behind our sacred human values.
 
DEBBIE LEFKOWITZ
Scarsdale, N.Y., Jan. 28, 1991

HEADLINE: Richer, and Poorer

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The Census Bureau's recently reported study of changes in household wealth from 1984 to 1988 (front page, Jan. 11) shows a much more shocking picture than your account of this study indicates. Your headline read "Rich Got Richer in 80's; Others Held Even." In fact the data show that while the wealth of the top one-fifth of households rose by 14 percent, the wealth of the "rest," the bottom four-fifths, actually fell by 23 percent.
As you report, the average wealth for all households (corrected for inflation) fell from $37,012 in 1984 to $35,752 in 1988 (a difference that was not statistically significant, but that nonetheless reflected the full data collected by the Census Bureau). But if the wealth of the top one-fifth rose in this period from $98,411 to $111,770, this means that the average household wealth of the remaining four-fifths fell from $21,662 to $16,748. This represents a decline of 23 percent, and this is significant, statistically and for what it tells us about the dramatic changes in the United States over a four-year period that did not even include a recession. It is time to stop viewing the 80's as a period of prosperity and recognize it for what it was, a period of Robin Hood in reverse.
 
PADDY QUICK
Professor of Economics
St. Francis College
Brooklyn, Jan. 17, 1991

HEADLINE: Japan Trade Surplus Falls

BYLINE: REUTERS

DATELINE: TOKYO, Feb. 1

 BODY:
Japan's surplus in the current account, the widest measure of trade in goods and services, narrowed to $3.71 billion, from $4.01 billion a year earlier, but widened from $1.75 billion in November, the Japanese Finance Ministry said today.
For the whole year, the ministry said, the surplus shrank to $35.79 billion in 1990, from $57.16 billion the previous year. The annual decline in 1990 was the third in a row. 
 "Japan has become another Germany, in that spending by tourists going abroad is eroding gains in exports," said Yukihiko Shimada, an economist at the Wako Research Institute.
Japan's invisible trade account posted a record deficit of $22.59 billion in 1990 because transport costs rose and more than 10 million Japanese went abroad, the official said.
But in contrast to the exodus of people, huge flows of Japanese money surged home in 1990. The Persian Gulf crisis and falling interest rates in the United States slashed Japan's deficit in long-term capital flows to $43.46 billion in 1990, from $89.25 billion a year before, the official said.
Exports in 1990 recorded their eighth straight year of growth, rising to $280 billion, from $269 billion in 1989, because of higher exports of automobiles, auto parts and audio visual equipment, ministry data show.

HEADLINE: Naivasha Journal;
Dutch Flowers? In Name Only. Ask the Kenyans.

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NAIVASHA, Kenya, Jan. 27

 BODY:
In a cavernous hall set in a 4,500-acre flower farm here, an almost militarily precise work force grades, ties in bunches, packs in boxes and refrigerates a million carnations a day.
After a rocky three-hour ride on trailer trucks from this lakeside area in the Rift Valley of East Africa, the flowers are loaded in Nairobi on jets bound for Europe, where Kenyan flowers are harvesting a name for quality and durability. 
 Last year, Kenya, better known for its tourism and coffee, exported 400 million flowers, ranking it sixth or seventh in the world after traditional flower producers like the Netherlands, Israel and Colombia, flower growers here say.
One company, Sulmac, the biggest Kenyan flower producer and the owner of what the company says is the largest carnation farm in the world, exported 214 million stems: carnations, roses, lilies, larkspur and a long-lasting, crisply textured flower called statice that often lends a splash of purple to supermarket bouquets in the United States.
 
Tourism Drops Off
 Delicate flowers from Africa gracing European salons? Sounds improbable. But in a country where coffee, tea and tourism have been mainstays of relatively scarce foreign-exchange earnings, flower exports are now the fastest-growing source of foreign exchange and have suddenly gained a special importance.
Not only have hard times come to Kenyan coffee, coveted although it accounts for just 2.4 percent of world coffee exports; tourism is hurting as well. The Kenyan game parks are nearly empty of visitors these days as vacationers cancel because of nervousness over the Persian Gulf war.
The Kenyan equatorial highland climate -- refreshingly cool at night, brilliant but not bruising sunlight during the day -- turns out to be ideal for flower growing, just as it has been well suited to coffee-growing since the early days of colonial settlement. As worldwide coffee prices remain at depressing lows, Brooke Bond, the largest coffee company in Kenya and parent to Sulmac, has received special permission from the Government to pull up coffee plants, traditionally considered almost sacred, and replace them with roses.
"The light is good, the water is available," said David Gray, the managing director of Sulmac, as he inspected field upon field of jade green carnation plants, their buds just bursting. "The soil is not good -- basically volcanic dust -- but we can put a lot on it to improve it."
While the large-scale flower business has been mostly dominated by Europeans since it was started a decade ago, many Kenyans, among them the governor of the Central Bank, Eric Kotut, have found ventures like rose growing to be profitable side-businesses. Some Kenyan university students are specializing in horticulture, which they see as a growth industry. And all around the mile-high Lake Naivasha, flower specialists are experimenting with hybrids to produce attractive yet long-lasting specimens that can survive the rigors of overseas travel.
On the rim of the lake, German and Dutch technical experts have perfected the art of growing carnations outdoors. In most places in the world, carnations are cultivated under cover, a method that makes the enterprise more costly.
In addition to the favorable environment, growers here enjoy the benefits of a cheap labor force, a factor that gives Kenya an advantage against more traditional flower-growing countries.
At most of the flower farms that encircle Lake Naivasha, workers are paid the equivalent of about $40 a month, plus free schooling for their children and medical services. Despite the huge volume of flowers processed every day, cheap labor means there is little automation in the Sulmac packing hall -- only a conveyor belt a few yards long.
"We can do it better by hand," said Joseph Kinyanjui, senior supervisor of the 680 workers, whose hands weave and flash through the air as they grade and pack. "Each grader moves at least 2,600 stems a day, some do 6,000 a day."
Since the freshness of the flowers is essential, speed is emphasized. Pickers in the fields collect stems with buds that are just about to open. The stems are left in bins at the end of the long rows of plants and collected by trucks that constantly patrol the fields. In the grading hall, the flowers are rejuvenated for up to 24 hours in buckets of water infused with preservatives, then graded, packed and cooled in a refrigeration room. A fleet of insulated trucks makes the arduous route to the Nairobi airport in three to four hours.
 
Cheating on the Labels
 "From field to plane is normally 36 hours," Mr. Gray said. "It can be 24 hours. From field to retail market, four to five days."
While trade barriers do not seem to pose a major challenge to Kenyan flower exporters, transportation does. Sulmac destroyed 10 tons of flowers a day before Christmas because there was not enough space on jets.
The bulk of Sulmac's flowers are sold through a company based in Nuremburg, Germany, which then distributes them to various parts of the world, including the United States.
Some are sold directly at auctions in the Netherlands and markets in England. At Heathrow Airport, bouquets of flowers with labels from the Netherlands are actually Kenyan. They are retagged, said Mr. Gray with a shrug, to add the aura of prestige that Kenyan flower growers are striving for but have yet to achieve.

GRAPHIC: Photo: In Kenya, where coffee and tea have traditionally been the main exports, flowers are now the fastest growing source of foreign exchange. Last year,Kenya exported 400 million flowers. In Naivasha, workers at the Sulmac Flower Farm grade, pack and refrigerate a million carnations a day. (Jane Perlez/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Heavy Sales Depress Dollar After Fed Acts to Cut Rates

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar took a pounding overseas yesterday and continued to lose ground in domestic dealings after a surprise interest-rate cut by the Federal Reserve and a worse-than-expected unemployment report.
Gold prices were mostly lower. 
 The announcement that the Fed was cutting the discount rate half a point, to 6 percent, set off strong selling in European markets and pushed the dollar lower in trading in the United States.
The move, which came a day after Germany's central bank raised two important interest rates, was compounded by a subsequent Labor Department report showing the United States' unemployment rate had inched up to 6.2 percent in January, the highest level since 1987.
The report was taken as a sign that "the economic slowdown is probably deeper and longer lasting" than previously thought, said John McCarthy, chief dealer at Algemene Bank Nederland in New York. "As a consequence, interest rates can come down" further to stimulate growth.
Low interest rates undermine the American currency by making dollar-denominated securities less valuable to foreign investors.
Traders shunned the dollar in favor of the mark, a move that also put pressure on the British pound. There were reports that both the Bank of England and the Bundesbank of Germany had stepped in to buy pounds against the mark to shore up the British currency.
The dollar lost more than a cent against the pound and more than a pfennig against the mark. But it still settled above its postwar low of 1.4625 marks, which some traders said might be a sign the currency was "approaching a major bottom," said Robert Hatcher, chief dealer at Barclays Bank P.L.C. in New York.
In Tokyo, the dollar fell to a close of 131.25 Japanese yen, from 131.40 yen on Thursday. Later in London, it was quoted higher at 131.43 yen. In New York, the dollar settled at 131.50 yen, up from 131.26 yen on Thursday.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.9765, from $1.9645 late Thursday. In New York, it cost $1.9760 to buy one pound, more expensive than the $1.9665 on Thursday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with the late Thursday rates, included: 1.4680 German marks, down from 1.4770; 1.2525 Swiss francs, down from 1.2579; 4.9960 French francs, down from 5.0245; 1,105.00 Italian lire, down from 1,111.25, and 1.1598 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1633.
On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery gained 30 cents to settle at $366.10 an ounce. But the Republic National Bank quoted a late bid for gold of $365.50, off 30 cents an ounce.
Gold fell in London to a late bid price of $366.55 an ounce, from $366.75 late Thursday. In Zurich, the metal fell to a closing bid of $365.50 from $366.40. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold lost $2 to close at a bid of $369.80.
Silver prices were mixed. On the Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $3.852 an ounce, up from $3.830 on Thursday. In London, silver fell to a late bid price of $3.83 an ounce, down from $3.84.

HEADLINE: WAR IN THE GULF: Japan;
Japan's Premier Backs a Compromise on Aid for the Gulf War

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Feb. 1

 BODY:
Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu, struggling to gain legislative approval of $9 billion in aid for the war against Iraq, has agreed in principle to a compromise that would prevent the money from being spent on arms, ammunition or anything else intended for lethal purposes, Japanese officials said today.
The officials said the money would be given to the United States and the allies fighting in the Persian Gulf, but only for "logistical" purposes. As a practical matter, the officials said, the contribution would free other money to be spent for weapons and arms. 
 Mr. Kaifu's decision was seen as a setback for the United States, which had asked that no strings be attached to the new contribution by Japan. On the other hand, American officials said, they are happy with the $9 billion and could easily live with the restrictions.
"There are plenty of things we can use the money for without having to spend it on lethal materials," an American official said.
 
Compromise Needs Approval

The compromise embraced by Mr. Kaifu, which officials said had not been approved in every detail, is to be announced next week as the debate in the Parliament heats up. Japan has already pledged $4 billion in economic and quasi-military aid, a little more than half of which has been spent.
The major opposition parties, which together control the upper house of Parliament, have announced their opposition to the measures proposed earlier by Mr. Kaifu, including $9 billion in aid with no strings attached and a plan to send military planes to evacuate refugees from Jordan.
Government officials said Mr. Kaifu had reluctantly agreed to the limits preventing the money from being spent on lethal materials because he needs the swing votes of the Clean Government Party, or Komeito, in the upper house of Parliament.
On Thursday Mr. Kaifu and his Cabinet agreed to put the entire $9 billion package in one bill that would appropriate the money, authorize taxes on cigarettes, gasoline and corporations to pay for it and issue Treasury bonds to cover the aid until the Government is reimbursed from the new tax revenue.
 
Parliament's Vote Uncertain
 His decision means that, contrary to earlier reports, the entire package will now have to be approved in the Parliament before it can proceed. Such approval is far from guaranteed, according to Government officials.
The Komeito party objects to the taxes and to the widespread impression that Japan is aiding the gulf effort out of deference to the United States. The party takes those positions in part because it will be competing for votes against the left-leaning Japan Socialist Party this year. The Socialist leader, Takako Doi, has denounced Mr. Kaifu's plans.
Polls vary, but it appears that the public is divided over how deeply Japan should be involved in aiding the gulf effort. Some surveys show more than 50 percent of Japanese objecting.
The Komeito party also objects to the Prime Minister's plan to send military planes to the gulf, saying that even a humanitarian mission to airlift refugees violates laws and policies banning the Japanese military from any role in a combat zone.
 
Defeat of Bill Feared
 At first, Washington denied it had pressed Japan for the money. But later Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d embarrassed Tokyo by saying the Bush Administration had indeed asked for the $9 billion and would receive it.
It was not clear whether Mr. Kaifu's gesture to the Komeito Party would secure enough votes for approval of the bill. One official said some were worried about a "nightmare scenario" in which the bill would go down in defeat, echoing the collapse of a plan last year to send military personnel to the gulf.
Defeat of the $9 billion aid package could bring a crisis in relations between the United States and Japan and topple Mr. Kaifu's Government.
For this reason, politicians say, the United States will have to accept the restrictions on the aid sought by Mr. Kaifu, since Washington, too, does not want to jeopardize the entire aid package.
 
$9 Billion Can Be Spent Easily
 Japanese officials say the allied forces in the Middle East can easily spend the $9 billion on "logistical" support. Up to now, the United States has been asked to spend the initial contribution only on transportation of nonlethal materials.
The Komeito party is a splinter group allied with a Buddhist sect and thus has pacifist leanings. Many of its volunteers are women, who, according to surveys, are mostly opposed to Japan's involvement in the war.
The ruling Liberal Democratic Party is so eager to placate the Komeito party on the gulf aid issue that Mr. Kaifu's aides are reportedly moving to deny renomination to the Governor of the Tokyo prefecture in his re-election effort this year because the Komeito objects to his continuing in office.

HEADLINE: Construction Spending Slid 0.5% in December

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1

 BODY:
Construction spending slid for a ninth straight month in December, falling five-tenths of a percent and helping to trim building growth for the year to just six-tenths of a percent, the Government said today.
Many analysts forecast a rebound in residential building later this year but no significant improvement on the nonresidential side. And government outlays are uncertain because of the questions on the effects of the recession on revenues. 
 Over all, said Daryl Delano, an economist at Cahners Economics in Newton, Mass., "I believe it will be a down year."
The Commerce Department said spending on residential, nonresidential and government projects in December totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $415.1 billion, the lowest level since a $410.5 billion rate in January 1988.
Spending during the previous two months was even weaker than first reported. November expenditures were revised to show a 1.5 percent decline, down from the six-tenths of a percent drop originally reported, while October spending fell one-tenth of a percent rather than rose three-tenths of a percent, as first thought.
For the year, spending totaled $434.9 billion, up from $432.1 billion in 1989.
But construction has been sliding each month since posting a four-tenths of a percent gain in March because of tight credit, high vacancy rates and faltering consumer and business confidence linked to the Persian Gulf crisis and a recessionary economy.
And a Labor Department report today suggested further declines in the months ahead. It said construction payrolls in January fell 155,000, after seasonal adjustment, following a 28,000 drop in December.
The report said 450,000 construction jobs have been lost since last May.
Residential spending continued to decline, falling 2.3 percent in December to an annual rate of $167.5 billion after a 3.2 percent decline a month earlier.
Spending on single-family housing dropped 3.2 percent, to $96.5 billion, after falling 2.8 percent in November. Apartment building edged up five-tenths of a percent, to $17.7 billion, but failed to erase a 6.4 percent drop a month earlier.
In December, nonresidential spending rose a eight-tenths of a percent, to $97 billion, attributed in part to a 7.1 percent increase in industrial building. Most other categories fell. Spending on the nonresidential sector had dropped 3 percent the previous month.
Government spending rose for the second straight month, up 1.1 percent, to $115.2 billion, after a 1.8 percent advance in November.

HEADLINE: New York State Unemployment Up to 6.5%

BYLINE: By RICHARD LEVINE

 BODY:
Unemployment in New York State rose a full percentage point in January, to 6.5 percent. And the jobless rate in New Jersey also jumped, to 6.4 percent from 5.7 percent.
The rates in both states were higher than the 6.2 percent reported yesterday for the nation as a whole. 
 The unemployment rate in New York City increased to 7.4 percent, from 6.3 percent in December, but was down from a recent peak of 7.9 percent in September.
Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, regional commissioner of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics, said that the numbers for New York State were especially troubling, with the state's unemployment rate at its highest level in four and a half years.
Mr. Ehrenhalt said New York had seen a sharp decline in employment in recent months, losing 100,000 jobs from August to December.
"Basically, unemployment is up, employment down and labor force participation is down," he said. "It's construction; it's trade; it's finance; it's manufacturing -- it's everything. It really adds up to the most serious deterioration in our economy since the 1970's."
In New Jersey, the 6.4 percent rate was a substantial increase from 4.9 percent in August and 4.5 percent a year ago.
In New York City, Mr. Ehrenhalt said research indicated there had been a worrisome shift in the composition of unemployment. Two-thirds of those who say they are unemployed are people who have been dismissed, he said. Three months ago, more than half of the city's unemployed were people who were searching for their first job or who had voluntarily left their jobs.
The city's unemployment rate, Mr. Ehrenhalt said, now reflects "a lot less churning" in the labor market and more of the impact of the slump that cost the city nearly 50,000 jobs in 1990.

HEADLINE: Yields Plunge As Fed Cuts Discount Rate

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
Interest rates plunged yesterday after the Federal Reserve, responding to a surge in unemployment and other negative economic data, cut its discount rate by a half-point, to 6 percent. The Fed also moved to lower the key interbank lending rate.
Because the bond market thrives on any negative economic news that will keep inflation in check and cause lower rates on newer issues, prices of Treasury securities exploded in the morning within minutes after the report that unemployment in January rose to its highest level since the summer of 1987. 
 Corporations also seized on the rise in bond prices and the drop in yields to offer $2.7 billion of new issues for sale yesterday. This surge compared with total corporate offerings of $5.7 billion for the current week.
 
A Bit of a Surprise
 While the Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, had indicated this week that a rate cut was needed to stimulate the economy, the central bank was not expected to act until after its policy-making Open Market Committee convenes next week.
But an hour after the job report was released, the Fed cut its discount rate to 6 percent from 6 1/2 percent, the second cut since Dec. 18. Within minutes, the Treasury's benchmark long bonds, the 8.75 percent issue maturing in August 2020, jumped well over a point, or $10 for each $1,000 of face value.
Despite repeated bouts of profit taking during the session, the long bonds were still offered at 107 14/32, up 1 9/32, while the yield fell to 8.08 percent, from 8.19 percent the day before and 8.22 percent a week ago.
"The Fed's action was too little and too late to adequately deal with the worsening recession," said Philip Braverman, senior vice president and chief economist at the DKB Securities Corporation, the domestic arm of the Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank of Tokyo, the world's largest private bank. "The Fed is behind the learning curve as we will see when the G.N.P. for the fourth quarter of 1990 is revised sharply downward. This quarter's G.N.P. will be far more dismal."
 
 Downward Revision Expected
 Mr. Braverman expects the 1990 fourth-quarter gross national product to be revised downward from the 2.1 percent decline reported last week to minus 3.5 to 4 percent. "We know the Fed will have to take stronger action to lower rates," he said, "and the longer it procrastinates the longer the recession will last."
William V. Sullivan Jr., senior vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., said: "Some market participants were troubled by the fact that the initial advance of the long bond wasn't extended. But the long bond did resist some heavy profit taking during the day."
Bill rates fell yesterday to their lowest levels since April 1988.
While bill rates are always the most immediately affected by any change in Fed policy, Mr. Sullivan attributed the steepening yield curve "basically to lack of investor follow-through at the long end of the market after the initial advance."
The discount rate on the 90-day Treasury bills plummeted 21 basis points, to 5.99 percent; six-month bills fell 22 basis points, to 5.98 percent, and one-year bills lost 22 basis points, at 5.91 percent. The Treasury announced it plans to auction $11.75 billion of one-year bills on Feb. 12.
 
 Shift Seen in Fed Funds Rate
 Meanwhile, the actions by the Fed led the market to believe that its new target for the vital Federal funds rate was being cut to 6.25 percent, from 6.75 percent. The funds rate is considered the bedrock cost of credit because that is what banks charge one another for temporary loans. The funds rate is also the basic rate most easily controlled by the Fed.
After the Fed's discount rate cut and infusion of reserves into the banking system, the funds traded at 5.5 percent at the close, after opening at 7 percent and briefly moving to 7.5 percent.
Because the market also expected the Fed to reduce interest rates further, dealers and traders are expected to be eager bidders at next week's record $34.5 billion Treasury quarterly refunding auctions.
 
 Next Week's Treasury Issues
 On Tuesday, the Treasury will offer $12.5 billion of three-year notes, which traded on a when-issued basis to yield 7.02 percent, down from 7.24 percent the day before. On Wednesday, $11 billion of 10-year notes will be sold and these traded to yield 7.88 percent, against 8 percent the day before.
The auctions will end Thursday, with the sale of $11 billion of new 30-year long bonds. The bonds also traded on a when-issued basis, to yield 8.06 percent, down from 8.18 percent the day before.
The refunding issues must be "settled," or paid for, by Feb. 15, which is common for such sales. What is no longer common is for the Fed to adopt an "even keel" posture on interest rates before a refunding. Mr. Braverman noted that the Treasury and Fed usually sounded out market sentiment about interest rates and other factors before refunding terms were announced and when-issued trading started, usually after the terms were announced.

HEADLINE: FEDERAL RESERVE CUTS LOAN RATES TO PROD ECONOMY

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1

 BODY:
In the face of stark new evidence of the nation's economic weakness, the Federal Reserve moved today with unusual force to stimulate the economy by sharply reducing the interest rates it controls.
Large banks across the country responded immediately by reducing their prime rate, the benchmark rate for many mortgages and other commercial and consumer loans. 
 But many economists predicted that today's steps would not be enough to bring the country out of recession. "I think the war has to end," said Jerry L. Jordan, chief economist at First Interstate Bancorp in Los Angeles. "I don't think you're going to get people borrowing and spending again until they are confident that the war is not going to spread."
 
Shift to Pessimism
 The pessimistic view of the economy, based largely on the Government's release today of new, disappointing data about employment and manufacturers' purchases, is quite a contrast to the judgment that prevailed only a week or two ago when economists were saying the worst of the recession might be over.
"These numbers are so devastating that they suggest the worst is ahead of us and not behind us," said David M. Jones, chief economist at Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, a Wall Street bond firm. They show that "the recession could carry through to next year," he added.
The Labor Department reported today that unemployment rose to 6.2 percent in January, the highest level since 1987; that payrolls, not counting farm workers, fell by 232,000 jobs, and that the average workweek shrank by half an hour. [Page 29.]
 
No Influence on Stocks
 The combination of bad economic news and the Federal Reserve's actions caused interest rates in the credit markets to plunge, but the stock market appeared to focus more on corporate profits and fell slightly.
Within minutes of the Labor Department's release of the employment figures this morning, the Federal Reserve announced that it had cut the discount rate to 6 percent, from 6 1/2 percent. This is the rate the central bank charges on loans to commercial banks. Since banks rarely borrow from the Federal Reserve these days unless they are in serious trouble, the discount rate is important mainly as a signal of policy intentions.
Later in the morning, the Federal Reserve bought large quantities of Government securities to indicate to the financial markets that it wanted to lower its target for the crucial Federal funds rate, apparently to 6 1/4 percent, from 6 3/4 percent. This is the rate commercial banks charge one another for overnight loans and is often a determining factor in the rates they offer customers. It was the second half-point cut in the rate in six weeks.
In Alan Greenspan's three and a half years as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, the Federal Reserve has almost always limited changes in the funds rate target to one-quarter of a percentage point at a time. This was the first time the Federal Reserve changed the discount rate and the Federal funds rate target on the same day.
Large commercial banks, including Citibank and J. P. Morgan in New York, the First National Bank of Chicago and BankAmerica Corporation in San Francisco, immediately reduced their prime rate to 9 percent, from 9 1/2 percent, and other large and small banks will surely follow suit.
"The employment numbers were so dreadful that the Fed had no choice but to respond immediately with decisive, unambiguous action," said Robert H. Chandross, chief economist in the New York office of Lloyds Bank.
The Federal Reserve's actions also reflected a report this morning by a private group, the National Association of Purchasing Management, showing that its purchasing managers' index had fallen to its lowest level since May 1982, in the midst of the last recession.
 
Attention to Manufacturers
 Mr. Jones, who has just completed a book on the Federal Reserve under Mr. Greenspan, says the chairman pays especially close attention to the monthly purchasing index, which measures what manufacturers are buying.
The Federal Reserve announced the discount rate cut shortly after 9 this morning instead of waiting, as it usually does, until after the financial markets closed. Economists who follow the Federal Reserve closely said it might have moved immediately on the heels of bad economic news so it would not appear to be succumbing to pressure from the White House. In a blast at the Federal Reserve in his State of the Union Message Tuesday night, President Bush said, "Interest rates should be lower, now."
In the statement accompanying its announcement of the cut in the discount rate, the Federal Reserve Board said, "Action was taken in light of further declines in economic activity, continued sluggish growth trends in money and credit and evidence of abating inflationary pressures, including weakness in commodity prices."
The vote to reduce the discount rate was 5 to 0 with one governor, Wayne D. Angell, absent. The board has one vacancy.
Because of the huge budget deficit, President Bush and Congress would find it almost impossible to take the standard steps during a recession of reducing taxes or increasing Government spending to stimulate the economy. That means the fate of the economy is almost entirely in the hands of the Federal Reserve.
 
Theory Behind the Cut
 By cutting interest rates, the Federal Reserve in theory has the power to make borrowing more attractive and thus generate economic growth through more spending by companies and individuals.
But this recession is unlike any before, apparently a result of two forces operating outside the normal business cycle. The first is the war with Iraq, which has made consumers and businesses uneasy about the future and thus unwilling to commit themselves to purchases. The second is the fragility of the banking system, which has made many banks unwilling to lend even to their regular, credit-worthy customers.
This is the first recession since World War II to take hold at a time when the Federal Reserve was already driving interest rates down. And even though the Federal funds rate has been reduced by almost two full percentage points in the last three months, that has had little effect on bank lending.
Mr. Greenspan studies economic statistics carefully, perhaps more rigorously than any of his predecessors did, and in an interview this week, he seemed clearly concerned about the state of the economy and his capacity to turn it around.
 
 Confidence Is Eroding
 He said that the "credit crunch," as he repeatedly called the lack of money to borrow, was proving more intractable than he had expected and that the country could face a long and deep recession because of the erosion of consumer confidence if the war was not over by the middle of April.
Mr. Greenspan said he was paying much closer attention than usual to the nation's money supply, basically the sum of all currency, bank deposits and money market accounts, because he thought that was the best gauge of credit conditions.
The money supply rose hardly at all in the last quarter of 1990. When the Federal Open Market Committee, the policy-making arm of the Federal Reserve, meets here on Tuesday, it will have access to the latest figures showing what happened to the money supply in January. That could determine whether the committee decides to reduce rates further.
Some economists say the Federal Reserve will now stand pat for a while to judge the effect of today's actions. "I think they'll pause at this point because they still have to be a little concerned about a bounce-back effect," said Mr. Jordan of First Interstate.
But Donald Ratajczak, director of the Economic Forecasting Project at Georgia State University in Atlanta, said further easing of rates was probably in the offing. "You can't move the economy along until you get more money in the system," he said.

HEADLINE: Job Losses Up Sharply Last Month

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1

 BODY:
In a sharp setback to hopes that the sliding economy had begun to stabilize, the Government today reported a heavy new wave of job losses in January and an unusually large contraction in the length of the average workweek.
The unemployment rate rose just one-tenth of a point, to 6.2 percent, but there was wide agreement among analysts that this understated the deterioration of the economy last month. One reason was that many of the newly jobless were thought to have not yet begun the search for other work and thus were not counted in the current data. 
 "There's a lot of dismal news here," said Janet L. Norwood, the Commissioner of Labor Statistics. She cited, among other things, the losses of 155,000 jobs in construction and 70,000 in manufacturing.
 
 Cuts in Interest Rates
 The job data, combined with a weak report from corporate purchasing managers, led to a half-point cut today in the Federal Reserve's discount rate, to 6 percent. This, in turn, caused commercial banks to cut their prime lending rates by the same amount, to 9 percent.
The Fed usually tries to avoid seeming to respond to any particular set of figures, but economists said the central bank was clearly worried by the job report, the first comprehensive gauge of economic performance for January. The fact that the Fed acted so promptly in the face of an increase in German interest rates on Thursday reinforced this view, economists said.
"They're much worse than the one-tenth increase in the unemployment rate would imply," said Rudy Oswald, director of economic research for the A.F.L.-C.I.O., referring to the Labor Department figures. "There are no signs of the recession ending. It's worsening."
 
 Outlook for the G.N.P.
 The rate move by the Fed is aimed at stimulating economic activity, which, as measured by the gross national product, fell at a 2.1 percent annual rate during the October-December period. Some analysts now think the G.N.P. could fall as much as twice that rate in the current quarter.
The job figures, based on a survey of businesses, showed payroll employment tumbling 232,000 last month, all but 3,000 of this in the goods-producing sector. This brought the decline since last June to more than one million jobs.
Analysts also noted that the decline in payroll jobs in December had been revised to 148,000, instead of the 76,000 initially reported.
Both the jobless rate and number of those out of work in January were at their highest points in more than three and a half years.
Officials said bad weather contributed to the drop of 155,000 in construction jobs, but, based on comments from the businesses surveyed, the dominant reason for the decline was the slumping economy. The construction figures, as are most other numbers in the report, are adjusted for normal seasonal variation.
The weakness in the building trades was borne out by a Commerce Department report today showing that construction spending fell five-tenths of 1 percent in December, the ninth straight month of decline.
 
 Weakness in Manufacturing
 The Labor Department said the loss of 70,000 jobs in the manufacturing sector included big drops in lumber, furniture and other construction-related industries and in the automobile industry and its suppliers.
Payroll employment would have fallen even further had it not been for what analysts called an artificial increase of 85,000 in retail jobs. In an effort to hold down costs, stores added relatively few temporary workers for the Christmas season and thus the January cutbacks were smaller than assumed by the seasonal adjustment factor.
Service jobs, which have shown steady growth for years, have now failed to grow for two straight months. Losses in government and in business services were partly offset by gains in the still-robust health-care field, which added another 40,000. The finance, insurance and real estate category contracted by 8,000, the report showed.
The workweek shrank by a full half-hour in the private sector as a whole and in manufacturing. It was an unusually severe drop in both categories, which had shown increases of about one-quarter of an hour in December. The January drop helped slash the index of aggregate weekly hours to 121.7, from 124 in December.
Norman Robertson, chief economist at the Mellon Bank, described the decline in employment over the last seven months as similar to the pattern established during the first seven months of the 1981-82 recession, the most severe of the eight recessions since World War II. It is not certain precisely when this recession began, but most analysts believe it began during the summer.
 
 Calculating the Rate
 The unemployment rate is based on a Labor Department survey of households and the picture from that survey was as bleak as that from the business survey. The department calculated that jobs plunged by 652,000 and the labor force shrank by 536,000. The resulting rise of 116,000 in the number of jobless people pushed the unemployment rate up by one-tenth of a point.
At 6.2 percent, the jobless rate is nearly a full point higher than it was in June, but that jump is just half the increase posted during the first seven months of the 1981-82 recession.
Even though the job-loss situation now is in some ways similar to that in the early 1980's, various social and demographic factors have produced a slowdown in the growth of the labor force, and that has limited the rise in the unemployment rate. Among those factors are the relatively low population of young people, which has cut down on the number of people seeking their first jobs, and recent signs that women are reducing their participation in the work force.
Statistically, teen-agers accounted for the entire rise in joblessness last month, with their unemployment rate jumping to 18.2 percent, from 16.6.
 
 Varieties of Unemployment
 Among the ranks of the jobless, the number of those who had lost their jobs rose by almost 300,000 last month, increasing this portion of all jobless to 53 percent, from just under half in December. At the same time, the number of people who voluntarily left their job fell by about 100,000, to 11.7 percent of the unemployed.
"Such hesitation of workers to leave a job and look for a new one is typical during an economic downturn," Dr. Norwood said.
Job losses were concentrated among adult men last month, reversing an unusual pattern for a recession that had seen women bearing the brunt of the decline in employment.
The number of people working part time because they could not find full-time work was virtually unchanged last month, at about 5.5 million, the report showed.
 
Texas Bucks the Trend
 Eight of the 11 biggest states showed increases in their jobless rate last month, with Massachusetts posting an increase of 1.3 percentage points, to 8.6 percent. The rate for New York was up one point, to 6.5 percent, while the New Jersey rate rose to 6.4 percent, from 5.7 percent. But Texas posted a decline of six-tenths of a percentage point, to 6.4 percent.
By region, seasonally unadjusted data showed the rates rose in the Northeast by 1.7 points, to 7.4 percent; in the Midwest, by 1.2 points, to 6.8 percent; in the South, by seven-tenths of a point, to 6.9 percent, and in the West by eight-tenths, to 6.8 percent.
Officials said today's figures were not appreciably affected by the call-up of military reserves after the war began in the Persian Gulf.
Average hourly earnings, the report showed, were essentially unchanged last month, but average weekly earnings fell 1.5 percent, to $347.14.
