HEADLINE: Lines of Jobless Grow as Benefits Staff Shrinks

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: STERLING HEIGHTS, Mich., Jan. 31

 BODY:
At 7 A.M. a full moon was shining down on Tim Peck as he stood outside an unemployment office trying to ward off the bitter cold and his rising anger.
Seven weeks after he was laid off from his job as a truck driver, Mr. Peck had yet to receive his first unemployment benefits. Several calls to the unemployment office went unanswered or brought a busy signal. So, despite an early morning snow, he waited with 30 others, knowing that if he arrived later in the day as many as 300 people would be in line and he would wait four hours to be seen. 
 "I'm going to grab someone by the throat," Mr. Peck said as he stomped his feet and clapped his hands to keep warm.
Mr. Peck's frustrations are being repeated in thousands of unemployment offices around the country as the unemployment rate climbs.
The problem is not with paying the unemployment benefits; they are financed by the states and have not been cut. But the benefits checks have been delayed because the Federal Government, which pays the costs of running the unemployment offices, has been cutting back on its payments in recent years.
As a result of the declining Federal aid, state officials have reduced the staffs at the unemployment offices. But now, as the recession has taken hold, the offices are being overwhelmed with claims, causing delays of up to six weeks in processing applications and mailing benefit checks. Those in line complain not only of the inconvenience but also of unpaid bills.
Nor is the situation expected to improve soon. Last fall, the Labor Department informed the states that contingency money that was supposed to be set aside to help in times of high unemployment would be cut by 25 percent, or $180 million to $200 million in the current fiscal year. As a result, state officials said they do not have the money to hire enough temporary workers to handle the crush of new applicants.
The length of the delays varies from state to state. Florida, for instance, is still making payments on time, even though the number of claims were 50 percent higher for the last three months of 1990 than in the same period in 1989. New Hampshire officials, on the other hand, say some of the unemployed have had to wait four to six weeks just to receive word that their applications for benefits have been approved.
"Here we are in what is officially been labeled a recession, and for the Government's No. 1 program to combat a recession, the funding necessary to administer this program isn't there," said Isaac Shapiro, a senior research analyst at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a research organization in Washington.
The program's troubles stem in part from the economic transition from recovery to recession. Labor Department figures show that nearly four million people claimed unemployment insurance benefits for the week ending Jan. 12, a 38 percent increase from a year ago. But the amount of money appropriated to run the jobless program was based on forecasts of unemployment made more than a year ago.
"We fund states for what we expect their workload to be and that is related to the unemployment rate," said Mary Ann Wyrsch, director of the Unemployment Insurance Service in the Labor Department. "The economy has changed dramatically in the last six to nine months from what the projections thought the economy would be."
 
Should Be Enough, Some Argue
 Yet state officials contend that despite erroneous projections, there should still be enough money to pay for adequate staff. They note that the unemployment offices' administrative costs are financed by a special tax, the Federal Unemployment Tax, that companies pay on the first $7,000 in wages earned by each employee.
The Labor Department estimates that $4.3 billion will be raised through that unemployment tax to run the jobless program in the current fiscal year. Of that, Congress has appropriated only $1.98 billion. The rest of the money has been used to lower the size of the Federal budget deficit.
Several states, including Ohio, New Hampshire, Colorado and Iowa are using state funds to make up for the Federal money. In essence, this means businesses in these states are being taxed twice to provide the same government service.
Representative Thomas J. Downey, the Suffolk Democrat who is acting chairman of the Ways and Means Subcommittee on Human Resources, which oversees the unemployment compensation system, has scheduled hearings for Wednesday on all aspects of the jobless program.
The National Governors Association is expected to pass a resolution early next week at its meeting in Washington calling on President Bush to declare a national employment emergency. Such a declaration would allow Congress to appropriate additional money to run the unemployment program without having to cut other domestic programs or raise taxes.
 
Detroit Area Is Hit Hard
 The unemployment office run by the Michigan Employment Security Commission in Sterling Heights, a community just north of Detroit, is among the worst hit. Seven automobile plants are situated in the region served by the Sterling Heights office, and all of them have laid off some workers or announced their intention to do so.
[General Dynamics Corporation said Friday that it would lay off 1,200 workers in the next seven months as a contract to build Army tanks is completed, Reuters reported. About 600 of the workers are in the Detroit area, 500 are in Lima, Ohio, and 100 in Scranton, Pa.]
When claims for unemployment benefits began to rise in November, Jeanette Sancricca, the director of the Sterling Heights office, did not have the money to hire the 10 temporary workers she needed to supplement her 22 permanent employees. By the time she got more money in January, her office was hopelessly behind.
Staff members at the office say it is not unusual for 300 or 400 people to be waiting in line for service. Each week, the office falls behind by another 1,000 applicants. Applications and other paperwork are stacked on the tops of cabinets and desks and in boxes on the floor.
Some changes that were supposed to cut down on the long lines have actually made the problem worse. Like many other states, Michigan allows the jobless to mail in their applications, and, if the applications are approved, checks are mailed back. But because of delays of six weeks in processing claims and mailing checks, people are left to wonder what has happened. They then call the office, tying up the switchboard. Unable to get through on the telephone, many people come to the office, creating long lines and defeating the whole purpose of mail-in claims.
 
Behind on Electric and Gas Bills
 Several of those waiting on line complained about the financial stresses caused by the delays in getting their checks. "I'm behind on my electric and gas bills," said Kim Killingbeck, 29 years old, who was laid off from a gardening job in November. He got one check in early December, but has gotten nothing since. His wife works part time and, he said, "If it wasn't for her, we'd be starving."
Mr. Peck said he had been unable to keep up with his mortgage payments and utility bills. "I've already gotten a note that 100 percent of my claim has been approved," he said. "But you can't take that to the bank."
Others complained about the inconvenience of having to wait all day in line. Pam Jackson, 29, looked dazed as she waited holding an infant seat in which her 4-month-old daughter slept soundly. Mrs. Jackson, who was dismissed after Christmas from her job as a home health care worker, said she breast-feeds her daughter and could not leave her with anyone.
"They could have some chairs out here and some numbers," she said, scanning the bare waiting area where the line snaked back and forth. "This is ridiculous."
After about 45 minutes, a security guard spotted Mrs. Jackson and showed her to a chair on one side of the room. He promised her that she would not lose her place in line.
 
'All This Paperwork'
 The backlog in the workload has also had its effect on the staff at the Sterling Hights office.
"I like to have a feeling of accomplishment, that I've worked all day and gotten something done," said Carrie Bobo, as she said at her desk sorting through a stack of gray-colored applications. "But I finish an application and I look up and there is all this paperwork. It makes you feel like you haven't done anything."
And the staff has to deal constantly with irate people. When Tim Peck sat down to talk with Nancy Lesperance, a claims examiner, he was angry. Ms. Lesperance listened to his complaints and then did a computer search of his records. It showed that two checks had been mailed to him, but he had moved and the office did not have his new address. He left with a promise that he would be getting some payments soon.
Santina Piazza, 49, who has been laid off several times from her job at a plant making furnace filters, is a veteran of long lines at the unemployment office. She never shows up without a book or crossword puzzles.
"I concentrate on that and try not to listen to other people complain about the wait and get caught up in that," she said. "And I don't look at the clock."

HEADLINE: Payments Are Missed By T.W.A.

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
Trans World Airlines said yesterday that it had defaulted on $75.5 million in payments on various notes. The airline said it wanted to conserve cash in the face of a severe drop in bookings that could last into the summer.
Carl C. Icahn, the chairman of the company, said the action was "imperative for the survival of T.W.A." 
 "It is now apparent that due to the war, summer vacation travel will be at its worst level in decades," Mr. Icahn said. "This further compounds the deleterious effects of high fuel costs, a falloff in leisure and business travel resulting from the recession, and fare wars that have affected the entire industry."
 
 Drop in Business Travel
 Many companies have told employees not to make overseas trips or to hold travel to a minimum. Since business travelers often pay full fares, the loss of these passengers has seriously hurt international airlines like T.W.A.
Mr. Icahn said the airline had $200 million in cash at the end of January, which included a payment of $110 million from American Airlines for the purchase of T.W.A.'s Chicago-to-London route.
T.W.A. said it would continue to pay its regular bills from suppliers and other obligations. Mark Buckstein, the airline's legal counsel, said, "T.W.A. has absolutely no intention of seeking the protection of the bankruptcy court under Chapter 11" of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.
Mr. Icahn gained control of T.W.A. in 1985 and took the company private in a leveraged buyout in October 1988.
 
 Rating at 'Junk Bond' Level
 After the announcement of the missed payments, Moody's Investors Service lowered its rating on T.W.A.'s senior debt to Caa, from B-2, putting it in the "junk bond" class.
Mr. Icahn said another worry was a warning this week by Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner. Mr. Skinner said an agreed-upon sale of all of T.W.A.'s London routes could be delayed by a deadlock between Britain and the United States. The two nations are in negotiations to alter their bilateral agreement so that American Airlines could take over T.W.A.'s right to land at Heathrow Airport near London, and United could take over routes there from Pan Am.
T.W.A. will get $445 million for its London routes if the sale goes through. In a filing with the Transportation Department, T.W.A. warned this week that if the deal was not approved it could be forced, like Pan Am, to seek bankruptcy protection.
Pan Am filed for Chapter 11 protection on Jan. 8. Its fate also hangs on the approval of a sale of London routes, in its case to United Airlines. Unless it receives a payment of $290 million for the sale, Pan Am will quickly run out of cash and be forced to liquidate.
 
 Shifts in Service
 T.W.A. has already made deep cuts in its flights to Europe and has shifted some resources to domestic service. It has increased flights between New York and Florida, for example.
It has put smaller Boeing 767's on some international routes to replace its larger Boeing 747's.
The airline has also laid off 2,500 workers, or 8 percent of its work force, in a move to cut costs.
Mr. Icahn said he would immediately contact creditors to find ways to change the terms of T.W.A.'s debt. "If we are to survive the losses we will almost certainly sustain during 1991 if the gulf war continues, we will need to use our cash reserves," he said.
He said the airline was witholding payment of $18 million in interest on 15 percent senior secured notes due in 1994; $48.4 million in principal and $3.3 million in interest on senior secured trust notes due in 1991, and $5.8 million in interest on senior secured trust notes due in 1996.
Raymond E. Neidl, an airline analyst for Dillon, Read & Company, said Mr. Icahn had a good chance of renegotiating the debt.
 
 'Time to Work Something Out'
 "He'll be negotiating with a small number of people," Mr. Neidl said. "There will be time to work something out." The analyst said T.W.A. had grace periods of about 30 days on some payments.
He said that if the negotiations failed, the holders of the notes could push the airline to seek bankruptcy protection. That might not be good for the noteholders, he said, since the collateral for some notes are older aircraft that would be unlikely to bring good prices on the market. Therefore, even if the creditors gain possession of the collateral through a bankruptcy proceeding, they may get only part of their money back.
That may make the creditors somewhat willing to change the terms of their notes by accepting equity in lieu of payments or putting off payments to see if the airline can ride out its problems.
"This is a prudent move to preserve capital," Mr. Neidl added. "They don't know what will happen to travel in the North Atlantic. If you're looking down the road, it's the best move to make."

HEADLINE: American and Pilots Brace for Strike

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, Feb. 1

 BODY:
Pilots at American Airlines started passing the hat a year ago to build a strike fund. The dollar count has swelled into the millions and, with contract talks bogged down, cockpit crews at the nation's largest airline are bracing for a walkout as early as March.
"Nobody wants it for personal reasons and financial reasons," said Steve Roach, a co-pilot based in San Francisco. "But all the past promises from management have been broken. The company is accusing us of everything except causing holes in the ozone layer, and we're just fed up." 
 This high-level feud over money, power and pride has pitted the aggressive management of Robert L. Crandall, American's chairman and chief executive, against a pilots' union whose ranks have surged with the airline's growth but whose pay and benefit levels lag behind some rivals.
Directors of the Allied Pilots Association, the in-house union for the company's 8,900 pilots, rejected a third contract offer late Wednesday, this time after a Federal mediator supervised bargaining in Washington that began Jan. 7.
American executives concede that just the threat of a strike will cost bookings, but the airline is banking on customer loyalty inspired by the frequent-flier discounts it pioneered. Some travel agents have said that if a strike deadline drew near, they would back up American reservations by booking a second seat on another carrier.
 
Two-Level Pay Scale
 The pilots are taking aim at another American innovation: the pay system that gives lower wages for the same work to pilots with fewer years at the airline. This "two-tier" wage scale played an important part in American's growth and its success against upstart low-fare rivals like People Express. One measure of the company's success was its adding 5,000 pilots since 1983; it also more than doubled the number of highly paid captains, to more than 3,400.
The lower pay scale applies to two-thirds of American's pilots and it has inflamed many of them. "The system is grossly unfair," said Wally Pitts, a first officer on American's international flights who is in the lower-paid group. "We feel that as an industry leader in profits and executive compensation, that all of the employees at American should directly benefit in a like manner, and therefore be compensated at the top of the industry," said Mr. Pitts, 33 years old, who was hired six years ago.
In addition to wanting higher pay, union members oppose the airline's demand that pilots begin paying an average of about $1,000 a year as their share of medical insurance costs. Most other company employees make such payments.
More than a year of talks in Fort Worth, where American is based, collapsed at the end of December with harsh accusations from both sides. Before the talks broke down, a period of abnormally high pilot absences had snarled American's schedules and disrupted 60,000 passengers during the Christmas holiday.
Within days, American, a unit of the AMR Corporation, said it would eliminate 250 of its 2,300 daily flights, including the intensely competitive Los Angeles-San Francisco route. The airline said it could not risk another episode like the December "sick-out," but union members said the pilots were being made scapegoats for cuts that American was forced into because of overly aggressive expansion. The route cuts became completely effective today.
 
More Talks Scheduled
 The Federal negotiators from the National Mediation Board decided Thursday to resume the bargaining in Washington on Monday. If the renewed talks break off, the board declares an impasse and both sides reject binding arbitration, a 30-day cooling off period would begin, and American's pilots could be on strike sometime in March.
In the event of a strike, the airline's strategy is to hire replacements. American has hired and trained 700 to 900 pilots a year since 1983 and company officials say any new pilots could be flying within five weeks of the day they are hired.
"There are plenty of pilot candidates in the marketplace who would love to fly for American Airlines," said Robert W. Baker, American's executive vice president for operations. "For every pilot we hire, there are 16 applications. When you consider the Eastern pilots who suddenly find themselves on the park bench, that puts another 3,000 pilots into the pool of potential candidates." Eastern Airlines Inc., in bankruptcy and out of cash, stopped flying on Jan. 18.
While American would suffer from a strike, its survival would not be threatened. The expansion that Mr. Crandall set in motion in 1983, at an estimated cost of $20 billion through 1995, has catapulted American ahead of all of its major competitors in passengers and, until last year's fuel cost increases, in profits.
In addition, People Express and other low-cost competitors have failed, merged or changed strategies, and many major carriers like Continental Airlines, Pan American World Airways and Trans World Airlines are in financial trouble.
 
Effects of Recession and War
 Still, the pilots say circumstances are on their side. They say recession, slack winter travel and fears of terrorism brought on by the war in the Persian Gulf have combined to reduce airline passenger loads by 20 percent from a year ago. Moreover, American's operations have been strained since the Pentagon last year called up 400 of the 1,700 American pilots who are active in the military reserves.
The American pilots want the airline to match the industry-leading pay levels that Delta Airlines granted its pilots last summer. If that scale were approved, the salary for a captain who had flown 15 years on a mid-sized Super 80 class of aircraft would rise to $135,954 from $118,557.
The highest paid pilots, the captains of the wide-bodied jumbo jets, would make $176,130 after 12 years, as against their current $145,368 after 15 years. The pay of a flight officer, the junior crew member, on a Boeing 727-200, would rise to a range of $58,482 to $96,525, depending on experience, from the current $31,995 to $75,519.
American's management has been holding out for a pay package that would essentially match the scale pilots at Northwest Airlines accepted last year. That scale is next highest after Delta's.
But American also is offering a bonus formula that would be tied to the airline's profit. In good years, the base pay and bonus would exceed the pay of Delta's pilots, the company said. But some pilots oppose such profit sharing because the amount is unpredictable and vulnerable to manipulation.
Mr. Baker, the company vice president, said he still hoped for a solution. "In an industry in the midst of turmoil, American has made our pilots a very rich offer." he said. "We think we have done everything possible to avoid confrontation and are astounded that the A.P.A. is unwilling to reach a reasonable agreement."
Mr. Pitts of the union said: "There is not one pilot on the property of American Airlines that wants to see the airline fail. We are tied directly to American's success and we truly believe the contract we are seeking allows American an adequate rate of return."

HEADLINE: About New York;
He's in Arabia; She, in the Bronx, In Her Own Fight

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN

 BODY:
Carmen Valentin hasn't heard from her husband, Andy, since the war began. He is an Army private somewhere in Saudi Arabia.
If they could talk, she said, it would go like this: "He would just tell me, 'Listen, Carmen. Don't worry.' And then we would start talking, and then we would break out in tears." 
 Mrs. Valentin spoke in a room at North Central Bronx Hospital, where she is being treated for an intestinal infection. She looked tiny in a hospital gown. A tube connected a vein in her arm to a bottle.
Like many children of the South Bronx, Mrs. Valentin, who is 20 years old, has lived a long life in very few years. She suspects her illness resulted from too much time in too many unhealthy places.
She has been homeless and knows the grim, dangerous interiors of shelters and welfare hotels. She knows the reality of cold nights in the streets. Lately she has lived in someone else's three-room apartment in the Soundview housing project. Four adults live there doubled-up illegally with 12 children, including 17-month-old Andy Jr.
That Mrs. Valentin's experience is common makes it no less awful. Her father vanished early. Her mother died of AIDS. Her sister is in jail. The family grew up surrounded by drugs, garbage and gunfire.
The brightest spot of her life was meeting Andy. In a snapshot, he looks proud and crisp in his uniform.
His hope was that by joining the Army he could be something other than a security guard and work for something more than the minimum wage. His wife said that he had always wanted to be a policeman or a fireman and that he now gets that satisfaction from the service. "He's 100 percent dedicated."
But this young couple never got on their feet. They couldn't find affordable housing where they could live as an unmarried couple.
Then, on Aug. 27, 1989, Andy Jr. was born. Mrs. Valentin moved into a welfare hotel to at least have a roof over their head. The father, then unemployed, would some times sneak in to see them. In November of that year, Mr. Valentin joined up.
 Mrs. Valentin remembers telling him: "I told you to get a job. I didn't tell you to go away."
 The reply she remembers: "I want to get straightened out. I want more babies."
Mr. Valentin headed for Oklahoma, Texas and Korea -- his stops before the Arabian desert. The two were married last Feb. 20.
Mrs. Valentin is being helped by the Soundview Health Center, which provides medical care and social services to families in the southeast Bronx, particularly those living in the Soundview project. The center runs support groups for people anxious about family in the military, and a participant had told the center about Mrs. Valentin's plight.
The center has helped her with medical matters, as well as enrolling her in its computer-training course. The center is also trying to enroll her in Medicaid, but this is a problem because she lacks an address in her own name.
Pedro Espada Jr., Soundview's executive director, said the war hits poor people hardest. His argument is buttressed by the fact that the first two New Yorkers killed -- Manuel Rivera Jr. and Ismael Cotto, both Marines -- were from the South Bronx.
Meanwhile, loved ones at home endure the suffering they have always known, with fear and loneliness now thrown in. "There are thousands like Carmen," Mr. Espada said.
This is a story with no easy moral. But Sandra Love, who works for Soundview, said Mrs. Valentin should be commended for two achievements. One is that she has stayed off drugs in a drug-plagued world. The other is that she has successfully fought to keep her child.
But both these victories have had their hollow side. Mrs. Valentin said that if she took drugs, addicts would take her in; if she sold them, she would have money. And if she gave up her baby to her mother-in-law, who insists she could take better care of him, Mrs. Valentin admits the child might benefit.
"I live in a place that's disgusting," she said. "I can't lie. My baby don't belong there. I know that."
So she remains poised on a tight rope. If she were again homeless -- instead of in an inadequate home -- she would be eligible for housing and other assistance. But her beloved child wouldn't have a roof over his head.
Too, there is the $500 that her husband sends her each month. The amount is enough to keep her off welfare, Soundview social workers say. And since Mrs. Valentin has no permanent address, her husband mails the money to his mother. His mother parcels it out in bits that Mrs. Valentin considers minuscule.
Mrs. Valentin has a dream. A nice apartment on an Army base after the war. And after her husband re-enlists.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Carmen Valentin (The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Daily News and Unions Begin Final Phase of Talks

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN

 BODY:
Amid signs of movement and rising urgency, The Daily News and its striking unions have begun what both sides regard as a crucial final phase of negotiations that would either end the three-month walkout or force the closing of the 70-year-old newspaper.
The News, which announced two weeks ago that it intended to shut down in 60 days if it was unable to reach a settlement or sell the paper, and its nine striking unions have stepped up the pace of talks, scheduling a series of negotiating sessions in recent days and over the coming week. 
 "We're getting to the end -- everything we do now is crucial," said George E. McDonald, head of the Allied Printing Trades Council, the unions' umbrella group.
"The situation is urgent," said James Hoge, the publisher of The News. "We must either reach settlements or conclude a sale, which would have to be based on settlements -- or shut down."
Yesterday, negotiators for The News and the drivers' union -- which began the strike 100 days ago and is widely regarded as crucial to any settlement -- met for nearly three hours at the Manhattan offices of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service.
No breakthrough was reported, but a person close to the talks said The News had offered a new proposal that included a reduction in the number of drivers from the pre-strike level of 700, and the union, rather than rejecting it outright, said it would study the plan over the weekend.
Mr. Hoge declined to comment on the talks, as did Jack Sweeney, the Federal mediator. Michael J. Alvino, the president of the drivers' union, formally known as the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers of New York and Vicinity, and Robert Ballow, a lawyer who leads The News's negotiating team, could not be reached for comment.
The Newspaper Guild, which represents 750 editorial and commercial employees, also was preparing a counterproposal to a News offer made this week, and its leaders said they would submit their plan to Daily News negotiators at a meeting next Tuesday.
There were other signs of movement as well. Mr. Hoge said in a brief interview that both sides, in an effort to focus on important economic issues, had agreed to set aside questions of what would happen to the 800 replacement workers hired during the strike. Early in the strike, the issue of the "permanent replacements" appeared to be an insurmountable primary question; in recent days, however, both sides have backed off, without abandoning their positions.
 
Talks Are Scheduled
 And some union leaders said The News had agreed to use the old contracts as a framework for negotiations and had agreed to eliminate for the time being most non-critical issues, like dues check-offs, bulletin boards, jurisdictional questions and other minor matters. Mr. Hoge noted that at least one negotiating session between The News and each of the striking unions had been scheduled before next Friday under the auspices of the Federal mediators, and that follow-up talks were also being sought.
The Allied Printing Trades Council scheduled a meeting for next Tuesday to report on the talks and to coordinate strategy. Few details have emerged publicly from the talks, but Mr. McDonald has said that The News this week offered the mailers' a 36-page proposal and that the mailers had countered with a four-point plan that included a wage freeze and a cut of 25 workers from a 100-member mailroom staff. Mailers insert advertising supplements into the paper.

The Economy
The Fed moved with unusual force to stimulate the economy by sharply reducing the interest rates it controls, acting on stark new evidence of economic weakness. Large banks responded immediately by reducing their prime rate. [Page 1.]
 A heavy wave of job losses in January and an unusually large contraction in the length of the average workweek was reported by the Government. The report was a sharp setback to hopes that the sliding econ omy had begun to stabilize. The unemployment rate rose only slightly, to 6.2 percent, but analysts said this understated the de terioration of the economy last month. [29.]
 Unemployment in New York State rose to 6.5 percent. In New Jersey, it jumped to 6.4 percent. [33.]
The manufacturing decline deepened in January, with the purchasing managers' index at its lowest level in nine years. [33.]
Construction spending slid for a ninth straight month in December, falling 0.5 percent, the Government said. [33.]
Corporations flooded the market with new debt issues in response to the rally in the credit markets. [33.]

HEADLINE: South Africa Moves to Scrap Apartheid

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAPE TOWN, Feb. 1

 BODY:
President F. W. de Klerk moved today to smash the legal bedrock of apartheid by announcing that he would scrap the remaining laws on which South Africa's ideology of racial discrimination has long rested.
In a speech opening the 1991 session of Parliament, Mr. de Klerk said legislation would soon be introduced to repeal the Land Acts of 1913 and 1936, which reserved most of the country's land for the white minority, the Group Areas Act of 1966, and the Black Communities Act of 1984, which entrenched the separate status of black townships.
In appealing for the revocation of racial laws, now considered to be virtually certain, Mr. de Klerk went beyond what had been expected by also mentioning the Population Registration Act, which classifies all South Africans into four racial groups: blacks, whites, people of mixed race and Asians. Reversing an earlier Government position, he said that the law, entrenched in the nation's Constitution, would, like the others, be soon eliminated.
 
Transitional Steps Proposed
 He said this could be done through the enactment of what he described as "temporary, transitional measures" needed to maintain the present Constitution until a new one can be negotiated and drafted.
"Should Parliament adopt the Government's proposals," Mr. de Klerk said, "the South African statute book will be devoid, within months, of the remnants of racially discriminatory legislation which have become known as the cornerstones of apartheid." [Excerpts from the speech, page 7.]
In Washington, the State Department welcomed the proposals as "dramatic and far-reaching," but noted that all political prisoners had yet to be released, as required under United States laws governing the lifting of sanctions.
 
Further Momentum
 The speech by Mr. de Klerk today lent further momentum to a process that the President began at the opening of Parliament last year, when the African National Congress and other anti-apartheid organizations were legalized and Mr. de Klerk announced his Government's intention to release the congress's leader, Nelson Mandela. Mr. Mandela walked out of a prison farm nine days later.
"In the short span of a single year," Mr. de Klerk said today, "substantial progress was made. The Government is determined to build on the foundations laid purposefully, efficiently and with due speed.
"South Africa cannot allow or permit the dynamic process of reform to slow down," he told Parliament.
As he spoke, the African National Congress, conducted mass marches in Cape Town, Johannesburg, Pretoria and some other cities to put pressure on the Government in advance of looming but as yet undefined Constitutinal talks. The anti-apartheid group also sought to underscore the reality that blacks remain excluded from Parliament and from institutional political life.
In Cape Town, Walter Sisulu, a senior leader of the congress, addressed a crowd of perhaps 15,000 people who had gathered outside City Hall.
 
Insists on Right to Vote
 "We still do not have the vote, and this is what our people want today," Mr. Sisulu said. He added that the scrapping of the apartheid laws must be followed by "measures to retrieve the damage they have done."
Mr. de Klerk reiterated his opposition to an elected constituent assembly to draft a new constitution and an interim government, something that the African National Congress has demanded.
"The idea that the present, legally constituted Government should relinquish its powers and simply hand over its responsibilities to some or other temporary regime cannot be considered in a sovereign, independent state," Mr. de Klerk said.
But he suggested that the Government might share some of its authority with the congress and with other groups outside the parliamentary process, once the transition to nonracial democracy was under way.
"Consideration may be given to certain transitional arrangements on the various legislative and executive levels to give the leaders of the negotiating parties a voice in the formulation of important policy decisions," Mr. de Klerk said.
 
Entrenched Inequality
 While the elimination of the remaining racial laws will likely signal the demise of apartheid as a legal system, the disparities, inequality and hostility that have divided black and white South Africans under the apartheid system are unlikely to be erased as categorically.
Though public facilities like libraries and community swimming pools were legally integrated in October, many of these remain unused by blacks. Similar recent laws enabling some formerly white schools to accept black pupils when more than 72 per cent of the parents approved have so far to led the integration of 205 schools, a small number nationwide, with generally few black children admitted at each school.
Once the laws cited today are repealed, a black South African will legally be able to live in a white neighborhood and buy land previously set aside for whites. In practice, though, few blacks can afford it. The Government has not said that it will return land confiscated from dispossessed blacks, with little or no compensation, in the last four decades.
Some lingering resistance to change was evident in Parliament, where legislators of the right-wing Conservative Party, the official opposition, angrily walked out during Mr. de Klerk's hourlong speech. The Conservative Party leader, Andries P. Treurnicht, said later that Mr. de Klerk's plans to scrap the apartheid laws struck at the roots of white community life.
"It is surprising that South Africa now has the only leader in the Western world who is negotiating himself, his party and his people out of power," Mr. Treurnicht said.
 
White Liberals Gratified
 However, Zach de Beer, the leader of the liberal Democratic Party, observed that President de Klerk had promised to repeal the Group Areas and Land Acts. But, Dr. de Beer said, "most of us did not expect that the Population Registration Act would go this year, and we're pleased."
The Government had said that the Population Registration Act would have to remain in force until a new constitution extending political rights to the black majority was adopted.
But President de Klerk said today that "following investigation, it would, in fact, appear possible to repeal this act, provided that this is accompanied by the adoption of temporary transitional measures toward the acceptance of a new constitution."
The total elimination of existing racial distinctions would throw into question the legitimacy of Parliament, which now has separate chambers for white, mixed-race and Asian legislators, though none for blacks. Mr. de Klerk was proposing, among other things, keeping Parliament, and by extension his Government, intact through temporary legal provisions in place of the Population Registration Act.
Gerrit N. Viljoen, the Minister for Constitutional Development, told foreign journalists that the racial classification of all new babies or immigrants would end the day the Population Registration Act was repealed. He suggested that the racial classification of other South Africans, while still on the registration books, would quickly fall into disuse.
The President is not expected to have difficulty enacting his proposed reforms because his National Party and the liberal Democratic Party control close to three-quarters of the seats in the white House of Assembly. The leaders of the Democratic Party have consistently sought discussions with the nation's black majority, and in recent years, Mr. de Klerk has convinced many in his own party that such dialogue is inevitable.
 
End of Emergency Rule
 Since he committed himself and his Government to fundamental change, Mr. de Klerk has repealed the Separate Amenities Act, which let municipalities reserve public services for whites, has opened hospitals to all races, among other changes, and has ended a national state of rule by emergency decree, which restricted political activity.
Foreign Minister Roelof F. Botha said that the measures announced today were not aimed at eliminating the economic and other sanctions imposed by Western nations, including the United States.
"What is happening today is confirming President de Klerk's clear statement that the process toward the dismantling of apartheid and fundamental change in South Africa is irreversible," Mr. Botha said.
 
Tutu Now Doubts Sanctions
 The Anglican Archbishop, Desmond M. Tutu, who attended the African National Congress march, told reporters there that President de Klerk's speech made it hard to dispute his seriousness about dismantling apartheid.
"We are getting very near to where it will be irreversible," said Archbishop Tutu, a prominent proponent of economic sanctions. "It is going to be very difficult for us to continue to ask for sanctions."
The Comprehensive Anti-Apartheid Act enacted by the United States Congress in 1986 provided that sanctions would end once the Pretoria Government released Nelson Mandela and other political prisoners, repealed rule by decree, legalized banned political parties and unfettered political activity, repealed the Group Areas and Population Registration Acts, and agreed to enter into good-faith negotiations with representatives of the black majority.
It further permits the President to suspend or modify sanctions once three of the last four conditions were achieved.
The President told Parliament that the constitutional reform he envisionedd had to be accompanied by economic growth to give blacks real equality. "Until the pressing problems of poverty and unemployment are alleviated," he said, "constitutional models will be of little avail to us."

 	 	 		--------------------	 		 	 	
 
U.S. Praise and Pressure
 WASHINGTON (AP) -- The State Department spokeswoman, Margaret D. Tutwiler today called President de Klerk's proposals "dramatic and far-reaching." But she said that South Africa has yet to release all political prisoners or people detained without trial.
Current American sanctions ban new investment in South Africa; the import of South African arms, iron, steel, gold coins and farm products, and also bar South African Airways flights. They also restrict banking activities. 

 	 	 		--------------------	 		 	 	
 
Europeans Encouraged
 BRUSSELS, Feb. 1 (AP) -- The European Community's executive body said today that Mr. de Klerk's plans to repeal South Africa's major apartheid laws could lead to a softening of sanctions against the country.
"The enforcement of these initiatives will allow the community" to discuss softening the economic sanctions imposed in 1986, said the community's External Relations Commissioner, Frans Andriessen.

Chart: "Dismantling Apartheid"
 
1985: Interracial marriages are legalized in South Africa. Some movie theaters are opened to all.
 
1986: Pass laws are abolished, permitting blacks to move to cities. Residents of so-called tribal homelands become entitled to South African citizenship.
 
1988: All races vote in separate polls for representatives of local governments.
 
February 1990: President F. W. de Klerk removes bans on African National Congress and other long-outlawed politcal parties. He frees Nelson Mandela and other politcal leaders struggling against white rule.
 
May 1990: Hospitals are technically opened to all races.
 
October 1990: Separate Amenities Act is repealed, ending legal basis of segregation in public places like community swimming pools and libraries.
 
January 1991: Ten percent of formerly all-white state elementary schools open their classrooms to some black pupils.
 
February 1991: De Klerk calls for repeal of Group Areas Act, Land Act and Population Registration Act.

HEADLINE: Arts Officials Voice Shock at Cuomo Cuts

BYLINE: By GRACE GLUECK

 BODY:
"We are reeling and on the ropes," Senator Roy M. Goodman said yesterday. Mr. Goodman, a Republican State Senator from Manhattan and chairman of the Senate Special Committee on the Arts and Cultural Affairs, was referring to Gov. Mario Cuomo's proposal for a cut of 56 percent in the budget for the New York State Council on the Arts.
For arts officials on the receiving end, the real news was not so much the cut itself as the size of it. 
 "We all knew there'd be cuts, but this is an outrage," said Nathan Leventhal, president of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts.
Richard Oldenburg, director of the Museum of Modern Art, said, "It seems extremely disproportionate, a sign of the low priority Governor Cuomo puts on arts and cultural programs in general."
Calling the proposed cut "a staggering inequity," Mr. Goodman said: "It's from 3 to 6 times the cuts in such areas as school aid, parks and recreation and the State University of New York. It means that from the Governor's standpoint, the arts are a disposable commodity."
In his package of spending cuts for the fiscal year 1991-92, the largest in the state's history, the Governor recommended that the arts council's overall budget be reduced by nearly $25 million from its present level of $46.7 million, bringing it to $21.9 million.
 
'A Long Leap Backward'
 Senator Goodman noted that the Governor's budget proposals would cut aid to schools by 10 percent, to parks and recreation by 19.5 percent, and to the State University by 20 percent.
"The Governor's budget takes us a long leap backward to the dark ages of arts funding in the state," he said. "The ravages of inflation have been bad enough at existing levels, but the proposed budget causes the arts to suffer acutely in terms of real purchasing power."
The New York State Council on the Arts supports a wide variety of cultural institutions and programs in the state, from big-budget organizations like the Metropolitan Museum of Art to the DeWitt Historical Society of Ithaca.
For arts organizations in New York City, the cuts would come on top of severe reductions in cultural financing by the city, as well as reduced contributions to individual organizations from the National Endowment for the Arts. For fiscal 1991, the New York City Department of Cultural Affairs' budget of $92.4 million was cut by $7.9 million and a further cut of $13.1 million is proposed for 1992.
 
Less Aid for Programs
 Because the National Endowment for the Arts was recently required by Congress to increase basic grants to states to 30 percent of its program budget of $125 million, it has had to make compensating cuts in the grants it makes to specific programs. It will thus have to lower by about $12 million the amount awarded cultural organizations and individuals who apply directly. In fiscal 1993, another mandated increase will provide the states with an additional 5 percent, amounting to another cut of $6 million in the program budget.
Asked whether the Governor's cuts could have been proposed in anticipation of more money from the National Endowment, an endowment spokesman said that even under the new mandate the total that would go to the New York State Council on the Arts in fiscal 1991-92 was projected at $727,000, only a small fraction of Mr. Cuomo's suggested cuts.
 "There's going to be less money from the Feds, and we're taking enormous cuts from the city; in the next fiscal year they're proposing $455,000," said Karen Brooks Hopkins, executive vice president for planning and development at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, which has an annual operating budget of about $12.5 million.
"As for the New York State Council," she continued, "this year we received $316,000; so if you halve that, we're losing another $150,000 plus. It's devastating for us because there's no way to cover it. We've cut as deeply as we can, but it's definitely a crisis for us."
If the larger organizations are affected by the proposed cuts, smaller ones in the state are feeling overwhelmed.
"For us, it's a double whammy," said Joseph Flaherty, director of Writers and Books in Rochester, which operates programs in 20th-century literature at schools, hospitals and senior citizens' centers.
He said that 25 percent of the organization's $350,000 budget had been provided by the New York State Council on the Arts. "This year we took a cut of 7 percent; we're also getting cuts on the Federal and county levels," Mr. Flaherty said. "About half of our budget is earned income from programs we run, but with cuts like this we have to dismiss program people. So not only do we lose grant income, but the earned income from programs. We can't run them without core funding for administrative costs."
 
Primacy Is Threatened

 For many in the arts community, the unkindest cut was to New York's primacy in the arts. Some officials cited a 1983 survey by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey that put the economic impact of the arts in the New York metropolitan region at $5.6 billion, including income generated from restaurant meals, transportation, hotel registration, sales taxes and so forth.
"That makes it even more difficult for arts organizations to understand why the cut is so drastic," said Tamara Watson of the Alliance of New York State Arts Councils, an umbrella organization for local arts councils. "It just doesn't make good fiscal sense."
Mr. Oldenburg of the Museum of Modern Art added: "It sends a very harmful signal nationally because New York has been the clear leader, in size of its arts budget, the scope of its programs, and the superb job it's done of encouraging the arts. This is a time when arts support on all levels, Federal, state and city, is under attack, and Governor Cuomo is in effect telling the country that the leading state thinks the arts are unimportant."
Officials at the New York State Council on the Arts would not comment, but issued a statement saying that the council would re-examine ways to continue providing "the artistic leadership that has made New York State the cultural center of the country."
The Governor's budget will go to the Legislature on Tuesday. "There'll be a lot of fighting," said Senator Goodman. "The Governor has been stopped before and we'll make every effort to do that this year. It may look like an anthill to him, but he's sitting on a volcano."
Senator Goodman added that he would call an emergency meeting of cultural leaders next Friday at 2 P.M. in Avery Fisher Hall in Lincoln Center.

HEADLINE: Hollywood Abuzz Over Cost Memo

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 1

 BODY:
An internal memorandum written by the chairman of Walt Disney Studios, Hollywood's most successful film studio, has quickly gained a wider readership here than any movie script, and set off a debate about the movie industry's inability to keep expenses under control.
In the 28-page document, originally issued to top executives at Disney, the studio head, Jeffrey Katzenberg, criticizes his own company and its rivals for succumbing to "a tidal wave of runaway costs and mindless competition" for actors and scripts. Since it was distributed to his colleagues on Jan. 11, the memorandum has been reprinted on fax machines at studios, agencies and production companies all over Hollywood, and by Jan. 15 parts of it had made their way into the trade journal Variety. 
 "If we remain on our current course, there will be the certainty of calamitous failure," Mr. Katzenberg wrote, warning that "fear and uncertainty in the real world" are likely to have a major impact on the movie industry in the months to come. "Costs have escalated; profitability has slipped, and our level of risk has compounded," he continued. "The time has come to get back to our roots."
Mr. Katzenberg suggested that in making "Dick Tracy," starring Warren Beatty and a host of other major stars, Disney itself had been guilty of the very practices he was criticizing. That movie, which grossed just over $100 million in the United States but cost nearly the same amount to film, market and promote, "made demands on our time, talent and treasury that, upon reflection, may not have been worth it."
 
Disappointment Expressed
 Officially, distribution of Mr. Katzenberg's analysis was to have been limited to about a dozen top executives at the Walt Disney Company. In a statement issued Wednesday, Mr. Katzenberg said he was "disappointed that an internal document that is an assessment of Disney's business, and only Disney's business, has found its way out into the Hollywood community."
Most studio executives, agents and producers, however, are convinced that Mr. Katzenberg intended from the start that the memorandum be a very public statement of Disney's principles and future direction. "He wants Hollywood and Wall Street to know that Disney learned a lesson from 'Dick Tracy' and won't make the same mistake again," said one producer, who spoke on condition he not be identified. "It's a brilliant analysis, but to pretend it was intended only for internal circulation is disingenuous, to put it mildly."
Though Hollywood executives have been talking in recent days of little else but the ideas raised in Mr. Katzenberg's memorandum, few have been willing to comment publicly on the document. The Disney Studios chairman singled out recent films made by its rivals Paramount, Warner Brothers, Universal and Carolco as examples of practices that are to be avoided.
Mr. Katzenberg was particularly critical of studios that, rather than developing scripts themselves, pay millions of dollars to acquire a screenplay or to hire a well-known actor or director, saying those practices are "a blatant admission of creative bankruptcy." Many movie executives believe his remarks were intended mostly for Jon Peters and Peter Guber, who have spent heavily to acquire the film properties that interest them since they were hired two years ago by the Sony Corporation to run Columbia Pictures.
 
Low-Budget Pictures
 "I didn't read anything that way," Frank Price, the chairman of Columbia Pictures, said at a news conference today when asked if he thought Mr. Katzenberg's analysis was directed at Columbia. "From my fairly casual reading of it, I saw only stuff that one should be in favor of," Mr. Price also said. "Make low-budget pictures and get big hits."
Mr. Katzenberg's other major target is the agencies that represent those who act in, write and direct the films Disney and other studios distribute. Mr. Katzenberg said that while Disney once "had a fairly strict and pretty successful strategy, which we referred to as our singles and doubles philosophy," most studios are now increasingly gripped by "home run thinking."
"Not surprisingly, this box-office mania is fostering a frenzy among actors, writers, directors and their agents," he continued. "If a leading star who received $6 million for his last film reads that another star is getting $10 million for a picture, he immediately calls his agent insisting on nothing less than $12 million for his next movie."
Hollywood's leading agent and the presumed target of those and other remarks, Michael Ovitz of the Creative Artists Agency, declined to comment on the memorandum. But other talent brokers reacted with a combination of irritation and amusement to Mr. Katzenberg's remarks.
 
'Just Say No'
 "It's not exactly a secret that he has no love for us, but I think he's gone out of his way to try to shift the blame away from the studios," one agent said. "Nobody is holding a gun to the head of any studio, forcing them to make this movie with that star. All they have to do is just say no."
With Mr. Katzenberg's memorandum, Disney becomes the third major Hollywood studio in recent months to make known its desire to move away from what the document calls "the dictates of the blockbuster mentality." Both Paramount, which has been Disney's principal rival over the last five years, and Warner Brothers, attempting to recover from a series of big-budget, big-name flops, had already let it be known that they intended to change course.
"We are putting fewer movie and TV projects into development in order to make sure that those we do develop are properly managed and nurtured," Frank Mancuso, the chairman of Paramount Pictures, said in a speech to the National Association of Television Programming Executives on Jan. 15. "To do this means not only more creative control but increasing economic efficiency as well. How much we invest is secondary to how productively we invest."
As part of its efforts to increase productivity and cut back on expenses, Paramount late last year announced the end of a longstanding association with the producers Don Simpson and Jerry Bruckheimer, regarded in Hollywood as the personification of the big-spending movie makers thanks to films like "Top Gun" and "Days of Thunder." Last month the pair resurfaced at Disney, leading to amused comment at rival studios that Disney was talking one way and acting another.
 
An Apparent Contradiction
 Mr. Katzenberg, who did not respond today to telephone calls seeking comment on his memorandum, addressed that apparent contradiction in the document. He argued that the producers' new deal at Disney is in line with Hollywood's new economic realities and will discourage any excesses on their part.
"I know that 'conventional wisdom' holds that they can only make giant big-budget movies," but "as usual, the conventional wisdom is wrong," he wrote. The deal with Mr. Simpson and Mr. Bruckheimer "will be structured so that they will be extremely well rewarded in success," he added. "But they will also be at substantial risk, along with us, in failure."

HEADLINE: Critic's Notebook;
Not Letting TV Do Its Best Job in the War

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN

 BODY:
"Television is inherently a medium of simplicity," observed David Gergen, the White House aide turned journalist, at a forum put on this week by the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism. Much of the day was given to criticism of television coverage of the war in the Persian Gulf from such other journalists and sometime journalists as the Rev. Jesse Jackson and Hodding Carter 3d. There was a lot of politics in the air, but Mr. Gergen's simple observation about simplicity seemed to strike most directly at the network news departments' current problems.
Television is at its most effective when presenting pictures that tell a story without many or any words. One does not look to the nightly news for complexity. It did not prepare viewers for the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait and is not likely to prepare them for the political and economic consequences of the American response. 
 What it can do, if permitted, is show, virtually while it happens, what war brings, especially on the receiving end. That is not the whole story; it may in fact be misleading; it is not likely to raise morale. But without that, no comprehension of any war can be complete. The pictures of damage that Iraqi censors have so far approved for export are too vague, and too plainly intended to make a point, to have much punch.
Only this week, for the first time, was the nation given glimpses of recognizable battle as land war broke out in the Saudi Arabian town of Khafji. There were tanks and helicopters on the move, marines under fire, a tall building being battered in the distance, and later, the remains of the recaptured town and the corpse of an Iraqi soldier, the first corpse of the television war. These pictures, although still somewhat remote, had the effect of focusing attention on how little actual warfare has been shown so far. (There were No pictures of the marines who were killed in the area.)
Without strong images, television reporting is either a return to radio as it was that first gripping but unrepeatable night or a display of stock photographs and talking heads, which have largely filled the hours since. One watches, absorbed by the details yet aware that television is not doing what only television can do. You want more yet fear to see too much.
There have been memorable pictures, such as the captured American pilots delivering their set pieces for Iraqi television and the perspective through the target sights of planes and missiles, but mostly the tube has provided official briefings, mild, sometimes boosterish interviews with troops in the field and experts galore. The latest Pentagon-supplied photographs of bridges being hit have a video-game fascination, but as the fellow says, if you've seen one . . .
It's all so far away, and expectations have been aroused by war movies: if a bomb is dropped, you get to see the bridge collapse.
Journalists are being kept from the action by a combination of the nature of the war and the nature of censors on both sides. As James Webb, a former Secretary of the Navy and Assistant Secretary of Defense noted at the Columbia Journalism School forum, the difficulty of covering the Gulf War is "absolutely ideal from the military's point of view."
To judge by a recent poll under the direction of Princeton Survey Associates, most people are satisfied with the news they are getting and think that military censorship is a "good idea." Complaints come, unsurprisingly, from those being censored. About 10 days before Bob Simon, the CBS correspondent, disappeared with his crew near the Saudi-Kuwaiti border, he said, "I suspect that the Pentagon, the Administration, would like war coverage to come back with F-15's taking off and landing, with aircraft carriers plowing the seas, with the kinds of footage that promote the kind of war which the Pentagon, which the Administration, would want to see on American television screens." The networks have complained about restrictions on coverage, but to no effect.
Opponents of the war, too, want up-close reporting, in the belief that only scenes of death and destruction can stir misgivings among the majority that supports the war. Today's military commanders, old enough to have endured Vietnam, when correspondents in the field became Washington's adversaries, evidently share that belief and are determined to keep reporters at a distance. The Pentagon won ground superiority over the press before it achieved air superiority over the Iraqis. The invasions of Panama and Grenada, from which journalists were effectively barred, were training grounds for the information officers of this war.
All those easily satirized retired generals and admirals and all those think tankists who have turned up (Mr. Carter called them "a dung heap of experts") have their uses. They have helped instruct the nation in the tools and tactics of modern war. But in relying so heavily on a technical approach and a trade jargon ("assets" for weapons is neat; "collateral damage" for civilian casualties is brilliant), the networks have found themselves playing the game by the Pentagon's specifications. War as a slide presentation.
 Those who attacked television coverage in Vietnam sometimes also lamented that the United States was forced to fight with at least one hand behind its back. In the Persian Gulf, it is the journalists who have their hands tied. Despite the best efforts of experienced reporters, network news has so far been giving the nation a controlled war, from afar and through the sights of the military. If the land encounters glimpsed this week are a signal of things to come, the pictures will grow grittier and bloodier, and many people around the world may find themselves thinking back wistfully to the days when watching the war on television was easier to take.

HEADLINE: Center for Auto Safety's Point Man

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1

 BODY:
For Clarence M. Ditlow, the seeds of activism were sown on field trips to Pennsylvania factories when he was studying chemical engineering at Lehigh University.
He was horrified, he now remembers, as he watched workers at a steel plant scatter when molten wire cable spiraled out of control, and he shuddered as employees at a sulfuric acid plant raced to the parking lot to move cars threatened by a shift in the wind. "I was struck by the working conditions," he said, "and I was struck by the environmental conditions." 
 For the last 15 years, Mr. Ditlow, son of a Chevrolet service manager in Harrisburg, Pa., has been director of the Center for Auto Safety, the consumer advocacy group founded by Ralph Nader and Consumers Union. Now 47 years old, soft-spoken and buttoned-down, he would hardly seem out of place in the General Motors executive suite. But he has become one of the automobile industry's most formidable and visible antagonists.
 
Victory for Air Bags
 These days he is savoring victories in several long campaigns, particularly the one that will put air bags in at least 35 percent of the new cars sold this year. By 1995, he estimates, air bags for both driver and front-seat passenger will be as common as automatic transmissions.
"There's no way but for our hard-core advocacy of air bags, including all the litigation, that we would have gotten them," he said.
Mr. Ditlow's center seeks to promote not just car safety but all aspects of automotive transportation, including highway design and fuel economy. "We're pragmatists," he said in an interview in his small, plant-filled office just off Connecticut Avenue. "The car is here, so why not not make it more efficient, safer, less polluting and more reliable? Our goal really is to make the car more socially acceptable."
With an annual budget of $800,000 and a staff of about 20, including part-timers and interns, Mr. Ditlow is gearing up for new battles. The agenda for the 1990's includes these goals:
*Extending Federal safety regulations for cars to pickup trucks, minivans and utility vehicles.
*Requiring car makers to notify all customers when they extend warranties because of defects, rather than extending them privately, on a case-by-case basis.
*Preventing the trucking industry from adding a third trailer to tractor-trailer rigs, increasing the longest truck to 120 feet. The center maintains that the third trailer is hard to control, posing a safety hazard.
 
'I Like Being the Underdog'
 Fighting these battles will mean fighting some well-financed lobbies in Washington. That does not seem to bother Mr. Ditlow. "I like being the underdog," he said. "I like challenges. You don't last long in the public-interest community unless you really like what you're doing. I can't wait to get in here every morning."
The motivation is not money, it would seem. Mr. Ditlow, who has never married, earns $41,000 a year. But as classmates headed off to climb various corporate ladders, he recalls asking himself whether there wasn't "a better way to get involved in the decision-making process."
So he went to law school at Georgetown University, while holding a full-time job evaluating inventions at the United States Patent Office (a job, he readily acknowledges, that kept him out of the draft in the Vietnam era). After that, he went on to Harvard, where he received a master's degree in environmental law.
Under Mr. Ditlow, the Center for Auto Safety was active in the battle to impose the first fuel-economy standards on new cars in the 1970's. That battle goes on in the 1990's: the center is now seeking to raise the standards substantially. "I frankly don't think there's any place in America for a car that gets 15 miles per gallon," Mr. Ditlow said, adding that with new technology even big cars can get double that mileage.
But auto makers say such increases cannot be achieved without reducing both size and weight, jeopardizing safety. If the center "really cared about safety," asked William H. Noack, director of communications in General Motors ' Washington office, "why would they even want to take the chance that there might be more fatalities" with smaller and lighter cars?
Mr. Ditlow acknowledges that big cars are safer than small ones, other things being equal, but says there is still much to be done to improve the safety of small cars. And he notes that in recent years big cars have shed an average of about 1,000 pounds -- a reduced disparity that helps small cars survive crashes with big ones. The center also receives complaints from consumers: about 40,000 last year, either about "lemons" or about problems that may be widely shared, like faulty brakes or gas tanks prone to catch fire in crashes. About three years ago this process was computerized, enabling the center to search for patterns. Its usual response is to send out information packets, mostly tailored to specific problems, along with solicitations to become a member of the center at $15 a year.
About 40 percent of the center's revenue comes from members or other private citizens; Mr. Ditlow said there were no big individual donors. Twenty percent comes from the insurance industry, which shares the center's interest in auto safety, and from foundation grants. Thirty percent comes from the sale of written materials, notably "The Lemon Book" and "The Car Book."
"The Lemon Book," published about every 10 years (most recently in 1990), offers advice to owners of problem-plagued cars. "The Car Book," which assesses the new models each year, was formerly published by the Federal Department of Transportation but was discontinued by the Reagan Administration.
 
'We're Not Really Enemies'
 The rest of the center's budget comes from investments and fees generated by research for product liability lawyers, who are billed at $60 an hour. Critics complain that the center is overly chummy with such lawyers, compiling manuals like "Ford Park-to-Reverse" and "Jeep Roll Over," which have been promoted in legal publications. Mr. Ditlow defends the practice by pointing out that in return, these lawyers often supply the center with information available nowhere else.
Mr. Ditlow, who drives a 1987 Chevrolet Nova (without an air bag), says Detroit is shortsighted in its resistance to the center's efforts. "We're not really enemies," he said. "We'd like nothing more than to see Detroit make good cars. Consumer protection is good for car companies and for consumers both."
He noted that Lee A. Iacocca, Chrysler's chairman, was a fellow Lehigh alumnus. "He makes 'em; we recall 'em," Mr. Ditlow said. "We have a standing offer to stop our opposition when they stop making bad cars."

HEADLINE: IN THE NATION;
An Opposition Leader?

BYLINE: By Tom Wicker

 BODY:
The Persian Gulf war obviously has wide public support, enough to intimidate dissident politicians from standing up to oppose it. Someone, probably but not necessarily a Democrat, nevertheless may be missing an opportunity by holding his or her tongue.
 A number of factors suggest that support for the war will fade, perhaps even rapidly. For one thing, not every patriotic American who backs the troops and hopes for his country's victory agrees that war was necessary or wise. Before the shooting started, the nation was deeply divided; and today's enthusiasm may fade as prewar doubts and questions re-emerge. 
 For another thing, the inevitable ground war is beginning, once again confounding the rosy claims of air-power buffs; in Gen. Norman Schwarzkopf's words, that means "the best is still to come." He might better have said "the worst," since he referred to the major allied effort to drive the Iraqis out of Kuwait, a push expected to bring hard fighting and high casualties. Soviet generals long familiar with the Iraqi military, as well as U.S. analysts, believe the U.S. has underestimated Saddam Hus sein's and Iraq's fighting potential.
 Unsettled war aims also may portend declining unity. The recent Baker-Bessmertnykh statement seemed to suggest, for instance, that Iraq might end the war with a "commitment" and "concrete steps" to withdraw from Kuwait, rather than the previously specified withdrawal itself. But Israel's Foreign Minister, David Levy, says the war will not end until the Iraqi regime is destroyed, an aim neither the Arab allies nor Moscow embraces and one that the U.S. has not yet formally avowed.
 What happens if, after hard fighting, the Iraqis are driven from Kuwait but do not give up? The U.N. mandate will have been satisfied but not Israeli demands or the desire of many Americans -- probably including George Bush -- that Saddam Hussein be removed and Iraq's military potential destroyed. Will the war go on in that event? Would it then enjoy such wide support?
 Sooner or later, moreover, many Americans will question the priorities that place the gulf war ahead of crying domestic needs barely acknowledged by the Bush Administration. How long can it be contended that war against Iraq is more important than the nation's failing education system, its inadequate health services, its massive crime problem? How long can or should superpower pretensions be maintained, in spite of the nation's weakened economic and social bases?
 For all these reasons, and perhaps others, the potential for a strong opposition to the gulf war exists. On the home front, too, the recession may well be longer and harder than President Bush says he expects; and Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, suggests that a long war might well cause a deeper recession. Thus, war and the economy might cause public opinion to move sharply against Mr. Bush.
 Who, in that case, would be the political beneficiary? At the moment, it's not surprising that none of those most often mentioned as possible Democratic nominees in 1992 are speaking out. Most no doubt remember that even an active and powerful domestic reaction against the Vietnam war failed to produce an outright opposition candidate in 1968; and that George McGovern, as such a candidate in 1972, lost a landslide.
 An opposition leader would have to weigh his words carefully in order not to be seen as undercutting brave American troops in the field. But the ambiguity of the Administration's intentions, the dark uncertainties surrounding a postwar settlement and numerous neglected domestic problems would provide such a leader with legitimate causes for his stand. He might genuinely argue, for example, that the most useful support for American troops is to spare them needless casualties in unwise battles.
 Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia, whom some consider a potential Democratic candidate, voted against authorizing the President to start the war. His current support for American forces and American victory can't change that vote, or the impression that he believed the war unnecessary up to the moment it was started.
 A Democratic dark horse, Senator Robert Kerrey of Nebraska, also voted against war. He has a Medal of Honor, and Senator Nunn has a history of military support and expertise, as a defense against charges of being "soft." But it's probably too much to expect that either would take the undeniable political risk of leading the opposition -- even to a war that's likely to lose acceptability as the months go along.

HEADLINE: Why the Gulf War Is Not Vietnam

 BODY:
"It won't be another Vietnam," President Bush keeps saying about the Persian Gulf war. That's a sure applause line. Americans now agree that the long U.S. military involvement in Southeast Asia was a disaster for America. But the President's oratory, and the applause, are confusing, because Americans still differ sharply about the nature of the disaster.
For liberals, Vietnam was an immoral war, in support of insupportable Saigon regimes. Worse, America lost its innocence through napalm attacks, carpet bombing and the My Lai massacre. The lesson: America should be wary of Presidential and Pentagon scenarios and go to war only as a last resort. 
 For centrists, Vietnam represents good intentions gone awry, proof that John F. Kennedy's summons to fight any Communist foe and bear any military burden was simply beyond America's means. Obsession with an unwinnable struggle distorted priorities and politics, ignited inflation and undermined patriotism. They, too, wish urgently to avoid another costly crusade in the name of American determination that ends up dissipating American resolve. To them, the lesson is: Pick wars carefully, fight with a sense of proportion.
For conservatives like Mr. Bush, Vietnam represents mainly a failure of political will. First, Washington forfeited public support by fighting a limited war, resisting, for example, military demands for all-out bombing of the North. Then, by withdrawing U.S. troops amid domestic political protest, America showed the world that it lacked staying power.
Conservatives believe that this showing invited subsequent policy disasters like Nicaragua, Afghanistan and Iran. To them, the lesson is: The United States must prove it has the will to fight for freedom.
Thus in the Persian Gulf President Bush moved rapidly to build up American forces. He quickly gave up on the economic embargo, which needs months to work. And he has lately been pressing for all-out military victory.
Are any of these lessons of Vietnam relevant to the gulf war? Probably not, if only because circumstances have changed so greatly. The United States is no longer in a global confrontation with Communism. And Washington can no longer afford the global commitments that a Pax Americana, J.F.K. style, would require.
The need to deter aggression remains -- with collective security, not new and improved versions of power projection in the cold-war style. That means not just financial burden-sharing and formal U.N. votes but serious commitments to joint diplomatic, economic and, if necessary, military actions in defense of international law.
In the days and weeks after Saddam Hussein seized Kuwait, Mr. Bush masterfully organized a collective response. Then after the November elections he changed tack, stressing the military, and the American, side of the equation.
The best way to avoid another Vietnam is to move forward into collective security rather than slip back into fantasies about a Pax Americana.
