HEADLINE: 100% Deposit Insurance Is Wrongheaded

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Let Every Depositor Sleep Securely" (editorial, Jan. 9) should give every taxpayer nightmares. Of all the proposals circulating in the name of banking reform, 100 percent deposit insurance has got to be the most wrongheaded. With the exception of an anomaly such as the case of the Freedom National Bank in New York City, that's what we have now, and it has undermined market discipline in banking. 
 Assuming you are correct that thecollapse of the Bank of New England threatened the local economy, deposit insurance is intended to provide stability to the banking system and not to protect a local economy, and certainly not every uninsured depositor. The Federal Reserve System is responsible, in its capacity as lender of last resort, for providing liquidity to good banks experiencing unusual deposit outflows. The banking system, indeed the national economy, is ill served by protecting banks that are truly bad.
Your "dream" of 100 percent deposit insurance removes any semblance of market discipline from the deposit-taking process. Market discipline can't be instilled by risk-based premiums unless they were established on an actuarially sound basis. Many banks can't afford the current level of premiums let alone the intolerably high premiums that would be required to maintain the actuarial integrity of a risk-based system.
The current deposit insurance system and certainly your 100 percent deposit insurance have a serious flaw that erodes, if not destroys, market discipline. That flaw is known in the insurance business as "moral hazard." It is a characteristic of insurance that reduces the insured's attention to the risks insured against. In the case of deposit insurance it makes insured depositors indifferent to the riskiness of the banks that hold their deposits. Rather, the incentive is to search for the bank paying an extra few basis points, which is probably going to be the riskiest bank since return is generally related to risk.
Risk is one thing, but as evidenced by many thrifts and the Bank of New England, one can buy an insured deposit from a failing or even failed institution. That's exactly the same as being able to buy fire insurance while your house is burning or, worse yet, after it has burned down.
An effective way of containing the moral hazard in deposit insurance has been suggested by the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis, the American Bankers Association and others: Limit coverage to one account per depositor, require depositors to share part of the loss over the per account insurance limit -- 10 percent for example -- and do away with too-big-to-fail.
No change in banking structure and certainly not enlarged powers should be considered unless and until market discipline is established in deposit taking. A 100 percent deposit insurance system is precisely what not to do. If deposit insurance is not reformed to instill market discipline in deposit-taking, depositors may sleep securely but they will do so at the expense of the taxpayers.
 
MELVIN L. BURSTEIN
Sr. Vice President, General Counsel Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis
Minneapolis, Jan. 15, 1991

HEADLINE: The Bad News Boys, Mr. Florio Cuts Back

 BODY:
Among the 30-odd states grappling with prospective deficits, New Jersey is in relatively good shape, thanks to big tax increases last year. But any deficit is difficult. Gov. Jim Florio's budget combines toughness, gimmickry and hope for only a mild recession.
Faced with an $800 million gap despite the higher taxes, Governor Florio proposes cutbacks for most agencies, layoffs for several thousand state employees and a salary freeze and higher benefit costs for the rest. It's a harsh but necessary menu. He would also consolidate several agencies and -- the big gimmick -- sell some highways. Selling roads is unusual, but other states have done it. 
 A year ago Mr. Florio got $2.8 billion of unpopular income and sales tax increases and a controversial new formula for channeling more help to poor school districts while cutting local property taxes. The uproar continues. Anti-Florio votes nearly unseated Senator Bill Bradley, and Democrats still fear they could lose majority control in this year's legislative elections. Running for cover, the State Senate's majority leader, John Lynch, wants to skim $395 million from the Governor's school aid plan, and parcel it out around the state for property tax cuts.
Given the dicey political atmosphere, and the inherent pain of spending cuts, Mr. Florio concedes his plan is negotiable -- a far cry from his inflexibility last year. There will be no new taxes, as such, but substantially higher tolls on the New Jersey Turnpike to support the sale of feeder highways to the Turnpike Authority.
Instead of retiring debt, the authority would use $400 million of surplus funds to buy connecting roads, but that requires higher tolls to pay interest on the extra debt. In addition to budget relief, the plan has fringe benefits: out-of-state drivers will bear half the burden, and some local turnpike commuters will switch to mass transit.
The Governor's plan is sufficient for the deficit he anticipates next year, but not beyond. He's done it with equal doses of courage and legerdemain. But salaries can't be frozen for long, and there's only a limited market for used pavement.
 

CORRECTION-DATE: February 6, 1991, Wednesday

HEADLINE: A Backwater Makes Good

BYLINE: By Gordon Williams; Gordon Williams is a business correspondent for ABC News.

 BODY:

THE WARRIOR WORKER
The Challenge of the Korean Way of Working.
By Robert P. Kearney.
276 pp. New York:
Henry Holt & Company.
$24.95. 
 Of all the have-not nations that have ascended the economic ladder, few started lower, or have climbed higher, than South Korea. As the economics journalist Robert P. Kearney reminds us in "The Warrior Worker," when combat with North Korea ended in 1953, South Korea was a destitute land that seemed likely to remain so for a long time.
The country lacked not only an industrial base, but the raw materials and the infrastructure to build such a base. South Korea's economic success has been constructed on the vitality of its people. But there are only 17 million people in the South Korean work force, against 60 million in Japan's. And the first half of this century saw the Korean people "colonized, brutalized, exploited . . . dislocated by the millions through conscription and war and the division of their country, killed, maimed, and terrorized."
That is hardly the basis for an economic boom. Yet South Korea's growth over two decades has run three and four times that of the United States, while its exports grew by 30 and 40 percent a year in the 1960's and 1970's. By 1988, South Korea's Hyundai automobile was America's best-selling subcompact import, Mr. Kearney says, and a nation that once lived on American handouts was running an $8.7 billion trade surplus with the United States.
If that growth continues apace, says Mr. Kearney, "by the end of the century, this Indiana-sized nation will be one of the world's top ten traders and have one of its top fifteen economies." Its standard of living will rival that of Britain. Yet Mr. Kearney calls South Korea "the most unnerving Asian nation," and the prospect of so promising an economic future scares him.
He worries that not only will South Korea take additional markets and jobs from the United States, but also that it is setting a model for economic competitiveness other developing countries will follow. "If these nations are even half as successful as Korea," he warns, "American workers will find their standard of living, and the terms and conditions of their employment, in serious jeopardy."
The country's model is militaristic, says Mr. Kearney, with South Korean workers subjected to long hours, low pay, harsh discipline and authoritarian rule. "Korea is, above all, a glimmering advertisement for the benefits of fascism," he insists.
Even Japan doesn't worry Mr. Kearney as South Korea does. He argues that Japan was an industrial nation before World War II, and has merely regained its place in the economic sun. But South Korea, only a generation ago, was "a bombed-out back water, a pathetic dump of a country." He frets that "if Korea could come this far in a few decades, why not India, China, Indonesia? This is a rationale for paranoia that Japan has never offered."
Yet South Korea may never experience either the glowing economic or quasi-totalitarian future that so worries Mr. Kearney. It is already coming under assault from within and without. At home, its workers have grown militant in demanding more from the nation's prosperity. South Korean productivity is certain to slip, and with it some of its competitiveness.
Abroad, South Korea faces trade restrictions from its best customers -- the United States included -- and growing competition from developing nations, which, whether they have emulated South Korea or not, are competing with it.
Finally, the world economy has turned hostile since Mr. Kearney wrote his book. He warns that "another oil shock or a recession in the United States . . . could send [South Korea's] economy reeling." Now, we have both.
South Korea provides a story of economic success that is both grand and troubling. Whether it can build on that success is questionable, and Mr. Kearney's concerns about Korea's economic future seem overblown. Still, that's a minor quibble about an otherwise admirable book. "The Warrior Worker" is extensively researched and crisply written. It is definitely worth reading to expand our understanding of a nation, a people and an economy we should know better than we do.

LENGTH: 1324 words

HEADLINE: Emancipation for What?

BYLINE: By Eric Foner; Eric Foner is DeWitt Clinton Professor of History at Columbia University. His most recent book is "Reconstruction: America's Unfinished Revolution."

 BODY:

FREEDOM
A Documentary History of Emancipation, 1861-1867.
Selected From the Holdings of the National Archives of the United States.
Series One, Volume Three. The Wartime Genesis of Free Labor: The Lower South.
Edited by Ira Berlin, Thavolia Glymph, Steven F. Miller, Joseph P. Reidy, Leslie S. Rowland and Julie Saville.
937 pp. New York:
Cambridge University Press. $54.50. 
 Future historians may well regard the work of the Freedmen and Southern Society Project at the University of Maryland as this generation's most significant encounter with the American past. A team of scholars headed by Ira Berlin has combed through millions of Civil War documents in the records of the Army, the Treasury Department and other Government agencies, and selected a few thousand for publication. The three volumes that have appeared so far bring vividly to life the greatest drama of the nation's history -- the liberation of four million African Americans from bondage.
The first volume, "The Black Military Experience," published in 1982, established the black soldier's critical role both in winning the Civil War and defining the war's consequences. The second, "The Destruction of Slavery," appearing three years later, centered on the black men and women of the South who fled to Union lines, thus helping to bring down slavery well before the Emancipation Proclamation. Now the series enters less familiar terrain. "The Wartime Genesis of Free Labor" proposes to trace in two volumes how new labor systems displaced slavery after the arrival of Union troops. A volume on "The Upper South" is forthcoming; "The Lower South" deals with the South Carolina Sea Islands, southern Louisiana and the Mississippi Valley.
Like its predecessors, this book represents interpretive editing at its best. Most historical editing projects aim above all at completeness. For Mr. Berlin and his colleagues, selection is the primary concern. The documents published here form part of a coherent historical argument, set forth in a long introductory essay that constitutes a major contribution to the literature of the Civil War.
The theme that unifies the account is the triangular struggle, involving former masters, former slaves and Northern conquerors, in which nothing less than the definition of freedom was at stake. Indeed, one of the volume's most profound insights is that rather than being an established, well-defined category, freedom was a terrain of conflict, whose meaning changed for blacks and whites alike during and after the Civil War.
To the former slaves, as a black minister told Gen. William T. Sherman, freedom meant "placing us where we could reap the fruit of our own labor." The best way to accomplish this was "to have land, and turn it and till it by our own labor."
Planters, whether loyal or Confederate, hoped to establish a new system as close to slavery as possible. Assuming blacks were either inherently lazy or simply determined to escape plantation labor, they demanded that the Army force the freed slaves back into the fields. To many planters, the end of slavery meant little more than an opportunity to throw off paternalist responsibilities. Even hardened military men were shocked by the frequency with which former slaveholders evicted the elderly and infirm from their plantations and discontinued food supplies and medical care for young children.
Northerners had traditionally viewed the wage earner, who lacked the economic independence necessary for republican citizenship, as less than fully free. But as the editors point out, the Northern definition of freedom was itself evolving in these years. As capitalism became entrenched, the hallmark of liberty became the ability to sell one's labor without hindrance in the marketplace, rather than the ownership of productive property. Thus, most Northerners rejected the planters' efforts to bind former slaves to the plantations. But most also believed that blacks could be genuinely free without owning land.
Overseeing the transition from slave labor to free labor was the Union Army. The Army itself began the employment of blacks as wage workers, using tens of thousands of them to lay railroad track, build fortifications and do other manual labor. Military commanders, however, were less interested in devising a new system of Southern labor than in winning the war. They often put refugees from slavery back to work on plantations simply to avoid responsibility for them.
Nowhere was the collision of competing definitions of freedom more revealing than on the Sea Islands. Among the participants here were: a black community that had achieved an unusual degree of autonomy before the war; Northern investors lured by a typically American desire to promote the "cause of Emancipation and human progress" while turning a tidy profit; military commanders; and Northern reformers bent on uplifting the former slaves. Conspicuous by their absence were the former slaveholders, who fled the islands when Union forces approached.
Despite the pleas of blacks, reformers and sympathetic military men, the Lincoln Administration did little to encourage black landownership on the islands. Instead, it auctioned abandoned plantations to Northern investors.
Many of the investors were self-conscious advocates of free labor, determined to prove that blacks were motivated by the same market-oriented desires as Northern laborers. In order to "multiply their simple wants," one plantation manager established stores with previously unavailable items like housewares, beef and fine clothing. The freedmen, he assumed, would happily work for wages in the cotton fields to improve their level of consumption. But the former slaves preferred to concentrate on food crops for their private use rather than on cotton for a market economy, and continued to insist that without access to land of their own, they had not achieved real freedom.
The situation in southern Louisiana differed substantially from that of the Sea Islands. Large numbers of planters remained on their estates, and the Lincoln Administration, seeking to weaken the Confederacy, hoped to bring the state back into the Union with their help. As slaves by the thousands fled the plantations, the Army ordered them to return under yearly labor contracts. Even after the initially low wages were raised, this system of compulsory free labor (extended to the Mississippi Valley in 1863) pleased no one, since blacks resented having contracts forced upon them and planters -- barred by the Army from using corporal punishment -- complained that they were unable to make their laborers work as diligently as slaves.
By the end of the war, nearly half a million former slaves had taken part in some kind of Federally sponsored free labor system. Only a handful were allowed to farm on their own. In January 1865, General Sherman set aside a large part of coastal South Carolina for black settlement. But before the year ended, President Andrew Johnson had ordered the land returned to the former owners. The final South Carolina document in the collection dates from December 1865, with three Federal tax commissioners protesting this "violation of the pledged faith of the Government."
One can safely predict that the volumes of the Freedmen and Southern Society Project (which will soon be moving on to cover such areas as the black family and black society ) will be examined by only a tiny fraction of those who watched the highly acclaimed PBS series on the Civil War. It is not easy to read the sometimes prolix reports of military commanders or the ungrammatical petitions of men and women just released from bondage. But those who persevere will appreciate something the television series never quite grasped: more than just a succession of battles, the Civil War was a genuine social revolution that helped to determine the very meaning of freedom for postwar America.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Freed slaves hired by the Union Army to work as laborers. (The National Archives)

HEADLINE: New & Noteworthy

BYLINE: By GEORGE JOHNSON

 BODY:
A PEACE TO END ALL PEACE: Creating the Modern Middle East 1914-1922, by David Fromkin. (Avon, $14.95.) A historian tells how today's Middle East jigsaw was carved from the Ottoman Empire with the help of the British, who wanted to insure that they had a land bridge to India. " 'A Peace to End All Peace' is one of the first books to take an effective panoramic view of what was happening," Wm. Roger Louis said here in 1989. "Among the reasons for Mr. Fromkin's success is the breadth of his vision, which takes the reader deep into areas normally not associated with the Middle East."
VINELAND, by Thomas Pynchon. (Penguin, $9.95.) In this novel by the elusive and seldom-photographed author of conspiratorial fantasies, the heroes of chaos and entropy are led by an ex-hippie named Zoyd, sworn enemy of the evil renegade Federal prosecutor and champion of order, Brock Vond. Last year our reviewer, Salman Rushdie, called the novel "free-flowing and light and funny and maybe the most readily accessible piece of writing the old Invisible Man ever came up with. . . . What is interesting is to have before us, at the end of the Greed Decade, that rarest of birds: a major political novel about what America has been doing to itself, to its children, all these many years." Also available from Penguin is a matching edition of Mr. Pynchon's 1973 novel GRAVITY'S RAINBOW ($12.95). 
DEVICES AND DESIRES, by P. D. James. (Warner, $5.95.) When Commander Adam Dalgliesh inherits a cottage from an eccentric aunt, he finds the coastal community haunted by a serial murderer and a controversy over a nuclear power plant. "While it has the richness of a classical novel, this topical tale is told in a taut time framework and unfolds in the near cinematic scenes that are Miss James's style," Judith Crist said here last year.
BARBARIANS AT THE GATE: The Fall of RJR Nabisco, by Bryan Burrough and John Helyar. (Harper Perennial, $10.95.) Two reporters who covered the $25 billion takeover of a seemingly lackluster behemoth named RJR Nabisco show why we no longer hear Wall Street financiers crowing about how leveraged buyouts and junk bonds are really good for the economy and the American way. This account has "all the suspense of a first-rate thriller," Patricia O'Toole said here last year. It is "one of the finest, most compelling accounts of what happened to corporate America and Wall Street in the 1980's." Plume has republished another chronicle of what has been called the biggest deal of the decade: TRUE GREED: What Really Happened in the Battle for RJR Nabisco, by Hope Lampert ($9.95).
LORD BYRON'S DOCTOR, by Paul West. (University of Chicago, $12.95.) In real life, Dr. John Polidori, who briefly signed on as the private physician to Lord Byron in the hopes of promoting his own literary career, seemed a rather dull, self-important buffoon. In turning him into the protagonist of this novel, Paul West "imagines a complex character roiling with envy, spite, fury and, most of all, the desire to be Lord Byron." The result is "a powerful book, a disturbing and memorable evocation of the pernicious consequences that Byronism could have."
WHAT KIND OF LIFE: The Limits of Medical Progress, by Daniel Callahan. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $9.95.) America's worship of technology and the good of the individual over the commonweal has left us with a health system that is ineffective and unaffordable, an expert on medical ethics argues. Daniel Callahan writes "with elegance and lucidity," Charles E. Rosenberg said here in 1989. "He excels at describing present irrationalities and in underscoring the benefits anticipated in his new model health care system."
ORDINARY LOVE AND GOOD WILL: Two Novellas, by Jane Smiley. (Ivy, $4.95.) In the first of these stories about the breakdown of families, a middle-aged divorced woman confesses to her estranged children that it was she who destroyed their happiness by having an affair with a neighbor; in the second, a Vietnam veteran exiles himself and his wife and son on an isolated farm. In 1989 our reviewer, Josephine Humphreys, said the two tales are "mutually resonant, thematically linked in satisfying and subtle ways."
THE DELUGE AND THE ARK: A Journey Into Primate Worlds, by Dale Peterson. (Avon, $11.95.) After the author learned that a species of South American monkey had been reduced to about the size of the student body of his old high school, he embarked on a journey to visit endangered primates and the people trying to save them. "His book is a fine expression of [his hopes] and a passionate plea for more, better and larger arks, in fact for treating the whole world more like the ark it once was and still could be," Paul Schullery said here in 1989.
FELLOW PASSENGERS: A Novel in Portraits, by Louis Auchincloss. (St. Martin's, $3.95.) Dan Ruggles, a lawyer who dabbles in writing detective fiction, provides a behind-the-scenes look at the rich people who like to confide in him. In 1989 our reviewer, Isabel Colegate, said the best of these stories are "reminiscent of Somerset Maugham at his most urbane."
A SAFE PLACE, by Leston Havens. (Ballantine, $8.95.) In a series of case studies -- of a troubled student, a suicidal depressive, a schizophrenic, a physician preoccupied by fears of death -- a psychiatrist shows that it takes more than theories to help people. The book provides "an unforgettable sense of a professional healer who is so empathetic that one can almost see his mind reach out to embrace another," Richard Flaste said here last year.

HEADLINE: Fashion;
WINDS OF CHANGE

BYLINE: BY CARRIE DONOVAN

 BODY:
EVERYTHING AFFECTS FASHION -- INCLUDING, undoubtedly, the fighting in the Persian Gulf. Paris designers just finishing up their spring couture showings, and those elsewhere who are deep into plans for next fall's collections, are as concerned, distracted and apprehensive about the conflict as everyone else. How all this will come together in cloth and thread is still to be determined. The only sure thing is that it will. History has shown that style inevitably absorbs the atmosphere of the moment and distills it into adornment.
But even before the current turmoil, the winds of change were whistling through the corridors of fashion. The most creative talents -- those whose sensitive antennae pick up the signals before the rest -- were already exploring new directions. Skirts, after all, have got to the point where they can get no shorter. Clothing that is so tight it clings to every curve has become commonplace. The skimpy look has reached its zenith, while vulgarity, expressed in excessive displays of color and razzle-dazzle, is now accepted as the norm. Unquestionably, the time is now for new moves. But what? 
 Shortly before the fighting in the gulf began, interviews with leading designers pointed out some of the shifts sure to give the international fashion scene a change of focus -- or perhaps even a jolt or two. "Fashion evolves; it's no longer a question of dramatic change," says Donna Karan, maybe America's most vocal talent. "Everything starts with the fabric. We're not going to lose stretch, but I'm looking for those that are crisper, that will hold their shape and not depend on the body to do it. . . . And I'm ready for a new shoulder with some shape." Shoes too, she says, are going to change: they'll be more chunky. As for new shades, "the shock of color is now commonplace," says Karan, predicting that "we'll be reversing to black."
 Over in Paris, two designers who wield worldwide influence, Karl Lagerfeld and Christian Lacroix, have already acted on their predictions. Lagerfeld's new spring suits for Chanel are made of the familiar tweeds, but these are now woven with stretch yarns. As a result, the jackets -- particularly their sleeves -- fit like snug gloves. These jackets are very long in line and go with skirts that are still above the knee, but not as short as before. Lagerfeld settled on these proportions after deciding "shorter you cannot go, and longer is too dull." But it is his shoes, with their bulkier soles, that give these new Chanels the distinct flavor of French fashion in the 1940's, during and just after the German occupation.
Lacroix, he of the famous flings of wild, wonderful colors and fanciful flourishes, now finds himself in a much more somber frame of mind. "This is not because of the war," he says. Rather, "it's a desire to design with more of an awareness of reality -- of what can be worn in the street, not in a fantasy world." He refers to his new silhouettes as "abstract and sculptural." And Lacroix is deep into black, white and pastels. His ball gowns, usually elaborate productions, will still be sumptuous, but more architectural in line and neutral in coloration.
Meanwhile, back home, Isaac Mizrahi, the imaginative, irrepressible new star, says: "I'm so bored with real life. We need fantasy. And color? All colors have now become neutrals." Mizrahi plans to make his fall collection a celebration of the variety of American ethnic influences. Just the other morning -- in the shower, Mizrahi says -- he decided to show as many midcalf-length skirts as short ones, because "the length of a skirt doesn't matter." Mizrahi adds that he detests 1940's-style platform-soled shoes -- "but that's my personal taste."
Bill Blass is, as always, brisk and businesslike. "In a soft economy, for whatever reason, women experiment with fashion," says Blass. "But I don't think a longer skirt is the answer. It tends to look dowdy." Blass's surprises will be in the way he puts colors together and in the use of contradictory fabrics -- a tweed strapless evening gown, for example, with a tulle skirt.
Down in Milan, Giorgio Armani, whose world influence is formidable, expects to stay on his serene path, making his elegant clothes "just a bit more modern and young."
As usual, Geoffrey Beene in New York has the last word. "There are just too many options today," he says. "All women are going to arrive at a 'uniform' look that works for them. . . . I said a decade ago that a chemist's tube was where the next real change would come from. We're going to have to develop fabrics that perform better." Abraham, the renowned Swiss fabric mill famous for its purebred silks and cottons, is supposedly working on some synthetics. Now that is real change.
The question is, where do all these winds of change lead the style-acclimated customer? Though it will be fall before most of these directions come to pass, it is clear now that there is an overall move toward a more subdued approach to chic. Beyond that, autumn will bring plenty of new options -- good news for those with an independent mind and personal flair, but not for women who want and need a fixed weather vane.

LENGTH: 1608 words

HEADLINE: They Shoot Presidents, Don't They?

BYLINE: By DAVID RICHARDS

 BODY:
Ever since he hunkered down in the Texas School Book Depository in Dallas and fired the bullets that slew President Kennedy, the question has refused to go away. Did Lee Harvey Oswald act alone or was he merely the front man, carrying out the orders of others?
Not only does "Assassins," the audacious new musical by Stephen Sondheim and John Weidman at Playwrights Horizons, unequivocally endorse the conspiracy theory, it actually names the co-conspirators -- eight in all. If I tell you that John Wilkes Booth is one, Lynette (Squeaky) Fromme another and John Hinckley a third, then you may get an idea of what I mean by audacious. History lesson, carny show and bad dream all swirled into one, "Assassins" is a spangled celebration of America, a land where anybody can grow up to kill a President. 
 Mr. Sondheim has long since accustomed audiences to expect the unexpected. His musicals have brought the characters in a famous pointillist painting to life, rolled merrily backward in time and taken the Brothers Grimm one step beyond happy ever after. He has imagined beguiling songs for Japanese warlords, over-the-hill Follies girls and a barber with a hyperactive razor. Nothing, however, quite prepares you for the disturbing brilliance of "Assassins," unless it is the irony that has always been the constant in Mr. Sondheim's work. And even that has been raised to teeth-chattering levels.
Those who claim that his music requires repeated hearings before revealing its beauties will have no cause to complain here. The score is instantly appealing -- an all-American compendium of show tunes and Sousa marches, broad-shouldered hymns and wind-swept folk songs. But melody and message are purposefully, defiantly, at odds. Watching "Assassins" is rather like receiving a death notice in the form of a singing telegram.
You have only to consider "Unworthy of Your Love," a brokenhearted lament that would appear tailor-made for popular success. First, however, it will have to disengage itself completely from the show. In "Assassins," you see, it is sung by a disconsolate John Hinckley (Greg Germann), and while it is possible to appreciate the quiet poetry of the opening lines -- "I am nothing / You are wind and water and sky" -- by the time he's moved on to, "Tell me, Jodie, how I / Can earn your love," your hair is beginning to curl.
 Soon, an equally despondent Squeaky Fromme (Annie Golden) joins in -- pledging her unworthy affections to a certain "Charlie," whom I probably needn't tell you is Charles Manson. No one's forcing the issue -- certainly not the two performers, who seem to be shot up with Novocain. Yet when they're through, a simple, seemingly unassuming number has taken on diabolical overtones. Indeed, with no further ado, Hinckley draws a gun, turns upstage and fires repeatedly at a billboard-sized photograph of a beaming Ronald Reagan, while Squeaky goads him on with her mockery.
 The full contingent of assassins -- actually, the full contingent minus one, but more about that in a second -- is lured on stage in the opening number by the try-your-luck spiel coming from the congenial proprietor of a shooting gallery. "Hit the Prez and Win a Prize," proclaims the sign over his head. "Some guys/ Think they can't be winners," he coos, all slick and encouraging, "First prize/ Often goes to rank beginners." One by one, they let themselves be convinced and plunk down their money, before adding their insolent voices to the sweet refrain: "Everybody's/ Got the right/ To their dreams."
Thereafter, Mr. Weidman's book -- a scrapbook, really -- plays fast and loose with time and place. It thinks nothing of having Charles Guiteau (the assassin of President Garfield), for example, put the make on Sara Jane Moore (who bungled her attempt on the life of President Ford). Samuel Byck, a lunatic in a Santa suit who plans to divebomb President Nixon's White House, frequents the same saloon as Giuseppe Zangara, who moans that nothing will cure the sharp ache in his stomach, until a dapper Booth steps forward and suggests, with all due respect, "Have you considered shooting Franklin Roosevelt?"
For its first hour or so, "Assassins" seems little more than a revue, content to present its characters and their heinous deeds in songs, sketches and monologues -- some of which are sardonically funny. Sara Jane Moore (Debra Monk) is a true flibbertigibbet, as likely to pull a banana from her capacious handbag as she is a pistol. When she finally does lay her hands on the pistol, nothing says she won't turn it on her dog or a bucket of Colonel Sanders' fried chicken. While a sullen Zangara (Eddie Korbich), strapped to an electric chair, waits for the switch to be thrown, a clutch of Florida vacationers reaps all his publicity by boasting, in a lively patter song, "How I Saved Roosevelt."
Byck (Lee Wilkof) almost qualifies as a stand-up comic, as he dictates a message to Leonard Bernstein into his tape recorder, urging him to save the world with his God-given talent and write more love songs. Then, barely taking time to shift gears, he decides that Bernstein, with his hotshot life style, probably doesn't give a hoot. Nobody gives a hoot! And he's off to get himself a President.
As for the preening Booth (Victor Garber), well, isn't he an actor already? The other assassins call him "our pioneer," but he seems to see himself more as an impresario of the damned.
If you find yourself thinking that matters are a bit scattered, I suspect that you're reacting just as the show's creators intend. Early on, a balladeer (Patrick Cassidy), who serves as the unofficial narrator, points out that, "Lots of madmen/ Have had their say /But only for a day." We are being encouraged to look upon the various assassins as flukes of history. Their craziness passes. The country mends. Who even remembers Leon Czolgosz (Terrence Mann), the unemployed bottle maker who took up his place in the receiving line waiting to greet President McKinley at the Pan American Exposition in Buffalo, and instead of pumping his hand, pumped lead into him? There may be madness in their acts, but surely no method, no pattern, no connection.
Then, the turntable at Playwrights Horizons revolves 180 degrees to reveal the Texas School Book Depository and Lee Harvey Oswald (Jace Alexander). We'd almost forgotten him in the preceding hullabaloo. No matter. He doesn't look much like an assassin, anyway. He's entirely too preoccupied with his own collapsing life to hear the news on the radio that President Kennedy's plane is landing at nearby Love Field. What concerns him is the note he's busy scribbling, after which he intends to train the pistol in his lunch box on himself.
Booth won't hear of it. Suicide is such a wasteful gesture. Appearing from behind a stack of cardboard boxes, he tries to stay Oswald's hand and redirect it to a more consequential target. Called in as reinforcements, the other assassins add their supplications to Booth's: If Oswald comes over to their side, they will no longer be freaks and misfits. They will be a force, a dark necessity, a permanent shadow on the national anthem.
"Bring us together," pleads Byck. "We're your family," intones Moore. "You are the future," asserts Zangara.
 It is a stunningly theatrical ploy, even though the outcome is a foregone conclusion. Suddenly, the fragments of "Assassins" have coalesced in a chilling vision of evil reaching out to evil, and dark acts begetting dark acts. There is no coherent sociological explanation for the behavior of assassins, nor does the show pretend to offer one. They simply are -- the lurking side of human nature. They come with history. Mr. Sondheim and Mr. Weidman have produced a morality play about the forces of good and bad, and then boldly exiled goodness to the wings.
No musical in the last decade has dared this much.
If the form is thought to be quintessentially American, it is because for years musicals fostered optimism and endorsed enterprise. Their brash spirits, we liked to believe, were the country's. "Assassins" has no shortage of energy in the grand Fourth of July staging by Jerry Zaks, but it turns the musical's traditional values inside out and delivers a rebuke to George M. Cohan on his very own turf.
Loren Sherman's set design, which relies on tabloid photographs and period etchings for backdrops, artfully evokes the twilight zone where journalism meets history. And one look at Squeaky Fromme's red dress and kerchief (sort of latter-day French Revolution) is enough to convince you that William Ivey Long has the costumes just right. Ms. Golden's drug-fueled fervor is manifestly the kind that wants to burn down the world -- the only question in her eyes, black as a badger's, is where to begin.
If some of the performances are more vivid than others, some assassins, frankly, have been more colorful than others. Ms. Monk makes Moore's shrill discombobulations wildly amusing, while Mr. Garber goes about Booth's dirty work with arrogant majesty. Jonathan Hadary's religious zeal, as Guiteau, extends to his bristling coiffure, which is also striving to meet the Lord. This puts him at the opposite end of the spectrum from Mr. Germann, whose Hinckley is nothingness itself, hiding behind glasses and woebegone bangs. Splendidly cursed, all of them.
In "Gypsy," Mr. Sondheim had three tired strippers coach an inexperienced Gypsy Rose Lee on the secret of success. "You gotta have a gimmick," they told her. But, of course, you don't. "Assassins" lets us know that a gun will do just fine.
And you, too, can be a shooting star.

PUB-DATE: February 3, 1991

SECTION: Section 10; Page 1; Column 2; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 2031 words

HEADLINE: Foreclosures Yielding To a Helping Hand

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:
WHEN Timothy Protzman left his job at a Hartford radio station three years ago, he saw no financial danger in the month-long break before the start of his next position, at a local televison station. But that unpaid furlough was the beginning of his financial freefall.
Within a year his wife left work temporarily to bear the couple's second child, and with every passing month it was more of a stretch to make his paycheck cover the mortgage for their new home, higher day-care expenses and credit-card payments. By last summer he was two months in arrears on his mortgage loan and on his way to missing a third payment. 
 But instead of demanding back payment in full and late charges, which came to more than $4,000, Citicorp Mortgage, based in Shelton, Conn., the lender holding the Protzmans' mortgage, stopped the clock and worked out an agreement letting them pay back the debt over time if they could get back on track with current payments.
Citicorp's leniency with the Protzmans is not unusual these days. In the face of a rising home mortgage delinquency rate, banks increasingly are throwing safety lines to borrowers facing default.
This financial breathing room can come in a variety of forms: The lender can extend the loan by tacking the amount in arrears to the end of it; it can temporarily lower the mortgage rate; it can agree to let the delinquent borrower pay the missed payments over time, and -- in rare instances -- it can forgive part of the debt to avoid foreclosure.
"I have been in credit counseling for many years," said Beverly Tuttle, executive director of the Hamden office of Consumer Credit Counseling Service of Connecticut, to whom Mr. Protzman turned for help last October. "I have never seen banks more flexible, more willing to work with delinquent borrowers."
Until recently, banks were not particularly forgiving when a mortgagee fell seriously behind in monthly payments. Banking regulations say that mortgages in arrears more than 90 days are legally delinquent. At that point a bank can start proceedings to foreclose. So a borrower who had missed more than three mortgage payments could expect a lender to start talking foreclosure if the debt were not satisfied.
Now, however, banks are willing to work with borrowers to help them find a way to keep their homes if they run into financial difficulties.
Both of the Protzmans are working again, and in addition to their regular mortgage payment of about $1,000 for their home in Newington, they are making payments of $500 to $1,000 a month toward settlement of their old mortgage debt.
"My wife has always been pretty good with managing money," said Mr. Protzman, who is now in the Consumer Counseling Service's debt-management program. "But with the higher mortgage payments on our new house, and the expenses of another child and problems with the car, it did not take long to lose control."
Banks concede self-interest in these rescue missions. Keeping the families in their homes is their best hope of saving loans.
"WE don't want to take these properties," said Roger Williams, a senior vice president of the Dime Savings Bank, which last year formed an asset recovery division of which he is the general manager. "We don't want people to lose their homes. Foreclosure is the worst outcome for all parties involved."
Most lenders consider a mortgagee in arrears if a loan payment is more than 16 days late. After that, many of them charge late fees. In the past, a bank might wait until a second payment had been missed before contacting the borrower, but most do not wait that long now.
"The rate of success with this type of intervention is much greater if we can get to people early," said Tom Dolce, a vice president with Midlantic Home Mortgage, a division of Midlantic Corporation, the second largest bank in New Jersey. "Past a certain point most borrowers just can't be helped."
Some of the banks with the most aggressive customer recovery programs are those that made so-called low-documentation mortgage loans in the 1980's as a way to expand or hold on to their share of the mortgage market. At the time, these lenders thought they had a safety net in the underlying value of the residences.
But because home values have fallen severely in many areas, lenders now face the prospect of taking a loss when the sale price of a foreclosed property does not cover the mortgage balance.
Another reason banks will go to great lengths to avoid foreclosure is that the process, which requires court action, can be long and expensive. As the number of foreclosures rises, the time it takes for cases to work their way through the court system increases.
"You cannot discount the human relations relations aspect, either," said Raymond Teed, vice president of marketing for Astoria Federal Savings, based in Astoria, Queens. "In a foreclosure, the bank plays the heavy."
The Dime, Mr. Williams said, learned a useful lesson watching the troubles that befell lenders in the Southwest a few years ago.
"We saw that the banks that survived in that atmosphere were the ones that worked with the borrowers to avoid foreclosure," said Mr. Williams. "We will be as innovative as we can to do that with our customers."
Mr. Williams said that last year the bank, which has extended mortgage loans in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, "saved" more than 1,000 loans advancing toward foreclosure. He said he expects to see an increase this year as the asset recovery division's counselors reach more borrowers early in their delinquencies.
Banks are reluctant to disclose the extent of their delinquent loans. But data collected by the Mortgage Bankers Association, a trade group based in Washington that represents home lenders, show that the New York metropolitan region is following the national trend of more delinquencies. The association's National Delinquency Report, a quarterly publication of data on mortgage bankers, savings and loan associations, commercial banks and service bureaus, shows an increase in mortgage delinquencies both nationwide and in the region. In New Jersey, for example, delinquencies increased more than a percentage point between the third quarter of 1988 and the third quarter of 1990, rising in that time from 3.91 to 4.92 percent.
In Connecticut, delinquent mortgages represented 3.09 percent of all outstanding home loans in 1988 and 3.50 percent the following year. The data show that in the third quarter of 1990 delinquencies were up to 3.55 percent.
The Mortgage Bankers statistics indicate that throughout New York State there has been a slight improvement in the delinquency rate: It was 4.56 percent in the third quarter of 1989 and fell to 4.32 percent in the same period last year.
BUT some mortgage lenders in New York City say that the statewide figures do not reflect the gravity of the situation in the city and its suburbs, where home sales outpaced those in the rest of the state.
Statistics from the Federal Office of Thrift Supervision showed a considerable jump in delinquencies in the area embracing New York City and Westchester, Rockland and Putnam Counties. In the six-month period between April 1 and Sept. 30 of last year -- the months for which the most current statistics are available -- the number of delinquent loans went from 82,666 to 94,015. The figures, which track permanent loans on one- to four-family residences, have not been calculated for the last quarter of 1990.
The reasons behind these delinquencies are many. But most lenders and credit counselors agree that the economic slowdown has dealt a blow to the budgets of many borrowers. Many are young professionals pushed back on their heels by huge layoffs in industries like financial services, real estate, insurance and advertising.
"Some people are feeling the hardship for the first time," said Ms. Tuttle of the Consumer Credit Counseling Service of Connecticut. She described them as "people not familiar with financial hardships who often do not think in terms of preparing for them."
No matter what color the collar of the mortgagee, the loss of one paycheck in a two-income household can sink a borrower without a reserve in a matter of weeks.
Not only unemployment has put people behind. The loss of overtime wages as companies economize can be nearly as devastating as layoffs in households that have relied on extra income to pay bills. Also, lenders have found among their delinquent borrowers home buyers who are now feeling the financial pinch of the higher monthly payments on adjustable-rate mortgages.
Banks like the Dime, Astoria Federal Savings and Midlantic Home Mortgage are among those in the region that have established special units to help borrowers in trouble.
Mr. Teed of Astoria Federal said that despite his bank's willingness to spread a safety net for borrowers in a financial bind, the bank is not a soft touch.
"There has to be a business rationale in every one of our workouts," he said. "In each case, we have to see that the borrower has the ability to make the loan current and cure the default and there has to be value in the property to justify this approach."
Few of the cure packages used by lenders cut into their profits. Rather, these repayment plans delay their revenue by giving the borrower more time.
Some mortgage restructuring plans call for the borrower to pay the arrears as a single-payment "balloon" at the end of the mortgage term. Others add the debt to principal owed on the loan and require slightly higher monthly payments.
In cases where the borrower's financial problems involve long-term changes -- like a drop in commissions in a sales job -- some lenders may agree to a temporary lowering of the mortgage interest rate until the income increases.
"IF the borrower has little prospect of an increase in income in the short term," said Mr. Williams, "there is little chance he will be able to resume current payments, let alone make contributions to the old debt."
A temporary lowering of the loan's interest rate or some other form of restructuring of the terms of the loan involves closing costs -- including legal fees or mortgage recording costs -- that the borrower must pay.
Mr. Teed of Astoria Federal cited a plan for one delinquent borrower on Long Island whose 15-year mortgage was rewritten. He was three years into the loan when he fell behind and the bank rewrote the mortgage with lower interest rates and lower payments. Even though the family's income was stretched to the limit, Mr. Teed said, the bank justified this approach because the owner was also willing to subdivide and sell part of his property, which was very large, and use the profit to pay down on his loan.
When the mortgage went from a $300,000 loan to a $200,000, the monthly payments were cut by $1,075.
For another borrower -- a mother of two who fell behind after a divorce and whose delinquency of several months was well past the point of legal foreclosure -- the bank agreed to extend the loan and reduce the monthly payments to $300 from $350 a month.
"Again," said Mr. Teed, "the extension of the loan was justified because of the amount of equity in the home, and most importantly because we could see that she was making a serious effort to meet the obligation."
Banks that have sold their loans in the secondary market, which is a common practice today, must have approval from the investor before offering to restructure a mortgagee's interest rate or extend the terms of the loan.
When keeping the borrower in the home is not possible, a bank often will agree to take a deed to the home in lieu of foreclosure. In this transaction, the borrower gives title to the bank, thus avoiding a court foreclosure and its consequent blemish on his credit record.
In cases where the borrower is able to avoid foreclosure by selling his home, but not at a price that will cover the mortgage, the lender in some cases will forgive a portion of the debt to avoid the expense of a foreclosure.
Mr. Dolce said that while rare, these "short sales" have taken place when prices have declined considerably in recent years.

HEADLINE: Co-op and Condo Delinquencies Rising

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS

 BODY:
IN a pattern showing up with increasing frequency at condominiums and cooperatives across the country, nine of the 31 shareholders at 210 West 103d Street -- a 50-year-old brick building in New York City's Manhattan Valley neighborhood -- have fallen more than 60 days behind in their monthly maintenance payments of about $725.
"It's one thing to be four weeks late," said Mark Schorr, president of the six-story co-op, where one-bedroom apartments sell for around $100,000. "Its another to be four months overdue. Our clock is ticking." 
 Time has already run out at Sherburne Village, a 96-unit condominium in Kingsboro, Mass. Collections there became so deficient just over a year ago that when the septic system failed the officers could not raise the $1.3 million to hook up to a sewer system. Instead, everyone had to leave temporarily and the vacant complex is boarded up.
"Its a real mess," said Don Lavallee, a former board chairman. In November, a court appointed a receiver to sort out the association's affairs because it could no longer pay its vendors. Many owners say they expect to lose their entire investment.
 As more people lose their jobs, it grows harder to collect monthly charges, which are vital to maintain such basic services as utilities, garbage removal, cleaning and structural repairs. In co-ops, the charges, or maintenance fees, also pay real estate taxes and the underlying mortgage.
 "It's becoming the No. 1 management problem of 1991," said Bob Kirkland, president-elect of the Research Foundation of the Community Associations Institute, a national network of professionals and elected co-op and condominium officers. At state chapters, around the country, he said, demand for education programs about collections, bankruptcies and foreclosures are "at the top of the list."
The institute represents 6,500 member condominiums and co-ops across the country with 1.3 million unit owners. It estimates that owners of 10 percent of the units in the Northeast and 5 percent in California are in default. The normal rate is 1 to 2 percent.
 In most places, boards are muddling through with a patchwork of temporary measures, such as dipping into reserve funds or special assessments. But, warn lawyers and managers, such steps are unlikely to sustain budgets over a long period.
 The problem tends to be compounded. Anthony Bryant, a businessman who owned an investor unit at Sherburne Village, said that when common charges were $96 a month he could meet them and his $625 monthly mortgage payments from rental income. But common charges eventually rose to $163 because of the sewer problem and to make up for rising delinquencies. Then an assessment of $1,000 was requested as legal costs and temporary pumping charges unbalanced the revised budget.
"It got to a point where I couldn't afford to pay and I don't expect I will ever catch up," said Mr. Bryant. He figures he owes about $3,000 in overdue charges and $10,000 in mortgage payments. The bank has taken the unit into foreclosure.
 Delinquencies on investor-owned units are a major problem. "When there's no equity left in the unit, investors lose interest." said Stephen M. Marcus, a lawyer in Braintree, Mass."Its not their home and they're not about to pay dues on a losing asset."
Also slipping into arrears are many condominiums used as second homes, again because the owner's vital interests are not so directly affected, said Charles Incandela, president of Maintainamation of Bohemia, N.Y., a management company.
 In New York City, well-established co-ops with high financial standards for admission -- some demand that buyers have a net worth two or three times the purchase price -- are well insulated from the delinquency problem. The shortfalls are most severe in their consequences in buildings converted in the last four or five years.
"Buyers paid top dollar for their apartments and were heavily leveraged," said Stuart Saft, vice president of the Council of New York Cooperatives. When charges started going up because of rising taxes or a special assessment, "some people just couldn't keep up," he said.
 Mr. Saft, a lawyer with Wolf, Haldenstein Adler Freeman & Herz of Manhattan, which represents some 140 buildings in New York City, said that in the past his firm typically pursued about 10 deliquencies a year and mere threats of legal action usually cleared the matter up fast. But by the end of 1990 some 50 owners were being chased and only half had agreed to settle.
ALONG the Virginia coast, delinquency rates have risen from an average of 2 percent a year ago to nearly 5 percent, said Mr. Kirkland, who is also president of Professional Property Managers of Virginia Beach, Va., which manages some 11,000 units. Also growing, he said, is the time that owners remain in arrears.
 The traditional safeguards that prevented the build-up of overdue charges are no match for today's chaotic economic climate. Historically, as soon as a unit owner fell more than 60 days behind, the lender who held the mortgage would quickly take over the collection chore to try to preempt trouble with its own loan, insisting the owner pay those charges or face foreclosure even if mortgage payments were current.
 Such rapid intervention meant that the unit was either sold very quickly and the arrears were recouped from the sale -- there was ample cushion in a rising market -- or the owner was sufficiently shaken to pay up.
"Now the banks have got so many bigger problems on their hands they can take months befoe they do anything at all," said Richard Pepin, president of Signature Management of Duxbury, Mass., which handles some 2,000 units in Boston suburbs.
 While the condominium association or co-op corporation also can legally initiate a foreclosure -- after placing a lien on the unit -- it becomes prohibitively expensive to do when the number of deliquencies starts to rise. And the chance of getting enough from the sale of a unit in a falling market is slim since there is rarely anything left after the mortgage has been paid off.
Moreover, "it's very costly to keep hiring a lawyer, especially when you are running low already," said Jeff Guertin, board chairman of the 293-unit Century Estates Condominums in Framingham, Mass., who did research on the problem for an article in the November issue of the monthly Condo Management.
 A foreclosure can take more than a year to complete because the courts are now heavily backed up with foreclosure actions, said Robert Huhtanen, senior property mangager with Thibodeau Management Services of South Windsor, Conn. Thibodeau manages over 8,000 units, 10 percent of which are now more than 60 days in arrears compared to a prior norm of 3 percent.
 Another obstacle has been the rash of personal bankruptcies, which tie the hands of the association or corporation and may entirely wipe out the debt. "We're dealing with four or five bankruptcies a month," said Mr. Kirkland. Where the developer or sponsor still owns units and has also declared bankruptcy, shortfalls are further compounded.
MOREOEVER, assuming the financially strapped owner is eager to cooperate and is indeed trying to get out, it can take months to find a buyer.
 Some associations are cutting corners, trimming cleaning staff, shortening pool hours or closing down the clubhouse. Others are dipping into reserve funds.
"Fifty percent of our properties no longer have adequate reserves because we've had severe delinquency problems in Houston for three years now and this was the way they chose to get by," said Rhonda Burrage, a supervisor at Bay Area Property Management of Clear Lake City, Tex.
 Only by explaining those dangers to residents, said Mr. Pepin, did he recently persuade the owners in a 210-unit condominium in suburban Boston to accept a $110 special assessment payable over three months to recoup a $23,000 shortfall -- $18,000 from unpaid dues and $5,000 for collection costs.
 As the problem worsens, lobbying for corrective legislation is beginning. The Community Associations Institute is planning an effort to alert members of Congress to the seriousness of the situation. And in Massachusetts, managers and lawyers have begun lobbying legislators for "superlien" rights for common charges -- the ability of a condominium association to collect unpaid charges from the proceeds of a foreclosure sale ahead of the first mortgage holder.

SECTION: Section 10; Page 5; Column 2; Real Estate Desk

HEADLINE: Perspectives: The Assessment Roll;
Changing a System of Unequal Burdens

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
BELATEDLY, assessments in New York City rose in the mid-80's to reflect the growth in market values. And now, again belatedly, they have begun to drop to reflect the decline.
The 7 percent drop in overall assessments may have been the most significant news embedded in the tentative assessment roll for the 1992 fiscal year made public at City Hall last month. It has been overshadowed for the moment by the awkwardly timed effort by the Dinkins administration to raise as much as $800 million more from the property tax than it is producing this year. To do that, tax rates will have to rise. 
 Homeowners on average would find their taxes going up about $300 a year from the average bill of $1,340 in the current year. Taxes on apartments -- rentals, co-ops and condominiums -- would on average go up about $230 a unit from a base of $1,430.
The biggest blow would fall on commercial property in Class 4, where billable assessments are still rising from past assessment increases on which taxes are being phased in. Additionally there would be a tax-rate increase of about 12 percent if Mayor David N. Dinkins's fiscal plan is fully enacted.
Property taxes in Class 4 would reach a level approximately double what they were in 1987, according to the Real Estate Board of New York. The year-to-year increase averages out to $1.28 a square foot. For a 10,000-square-foot office tenant, this is a $12,800-a-year rent increase, since tax increases are passed on under standard leases.
Apart from the anomaly of falling assessments and rising property taxes, however, the roll has an interest in its own right. It is the first to be produced under the leadership of Carol O'Cleireican, an economist, as Finance Commissioner. She has pledged a new openness and fairness in the property assessment system. On the first point, she has already made a notable contribution. But on the second, well-wishers may be permitted skepticism. Unfairness in terms of the ratios of assessed values to market values is legislatively built into New York City's assessment system. An argument can be made that the situation is growing worse.
"I know that reform will not be easy," said the Commissioner in a statement that accompanied the publication of the roll, which will become final following adjustments made by the Tax Commission after an appeals period. "But every long journey begins with a first step."
The first steps toward openness have already been taken. This year the Finance Department disclosed to the owners of income-producing properties the figures known as capitalization rates that assessors assign to categories of income-producing property. The assigned rate reflects their judgment of the current value of a building's income stream, or rents after operating expenses are deducted, to a buyer. Rates are influenced largely by geographic location and building age. The lower the rate, the higher the presumed value.
For example, if the net income is $100,000 and the assessors use an 8 percent capitalization rate, the assessed value would be $1.25 million. But if they use a 12 percent rate the valuation would be $833,300.
Last year, owners of so-called Class B office buildings -- older buildings in nonprime locations, including many in Manhattan that were upgraded or changed from manufacturing to office use in the 80's -- organized themselves as the Property Tax Fairness Coalition and commissioned a study by a Los Angeles consulting firm with a Manhattan office, Hamilton Rabinovitz & Alschuler.
"We found that the system as it was administered produced an unfair distribution of the burden on small older buildings compared with prime properties," Mr. Alschuler said. "There was no deliberate attempt at bias, but the lag between the marketplace and the ability of bureaucracy to react is too great."
WITH rents going down and taxes going up, taxes can be expected to consume over 30 percent of every rent dollar in these secondary, or Class B, office buildings over the next two to three years, said Stephen Green, chairman of S.L. Green Real Estate, which manages about three million square feet of office space, mainly in the midtown south area. Mr. Green was an organizer of the coalition.
On the fairness issues, however, Ms. O'Cleireican's task is more formidable. In the New York City assessment system, inequality among classes of property has been legislatively fixed since 1981 and in fact has grown. Many legislators would argue that fairness to small taxpayers requires nothing less. The issue has a history, all of it pointing to the conclusion that "fairness" usually implies raising the tax burden on commercial property.
To overcome a legal threat that the city would be required to reassess all property at the same relationship to market value, the Legislature in effect froze the existing relationships among the classes. Then it put a limit of 6 percent on how fast homeowners' assessments -- Class 1 property -- could rise in one year, with a limit of 20 percent over five years.
As homes rose faster in market value in the 80's than any other property class, they are now being assessed on average at 8 percent of market value.
This year, after two postponements, the Legislature is supposed to adjust the class shares. But it is to be based on changes in market value between 1989 and 1990. It is not likely to result in a radical shift.
Meanwhile, the City Council systematically used its authority in the 80's to lift 5 percent of the tax burden from one class and put it on another. It was lifted from Class 1 and shifted to office buildings and other commercial property. For these properties, at least in Manhattan, high sale prices in the mid-80's and an effort to lift valuations of unsold properties felt to be undertaxed led to rapidly rising property taxes.
As a result, Class 4 properties bore 52.9 percent of the property-tax burden in the current fiscal year, up from 41.5 percent in 1983. If class shares remained unchanged, they would pay the same percentage share in fiscal 1992. The class can be assessed at up to 45 percent of market value. There are no limits on how much assessments can rise in any single year, but higher taxes are phased in over five years under a transitional, or billable, assessment.
MEANWHILE, other small-property owners have lobbied successfully for the caps and phase-ins that have protected homeowners. Two years ago vacant land was moved from Class 4 to Class 1, protecting homeowners with yards that are separate tax lots. Earlier, caps and phase-ins were applied to smaller rental buildings.
The Finance Administration itself, in its proposed assessment roll, has decided to put certain "mom and pop" mixed-use properties under this umbrella, lowering assessed value for 1,500 properties to $1.3 billion from $1.8 billion. The reclassification occurs when 50 percent or more of the space is in residential use. In buildings with three or fewer units, the reclassification is to Class 1. If there are four to six, to Class 2a, or seven to 10 to Class 2b, which also have caps and limited phase-ins.
Among co-op and condominium owners there was an outcry a year ago when assessments leaped in many buildings. The Legislature had tried to protect these owners, too, by requiring that their assessments be comparable with that of rental property. But in certain cases assessors apparently found recently built rentals with close to market rents from which to derive comparables. In others, assessments on co-ops in high market-value areas like the East Side have been held down by the presence of older stabilized rentals with long-term rental occupancy.
Fairness, in a nutshell, will always be an elusive and ambiguous concept in assessments that are set at any less than uniform percentages of value. But if it is defined as the relative share of the tax burden borne by the classes in 1981, it is clear that a major shift away from fairness has occurred over the last 10 years.

HEADLINE: Delinquencies of Condo and Co-op Owners Rising

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS

 BODY:

SECTION: Section 10; Page 12; Column 5; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 178 words

HEADLINE: Businesses Try to Trim Health-Care Costs

BYLINE: By CHARLOTTE LIBOV

 BODY:
SPENDING $11.2 million to build a luxury hotel may not seem like a way to cut down health-care costs. But saving money is the idea behind the New Haven Medical Hotel. The hotel, designed to serve patients recovering from surgery who do not need a more costly hospital room, is one of several new approaches being used by Connecticut businesses to try to control spiraling medical-care costs.
As a growing number of companies rate employee health-care costs as their prime concern, some are installing health-management systems that penalize patients for not obtaining authorization for some medical services. Other employers are requiring workers to contribute more to their health-care costs. 
 "Every year, we do a membership survey to determine the major problems facing our companies," said Jan Spegele, vice president of the legal department at the Connecticut Business and Industry Association in Hartford, a business organization with 7,000 members. "This year, for the third year in a row, the cost of health care has been identified as the No. 1 cost concern for them, and, with the recession, it will be getting worse."
Like its competitors, the state's largest health-insurance carrier, Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Connecticut, has been raising its charges for several years, said a spokeswoman, Paula Laudano. In 1986, the average annual Blue Cross and Blue Shield rate increase for groups with at least 50 members was 8 percent, she said. The average increase was 12.5 percent in 1987 and 23 percent in 1988. In 1989, the average increase was 36 percent and apparently will be the same for 1990 when current figures are compiled, Ms. Laudano said.
To help contain costs, Blue Cross and Blue Shield, which serves 1.2 million people in the state, is instituting a system of "managed benefits" for most of its member groups, Ms. Laudano said. Under the new system, patients must notify the insurer when a hospitalization is imminent, so the expected costs can be reviewed. If the procedure is not followed, she said, the patient may face additional charges.
"If you can't control doctor's costs or what hospitals charge for an admission, maybe you can control that patients are not going in for a seven-day stay when they could go in for a five-day stay," she said.
But some physicians say the time needed to deal with the new insurance procedures will add to, not reduce, medical costs, said Robert Brunell, director of scientific affairs for the Connecticut State Medical Society, which represents 6,000 physicians.
 
Innovative Hotel
 "All of a sudden, the doctor is getting phone calls from people he's never heard of, requiring more paperwork and more time with a claim," he said. "These claims cost him more time, so the cost is probably shifted to other patients and third-party insurers."
Attempts to deliver medical care at lower cost than in a traditional hospital have inspired controversy, too. Blue Cross and Blue Shield said it is not yet certain whether to cover stays at the New Haven Medical Hotel, which opened on Jan. 7. The insurance carrier said it is concerned that the hotel it will increase the overall cost of patients' care.
The hotel features a 28-foot atrium, guest rooms with a total of 93 beds, a swimming pool, restaurant and cocktail lounge. The rooms are comfortably furnished and designed to resemble those in a hotel, not a hospital, said James Cullen, vice president for operations at St. Raphael Hospital in New Haven, one of the investors in the for-profit venture. Other investors in New Haven are the Temple Medical Center, which provides ambulatory surgery; Fusco Corporation, which built the hotel; United Illuminating Company, and 100 local physicians.
The hotel, the first of its kind in New England, charges $190 per night, compared to the average $500 charge for a semiprivate room at St. Raphael, Mr. Cullen said.
The hotel was designed to serve patients recovering from surgery without complications, including those who have undergone open-heart surgery several days before. It will also enable the Temple Medical Center, which offers outpatient surgery, to expand into other services, said Dr. Alvin Greenberg, a neurosurgeon who is president of Temple and the hotel's chief executive officer.
"We saw this as an opportunity to expand the continuum of care," he said. "It is more ambient for the patient, and it saves money, as long as it's safe and there are adequate quality-of-care controls."
 
Dispute Over License
 Blue Cross's concern about the hotel "can be summed up in one word: appropriateness," said Albert May, a spokesman for the insurer. In some cases, patients who might have been discharged to home care might be sent to the hotel, which will be more expensive, he said. Blue Cross said it is also reluctant to cover the costs because the hotel is not licensed by the state as a medical site. But Dr. Greenberg said he was told that no such license is required.
Like employers, workers are also concerned about health-care costs, but sometimes those goals clash.
For the past several years, United Technologies Corporation of Hartford has attempted to reduce the sum it spends on health care for its employees throughout the nation, which is $335 million annually, said Paul M. Thomson, director of compensation and benefits. Workers at United Technologies used to enjoy virtually free health insurance coverage, he said. But last year, a "flexible benefits" plan was enacted for non-unionized employees, who were offered a variety of plans, all which require workers to contribute to the cost of the insurance. The contributions range from 10 to 30 percent of the cost, Mr. Thomson said.
Labor unions that represent United Techologies employees are fighting what they have called an erosion of the health coverage that workers have traditonally enjoyed.
"The labor movement tried to establish a principle that organized workers were entitled to reasonable health care at the employer's expense," said Daniel E. Livingston, a Hartford lawyer who represents unions and employees. "Over the past five or six years, numerous employers have conducted open warfare against that principle. Sometimes it's been financially motiviated, because companies are in trouble. But sometimes it's used as an excuse to go back on gains workers have won in struggles over many years."
United Technologies had tried to create its own health-care network by contracting directly with doctors. The company had planned to create a nonprofit corporation called Valuecare to provide health services for employees of United Technologies and 18 other businesses in Connecticut.
In January, however, the employers decided to give up the effort, after only 250 doctors signed up, far short of the 1,500 Connecticut physicians needed, said Daniel O'Connoll, corporate director of human-resources planning for United Technologies.
Mr. O'Connoll said doctors were unhappy over Valuecare's desire to select among them. But Mr. Brunell of the Medical Society said some members of the group had voiced concerns about some of Valuecare's contract stipulations.
With Valuecare's demise, the problem of health costs "has not gone away," said Mr. Thomson. "We've really scratched the surface with what needs to be done in controlling health-care costs. It's a major national problem."

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY ON THE GULF CRISIS -- PARIS;
Stepped Up Airport Security: Reports From Abroad and the U.S.

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING

 BODY:
On Jan. 2, the first phase of a special security plan known as Vigipirate went into effect all over France, with 200,000 police officers and gendarmes placed on the alert. Phase two, declared on Jan. 17, represents the tightest security France has known since the 1954-62 Algerian war, with 3,000 "sensitive points" given extra protection. These include the Charles de Gaulle and Orly airports outside Paris.
At both, to allow time for new security checks, travelers are being asked to check in 30 to 60 minutes earlier than usual. For Pan Am economy class passengers, for example, this means three and a half hours before take-off. Paris Airports, which runs the two airports, has also urged passengers to travel to Charles de Gaulle and Orly by bus or subway and not by car. Paris Airports said that, on average, half of all flights were leaving Paris 30 minutes late.
A spokesman for Paris Airports said the number of unaccompanied bags destroyed since the war began was considerably higher than the pre-war average of 10 a day. He said several bomb threats had required all or parts of terminals to be cleared, but would provide no details.
At Orly, where many flights to North Africa and the Middle East originate, passengers must now show tickets to the police before approaching check-in counters. Normal X-ray and metal detector devices then check passengers and hand luggage at the departure lounge. Arriving passengers are also being asked to show their tickets before being allowed into the baggage area. Arriving passengers are also being required to show a passport and answer questions when they head for the "Nothing to Declare" exit at Customs.
At Charles de Gaulle Airport, several roads and overpasses have been closed to allow police spot checks on cars. A spokesman for Pan Am said the airline was happy with security at the airport. This has not, however, stopped Pan Am from closing its only downtown Paris office for security reasons, referring all queries the airport.
The sharp drop in passenger traffic has helped security operations. Although January is traditionally a slow month, the outbreak of war brought a rash of flight and passenger cancellations. Air France said that a comparison of the third week in January 1991 with the same period last year showed an 86 percent drop in passenger traffic to the Middle East, a 44 percent drop to North Africa and a 23 percent drop within Europe, but only a 1.8 percent drop to North America.
