HEADLINE: Balancing The Budget With an Idea Borrowed From Past

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN

DATELINE: NEWARK

 BODY:
GOV. JIM FLORIO'S plans to stanch the flow of red ink and balance his $14.3 billion budget for next year include finding some novel revenue sources, including the funds of the New Jersey Turnpike Authority, which previous governors have tried to capture without success.
On Tuesday Mr. Florio met his constitutional obligation to present the Legislature with a budget that is balanced, at least on paper. He told the lawmakers that if they did not like any of his spending or revenue measures, they had better be prepared to come up with the money to pay for any changes. 
 "I come here today because it's my job to propose a budget," Mr. Florio told a joint meeting of the Legislature. "I do not come here with a monopoly on ideas. I know there are things in this proposal that different people and groups might want to change. Let's talk about it."
The Governor's plan to trim 8,000 jobs, some through attrition and buyouts but also with about 3,700 layoffs, has already drawn some grumbling from members of his own Democratic Party. They include Assembly Speaker Joseph V. Doria Jr. of Bayonne and Senate President John A. Lynch of New Brunswick, who are trying to find ways to keep party control of both houses in this November's legislative elections. Mr. Lynch generally praised the Governor's announced aims to make state government smaller and more efficient, but he added, "At the same time, our determination to arrive at a consensus spending plan for the coming year must not ignore the legitimate concerns of all the working people in state government."
The Governor's proposal to sell still unspecified state roads to the Turnpike Authority for $400 million and perhaps to siphon funds from other independent authorities is inspiring the most discussion.
Critics of the plan say that it may be illegal and will probably prompt a lawsuit from bondholders and that, even if it succeeds, it is a one-shot fix that will leave the succeeding 1993 budget with a $400 million revenue gap.
The plan to sell state assets to the authority came on the heels of Mr. Florio's announcement that he would approve turnpike plans to increase tolls on cars by 70 percent and on trucks by 100 percent.
The deputy Assembly minority leader, Gerald H. Zecker, Republican of Clifton, said the Governor's proposal could backfire. "The authority, which has financial problems of its own, would become responsible for the maintenance of these roads," Mr. Zecker said. "So motorists could very well pay for these 'savings' through higher tolls in the future. And I find it disturbing that the Governor would propose such an idea right after approving a toll increase for the turnpike."
But David J. Goldberg, the chairman of the Turnpike Authority and a former State Transportation Commissioner, said, "I told the administration it was worth going through the process of studying the idea."
He said that every Governor had felt that the state's independent authorities had a responsibility to help the state meet its needs and "are not totally insulated just because they are independent authorities."
He recalled that former Gov. Richard J. Hughes, under whom he served in the 1960's, once tried to merge the Turnpike Authority with the Transportation Department in order to use some of the authority's surplus for the state budget but that the idea was voted down.
 
Merger Proposal in 1970's
 John P. Sheridan Jr., another former State Transportation Commissioner, recalled that a proposal to merge the three independent toll road authorities -- the Turnpike Authority, the New Jersey Highway Authority, which operates the Garden State Parkway, and the New Jersey Expressway Authority, which operates the Atlantic City Expressway -- under a single authority and use some of the surplus for state programs was studied during the Cahill administration in the 1970's but never put into action.
Both Mr. Goldberg and Douglas C. Berman, the State Treasurer, said details of how Mr. Florio's plan would be put into effect had not yet been worked out.
"This represents an attempt on the part of the administration to get the maximum utilization out of a resource, and in that sense I'm not troubled by the approach," Mr. Goldberg said. "How we do it and whether it will work, we still don't know."
Mr. Berman said his conversations with state transportation officials, turnpike lawyers and the Attorney General's office "leave me with a high degree of confidence that it can be worked out."
Among the questions to be answered are whether the plan would violate convenants with holders of turnpike revenue bonds or the statute creating the authority and whether the Federal Government would have to be reimbursed for the highway aid it provided for construction of the state roads if the turnpike took them over.
But Mr. Berman said he had talked with Wall Street and had got a positive response because the state had made tough choices last year by increasing its tax base and this year by proposing cuts in the size of state government. Both Standard & Poor's and Moody's Investors Service continue to give a triple A credit rating to New Jersey, one of the few states to enjoy this level of investor confidence, he said.
Last June the Governor's $2.8 billion tax program, which increased the state sales and income taxes, was enacted. It prompted protests from taxpayers and inspired the formation of protest groups who are working to roll back the increases.
Mr. Berman said he recognized the one-time nature of the plan to obtain the turnpike revenue. And he said if the money were going to support some new program, it would be an irresponsible move. But with the tax changes and the planned cuts in government staffing levels, he said, the state is poised to make a strong recovery from the current recession and should not need another infusion of revenue outside the normal tax base.
"In an ideal world, we should not rely on one-time revenue sources," he said. "But this is the real world, and this is a real recession."
Mr. Berman said the money the state hoped to obtain would come from a $2 billion bond issue approved by the Turnpike Authority during the Kean administration. It was designed to pay for a major widening program, but Mr. Berman said $700 million was spent chiefly on planning and environmental studies, prompting Mr. Florio last year to reject the idea of a toll increase for the authority. He said the Governor agreed last month to approve the increase after the turnpike outlined a series of improvements it would undertake in the next five years.
This program will cost $900 million and will leave $400 million from the bond authorization that can not be spent in that time, he said. "A toll increase would be needed anyway to pay off the bond revenues that were already spent," Mr. Berman said.
In his budget address, Mr. Florio also proposed merging the Departments of the Treasury and Personnel, which employ 6,500 people, and combining "dozens of divisions and agencies." He will also place all responsiblity for managing the state's $1.2 billion Medicaid program in the Department of Health, which now shares the responsibility with the Department of Human Services.
He said the program, which provides health care for the poor, made up almost 10 percent of the state budget and was "a major force behind the rising cost of health care."
But the major battle in the coming weeks will come with the unions representing state workers. In addition to the proposed layoffs, the administration wants to lower health and pension benefits for state workers and to forgo pay increases called for in state contracts.
Money to finance these obligations was omitted from the budget, and the administration is preparing legislation to reduce benefits, which Mr. Berman said were better than those for comparable jobs in the private sector.
State officials are negotiating with the unions about the proposed wage freeze. The administration contends that language in the contracts indicates the raises will be paid if the money is available in the budget. The unions disagree with this reading of the contracts and say they will go to court if the raises, amounting to about $188 million, are not paid.

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY ON THE GULF CRISIS -- BANGKOK;
Stepped Up Airport Security: Reports From Abroad and the U.S.

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER

 BODY:
Security has been heightened considerably at Bangkok's Don Muang Airport, hotels and Western embassies since the United States State Department issued a warning Jan. 19 of "possible terrorist action" here.
Tourist arrivals are said to be down as much as 40 percent.
Thai army soldiers are guarding Western embassies and patrolling the airport, and passengers and their luggage are being searched more intensively. The warning to travelers and residents said there is "a credible threat" of terrorism in Thailand and "neighboring countries" due to the war, and it suggested that Westerners "exercise caution." The warning is believed to stem from information that Iraqis with diplomatic status have been moving grenades and other weapons out of their embassy here.
The travel advisory, which has been repeated by the British and Australian authorities, has prompted complaints from Thai tourism officials. Tours are being canceled; walk-in trade is down; tourists here are switching to non-American airlines. Japan Air Lines says 10,000 people canceled bookings for Jan. 17 to Jan. 31, including 4,000 to Southeast Asia. Some United States airlines have canceled flights to Bangkok.
Immigration Department officials, releasing figures a week ago, said say tourist arrivals dropped 40 percent after the war began, compared with last year at this time, when 20,000 tourists arrived in Thailand daily. The recession is also a factor.
The head of the Thai Airport Authority, Air Chief Marshal Somboon Rahong, said the number of flights through Bangkok dropped 10 percent after Jan. 15, but the drop in tourism wascloser to 20 percent.
Tourists moving through the airport said there was no undue delay or complications, and that security guards were polite and helpful.

HEADLINE: Campus Life: Purdue;
Fraternities Adopt A Ban on Kegs At Their Parties

DATELINE: WEST LAFAYETTE, Ind.

 BODY:
Beer kegs will soon be a thing of the past at fraternity and sorority parties at Purdue University. Come March 10, it's strictly B.Y.O.B.
A new policy, written jointly by the Interfraternity Council and the Pan Hellenic Association, prohibits the use of fraternity and sorority chapter money for alcohol, including kegs of beer. 
 Richard R. Halderman, president of the Interfraternity Council and a senior majoring in agricultural economics, said the policy was a response to a court ruling that said serving alcohol from kegs was more of a risk than having a cash bar or having people bring their own bottle.
Because Purdue does not allow the sale of alcohol on university property or in any fraternity or sorority house, the Greek system has adopted the bring-your-own-bottle approach. People can take alcohol to a Greek house if they are identified by a hand stamp or a plastic bracelet as being 21 years old and if the alcohol is given to a bartender, who then gives out tickets equivalent to the number of drinks brought.
 
Alcohol Availability
 Mr. Halderman said the system should cut down on the number of underage drinkers at parties.
"The availability of alcohol is just not there anymore," he said. "When kegs were used, it was easy for anyone to drink from it. This policy shows we are not only concerned about liability but with safety, too."
The policy also requires the host fraternity or sorority to designate drivers and door monitors. A sober patrol comprising both fraternity and sorority members must check periodically at fraternity and sorority parties to make sure they are following the policy.
Melissa K. Bock, vice president of the Pan Hellenic Association and a senior in education from Midlothian, Va., said the policy changes may also help reduce incidents of drunken driving, date rape and alcohol poisoning, which have been growing concerns of Purdue students and faculty. The policy goes into effect March 10.

HEADLINE: World Markets;
The Bundesbank as Bogyman?

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
Both the Federal Reserve Board and the German Bundesbank moved key interest rates last week. On Friday, the Fed lowered its discount rate half a percentage point and was apparently trying to cut the Federal funds rate by the same amount. The day before, the Bundesbank pushed its key short-term Lombard and discount rates up half a percentage point.
While both moves were expected, the timing of each was surprising. 
 The German move raised disturbing questions about the state of international cooperation at a time when the Persian Gulf war makes economic management as difficult as it can be.
The Bundesbank acted just 10 days after the finance ministers of the Group of Seven -- Britain, Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan and the United States -- met in New York. At the session, the United States tried to set a tone for lower worldwide interest rates. The hike in rates ordered in Germany reflected a power struggle within the Bundesbank, analysts said, noting that earlier last week, the central bank's president, Karl Otto Pohl, said an increase in rates now was not appropriate.
Meanwhile, in Washington, the Fed moved sooner to cut rates than many people thought it would. The lowering of the discount rate to 6 percent -- combined with the apparent effort to set a target for the Fed funds rate of 6.25 percent -- represented a new aggressive posture that reflected a deeper concern about the decline of the American economy.
The immediate reaction of world stock markets to the German and American moves was muted.
Equities rose in Europe even though the German move, which will have repercussions throughout the continent, could slow growth and hurt earnings.
In the United States, the Dow Jones industrial average fell 5.70 points Friday. But that decline came on the heels of a 73.77-point rally Wednesday and Thursday that was fueled in part by hopes for lower rates and an early end to the recession.
For its part, the dollar fell Friday to a new post-World War II low of 1.4680 against the mark, but the decline was not precipitous.
Of course, reactions to news events often are muted at first, even when there is an element of surprise. But some analysts said Friday that the shifts in rates would not change their outlook for stock markets for the year because such moves had already been incorporated into their forecasts. Nonetheless, the combination of higher German and lower American rates should push the dollar down at a faster clip than had been expected. This year, the dollar is already down 1.6 percent against the mark.
The Fed's actions show that board members may be much more concerned about the state of the American economy than Alan Greenspan, the Fed's chairman, let on in testimony before Congress last month. At that time, he indicated that the recession could be over soon.
Now, however, it looks as if the Fed is starting to worry that the war in the gulf might drag on. Last week, Mr. Greenspan said in an interview that "if you get beyond three months, you begin to risk consumer confidence erosion and that would abort any meaningful recovery."
The lowering of the discount rate came within an hour of the release of discouraging economic data for January, the first month of the gulf war. Unemployment data for January and the newest report from the nation's purchasing managers showed that the economy may not be in for a quick turnaround.
As for the Bundesbank rate increase, that move "showed just how thick-skinned they can be," said George Magnus of S. G. Warburg in London.
The rise to 9 percent for the Lombard rate and 6.5 percent for the discount rate will increase the economic squeeze on Germany's neighbors in the European Community. It will make it harder for Britain to lower interest rates to fight its recession and for France and other countries to lower rates to counter their slowdowns before they become recessions. It will hurt the dollar. And it will, in part, shift some of the cost of the unification of Germany to its neighbors and allies.
"It is neither the appropriate timing nor the appropriate means," added Norbert Walter, the senior economist at Deutsche Bank in Frankfurt. What should the Bundesbank have done? It should have switched to a floating Lombard rate, Mr. Walter said, a move that would have amounted to less of an endorsement of higher rates.
Mr. Walter said that the rate increase appeared to have been pushed though by the presidents of the country's regional banks, which would have lost significant authority over monetary policy if the Bundesbank had switched to a floating Lombard rate. A floating rate moves with market interest rates, rather than acting as a stimulant for broader increases.
"It was not only a situation when there was a G-7 meeting 10 days ago," added Mr. Walter, commenting on the poor timing of the Bundesbank. "We obviously have a difficult situation with the economies in our neighboring countries," and the interest rate hike "is really posing a problem."

HEADLINE: Chasing Few Buyers With Too Many Tires

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

DATELINE: AKRON, Ohio

 BODY:
Tom H. Barrett has had a gruelling two-year tenure as chairman of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company. Since he took over, Goodyear, once known by its rivals as The Gorilla because of its dominance of the world tire business, has lost the lead to France's Groupe Michelin. And the tire business has taken a turn for the worst.
None of the top companies -- not Michelin, Goodyear or Japan's Bridgestone Corporation -- is faring well. And the uncertainty over oil prices, the unending price cutting and chronic overcapacity among tire producers, plus anemic auto sales, are likely to keep the industry in a tailspin. 
 There are simply too many tires chasing too few buyers. Despite consolidation of the industry into the hands of a few global companies over the last decade and the idling of dozens of plants, producers have been unable to raise prices as industry costs have increased, leaving them little choice but to cut their own costs to make money.
And here, no company has been any more aggressive than Goodyear. As the only publicly traded tire company among the top five, which also includes Germany's Continental and Italy's Pirelli, Goodyear is under greater pressure from investors than its rivals to post quarterly improvements.
Mr. Barrett and his top managers decided last summer to slash the company's capital spending and flatten the layers of management in its North American operation. Over the next two years, Goodyear expects to lay off about 3,000 employees, nearly 3 percent of its work force worldwide -- the largest layoff in its history.
"We have taken some actions that have been difficult, but they will help this company compete," said Mr. Barrett, a plain-spoken man from Topeka, Kan., who has been with Goodyear for 37 years, principally in manufacturing. "These are difficult times for us. And I get a little impatient that we're not moving as fast as we should in some areas."
With up-to-date plants that are as efficient as any in the industry, Goodyear may now be poised for an improvement. Indeed, since the company announced the restructuring, its stock price has climbed. It is trading at around $20, up from $14 in November. Still, that's well down from the $50-plus range of 1989 and last week, the Standard & Poor's Corporation said it was considering downgrading some of the company's ratings.
"A lot of what they're doing is positive, but it's not payting off yet," said Dennis Byrne, a professor of economics at the University of Akron and a tire industry consultant.
Harry W. Millis, an independent tire analyst in Cleveland, said "Oil prices will probably be lower than people expected and Goodyear has done a lot of cost cutting that will show up in the next year," He expects the company to earn $120 million this year. That would be well below its performance in 1989, when it netted $206.8 million on sales of $10.8 billion, but better than 1990. The company has yet to report results for all of last year, but analysts project a net loss of at least $30 million on sales of more than $11 billion.
Tire makers are being tarred in part because they are captives of the auto market. The slump in auto sales has already caused auto makers to slash the price they're willing to pay for new tires by about 20 percent. At the same time, competition in the replacement market, which accounts for about two-thirds of the industry's roughly $47.5 billion in worldwide sales, is forcing companies to cut prices so deeply that profits are thinner than they have been in decades.
"The industry just doesn't seem to make any sense," said Professor Byrne. "It seems as though the major goal among the tire companies is to get market share and they will do anything to sell more tires than the next guy."
Earnings might have been healthier if companies had been shouldering less debt. Each of the top five has taken on a mountain of debt in the last five years either to make an acquisition or, in the case of Goodyear, to fend one off. For instance, Michelin, which recently said that it would report a $400 million loss for 1990, assumed $800 million in debt in its purchase last year of the Uniroyal Goodyear Tire Company. The acquisition vaulted it into the market-share lead, but brought its debt to $6 billion.
Goodyear is the only top-tier tire maker not to have merged in the last decade. Still, it has yet to recover from a 1986 takeover attempt by Sir James Goldsmith, the British investor. To fight off the pursuit, Goodyear sold its highly profitable aerospace division to the Loral Corporation for $650 million and took on $3.8 billion in debt, largely to finance a $2 billion stock repurchase plan. The company's ratio of debt to equity soared to more than 70 percent, from 30 percent, and has since fallen back only to the 60 percent range.
And Goodyear has suffered other headaches that rivals have not. A big one: The unprofitable 1,750-mile crude oil pipeline between California and Texas that it bought in 1985 as a way to diversify. Although the pipeline is designed to carry more than 400,000 barrels of oil a day, it is handling only about 100,000 barrels.
"The revenues are probably not running more than 10 percent of what they had anticipated," said Mr. Millis. "What should have been a $100 million-a-year positive is a $110 million to $120 million drag on earnings."
War in the Persian Gulf, should it push oil prices up, might yet make the pipeline pay. "The question is how good a project it turns out in the long run," Mr. Barrett said. "It has the possibility of doing what we projected." On the other hand, he added, "I'm not saying it's a great investment." And an oil-price rise would hit its basic business hard (box, lower right).
Mr. Barrett is putting more faith in the measures he has taken to retread Goodyear's tire operation. Under his management, the company has established 28 regional offices that report directly to headquarters here. Previously, 43 district offices reported to five regional divisions, which in turn reported to headquarters. In addition to realigning the company's divisions, Goodyear slashed its capital spending budget by about $125 million, to about $575 million last year. And it expects to cut the capital budget further, to $450 million this year.
But the retrenchment has zapped morale of Goodyear's 109,000 workers. Said one senior-level executive, who asked to remain anonymous: "People see the layoffs coming, which have never been part of the Goodyear tradition, and wonder when it's going to end. Employees are feeling a sense of fear of the future that is unusual around here."
When will Goodyear be able to raise prices and lift profits? "I don't see anything in the short term that's going to change and improve conditions in the industry," said John J. Nevin, now retired, who was chairman of Firestone until it was acquired by Bridgestone four years ago. "You've got a recognition on the part of tire makers that, to survive, they have to maintain strong positions around the world."
Professor Byrne contends that 15 to 20 percent of the worldwide tiremaking capacity needs to be shut down before supply and demand come into line. Michelin announced in December that it would close some old Uniroyal-Goodrich capacity. And Goodyear said it is considering some shutdowns of plants. Overall, though, tire makers have been slow to mothball plants.
 Some industry executives hope that further consolidation will improve conditions. Fifth-place Pirelli S.p.A., which purchased the Armstrong Tire Company of New Haven, Conn., in 1988 but is still considered a regional southern European player, last year proposed a merger with fourth-place Continental A.G. of Germany. That would create an $8.4 billion company with about 14.5 percent of the world market. Continental said in January it had no interest in such a move. But Pirelli, which claims it can muster more than half the voting shares of Continental, said it will take the issue before shareholders next month.
Mr. Barrett, meanwhile, seems only mildly daunted by the prospect of resuscitating the old gorilla. "I think you're going to see some improvements for the industry," the Goodyear chairman said. "I feel that Goodyear is a position to maybe improve at a better rate than the rest of them."
 
OIL PRICES ANOTHER PROBLEM
 One wild card in any recovery scenario for the tire industry is oil prices. Higher oil prices after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait put a dent in tire markers' margins. Tom Barrett, Goodyear's chairman, said their costs have increased at least 3 percent since August because of the oil price increases.
That, some analysts say, could mean the difference between making or losing money. The average passenger tire takes about seven gallons of oil or derivative products to produce.
"Under those circumstances you get killed on the cost-price relationship," said Harry W. Millis, an independent analyst in Cleveland. "You can only squeeze out a little black ink, if you're lucky."
Dealers have been resistant to increases in the price of tires, balking at the latest attempt by tire makers to raise prices last fall. Even when they do stick, price hikes are not always helpful. When Goodyear raised prices in the fall of 1988 by about 15 percent, dealers rebelled: Its share in the United States replacement market dropped to about 26 percent, from about 30 percent. Only after lowering prices to match the competition did market share climb back to nearly 30 percent.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Reverberations From a Forgotten Recession

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
When the word "recession" is mentioned on Wall Street, it is the downturns of 1974-75 and 1981-82 that are recalled. But there was another recession sandwiched between those two, one that has been almost forgotten.
That was the recession of 1980, and it may soon seem to be a precursor of our current recession. Then, as now, weak economies suffered a quick blow from an unexpected event. In 1980, it was credit controls imposed by a Government fearing inflation. In 1990, it was rising oil prices and falling consumer confidence, brought on by Iraq's invasion of Kuwait.
There are big differences between 1980 and now. Then, the problem was rampant inflation. Now it is the economy's excessive debt burden. But in both cases the sharp blow was short-lived. Oil prices are now down, just as credit controls were quickly lifted in 1980. In each case, the Federal Reserve responded by aggressively easing credit. 
 In 1980, stock traders responded with alarm to the start of the recession, and with glee to signs that it was ending. The Dow fell 16 percent in less than three months, but regained that ground within a few months and soon climbed above the then-magic number of 1,000. It hovered in that area until the spring of 1981, when evidence of a new recession sent it plunging again. The quickie recession, it turned out, had done little to solve the economy's underlying problems.
This time, the Dow also took less than three months to hit bottom, but it fell further, losing 21 percent of its value. Less than four months later, it has recovered about three-fifths of the lost ground. Last week, the Dow rose 71.28 points, to 2,730.69.
The signs of economic revival now are limited at best: durable goods orders rose in December, thanks to a surge in military buying, and consumer confidence showed signs of reviving after the war began. On the other side are a dismal employment report for January and an even worse survey of purchasing managers.
Still, Wall Street is betting that this recession will be over soon. It is following one of the oldest, and best, pieces of investment advice: Don't bet against the Fed. Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, seems to be determined to push down interest rates, and evidently is quite unconcerned that the dollar is also tumbling.
Other Government officials are also scrambling to stimulate borrowing and avoid blame for the bad economy. Robert L. Clarke is well on his way to losing his reputation as a Comptroller of the Currency with a backbone. Now he says it is O.K. with him for banks to avoid writing down loans by declaring that the assets backing the loans are only "temporarily impaired," as if an increase in prices were a sure thing.
In 1980, the Government managed to end the recession by pumping the economy in every way it could. But while that pleased the stock market temporarily, it did no long-term good, and only set up the country for a longer, and deeper, downturn that began in 1981. That is a precedent that officials, and traders, might do well to recall.

HEADLINE: Hutchinson No Longer Holds Its Nose

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

DATELINE: HUTCHINSON, Minn.

 BODY:
Paul Ackland, Mayor of this prosperous little river city, noticed that his visitor was troubled.
"What's wrong with 3M?" the man asked. The pungent, chemical smell that meant 3M's two big plants were running was missing. The visitor feared that so, too, was the town's biggest employer. 
 It's just the smell that's gone, though. The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company, best known for consumer products like Scotch sealing tape and videotapes, last summer installed $26 million worth of equipment to recycle and burn off solvents from the two plants -- in an area that already meets Environmental Protection Agency standards. After pumping 25 million pounds of volatile organic solvents into Hutchinson's air in 1989, "we are achieving 95 to 98 percent reduction" in emissions, said Carol Neis, a 3M engineer in Hutchinson.
Environmentalists and financial analysts alike say that 3M, perhaps more than any other major American company, is dedicated to cleaning up after itself through a program that provides case-study examples of how managers at all levels should handle environmental issues. It is nowhere near finishing the job, and continues to emit large quantities of toxic chemicals. But it has ambitious goals, and a record of achievement.
"They are one of the few companies that have been doing the right thing for years," said Barry Commoner, director of the Center for the Biology of Natural Systems at Queens College and a long-time environmental activist. "They understand that the way to prevent pollution is to eliminate the production of toxic materials."
The Franklin Research and Development Corporation, a Boston-based investment firm that rates companies on social responsibility, has given 3M the highest ranking on environmental issues on a scale where 1 is the best and 5 the worst. "They are rated 1 on the environment," said Stephanie Leighton, an analyst at the firm. "That is unusual; most companies are down around 3."
At a time when companies big and small must pay closer attention to the toxins they release into America's air and water, the $13 billion company has melded its environmental strategy -- now 15 years old -- into all layers of management and production.
 
The Overall Program
 * It has been building environmentally sound processes into product design and manufacturing to insure that new processes are as clean as possible. A company policy that fosters innovation -- 3M wants to make 25 percent of each division's sales come from products introduced within the past five years -- means that engineers regularly revamp production processes and this provides easy access for pollution-reducing technology.
* In older plants, 3M is investing in pollution-control equipment. It says it will invest $150 million by 1993 to install state-of-the-art air pollution control equipment at its plants, a move that it says will cut air emissions by 70 to 75 percent from 1987 levels. It wants to cut all emissions 90 percent by the year 2000 from a base of 1987; it also wants to reduce the generation of hazardous waste 50 percent by the same date. Others -- including the Monsanto Company and E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company -- have set similarly ambitious targets in recent years as public concern about deterioration of the environment has increased.
* At factories around the country, 3M is forfeiting -- rather than selling -- Federal pollution-reduction credits, a move it says will reduce pollution overall rather than merely allowing other companies to do it. (Box, page 6.)
* The company is using its environmental policy as a competitive tool, offering to help customers reduce their own waste problems by taking back some of its packaging.
* For years, it has been cleaning up its operations before state or Federal regulations force it to do so.
"The company is run by a group of executives who believe in making their own strategic decisions without relying on signals from the Government," said Bruce W. Piasecki, an associate professor of environmental management at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute in Troy, N.Y. For example, it is digging up all of its underground chemical storage tanks, planning to replace them with above-ground units by 1992 rather than 1998 as Federal rules require. Above-ground units are considered to be less hazardous because they reduce the risk of leakage into water supplies.
"Like everyone else we are trying to develop new products more quickly," said Robert P. Bringer, 3M's vice president for environmental engineering and pollution control, the head of its environmental efforts. "But regulations have the opposite effect; they are time expanding. So if we get rid of the pollution, we get out from under the regulations."
As a business strategy, that gets little argument. "They don't do these things because they are in love with nature; they do it because it is smart," said Alfred Marcus, an associate professor at the University of Minnesota's School of Management. "Why spend the money to clean up pollution at the end of the pipe when you can redesign a process to avoid generating it in the first place?"
 
A Major Polluter
 All the praise notwithstanding, 3M has a formidable job on its hands. It has been a major air polluter for years, and it remains the largest emitter of chemicals -- among them, methyl ethyl ketone and toluene -- known to cause or suspected of causing birth defects, according to data filed with the E.P.A. The most recent figures available, for 1988, show that 3M spewed 61.3 millions pounds of toxic materials into the air -- 52.8 million pounds of them linked to potential birth defects. The second-worst company in the E.P.A.'s birth defect category is the General Motors Corporation, at 40.6 million pounds.
In their defense, 3M executives say that the E.P.A.'s classification of chemicals in the birth defect category is based on limited animal tests done at concentrations well above anything that would be encountered near a 3M plant. They also note that the new controls at Hutchinson and other facilities will sharply reduce emissions beginning this year.
Overall, on a list of companies that emit toxic chemicals to the air, land and water, 3M ranks No. 13. Topping the list are Du Pont, Monsanto and American Cyanimid.
"They are good salesmen," said Virginia Yingling, chairman of the Sierra Club's chapter in Minnesota, where 3M has its headquarters. "They are one of the largest polluters in the state. Our impression is they only make changes when it has a good public relations impact or when it looks like the state may take action."
Still, 3M has since 1975 operated a program it calls Pollution Prevention Pays. So far, the company said, 2,511 individual 3P programs have saved $500 million -- $426 million in the United States and $74 million overseas -- by altering processes to avoid the generation of wastes that would have had to be treated. The program has also reduced total pollution to half of what the company said it would have been, given the company's growth and considering production increases.
 
Bringing Initiative In
 At first, the 3P program was based on initiatives at the plant level. Then, in 1989, it was superceded by a more structured plan, 3P Plus. That plan calls for each of the company's 40 product-operating divisions to develop plans to minimize waste and increase recycling. A pollution prevention group monitors these efforts at the corporate level. Meeting environmental goals has become part of the criteria used in annual performance reviews for executives, reviews that determine pay increases and other benefits.
"We think the 3P program has been a model for industry," said Ms. Leighton of Franklin Research.
Some of those close to the company attribute its leadership on environmental issues to its roots in the upper Midwest, where access to the outdoors is highly prized and a clean environment appreciated. "People around here are very conscious of the environment," said Mayor Ackland of Hutchinson, where almost one-quarter of the city's budget -- the largest single item -- is spent on parks and recreation.
Whatever the case, Wall Street likes the company. "People have a lot of confidence in the quality of management," said Curt Rohrman, an analyst with the First Boston Corporation. "I don't know if they get separate Brownie points for their environmental stance, but it all goes into the mix. A lot of the expenditures they are making now on pollution control equipment is spending they will have to make some time, so it makes sense to do it now while profits are strong."
Indeed, 3M expects that the $26 million invested to clean up the Hutchinson plants will produce more than just environmental savings. It said the solvent recovery system at the videotape plant, for example, will save $5 million to $7 million a year in chemicals that had been lost to the atmosphere. That works out to a little under 4 cents per videocassette.
The company envisions other benefits, too. In addition to producing cassettes for home recording, the Hutchinson plant sells bulk videotape to companies that duplicate movies for sale to the public. The big rolls of tape -- called "pancakes" in the trade -- are shipped in plastic foam packaging to protect them from damage. The used packaging is then collected at customer sites and shipped back to the plant where it is used over again. This means 3M's customers do not have to pay for dumping the material into landfills -- an increasingly difficult and expensive proposition in the large urban areas where duplicating companies are located.
 
A Competitive Edge
 "This gives us an edge over suppliers from Japan or Korea," said Doug D. Ward, manager of the videotape plant. "They are in no position to recycle their packaging." Tactics like these have helped 3M hang on as the last major American manufacturer of videotape.
At retail, the cleanup effort also looks bright. "Green products will be a new area of product differentiation over the next 10 years," said Mr. Bringer. The company is already using some recycled wood fiber in its Post-it notepads and plans to use more once it figures out how to remove the glue from the pads.
Several recent surveys have indicated that consumers are willing to pay a little more for products that offer some environmental benefit. That's just as well, as the pollution-related savings are still a way off.
"That equipment being installed in Hutchinson adds to the price of a roll of Scotch tape," said Theodore F. Bolles, technical director of 3M's basic research laboratories in St. Paul. "That has an impact on the survival of American industry in global competition." The capital invested in them, as he and others point out, adds nothing to output and tends to put the company at a competitive disadvantage vis-a-vis competitors in areas with lower environmental standards.
But this doesn't mean 3M should retreat on environmental issues, Mr. Bolles said. Rather, it should develop methods of making things that are inherently less polluting than the ones now used. Research is a big deal at 3M, which spends 7 percent of its annual sales, or about $850 million this year, in the laboratories.
 
Cleaning Up Coatings
 A large percentage of the company's thousands of products -- from sandpaper to tapes to Post-its -- involve putting a thin layer of something on a base material. In the past, that usually involved the use of solvents, which were used to suspend or dissolve the material to be applied and then driven off with heat after application. The problem is that solvents -- like the toluene, xylene and methyl ethyl ketone used at Hutchinson -- combine with nitrous oxides and sunlight to form smog. The new Clean Air Act will tighten allowable emissions of such volatile organics and some state and local restrictions are even stiffer.
In some instances, water can be substituted for the organic solvents. That solves the emissions problem, but adds to energy costs because it takes more heat to evaporate water than the more volatile organics. Nevertheless, water is used for many of the Scotch tapes made here.
At 3M's research laboratories in St. Paul, different coating methods are being tested. Not one involves a chemical solvent. Scientists are testing materials that undergo polymeric reactions when exposed to light; they may become emission-free paints. Other experiments involve laser and electrical discharge treatment of plastic surfaces, enabling them to be coated without chemical preparation.
However, mindful of the negative publicity that manufacturers of plastic garbage bags received after bragging about biodegradability -- when degradability offered little environmental benefit -- 3M is making no advertising claim about recycled contents. "We will take a cautious approach on claims," Mr. Bringer said. He said as definitions of just what recycled means are developed, the company will market as "green" the products that meet the definitions.
 
POLLUTION CREDITS: OPTING FOR A TAX DEDUCTION
 In addition to trying to anticipate regulations and comply with them in advance, 3M has pledged not to sell Federal pollution "credits" -- which allow emissions -- even though it may do so under law and will lose money if it does not.
Companies that install equipment reducing air pollution in areas not meeting clean air standards earn credits based on the amount of the reduction. Under Federal law, these credits can be traded within a region. For example, if a company reduces emissions of a polluting substance by 100 pounds a day, it can sell the right to emit that much more to another company.
Such trading couples economics with environmentalism, or so the reasoning goes: Trading is said to reduce pollution by encouraging companies that can clean up at the lowest cost to do so -- and to let them make money by selling credits to those whose cleanup costs would be higher.
Not everybody agrees with this approach. Critics, including Barry Commoner at Queens College, denounce the practice as just "trading the right to pollute."
Executives at 3M have decided to take the environmental rather than the overtly economic approach by declining to trade any credits the company earns. It is returning any credits it earns to local air quality control authorities, thereby permanently removing that amount of pollution from the atmosphere.
"Top management felt if we sold credits all we would have done is transfer emissions, not reduce them," said Thomas W. Zosel, one of 3M's environmental specialists. "Making money by selling credits was not the purpose of the program. It was to reduce emissions." The company does, however, take a tax deduction based on the value of the credits.
So far, according to Mr. Zosel, the company has returned credits allowing the emission of 1,000 tons a year of organic solvents in New Jersey; 1,059 pounds a day in the Los Angeles area, and 140 tons per year in Ventura County, north of Los Angeles. "We expect to do a few more" in 1991, Mr. Zosel said.
The Los Angeles credits alone could have been sold for more than $1 million, experts say. "Credits are worth $1,000 a pound a day in the Los Angeles market," said John S. Palmisano, the head of Arex, a Washington-based company that brokers air emission credits.
Arex executives said that while some other companies have occasionally turned in credits, 3M is the only one to have a stated policy of doing so.
 
RECAPTURING SOLVENTS

In Hutchinson, 3M has added the equivalent of a chemical refinery to its videotape plant. Its goal: to recover and re-use the solvents toluene, cyclohexanone and methyl ethyl ketone that, in the past, have been released to pollute the air.
At the plant, a system of ducts collects chemicals as they are evaporated off the tape soon after those chemicals have helped apply a magnetic layer that records sound and picture information on a plastic base. The fume-laden air is blown into one of three large tanks -- each 40 feet long, 12 feet in diameter -- that are adjacent to the factory and filled with activated carbon.
The carbon adsorbs, or collects, gaseous solvents, leaving almost completely clean air to be exhausted to the outside. Once a tank begins to approach the limit of its adsorbing capacity, it is taken off line and purged with steam. The solvents are driven out of the carbon by the steam. The steam-and-solvent mixture is transferred to another vessel, where the steam condenses into water. The mixed solvents then are separated in a distillation tower and prepared for re-use in the plant.
Because the solvents are so critical to the quality of the videotape produced, 3M technicans are still testing the recycled product for this use.
But eventually, according to 3M engineers, the recovered solvents are expected to be purer than any they can buy commercially. The recovery system is expected to save the company from $5 million to $7 million a year in purchases of new solvents.

HEADLINE: Business Diary/January 27 - February 1

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
 
Greenspan Points a Finger at the Persian Gulf War
 
Jittery consumers and rising unemployment have made Alan Greenspan change his optimistic tone. On Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Board chairman said that if the war drags on for more than three months, consumers will turn gloomy and the recession will become severe. On Friday, with a dismal unemployment report, he led the board in a unanimous vote to lower the discount rate a half-point to 6 percent, the second cut in six weeks. Banks responded by reducing their prime lending rate a half-point also, to 9 percent. Mr. Greenspan might be doing some pre-emptive rate-cutting and explaining. Politicians say he shares the blame for the recession, President Bush used his State of the Union address to press for lower interest rates, and Mr. Greenspan comes up for reappointment in August. If the economy does crash, Mr. Greenspan is in effect saying blame the war, not me.

The Falling Payroll
 
So much for the notion of a stabilizing economy. The Government said Friday that the nation's payrolls fell by 232,000 jobs and that the average workweek was a half-hour shorter in January. The unemployment rate climbed only one-tenth of a point, to 6.2 percent for the month, the highest rate since 1987, but analysts agreed that the figure understated the deterioration of the economy.

Is It Over Yet?
 
The bleak unemployment picture undermined the weak hint of a recovery in the Government's forecasting gauge, which sent the stock market on a brief mid-week spree. The index of leading indicators for December rose one-tenth of 1 percent, the first sign of growth in six months. Last week's figures on durable goods orders and personal income also came in rosier than expected, if not in full bloom. But many economists want to wait until March or April to decide if sunnier days are truly here. "You have to see three or four months before you see a story," said Lawrence Kudlow, chief economist at Bear Stearns. The decline might be slowing, he said, but he won't declare the recession over.
 
America's Medical Bill
 
It's as if corporate America's largest stockholders, and most insistent greenmailers, were the M.D.'s. Last year, medical costs swallowed up 26 percent of the average company's earnings. The average cost for each employee rose 17.1 percent to $3,217, according to a survey that A. Foster Higgins & Company, a benefits consulting firm, publicized last week. "You cannot have increases like that and continue to be competitive internationally," said Philip R. Lee, who directs the Institute for Health Policy Studies at the University of California at San Francisco. Costs were highest, at $3,500 an employee, in the Middle Atlantic region, which has relatively few cost-containment plans. Dr. Lee admits that, as an Assistant Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare in the 1960's, he was mistaken to expand the supply of doctors in hopes of controlling costs. In general, he now says, the more doctors per capita, the higher a state's medical costs. Many doctors aim to achieve target incomes with busy practices that generate a host of tests and hospital admissions.

The Fed's Chain Reaction
 
Minutes after the Government released unemployment figures for January on Friday, the Federal Reserve lowered the boom on interest rates to stimulate the economy. The move set off a chain reaction among the banks, including J.P. Morgan and Citibank, which lowered their rates. But economists say further cuts will be needed before the economy changes direction. And many are much grimmer about the forecast, saying hard times may last until next year rather than this summer.
 
Dissension on the Bank Fund
 
Last week, L. William Seidman, the nation's top banking regulator, sounded more optimistic about the banking system than either the White House or Congress. Mr. Seidman, remember, was so gloomy last year that Administration officials frequently urged him to leave public life. On Thursday, he said no taxpayer bailout would be needed to keep the bank insurance fund afloat. The fund, rapidly dwindling, will remain solvent, he said, adding, "There is no crisis here." The Office of Management and Budget predicted that the fund will have a deficit in 1992; the Congressional Budget Office predicted one by the end of 1991.
 
 
 
COMPANIES

 
Intel's Japanese-Style Strategy
 
Let other companies scatter their money on high dividends and other means of filling short-term investors with glee. The Intel Corporation will spend as much as $1 billion this year on plant and equipment, probably outdoing any other semiconductor company in the United States or Japan. In the flush times of 1988, Intel spent $450 million. The company is adopting the Japanese strategy of raising capital spending in a recession to charge ahead of competitors.
 
Unfair Advantage for Airlines?
 
Finally, Eastern Airlines' creditors heard some unexpected good news: the carrier's airport gates and flight slots have brought so much interest that the bankruptcy judge handling the liquidation has scheduled an auction for Monday. Airlines are among the likely bidders. The Justice Department's antitrust lawyers -- sensing something anti-competitive about, say, Delta Air Lines maybe having 87 percent of Atlanta's passengers -- have promised to review the sales.
 
A new No. 1 to the sun? Airlines trying to climb out of bankruptcy proceedings usually don't look for ways to expand. But Continental Airlines is trying to capture Eastern Airline's traffic between New York and Florida. Continental added 32 flights last week -- a dozen from Newark to Florida.
 
I.R.S. Catches an Outlaw
 
Farmers are now doing well enough to organize a concert called "Willie-Aid." Mr. Nelson has long cultivated an image as a musical renegade, an outlaw, and now the Internal Revenue Service has taken him at his word, demanding $16.7 million in back taxes. The I.R.S. has auctioned off his Texas ranch, his grand piano and a golf cart shaped like a Rolls-Royce. If the proceeds fall short of the tax bills, Willie Nelson's fans -- Texans, country music lovers and other prideful separatists -- will find that going to his concerts means supporting the Treasury of the United States.
 
Gannett's Tonic for Low Profits
 
The Gannett Company posted its first annual earnings decline since going public in 1967. It is the nation's largest chain of newspapers; its flagship, USA Today, is known to be sassy, quick-reading and upbeat. Gannett earned $377 million, about $20 million less than the year before. The company's advice:
* Don't blame us. The economy's bad.
* Hold the stock. Things might get better.
* Buy our newspapers to cheer you up.
 
USX Separation
 
The USX Corporation filed papers last week for a trial separation from its traditional business of making steel. At the insistence of Carl C. Icahn, the company's largest stockholder, USX agreed to separate its energy and steel operations by issuing new stock for the steel. Mr. Icahn, who has said that spinning off steel would raise the value of USX shares, agreed to buy no more of the company's stock for seven years.
 
Rules of Auction
 
New York's leading auction houses defended their right last week to accept bids from inanimate objects like chandeliers. Auctioneers recognize "chandelier bids" to get things going when nobody else bids an item up to the secret minimum price. The practice is legal in New York City, but some at a state legislative hearing on Wednesday questioned whether it should be. "It's nothing short of an effort to deceive people into thinking there's real competition when their isn't any," said one leading dealer. But John L. Marion, chairman of Sotheby's North America, said a secret reserve price is a " time-tested and universally accepted device to protect sellers from accepting too low a price."
 
In Brief
 
Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation Ltd. reached an agreement last week to reschedule $7.8 billion in debts due this month. The debts, which underwrote Mr. Murdoch's global media expansion, are now due in February 1994.
 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
Fighting Inflation in Brazil
 
All it took to set off a run on cooking gas in Brazil was for President Fernando Collor de Mello to go on television with a warning to conserve it. On Thursday, his Government tried to order a halt to inflation; the monthly rate is now 20 percent. It froze wages and prices and abolished inflation-indexed savings accounts. The plan's success is at best uncertain. The Government insists that the move is an extension of the inflation-fighting program unveiled last year, which included freezing about two-thirds of the money supply. Wage and price controls during the late 1980's capped inflation only temporarily, and now Brazil has fallen into the worst recession in a decade.

Argentina's 'Last, Best Chance'
 
In Argentina, President Carlos Saul Menem treats every economic ailment with the same prescription: a new Economy Minister. With prices again soaring and the country's financial markets plunging, Mr. Menem named Domingo Cavallo on Tuesday as his fourth Economy Minister in less than 19 months. Riordan Roett, a Latin America specialist at the Johns Hopkins School of Advanced International Studies, said Mr. Menem might finally have a Minister with the prestige, charisma and political skill to bring the President's free-market reforms to fruition. "He is probably the last, best chance," Dr. Roett said. The nation's investors, familiar with Mr. Cavallo's record as Foreign Minister, celebrated by bidding up stock prices 30 percent the next day. But inflation is so severe -- the price of sugar was up 40 percent early last week -- that many shops refuse to take credit cards for fear the currency will be worth less when the banks settle. "The problem is, the Argentinians don't believe in Argentina," Dr. Roett said.

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
Global Bond Funds' Gulf Strategy

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
Managers of global bond funds were among the top performers last year. But now they're at the center of wildly volatile international markets. Their worst nightmare, they say, is this: Iraq bombs the oil fields of Saudi Arabia, disrupting world oil supplies, sending up inflation and depressing bond prices. A major breakdown in the flow of oil is the wild card in all of their strategies, the worst-case scenario.
Despite such fears, fund managers in the $4.4 billion global bond market say they have done so much scrambling since the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait in August that they are now sitting tight -- however temporarily -- to see how things unfold. 
 Their major strategy has been to juggle the maturities in their portfolios. When the United States began massing troops after the Iraqi invasion, many managers cut back on the maturities to give themselves more flexibility to react to any developments in the Middle East. But as events began to unfold, they slowly began to lengthen the maturities again, locking in higher rates. Now, as they sit tight, many are trying to find opportunities in the troubled markets.
 "The war was so well heralded that it was discounted in the bond and currency markets," said Gordon K. Johns, manager of last year's top-ranked Kemper Global Income Fund, with $57 million in assets. After the Iraqi invasion, he had shortened the average maturity of his holdings to about three-and-a-half years from six. But in early January, just before war broke out, he lengthened that to more than four years.
Clearly, he and others are trying to extend the gains they racked up last year. As a group, the 30 global bond funds gained 12.4 percent last year, ranking No. 2 among all bond funds, just behind the short-term world income funds. (In that period, all bond funds rose 4.3 percent, on average.) Grouped with the world income funds, they ranked second, too, among all the equity and bond funds tracked by Lipper Analytical Services. (The No. 1: health-and-biotechnology funds.) And two global bond funds were among 1990's top 10 performers: Kemper Global Income, with a 22.7 percent gain, placing it sixth among the 3,110 funds ranked by Lipper, and the Scudder Global International Bond Fund, up 21.1 percent, for 10th place. Much of that performance came from currency gains that followed the dollar's plunge against foreign currencies. Money managers do not expect that to be repeated this year because the dollar is so cheap. Instead, they say, performance will be driven simply by rising bond prices.
S. Mark Turner, who manages Scudder's International Bond Fund, with $200 million in assets, has been extending the maturities in his fund, to more than five years at present, to lock in high rates worldwide. And he is looking beyond the war, which he says is obscuring an unfolding recessionary environment worldwide. The war may well push fragile economies like those in Canada, Australia and Britain into recession, he said.
"The real worry that people had was an oil price spike to $40 or $50" a barrel when war broke out, said Bill Kohli, who manages the Franklin Partners Tax-Advantaged International Bond Fund, with $4.3 million in assets. That didn't happen, so "we're starting to look at longer bonds," with a duration that could stretch 10 to 20 years, he said. He is avoiding the United States Treasury market in favor of Canada, with its higher interest rates and, he says, lower risk. If the gulf conflict isn't resolved quickly, he fears "significant economic consequences as the United States seeks to borrow to finance the war."
Looking past the war is not so easy for Nimrod Fachler, manager of the Paine Weber Master Global Income Fund, with $1.4 billion in assets, whose high school in Tel Aviv was leveled by an Iraqi missile. Still, he and others say the country to watch is Germany, not Iraq. That's because the costs and pace of German unification are now clear and the Bundesbank is tightening credit, which is pulling up European interest rates. But those rates may not be sustainable. "As soon as people realize the war is over and oil isn't a problem, long-term interest rates will fall," Mr. Fachler said. Since mid-December, he has lengthened maturities to nearly five years, from less than two.
In the end, war puts a damper on economic growth, an ideal environment for bonds to flourish. "War is a terrible thing," said David P. Boardman, manager of the $444 million T. Rowe Price International Bond Fund. "But the reduced economic activity sets the stage for future bond market gains, if inflation is controlled."
Les Nanberg, manager of the $150 million MFS Worldwide Governments Trust, says the war has given him "a more cautious view on bonds in the near term." But unlike his colleagues, he is shortening the average maturity of his portfolio from 10 years to roughly five-to-seven years. He has doubled cash levels to 20 percent, arguing: "I'd rather be in cash and find out tomorrow that the war is over and risk a little of the upside than to be fully invested and find out that things aren't working out as expected."

HEADLINE: FORUM;
The War's Inevitable Fifth Horseman

BYLINE: By THOMAS FERGUSON; Thomas Ferguson is professor of political science and senior associate at the John W. McCormack Institute of Public Policy at the University of Massachusetts, Boston.

 BODY:
As the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse rampage east of the Suez, yet another scenario for a short, bargain-priced war is vanishing in the sands. The ghastly implications of this"creeping Vietnamization" are clear. But human sacrifices will not be the only costs.
In modern wars, a Fifth Horseman always trails behind the more familiar quartet to claim the toll on mountains of debt run up by the armies as they fire the cash equivalent of Mercedes-Benzes back and forth at each other. In 1991, this horseman's long, black shadow already stretches far across America. 
 Back in November 1990, when Desert Storm was still Desert Shield, the Center for Defense Information, a private research organization in Washington, estimated that the operation added about $74 million a day -- or $27 billion a year -- to the military budget.
This sum, however, did not take account of subsequent deployments, later revelations that the Pentagon was paying premium prices for equipment acquired on short notice or the gigantic costs of canceled debts and foreign-aid payments funneled to third world economies devastated by the crisis. For example, the United States has already forgiven about $7 billion in loans to Egypt alone. As of last December, at least half a dozen more countries had also received money from the allied coalition.
Once the air war started -- at about $500 million a day -- the sky became the limit in many senses. A recent Congressional Budget Office report suggests that a short, one-month war could cost about $28 billion while a longer one of six-months would cost $86 billion. But these widely repeated figures also neglect the costs of foreign aid and debt forgiveness.
The Administration, however, argues against any tax increase, claiming that the war amounts to an extraordinary one-time expense, which should simply be rolled into the deficit.
The Bush team also suggested that the allies and the gulf states will bail out the United States by agreeing to pick up much of the tab, a claim the President advanced himself in the State of the Union address.
These assertions essentially represent a very curious new "voodoo economics" of war.
While Administration economists sit in one room of the White House explaining that the war is a one-time expense, their colleagues down the hall at the National Security Council and across town at the State Department are leaking sweeping plans to restructure the whole Middle East once the shooting dies away.
Now it is perfectly obvious that the web of bilateral treaties and special security agreements American policy makers envision for the region will be spun from threads of the purest gold. Foreign aid "loans" -- better read as grants -- and, particularly, foreign military assistance, are destined to skyrocket. And while the Chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, argues that costs can be contained by not replenishing depreciated equipment, the postwar scenarios envision a massive pre-positioned buildup in the desert for possible future use.
The golden cloud does come with a silver lining: Saddam Hussein is an authentic monster whose departure will be extensively unlamented.
But there is a tunnel at the end of the light. Apparently unaware of how its "new world order" looks to the vast mass of poor Arabs, Washington now appears determined to throw its full weight behind a set of quasi-feudal regimes on the verge of a head-on collision with democracy and the 20th century. This we have all seen before and as we know, implies further visits by all Five Horsemen.
As for the allied promises to pay, the paltry amounts actually anted up thus far suggest that for purposes of realistic fiscal planning, these must be regarded as the equivalent of sovereign "junk bonds": worth something, but much less than face value.
Nor is it reasonable, once the war ends, to expect either the gulf states or the allies to finance a Middle Eastern Pax Americana at anything remotely resembling concessionary rates. Obtaining foreign financing for two major wars cost Britain its empire; in the long run, Americans cannot expect to pay any less if they go that route. Citizens and especially the Congress, accordingly, should recall that the policy makers who now assure them that foreigners will open their wallets are the same ones who said the allies would open their markets.
The Fifth Horseman, however, is implacable. He must still be paid. How?
Probably not in steeply inflated dollars. For this to occur, the political and economic establishment would have to be prepared to cede the international role of the dollar. This is about as likely as oil flowing uphill.
In the end, it is all too clear who will pay. American overseas assistance to less strategic areas will be cut even more, but most of the costs will come out of the domestic civilian sector.
Spending on virtually everything besides the military will be even more desperately squeezed. Financial pressures on states and cities will intensify. However, many of the foregone expenditures are precisely those that are most vital to the revival of American productivity.
But the Fifth Horseman will claim still more. In the short run, extra military spending will help pull the economy out of recession. But as the economy revives, the tumescent deficit will keep fueling total demand. To limit inflation, the Federal Reserve will have to tighten the money supply, bringing the economy right back to the devastating combination of tight money and expansive fiscal policy that defined real-life Reaganomics.
In the short run, as we learned in the 1980's, such policies can produce political business cycles substantial enough to guarantee the re-election of almost any regime. But as we also learned in the 80's, the cost in terms of long-term industrial competitiveness is steep: fixed investment by business -- outside of the military sectors -- is desperately squeezed, while import-competing and interest-sensitive industries like automobiles are hammered.
The Fifth Horseman's ultimate victims will thus be the middle- and working-class Americans whose real earnings will continue falling while racial and economic inequality increase.

HEADLINE: All About/Denim;
The Appeal of Blue -- Now Red or Green -- Jeans

BYLINE: By ANNE-MARIE SCHIRO

 BODY:
High-fashion denim, these days, means much more than designer jeans. Franco Moschino covers a denim jacket with transparent sequins. Donna Karan shapes a strapless denim minidress. As sales of blue jeans flag, designers are devising new uses for a familiar fabric.
These novelties tickle the fashion-conscious, but to most people denim still means jeans. More than 650 million square yards of denim are produced in this country every year, mainly by automated factories in the South. At least 90 percent of the denim goes into the basics: blue jeans, jackets, overalls and skirts. The domestic denim market has matured as a vast business. At $6 billion in 1989 retail sales for jeans and $8.25 billion for all denim clothing, it represents one of the largest categories of apparel. 
 Jeans and denim manufacturers remain optimistic despite fluctuations in their markets. Domestic demand has suffered from turmoil in the retail industry, a recession and the graying of the jeans generation, but foreign demand is on the rise. Manufacturers continue to expand the variety of jeans with new fabric finishes, colors and styling. "The key to the growth of the jeans business is innovation," said Arnold Elder, a vice president of Swift Textiles Inc., a major denim manufacturer. "In order to get a person to buy another pair of jeans, the eye must be attracted to something different."
 
Made in the U.S.A.
The Big Mills Are In the South
 The United States produces more denim than any other country, primarily for domestic use but increasingly for the world market. The largest denim mills bear little resemblance to the crowded plants of the past. Towering machines suck cotton from bales and spin it into yarn, dyeing the fibers, then weaving them into fabric that flows onto wide 600-pound rolls. The plants are spacious, but eerie for the scarcity of employees, whose duties are mainly to adjust the computer controls and tweak the machines.
Swift Textiles Inc., a United States subsidiary of Dominion Textiles Inc. of Montreal, is generally regarded as the world's largest supplier. For the year ended last June, Swift Textiles sold more than $300 million of denim, supplying major jeans makers like Levi Strauss, Lee, Wrangler, Sassoon and Liz Claiborne.
Next comes the Cone Mills Corporation of Greensboro, N.C., privately held but willing to confirm an annual output of more than 165 million square yards. The company says Levi Strauss is its largest account, since almost all the denim for Levi's best-selling five-pocket 501 jeans comes from Cone Mills. It also supplies Oshkosh B'gosh, Calvin Klein and Polo/Ralph Lauren. Industry executives say the next-largest producers are Greenwood Mills Inc. of Greenwood, S.C., and then Burlington Industries Inc. of Greensboro, N.C.
The mills have learned to produce much more than the traditional, 14 1/2-ounce-per-yard denim used in 501's. The fabric can be as light as 4 1/2 ounces, known as chambray, or as heavy as 15 1/2. About 90 percent of the denim is pure cotton, with 10 percent containing some polyester and a very small percentage incorporating stretchy spandex. Four of every five yards are indigo blue.
More American-made denim is going to South America, the Far East and especially Western Europe, which imports 40 million to 50 million yards annually. This amount is more than all the other markets combined, said Nessim Levy, president of the Level Export Sales Corporation, which sends Cone Mills products to Europe. Fashion-conscious Italians buy the most from the United States. American denim and jeans makers hope to find large new markets in Eastern Europe.
But denim production is by no means limited to the United States. Europe weaves an estimated 275 million square yards annually, while Japan fills much of its own demand and imports some from Hong Kong.
Arnold Elder, a vice president of Swift Textiles, said exports can more than make up for stagnant domestic consumption. "Denim is being worn today for everything from casual sportswear to shirts to dresses," he said. "It's acceptable around the world."
 
Levi, the Leader
Foreigners Want The American Look
 Levi Strauss & Company, a privately held corporation with headquarters in San Francisco, remains by far the largest jeans company in the world. Since Levi's founding in 1850, when a Bavarian immigrant used French cotton serge to sew sturdy trousers for California miners, the company has stitched up two and a half billion pairs. Sales reached $3.6 billion in 1989, with more than $4 billion estimated for 1990. The figures include Levi's Dockers, a line of cotton twill pants introduced in 1986, with sales of $600 million last year. Dan Chew, Levi's marketing manager, attributes the company's steady growth to the success of Dockers and the increased global demand for American jeans.
Europe is Levi's biggest foreign market, but Asians also like the American look. "Even though we manufacture in Japan for the Asian market," Mr. Chew said, "Asians go to great lengths to obtain Levi's 501's made in the United States, so we do export some American-made jeans to Asia."
Mr. Chew said Levi Strauss sells twice as many jeans as its closest competitor, Lee Jeans. Both Lee and Wrangler are subsidiaries of the V.F. Corporation of Reading, Pa., the country's largest publicly held apparel company. Lee estimates that it has sold one billion pairs during its one-century lifespan.
Jeans makers are still trying to develop computers and machines that can stitch up pants as well as they can weave fabric. Most jeans factories have rows of women tending sewing machines, with computers reserved for cutting patterns, tracking orders and managing inventory and distribution.
 
The Designer Craze
Paying for a Name On the Pocket
 Farmers, ranchers and laborers have always worn denim work clothes, but as a fashion for those with whiter collars, blue jeans have been cyclical. They represented social rebellion in the 1960's and entered the realm of high fashion in the late 70's and early 80's. When Brooke Shields promoted one designer by cooing about her Calvins, other designers rode the trend. Jeans sales reached an all-time high of 502 million pairs, 77 percent of them denim, in 1981.
Much of the appeal of designer jeans still lies on their back pockets, where labels like Calvin Klein, Gloria Vanderbilt or Ralph Lauren merit prices of $70 to more than $100. Basic jeans can be found for less than $20.
Designers who insist the extra money buys sassier styling do not discount the value of cachet. "Designer jeans historically cost more, but you buy a name and a fit," said Denise Seegal, president of DKNY, Donna Karan's less expensive line of sportswear.
DKNY spawned DKNY Jeans last year as a separate division, and Ms. Seegal projects sales of $40 million in 1991. But the basic DKNY jeans that sold for $85 in 1989 can now be had for $70. "I took a haircut to lower the price to position myself to compete," Ms. Seegal said. But Donna Karan is no kin of Levi Strauss. "When a store asks me why we can't sell jeans for $20," Ms. Seegal said, "I tell them that if you produce a million pairs, it costs less than producing a thousand pairs or a hundred thousand."
A designer's name may sell the first pair of jeans, but it will not necessarily produce repeat sales, some jeans makers have found. The customer must be tempted by something new, something he or she does not already own.
Now there are black jeans and white jeans, jeans in several colors absent even from the rainbow. All manner of finishes -- bleaching, over-dyeing, acid-washing, stone-washing, sand-blasting and even shotgun-blasting -- give denim a new, or old, look.
Until five or six years ago, 70 percent to 80 percent of the Levi's sold were rigid or slightly prewashed, said Mr. Chew. Now, 80 percent have further finishes. About 35 percent are acid-washed ("But that's on the way out," he said) and 30 percent stone-washed. All these washes and finishes make jeans softer and more comfortable. What's more, the styles make the wearer look like the survivor of a month on the ranch, a landslide, a shootout or at least a good dunking in a Clorox vat.
 
 
THE LITTLE BLACK DENIM DRESS
 Donna Karan calls denim the new gabardine. She uses it for much more than jeans. She has had a denim blazer in her DKNY line for two years and included denim in her latest high-fashion collection for spring. She uses a silk-and-cotton denim for dresses, jackets and skirts that bear as little resemblance to jeans as a cocktail party does to a hoedown. Her prices befit her clientele of movie stars and top executives: $640 for a short, strapless denim dress, $1,000 for a satin-lined denim coat.
Such are the inspirations that have allowed Ms. Karan to become one of the hottest designers in the country, building sales of more than $150 million in six years. "Denim is wonderful to style," she said. "It comes in different weights and it tailors beautifully. Everything can be made in it. Denim for me is a classic. It's a seven-days-a-week, day-to-night fabric."
Young American designers like Rebecca Moses and Zang Toi also used denim in unconventional ways for spring. Ms. Moses made a bustier and pants covered with transparent sequins. Mr. Toi used bright pink and red denim for short trench coats, strapless dresses and boleros with jeweled fringes.
American designers are not the only ones pursuing denim panache. Franco Moschino, the enfant terrible of Italian fashion, has a jeans line that racked up worldwide sales of $80 million last year. The line includes sundresses, sequin-covered jackets, skirts trimmed with beaded fringes and denim pants with pleated legs of see-through rayon.
The basic slacks account for only 10 percent of Moschino Jeans sales. To keep the price of these pants down to $32 wholesale, they are made in this country. The rest of the line is sewn in Italy of American-made denim from Cone Mills and Burlington. "In Italy, people wear Moschino jeans the way we wear Levi's," said Anne Marino, executive vice president of Simint U.S.A.
Simint, an Italian holding company, manufactures and markets Italian designer jeans and leisurewear, including Moschino's. The largest leisure apparel company in Italy, it also makes and distributes Armani Jeans in Europe and supplies the jeans to Emporio Armani boutiques in the United States.
Armani Jeans, a $100 million business, was one of the first to offer jeans in a wide range of colors and finishes, including ones it calls smoky wash, ice-blue wash and tea wash.
Like other designers looking to the 1960's for inspiration, Mr. Armani has turned to the past in his jeans line, reviving tie-dying. And Norma Kamali has reintroduced another 60's fashion that may portend the next direction for jeans: bell-bottom hip huggers.
