HEADLINE: FORUM;
Afterward, Make Africa a Priority

BYLINE: By SALIM LONE; Salim Lone, a Kenyan, is editor of the United Nations periodical Africa Recovery.

 BODY:
When the war in the Persian Gulf is over, the United States will turn to the other pressing international concerns that need its attention. But there is a growing fear among United Nations, African and other development officials that one vital concern -- the deepening, decade-long economic crisis in Africa -- is unlikely to feature prominently in the post-gulf agenda of the United States and the other major aid-giving powers. Such neglect would deal a severe blow to the profound but largely unreported political and economic reforms being undertaken on the continent -- reforms that are Africa's only hope for reversing what is nothing less than an economic and social nightmare for its peoples.
Even before Jan. 16, when the war in the Persian Gulf began, it was getting increasingly difficult to mobilize the kind of attention from which Africa benefited in the mid-1980's, when a special session of the United Nations put the region firmly at the top of international development concerns. The democratic revolutions of Eastern Europe and the need to financially support their market reforms rapidly pushed Africa down the list of Western priorities. The ending of the Cold War also stripped the continent of its strategic significance to the superpowers. And Africa's puny contribution to international trade made it seem less and less relevant to the economic growth of richer nations. 
 If this marginalization continues, the dire present will lead to a cataclysmic future. Africa is the only continent where the gap between food production and food needs continues to widen. If present trends proceed unchecked, the continent's already crippling deficit of about 15 million tons of maize in 1990 is projected to grow within 30 years to 200 million tons -- nearly equal to the annual cereal output in the United States. Similarly, by 1995, Africa's poor will have nearly doubled, to 405 million from 210 million in 1985, while the proportion of those living in poverty will have substantially declined everywhere else in the world. And the just-released annual report of the Economic Commission for Africa reveals that per capita incomes fell again, for the twelfth straight year. The scale of Africa's woes can best be gauged by one stunning statistic: the nearly 500 million people of sub-Saharan Africa have a combined gross domestic product lower than that of the New York area.
There is an explicit link between such levels of deprivation and the bloody civil wars that rocked Liberia, Somalia, Chad and Rwanda during 1990. Predictions of even greater breakdowns of political and civil order abound.
A number of things need to happen if this grim scenario is to be averted. By far the most important of these -- the political and economic reforms within African countries themselves -- are well under way across the continent. The vast majority of African nations, including such determinedly socialist ones as Mozambique, Tanzania, Algeria and Ethiopia, have adopted painful, and politically risky, market-oriented economic reforms.
But the assistance that had been promised by the West to insure the success of these reforms has yet to materialize on anywhere near the scale needed. Instead, Africa watches helplessly, and with increasing bitterness, as much larger support for the Eastern European reforms is mobilized at record speed.
Action on two of the three urgently required areas of assistance -- debt relief and easier terms for receiving aid -- can be provided relatively painlessly by the West. The third area, finding ways to stabilize income from commodity exports, will take some doing. The prices of commodities, which account for 90 percent of the continent's income, plummeted throughout the last decade. The price index of two of Africa's major exports, cocoa and coffee, slid from 100 in 1980 to less than 40 in 1989. Finding a solution to this and other trade issues will take negotiation.
But action in the first two areas can come quickly and unilaterally from the richer countries. Recognizing that Africa's debt burden of $270 billion is unbearable as well as unpayable in full, Western governments, to whom the bulk of the debt is owed, have repeatedly indicated since 1987 that they intend to provide significant debt relief. The pace of this relief is perilously slow.
African governments are also pressing for relief from the stringent set of standardized policy prescriptions that are now a precondition for aid. As indicated, most African governments have demonstrated in practice their commitment to reforms favored by donors. Such governments now need to be given greater freedom in formulating policies they believe are appropriate to their particular environment. This is especially true since there is growing evidence that some external prescriptions -- such as cutting subsidies on food and social services for the poor -- are in fact deepening poverty and inhibiting economic recovery.
These are small prices to pay for a continent in severe distress. The cost of not paying now is rising every month, in dollars and in lives.

HEADLINE: Lower the Boom on the Bankers

 BODY:
To the Editor:
A recent Market Watch dealt with a different standard for accounting for banks, ("Alice Meets the Accountants," Dec. 30). The real problem, of course, is not accounting methods, it is incompetent bankers. An article in Fortune in the late 1940's, "The American Genius For Bankruptcy," contained the statement: "Americans want banks so bad that even you and I can borrow from them." It is not polite to mention it, but we have suffered from incompetent bankers in this country for over two hundred years.
The solution, then, is not deregulation but better regulation. The savings and loans institutions were crippled by high interest rates that resulted from the Federal Reserve system's tight money policy, so Congress permitted them to make loans in fields where they had no experience. There was fraud, but that was a very small part of the problem. As Fred Schwed Jr., said in the 1954 edition of "Where Are the Customers' Yachts,": "Investors like to think they were robbed, rather than that they were fools on the advice of fools."
 
JARED S. WEND
Kalamazoo, Mich., Jan. 18

HEADLINE: Unexplored Territory, A Recession in Services

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
The unusual wave of white collar layoffs in the early stages of this recession is a sign that the United States service sector, once heralded as a powerful engine for new jobs, is undergoing a broad retrenchment, much as the manufacturing sector did in the past decade.
And economists are predicting that the trend may worsen the recession and slow the pace of a recovery in the short run. "It's one of four or five factors that will be a drag on growth," said Robert Gay, an economist at Morgan Stanley & Company.
 
Sharp Contrast to the Past
 This is a sharp contrast to previous experience when regions with established service industries were often protected from extreme pain in recessions. 
 Unemployment will climb more than it would otherwise. "In the last recession, services were a sponge that soaked up laid off factory workers. Now you don't have that," said Mitchell S. Fromstein, chairman and chief executive of Manpower Inc., a temporary help concern based in Milwaukee. The Blue Chip consensus of economic forecasters expects unemployment, at 6.2 percent in January to reach 6.6 percent or more in a few months.
Over the long term, economists say, the nation's economy will benefit from this streamlining in the services, justas America's smokestack industries benefited from the retrenchment in the past decade. A leaner, fitter service sector, they predict, will help ease two perennial problems of the American economy: wage inflation and sluggish productivity growth.
Apart from the health-care field, which has an endless appetite for workers, service companies like retailers, financial service, accounting, real estate and temporary-help firms, have shed 208,000 jobs since August, according to a Labor Department report issued Friday. The latest monthly employment data showed that most service industries continued to cut jobs in January. "The services are weakening more rapidly than in past downturns," said Bruce Steinberg, an economist at Merrill Lynch.
The emerging picture is that service companies went on a hiring binge during the 1980's. Retailers, restaurants and financial service firms, the producers of "invisibles" added a stunning 19 million jobs -- all the new jobs generated by the private sector since the end of the last recession in 1982. But while payrolls bloated, white-collar productivity languished. "Some service firms display the same excesses -- too many employees and high operating costs -- as manufacturing firms going into the last recession," said Mickey D. Levy, an economist at CRT Government Securities in New York.
One reason for the decline in the service jobs is that the demand for some services is shifting. Consumers, who have not saved much, are curtailing their spending. Corporate appetite for debt is fading. And takeover activity on Wall Street long ago eased from the fevered pace of the 1980's.
The result: too many banks, retail stores, fast-food restaurants and other service establishments. "The primary problem is that services expanded faster than long-run demand," said Mr. Steinberg of Merrill Lynch.
 
Worse on Wall Street
 Nowhere has the cutting come closer to the bone than on Wall Street. Securities firms have already shed 50,000 jobs, 20 percent of the work force, since the 1987 crash. But revenues have fallen even more, and the industry is now in the red. So more cuts are coming, including further layoffs, pay cuts, canceled perks and, most important, efforts to consolidate huge, underused back office operations that process the river of paper. "Many service industries are reinventing themselves," said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, regional commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics in New York. "It started a while ago and there's no end in sight,"
New York, which got off relatively lightly in the last recession, will have a longer, deeper recession than the entire country. Here, 9 of 10 jobs are service jobs compared with 8 of 10 throughout the United States. As of December, New York City payrolls had shrunk 3 percent compared with 1 percent for the country, the opposite of what happened in the last recession. In fact, the recession here started a year before the national one, Mr. Ehrenhalt said. Forecasters at DRI/McGraw-Hill, an economic forecasting firm in Lexington, Mass., also expect the New York recession to last longer.
 
More Mergers Expected
 More mergers are in the offing, too, especially among the more than 12,000 banks. Thanks to a bundle of bad real estate loans, the Government predicts that 340 banks will fail in the next two years and some of the country's largest banks are seriously short of capital. All banks face increasingly fierce competition for the best customers from non-bank lenders like mortgage companies and finance companies.
Low-cost companies are gobbling market share from high-cost firms. Take retailing, which added three million jobs during the 1980's. Bernard Sosnick, an analyst at Deutsche Bank in New York, said, "The strong are getting stronger." For example, hard- driving Wal-Mart Stores Inc. opened 175 new stores last year, but Sears, Roebuck & Company, the country's biggest retailer, just announced 21,000 job cuts and is contemplating the sale of its 103-year-old catalog division.
 
Effort to Increase Efficiency
 
Elsewhere, companies are working overtime to increase efficiency, trying to squeeze more sales out of the exisitng work force or maintain sales with a smaller staff. Productivity in the restaurant business has actually fallen in the past decade. Facing a saturated market, some fast-food chains are reducing the amount of kitchen space to create more space for customers. So they are experimenting with new grills or using food prepared elsewhere under factory-like conditions. "Everybody's trying to cook more food with fewer hands," said Michael G. Mueller, an analyst at Montgomery Securities in San Francisco.
Service companies are using computer technology to contain costs as well as improve quality. Price Waterhouse, the big accounting firm, is using a new computer technology to make huge amounts of sophisticated information easily accessible to its auditors. They are investing in such technology "to make life more interesting," said Arthur H. Siegel, vice chairman for auditing and accounting. It has an important side benefit: the firm will need to hire fewer junior auditors each year -- about 900 instead of 1,300.
Now when service firms are expanding, they are expanding mostly overseas. McDonald's Corporation built more Golden Arches overseas than at home last year.
"This is a permanent change, not just a response to the recession." said Mr. Gay of Morgan Stanley. "The era of indiscriminate hiring in services is over."
More restrained hiring by service companies would help get inflation down by easing the pressure on wages, a main element in inflation's momentum. There are already signs of some slowing. In the past year, compensation costs in service industries rose 4.8 percent, compared with 5.1 percent in the previous year.
Even more important, the overhaul in the service industries is key to overcoming the nation's chronic white-collar productivity problem. While efficiency gains in the nation's factories in the 1980's were stunning, productivity in the services as a whole stagnated.
 
An Early Positive Effect
 The unusually steep cutbacks in the service sector may already be having some effect, Mr. Gay said. He notes that the number of hours by non-farm employees worked fell further than non-farm output last fall. He concludes that productivity probably edged up. "That's never happened in the first quarter of a recession before," he said. "Productivity always falls at the beginning of recessions as companies hang on to workers while they try to figure out how long the downturn is likely to last."
The typical pattern in the past was that service companies just slowed down hiring when a recession started, but did not freeze or shrink payrolls. A recession was usually about a year old before that happened. And in shorter recessions, service employment usually continued creeping up.
This time, payrolls were frozen a year before the economy slipped into a recession and jobs were cut in the first months of the recession. "These industries were in trouble already," said Mr. Gay, the Morgan Stanley economist.
So that great American job machine, the service sector, is grinding into lower gear. But not everybody is complaining. Alan Sinai, president of the Boston Company Economic Advisors, said, "The benefits from lower inflation and faster productivity growth will provide a healthy foundation for future growth."

HEADLINE: As Economy Changes, the Port Authority Must Overcome Its Own Image

BYLINE: By RICHARD LEVINE

 BODY:
Tapestries adorn the walls and helicopters carry officials to meetings, but these days the once-prosperous Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is in the unaccustomed position of paring costs and pleading for money.
Stagnant revenues, rising expenses, the travails of the airlines, shifts in trade and, to an extent, some of the authority's own initiatives have led it to seek a $1 increase in bridge and tunnel tolls only months after a similar plan was withdrawn in the face of opposition. 
 In renewing its campaign for higher tolls, the authority is trying to overcome its free-spending image and stressing its role in spurring growth as the regional economy stumbles. It asserts that 425,000 jobs depend on business sectors "anchored" by its investments and that another 166,000 construction and 20,000 permanent jobs will be generated by what it hopes will be $5.4 billion in new capital spending over the next five years and private investment that will accompany it.
 
2 Postponements
 But without higher tolls, the agency says, it will be forced to cut into plans to rehabilitate and expand not only its Hudson River crossings but also the region's airports -- just as they face increasing competition from airports in other parts of the country.
And even with a rise, expanding the capacity of the Goethals Bridge between Elizabeth, N.J., and Staten Island, building a rail link to Kennedy International Airport and unclogging the all-too-common jam in the Bronx from the George Washington Bridge will have to wait.
"The case that we must have an increase to continue the capital program is airtight," said Richard C. Leone, chairman of the 70-year-old bistate authority.
But despite a report from the accounting firm of KPMG Peat Marwick supporting its case, the agency has twice in recent days postponed a vote on raising tolls to $4, from $3, after failing to gain the support of both Gov. Jim Florio of New Jersey and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York. Both have the power to veto the increase. Mr. Florio has already rejected a 25-cent increase in the PATH fare that the authority had also sought.
Mr. Leone acknowledged that a toll increase would be an "enormous burden" for the Governors, given public antipathy to higher taxes and fees. But the $130 million that such an increase would provide -- which could enable the authority to issue bonds to finance about $1 billion in new investments -- would also seem an enormously tempting sum for two men struggling to fill huge budget deficits.
In the negotiations, New York and New Jersey are seeking to speed up some projects already in the authority's plan and to add others that could take some of the strain off the fiscally stressed states.
 
State's Plans
 New Jersey is interested in help for several expensive undertakings, including a mass-transit link to Newark International Airport, a Secaucus transfer station that would let some N.J. Transit rail passengers switch to trains on Northeast Corridor tracks for New York City and a connection at Kearny that would link the N.J. Transit Morris and Essex line to Northeast Corridor tracks.
New York State is concerned about residents on Staten Island, who are surrounded by toll bridges and have scant mass-transit options.
So far the changes being discussed by both states are said to affect about $400 million of the authority's plan. But if the talks drag on, there is a danger of a tug of war that could push the figure higher, forcing the agency to cut projects that it wants, even with a toll increase.
"This kind of interstate bickering is only going to lead to problems," said Richard T. Anderson, president of the Regional Plan Association. He said the authority should raise tolls by $2, pulling it even with the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority, which charges $2.50 each way on its East River crossings.
 
Past and Present at Odds
 But the Automobile Club of New York, in a letter to Mr. Cuomo, called the Port Authority toll increase discriminatory against motorists, especially on Staten Island. It questioned the agency's policy of using the suplus from the Hudson crossings, which the auto club put at about $200 million a year, to subsidize the PATH system.
"We know of no valid reason why bridge and tunnel users should be singled out to pay for a capital program that includes relatively little in the way of bridge and tunnel facility improvements," it said.
Politicking over tolls seems almost out of character for an agency that had the savvy to outfox Robert Moses twice -- gaining control of the airports and building the bus terminal in midtown over his objections -- and the wherewithal to build what were once the world's tallest buildings, the twin towers of the World Trade Center.
"Very few people believe that we're in need of a cash infusion," said Stanley Brezenoff, the authority's executive director.
That may be in part because of the authority's reputation for perquisites and salaries that Mr. Cuomo has complained are too high. Of the authority's 9,480 employees, 49 are paid $100,000 or more a year. The Metropolitan Transportation Authority has 64 employees who are paid $100,000 or more, but has a payroll of 67,000.
 
Helicopter for Guest
 Port Authority officials note that 300 jobs, most of them managerial, have been trimmed, a hiring freeze is on and administrative spending has been kept to the level of inflation.
The authority was recently embarrassed when a New Jersey newspaper, The Record, published an article about travel expenses and the use of cars and drivers by authority officials, reporting that a commissioner had dispatched a helicopter to pick up a guest for a business dinner at the World Trade Center in 1989.
The agency is "coming down much harder on anything that looks like waste and abuse," Mr. Leone said.
The authority owns two helicopters. It says they are needed to move staff members across the region. But that is two more than the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which also has enterprises in many counties.
The Port Authority also owns 89 major works of art that are valued at $17.9 million. They were acquired for $2.9 million, the agency said and almost all are on public display.
But if the decor in the agency's executive offices is costly, at least by government standards, the mood is uncertain. Although they do not face the huge deficits that the Governors must cope with, officials can look out their windows at the trade center and see problems in nearly every direction.
 
Bridge and Tunnel Surplus
 The authority said it expects the PATH system, the Port Authority rail lines connecting Newark, Jersey City and Hoboken to Manhattan, to have a $135 million deficit this year, more than twice the deficit in 1984. The bus terminals, on Eighth Avenue in mid-Manhattan and in upper Manhattan near the George Washington Bridge, are expected to lose another $63 million, three times the deficit in 1984.
The authority offsets part of what it calculates is a $2 subsidy for each PATH passenger and a $1 subsidy for each bus rider with a surplus from bridges and tunnel tolls, arguing that if PATH and bus riders were to switch to cars they would paralyze the Hudson crossings.
Without higher tolls, officials say, the authority's entire interstate transportation network would lose $77 million this year, eating into surpluses of $131 million and $115 million, from the airports and the trade center, respectively, at a time when the authority wants to invest more money in them. The figures do not include interest.
The 110-story trade center towers, designed in the early 1960's, need $100 million over five years just to begin to modernize the elevators, part of $366 million in renovations scheduled during that period.
 
'Three Big Problems'
 At the three major airports, which economists consider crucial to the region's economic well-being, the authority projects that the number of passengers will grow to more than 100 million by the year 2000 -- if it can find ways to accommodate them.
"There are three big problems at the airports," said Prof. Mitchell L. Moss, director of the Urban Research Center at New York University. "Kennedy, LaGuardia and Newark."
The authority's plan calls for $3 billion to be invested in the airports, including a "people mover" and more parking at Newark and new roads, new parking and another "people mover" at Kennedy. But the agency had to shelve the centerpiece of the Kennedy effort -- a 1.3 million-square-foot central terminal -- when the airlines balked. And the authority's five-year plan includes just a small part of its share for a transit link to the Newark airport and only planning money for a rail link to Kennedy.
Meanwhile, the region's seaports, on which the authority expects to lose $11 million this year, have been eclipsed as the nation's pre-eminent port by Los Angeles-Long Beach and need expensive rail connections and other improvements to stay competitive with other East Coast ports.
Professor Moss and others trace some of the authority's fiscal stress to the late 1970's, when the agency, flush with revenue, set out on a series of ambitious and innovative economic development projects.
 
Real-Estate Development
 The Fishport, a $25 million effort that was supposed to attract boats and dealers to South Brooklyn, was open only about a year and a half, the victim of sluggish sales. Space at Teleport, an office center with sophisticated communications links on Staten Island, has been difficult to fill.
Of its industrial parks, the authority expects to make $800,000 this year in the Bathgate section of the South Bronx but lose $2.5 million in Elizabeth, N.J., and $3 million in Yonkers. The resource recovery plant in Essex County, N.J., will make $9 million. The Newark Legal Center will lose $3 million. None of these figures includes debt service.
Voters in Hoboken rejected the authority's plan to rebuild a 32-acre section of its waterfront. Another development project involving the authority, at Hunters Point in Long Island City, Queens, was approved by New York City but faces a depressed real-estate market.
Peter C. Goldmark Jr., the authority's executive director when many of those projects were initiated, defended them as the kind of job-creating enterprises that the agency should have undertaken to stimulate economic growth.
But George Sternlieb, professor emeritus of urban planning at Rutgers University, said the authority is now "saddled with some pretty hefty stuff." "They're in the real-estate development business, and real estate stinks," he said.
 
Rising Debt
 In any event, under Stephen Berger, Mr. Goldmark's successor, the agency turned inward, starting to redress what Mr. Berger regarded as underinvestment in its main businesses -- bridges, tunnels, seaports and airports.
But as the region's economy cooled, traffic leveled off and revenues softened. The agency's debt is projected to grow to $4.6 billion this year, from $2.3 billion in 1984, while reserves would rise only to $800 million from $660 million.
To ease the pressure, Mr. Berger unsuccessfully sought higher tolls in December 1989, a year before the agency had expected to raise them, and the authority discussed a $6 toll in 1993.
"Steve fell on the barbed wire," Mr. Brezenoff said, "and now I'm walking across."
In its forecasts, though, the agency expects a $150 million gap in 1994 that may at best be offset in part by a new passenger surcharge at the airports. So even if it raises tolls this year, it seems likely to try to raise them again soon.

HEADLINE: Despite War, Pentagon Plans Big Cuts

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2

 BODY:
Faced with severe budget pressures, the Pentagon is proceeding with its plan to reduce the armed forces by a quarter by 1995 despite the war in the Persian Gulf and renewed strains in American-Soviet relations.
"With the ongoing withdrawal of Soviet armed forces from Eastern Europe, the dissolving Warsaw Pact military organization, and reforms in Moscow, the U.S. no longer focuses its defense planning on preparing for global, short-notice conflict," says a draft of the Pentagon's annual report to Congress, which has circulated among senior Defense Department officials. 
 Instead, the report said, planning will focus on "regional contingencies, often unforeseeable."
 
Looking Beyond Cold War
 Since the United States and its allies began their military campaign two and a half weeks ago to evict Iraqi troops from Kuwait, Pentagon officials have been preoccupied with the war. But the Defense Department is also adapting forces and strategy to the ending of the cold war.
The Pentagon's plans for cutting and reshaping the military are laid out in its new $278 billion budget for the fiscal year 1992. That spending request is to be unveiled Monday, but Pentagon officials, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, discussed it beforehand. The spending request is $5 billion more than the Pentagon's authorized spending this fiscal year but 1 percent less when adjusted for inflation.
While the Pentagon is projecting big cuts in Army, Navy and Air Force units, the reductions are timed to guard against a worsening of American-Soviet relations, a senior Pentagon official said.
 
Lessons on Transportation
 The new Pentagon plans also reflect some of the lessons of the American military operation in the Persian Gulf. The Pentagon is now budgeting more than $2 billion through 1997 for additional transport ships or the positioning of military equipment overseas to ease the deployment of Americans for conflicts in third-world countries.
The budgeting of the funds reflects difficulties in quickly deploying troops in Saudi Arabia, as well as Congressional criticism that the Pentagon has failed to budget adequate funds for transport ships. Congress put in more than $1 billion for these purposes in the 1991 budget, which the Pentagon is now prepared to spend as soon a program is devised. In addition, the Pentagon is now budgeting an average of $250 million a year in additional funds, starting in 1993.
And the Pentagon now plans to keep A-10 anti-tank planes in the American arsenal. Before the conflict in the gulf, the Air Force had sought to phase out the A-10 planes from its active, non-reserve forces in favor of developing an improved version of the F-16 for close-air support of ground troops. But the A-10's have proved to be useful in Saudi Arabia.
 
The Army Slims Down
 As described by Pentagon officials, the Defense Department's plans call for cutting the number of active Army divisions to 12 from the current 18 by the 1995 fiscal year. The number of reserve Army divisions is also being cut to 6 from the current 10.
The Pentagon also plans to create two Army "cadre" reserve divisions, or partially manned units that would be brought up to full strength during an international crisis.
The Navy, which has 6 carriers deployed in the Persian Gulf, is also being reduced. The number of carriers is being cut to 12 by 1995 from the current 13, while the total number of ships is being cut from 545 to 451.
In an innovation promoted by Adm. Frank B. Kelso 2d, the Chief of Naval Operations, the Navy plans to transfer some frigates to the reserves. The ships would be manned by a small crew of active duty naval officers who would train reservists to operate the vessels. The Navy has previously turned down suggestions from Congressional critics who have suggested that the service make greater use of the reserves.
 
Planes and Missiles Affected
 As for the Air Force, it will see the number of its active and reserve air wings reduced to 26 1/2 by 1995 from the current 36, a Pentagon official said. About 15 of these wings will be in the active Air Force. One and half wings will be made of F-16 planes that will double as reconnaissance aircraft and combat planes. A wing is normally about 72 planes.
Strategic nuclear programs are also being pared, officials said. The Pentagon has virtually abandoned its plan to put MX missiles, each with 10 warheads, on rail cars.
A senior Pentagon official explained that research money has been budgeted to test fire an MX missile from a rail car, but that after that test the program will go into hibernation. No procurement money that would enable the Air Force to deploy the system is being sought.
The Pentagon is also planning to phase out all of its old Minuteman II missiles in anticipation of a new American-Soviet pact to cut long-range nuclear arms. But a Pentagon official said the Air Force would probably maintain some of the concrete missile silos so the United States could expand its strategic nuclear aresenal if there was a serious crisis in American-Soviet relations.
 
End of the Rainbow
 In another signficiant cutback, the Pentagon is canceling the Tacit Rainbow missile, which is intended to destroy Soviet radars so that American aircraft could carry out nuclear strikes.
The cancellation of the Tacit Rainbow system is especially ironic since Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d expended considerable negotiating effort in his meeting with the Russians to get Moscow to allow it under the emerging strategic arms treaty, and a senior State Department trumpeted this as one of the Secretary's more important negotiating triumphs.
The Defense Department plans to seek funds for the military operation in the Persian Gulf as part of a separate budget request. But experience with the military operation there has already influenced planning for the transport of troops and weapons and the storing of equipment overseas.
The Pentagon is planning to spend $200 million to $300 million a year, starting in 1993, for additional ships to carry troops and supplies or to store American equipment overseas.

HEADLINE: White House Reassures Hard-Pressed Governors

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2

 BODY:
The nation's governors, their states battered by recession, came to Washington today to seek more Federal aid and greater flexibility in administering Federal programs.
Leaders of the National Governors' Association, which opened its annual midwinter conference here, said after a meeting with top White House officials today that the Administration was sympathetic to their requests. The White House would not comment. 
 In his State of the Union address, President Bush said he would turn over at least $15 billion in Federal funds now earmarked for specific programs to the states for "flexibile management."
The governors have now made a number of specific proposals and said they were favorably received. They included a request for $120 million in emergency funds to supplement state unemployment insurance for tens of thousands of jobless people; a two-year moratorium on the 10-year expansion of the Medicaid program enacted last year, and a freeze on any further shift in costs from the Federal Government to the states.
 
Health Reorganization Sought
 The governors, noting that the increase in health costs accounts for the greatest rises in their state budgets, are also seeking a long-term reorganization of the health care system.
The governors said they were told that President Bush's promise on the $15 billion was "absolutely flexible."
"It might be $5 billion, it might be $50 billion," Gov. Booth Gardner of Washington, a Democrat who is the chairman of the governors' association, said today after a meeting with John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff; Richard G. Darman, director of the budget, and Roger Porter, the President's domestic policy adviser.
"This was a late entry into the State of the Union," Mr. Gardner told reporters. "It was something the President thought was important. Every time the President meets with governors and legislators he asks, 'If I could do one thing for you, what would you like?' And we always say 'flexibility.' "
 
'Difficult for Congress'
 Mr. Gardner added, however, that the promise of the turnover of Federal funds to the states "is going to be difficult for Congress" because "the states aren't always the pure laboratory of efficiency that we'd like to see them." He also suggested that Congress might be unwilling to lose the patronage associated with some of the programs.
Mr. Gardner said that he thought it would be best if the Federal money to be turned over to the states came from education programs and community development block grants.
Gov. John Ashcroft of Missouri, a Republican and the vice chairman of the group, who also attended the White House meeting, said that he initially feared that Washington might want to turn over programs afflicted by escalating costs, as well as programs that Washington no longer cared about.
"I was concerned about the possibility that these were the programs they wanted to dump," Mr. Ashcroft said, "but that doesn't seem to be the case."
Nor would the turnover be a short-term strategy. "There were definite assurances of longevity," Mr. Ashcroft said, noting that the White House was speaking of a five-year plan.
 
Shortages in 31 States
 The governors' association noted in a policy paper: "Currently, 31 states are struggling with budget shortfalls. A significant part of the fiscal pressure on states is coming from increased costs in the Medicaid program. In 1980, Medicaid spending accounted for 9 percent of states' budgets; in 1990, it accounted for nearly 14 percent of all state spending."
The 10-year expansion of the Federal-state Medicaid program for the poor was enacted last year as part of the budget bill. It would gradually expand Medicaid to pay the health costs of all pregnant women and children under 18 whose incomes were 133 percent of the poverty level. Under current law, the states determine who qulifies for Medicaid,
A two-year delay in implementaing this expansion would save the states about $2 billion over a five-year period, in the opinion of an aide to the governors' group.
In a survey of state legislators released in conjunction with the governors meeting, a majority of the lawmakers in 30 states said that their states were in a recession, while a majority of those in 11 more states said they were headed for a recession. A majority in 31 states predicted that their states would raise taxes this year.

HEADLINE: Bush Blurs Home Goals

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2

 BODY:
Republican aides and analysts responded to the domestic side of President Bush's State of the Union Message this week as though it were a Rorschach test, with each projecting different hopes and fears onto what seemed to be its indeterminate content.
 That so many could come away with wildly varying interpretations renewed a bipartisan suspicion: that the President has not formulated a broad domestic policy. Indeed, some argue that politically he may not need one.
"It's an attempt to create the facade of a domestic policy without the significant content of one," said Kevin Phillips, a Republican analyst who has frequently been critical of the Administration's domestic activity.
The Administration has individual domestic policies, of course, and the speech provided a recitation of them: tenant-run public housing, a cut in the capital gains tax and a call for volunteerism. And to these familiar items, Mr. Bush appended others, from references to research and development to an overhaul of the nation's banking laws.
 
Months of Feuding

The speech was warmly received, and Mr. Bush has endured two years of criticism about a lack of domestic vision without suffering in the approval polls. If anything, his Presidential experience may have only confirmed his instincts to avoid the subject.
While his conduct of foreign affairs has won him praise, his few domestic forays, like those into taxes and minority scholarships, have brought battles with special interest groups and Congress and created factions among his own staff.
The State of the Union Message that Mr. Bush delivered Tuesday came after months of feuding among Administration officials over the tone and substance of domestic policy. Either despite its vagueness, or perhaps because of it, the speech has for now quieted the bickering.
Some of Mr. Bush's aides, most notably Jack F. Kemp, the Housing Secretary, and James P. Pinkerton, a White House deputy assistant for policy planning, had been pushing Mr. Bush to become the "empowerment" President.
The charged word refers to a list of social policies that circumvent bureaucracies, most notably tenant management of public housing and plans that let parents choose the schools their children attend. More generally, it is a plea for the President to set a more active tone on a variety of domestic fronts.
"The problems in our inner cities and poverty areas cry out for audacious solutions," Mr. Kemp wrote in a memorandum to the President last fall, suggesting ideas for the speech.
But others like John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff, and Richard G. Darman, the budget director, have viewed these enthusiasms warily. And they oversaw the drafting of the speech.
An Administration official said early versions had the President applauding Kimi Gray, the Washington tenant leader whom Mr. Kemp has turned into a symbol for his cause. But after review by Mr. Darman and Mr. Sununu, that and other empowerment touches went by the wayside.
Mr. Bush never mentioned the word "empowerment" in his speech, although he spoke 10 times of "power," as in pledges to move "power and decision-making closer to the people."
 
A Victory or a Defeat?

Is that a victory for empowerment or a defeat? Political referees were scoring it both ways.
The address was solidly Republican in its reference to a capital gains cut to stimulate economic growth. But in claiming that a renewed country was "within our reach," it seemed to borrow from the title of a book by Lisbeth Schorr, a liberal academic, whose writing promotes precisely the kind of Government social programs that the empowerment theorists criticize.
Martin Anderson, who served as domestic policy adviser in the early years of the Reagan Administration, argued that Mr. Bush's call for a capital gains cut was a signal of a resolve to tax and spend less.
But Burton Yale Pines of the Heritage Foundation had the opposite fear, worrying that the speech's call for new highway and energy policies might be opening the door to "an enormous pork barrel."
Mr. Bush seems most comfortable, and most committed, when he speaks of voluntary service.
But in places like the Robert Taylor homes, the Chicago housing project where even the police are afraid to go inside. Does Mr. Bush truly envision a phalanx of volunteers stepping forth to do what he calls "the hard work of freedom?"
Mr. Phillips argues that a more active policy on social welfare issues could bring political risks. "He'd be playing with issues on which the Democrats have more credibility," he said. "If you give it lip service without being too specific about it, they can't tie you to it much."

HEADLINE: WAR IN THE GULF: Britain;
In Cotswold Town, Chance to Relive Finest Hour as B-52's Return

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY

DATELINE: FAIRFORD, England, Feb. 2

 BODY:
The Royal Air Force flew British Stirling bombers against targets in Germany from here in World War II, and gliders that landed 250 troops behind the beaches of Normandy on June 6, 1944.
Any day now, giant American B-52 bombers will swoop down on the long runway, load up with up to 29 tons of bombs apiece, and take off again to unload on Iraqi targets 2,750 miles away. 
 For most people in Fairford, a picturesque Cotswold village about two hours west of London, the Americans are a welcome sight, since the R.A.F. no longer uses the base and the United States Strategic Air Command also pulled out, and pulled the plug on a part of the local economy, only last year.
That was after it was clear that war with the Soviet Union probably would never come. But fighting a real war to force Iraq out of Kuwait is something the British, with 40,000 troops in the Persian Gulf, take in stride.
 
Forgetting the Economy

For many villagers in this town of 2,500, participating in the war effort is a chance to relive their finest hour, forgetting the miseries of high inflation and rising unemployment, and fighting shoulder to shoulder with the United States against a faraway dictator, a role some have yearned after for the last 45 years.
"There's a war on, and the B-52's will help get it over with sooner," said Ruth Ritter, 65, the town mayor who served in the air force in what everybody here still calls the last war. "I think all war is a tragedy, but the place has rallied round, and most people are pleased the Americans are coming back. It's going to help unemployment for the short term."
Philip Hope, the 54-year-old proprietor of a news agent's shop on the market square, said that about a thousand United States Air Force medical personnel who were the first to arrive last month had found their mothballed housing lacking such necessities as blankets, sheets and pillowcases.
 
Truckloads of Blankets

"The girls are all dressing in the dark, because they don't have any curtains," he said. "We found out by chance, talking to them, that they didn't have any blankets, so we put up a notice in the store window, and we've had a great response -- two or three truckloads so far."
Outside, a dusting of snow lay on the slate roofs of the gray Cotswold stone houses and some of the Americans, part of a contingent of 1,000 staffing the 870th United States Air Force Contingency Hospital at the nearby air base of Little Rissington, were sightseeing around the 15th-century Perpendicular Gothic Church of St. Mary the Virgin in a cold mist.
"It's been a super reception," said one of the hospital's doctors, Lieut. Col. Michael Wilson, 40, of Iowa City, Iowa, who arrived Jan. 15 from Lackland Air Force Base in Texas, where he is chairman of orthopedics and his wife is also a military physician.
Capt. Michael Rein, the unit's public affairs officer, said the 870th had been eastablished in 1984 as a 1,500-bed, long-term treatment center for casualties from the NATO-Warsaw Pact conflict that the B-52's had also originally been stationed here for.
 
No Eyebrows Raised
 While American nuclear weapons deployed in Britain to deter Soviet attack have often given rise to vigorous antiwar protests, the knowledge that eight-engine B-52's will soon be screaming down the runways with bellies full of conventional bombs to kill Iraqi Republican Guards does not seem to raise so much as an eyebrow hereabouts.
"Nobody here's against the planes for what they're going to do," said Clive Whitehead, 51, a local greengrocer on London Street. He said that a few of the villagers who lived along the runway approaches beyond the hill that separates the base from the town might be worried about the noise.
Several thousand chickens live there at Michael Griffin's poultry farm, but Mrs. Griffin gave the impression that the birds would be fine. When B-52's had flown in and out of the base in the past, she said, the birds had been more unnerved by helicopters than bombers.
 
Air Force Tankers Until '90
 KC-135A Air Force tankers were based here from 1979 until last summer, refueling the B-52's from American units that came here in annual exercises dubbed Mighty Warrior. The base was officially inactivated only last Oct. 1.
Plaques from two B-52 units, the Second Bombardment Wing and the 62d Heavy Bomb Squadron, decorated the wall of the bar in The Bull, the hotel on the main town square. Its manager, Leslie Hathaway, 39, said that business, which had dropped off considerably when the Americans left last summer, had picked up again since last week.
Knots of people warming themselves by the fireside talked mainly about the war.
One man, Steven Sevage, 21, an electrician from Liverpool, argued against it. "How far in evolution do we have to go before people stop getting stabbed in the heart with a bayonet," he asked. "How many countries in the Middle East did the British Empire invade? Nobody stopped us then."

HEADLINE: President to Seek $23 Billion Saving in Medicare Costs

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2

 BODY:
Just three months after signing legislation to cut Medicare payments to hospitals and doctors by $32 billion over five years, President Bush will ask Congress on Monday to cut at least $23 billion more in a similar period from the fast-growing program.
The proposals, part of the President's budget for 1992, are sure to reignite debate over Medicare, which finances health care for 33 million elderly and disabled Americans. Some lawmakers are already suggesting that the proposals will break a budget deal sealed in October. 
 "As far as I'm concerned, further Medicare cuts would be a deal-breaker," said Senator Lloyd Bentsen, Democrat of Texas. As chairman of the Finance Committee, Mr. Bentsen has more influence over Medicare legislation than any other senator.
 
Impact of Gulf War
 Congressional leaders of both parties say they want to preserve the framework for Federal spending and taxes forged by the White House and Congress last year. But it may be blown apart by the costs of the recession, war in the Persian Gulf and Federal insurance for depositors in banks and bankrupt savings and loan associations.
The Congressional Budget Office says the war could cost $28 billion to $86 billion, of which at least half may be defrayed by foreign contributions. Despite the war, Mr. Bush's budget for the fiscal year that begins in October proceeds with the Pentagon's plan to reduce the armed forces by a quarter by 1995. [Page 19.]
"Were it not for the twin problems of recession and the war," Senator Jim Sasser, chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, said in an interview, "this would be a smooth budget year, and we could have taken an uncomplicated, uncontroversial approach. But if the war goes on for more than two or three months, we may have a very turbulent budget year."
Within the constraints of the budget agreement last fall, Mr. Bush will also propose low-cost steps to combat infant mortality, a modest expansion of some child nutrition programs, major reductions in Federal aid to college students from middle-income families and a substantial increase in spending for highways and space programs.
Administration officials acknowledge that the proposed cutbacks in the growth of payments to hospitals and doctors were not required by or envisioned in last year's budget agreement. But they say it is essential to slow the growth of Medicare costs, which rose nearly 14 percent last year, to $107 billion.
Last year's budget agreement covered five years, and many lawmakers say they assumed they would not have to make another major effort at deficit reduction before the 1992 elections.
It is not clear what Mr. Bush wants to do with the money he would save by trimming Medicare payments to hospitals, doctors, laboratories and suppliers of medical equipment to the elderly and disabled.
 
Teaching Hospitals Affected
 The biggest savings, $1.4 billion next year and $9.6 billion over five years, would result from his proposal to cut payments to teaching hospitals. Such hospitals receive an allowance for their extra costs from training doctors and treating people who are more severely ill than the average patient. Most teaching hospitals are in inner cities and serve many poor people.
Under another Bush proposal, the Federal Government would no longer pay hospitals for certain outpatient services provided to Medicare beneficiaries within 15 days after they are discharged from a hospital. The Administration contends that such a change is justified whenever the outpatient services are related to the illness or injury for which a person was admitted to the hospital and for which the hospital has already been paid. Medicare officials say this change would save $30 million next year and $230 million over five years.
Paul C. Rettig, executive vice president of the American Hospital Association, said the proposed cuts, if approved, would almost certainly contribute to "a deterioration in the quality of care and access to care."
After an agonized struggle over the budget last year, Congress appears unlikely to accept the President's Medicare proposals, some of which were previously considered and rejected by Congress. But many lawmakers operate on the premise that doctors are overpaid, so it is conceivable that Congress could agree to trim Medicare payments to certain medical specialists as the Administration suggests.
 
Change in Payroll Taxes
 Confidential budget documents show that the Administration is seeking to trim Medicare by $3.2 billion next year and more than $23 billion over five years. Nevertheless, Medicare would continue growing, to $123 billion next year, from $114 billion this year.
Mr. Bush also proposes to raise revenue for the Medicare trust fund by requiring more state and local government workers to pay Medicare payroll taxes.
Under current law, state and local workers are required to pay such taxes if they were hired after March 31, 1986, but not if they were hired on or before that date. Although there is a sizable pool of state and local workers who have not contributed to the Medicare and Social Security programs, most will still qualify for Medicare benefits because of other jobs they or their spouses have held. The Administration says eliminating this tax break would produce $1.2 billion in new revenue next year and $8 billion over five years.
The Medicare program is less than half the size of Social Security, but is growing twice as fast. Medicare outlays grow rapidly because the elderly population is increasing, because medical care costs are outstripping other prices and because beneficiaries are using more and increasingly complex services.
Mr. Bush's budget assumes that the recession will end by midyear and that the economy will start growing, so the gross national product will rise this year by nine-tenths of 1 percent, after adjusting for inflation.
In one chapter of the budget, Mr. Bush says deterioration of the economy will have "a large negative impact on the deficit," driving it to a record $318 billion this year. The Administration estimates that unemployment, which rose to 6.2 percent in January, will average 6.7 percent this year.
Here is a summary of other proposals in Mr. Bush's budget:
STUDENT AID: The maximum Pell Grant for students attending a college or trade school would be increased to more than $3,500, from the current $2,300. About 3.3 million students now receive such aid. To finance larger grants for the neediest students, Mr. Bush would reduce or eliminate grants to students from middle-income families. One result would be to channel more of the available money to trade schools, which enroll many of the neediest students.
HEALTH: The Federal Government would spend $170 million next year to provide comprehensive prenatal care and other medical services to pregnant women in 10 cities with the highest infant mortality rates, including Detroit, Philadelphia and Washington. But much of the money would be taken from other maternal and child health programs and from community health centers serving low-income people.
CHILD NUTRITION: Mr. Bush proposes a modest expansion of the Special Supplemental Food Program for Women, Infants and Children. The program, known as WIC, provides low-income families with Government vouchers to buy milk, cheese, infant formula, cereal, eggs and orange juice. It serves 4.4 million people, representing 60 percent of those who are fully eligible.
But Mr. Bush is also proposing to slash cash and commodity subsidies for lunches served to schoolchildren from families with incomes more than three and a half times the official poverty level, which was $12,675 for a family of four in 1989.
The White House is notoriously prone to error in predicting the deficit. In January 1990, for example, it predicted a 1990 deficit of $124 billion; in fact, it was $220 billion.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 4; Column 1; Week In Review Desk

LENGTH: 940 words

HEADLINE: The World;
Central America Faces New U.S. Policy: The Cold Shoulder

BYLINE: By MARK A. UHLIG

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY

 BODY:
AFTER a decade of war, clashing ideologies and Washington's obsessive involvement, Central America has found itself the object of perhaps the only United States attitude that could still leave regional leaders off balance: indifference.
Just 10 years ago, the strategic importance of the tiny continental appendage was considered a given. Leftist rebels were waging a "final offensive" in El Salvador. Sandinista Nicaragua seemed ready to export revolution. And the Reagan Administration declared the region's battles to be an apocalyptic showdown between freedom and Communist domination. 
 Today, with the collapse of the Soviet bloc, that grand geopolitical concern seems almost quaint. And the Persian Gulf, where Americans, not just their surrogates, are dying, has riveted the attention of United States citizens and policymakers alike.
But for Central Americans, who had rarely viewed their own troubles in cold war terms, the abrupt reduction in United States interest has proved just as baffling and precipitous as its sudden onset a decade ago. Like a train roaring through a rural town, United States foreign policy burst through central America at full speed and has now disappeared into the night.
Historians note that the reduced importance of Central America on Washington's foreign agenda merely continues a cycle of inattention, alarm and intervention that has characterized United States policy for a century and a half. It can also be explained as a function of domestic politics in Washington: Central America has become a subject of high political cost and minimum political benefit.
Having watched Ronald Reagan sacrifice public support to his commitment to the Nicaraguan contra war, George Bush recognized early on that the anti-Sandinista struggle was a political tar baby. The victory of Violeta Barrios de Chamorro in Nicaraguan elections last year only permitted Mr. Bush a more graceful exit from a foreign policy conundrum that he was already determined to escape.
But a striking measure of the Administration's desire to put Central America aside has been the degree to which Washington's principal goals remain unaccomplished. In Nicaragua, Mrs. Chamorro's Government remains a thin, ineffective veneer over a still-formidable Sandinista-controlled army and police apparatus. In El Salvador, the bloody civil war grinds on. Even in Panama, a peripheral dilemma that Mr. Bush attempted to resolve once and for all by removing Gen. Manuel Noriega, no strong or stable democracy has taken root since the American invasion.
So completely has America's attention moved beyond such issues that events which might once have ranked as hemispheric crises have slipped past with no lasting consequences. In El Salvador, neither the murder of an American helicopter crew by rebel guerrillas nor the Government's refusal to fully investigate the 1989 assassination of six Jesuit priests has been enough to provoke serious changes in American policy. In Panama, a quixotic coup attempt by former military officers was put down, then ignored. And in Nicaragua, admissions that Sandinista army officers had shipped sophisticated weapons to Salvadoran rebels -- the incendiary charge that had ignited a decade of war -- was shrugged off after Mrs. Chamorro's Government stepped in to exculpate her Sandinista-dominated military command.
Once scrutinized and interpreted in the United States as part of a great national debate, such events have slipped back into the tedium and assumed irrelevance of most third world news. In San Salvador, the once-shocking chronicle of a self-destructing society has become a trickle of wire-service stories. In Managua, a once formidable press corps has shrunk to its lowest levels since before the Sandinista revolution in 1979.
To many experts, the eclipse of Central America as a foreign policy issue is a testimony to the power of the American President's ability to determine the nation's political agenda. Once defined by President Reagan and his first Secretary of State, Alexander Haig, as a cold-war battleground, Central America was invested with political importance independent of its true strategic value.
Since the Soviet bloc dissolved and the White House turned away, however, the effect has been reversed entirely. No strategic importance has been found where none is acknowledged. And viewed without a cold war lens, the region's sharp contrasts have turned to gray.
"Central America was always viewed as a story of good guys or bad guys," said Robert Pastor, an expert on Latin American affairs at Emory University. "Problems of political transition, economic adjustment -- those are not easy to describe in black and white terms, and they're even harder to resolve."
For many opponents of the Reagan approach to Central America, America's new indifference has been greeted as a source of hope and potential assurance against future intervention.
Paradoxically, however, perhaps no one has been as surprised or dismayed by Washington's attention as those who were the chief targets of its ire. As if hungering to reinject himself into American policy discussions, the former Nicaraguan President, Daniel Ortega Saavedra, journeyed to Baghdad in January with the declared aim of averting the Persian Gulf war and giving Saddam Hussein advice on how to negotiate with Washington.
But the Central American revolutionary, who had once obsessed and enraged Washington with his every utterance, earned only a few wordless seconds on TV and an unaccustomed lesson in the oldest law of politics: the only thing worse than bad press is no press at all.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Nicaraguan President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, right, with Costa Rican President Rafael A. Calderon Jr. and his wife, Gloria, as Mr. Calderon arrived in Managua last week for economic talks. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: The World;
Bush's Holy War: The Crusader's Cloak Can Grow Heavy on the Shoulders

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
AS President Bush gambles for greatness in the Persian Gulf, he finds himself in a rare predicament.
The pragmatic President who plied Realpolitik for the first two years of his Administration is suddenly on a moral crusade. The President who always tended to shy away from rallying the American public to any cause for any sustained period is now offering a passionate disquisition on good versus evil, right versus wrong, a just war, a moral use of force, virtue and vice, religious values and the will of God. 
 In explaining the war in the Middle East and building support for it, Mr. Bush must blend the proper elements of strategic realism and morality. If he errs on the side of realism, without offering a greater good, he demoralizes the troops and the country and encourages the notion that this is a conflict involving no more than trading blood for oil, as the protesters suggest. If he offers too much moral umbrage, too many overdrawn comparisons to Hitler, he runs the risk of so enlarging the war objectives that he could not accept anything less than total capitulation; how can you leave Evil Incarnate to run Iraq?
Wars are just, after all, precisely insofar as their aims and means are limited, keeping the violence in proportion to the reason for fighting. That is what makes them different from holy wars, in which there are no restraints or boundaries because it is God's will to slaughter the infidel.
For better or worse, by talking so aggressively about right and wrong, Mr. Bush has set a new moral standard by which to measure his future foreign policy. "If you claim to act from moral motives on one occasion, your motives will be questioned on other actions," said Michael Walzer, author of "Just and Unjust Wars." "There has to be a balancing of the moral ledger over the long haul."
The Democrats have already indicated that they will hold President Bush accountable for some consistency on the issue. In his response to the President's State of the Union address, Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine said America must seek a world "where justice and human rights are respected everywhere."
"Students massacred in China, priests murdered in Central America, demonstrators gunned down in Lithuania -- these acts of violence are as wrong as Iraqi soldiers killing civilians," Mr. Mitchell said. "We cannot oppose oppression in one place and overlook it in another."
There will be some awkwardness about the President's returning to the "let's make a deal" style of policy-making that he practiced for two years with his friend Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d -- guided not by the sort of ideologies and moral edge that influenced Jimmy Carter and Ronald Reagan, but more completely by instinct, reasonableness and a sensitivity to American economic interests. The White House has not given a high level of attention to Amnesty International reports in the last year detailing abuses in such countries as Iran, Burma, Sri Lanka, Egypt, Brazil and Saudi Arabia. And while the State Department's annual report on human rights calls Iraq's record "abysmal," it also sharply berates Syria, an American ally in the gulf war, and to a lesser degree criticizes Kuwait, Turkey, Saudi Arabia and Israel.
But just before he began the bombardment of Baghdad, Mr. Bush said "the moral purpose" of the war could be found in an Amnesty International report detailing the tortures and killing of Kuwaitis by Iraqi soldiers.
"I don't know about the rest of the American people, but I care," the President told People magazine. "Kids there who were passing out leaflets in Kuwait were picked up by the Iraqis. They were 15 or 16. They were tied to a stake in a square in Kuwait and then they were made to wait 'til their parents came and then they were shot. Does the world give a damn about that any more? I do, and I think those kids out there in the desert understand, too."
A senior Bush adviser was asked before the war why the lives of the Chinese young people were less a subject of vocal American moral outrage than the lives of the Kuwaiti young people. "Regimes doing it to their own is different because there's relatively little you can do about that," the White House official replied. "And the President thinks it's particularly horrible when an outsider comes in and visits these horrors on people."
Of course, Saddam Hussein has killed his own people, too, and with poison gas, but when he did it the United States was still in its time of Middle East pragmatism, hoping that Mr. Hussein's Iraq, however brutal, could be kept on a leash while continuing to balance the fanatacism of Iran. The United States had, after all, been hoping for that since Iraq invaded Iran in 1980.
The President's newfound vocal morality may make it more difficult for him to make the sort of trade-offs that he has made to keep the anti-Iraq alliance together, or it may at least give his critics ammunition when he does. The most dramatic of these maneuvers included refusing to strongly criticize Mikhail S. Gorbachev after Soviet security forces killed 21 pro-independence demonstrators in the Baltics, and posing for a smiling picture with Hafez al-Assad, even though the State Department notes that the Syrian leader's record on human rights is almost indistinguishable from Saddam Hussein's and even though it is believed that Syria is harboring the perpetrators of the bombing of Pan Am flight 103.
Political leaders must use moral rhetoric to justify wars because they have to defend, both ethically and politically, the act of killing people. On a purely cynical level, it is necessary to build a consensus. As Nietzsche once wrote, "Morality is the best of all devices for leading mankind by the nose."
But the United States is a nation with a streak of piousness and a belief that morality must be part of public policy, and leaders who fail to morally engage Americans risk a backlash. Patrick Glynn of the American Enterprise Institute noted that when Lyndon Johnson tried to keep Vietnam on a back burner and avoid a moral dialogue, fearing that his social programs might be swept aside if war fever raged and the political right benefited, the war protesters started the moral debate for him.
Mr. Bush may be known for the malleability of his political principles, but his advisers say he truly believes he has the moral high ground in the gulf. As one of his aides earnestly put it, the week America went to war: "This is not about oil. This is about right and wrong."
 Mr. Bush is, after all, from the Eastern upper class that dominated the foreign policy establishment for decades, certain of its own morality and its right to lead. Within that class, he was among those committed to the principle that America had an obligation to intervene to help less powerful countries and to hold the line against aggression.
In June 1940, 16-year-old George Bush listened raptly when Henry L. Stimson, Franklin D. Roosevelt's Secretary of War -- who later would take a major responsibility in developing the atom bomb and deciding to drop it on Japan -- spoke at the graduation at Phillips Academy in Andover, Mass. Colonel Stimson, who believed that internationalism went hand in hand with moral responsibility and that it was America's duty to civilize the world, told his young listeners he envied them "the opportunity" to choose between "right and wrong" and stand up for good against evil.
Last week, Mr. Bush cited Plato, Cicero and St. Thomas Aquinas in arguing that "the first principle of a just war is that it support a just cause."
"It is a war with which good will prevail," he told the National Religious Broadcasters Convention. "Our cause could not be more noble." In his proclamation for a National Prayer Day today, he said that, "entrusted with the holy gift of freedom, and allowed to prosper in its great light, we have a responsibility to serve as a beacon to the world."
While some American commentators have questioned whether it was prudent for Mr. Bush to go to war, Saddam Hussein makes such a seductive villain that few pundits have questioned the President's assertion that this is a just war.
St. Augustine developed the just-war theory in the fifth century, on the premise that there are worse evils than physical destruction; it has been the dominant Christian ethical position on war ever since. "We go to war to gain peace," he wrote, and St. Thomas Aquinas added the refinement that the invaders should have "a rightful intention."
Ethicists are heartened that the country is engaged in a moral debate. And, they point out, morality is not like logic. It is not always consistent and it is not always pure. A leader must act appropriately to each occasion, applying prudence and hopefully some consistency. But they also agree that now that Mr. Bush has shown his moral edge, he may not be able to sheathe it after the Iraqis are punished. As Mr. Glynn put it, "He may end up being carried along by this ball he's begun rolling."

HEADLINE: The World;
For the Economy, the Gulf War Has Little Impact -- So Far

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
WAR has a way of putting lesser matters in a different perspective, but as a number of politicians and economists noted last week, it does not make them disappear. Washington must still cope with the age-old issues of guns vs. butter. And mercifully, economists say, if there is ever such a thing as the right time to fight a war, this is it. Unless Iraq manages to wreak havoc in the Saudi oilfields or shocks American consumers into a prolonged and unaccustomed bout of self-denial, it will barely cause a ripple in the economy.
Astonishingly expensive weapons are going up in smoke in Operation Desert Storm -- a single Patriot missile costs as much as a year's worth of Head Start for 500 pre-schoolers. But as Robert Hormats of Goldman Sachs International notes, "this is a prepaid war" -- the weapons are coming out of the enormous stockpiles amassed for a no-holds-barred defense of Europe, and most will probably not be replaced after the fighting is over. 
 No war, of course, can be fought entirely out of inventory. The Pentagon is shopping for hundreds of items ranging from sand-resistant boots to anti-nerve gas injectors.
At least one big-ticket item, fuel, is being picked up by the Saudis. And unlike Korea or Vietnam, this war is being fought during a recession. With excess capacity in almost every domestic industry, war production need not come at the expense of consumption or business investment.
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, warned last week that one real risk is that the war will retard the economy, not overheat it. A big spike in oil prices or a mass strike by consumers would work like a tax increase, paring demand and deepening a recession that, in light of the latest unemployment figures, is looking increasingly serious.
 
Stimulating Demand
 But neither seems likely. Worldwide inventories of oil are apparently sufficient to buffer anything short of a wipeout of Saudi oil operations. And though consumer confidence has yet to rebound from prewar jitters, few analysts think the war itself will keep shoppers out of stores for very long.
Wars typically stimulate demand for goods and services, straining productive capacity and driving governments to extraordinary efforts to contain civilian buying power. In World War II, for example, Washington simply ordered companies to stop making low-priority items and rationed many others. These direct constraints were supplemented with high-pressure appeals to buy war bonds.
In the case of Vietnam, President Lyndon B. Johnson dared not ask Congress to cut domestic spending or take more out of workers' paychecks, and the public was hardly in the mood to save. The result was inflation -- what Richard Nixon the Presidential candidate called "the cruelest tax."
This time around, argues William A. Niskanen, the head of the Cato Institute, who was an economic adviser to President Ronald W. Reagan, circumstances are different. Great quantities of costly munitions are being expended in the air war, and a ground assault could use up hardware at an unprecedented rate. But conventional weapons inventories, built up over the last two decades to defend Western Europe against the Red Army, far exceed most analysts' estimates of projected needs.
Consider, for example, the TOW infantry missile. According to Steven Alexis Cain of the Defense Budget Project, the Pentagon has purchased some 267,000 TOW's since 1974. And while procurement is only a "rough estimate" of inventories, it is difficult to see how the Army could use up more than a small fraction of them against Saddam Hussein's few thousand tanks and armored personnel carriers.
A similar story can be told about the pinpoint-accurate Tomahawk cruise missile, used to wipe out command and communications facilities in the wee hours of the war. Some 200 Tomahawks were launched -- leaving 2,200 of the $1.35 million weapons. The Pentagon is doing some buying. The Commerce Department reported last week that factory orders for machines and other durable equipment were up 4.4 percent in December, with the gain due largely to orders for military goods. But thanks to the recession, the economy apparently has the capacity to meet military demands without breaking a sweat.
The gain made up less than half the 10 percent decline in factory demand in November, and left total orders a full 7 percent below last year's level. It is always possible, Mr. Niskanen concedes, that war demand will cause economic bottlenecks -- laid-off auto workers in Detroit won't jump on the first plane to Arizona, where jobs riveting helicopter fuselages are going begging.
 
Disguised Blessings
 The industry that might have been most greatly affected by shortages of specialized workers was air transport, which lost thousands of pilots in the call-up of reserves. But the call-up has proved a blessing of sorts, trimming payrolls while every airline had too many seats and too few passengers. The callup had similar effects in other industries undergoing layoffs.
It should thus come as no surprise that Robert Reischauer of the Budget Office argues it would be premature to offset increased military demand with higher taxes. Indeed, the Fed chairman, Mr. Greenspan, suggests the greater risk is that the war will actually lengthen and deepen the recession by curbing total demand.
The doubling of oil prices after the August invasion of Kuwait drained domestic purchasing power -- and with it any doubts that the American economy was in recession. Oil prices ebbed in December, as Saudi Arabia made good on its promise to make up for supplies lost in Iraq and Kuwait. And they fell sharply when it appeared that the liberation of Kuwait would be swift and easy. But a successful Iraqi attack on Saudi refineries and loading operations might again push crude prices toward $40 a barrel.
 
Awash in Oil
 Philip Verleger, an economist at the Institute for International Economics in Washington, notes that the world is now awash with oil. Commercial inventories are at their highest since the early 1980's, and the industrial economies are committed to selling 2 million barrels a day from strategic reserves to cover temporary shortfalls in production.
Tom Wallin, an analyst at the Petroleum Intelligence Weekly, adds that seasonal oil consumption patterns are also working in the allies' favor: energy demand will dip to the annual low in April or May, giving the allies breathing room to repair any damage to the oil infrastructure.
With or without higher oil prices, the war could cause the economy to contract if Americans put away their credit cards for the duration. "You risk consumer confidence deteriorating," Mr. Greenspan told the House Banking Committee Thursday. "This economy is obviously subject more than at anytime I have seen in the recent past to changes in psychology."
But it is important to distinguish shoppers' decisions to stay home to catch the war news -- what has been dubbed "The CNN factor" -- from decisions to forgo consumption that reflect more fundamental concerns about their financial security. It is hardly surprising, argues Mr. Reischauer, that people think twice in the early days of a war before buying a new Cadillac. But he finds it improbable that the war worries would generate enduring changes in spending.
Historically, he notes, changes in consumer confidence are the effect rather than the cause of real changes in the economy. People may buy less because they fear unemployment. "But most analyses," he concludes, "suggest that expectations don't in themselves explain much."
The odds are still high, then, that the gulf war will neither generate new inflationary pressures nor add much to the pain of the current recession. That's good -- or is it?
In past wars, the effects have quickly been felt at home in the form of higher prices or material shortages. That has translated into a sense of shared sacrifice with the soldiers at the front -- or in the case of Vietnam, a check on the militancy of policymakers. This time around, harsh economic realities will not help fill the gulf of perception between those who do the fighting and those who watch it on TV.
