HEADLINE: The Region;
New York City Tallies The Human Costs Of Its 1970's Cutbacks

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
FORCED to pare spending, some New York City officials are expressing concern that false economies will return to haunt them. Since the city's 1975 fiscal crisis, the enduring impact of thousands of layoffs, of other wholesale budget cuts, and of deferred maintenance of bridges, school buildings, roads and mass-transit equipment is difficult to quantify. But, as the city again considers economies of that magnitude for the first time since the mid-1970's, and New York State does, too, some officials are quietly asking -- and advocates outside government are questioning more vocally -- what price today's cutbacks will exact.
"We know from our experience in the 1970's," said Mayor David N. Dinkins, "that the budget cuts of today lead to higher social costs a decade from now." 
 As it begins its second year, the Dinkins administration is still struggling with the legacy of budget cuts made as long as a decade and a half ago. Mr. Dinkins has sought to protect and expand preventive services like prenatal care that he had championed as the Manhattan Borough President. But the dimensions of cutbacks now being contemplated, coupled with legal mandates to spend and political pressures that narrowly define what can be cut, have revived profound questions:
* Will curtailing school, social service and repair programs again prove to have been imprudent?
* Has the city been too timid to explore the elimination of frills that it can no longer afford instead of cutting into bone?
* Are officials transforming adversity into opportunity, as previous administrations did when, for instance, they managed to negotiate reductions in manning levels for garbage trucks and for certain police patrol cars?
Years before the fiscal crisis erupted in public, the neglect of New York City's physical structures was graphic. The plunging of an asphalt truck through the deteriorated deck of the West Side Highway in 1973 was paradigmatic of the city's deferred maintenance philosophy.
Measuring the impact of personnel decisions is more difficult, although the firefighters' union linked the deaths of two Queens men last month to the closing of a nearby firehouse. The city is still reaping the consequences of contract perquisites, including days off, that were granted in place of raises and of early retirements that depleted the ranks of experienced supervisors.
Many law-enforcement authorities draw a more direct line between the layoffs of several thousand police officers in the summer of 1975 and a precipitous rise in street robberies that peaked in 1981. They acknowledge, however, that other factors have fueled the increase in reported crime. Repeated campaign promises have been insufficient to restore patrol strength to pre-fiscal crisis levels.
"If you make a decision to lay off and not hire for five years, you pay a price for 15 years," said Chief Anthony M. Voelker of the Police Department's Organized Crime Control Bureau. The force shrank from nearly 32,000 in the early 1970's to fewer than 22,000 in 1981. Numerically, the department never recovered -- there are 26,851 officers on the force today (although other variables, including the expanded use of civilians in clerical jobs to free up uniformed officers, can skew comparisons).
"We're still trying to catch up," said Raymond W. Kelly, the first deputy commissioner. "Reported crime is up 60 percent, manpower is down 20 percent. We're training in an inadequate building. That's the immediate tangible legacy."
Correlating the decline in education and social services and soaring rates of juvenile crime, poverty and unemployment is more theoretical -- particularly when there may be little empirical evidence and when many other cities that did not suffer a fiscal crisis are experiencing some of the same problems. Anecdotal evidence suggests some connection, though, and even cuts that seem marginal in terms of a $29 billion budget can have major consequences for the public when an agency has to pare expenses by a hefty percent.
"A lot of these young people who are committing violent crime today are the negative beneficiaries of the cuts 15 years ago," said Deputy Mayor Bill Lynch. "If we would've served 10 more kids it would have been worth it. But whether real alternatives would have worked, we will never know."
That more than 100 elementary schools are still without librarians and the fact that 4 in 10 teachers will be eligible for retirement in five years are both direct results of budget-cutting in the mid-1970's, Board of Education officials say. High-school dropout rates and the demand for remedial programs may still be, in part, a consequence of larger classes, lack of guidance counselors and elimination of organized after-school activities.
Some educators argue that increasing class size by several students probably had only a modest impact. Barbara Blum, a former city welfare official who is now president of the Foundation for Child Development, an advocacy group, suggests that shrinking services contributed to some of the high unemployment and antisocial behavior by young people, just as the decline in manufacturing jobs and other economic changes did.
While the enduring effects may be difficult to quantify, few people dispute who bore the brunt of the cutbacks. "The greatest burden was borne by the city's poor, whose standard of living was reduced," Professors Charles Brecher and Raymond D. Horton, now officials of the Citizens Budget Commission, a research group financed by businesses, wrote in "Setting the Municipal Priorities" (Allanheld, Osmun and Company Inc., 1981).
The legacy of the fiscal crisis has not been all negative. Some lessons were not forgotten as the city again imposed painful economies. "We learned that imposing layoffs in the middle of a school year imposes unique havoc," said Ruth W. Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President. "I'm the mother of a 22-year-old son who had six first-grade teachers and learned to read when he was 9."
Some New Yorkers were galvanized into greater civic commitment. Citizens formed security patrols, and businesses joined self-taxing districts to provide additional services, and a subway transfer point that had been contemplated by government for years was finally built by a private developer. Mr. Dinkins has commissioned more studies of how to deliver services more efficiently. "The one enormous legacy of the fiscal crisis was a missed opportunity," Mr. Horton of the Citizens Budget Commission said. "We didn't change the way we provide public services. We simply shrunk the system."

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends;
The Push to Consider A Once Taboo Subject: National School Tests

BYLINE: By KAREN DE WITT

 BODY:
IS there something un-American about testing all elementary and high school students and providing the results to colleges and potential employers?
For more than a decade the notion of setting national standards that could be used to evaluate the performance of schoolchildren -- and their schools -- has been percolating among educational theorists. Such tests drive students' efforts in Japan, Britain, France, Germany and most of the rest of the industrialized world, and many argue that the United States has to adopt such methods to keep up. 
 While sharing the concerns about the quality of education, though, American politicians, educators and others have rejected any suggestion of weakening the tradition of state and local control over education as too radical for a nation of Horatio Alger bootstrappers.
But now proposals for national testing are being talked about and pushed by politicians and business groups frustrated with the under-prepared workers the American education system produces.
Reflecting that concern is the Secretary's Commission on Achieving Needed Skills, set up by former Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole to develop a test to determine the workforce skills that 16-year-olds should have. There is also talk of expanding into a national examination the testing already being conducted by the National Assessment of Educational Progress, a branch of the Federal Education Department charged with monitoring what students learn. .
With growing support for such standards, education groups are being forced to reconsider the issue.
Last week, for example, Educate America Inc., a new education group headed by former New Jersey Governor Thomas H. Kean, proposed mandatory national tests for all high school seniors, with results made available to colleges and employers.
And two weeks ago, a Presidential advisory group made up of business executives, politicians and educators recommended a national examination for all elementary and high school students.
"There has been a sea change on this front in the last year or two," said Chester E. Finn, one of the 25 members of the President's Education Policy Advisory Committee. "The idea is attaining a level of legitimacy it didn't have before and is beginning to find its way into policy circles."
Apart from fears of losing out in the international competition, the momentum is being fueled by the national education goals for 2000 agreed upon by President Bush and the governors last year. Without tests, proponents say, the country won't be able to assess whether it is moving toward the goals.
But getting from policy circles to implementation will be a formidable task politically.
Adopting such a system would involve a fundamental change of course in the country's approach to education. The United States has always emphasized standardized testing that is intended to measure ability and aptitude. Other countries test students on whether they attain standards that are publicly set in a national standard tied to a national examination system.
 Experts say a national examination in the United States would probably draw on European experience, but it would be significantly different, in part, because it would be shaped by a debate over who would control it.
 
Contending With Sensitivities
 It also will have to contend with sensitivities in the states and even within school districts to the comparisons on performance that inevitably will be made and with the problems of drawing standards and tests to cover a diverse population fairly.
 Apart from established education groups, which remain opposed to such tests, poor people, minority groups and states with high levels of poverty also have been wary. That is because the performance of poor, black and Hispanic students on standardized tests has consistently been below that of other groups.
 A chief issue has been what shape such an examination will take. To date, the most comprehensive proposal has come from two nonprofit education research centers. Mark Tucker, president of the National Center on Education and the Economy, in Rochester, and Dr. Lauren Resnick, director of the Learning Research and Development Center at the University of Pittsburgh, have called for curriculum-driven testing in three parts, called performance, portfolio and project examinations. In a test intended to measure performance, a student is given a task to be carried out in limited time. A portfolio examination evaluates a body of work assembled by a student. A project examination assesses how a student works with a group.
For all the debate on the issue of a national testing system, a number of questions remain. But what is new, and startling, is that the questions are being discussed in increasingly wider circles.
The American Association of School Administrators, which represents 18,000 local school superintendents and administrators and which has been against national tests and standards, for example, again considered the issue late last month.
"The idea of a single national test of 40 million schoolchildren was rejected outright," said Bruce Hunter, associate executive director of the organization. "But that we needed a national agreement on what children ought to know -- that there should be some national dialogue on standards -- there didn't seem to be any objection to that. "

HEADLINE: The Region;
For Schools Chancellor, No Hat and No Rabbit

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER

 BODY:
THIS has been a strange and often cheerless winter for Joseph A. Fernandez, the New York City Schools Chancellor.
When he flew in from Miami a year ago, he hit the ground running with a string of dazzling managerial and legislative triumphs that promised to rejuvenate the city's ailing schools. But in recent months he has become mired in budgets and labor negotiations. 
 When the Chancellor has had time to discuss ideas, they are attention-getting, but usually not things that are considered central to his reform mission: a plan for making condoms available on request to high school students, an experimental school for black and Hispanic males and warranties that graduates can read and calculate.
To critics, the proposals are sketchy and not well-researched. All are adrift in controversy. Questions are being raised why the condom program needs to be so far-reaching when there is no proof that such a program will reduce AIDS among teen-agers and when the disease seems largely confined to homosexuals and intravenous drug users or their sexual partners. Civil liberties groups have attacked the proposed school for what they see as its separatist ideology.
The warranty plan, while lauded by educators in Massachusetts and Maryland who have tried it, has been seen by some educators as more of a promotional gimmick than as a solid effort to tackle weaknesses in instruction or academic requirements.
While those proposals have been slowed by such reservations, Mr. Fernandez has moved quickly to confront the impact of the financial crisis on the school system. A week ago, he capped an effort to prevent thousands of layoffs of teachers by getting officials of the teachers' union to agree to defer 1 to 1 1/2 percent of members' wages this year into 1995 and 1996.
Not only did he prevent almost certain disruptions in class and student assignments, but his solution will undoubtedly be followed by the Dinkins administration with other unions.
Still, advocates like Noreen Connell, executive director of the Educational Priorities Panel, wonder who is providing leadership in learning.
 
A Job of Damage Control
 "Fernandez is a great communicator," said Ms. Connell, whose group is a coalition of advocacy groups, "and it would be nice to see that kind of excitement around the issue of learning come to the foreground."
Some critics feel there has been too little talk by Mr. Fernandez about reinvigorating what gets taught and how -- the subject of mathematics being the one exception -- and about sparking the attention of the flocks of children from troubled homes, about the basics of reading and writing.
Others, like Marjorie Wilkes, executive director of Interface, a nonprofit research group that studies educational programs, worry about the nature of Mr. Fernandez's tight inner circle. Mr. Fernandez has surrounded himself with talented lieutenants, she said -- administrators like Stanley S. Litow, Amina Abdur-Rahman and Robin Willner -- but they are not educators and are not experts in fields like instruction and subject content.
"Which says something about the priorities of this administration," Ms. Wilkes said.
Still others absolve the Chancellor, saying he came to New York to revitalize the school system but suddenly finds himself spending most of his time keeping it intact. Mr. Fernandez's predicament comes after such triumphs as the state laws making it easier to transfer principals out of their schools and abolishing the Board of Examiners.
"He's been bogged down in budget," said Charles I. Schonhaut, dean of Long Island University's education school and a former deputy chancellor. "Those initiatives that he wants to bring off he hasn't been able to pay the kind of attention to them that he should." Other educators note that Mr. Fernandez has lacked the money to undertake anything expensive.
Mr. Schonhaut, who was assistant to Chancellor Irving Anker when he had to cope with the bitter fiscal crisis of the mid-1970's, in which 14,000 teachers were laid off, said at such times the job of an educational leader is "damage control -- how can we have the system survive despite this enormous blow it's taking."
 Interviewed as he began his second year, Mr. Fernandez acknowledged that the budget crisis was a major diversion, but said that it would not set back his plans. "I came here on a reform agenda," he said. "And while there may be distractions, they're not going to change my fervor for getting it done."
The trouble is that the budget quagmire will not go away. Many of the artful strategies that Mr. Fernandez put together in recent days, like the wage deferral plan, only delay painful decisions.
New Yorkers may have to become more tolerant about the slow pace of change, suggested Jeanne Frankl, executive director of the Public Education Association, an old-line advocacy group. Ms. Frankl blamed the city's political culture and not Mr. Fernandez for some of the Chancellor's more superficial stabs at change.
"I really think these glamorous initiatives are a response to the very high expectations of New York business and media and nonpublic school communities that some hero will come in and fix it all up," Ms. Frankl said. "And being a very skillful politician and public figure, he has responded to those demands."

HEADLINE: The Region;
Two Governors Face the Facts Of Life in a Lean Time

 BODY:
IT was a big week for bad news.
On Tuesday, Gov. Jim Florio of New Jersey proposed a $14.3 billion budget that called for thousands of layoffs and an 8 percent across-the-board cut in spending by state departments. The budget called for no new taxes, but included a controversial revenue-raising trick: the sale of $400 million worth of state roads to the New Jersey Turnpike Authority. 
 Although Governor Florio's budget reflects recessionary times, it nevertheless increases spending by 13 percent. The money will come from higher taxes that went into effect last year, and it will be largely eaten up by new costs the state has taken on for education and for welfare payments formerly paid by local governments.
On Thursday, it was Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's turn in New York. Mr. Cuomo offered a $29.1 billion budget that called for state spending to remain unchanged for the coming year.
Because the cost of state services will increase with inflation, this no-growth budget translated into deep cuts in programs. The Governor proposed to slash spending on education, Medicaid and aid to local governments. He also called for a 10-cent-a-gallon rise in the state gasoline tax, a 2 percent tax on out-of-state telephone calls and an extension of the state's sales tax to include moving services and mandatory gratuities. Mr. Cuomo was also looking for novel ways to raise money: he proposed selling Aqueduct race track to the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.
Both Governors' budgets represent only the first round of drawn-out budget battles in Albany and Trenton. Expect the fighting to be fierce.

HEADLINE: The World;
If It's Good News For the Oil Industry, The World Beware

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
THERE is war in the Persian Gulf, recession nationwide and stubbornly high gasoline prices on every street corner, but over the last few days the major oil companies have nervously weighed in with news of a different tone: their profits are up sharply.
 Oil is probably the only industry that is bashful about higher profits, and with good reason. "Profits are exceptionally high only when there's some exceptional condition," said John H. Lichtblau, president of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation, a nonprofit group in New York, "and it's very often tied to exceptional bad news." 
 The last time many of the companies had it so good, at least in terms of prices, was at the beginning of 1990, when a record-breaking cold spell drove the price of heating oil up sharply, along with consumers' tempers. In spring 1989, they enjoyed a sudden spike in gasoline prices brought on when the Exxon Valdez fouled the waters of south-central Alaska and the port of Valdez was briefly shut.
 To economists, this all seems natural. "All U.S. industries should be expected to 'make hay while the sun shines,' just as they endure unfavorable conditions," wrote Robert L. Bradley Jr., president of the Institute for Energy Research in Houston. "Does a homeowner sell his house at historic cost or at whatever price the market will bear? If homeowners were forced to sell their houses at historic cost in a rising market, there would be excess demand for homes and a housing shortage -- just as there were oil shortages in 1974 and 1979." Those shortages were made worse, he argued, because prices were held down by government controls, so consumers did not conserve.
 Oil is an industry people love to hate. As industry executives see it, people resent it that the car, the symbol of independence, is actually tied to the multinational corporations that supply the fuel. "People don't like to feel dependent, helpless, without options," said Arthur E. Weise, a spokesman for the American Petroleum Institute, the industry's main trade association. The oil market is often compared with the market for other commodities, he said, but if the price of orange juice rises, "people can drink tomato juice or not drink anything, and still lead perfectly fulfilled, happy lives."
 Another problem, he said, is that the oil companies are so huge, with profits in the billions. Other industries have huge companies, but few that deal directly with the public. "No one goes in and buys steel," he said.
 Others trace the public's feelings to the old days of the Rockefeller oil trust, Standard Oil. "It goes back to Standard Oil and price fixing," said Kent Hance, a former Congressman and chairman of the Texas Railroad Commission. "You learned about it in school," he said, "and you grew up thinking that oil companies are going to gouge you on gasoline, regardless. If gasoline was 20 cents a gallon, some people would be saying 'they're gouging us.' "
 Certainly the industry's timing, from a public relations standpoint, is dreadful. The profitable fourth-quarter results came out as the air war started. Many oil companies commission polls to measure how they are perceived. They know the world hates them. And they would rather be loved, not least because of renewed calls for a tax on "windfall profits," as was imposed in the 1970's, by lawmakers who think it is wrong for a well owner to benefit because the barrels he used to sell for $20 are now worth $40.
 The companies, chastened by President Bush last August to "show restraint" in gasoline prices and "not take advantage of the Middle East situation," thought they were ready when the bombers went in two weeks ago. Most of them declared price freezes in the first few hours of the air war. This gesture did them little good, however, because oil prices unexpectedly fell. In New York, the freeze actually seemed to hurt the companies' image; New York City's Consumer Affairs Commissioner and the chairman of the state Consumer Protection Board quickly charged that the freezes were a ploy to keep prices from falling.
 The industry conducted an intense campaign as the season for announcing fourth quarter results approached, explaining that American companies do not control the oil market, and that despite sudden prosperity they were not, over the long haul, terribly profitable. With the drop in prices as the war began, the current quarter will not be particularly attractive, they say.
 Mobil ran ads in national publications saying that in 12 years of the last 20, everything from television to tobacco was more profitable than oil.
 But others painted a different picture. John S. Herold Inc., a financial analyst that regularly publishes value estimates of oil companies, said last week that for shareholders in most major oil companies, total returns -- capital gains plus dividends -- were higher than for the Dow Jones index as a whole for the last five years.
 Chevron, based in San Francisco, sent its chairman to New York with a sheaf of charts to persuade reporters that oil was friendly. Prices for gasoline never rose nearly as much as the crude from which it is made, he said.
 But a telephone survey of 1,500 adults in December by Winona Market Research Inc., commissioned by Chevron, showed that among the 27 percent who opposed President Bush's decision to send troops to the gulf, one third thought the reason troops were sent was "to protect U.S. oil companies' assets in the Middle East."
 In reality, as Chevron noted, nearly all of those properties were nationalized before the Arab oil embargo of 1973-74. Chevron and other companies do not claim that oil has nothing to do with the war; they stress, though, that the issue is access. Few of the people surveyed knew of a Department of Energy report exonerating the companies of price gouging early in the crisis, but those who were told of it still did not trust the industry, the survey found.
The public, rightly or wrongly, continues to bite the hand that lights it, heats it and propels it. Oil provides about 42 percent of the energy consumed in this country, down only slightly from its share at the time of the first major oil crisis, in 1973, and is unlikely to fall sharply any time soon. Confronted with decisions about whether to drill in wilderness areas, whether to grant tax breaks or whether to institute import fees, the nation is facing the challenge of making rational policy judgments about an industry it hates.

HEADLINE: PRO BASKETBALL: Midseason Report;
After a Half, Knicks Faltering on All Fronts

BYLINE: By CLIFTON BROWN

 BODY:
Anyone who can solve the Knicks' problems should report to Madison Square Garden immediately. The team needs help. No one expected New York to be well under .500 this late in the season; not the players, not the coaches, not the front office, not the fans, not even the team's opponents. But the Knicks, with a record of 20-25 after their victory over Sacramento last night, have earned every defeat.
Their play has lacked emotion. Their overall effort has been questionable in many games. And while they are a veteran team, they have not matured as a unit on the floor. Under pressure, they are prone to make costly turnovers, to force bad shots, to make mental errors, to forget teamwork and to resort to one-on-one play. 
 If the Knicks make the playoffs, what are the odds of them beating Boston, Detroit or Chicago in a series when they have trouble beating Orlando and Minnesota at home? With New York apparently headed toward an early summer vacation, here is an assessment of the team midway through a disappointing season, with the criticism spread around:
 
Front Office
 Before last Thursday night, when Bernard King scored 49 points in leading the Washington Bullets past the Knicks, had you ever heard fans heckling a general manager in the middle of a game? Al Bianchi, the Knicks' general manager, is taking so much heat these days, it's surprising he doesn't have a permanent tan.
With the Knicks over the salary cap when his tenure began in the summer of 1987, Bianchi inherited a difficult job. And the team improved dramatically during Bianchi's first two seasons, largely because he acquired Mark Jackson, Charles Oakley, Rod Strickland, Johnny Newman and Sidney Green.
But Bianchi's most recent moves have not worked out as he had hoped.
The decision last summer not to re-sign Newman, who accepted an offer from the Charlotte Hornets, was based on economics. But the Knicks are still over the salary cap without Newman's salary, and they miss his scoring.
Strickland, unhappy with his playing time in New York last season, forced the Knicks to choose between him and Jackson as the point guard of the future. Before last season was over, Bianchi traded Strickland to San Antonio for Maurice Cheeks, who despite a potential Hall of Fame career, is 34 years old. Strickland is 24. And Cheeks's arrival only enhanced the point guard controversy. Now the Knicks are wondering what to do about the 25-year-old Jackson, who is unhappy playing behind Cheeks.
While Bianchi has been waiting for the Knicks to improve as a half-court team for two seasons, their personnel remains better suited to playing up-tempo basketball. Last fall, Bianchi became disenchanted enough with Stu Jackson to replace Jackson on Dec. 3, just 15 games into the coach's second season, with John MacLeod. But despite MacLeod's emphasis on fundamentals and teamwork, the Knicks are struggling worse under MacLeod than they did under Jackson.
Bianchi wants to make a trade, perhaps several trades, before the Feb. 21 deadline. But he is bargaining from a weak position. Many league executives feel the only two Knicks with strong trade value are Patrick Ewing and Oakley. Jackson's huge contract, Gerald Wilkins's erratic play, Cheeks's age, Kiki Vandeweghe's propensity for injury and Jerrod Mustaf's untapped potential make them hard to trade for someone of value.
Bianchi knew the Knicks needed help last summer, but he did not make a deal. Now it may be too late.
Hindsight is easier than foresight, and Bianchi staunchly defends almost all of his decisions. But consider this: Is the Knicks' present roster weaker than it was two years ago, when they ended the season with Oakley, Newman, Ewing, Jackson and Wilkins as starters, with Vandeweghe, Strickland, Trent Tucker, Kenny Walker, Sidney Green, Eddie Lee Wilkins and Pete Myers on the bench?
Perhaps the Knicks have been overestimating their talent for the last two years and are paying for it now. Unless they finish the season strongly and win at least one playoff series, New York fans may not have Bianchi to kick around anymore.
 
Coaching
 Those who thought Stu Jackson was the major reason for the Knicks' slow start this season have discovered otherwise. From his first day on the job, MacLeod has emphasized improving the Knicks' fundamentals: blocking out for rebounds, playing one-on-one defense, passing unselfishly, taking high-percentage shots. But whatever improvement New York has shown in these areas has come slowly and appeared inconsistently.
Some players are upset by MacLeod's failure to set defined roles. One night, a player may get 20 minutes; the next, he may not play at all. MacLeod also has tried numerous starting lineups, and says he will continue to make changes until the Knicks win consistently. But the constant shuffling of players may be doing more harm than good.
MacLeod is a proven winner, but it does not matter who is coaching the Knicks if they do not practice what the coach preaches. The Knicks may have too many problems to solve before April. And unfortunately for MacLeod, he may not get the opportunity next year to work with the Knicks from the opening of training camp.
 
Players
 Forwards -- Oakley is one of the game's best rebounders, but he also has games when he grabs just five or six rebounds and is virtually not a factor. And Oakley's lack of post-up moves leaves Ewing as New York's lone consistent low-post scorer.
Vandeweghe's chronic back condition rarely allows him to play at top effectiveness for more than a few weeks. He can score consistently, but he is no longer one of the league's most feared offensive players.
Walker's contribution off the bench has dropped dramtically this season because of a sore knee and reduced playing time. Brian Quinnett has an excellent jump shot, but lacks the all-round game to contribute consistently. MacLeod has turned away from Mustaf, preferring to use more experienced players.
Center -- Ewing has retained his rank as one of the game's top players. And win or lose, Ewing always gives maximum effort, one of the qualities that make him extraordinary. Despite his frustration with the Knicks' record, he never lets it affect his mental preparation for games.
One of the few criticisms of Ewing is his reluctance to take a more forceful role in the locker room. He is a quiet person by nature, but Ewing is the only Knick who carries enough clout to make a difference in the team's attitude. Magic Johnson, Michael Jordan, Isiah Thomas and Larry Bird have been known to pull teammates aside when they are not performing, even yelling at teammates during games. Ewing seems to prefer leading by example, a trait that this team does not seem to respond to.
Eddie Lee Wilkins has never changed. He looks to score whenever he gets the ball, and sometimes he does. Yet he is still prone to foul trouble and he is not an intimidating defensive presence.
Guards -- Cheeks is totally unselfish, careful with the ball, a gifted defender, and has great basketball intellect. He is not a scorer, though, and he sometimes passes up open shots.
Jackson is in excellent shape, has played much better than last season, and has managed to control his anger concerning his backup status. His biggest problem is defense. Opposing guards go by Jackson consistently, putting pressure on New York's interior defense.
The more Jackson plays, the better he is. He made need a change in scenery to regain his form of two years ago.
Gerald Wilkins has improved his outside shot and has as much athletic ability as any of the Knicks. But he is still inconsistent, and he is prone to make blatant turnovers, especially in half-court situations. He would probably be more effective on a team that played more transition basketball.
John Starks plays with enthusiasm and has ignited the Knicks on several occasions. But his outside shot is not good enough to make him a consistent scoring threat.
Tucker has gone from hardly playing at all to becoming a starter last week. His outside shot has not been as consistent as it has been in the past, but he would probably have a higher shooting percentage if he were playing more regularly.
 
Outlook
 If the Knicks make a beneficial trade and become more comfortable with MacLeod's system, it is possible they could improve during the second half of this season. But right now, they show no signs of doing so. None of the Knicks are canceling their vacation plans for June.

HEADLINE: HORSE RACING;
War and Recession Hit Thoroughbred Industry

BYLINE: By JOSEPH DURSO

 BODY:
When war broke out in the Middle East two and a half weeks ago, the eyes of the horse-racing world were turned on the annual January sale of thoroughbreds at Keeneland in Kentucky, a world-class auction that can make champions or break fortunes.
To be precise, the eyes of the racing world were turned on the big plungers, the princes and sheiks from Dubai and Saudi Arabia, who have spent $250 million at Keeneland in the last 10 years and now own 500 mares and 900 thoroughbreds in training on a dozen major farms in Kentucky, Ireland and England.
This time, they bought two horses. 
 "They arrived in Kentucky in 1981 and they've been the most significant group of foreign buyers by far," said James E. Bassett 3d, chairman of the Keeneland Association and director of the Breeders' Cup. "They buy at the top of the market. But their interest may wane."
To Calumet Farm, the home of champions, it looked as though everybody's interest might wane. The farm sent 96 horses into the auction ring at Keeneland that same week in an effort to reduce its stock, didn't hear the bids it had expected and went home with 34 of them.
"I've never seen many people sell horses," explained J. T. Lundy, the president of Calumet, "that didn't have a bottom price."
Thoroughbred racing is a luxury to some, a way of life to others, a livelihood to thousands and a $2 bet to millions. It attracts about 60 million people to tracks in 36 states on a total of 8,000 racing dates each year, and they bet more than $9 billion, while $3.5 billion more is bet at offtrack parlors or casinos.
But attendance and even betting seem to be waning, along with the sheiks' interest in buying horses at Keeneland. And racing people are wondering if these are omens:
*Gulfstream Park in Florida opened its current meeting to a record crowd on Jan. 14. But two days later, the war started in the Persian Gulf. Since then, tourism has plunged and attendance and betting at the race track have dropped 10 percent from a year ago.
*Santa Anita in California, which is usually spared the uncertainties of tourism and weather, is averaging 4.1 percent fewer customers in its current season, and they are betting 5.2 percent fewer dollars.
*Aqueduct in New York, which labors through the winter every year, is laboring more than ever this winter. It was hurt by one snowy day last month when only two races were held and only 2,329 persons showed up. But the numbers are stark, anyway: attendance is off by 14 percent, betting by 13 percent.
Is the recession eroding the life style centered on the horse? Is the war in the Middle East stemming the flow of money from Arabian investors, and transforming the financial structure of thoroughbred breeding? Or is horse racing reflecting a cutback in the public's spending on travel and leisure because of both the recession and the war?
On the international level, the answer for now seems to be no: The bloodstock market has been sinking for some years, initially because of changes in tax laws, lately because of the recession. But the heavy investors from the Middle East are probably wealthy enough to withstand fluctuations. And their horse holdings are based mainly in Kentucky and Britain.
On the national level, the answer seems to be yes: Fewer people betting fewer bucks at race tracks around the country. The recession diverts their dollars; the war diverts their interest.
"Everybody's weeping," said Joe Tannenbaum, a longtime racing official at Gulfsteam Park. "Dogs, travel, horses. The tourists aren't coming in big numbers, and the locals are staying home. Besides, we've got a great number of unemployed, especially since Eastern Air Lines folded and 8,000 jobs were lost here in South Florida alone.
"The big problem is the economy and the preoccupation with the war. Even our own staff keeps tuning in to TV."
"The only place we've gained," said Jane Goldstein, director of communications at Santa Anita, "is in overall betting at the track, by satellite and by commingling. And the reason we gained there is because we didn't have commingling last year."
Commingling is a system of taking bets at selected outside locations and feeding them into the betting pool at the track where the races are being run. It differs from the usual offtrack betting, which is independent of the track's wagering system.
Like most tracks, Santa Anita is introducing television and satellite technology to reach new markets of bettors, even far from the track. It now accepts commingling bets from the Nevada bookmakers, the Canterbury Downs track in Minnesota, the Birmingham Race Course in Alabama and Mountaineer Park in West Virginia.
But racing people everywhere concede the problem is double-edged: How to get people to come to the track to spend their money, and how to get people who can't come to the track to spend it, anyway.
"We've got to find reasons to get people to come out and watch a horse," said Jerry Lawrence, the new executive vice president of the New York Racing Association. "The competition is increasing from offtrack betting, casinos, a lot of things."
But Philip Dunn, executive director of television systems and simulcasting for New York racing, said: "The future is not on the track. You have to bring the product to the people."
Rich Rolapp of the American Horse Council in Washington gave a global overview that linked all the tremors in racing.
"With the Persian Gulf crisis," he said, "people just aren't going out as much. Travel's down. Theme parks are down. Casinos in Las Vegas are down. I don't think it's so much a reflection of the economy as the war. People are focusing on it.
"The bloodstock market has been in a downtrend for years. Tax changes in 1981 set the stage, and again in 1986. People were putting their money into stocks and bonds and other tangibles. Then the recession comes along, and the people who might buy horses may not have the money.
"The Arabs always bought horses at peak prices. The money comes from the small but wealthy Arab states. My impression is they stopped investing after the invasion of Kuwait because of the uncertainty of the Middle East situation."
But Ted Bassett, who heads both the Keeneland track and the Breeders' Cup series of championship races, suspects that the Arabs didn't spend as freely at the horse sales last month for a simpler reason: They already have all the race horses they can use for now.
"They're not affected by the recession in the United States," he said. "I don't think they're even affected by the war. They all have major farms in Kentucky and half a dozen in Ireland and England.
"They arrived in 1981, and they've spent in excess of $250 million at Keeneland since then. There are two groups: Sheik Mohammad Bin Rashid al Maktoum and his two brothers from Dubai in the United Arab Emirates, and Prince Khaled Abdullah from Saudi Arabia. Their interest may have waned at our sales, but only because they had reached a maximum level."
But, looking past today's financial hurdles in racing, Ted Bassett saw a glimmer.
"Horses generally appreciate faster than the rate of inflation," he said. "So, they're a good investment in down times."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL NOTEBOOK;
Hall of Famer Palmer Says He Pitched Wrong

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
Jim Palmer's attempted comeback, as improbable as it might seem, has to be particularly galling to Pete Rose. Not only can't Rose make a comeback, but he also will learn tomorrow that he's not eligible for the Hall of Fame. Palmer is already in the Hall of Fame.
The hall's board of directors meets tomorrow to act on the recommendation by a special committee that anyone who is on baseball's permanently ineligible list be ineligible for the Hall of Fame. Rose is the only one around who in recent years has come to fit that description, so it's not difficult to link the board's action to Rose. 
 Palmer, on the other hand, is on the voluntarily retired list. He has been on that list so long, in fact, that he was eligible for the hall a year ago and gained instant entrance. Now, at the age of 45, six years after he last pitched, he is working to get himself off the voluntarily retired list.
"The career that got me to the Hall of Fame is over," Palmer said. "This is something different."
It certainly is different. No member of the hall ever has come back and played in the major leagues. Palmer doesn't know if he can, but he's just about ready to let people tell him if he can. Scouts from several clubs, including Baltimore, Montreal, Milwaukee and the Chicago White Sox, are expected to scrutinize the right-handed pitcher next weekend in Florida, where he has been throwing since mid-December.
Lazaro Collazo, for one, believes the scouts will like what they see. "I think he can get major league hitters out," Collazo said. "As a matter of fact, I know he can."
Collazo is an assistant coach for the University of Miami baseball team, for which he pitched several years ago. He has, in effect, been Palmer's guru in his comeback, even though he was born only the year before Palmer began pitching in the majors.
Known as Lazer, the 26-year-old Cuban has made an apparently significant change in Palmer's pitching motion.
"I told him how bad his mechanics look," Collazo said. "Instead of getting mad, he listened and worked on it. He had bad mechanics when he pitched. He could have got a lot more out of his body and arm if he had done it right."
Palmer recalled how Collazo approached that subject.
 "For a guy who's getting in the Hall of Fame, your mechanics are awful," Collazo said to Palmer.
"I'm in the Hall of Fame," Palmer countered.
"Lazer is great," Palmer said. "It took a lot of nerve to tell me my mechanics were awful."
The change in mechanics has to do with the positioning of Palmer's glove when he pitches the ball. Instead of snapping the glove back toward his chest, Palmer always let it wander off toward the first-base line, pocket side away from him. That move placed great stess on his left side, he recalled.
"My left side used to hurt as much as my right side," he said. "I kept winning 20 games, so no one wanted to change me. If it ain't broke, don't fix it. Now, the way I'm doing it, it's very relaxing. If Lazer hadn't given me this tip to change my mechanics, I could never be doing this."
The question, though, isn't why has Palmer changed his mechanics, but rather why does he want to pitch again.
"What prompted me to do it was the state of the television industry," said Palmer, who did baseball games for ESPN last season. "It was kind of frustrating to be nominated for an A.C.E. award and get a congratulatory letter from ESPN, then two days later have them say we want you to work for us for three years at a drastic pay cut. All because they overpaid for the rights and losing over $50 million. I told them I'd take a pay cut for a year, but they said three years.
"The correlation of doing a good job and being rewarded for it doesn't exist so you look for something else to do. Part of feeling good about yourself is to have alternatives. I come to Florida every winter so I figured I'd start throwing and see where it went. One alternative is to do more games for the Orioles, which is what I'll do if I don't pitch. I'll let them know by mid-February."
Collazo said Palmer had been throwing his fastball in the 84- to 86-miles-an-hour range and has had a "great" breaking ball and a "great" changeup. Palmer, who regularly threw 95 m.p.h. in his prime, said he was throwing six or seven miles an hour harder than in 1984, his last season.
"I've been pleasantly surprised," said Palmer, who pitched 268 victories in a 19-year career with Baltimore. "I'm sure some people won't look on it with much credence, but I know I can pitch again. I've had a blister problem, and if the blister gets well, I think they'll be pleasantly surprised. I'm going to let other people determine if I can pitch. If not this year, I'll hold the microphone with my left hand and throw with my right. I'll throw all year and do it next year. There's plenty left in my arm."
 
The Orioles' Influence
 The Mets' elevation of Al Harazin to the position of executive vice president, where he is a step away from succeeding Frank Cashen as general manager, is the latest boost for the fertile front-office field of the Baltimore Orioles.
Harazin spent seven years in the Orioles' front office, which Cashen ran for 10 years. The major leagues are filled with general managers who learned the business, or a major part of it, as employees of the Orioles. Their executive history is akin to the trail of former Dodgers who became managers and former players of Paul Brown who became football coaches.
Like Cashen and Harazin, Harry Dalton of Milwaukee, Lou Gorman of Boston and John Schuerholz of Atlanta began their major league careers in Baltimore's front office. Hank Peters of Cleveland began his career with the Orioles' predecessors, the St. Louis Browns, then later served as the Orioles' No. 1 executive for 13 years.
Joe McIlvaine of San Diego was an Orioles scout for three years in his first major league job, and Herk Robinson of Kansas City spent a season as a Baltimore scout before joining Gorman and Schuerholz with the fledgling Royals franchise.
Jim Frey of the Chicago Cubs served as a scout and a coach for the Orioles for 16 years. Pat Gillick of Toronto didn't work in the Orioles' front office, but he played in their minor league system for five years. Bill Lajoie, Detroit's recently departed general manager, played in the Orioles' organization for 10 years.
Counting Roland Hemond, current holder of the Baltimore job, 10 of the majors' 26 general managers have some link to the Orioles.
 
Another Height for Clemens to Scale
 His confrontations with umpires and police officers have not reduced the value Roger Clemens has to the Boston Red Sox. The two sides, in fact, are said to be close to announcing a contract extension that will be the most lucrative contract in baseball's rapidly changing economic history.
The Red Sox had wanted to hold the extension to four years, but Clemens wanted five and will apparently get his wish. He will also receive what officials of other clubs have heard will be a total in the $25 million to $27 million range. Jose Canseco of Oakland has the heftiest contract now: five years for $23.5 million.
Clemens's contract will have the impact of a resounding thud on the Mets' negotiations with Dwight Gooden and Frank Viola for extensions. The Mets would like to hold those deals to three years for something less than -- certainly no more than -- $12 million. The pitchers, who have different ideas, will have those thoughts enhanced once the Clemens negotiations are completed.

HEADLINE: Never Saw a Protest I Didn't Like, but Now. . .;
Blacks in the Military

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "The Protesters, Heard" (editorial, Jan. 27), you suggest that the disproportionate representation of blacks in the United States military is testimony to the opening of the military to advancement by minorities, and not itself a symptom of social pathology. Contrary to your observation, the rise of Gen. Colin L. Powell to Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, and the positive racial role model that may provide, does not explain why blacks are 12 percent of the United States population but 29 percent of the armed services.
Blacks are two and a half times more likely to join the military than other Americans because their civilian options are so severely limited. Young blacks face an unemployment rate of more than 50 percent. When the effective choices are poverty, criminal activity or the military, the military's offer of upward mobility may be exceptionally attractive.
For blacks in the United States, as for the impoverished in the third world, the military has historically served as a vehicle for upward mobility. But before we congratulate ourselves for providing this opportunity, we should acknowledge its social genesis in racism, poverty and lack of alternative options.
 
GAYLE BINION
Chairman, Law & Society Program, University of California
Santa Barbara, Calif., Jan. 27, 1991

HEADLINE: Never Saw a Protest I Didn't Like, but Now. . .;
But Does Hussein Care?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Gary C. Hufbauer and Kimberly A. Elliott ("Sanctions Will Bite -- and Soon," Op-Ed, Jan. 14) drew conclusions about the effect of sanctions on Iraq that go well beyond what their evidence shows. They have looked at 115 cases in which sanctions were used, but as they acknowledge, they are not acquainted with Iraq's economy. I am, as the former desk officer for Iraq at the International Monetary Fund, and I have done a detailed study of the effect of sanctions on Iraq, published by the Washington Institute for Near East Policy.
Those of us inside and outside the Government who know Iraq's economy agree almost entirely about the impact of sanctions on it. Iraq is becoming a poorer and militarily weaker country day by day, and the food situation will be critical in May just before the wheat and barley harvest, which will give Iraq enough cereals to last until fall or winter. This, however, does not tell us whether Saddam Hussein cares enough about the growing poverty of his people to leave Kuwait.
I would hate to see us base our policy toward any country on an average of what has happened in the last 115 similar cases. Historical analogies are interesting but not decisive. Furthermore, Mr. Hufbauer and Ms. Elliott have an intriguing idea of how to read the record of the past. Among their 34 percent of successful cases of sanctions are World War I, World War II and the Falkland war. I wonder how many professional historians would agree with their judgment that sanctions made an important contribution to the outcome of those conflicts.
 
PATRICK CLAWSON
Philadelphia, Jan. 16, 1991
The writer is editor of Orbis, a journal of world affairs.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property: Showroom Buildings;
Specialty Dealers Remain Together To Draw the Buyers

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
A VACANCY RATE of 9 percent would look good almost anywhere, certainly in an 84-year-old building. But that is not all that distinguishes 225 Fifth Avenue.
"There are probably more wicker baskets in this building than bricks to hold it up," said Sean T. Higgins of Cushman & Wakefield, executive director of the property, which is best known as the Gift Building. Offering little outside evidence of its special character, the 12-story structure between 26th and 27th Streets is home to more than 175 tenants, representing something like 2,400 lines of wholesale merchandise. 
 Along potpourri-scented corridors that the public cannot travel are show windows filled with stuffed bears, ceramic rabbits, copper pigs, illuminated dachshunds, pewter nudes, enameled eggs, silk fruit, embroidered picture frames and crystal grandfather clocks.
No. 225 is among a cluster of specialty buildings, including the Toy Center South, 200 Fifth Avenue, between 23d and 24th Streets; the Toy Center North, 1107 Broadway, at 24th Street, and the Textile Building, 295 Fifth Avenue, between 30th and 31st Streets.
These buildings benefit from their tenants' having to stay close together to attract the greatest number of buyers, but they can also suffer more than those with heterogeneous rosters, because any industry-wide malaise affects every tenant in the building.
"The recession hits here first and it hits somewhat precipitously," Mr. Higgins said. "But this industry levels off more quickly. People may cut back here first, but Christmas doesn't go away. Birthdays still occur in a down market. So does Easter, bar mitzvahs, Mother's Day, Father's Day. People don't put off purchases of gifts for three years, as they might a refrigerator."
Thomas S. Arbuckle, the general manager of the Toy Center and a vice president of Helmsley-Spear, said that while his two buildings were completely occupied (except for ground-floor retail space on 23d Street), the days were long past when the industry was thought of as recession-proof.
"As a result of bankruptcies and other difficulties," he said, "there are fewer retailers to sell to than ever before. And many retailers are in a financial condition that it's questionable whether one can sell to them. That's very damaging to the toy industry. It's pretty frightening when you talk about whether people are afraid to sell to Macy's."
The Toy Center, whose tenants include Binney & Smith, Color Forms, Flexible Flyer, Kenner, Lego, Lionel, Matchbox, Ohio Art, Parker Brothers, Tonka and Tyco, is bracing for the annual Toy Fair, which begins Feb. 11, when 20,000 buyers descend on the buildings.
At the Textile Building, where the bed, bath and linen industry shows its lines, the vacancy rate is 7 percent. "The industry is not doing too well because it's dependent on the health of the big stores," said Claude J. Litton, president of the Manhattan Properties Company, which owns and manages the building. "We've had a certain weeding out. We've had people going bankrupt lately. However, over the long run -- and that's what we're geared for -- we do fine."
The Textile Building is in the hands of the family that built it in 1920. The Toy Center South has been under continuous ownership for 40 years by a syndicate formed by Harry B. Helmsley and the late Lawrence A. Wien, which now includes Mr. Wien's son-in-law, Peter L. Malkin. They have also owned the Toy Center North since 1967.
For many years, the Gift Building was owned by Milton Kimmelman, a hotelier and landlord, who died in 1984. It was bought from his estate in 1989, for $92.5 million, by the Japan Green Stamp Company of Tokyo and Saxon Capital Corporation of Manhattan.
"IN Japan, the trading-stamp business is still very successful," said Masahiko Kasuga, president of Japan Green Stamp America. "Because of the type of business, we can produce lots of cash flow." Looking for a place to invest some of that money, Japan Green Stamp began investigating Manhattan real estate in early 1988.
"We saw some high-profile hotels but that was not really what we wanted to do," Mr. Kasuga said. Noting that Japan Green Stamp owns the LS Collection boutiques, he said, "We're very interested in the gift business, so this building was the perfect match."
At the time, the building was 87 percent occupied. Since then, the new owners have put almost $3 million into remodeling the lobby, building a special-events room and cleaning the facade. Meanwhile, several tenants -- the Towle Manufacturing Company most prominent among them -- were filing for protection under the bankruptcy code. Now the building is 91 percent occupied.
"We've been going through even more tragedy in the industry than we expected," said Dennis A. Frank, president and chairman of the board of Saxon Capital. But he also noted that several leases now being negotiated would, if signed, bring the occupancy up to 94 or 95 percent.
To change the tone of the building, the new owners renamed it the International Showcase and set to work on the lobby. Mr. Kimmelman's son-in-law, Mitch Leigh -- the producer, director and composer ("Man of La Mancha") -- had earlier tried to put some Broadway sizzle into the space, with moving lights, pink and black walls and a front desk in the form of a grand piano. The results, however, were not to everyone's liking.
The new lobby, designed by Vicente Wolf Associates of Manhattan, has mahogany-paneled walls, a white barrel-vaulted ceiling and massively rusticated columns that echo those on the exterior.
As a result of the renovation, "the attitude in the building changed overnight," said Al Reiner, president of Knobler International and Pilgrim Glass and head of the tenants association. "When a buyer comes in, we want to set a tone that they're in a building that has exquisite taste," he said.
TENANTS were pleased when the new owners rolled back the rent 5 percent for the six months, from February to July 1990 (a gift from the landlord, dictated by Japanese custom, to celebrate the first anniversary of the acquisition); picked up the tab for challenging the city's real-estate assessments and then agreed to hold back 50 percent of the rent escalation pegged to the Consumer Price Index this year. "That's approximately $1,000 a month I'll save," Mr. Reiner said. "I promised that I'd take that money and put it into advertising, to attract buyers to 225."
Mr. Higgins, who says that 225 Fifth Avenue has to be run "more like a hotel than an office building," has found other ways to accommodate tenants. "As you know," he said, "it's against the law to get married without receiving five or six ice buckets." Competition is therefore intense to offer the latest, most eye-catching designs. So in the weeks before the semiannual Tabletop and Accessories Show, Mr. Higgins is besieged with requests for rolls of white paper, which tenants use to cover showroom windows and frustrate the spies among their neighbors.
There is one respect in which conditions have improved considerably, according to owners and managers, and that is the closing of the Prince George Hotel on East 27th Street, between Fifth and Madison Avenues. By the mid-1980's, the Prince George and two other hotels on the same block, the Latham and Madison, housed the greatest concentration of homeless people in New York City.
"Those three hotels stopped cold the growth that was taking place and actually reversed it for a short period," Mr. Arbuckle said. "We're just now beginning to recover from the damage that was done."
"We would like to see somebody buy the Prince George Hotel to renovate it into a businessman's hotel," Mr. Frank said. "That will help the situation tremendously."

CORRECTION-DATE: February 17, 1991, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Feb. 3 about showroom buildings misidentified the owner of the Toy Center and misstated the role of Harry B. Helmsley in the ownership. The owner is Fifth Avenue Building Associates. Mr. Helmsley is a minority partner of the buildings' operator, 200 Fifth Avenue Associates, not a partner in Fifth Avenue Building Associates.

HEADLINE: From Riches to Rags

BYLINE: By Michael Lewis; Michael Lewis is the author of "Liar's Poker" and an associate editor of The Spectator.

 BODY:

SQUANDERED FORTUNE
The Life and Times of Huntington Hartford.
By Lisa Rebecca Gubernick.
Illustrated. 272 pp. New York:
G. P. Putnam's Sons. $24.95. 
 A woodworker once told me that he learned more about furniture from taking it apart than from putting it together. Lisa Rebecca Gubernick's tale of a shiftless heir, "Squandered Fortune: The Life and Times of Huntington Hartford," should be read in a similar pathological spirit. In 1940 the Hartford family ranked among the nation's four wealthiest, trailing only the du Ponts, the Rockefellers and the Mellons. The family money came from the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, now the A.& P., which was owned by Huntington Hartford's grandfather. As late as 1955 Mr. Hartford, then 44 years old and poorer than when he was born, was still worth $100 million (the equivalent of about $400 million today). Thirty-five years later he had very little to show for it but photographs.
Most of them showed his mother, Henrietta. Mr. Hartford's father, Edward, died young, leaving his son in the care of a mother with ferocious social ambitions. Little Hunt wasn't raised so much as groomed. Each day he and his mother played croquet; each evening "they would walk around the porch, mallets in the small of their backs, following her regimen for proper posture." Hunt's teachers at St. Paul's School in Concord, N.H., referred to him in the classroom as the "million-dollar milk-fed baby." When he entered Harvard his mother moved to Boston to study with her son. The heir was left so exquisitely dependent that later, wishing to rid himself of his first wife, he actually suggested that his mother adopt her and make her his sister.
I'm stealing all of this from Ms. Gubernick -- who is worth stealing from. A senior editor at Forbes magazine, she writes well and handles her subject with the touch of a natural storyteller, interweaving Mr. Hartford's dissipation with the decline of the A.& P. (once a symbol of American capitalism, now owned by a German company -- a symbol of a different sort). As she tells it, some of the most pathetic moments concern Mr. Hartford's lifelong search for a job, a cause or a purpose. After leaving Harvard he joined the A.& P. as a clerk in charge of monitoring sales of bread and poundcake. He arrived late, left early and occasionally abandoned his desk to sleep on the floor. "There he was," said his uncle and employer, "surrounded by people who really had to work for a living, and he was receiving callers who wanted to sell him paintings." He was warned that if he took another day off he'd be fired. He pressed his luck. "Yale stopped Harvard 14-0 on November 24, 1934," writes Ms. Gubernick, "and Hunt and Mary Lee [his first wife] were there to see it. Thus ended his career at the A&P." "I had an income of over a million dollars a year," Mr. Hartford later said. "Can you imagine me sitting out with a bunch of clerks?"
Well, no. The idea of Huntington Hartford counting loaves of bread does seem ridiculous, especially if you believe -- as we like to pretend we do -- that the purpose of work is to get money. Mr. Hartford was denied this excuse to work by birth. He found himself nearly as disconnected as a pauper from the daily give-and-take of the money economy, and he flopped about his entire life in search of some plausible economic identity. He was hired by the short-lived New York newspaper PM as a reporter -- in exchange for his investment of $100,000. He tried to live on his salary of $120 a month. "I want to inject the element of struggle in my life," he said. The struggle lasted a few days. The job lasted six months. He opened a modeling agency, then was forced to sell it when the New York City Department of Consumer Affairs caught him propositioning the models. He opened and closed an institute for handwriting analysis. And so on. "Hunt spent his money the way he did," said wife number two, "to try to show that he could do serious things."
It wasn't until Mr. Hartford tried seriously to invest his fortune that it began to vanish. He then became a magnet for all those forces -- gold-digging spouses, bad advisers, shifty partners -- that exist to separate capital from its owners. His first three wives demanded seven-figure divorce settlements. His fourth wife sold his antique furniture. In one business deal alone -- the purchase and resale of an island called Paradise in the Bahamas -- Mr. Hartford in less than seven years turned $30 million into $1.5 million. The ease with which he was exploited suggests a strength of modern American capitalism: there is less than there is in, say, England, to shelter entrenched wealth from grasping upstarts. (If Karl Marx had been born in modern America he'd be dealing in real estate rather than protesting the tyranny of the capital-owning class; it's quicker.)
The few millions the cat-skinners missed were poured into the arts. Mr. Hartford, "a man who weighed his worth by the number of projects that bore his name" in Ms. Gubernick's words, founded a retreat for artists in California and named it the Huntington Hartford Foundation. He opened a theater in Los Angeles and an art museum in New York, both of them named for himself. For a brief moment he seemed something other than a case for confiscatory inheritance taxes.
"I have always wanted to be a crusader for that religion known as culture," he said. To that end he wrote a reactionary pamphlet on contemporary art entitled "Has God Been Insulted Here?" His zeal in denouncing such trends as abstract expressionism led a young journalist named Tom Wolfe to describe him as the new Martin Luther. But Mr. Hartford's Luther was comic. He was a Luther who journeyed to Wittenberg Cathedral with his theses and hammer only to realize he had forgotten his nails. Mr. Hartford could never make his points stick. He was, as Frank Lloyd Wright is reported to have remarked to a friend about Mr. Hartford, "the sort of man who will come up with an idea, pinch it in the fanny and run."
Until he could run no longer. Ms. Gubernick ends her story with a visit she made in 1989 to Mr. Hartford's Manhattan town house. There she found a squalid courtyard reeking of garbage, a warning on the front door from the Health Department and a broken man. "I pounded on the door for five minutes," she writes, "before Hartford, clad in a stained oxford-cloth shirt and boxer shorts, finally appeared. He said nothing as he opened the door. . . . I followed [him] up to his bedroom, watched as he lay down on the bed. 'I'm so tired, I'm just so tired.' He sighed and curled into fetal position . . . then drifted off into unconsciousness."
 
THE WONDER AND THE PITY
 Lisa Rebecca Gubernick admits to having a "weakness for broken butterflies." And when Ms. Gubernick, who writes about the entertainment business for Forbes magazine, was sent to interview Huntington Hartford, she found herself fascinated by the "wonder and the pity" of his life. "I couldn't believe what I was seeing," said Ms. Gubernick of her first encounter with a broken Mr. Hartford. "What I saw was downbeat and depressing, but it was also a great story about how so much can go so wrong."
For Ms. Gubernick, exploring Mr. Hartford's life was a way to explore Newport in the 1930's, Hollywood in the 1940's and the development of Paradise Island in the Bahamas in the 1960's. The James Bond-style Bahamian hideaway was typical of his ventures, costing him millions before he lost control. And her odyssey also afforded Ms. Gubernick a chance "to look at what money does to people."
"I don't see him as entirely unsympathetic," Ms. Gubernick said in a telephone interview from Los Angeles, where she was on assignment for Forbes. "I think he is a victim. He was never schooled in survival. Giving him so much money was like sticking a machine gun into the hands of a 3-year-old."
Ms. Gubernick, however, is far less charitable to Mr. Hartford as a father. She recalls attending Malcolm Forbes's funeral while writing "Squandered Fortune" and being touched by the eulogies from his children. Such affection is not the case with Mr. Hartford, who had four children from two of his four wives and from a mistress who later committed suicide.
His illegitimate son, who yearned for the Hartford name, also committed suicide. One daughter became a drug addict before dying young. Another son has kept his distance. Only his youngest daughter has regularly visited him.
"Each of the children," Ms. Gubernick said, fought for Mr. Hartford's attention "over and over again. There were so many material resources available and they were incredibly impoverished emotionally. He didn't have a father. He never knew how to be one." -- LESLIE WAYNE
