HEADLINE: Boxing;
Leonard Still Ticking as Clock Winds Down

BYLINE: By PHIL BERGER

 BODY:
It has come to this: He is 34 years old and the opponent this time around wears an earring. Need we further reminders that the clock is ticking down on the career of Ray Charles Leonard?
Conjure up the Sugar Ray Leonard whose 100-kilowatt smile and whirring fists won him a gold medal and worldwide acclaim at the 1976 Olympics in Montreal. That was nearly 15 years ago. 
 Fifteen years. Think about it. Ray Jr., who was 5 1/2 years old when he appeared with his famous father a few years later in those appealing soft drink commercials, is now 17, a senior at Churchill High School in Potomac, Md. College recruiters are scouting him as a running back and high hurdler.
Time flies, and in its flight it keeps agitating Leonard to rub up against danger, in seeming defiance of the deadening effects middle age routinely has on prize fighters. The other American gold medalists from those '76 Olympic games -- Michael and Leon Spinks, Howard Davis, Leo Randolph -- have all retired, but Leonard, who turned pro in February 1977, is still at it.
On Saturday at Madison Square Garden, he goes back into the ring once more, this time to fight Terry Norris for Norris's World Boxing Council superwelterweight title. The bout will be televised live on Showtime.
The 23-year-old Norris, who fights without the earring , is quick and strong and has a reputation of being a big puncher, particularly in the early rounds. He won his superwelterweight title (154-pound limit) by knocking out John (the Beast) Mugabi in one round last March, and in his only title defense, a decision over Rene Jacquot last July, he had Jacquot on the canvas three times, in the 1st, 2d and 12th rounds.
Leonard, whose opponents have lately been mostly over 30 -- the so-called seniors tour -- welcomes the test against a youngblood like Norris, believing it will clarify just how well his skills have or haven't held up. "My palms sweat," he said, underlining his eagerness for this combat.
"Everything holds more significance for me because I'm touching the end of my career," he said. "So I value each and every time I step out there. And I can tell you this: I still want to train and be in shape and look good. I don't want to just show up."
If Leonard seems reluctant these days to acknowledge being any less the fighter he was in earlier years -- "I'm just as quick," he said -- the longer that self-analysis proceeds, the more it echoes a boxer keenly aware of inexorable change.
"I'm more economical now, and far more analytical," he said, in assessing the fighter he has become. "I try to break my opponents down mentally even more than physically."
As ever, though, a fight is a test of wills, the outcome often depending on that innate spark that a boxer either has or hasn't. When Leonard says, "I'm still as gutsy as I ever was; I still go for it when the fight is tight," he sounds like a man not about to yield center stage, middle age or not, without a furious struggle.
"Norris is a young, fresh champion with physical attributes like mine: the speed and mobility," Leonard said. "He's got the ability to push me to the limit. But as far as I'm concerned, I can contend with any guys in this era."
As for Norris (26-3, 15 knockouts), he said that when he was a youngster Leonard was his hero, but he professes to be undaunted by the prospect of having to thrash him now. "It's my time; it's my turn," Norris said.
Leonard (36-1-1, 25 knockouts), who has won world titles in weight classes ranging from welterweight (147-pound limit) to light heavyweight (175-pound limit), has not fought in more than a year. The last time was on Dec. 7, 1989, when he outboxed Roberto Duran to win a lopsided 12-round decision.
The Duran bout was not the sort of thriller on which fans of Leonard were raised and by which Leonard became crowd pleaser enough to earn more than $105 million in purses, which is the career total credited to him by his attorney, Mike Trainer.
Against Duran, Leonard fought more conservatively than he usually does, content to jab Duran silly and then retreat. But he was not unaware of the crowd's restlessness with his tactics, and late in the fight he tried to mix with Duran. The assault backfired. While trading punches, he suffered cuts over his right brow and on his left eyelid.
Leonard would later say the cuts came from Duran's head rather than his fists. But the wounds were the latest of the small calamities Leonard has known in recent bouts.
In November 1988, when he fought Donny Lalonde for the W.B.C. supermiddleweight and light-heavyweight titles, Lalonde knocked him down in the fourth round and rocked him in the ninth, the same round in which Leonard came on to stop him.
In June 1989, Thomas Hearns scored two knockdowns in a disputed draw, a decision that Leonard now says should have gone to Hearns. In the early rounds that night Leonard seemed acutely wary as Hearns winged serious punches, a tentativeness out of character for him.
Taken in the cumulative impression, these sticky moments could be viewed as a portent of things to come Saturday. To Leonard, though, they are merely the vagaries of a hard trade and by no means a signal of his imminent demise. He is the man, after all, who shrugged off a detached retina and came out of retirement twice to make comebacks that included a stunning upset of the seemingly invincible middleweight, Marvelous Marvin Hagler.
So while the rough patches in recent bouts may signal the first stage of decrepitude to some, attention must be paid to Leonard, who disagrees.
On Lalonde: "He may look somewhat awkward and all but hey, Lalonde can punch. His right hand is lethal."
On Hearns: "Tommy was ready. My problem was I listened to what you guys were writing -- that he was a shot fighter -- and I think inadvertently I fell into that mode. Everybody was saying it, my camp, my brothers: 'One good shot and it's over.' But let me tell you, whoever fights me gets themselves to another level. Think of the rewards of beating me."
On Duran: "Other than the cuts, I felt, 'Hey, I got it all back.' Deja vu. The movement, the speed."
If skeptics might see these responses as the usual palliatives fighters concoct to sustain their illusion of potency -- a necessary illusion, to be sure -- Trainer insists that they would be wrong to think that of Leonard. For what Leonard has done, he says, is to show an artiste's compulsion for challenge, in recent years fighting opponents whose weight advantage was often far greater than it seemed.
"While the other guy would go in the ring 5, 6, 7 pounds heavier than he was at the weigh-in, Ray would actually lose weight the day of the fight," Trainer said. "It's adrenaline, and more: it's his nature.
"Look, the cuts from the Duran fight can happen to anyone. There isn't a guy in boxing that gets examined more regularly than Ray. He's been to the top dermatologists. They tell him, 'Your skin is fine.' As for the knockdowns, if you go back and look at Ray Leonard's history, you'll find Ray always got hit. He got hit because he was aggressive. The difference is back then he was hit by guys his size."
After Leonard beat Duran, he was eager to fight again, as soon as possible. But his divorce from his wife, Juanita, grew thorny, in spite of a prenuptial agreement that Trainer said the fighter and she signed before their marriage in January 1980. Leonard was soon deep in marital complications and not thinking of boxing.
"I was trying to resolve that marriage situation," Leonard said. "It became a priority, to settle it without it becoming a circus."
The case was settled in November and the divorce became final in December, with Leonard and his wife agreeing to joint custody of their two sons. Leonard retained the five-bedroom home on two and a half acres in Potomac, Md., where he now lives with Ray Jr. His wife resides with the younger son, Jarrel, 6, in the house Leonard bought her in Bowie, Md., when they separated about two years ago.
In the period since he fought Duran, Leonard has been shuttling between Los Angeles, where his girlfriend lives, and Potomac, where he has been spending time with his sons, on occasion feeling chagrined by paternal duty.
"One time I took Jarrel to the Air and Space Museum at the Smithsonian," said Leonard. "I got down there. Jarrel says to me, 'Daddy, the jets are upstairs.' And he proceeded to give me the tour.
"Little Ray has a class in film production in high school, and had a project to direct and produce a commercial. He got home one night; I asked him what he was doing. He said he had to edit the commercial. I asked him, 'Where's the story board?' He looked at me, like he couldn't be bothered, and said, 'Daaaddy, I'm busy.' "
A smile, a shrug: the boxing legend as befuddled father.
Over the past year, Leonard said, he did no boxing workouts, but kept a semblance of condition by running several times a week and playing tennis. In December, though, when he began training for Norris, he found that he was a long way from being in fighting trim. A week or so into his training camp, he was knocked down by a sparring partner, Michael Ward. Leonard termed the knockdown "my wake-up call."
The prevailing sentiment is that despite being the betting favorite, Leonard stands at some risk against Norris, jeopardy that is accentuated by the minor hitches that have developed in recent fights. Of course, the element of danger is heightened by Leonard's advanced boxing years -- he will be 35 in May -- an age that prompts alarmists to view his refusal to retire as folly. The frequently heard refrain is: What does he need it for? What's he trying to prove?
Trainer said for sure Leonard was not boxing for just the money.
"Ray can't spend the interest he's earning," Trainer said. "It's seven figures a year, interest on a very conservative portfolio. Tax-free municipal bonds, treasury obligations, C.D.s under $100,000, Ginny Maes, I.M.R.A.'s. There are no stocks, no cattle, no investments in oil and gas drilling or historic hotels. He doesn't own a plane, a yacht or limo, and isn't in any joint ventures or partnerships. The only exception: He did make a commitment to a local group vying for a major league baseball franchise to be a minority investor."
Then if not the money, what keeps Sugar Ray on boxing's center stage?
"Simple," Leonard said. "I enjoy it, and I do it fairly well. Why 34 is such an old and ancient age beats me. I guess it gets to me when people say, 'Why are you still fighting?' Why shouldn't I? If I beat the guys that claim to be monsters, why can't I?"

GRAPHIC: Photos: Sugar Ray Leonard, now 34 years old, will fight at Madison Square Garden on Saturday night (Jeff Chevrier) (pg. 1); Sugar Ray Leonard fighting Roberto Duran, Thomas Hearns and Marvin Hagler (pg. 4)

HEADLINE: GOLF;
L.P.G.A. Seeks Stability With Mechem

BYLINE: By JAIME DIAZ

 BODY:
The Ladies Professional Golf Association's 41st season opened in Jamaica the same week war broke out in the Persian Gulf, and the sense of incongruency was emphasized by the lack of televisions at the cloistered Tryall Club.
So while Charles S. Mechem Jr. tried to explain his views on becoming the tour's new commissioner in a sitting room equipped with a rare and unactivated television, several people craving an update on the war anxiously popped their heads in.
"Any more bombing?" one man asked. 
 "Not that I know of," said Mechem in the pleasant intonation that is his natural voice. Turning back to his interviewer, Mechem gestured toward the television and said, "I guess we're lost without it."
The commissioner could have been talking about the L.P.G.A., whose irregular presence on the tube in recent years has caused it to stagnate in the national sports consciousness. If the 60-year-old Mechem has a mandate, it is to get women's golf on television as much as possible.
Mechem appears well-suited to the task of stablizing an organization that has undergone an intense self-examination in the last three years. With a background that has included prolonged stints as a lawyer, television executive and women's tournament sponsor, Mechem is on paper the most well-rounded, highly qualified commissioner the L.P.G.A. has ever had.
"I think the L.P.G.A. made the perfect choice," said Frank Chirkanian, the executive producer of golf for CBS. "It's important they have somebody who is an expert in what makes professional golf work, and Charlie is a man who will make good things happen."
Judy Dickinson, the L.P.G.A. president who was instrumental in persuading Mechem to take the job, takes a more comprehensive view.
"Charlie gives us a lot of respectability in every area," said Dickinson. "I think that with this commissioner, the sky's the limit."'
Perhaps, but Mechem inherits an L.P.G.A. vessel that recently underwent a bumpy emergency landing. The association is recovering from the divisive, sometimes chaotic regime of Bill Blue, who was forced to resign last September after 19 months on the job.
Blue, who was hired for his expertise in marketing, mixed a slick public presentation with a brusque interpersonal manner that ended up alienating him from sponsors and players and left him open to charges of questionable integrity.
Mechem, while taking pains to avoid casting even indirect aspersions on his predecessor, has made it clear by his actions that his style will be substantially different.
Unlike Blue, who never moved his primary residence from his luxury condominium in Beverly Hills, Mechem has taken up an apartment near the L.P.G.A. headquarters in Daytona Beach, Fla., a location only 200 miles from the permanent residence he and his wife keep in Jupiter.
To heal wounds and establish the kind of relationships he feels will be essential to longterm success, Mechem has begun his tenure crisscrossing the country to meet with as many sponsors, players, media, and of course, television executives, as possible.
"I trust Mr. Mechem, and that's very important," Vic Higgs, the tournament director at Jamaica who was one of the first sponsors to speak out against Blue. "The commissioner should be equal parts manager, diplomat and salesman, and I believe he will be very good at all those things."
While the tenor regarding Mechem's early reign is optimism, the L.P.G.A.'s players, despite Dickinson's "sky's the limit" metaphor, are cautious. It was not that long ago that they were singing the praises of the newly appointed and unproven Blue.
"We know we have a good man who is going to do the best possible job for us," said the veteran player Colleen Walker. "The money will go up, and we will probably get on television more, but we don't really expect anything specific. We just want an organization we can be proud to belong to."
Such a view is consistent with Mechem's own track record of achievement the old-fashioned way. Born and reared in the small town of Nelsonville, Ohio, he earned a law degree from Yale and was a captain in the Army before joining a law practice in Cincinnati.
In 1967, Mechem became chairman and chief executive of Taft Broadcasting (now Great American Broadcasting), which owns five television stations, 17 radio stations, Hanna-Barbera Productions, and helps develop amusement parks. For 12 years, the company was also a co-sponsor of the L.P.G.A. Championship. Mechem retired from Great America last May.
Dickinson and the tour's executive board and offered a five-year contract conservatively estimated to be worth well over $1 million. After talking it over with his wife of 38 years, Marilyn, Mechum agreed in November to become the fourth commissioner in the L.P.G.A.'s history.
But even if his social skills and integrity are unquestioned, Mechem has a tough job ahead. Women's golf has in the last decade been decisively passed by the Senior Tour. And in an uncertain economy in which even the burgeoning PGA Tour has begun to lose some sponsors, the L.P.G.A.'s traditional slow but steady growth could be in jeopardy.
In 1991, the women will be playing for more money than ever with $17.4 million in total purses. But the schedule will again contain a three-week gap in April devoid of an event that has been derisively dubbed "Spring Break." Only 12 of the 37 events will be televised in this country, with no television scheduled from April 1 to June 27.
The L.P.G.A. also needs to expand and improve its administration, which lost two high level deputies with Blue's ouster, as well as implement an anti-discrimination policy for its host clubs similar to ones adopted by the PGA Tour, the PGA of America and the United States Golf Association in the wake of Shoal Creek.
With the male dominated structure of most private clubs, this could be tricky for a women's organization that is not in a power position financially.
As he learns the lay of the land, Mechem is hesitant to get into specifics about future moves.
"The only way I've ever known to really market something is to make the organization so strong and so attractive that it basically sells itself," said Mechem. "If you try to do it any other way, you're going to have some Roman candle kind of successes: a big display, and then nothing."
Mechem has started to use his building-block approach to make inroads into the quicksilver starmaking machinery of television. He has visited with heads of all three networks, as well as several major cable outlets. Mechem isn't daunted by the traditionally low ratings L.P.G.A. events have received, arguing that nearly all golf telecasts receive low rating points, but are generally watched by audiences with "high" demographics.
"There's a growing realization that television ratings are compressing into a sort of band where the difference between the high guy and the low guy is a hell of a lot tighter than it used to be," said Mechem. "If you can get a strong sponsor, television will listen."
Although Chirkanian agrees Mechem's background will give him some leverage with the networks, he believes that the only place women's golf can significantly expand their presence on television will be on cable. Of the 12 L.P.G.A. events being televised this year, six will be carried on cable.
"I don't see any of the major networks having anymore room for women's events," said Chirkanian, adding that CBS, which is not contracted to do a women's event, is scheduled to air 74 individual golf telecasts this year. "I think eventually that Charlie will have to find himself a cable network that considers the L.P.G.A. its primary agenda."
Mechem, knowing the pitfalls, is cautious about being perceived as a surefire pipeline to television.
"Even if we don't get more television," he said, "we can improve other things, like the quality of our tournaments and the amount of money we play for. There are a lot of other things I'd like to be measured by down the road."
Mechem believes he can market the L.P.G.A. simply as the best women golfers in the world. He seems less inclined than his predecessors to emphasize sex appeal, and more inclined to be open about things like how far the women actually hit the ball. Most L.P.G.A. players drive the ball an average of about 215 yards, but the association has never released driving distance statistics.
In fact, Mechem has a lot to sell in terms of top competition, with Beth Daniel, Betsy King and Patty Sheehan at their peaks, and Amy Alcott and Pat Bradley closing in on the L.P.G.A. Hall of Fame.
The possibilities have reenergized Mechem at a time when he was considering a placid semi-retirment rather than high profile job. He describes himself as both excited and impatient, a mood that is verified by the yellow legal pad he carries that now contains more than 70 ideas and future projects he would like to implement.
"I don't want to say that the job that has been done for the last number of years hasn't been a good one," said the always diplomatic Mechem. "But what I will say is that the L.P.G.A. has a vast, unrealized potential."

HEADLINE: Tough Times Pinch Welfare Programs

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
ACROSS Connecticut, municipal officials are finding that welfare budgets, prepared before the economy took a serious downturn last spring, are woefully inadequate.
Roberto Garcia, director of the welfare department in Bridgeport, said he believes his $15.4 million budget will fall about $1 million short by June 30, the end of the fiscal year. 
 "When we were preparing our budget last year, we had hoped the caseload would level off at less than 2,400," Mr. Garcia said. But the city had 3,110 people on welfare by the end of December, and he estimated that the number topped 3,300 by the end of January.
At a recent meeting of 36 municipal social-service directors, Donald T. Muirhead of Windham asked how many had already requested supplemental appropriations to cover welfare costs. Representatives of 11 towns said they had, and another 23 said they expected to need additional funds in the current fiscal year. Only two of the welfare officers said they could probably make it through the year without additional money.
The higher welfare costs are a barometer of recent layoffs and job losses in the state's economy, state and city officials say. The higher costs, they say, are adding to the fiscal problems already facing some localities and the state governmnent, which pays most of the welfare costs of the cities and towns.
Even relatively affluent suburbs are being hit by the rise in welfare cases. Sheila T. Knox, director of social services in Newtown, said that January's average caseload was 30 to 35, compared to 11 or 12 a year earlier and 5 in 1989.
Ms. Knox's general-assistance budget was more than doubled for the current fiscal year, to $55,000 from $24,000, she said, but the money was still depleted by December, halfway through the year. Her budget request for the 1992 fiscal year, which begins on July 1, will be more than $100,000, she said.
 
First-Time Applicants
 "We're seeing people who have never had to apply for any type of assistance before in their lives," Ms. Knox said. "We used to see only people who couldn't work for medical reasons. But more and more, it's people who just can't find a job."
Greenwich has had problems with its welfare budget this year, said Carol A. Femia, commissioner of social services. "We started to see it beginning last January, just a trickle," she said. "Then it really started getting heavy in March.
"It wasn't that the number of new cases was up that much. It was that people were staying on much, much longer."
Ms. Femia said that for the fiscal year that ended on June 30, 1989, her department handled 233 cases, costing $224,647. For the fiscal year that ended last June, the number of cases was up 5 percent, to 245, and the cost was up 37 percent, to $306,928, she said.
This year, she said, the town actually trimmed its welfare budget because of concerns about higher taxes, reducing it to $304,588 from $313,500. "We had always been running a surplus," Ms. Femia said. "But it now looks like we'll need at least another $150,000 to get through this year. And for next year, we're asking for $600,000."
Because the state reimburses towns for 90 percent of direct welfare costs, the impact on towns is softened. But the towns' 10 percent share is rising sharply, and the administrative cost, which is not reimbursed, is up also, because more cases must be handled.
And all the towns are worried about a recommendation now under consideration in Hartford that reimbursement be lowered to 50 percent in an attempt to control the state budget. "The cities in no way could absorb that kind of a budget shift," Mr. Muirhead said.
William Rufleth, director of general assistance for the state Department of Income Maintenance, said for the quarter that ended on Sept. 30, the most recent statistics available, welfare costs were up 34 percent over a year earlier. This year, the state budgeted $83 million for welfare, but the actual cost will probably be closer to $100 million, Mr. Rufleth said.
 
Exhausting Unemployment Benefits
 Unemployment has increased, and more people are exhausting their 26 weeks of unemployment compensation benefits before they find work, said C. Richard Ficks, a spokesman for the state Department of Labor. Some 66,0000 people a week were receiving unemployment compensation at the end of December, he said, up 32 percent from 50,000 a year earlier.
"Between 800 and 1,000 people a week have been exhausting their benefits," Mr. Ficks said.
Unemployment compensation pays a maximum of $270 a week plus $10 for each dependent, up to $50, Mr. Ficks said. Welfare payments depend on the region, with a family of four getting $792 a month in western Connecticut, $683 a month in the state's east.
In most cases, the shortfalls are much more severe in small towns, local officials said. While some towns are facing an increase in welfare costs of 100 percent or more, most city welfare budgets are expected to be short by 25 percent or less.
"In the large towns, poverty is really a constant," said Mr. Muirhead of Windham. "We have bad in good times, so we're less impacted in the bad times."
Stonington saw a tripling of its welfare budget when its caseload went from three to nine, whereas a six-person increase in Windham would barely have been noticed, Mr. Muirhead said.
 
Consequences of Cutbacks
 Because many towns are seeking ways to trim municipal budgets, Mr. Rufleth said, "the social-service directors are faced with the prospect of laying off staff at the same time they've got more people coming through the door."
Bridgeport has learned the consequences of administrative cutbacks. Because it was short of staff, the city's welfare department was taking up to 18 working days to process new applications. Connecticut Legal Services filed suit, and a Superior Court judge threatened to jail Mr. Garcia unless he got that delay down to four working days before Feb. 11. Late in January, he managed to meet the judge's requirement, and his experience is likely to make other towns wary of cutting too deeply.
Deborah A. MacKenzie, director of welfare in Danbury, said that as of Dec. 31, halfway through the fiscal year, her budget was 63 percent depleted and going quickly. She said the first clients through the door early last year were typically restaurant workers, custodians, retail clerks, and laborers, who are the first to be let go in a downturn.
"We have painters and carpenters on general assistance now, who are subject to seasonal employment anyway," she said. "But in 1989, the season ended a lot quicker" than in previous years, "and in 1990, it never really picked up."
Ms. MacKenzie predicted that the problem will get far worse. People who are on welfare do not make enough money to afford most apartments in Danbury, she said, which rent for an average of $700 to $800 a month.
"People who are evicted become homeless," Ms. MacKenzie said. "And then there is no easy way for them to regroup, and they stay on welfare a lot longer."
 
Lives Fall Apart
 Ms. Knox of Newtown said she is seeing related problems as well. Two years ago, the town might see one application every few months from a person who wanted in-patient substance-abuse treatment. By last year, that had risen to two a month, and in January there were eight.
"We've seen people who had a job and house and other things, and they've seen one thing go after another, and they turn to substance abuse," Ms. Knox said. "The economy is bad, and they can't find work, and people are enormously stressed out."
She said more people are also relying for longer periods on private sources of help, like food pantries and the Salvation Army. "Those are supposed to be for families in crisis," Ms. Knox said. "But the crises are lasting a lot longer."
Mr. Garcia said the number of welfare cases has been rising steadily since January 1989, without any of the mid-year softening that had occurred in the past. He and others said they hope to see the cases fall off this spring.
"The end of March is our best indicator," Mr. Garcia said. "If things don't bottom out in March, we're going to be a lot more worried about this trend."

HEADLINE: Few Bidders Are Expected In Bank Sale

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE

 BODY:
Like skeptics coming to kick the tires at a used-car lot, bankers have been flying to Boston to examine the books at the failed Bank of New England. Within three months, the bank is scheduled to be sold by the Federal Government, most likely to another bank. But those close to the process say it will not be an easy sell.
So far, the Bank of America, the nation's third-largest bank, and the Banc One Corporation of Columbus, Ohio, the 27th largest, have sent examiners. The investment group Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company is also said to be interested, but will not comment. And while talk is circulating of interest among regional and foreign banks, no other bidders have emerged. 
 In fact, only a handful of bidders, if that many, is expected. New York City banks, which have long hungered to enter New England, lack the capital to take over an institution as large and troubled as the Bank of New England, which has more than $3.3 billion in troubled loans. It is expected the buyer will need to provide some $800 million in fresh capital to meet Federal guidelines to establish a financial cushion for future losses.
 
Other Logical Buyers
 New England banks are not considered strong enough to make a bid, and other logical buyers, like the NCNB Corporation in Charlotte, N.C., which has bought failed banks and savings and loans in Texas, have said they are not interested.
"There's not a lot of buyers out there," said David Cates, an analyst with Ferguson & Company, a Washington consulting group. "There are not that many healthy banks, and everyone believes we are headed into a difficult period."
For its part, the Government, which is obligated to protect the bank's $15 billion in deposits, wants to shift this responsibility to someone else at the least cost possible and with the minimum strain to the banking system. The longer the process takes, the greater the likelihood that the value of the bank will deteriorate as customers flee, and the higher the ultimate cost to the Government.
The Government estimates that the Bank of New England will cost at least $2.3 billion to rescue, the largest bailout yet. And analysts say the tab could run higher if the New England economy continues to sour and further reduces the value of the bank's real estate loans.
Rather than face the costly prospect of liquidating a bank and simply compensating depositors, the Government generally tries to arrange the sale of a failed bank's deposits and loan portfolio to a healthy bank, which then puts up its own capital to support expanded operations. The difference between the deposit obligation taken on by the new bank and the value of the loan portfolio of the failed bank is what the Government must pay the buyer -- and that is where all the negotiating takes place.
That is also where the trouble can begin. Last week, for example, a Congressional report criticized the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation for its handling of the sale of the two biggest banks to collapse before the Bank of New England. The report claimed that in arranging the sale of two Texas banks -- the First Republic Bank to NCNB and MCorp to Banc One -- the Government offered "overly generous" subsidies while retaining most of the risk and costs.
"From the Government's side, you have to make the deal attractive enough to find a bidder," said Charles Peabody, a banking analyst with Kidder, Peabody & Company, "but not so attractive that you end up in the political hot seat with Congress."
 
Casting Off Bad Loans
 But potential buyers simply will not touch a deal like the Bank of New England without some Government protections -- usually an agreement allowing the buyer to cast off bad loans back to the Government long after the bank is sold.
"Whoever gets Bank of New England will not be able to gamble on its problem loans," said Bert Ely, a consultant in Alexandria, Va. "They want very little, if any, risk, and that's the key."
Potential bidders have only to look to Texas to see that deals with the Government are not necessarily without risk. The former chairman of the First Chicago Corporation, A. Robert Abboud, led a rescue in 1988 of the First City Bancorp in Texas, and that venture has turned into a money-loser.
Apparently, Mr. Abboud's group miscalculated the amount of Federal assistance needed to reverse that bank's fortunes. After raising some $500 million in private capital, the bank reported a 1990 loss of $158.3 million and is struggling with a portfolio of bad loans. Similarly, the Hallwood Group, an investment group, put up $50 million to buy BancTexas, only to see that institution fail and fall back into Government hands.
 
A Regional Opportunity
 Still, potential bidders for the Bank of New England seem drawn to the opportunity to become a force in the region in a single transaction. But any buyer would be making a bet on the New England economy, which may or may not have hit bottom.
"It's not that a buyer wants the bank, it wants the territory," said Thomas A. Hanley, an analyst with Salomon Brothers Inc.
Those close to the process say the F.D.I.C. has also indicated that it is open to bids from a group of buyers who then might divide up the bank's parts -- it has subsidiaries in Connecticut, Maine and Massachusetts. Such a bid might come from Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts.
The New York firm, which has organized several huge leverage buyouts, may have gained support for a bid in last week's Congressional report. The report criticized the selection of Banc One in the MCorp sale and said Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts had been rejected more for political reasons than for the quality of its bid.
 
Change in Attitude
 The F.D.I.C. responded that Kohlberg, Kravis was rejected because it lacked bank management expertise. At the time of the MCorp sale, regulators were being criticized for making deals with financial entrepreneurs. But the Congressional report, say those close to Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts, indicates that attitudes in Washington have changed and that the firm may have a better chance now.
"I think K.K.R.'s interest is genuine, and I think there is a lot of nontraditional money looking at the banking industry," said James McDermott, president of Keefe Bruyette & Woods, a bank research firm.
Other nonbank groups have also been investing in banks: Warren E. Buffet, chairman of Berkshire Hathaway Inc., a multi-industry holding company in Omaha, recently took a big stake in Wells Fargo & Company, the large California bank. And the Tisch family, with interests ranging from broadcasting to real estate, has large holdings in the Bank of Boston and other New England banks.
Still, some question whether such nonbank entities could attain cost efficiencies that an existing bank, with its established back office, could get in the deal.

HEADLINE: Environmental Coalition Is Split

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
An unlikely coalition of state officials, industry representatives and environmentalists that had pledged to reduce the amount of solid waste going into landfills in the Northeast has become divided over rules intended to cut down the amount of packaging used in consumer products.
Eleven environmental and consumer organizations have stopped participating in the Source Reduction Council of the Coalition of Northeast Governors because of what they said was a lack of action on setting specific packaging-reduction goals. 
 Their departure raises questions about whether the venture can move beyond broad goals to make a dent in the solid waste disposal problem in the Northeast. In establishing the council in 1989, the governors of the states involved described it as "the first-ever concerted regional effort to develop a coordinated strategy to reduce waste at the source."
 
A Common Policy
 The plan in the Northeast was to develop a common policy for the region to avoid fighting the same battles repeatedly in the nine state legislatures from Maine to Pennsylvania. Because packaging represents about one-third of all municipal solid waste, it quickly became the focus of the council's efforts. Last year the council drafted model legislation that limits the amount of toxic heavy metals in packaging. The legislation has been enacted by eight states, including six in the Northeast.
But talks have bogged down on various issues, including how to define such environmental claims as "recycled" and how to impose standards for reducing the amount of packaging in products. In general, packaged-goods companies and packaging makers want loose, voluntary standards for labeling and reduction efforts, while environmental and consumer groups want specific goals and timetables.
 
Debate Over Standards
 For example, many environmentalists contend that a package should have a minimum amount of recycled material, perhaps 50 percent, before it can be labeled "recycled" or "contains recycled material." But industry spokesmen say specific minimums are unnecessary and could cause confusion if different rules are adopted in different states.
Similarly, environmentalists say labeling a package as "recyclable" is misleading unless convenient systems to recycle that package exist. But industry's response is that labels have an educational value, particularly if they include information on where recycling centers can be found.
"The Source Reduction Council has generated not one pound of solid waste savings in the Northeast in two years of operation," said Allen Hershkowitz, vice chairman of the panel and an official of the New York-based Natural Resources Defense Council. He said industry representatives appeared more interested in protecting their individual company's economic position than in reaching overall waste reduction goals.
 
'Going in Circles'
 "We were going in circles on the packaging guidelines," said Jan Beyea, a scientist at the National Audubon Society. "We were successful with the toxics bill, but since then there has been no progress."
Other environmental organizations involved include the World Wildlife Fund and the Environmental Defense Fund, along with state-level groups.
Some of those state organizations, notably the Public Interest Research Groups in many of the Northeast states, are planning a lobbying effort this spring to back legislation restricting the use of packaging.
One effort, which would have required that packages be reusable or made of recycled or recyclable materials, was defeated in Oregon last year. "There will be legislation on the Oregon model and debate in the legislatures this year," said Susan Birmingham of the United States Public Interest Research Group, an umbrella group for the state organizations.
In a letter to the governors late last year, the environmentalists on the Source Reduction Council charged that their influence had been reduced by changes in the group's operating procedures. "We simply cannot participate in a forum that can use the good name of our influential organizations to further a policy with which not one of us agrees," they said.
 
Reports Are Blocked
 To encourage consensus, the council originally agreed that at least one vote from each of the sectors, designated as state, industry and nonprofit, would be needed to approve any action. But when the environmentalists blocked the issuing of several reports, state officials changed the rules so that only a simple majority of votes was needed.
"Over time it became difficult to get at least one vote from each sector," said Anne Stubbs, the executive director of the governors' coalition. "So last fall the state members decided that information we had developed should be forwarded to the states with majority and minority views. The nonprofits had a problem with that."
Ms. Stubbs said the council was continuing its work without the environmentalists, but some industry representatives questioned the value of the effort without their presence. "We are not going to renew our membership next year," said Chaz Miller of the Glass Packaging Council, which represents manufacturers of glass bottles and jars. "I do not see the benefit without the environmentalists being there."
Nevertheless, several industry executives appeared eager to include the implicit approval of the environmentalists on a 50-page set of voluntary guidelines for reducing packaging that the governors' coalition is preparing. "The preferred packaging guidelines manual reflects the comments we received from them," said Frank Consoli, a packaging manager at the Scott Paper Company and a member of the Source Reduction Council.
 
'We Have Not Signed Off'
 But Mr. Hershkowitz said any reports issued by the Source Reduction Council would not carry the endorsement of its environmental groups. "We may have worked on some things in the drafting stages, but we have not signed off on anything," he said.
Ms. Stubbs said a final decision had not been made on defining and releasing the packaging guidelines. She indicated that the governors' group would seek a reconciliation with the environmentalists first.
But Mr. Beyea of the Audubon Society said: "We will not participate unless there is movement in our direction. If the governors are not interested in coming up with goals for packaging, then it is a waste of time."

HEADLINE: Developers Shrug Off Rate Cut

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
The latest steps to reduce interest rates -- the Federal Reserve's half-point cut in the discount rate on Friday and a similar cut in the prime rate used by banks -- are no more likely to provide relief to developers and investors in the beleaguered commercial real estate market than other interest rate cuts in the last six months, developers and financiers say.
These people say the risks of investing in the overbuilt real estate market still overshadow the lower rates. After the Fed cut the discount rate, the rate it charges on loans to commercial banks, most banks cut the prime lending rate to 9 percent from 9.5 percent. 
 But despite the lower rates, investors still perceive real estate as a risky investment for all but the best quality projects, said Henry Elghanyan, chairman of the Rockrose Development Corporation, a New York real estate company.
 
'The Bankers Are Scared'
 "With regulators looking over everyone's shoulder, the bankers are scared, and any project that is marginal is having a difficult time being financed, despite lower rates," he said.
Andrew J. Singer, president of Ackman Brothers & Singer, a mortgage brokerage firm for commercial real estate projects, said, "Lower rates might help some borrowers hang on a little longer" but have done little to increase the availability of money needed to finance sales or refinancings of existing buildings.
Not all sectors of the economy are so unexcited about the lower interest rates. Businesses with bank loans tied to the prime rate or other short-term interest rates, including some companies carrying heavy debts as a result of leveraged buyouts in the late 1980's, will quickly benefit from lower interest payments. Consumers with credit card debts or home-equity loans pegged to the prime lending rate are also benefiting.
 
Looking for Even Lower Rates
 Analysts noted that interest rates were still not as low as they were in the last half of 1986 and early 1987, when the prime rate fell to 7.5 percent and the yield on Treasury bonds fell below 7.5 percent.
"If and when rates come down another percentage point or two from today's levels, then you could see some positive effects," Mr. Singer said.
Because of the increased risk of default by borrowers, he said, lenders are now asking interest rates on 3- to 10-year commercial mortgages that are 1 3/4 to 2 percentage points higher than Treasury securities of comparable maturity. That is at least a quarter-point more than the gap between mortgage rates and Treasury securities in 1988 and 1989.
"The higher spread has more than offset any decline in interest rates on Treasury notes," Mr. Singer said.
Mr. Elghanyan said part of the problem for the real estate market is that rates of return demanded by real estate investors "are not tied so much to interest rates as they are to the more subjective judgment calls of value."
 
'An Absolute Standstill'
 Even in the residential mortgage market, where consumers are normally responsive to lower interest rates, the immediate reaction was muted.
"If we did not have lower interest rates, we would probably be at an absolute standstill," said Angelo R. Mozilo, president of the Countrywide Funding Corporation, a Pasadena, Calif., company that specializes in home mortgages. "As it is, lower rates have counterbalanced consumers' worries about the economy, unemployment and the melancholy induced by the war in the Persian Gulf."
Mr. Mozilo said Countrywide, the largest independent originator of home mortgages in the country, was handling about 220 applications a day, down from 280 before the military buildup in the gulf in August and 300 a day in the first half of 1990. He noted that activity had declined even though mortgage rates were lower than last year.
As of Friday, when yields on 30-year Treasury bonds fell to 8.08 percent, the lowest level in a year, 30-year mortgages were being offered for about 9.5 percent for loans with a Government guaranttee and 9.75 percent for those without Government backing. In the past, mortgage rates below 10 percent have often been the catalyst for a noticeable increase in consumer demand.
 
Reduced Income Estimates
 Charles A. Shorter, senior vice president at the Real Estate Research Corporation, a Chicago company that specializes in real estate appraisals and advisory work across the country, said owners and potential buyers of a wide variety of commercial projects were reducing their estimates of the income those buildings would produce.
Because of the widespread vacancies and the incentives offered new tenants, some large tenants who signed leases a few years ago when rents were high "are now demanding and obtaining rent reductions," Mr. Shorter said. A decline in rents from a commercial building is a powerful depressant on the building's price.
Mr. Shorter said the benefits of lower interest rates were also obscured by investors' perception that the risk had increased and by lenders' demands that investors commit more of their own money as equity.
Peter Manning, chief financial officer at the Bank of Boston, said some accounting changes under consideration by regulators "might be more effective than lower interest rates in inducing new lending." He said the normal benefits to borrowers of lower interest rates were being held back by bankers' concerns about harsh accounting treatment for loans that they expect to be repaid in full eventually, but that are now seen as risky because of the slump in real estate prices.
 
'Temporarily Impaired'
 Mr. Manning and other bankers have urged Federal regulators to change some rules to reduce the amount of reserves a bank needs to set aside as a buffer against possible losses from loans that are found to be "temporarily impaired."
Robert L. Clarke, the Comptroller of the Currency and one of the top banking regulators, said Thursday that his office was considering guidelines that would encourage bankers to make more use of the temporarily impaired designation. These guidelines would include information about how bankers could prove that a particular loan would eventually be repaid in full, despite the current slump in real estate prices and rents.
Mr. Manning said regulators might reduce the amount of reserves banks would have to set aside for possible losses in the case of new loans made to borrowers who have difficulty paying the original interest rate but can make some payments. He said regulators could recognize that partial interest payments might still equal the bank's cost of money, even if they are far short of the original terms of the loan.

HEADLINE: Scandal Yields Windfall for an Impoverished City

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EAST ST. LOUIS, Ill., Feb. 3

 BODY:
Frustrated by the roller coaster of high hopes and dashed dreams that this nearly bankrupt city has been riding for years, a Federal district judge has found a way to turn a financial scandal into a windfall for its residents.
The judge, William D. Stiehl, on Thursday sentenced the Wall Street investment firm of Matthews & Wright Inc. to pay $7 million as community service in exchange for a guilty plea to one count of conspiracy and fraud for its role in a $223 million municipal bond issue for a river port that was never built. 
 United States Attorney Frederick Hess, whose office prosecuted the case, said it was the first time a corporation has been sentenced to perform community service through payment.
Judge Stiehl also established the East St. Louis Community Fund to oversee the spending of the money for the benefit of East St. Louis. The court order calls for the money to go for projects that include education, health care and housing.
 
First $1 Million Surrendered
 A representative of Matthews & Wright gave the court a check for $1 million. The firm must outline to the judge within 30 days a plan for an annuity that would provide $1 million a year through 1997. It was also fined $1 million.
Arthur Abba Goldberg, the former executive vice president for Matthews & Wright who arranged the bond transaction, was sentenced to 18 months in prison. He had pleaded guilty to one count of conspiracy and fraud.
David Aufhauser, a Washington lawyer representing Matthews & Wright, said the sentence offered his client solace and even a little pride at being able to do something constructive with the $7 million.
Judge Stiehl formed his plan for overseeing the fund after weeks of research and consultation with not-for-profit foundation professionals. Bruce Reppert, the assistant United States attorney who negotiated the plea agreement, volunteered to serve as counsel to the fund without charge.
 
Six-Member Board for Fund
 Judge Stiehl appointed a six-member bipartisan, biracial board for the fund. The $1 million was deposited in the Union Bank of Illinois here, which will act as the fund's trustee. Any project costing more than $50,000 must be approved by the court.
After the judge consulted the Ford Foundation, that organization and the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation offered to provide a $40,000 grant to the National Economic Development and Law Center in Berkeley, Calif. The center will use the money to train the fund's board and help it plan.
"East St. Louis has really become known around the country as a symbol of hopelessness and despair and absence of leadership," said Robert Curvin, director of the Urban Poverty Program for the Ford Foundation.
 
'No Politics or Politicians'
 Judge Stiehl bypassed the troubled municipal government in setting up the fund. "There will be no politics or politicians involved with this fund," Judge Stiehl said.
Mayor Carl E. Officer had argued in a Jan. 17 letter to Judge Stiehl that the money should be paid directly to the city. He said that the city was the victim of the fraud and that "the city, not a trust fund, is the entity responsible and accountable for providing services to citizens."
Eric Vickers, a St. Louis lawyer who acts as corporate counsel for East St. Louis, said racism was behind the decision to create the fund. Mr. Vickers and Mr. Officer are black, as are most of the residents of East St. Louis. The judge and the United States Attorneys involved with the case are white.
But Johnny Scott, president of the East St. Louis chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, disagreed with Mr. Vickers. "I see nothing wrong with the concept," he said after the sentencing. "In fact, I applaud it."
Mr. Vickers also said Mayor Officer is under investigation in the bond fraud. Mr. Reppert confirmed that the investigation was continuing, but he declined to confirm or deny that the Mayor was a target.
Judge Stiehl told a packed courtroom on Thursday: "It is important that this fund not be another pie-in-the-sky scheme. It is imperative that their hopes and dreams not be raised, only to be dashed to the ground again, as they were in this case."
 
Scheme Involving the Bond
 The scheme to which Judge Stiehl referred was a $223 million bond issue underwritten by Matthews & Wright in 1985 to finance a huge river port that prosecutors said the conspirators in the fraud had no intention of building. The project was billed by city officials as one that would attract industry.
East St. Louis, where 43 percent of the population lives below the national poverty level of about $12,675 a year for a family of four, has been running at a deficit. The city is now about $50 million in debt, and the Chamber of Commerce says that nearly half of its 40,000 residents are unemployed.
What happened in the bond deal, the prosecutors contended, was that Mr. Goldberg used a bogus check drawn on a credit union to guarantee the closing of the bond issue in 1985 before an anticipated unfavorable change in the tax law. At the same time, Matthews & Wright arranged a sham sale of the bonds to a bank on the Pacific island of Saipan, the prosecutors said. The bonds were in fact sold in 1986, the prosecutors said.
Neither the bondholders nor East St. Louis lost money. The Government said Matthews & Wright made money in fees from sale of the bonds and on returns from investment of the money.

HEADLINE: SOVIET VENTURES ARE LOSING APPEAL FOR U.S. BUSINESS

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

 BODY:
One casualty of the political and economic chaos in the Soviet Union has been American enthusiasm for investment there.
The explosive tensions between Moscow and the Baltic republics, as well as the bureaurats' dogged hold on power, make the Soviet Union a far less welcome place for investors than Eastern Europe. Most former Soviet satellites have eased visa restrictions, are closer to the Western European market and, unlike Moscow, usually do whatever it takes to attract Western ventures. 
 As a result, the small but steady flow of American investment into the Soviet Union, which began in 1987, has greatly slowed down. Many companies that were leaning toward investing here are thinking again. The dollar amount lost might be relatively small, but the Soviet Government remains hungry for Western technology and management expertise as well as money.
 
Three Forms of Caution
 "The Western financial and investment community is more cautious now," James H. Giffen, president of the American Trade Consortium, a group of major American companies that is negotiating to invest in the Soviet Union, said in an interview at his Moscow office. "This caution is taking the form of either withholding investment entirely, slowing investment or downsizing investment."
The experience of Dresser Industries, a Dallas-based producer of oil-drilling equipment, reflects the difficulties facing Western investors. When President Mikhail S. Gorbachev began courting Western investors four years ago, Dresser jumped at the chance and set out to build two factories in the world's largest oil-producing nation.
Today, despite climbing hurdle after hurdle, Dresser's plans, remain just that -- plans. The ministry Dresser was working with was almost abolished. It found it had to negotiate with both Moscow and the republics, which are locked in a tense tug-of-war. And Dresser's state-owned joint-venture partner said it did not have the money to help build the factories.
 
'Situation Getting Prohibitive'
 "Things have changed," said Raymond Cossette, coordinator of Soviet activities for Dresser, which says it has not given up. "The situation in this country looks as if it's getting prohibitive."
Other American companies have similar woes, and many corporate executives are considerably less enthusiastic than they were when plans for Soviet investment were formulated. After two years of negotiations, RJR Nabisco Inc. is still waiting to sign papers to produce cigarettes in Leningrad and crackers outside Moscow. The Colgate-Palmolive Company is mired in negotiations with the Ministry of Health to open a toothpaste plant this year in Kiev.
"The Soviet Union is a large market with a massive population of 280 million people, and obviously that represents a lot of teeth for us," said Edgar J. Field, group vice president for international business development at Colgate-Palmolive.
 
Still Seeing Opportunities
 Many American companies are loath to drop their plans. They still see colossal opportunities, and America's corporate giants want to make sure they are not the last to arrive as one of the world's largest countries and consumer markets opens its economy to the outside world.
Among the other American companies that continue to negotiate in the Soviet Union are Texaco, Chevron and Eastman Kodak. They hope to join companies that have already invested here, Pepsico, McDonald's, Johnson Wax and Combustion Engineering among them.
Some American executives even privately support a drift to dictatorship, saying someone needs to take firm control of the chaotic situation. Still, they worry that the increasing power of old-guard Communists will slow, and perhaps threaten, the transition to a market economy.
"The fact that there may be some reactionary influences at work I don't think scares investors all that much," said Karl von der Heyden, chief financial officer for RJR Nabisco. "The basic thrust is toward a more open society."
 
Abundance of Horror Stories
 Every American in Moscow has a horror story or two about the difficulty and unpleasantness of living and working in the Soviet Union. Even though the McDonald's restaurant in Moscow had a contract to buy chopped meat for one ruble a pound, it is being forced to pay seven times that. Some American executives who come to explore prospects go away complaining about unappetizing meals that cost $75 and shabby $200-a-night rooms in hotels where 25-watt bulbs and prostitutes are part of the decor.
Making investment less inviting are the K.G.B. officials who rail against Western executives for gathering what the K.G.B. contends is sensitive information about the Soviet Union. American companies are also often unsure whether they should negotiate with the national Government or individual republics.
"There's a lot of uncertainty about what can and cannot be done," Michael Adams, chief executive of the Young & Rubicam advertising agency office, said in an interview in his Moscow office. "You have the Russian Federation saying, 'Come on down; let's make a deal,' and then you have the all-union government making fundamentally different policy. You don't know whether to scratch or wind your watch."
 
$12,500-a-Month Rental Unit
 For months, Mr. Adams has been searching for a respectable house or apartment. A Communist Party official who got wind of his quest invited him to look at a modest house at a riverside retreat for party functionaries. Mr. Adams inquired about the rent and was stunned: $12,500 a month.
American investment in the Soviet Union is as varied as American industry. Chevron plans to drill for oil; McDonald's has opened the world's busiest restaurant, on Gorky Square; Price Waterhouse has a small accounting office; Tambrands makes sanitary napkins in the Ukraine; Combustion Engineering's joint venture makes process controls for oil refineries.
Mark S. Vecchio, a Moscow-based lawyer with the firm of Coudert Brothers, said many American companies were attracted by the nation's immense natural resources and large proportion of highly skilled low-wage workers. But some companies invest without doing their homework, he said.
 
'Lots of Wishful Thinking'
 "There is lots of wishful thinking about what is possible," he said. "Some companies think, 'If there is such an immense consumer market, then all I have to do is come in and the Soviets will buy my product.' But they forget that the Soviet ruble is not convertible, which makes it hard for them to take out their profits."
More than 2,000 joint ventures have been registered so far in the Soviet Union, but because of the bureaucratic thicket they must hack through, only about 500 are up and running. Of these, about 100 are losing money.
Several of America's best-known companies have set up the American Trade Consortium, in which one member, Chevron, will in theory provide the hard currency for the others through its revenues from exploring and developing Soviet oilfields. All told, consortium members hope to invest more than $10 billion over the next dozen years.
"We wouldn't be here if we didn't think we could make a profit," said Mr. Giffen, president of the consortium and chairman of the Mercator Corporation, which is serving as its merchant bank. "The trick is to have a profit level commensurate with the downside risk."
 
Soviet Entrepreneur's View
 Andrei Stroyev, widely considered the Soviet Union's foremost entrepreneur, criticizes Americans for being far more hesitant than Europeans to invest here.
"American business thinks that the best solution is just to be careful and that waiting is better," Mr. Stroyev, a real estate developer, said. "But I can't close my door because there are so many Germans, Swiss, Swedes, Austrians, Italians knocking."
He is co-chairman of one of the few successful Soviet-American joint ventures. It is named Perestroika, and it specializes in real estate development. Its American partner is the Worsham Group, an Atlanta-based developer.
The two-year-old venture renovates buildings and then rents offices to blue-chip companies, including Hoechst, Mitsubishi and Fiat. They pay their rents in hard currency, making the Worsham Group one of the few companies that can easily repatriate its profits.
 
Service-Oriented Concerns Gain
 Many service-oriented companies have also been successful. Ernst & Young, Price Waterhouse and other large accounting firms rushed to open offices here, which help Western companies prospect for partners and analyze Soviet businesses and balance sheets.
Advertising agencies do market research and public relations for Western companies. The law firms here, including Coudert Brothers and Baker & McKenzie, help draw up contracts and negotiate with Kafkaesque ministries. Manufacturers have a far tougher time.
An aluminum company wanted to start a joint venture in Armenia, for example, but backed off when it learned that neighboring Azerbaijan had cut the rail lines.
 
McDonald's Talks Took 14 Years
 McDonald's had to weather 14 years of negotiations before opening one restaurant in Moscow.
Although the rubles-only restaurant has generated little hard currency earnings, George Cohon, chairman of McDonald's Canada and vice chairman of McDonald's in Moscow, said the outlet was a huge success, with 50,000 customers a day and 1,200 workers. The company plans to open several more restaurants soon, including one that would sell hamburgers for hard currency.
Looking out at the 90-minute-long line of shivering people, he said: "Sure, it's a risk to be here now. But it might be a bigger risk to wait. I don't care what system there is in this country: people are going to continue flooding into this place."

HEADLINE: Oakland Journal;
Schools Resist Call of the Military

BYLINE: By KATHERINE BISHOP, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: OAKLAND, Calif., Jan 31

 BODY:
Oakland Technical High School is a campus of nearly 1,600 students, 93 percent of them black, Hispanic or Asian. Unlike some other inner-city high schools, it appears to be winning the war against drugs and gangs and is keeping its old buildings well-maintained and nearly graffiti-free.
But in this school, students and parents complain of another source of concern: the tactics of military recruiters. 
 Like thousands of schools around the country, Oakland Technical has been making its senior class list available to military recruiters. The lists have names, home addresses and telephone numbers, and people here say the recruiters have made liberal use of them.
"Some kids have been called 10 times by the same branch of the service," said Dr. Gerald Kramer, the school's principal. "They say they are not interested and they still get called again and again."
In January, a week before fighting broke out in the Persian Gulf, the Oakland Board of Education voted unanimously to stop giving recruiters the lists from its six high schools. A week after the war began, the Los Angeles School Board followed Oakland's lead, ending a 20-year practice.
The resolutions do not affect the ability of the military to come to campus and contact interested students, like any other potential employer.
Sheila Jordan, the Oakland School Board member who sponsored the resolution and whose son attends Oakland Tech, said the vote came after a public meeting in which there was "an incredible outpouring from both parents and students."
Ms. Jordan, who was active in the peace movement during the Vietnam War, said that for her generation the times have "such a ring of familiarity with demonstrations, war, being upset with the government." But to these teen-agers, the experience is a new one.
"A lot of the students are very confused," she said. "They don't want to be unpatriotic, but they feel specially targeted. There is a high level of political consciousness around race and oppression here."
Barbara Sorensen, a spokeswoman for the Army Recruiting Command, denied that minority and poor students were being singled out for recruitment. Rather, she said, many young people whose horizons seem limited view the military as providing them with training and college money.
State education law allows schools to give students' names to the military, and many districts continue to do so.
Rick Jahnkow, program coordinator for the Project on Youth and Non-Military Opportunities, a group based in San Diego County that informs high school students about career and college alternatives to the military, said many schools went well beyond giving the names of students. Thousands of schools give the military's vocational aptitude test or allow recruiters to administer it and use the results for recruiting. "These recruiters are the best-trained salespeople in the world," Mr. Jahnkow said.
Some students say that while they dream of a college education the military seems to be the only way it is economically possible. Mr. Jahnkow says that even in California, with its enormous system of tuition-free community colleges and state universities, many students whose parents did not attend college mistakenly think there is no other way for them to go either.
Like many other critics, Mr. Jahnkow said recruiters deliberately focused on inner-city schools in areas with large black and Hispanic populations and high unemployment rates. "They try to do more outreach to schools where kids are more vulnerable," he said. "Recruiters don't put effort into schools where they know the kids have options."
Along corridors filled with boisterous teen-agers on their lunch break, Breeze C. Murphy, a senior at Oakland Tech, said he had been called by every branch of the service. "They talk like they're selling a used car," he said. "They said I didn't even have to agree with the United States foreign policy, that I should just do it for the money and the benefits. Service for the good of the country is one thing. But they're inducing selfishness."
Ms. Sorensen of the Army Recruiting Command said: "We're not going to apologize for the opportunities the Army offers. Money for college is part of the reward for service."

HEADLINE: As Realty Taxes Go Up, Up, Dreams Die in New Jersey

BYLINE: By PETER KERR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EDISON TOWNSHIP, N.J., Jan. 31

 BODY:
Much of the often angry politics in Trenton these days boils down to the kind of numbers that torment Angelo Verduci, a 74-year-old retiree in this fast-growing suburb.
His income: $13,000 a year.
His property taxes: $2,654 and rising.
Mr. Verduci fears that taxes will some day force him to leave the small cement house that he built himself 30 years ago, when much of Middlesex County was still rural. In the meantime each increase in property taxes cuts into his budget for food, clothing and medical care.
 
No Thought of Moving
 "This is a place I built to live and die in," said Mr. Verduci, whose property taxes rose 20 percent, more than $400, last year.
In this state of bedroom communities, where Democrats depend on the votes of modest homeowners, rising property taxes have seared the electorate and deeply divided the party.
Property taxes are a growing frustration across the state, in wealthy communities as well as middle-class ones, as soaring garbage-disposal bills, expensive labor contracts, a decline in Federal aid and other factors drive up the cost of local government and schools.
For the less affluent, and particularly people on fixed incomes, the rising taxes on their homes can rouse the kind of anger more often associated with issues like race and crime.
 
Cutting to the Bone

"It's gotten to the point where we've cut everything to the bone," said Mr. Verduci's son Bradley, a 44-year-old mechanic who lives next door with his wife and two children. Taxes, he says, have forced him to think of leaving the neighborhood.
"One more rise in taxes, and it will be very hard to make it, to pay our bills."
People like the Verducis, lifelong Democrats with conservative social leanings, were the type of New Jersey voters who often decided elections in the last decade, giving victories to Presidents Ronald Reagan and Bush and to Govs. Thomas H. Kean and Jim Florio.
Realizing the importance of property taxes to people of modest means, Governor Florio promised them property-tax relief last year as he pushed through the Legislature $2.8 billion in sales, income and other tax increases.
Part of $1.3 billion in higher income taxes imposed on the state's top 17 percent of wage earners was aimed at reducing property taxes, with the rest marked for more aid to the state's poorer school districts.
 
Little Help Envisioned
 Now some Democrats, including the President of the State Senate, John Lynch, say Mr. Florio's plan will do too little to help people like the Verducis. By miscalculation or plan, they say, the Florio tax package will pour hundreds of millions of dollars into poorer schools but permit, or even require, property taxes to rise for most people.
Mr. Lynch has proposed stripping $395 million from the Florio school plan and directing it to municipalities to help keep property taxes down.
In 1988, New Jersey had the third highest per-capita property taxes in the United States, according to a preliminary study of United States Census figures gathered in the fiscal year beginning July 1987. For every resident, $933 in property taxes was collected, compared with $860 in New York and $911 in Connecticut.
Alaska had the highest property taxes, followed by New Hampshire.
 
Recession Makes a Difference
 Between 1989 and 1990, property taxes rose substantially in New Jersey, said Ernst C. Reock, director of the bureau of government research at Rutgers University. County taxes rose an average of 9.8 percent, municipal taxes 12.4 percent and school taxes 13.1 percent.
But the consternation over property taxes, particularly among middle- and lower-middle-income New Jerseyans, goes beyond those numbers, Mr. Reock said. Rising property taxes were not felt so much through the 1980's as the economy boomed, salaries rose and the value of real estate advanced steadily.
With the onset of the recession and sharp drops in property values, wage earners who believed they were increasing their wealth merely by owning a house now feel they have lost money. And people who believed they could make up for higher taxes with steadily rising salaries now face flat incomes and the fear of unemployment.
"What complicates matters is that people in the 1980's got themselves into a position where they were living at the edge of what they can afford in good times," Mr. Reoch said. "Now they have slipped below that level."
 
Acute Problem in Edison
 In Edison, a sprawling township near the convergence of the New Jersey Turnpike, Garden State Parkway, Interstate 287 and Route 1, property-tax problems are particularly acute. Through the 1980's it was one of the fastest-growing towns in the state, lifting its population by 26 percent -- to 88,680 from 70,193. And for years the government kept taxes relatively low by selling municipal lands in deals that now are being criticized by some residents as grossly mismanaged.
In 1990, residents saw their property taxes rise 19 percent -- from $1.36 for every $100 of assessed valuation to $1.63, said Paul Raffiani, Edison's Tax Assessor. In previous years taxes had risen at 7 to 8 percent a year.
To Elizabeth Conway, another Edison resident, there is little doubt that the state must turn its attention to the property-tax burdens of less affluent suburbanites. At 36, she and her husband look back on the years when they both worked, saving money so she could stay home to raise children.
Now her husband's job is threatened: he works as a heating and ventilation specialist in a largely empty office building that once housed the investment firm of Drexel Lambert, which has gone bankrupt.
Meanwhile property taxes on their three-bedroom colonial house have risen to $100 a month this year. Ms. Conway says life for her children, aged 5 and 2, will be far different than originally planned. There will be no vacations to Disneyland in the winter, no summers away from home. If things get tougher, Ms. Conway expects she will have to return to work.
 
Living Precariously
 On Ethel Road, where the two generations of Verducis live side by side, the mood is particularly dark in the home of the elder Verducis.
Both Angelo and Mary, who is 73, recall arriving in the area from other states as children, when Ethel Road was farmland where Angelo would hunt for wild asparagus and pick blueberries and huckleberries for his mother to make jelly.
Out of the Army in 1946, Mr. Verduci paid $675 for a plot of land, and together with his father-in-law, who bought the adjacent plot, the two men spent 13 years building the homes at night after Mr. Verduci finished working his shift as a technician at the Squibb Corporation. He retired in 1979.
In the last year the property taxes for the elder Mr. Verduci and his wife rose from $2,162 to $2,654. With one out of five dollars of their fixed income going to property taxes, there is not enough money for a movie or an unplanned drive. Both he and his wife live in fear of getting sick, for just about any doctors' bills are beyond their budget.
Most of all, Angelo Verduci fears that new increases in property taxes will make it impossible for them to keep their home.
 Next door Bradley Verduci said that until recently he had thought he could sell his home, which tripled in value during the 1980's to $149,000, according to the Town Assessor. But the idea of moving to North Carolina dissolved with the eroding real-estate market, which in many New Jersey suburbs has seemingly produced a "For Sale" sign on every other front lawn.
The new austerity in Bradley Verduci's home has meant, for example, that he was forced to delay for months a $300 repair of the kitchen stove. His wife suddenly found herself doing all her baking next door in her mother-in-law's kitchen.
"Even if they put a freeze on my taxes, it still would be out of proportion to what I can afford," he said.
