HEADLINE: WAR IN THE GULF: Latin America;
War's Ripples Lap at Latin America

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador

 BODY:
One recent morning, a group of young men hurled paint bombs at the United States Consulate here, protesting American participation in the Persian Gulf war.
The same day, a separate group of young men gathered at the consulate to inquire about enlisting to fight for the United States in the Persian Gulf. 
 While the first group was motivated by politics and the second by unemployment, the context was similar: as North America goes to war, South America once again watches from the sidelines.
With Brazil on the war's distant periphery, tourist officials predict a surge in reservations as Europeans and Americans change vacation plans and book flights to a destination that suddenly seems safe. The region's largest oil importer, Brazil has imposed curbs to cut gasoline consumption. Fuel pumps across Brazil are now closed on Sundays and weekday evenings.
 
Company Continues Aid
 Brazil's rocket manufacturer, Avibras, caused a furor when it disclosed that it was continuing to provide Iraq with technical aid to maintain its Brazilian-made radar and land-to-land rocket systems. A Foreign Ministry spokesman immediately vowed to take "all legal measures" to end the aid.
In Argentina, the decision by President Carlos Saul Menem to send two warships to the Persian Gulf provoked demonstrations outside of Congress and fist fights inside. Although Kuwait's government-in-exile paid Argentina $18 million in January for the aid, congressional approval was won only after a debate that split the nation and the presidential couple.
Zulema Yoma de Menem, the President's estranged wife, condemned the interference in the Middle East of "a group of powers with hellish destructive power." Mr. Menem declared to the nation, "Argentina is at war."
Most visible are the protests and bombings that have taken place across South America. Many have tapped traditional resentments against the United States.
 
Protests Outside Embassy
 "Arabs should attack interests of the U.S.A. in reprisal for its imperialist war," Ali Muhama, a Brazilian of Palestinian origin, told a demonstration on Jan. 12, four days before war broke out.
There have been protests outside the embassy and four consulates of the United States in Brazil, but none have been reported outside Iraq's embassy in Brasilia. In one evenhanded exception, Brazil's Green Party formed a human "peace chain" that linked the United States Consulate in Rio de Janeiro and the local office of Iraqi Airways, two blocks away.
So far, attacks on American installations have been minor. A small bomb broke windows at the embassy library in Quito, Ecuador, and a small rocket damaged the central air-conditioning unit of the embassy in Lima, Peru.
"We have had far more people trying to enlist than people throwing stink bombs," said a spokesman at the embassy in Lima, where a sign warns that the embassy is not accepting volunteers. "It's presumed to be a ticket to a green card," the spokesman said, referring to the United States work permit for immigrants.
 
Bomb Threats in Sao Paulo
 In Sao Paulo, Brazil, the continent's most populous city, the local bomb squad had investigated 42 bomb threats by mid-January, eight times the normal rate. In Brazil's only two bombings recorded to date, both on Jan. 20, a bomb damaged a synagogue in Porto Alegre and another damaged a Mormon church run by American missionaries in Goias.
The bomb threats have created a siege mentality among American diplomats, who have left explanations of the United States participation in the war to Cable News Network, which is extensively broadcast by local television with Portuguese or Spanish voice-overs. In contrast, Iraqi diplomats are peppering the press in Argentina, Brazil and Uruguay with interviews.
"Our missile attacks on Israel have killed 1,000 people and wounded 2,500," Munthir Mushin, Iraq's charge d'affaires in Argentina, recently asserted in an interview with a Buenos Aires newspaper.

HEADLINE: Science Would Receive One of Sharpest Rises in Spending in Bush Plan

BYLINE: By PHILIP J. HILTS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3

 BODY:
Science and technology would receive one of the highest rates of increased spending under the budget that President Bush will send to Congress on Monday, Administration officials say.
That increase, for the 1992 fiscal year, would be $8 billion, to a total of $72 billion, a 13 percent rise over the current year's level, not accounting for inflation. By comparison, the rest of the budget would rise only 2.6 percent over all. 
The Administration would give a particular boost to "big science" projects, like the superconducting supercollider, the 50-mile-long atom smasher that is to be built just south of Dallas, and the Human Genome Project, which seeks to find and map all the genes in the human body. Financing for the supercollider would increase 120 percent, to $534 million, and for the genome project 26 percent, to $169 million.
In addition, the National Science Foundation, the chief source of all civilian science grants outside medicine, would get a 16 percent increase in spending authority, to $2.1 billion, and the spending authority of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration would rise 18 percent, to $8.6 billion.
 
AIDS Spending About Steady
 Financing for AIDS research, education and treatment, totaling $2 billion, would not be significantly increased beyond inflation. It would rise $120 million over the current year's level.
As has frequently been the case with the Federal budget in recent years, the greatest amount of the increase for science and technology would be devoted to developing military hardware. Of the $8 billion increase, $5.2 billion would be spent to further develop new weapon systems, including an advanced version of the Cruise missile, a new tactical jet fighter loaded with electronics, a new attack submarine and the Stealth bomber.
This increase in spending on military technology comes as the overall military budget loses 1 percent to inflation.
The science and technology increases "are part of an ongoing campaign of the President to invest more in the future of America rather than just programs for the present," said an Administration official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. "In other words, it is the third budget in a row in which he has placed heavy emphasis on research and development."
 
Response From Scientists
 Dr. Leon Lederman, a Nobel Prize-winning physicist who is president of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, the largest general science organization in the world, said in an interview that the President's budget was a "good" one, "considering what we face and what is happening to others in the budget crisis."
But, he said, the proposal "will not solve the problems that we raised earlier."
Dr. Lederman raised those problems a month ago, when, after questioning 250 researchers at 50 universities, he reported that the responses "paint a picture of an academic research community beset by flagging morale, diminishing expectations and constricting horizons."
His report to the association said: "From one institution to the next, across demographic categories, across disciplines of research, the nation's scientists are sending a warning: Academic research in the United States is in serious trouble."
At the time, Dr. Lederman recommended doubling the Federal budget for science over the next few years, and following that with increases of 8 percent to 10 percent "continuously."
 
Increase in Costs
 Dr. Lederman said that after adjustment for inflation Federal financing of science was only slightly higher in 1990 than in 1968. In the intervening years, the number of scientists with doctorates has more than doubled, the cost of instruments and laboratory buildings has gone up several-fold and the cost of paperwork and overhead as a whole has also risen sharply, he said.
Albert H. Teich, a budget expert with Dr. Lederman's organization, said that the increases proposed by the President were a step in the right direction but that, after subtracting 5 percent for inflation and assuming that Congress would trim some of the proposals, they were modest.
Given the thaw in the cold war and pressures to increase spending on non-military science, he said, the biggest surprise is that military weaponry is once again the big winner while some other science programs suffer.
In the last seven years, Federal spending on science as a whole has been increasing somewhat, while spending on many other sectors of the budget have been held level, and Dr. Lederman said this posed "a great dilemma for us: how to complain when science is being favored."
 
New Limits Imposed
 He said of Mr. Bush's budget: "This is a good step. But it will still be an uphill fight to get the kind of exuberant leadership" by the President that science enjoyed 25 years ago.
Mr. Bush's request is the first under the new budget rules laid down last fall, in which caps were imposed on each of three broad categories: discretionary domestic spending, military spending and foreign programs spending.
"The caps were explicitly intended to force a competition among programs on their merits" within each of those categories, an Administration official said. "There is a clear message here: a chief priority is science, research and development, and an objective debate on the merits, we believe, will result in science winning."

HEADLINE: Cuts After Decade of Cuts: Governors Grim at Meeting

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3

 BODY:
People who have been attending the midwinter meetings of the nation's governors for years cannot remember a bleaker assessment of the states' financial condition than the one they heard this weekend.
The governors, who spent the last decade lamenting cutbacks in Federal aid, said they were so bereft of money when the current recession arrived that they now faced unprecedented budget deficits and threats to essential services, including health and welfare programs. At the four-day meeting of the National Governors' Association here, they are exchanging proposals to freeze benefits, reduce services, shrink programs and lay off state employees. 
 "The atmosphere is much bleaker than the meetings during the 1981-82 recession because states had not gone through a decade of spending cuts," Brad Johnson, director of New York State's office in Washington, said today. "States are already at the bone, and the recession is ravaging their budgets across the country."
A survey conducted by New York State found that 40 states predicted deficits totaling $33 billion in the next fiscal year. New York expects a $6 billion shortfall, out of a $30 billion budget, in the fiscal year beginning in April.
 Gov. Pete Wilson of California, a Republican, told his fellow governors, "We are now facing in most of the states a gap between revenue and expenditures that is unprecedented."
He predicted a $7 billion to $10 billion deficit in the next 18 months and proposed a freeze on all increases in cost of living allowances and state salaries and a reduction in welfare payments. "We want to avoid further health and welfare cuts," he added.
Gov. Richard A. Snelling of Vermont, a Republican, said, "There isn't any entity of government that isn't being sorely stressed."
Today John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff, reassured the governors that President Bush's proposal to give the states control of $15 billion worth of Federal programs would not mean a cutback in Federal assistance.
"They understand that it is not designed to save one cent in Federal spending," Mr. Sununu told reporters after a private luncheon meeting with the governors. "We want it to be programs that they and their state legislatures feel comfortable with."
 Mr. Sununu said that the turnover would last at least five years, and that the programs would be selected from among those totaling $22 billion in Federal spending.
Gov. Lawton Chiles of Florida, a Democrat who had expressed concern that Washington would underfinance the programs, said after Mr. Sununu's luncheon presentation, "He was very reassuring." He was echoed by Gov. William F. Weld of Massachussets, a Republican, who said, "People were worried they might be trying to sell us a pig in a poke."
Discussions of state fiscal problems dominated the meeting. "The recession is driving these budget deficits," said Mr. Johnson of the New York State office. "Forty governors have not engaged in gross mismanagement simultaneously. The lion's share of the gap is a revenue falloff."
But the recession has also meant more people on Medicaid and welfare and more people receiving unemployment insurance. And in recent years Washington has directed the states to spend their own money on a wide variety of programs, especially those involving health and the environment.
 
Paying for New Programs
 Gov. John Ashcroft of Missouri, a Republican, said, "We have $140 million in new revenues, but 14 new mandates will cost $112 million." He said a projected deficit of $100 million meant that "we've had to ratchet back education and a variety of programs."
Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, a Democrat, told his fellow governors this morning, "We need to get a handle on the Medicaid mandates, otherwise some of us are going to go broke," especially those with large and growing numbers of poor people.
But Governor Chiles pointed out that Congress mandated state expenditures because it felt that the states dealt inadequately with problems like providing prenatal care to poor women. "I helped put some of the mandates on," said Mr. Chiles, a former Senator. "Some states weren't doing anything about it."
Gov. Jim Florio of New Jersey projected a $600 million to $800 million deficit in the current year, which he called "substantial but manageable." He has proposed eliminating three departments and consolidating 40 agencies and divisions.
Connecticut anticipates a $1.5 billion deficit, Texas a $4.2 billion deficit in the next two years, and Virginia a $1.9 billion deficit, according to the New York State survey.

HEADLINE: With New Law, Budget Makers Face New Limits

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3

 BODY:
Some items in President Bush's 1992 budget, which will be made public on Monday, will be worth careful scrutiny. Others can be safely ignored.
One figure not worth much attention is the projection that the deficit for the 1992 fiscal year, beginning in October, will be $281 billion. 
 The size of the deficit will depend to a large extent on whether the country pulls out of the recession before October, on how long the war with Iraq lasts and what it costs, and on how much the Government will be forced to spend on failed banks and savings and loan associations.
No one knows the answers to those questions. But since this $1.45 trillion budget assumes optimistically that the recession will be over by summer and allocates only $15 billion for the war the deficit figure is much more likely to be higher than $281 billion than it is to be lower than that.
 
Political Battles in One Field
 What should be looked at carefully is how the Bush Administration wants to allocate money in three broad areas: the military; benefit programs, like Medicare and welfare for which payments are automatic to everyone who is eligible, and discretionary domestic programs, like education and highways. This is the field where the political battles will be fought.
In contrast to previous budget laws, which set overall defict ceilings, the budget law that was enacted last fall works this way: spending ceilings are set for three categories, the military, foreign assistance and most domestic programs. In addition, the law prohibits additional spending for benefit programs unless it is offset by cuts in these programs or new taxes. Most important, the law precludes, for example, cutting military spending and using the money to pay for domestic programs. But within the spending limits of each category, it does not say which weapons should be produced and which ones scrapped, or specify which domestic programs the Government should emphasize.
Details of the budget are not so tightly held these days as they once were, and many of the important elements of the documents that will be sent to Congress on Monday have seeped out in the last few days.
Richard G. Darman, the White House budget director, ran through some raw numbers this morning on the NBC News program "Meet the Press": "$87 billion for children. $2.7 billion for the Department of Education more. $2.1 billion for Head Start. $11.1 billion for drugs."
 
Benefits for Wealthy May Be Cut
 He also suggested, without providing details, that the Administration would propose limits on Medicare benefits to wealthy elderly people. This is a proposal that Mr. Darman has made many times in the past but one that has been rejected by Congress.
The Pentagon budget, Mr. Darman said, will provide $15 billion for the war with Iraq. He called the figure a "place-holder" and said it would be raised or lowered depending on how much the war cost and on the extent to which the tab was picked up by contributions from the allies.
Defense Department officials have said the Pentagon budget would reflect deep cuts in Army, Navy and Air Force units; cuts in new purchases of A-10 antitank planes, which have proved useful in Saudi Arabia; a reduction in the number of Navy ships to 451, from 545, by 1995, and a cancellation of the Tacit Rainbow missile, which was designed to destroy Soviet radar equipment.
Potential political fights could develop over closing military bases and other military cutbacks that might have economic effects in certain states and Congressional districts.
 
Congress to Make Changes
 On the domestic side, according to the latest available documents, the budget will call for large cuts in Medicare payments to doctors and hospitals, low-cost steps to combat infant mortality, a modest expansion of some child nutrition programs, cuts in Federal aid to college students from middle-income families and a substantial increase in spending for highways and space programs. Congress, of course, will have different priorities, and many of the Administration's proposals will be rejected.
As a rule, Administration budgets nowadays are not as important as they were a generation ago. Then, Congress could be expected to make marginal changes in the President's master plan, but, as is the case in parliamentary democracies, the Government ran generally according to the initial blueprint provided by the chief executive. But lawmakers became upset by what they saw as Richard M. Nixon's usurpation of Congress's constitutional power of the purse and established new budget procedures to put it on an equal footing with the executive branch.
Now Congress has its own experts and computers. And with Democrats holding large majorities in the Senate and the House of Representatives, Congress has recently been unwilling to accept the priorities set by Republican Presidents.
 
Openly Political Documents
 Ronald Reagan turned his budgets into openly political documents. Year after year, he offered proposals like deep cuts in mass transit subsidies that stood no chance whatsoever of approval. His supporters and opponents alike realized that these budgets were, in the phrase of the time, "dead on arrival" on Capitol Hill.
The budget that Mr. Bush submitted last January, covering the fiscal year that began in October, had much the same tone. His economic forecasts were so optimistic that the deficit for this fiscal year is expected to be three times the $100 billion he projected.
The budget he submits Monday will have much less room for political extravagance, since the spending on the military ($295 billion), benefit programs ($687 billion) and other domestic programs ($211 billion) is fixed in law.
But his proposal for a cut in the capital gains tax was meant mostly to satisfy his conservative Republican allies, although having been rejected by Congress for two years, it is unlikely to be adopted this year. And Mr. Darman acknowledged in his television interview today that cutting the Medicare benefits of well-to-do elderly people had a particular political attraction.
"It will be somewhat ironic," he said, "if the Democrats, who are expressing concerns about fairness, are reluctant to reduce the subsidies for the wealthiest Americans."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Paperbacks Seem to Be Making a Comeback

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN

 BODY:
In the economically lean 1990's, people have been returning to sensible things like home-cooked dinners and family cars. Now, publishers are beginning to detect a swing back to another sensible product, the paperback book.
For more than 40 years, mass-market paperbacks thrived because they were cheap and convenient. But in the last decade, the handy, portable volumes introduced in the United States by Pocket Books in 1939 languished. During the high-rolling Reagan years, they lacked the pizazz of many hardcover best sellers. 
 "It was a little annoying, all the attention paid to hardcovers, but the big publishing revolution of the 80's was there," said Lou Aronica, the publisher of Bantam's mass-market paperback division.
 
Readers Switch Allegiance
 Lured by discounted hardbacks promoted in chain stores with the aggressive marketing techniques first introduced by paperback publishers, readers switched allegiance and created the new phenomenon of the mass-market hardcover book selling as many as two million copies.
Meanwhile, huge paperback best sellers like "The Exorcist" and "Jonathan Livingston Seagull," which sold as many as 10 million copies, became a thing of the past.
"During the 1980's, the mass paperback market was stagnant," said Carolyn Reidy, the president of Avon Books. "There were fewer paperback racks out there, and market shares shifted."
Mass-market paperback sales grew at a rate of just 6.5 percent a year from 1982 to 1989, compared with a 12.4 percent annual increase in the same period for adult hardbacks, according to the Association of American Publishers. Whereas adult hardback sales more than doubled to $1.7 billion a year in 1989 from $770.8 million in 1982, paperback sales only increased to $1.1 billion from $703 million in that period.
Bill Lofquist, a publishing analyst at the Commerce Department, said the increase in paperback sales was mainly a result of higher prices. Unit sales scarcely rose, he said.
But 1990 appears to have been a much better year for paperbacks than for hardcover books. Preliminary figures for the first 11 months of 1990 show mass-market paperback sales rising 7.2 percent over the comparable period in 1989, while hardback sales increased only 4.4 percent. These figures could change when December -- an important month for book sales -- is added in, but publishers said December's paperback sales were particularly good.
Although paperback sales also grew faster than hardcover sales in 1984 and 1988, publishers see the latest figures as an indication that in a recession people may be much less willing to pay more than $20 for a book when the same thing can be had a little later in paperback for $5.95.
"For the first time in years, I'm beginning to see a rise in actual units of paperbacks sold," said Phyllis Grann, the chief executive of the Putnam Berkley Group. "It's early to say, but this could be the next trend."
David Shanks, the president of Berkley Books, agreed. "I don't know whether it's the recession or the boom in military thrillers linked to the gulf situation, but our sales in recent months have been remarkably strong," he said. "We printed four million more books last year than in 1989."
While paperback publishers caution that evidence of a resurgence is still too flimsy to be called decisive, a new optimism is evident.
"It's entirely likely that during the recessionary period, there would be a greater impact on hardcover than on paperback and probably some trading down," said Jack Romanos, the president of Simon & Schuster's mass-market division. "That should continue to benefit paperbacks."
Several factors contributed to the stagnation of the paperback market during the 1980's. Among them, the price difference between hardbacks and paperbacks narrowed. Whereas paperbacks had once been a tenth of the price of hardbacks, they often became only a third cheaper.
Moreover, some retail outlets like Woolworth began to abandon unprofitable paperback racks.
 
Several Big Mergers
 As a result of its problems, paperback publishing began a period of restructuring. Several big houses merged. Ballantine bought Fawcett; Berkley bought Ace Charter; Penguin acquired New American Library, and Bantam was brought together with Doubleday Dell.
Most crucially, the old habit of being essentially a reprint business was abandoned. Paperback publishers like Bantam, Simon & Schuster's Pocket Books and Berkley began re-inventing their business, becoming publishers of original paperback material that was more varied than ever. Authors like John Saul and Jude Deveraux became best-selling writers through original paperbacks.
The trade paperback -- a hyrbid of the paperback and the hardback, bound in paper but larger than the traditional paperback -- was developed into a $1 billion business. Many paperback houses, including Pocket Books and Bantam, also became serious hardback publishers.
At Pocket Books, 75 percent of the paperback books are now from original manuscripts. "If you remained reprint-oriented, as we were at the beginning of the 80's, your business disappeared," Mr. Romanos of Simon & Schuster said.
At Bantam, too, the proportion of original paperback books has risen. And this year the company divided its mass-market paperback list into six genre imprints -- science fiction, crime, historical saga, women's fiction, high-tech action and nonfiction.
"For a long time, we all clung to the belief that there were still paperback books that everyone wanted to read," said Mr. Aronica, the Bantam mass-market president. "But mass-market is now a misnomer. There are many big audiences, but all different."
Thus, the return of the paperback is unlikely to bring a return of blockbusters like "The Exorcist." The market has changed.
"The days of the 7- or 10-million-copy paperback are gone," said Susan J. Petersen, the president of Ballantine/Del Rey/Fawcett/Ivy Books. "You won't get one book that size, but millions of books selling some copies."

HEADLINE: A Sudden Revival for East Asian Oil

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SINGAPORE

 BODY:
In the months before Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, East Asia was beginning to despair of its role as a producer and refiner of oil and feared that its huge dependence on the Middle East for crude oil would only rise as this region's continuing economic boom sent fuel consumption soaring.
But war in the Persian Gulf has changed that -- at least for now. The region is stepping up efforts to drill for oil and several governments are scrambling to profit from the demand for crude oil, both in the short term and the long. Suddenly there is fresh interest in exploring the South China Sea, from the coast of Vietnam to the shores of Borneo, along with a host of projects to increase the output of existing wells and to build new refineries. 
 For now, the biggest beneficiary is Singapore, which has long been a "swing" refiner because of its ability to make up for specific shortfalls in a fuel. Singapore has been an oil trading center, but never an oil capital. Temporarily, at least, that has changed. The refineries on the islands off Singapore's shores are running above capacity. On the horizon, full tankers are bobbing around, unable to move because there is no room for storage ashore. Saudi Arabia, long one of Singapore's biggest suppliers, has suddenly become one of its biggest clients -- mostly for jet fuel for allied warplanes.
 
'Running at Full Tilt'
 "All of us are running at full tilt, many even faster," said Cheng Hong Kok, the president and chief executive of the Singapore Petroleum Corporation, the biggest local refiner listed on the Singapore stock exchange. "With Kuwait looking like it will not be operating for a long while and many tankers afraid of moving through the gulf, we may be producing like this for some time."
Of course, this boom could be short-lived. For one thing, if oil prices stay relatively low several projects will probably be scrapped.
Moreover, the refining boom will continue only as long as crude oil flows readily from the Middle East. And though stockpiles are high now, there are growing fears that a long war could plunge some of the world's fastest-growing -- and least oil-efficient -- economies into a severe slowdown.
East Asia does produce some oil, but it depends on the Middle East for nearly three-quarters of its crude oil. Some studies suggest that over the next decade dependency will worsen, as countries like Malaysia and Indonesia deplete their reserves and the region's demand increases.
A recent study by the East-West Center in Honolulu predicted that East Asia's oil exports in the next 10 years, now a major source of foreign exchange, would decline significantly as production was diverted to domestic demands.
 
Decline Reversed
 For Singapore, the latest turn of events is an unexpected change. The refining business had shrunk here since the mid-1980's, with the Government estimating refinery output at 800,000 to 900,000 barrels a day, though the industry had capacity for more than a million barrels. Shell, which has dominated Southeast Asia's oil markets since colonial days, mothballed some operations in the mid-80's. Recently they reopened, and other refiners here say they have been installing new equipment to increase output.
In a nation that leaves little to chance, this sudden boom is not exactly what Singapore had in mind to revive its role in the oil business.
Gong Wee Lik, the deputy director of the industry development division for Singapore's powerful Economic Development Board, said Singapore had been moving for some time into specialized petroleum products, hoping, for example, to produce plastics and other materials that could be turned into circuit boards for the country's numerous electronics makers. Instead, it finds itself trying to make up for Japan's sudden shortfalls in kerosene and the United States' sudden interest in a quick supply of jet fuel.
 
Searching for New Fields
 A number of neighboring countries plan to open refineries in the next few years, including a giant plant near Malacca, the ancient trading city of Malaysia.
As a result, the war in the gulf has stimulated exploration.
"There is such a heightened sensitivity now that if you can find any oil away from the Middle East, you will go for it," said Lisa Totto, a researcher at the East-West Center. "And Asia needs it so much, there there does not seem to be such a big problem finding capital for exploration."
Malaysia's state oil company, Petronas, is already worried about meeting its promise of increased production during the gulf crisis, and it is renewing its interest in fields off Sarawak and Sabah, the two Malaysian states on the island of Borneo.
Indonesia, the region's largest producer, is offering incentives to recover oil from fields that many producers had all but abandoned. It has entered a number of exploration contracts with foreign companies in recent months. By some estimates, more than $4 billion will be spent by American and European companies in the next five years to hunt for oil in Indonesia. Still, the country's production is expected to fall, as existing fields begin to dry up.
Oil executives here say that much of the problem is the difficulty in exploring many of East Asia's most promising areas. Many lie in deep water, and a few in deep jungle with no roads. "These are areas that will be explored only if the war drives oil up to $40 a barrel or so," said one American executive in Malaysia, who insisted on remaining anonymous. "Otherwise, no government is going to convince anyone to take the risk."
 
Political Hurdles
 More than a few of the obstacles are political. One of the more promising oil producers over the next few years is Vietnam, which by the most optimistic estimates may have reserves of one to two billion barrels. American oil companies are barred from exploring there because of the longstanding United States trade embargo against Hanoi. But that is hardly slowing Japanese businesses, which are buying most of Vietnam's current crude-oil production, and are negotiating for exploration rights.
Malaysia, Vietnam and other East Asian nations are also in the race, and the decrepit few hotel rooms in Hanoi are filled these days with Asian business executives hoping to strike a deal with a Government still uncertain how to exploit its offshore riches.
In the last two years, Vietnam has signed about 10 contracts with overseas oil companies to explore its reserves and to share any resulting oil. Under one such contract, completed recently with the Broken Hill Proprietary Company of Australia, Broken Hill will spend the next five years exploring, and bear all costs if no oil or gas is found. But if they are found, Broken Hill's capital investment will be reimbursed and it will have an interest in the oil field.
Myanmar, formerly known as Burma, is another potential producer, though on a smaller scale. But the Government there is still trying to keep the lid on a smoldering democracy movement and is fighting rebellions in its northern territories. Few foreign investors, even the Japanese, traditionally Myanmar's biggest source of foreign aid, seem willing to take the risk.
Malaysia and Thailand are arguing over fields in the Gulf of Thailand, though a joint-exploration agreement now seems likely to work. And then there are the Spratly Islands, a desolate and otherwise forgettable cluster that is claimed by the Philippines, Malaysia, Vietnam, China and Taiwan, all of which believe that the chain might be sitting on top of one of East Asia's most lucrative fields.
When battling over Kuwait is over, the islands are believed to be a good candidate for the site of the next power plays for oil.

HEADLINE: Fiscal Reality: Bumpy Streets, Library Cuts and Tuition Rise

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL

 BODY:
The sleek stone facade of the central branch of the Brooklyn Public Library is to be draped in black today, in mourning as much as protest, over a New York City fiscal crunch that is only now beginning to impinge on the lives of New Yorkers.
After months of dire and sometimes confusing statements at City Hall, evoking for many the city's brush with bankruptcy in the 1970's, the pronouncements are beginning to turn into an unpleasant reality -- shorter library hours, dirtier and bumpier streets, broken street lights, higher tuition for the City University system. 
 Starting today, the central branch of the Brooklyn library on Grand Army Plaza is to be closed on Mondays, the first time in its 50-year history that it is to close regularly on a weekday.
 
Reduced Hours for Branches
 Handwritten notes taped to the doors of scores of branch libraries last week announced a reduction in days and hours, with many libraries to be open only four days a week, some three. Schoolchildren, the main users of the city's libraries, are to lock the Brooklyn library's doors symbolically with a chain of paper.
Street cleaning is also suffering. The Sanitation Department has started to reduce street-cleaning routes in business districts across the city. On the Upper West Side of Manhattan, for example, post-midnight sweepings by mechanical brooms along Broadway, Columbus Avenue and the major cross streets have been eliminated.
Manual street sweeping is being virtually eliminated as the cleaning force is being cut to 800 from a peak of 2,500 several years ago. "We will be doing less street cleaning than we did during the fiscal crisis," said Steven M. Polan, the Sanitation Commissioner. "There will be a decline in cleanliness."
At the American Museum of Natural History in Manhattan, administrators have just learned that the city will immediately cut $744,577 from its annual subsidy for the museum, an 11.1 percent reduction. They were told to expect an additional 19.4 percent cut starting in July. Over all, aid to cultural programs was cut by more than $7 million this year and will be cut by $13 million next year from the spending levels announced last July.
Administrators at the museum have begun to debate whether to slash educational programs for children, close exhibition halls during the day, reduce hours or raise the recommended admission fees to make up for the budget cuts. "These cuts will clearly have an effect on our operations," said Barbara Gunn, the museum's vice president for finance.
The Parks Department, facing some of the steepest cuts, is closing the Central Park children's petting zoo, cutting the number of playground attendants by a third, reducing park flower planting and cutting lifeguard hours at public beaches. The swimming season at the city's major outdoor pools will be shortened, and 33 neighborhood mini-pools will not be opened at all.
To reserve a ball field, softball leagues will have to pay $8 instead of $4. The marionette theater in Central Park will be shut. Betsy Gotbaum, the Parks Commissioner and a top fund-raiser for Mayor David N. Dinkins during his campaign, said that she hoped to solicit private contributions to reverse a small part of the cuts but that many would be unavoidable.
In all, the jobs of 430 full-time and 76 seasonal city park workers are being cut. Also being cut are 109 Parks Department administrative jobs.
To forestall cuts in city bridge maintenance programs, Transportation Commissioner Lucius J. Riccio said he had ordered deep service cuts in several programs, slashing plans to rebuild city streets and to make nonemergency highway repairs.
 
'Kind of a Heartbreaker'
 The city will repaint fewer lines on highways, cut crews surveying streets for pothole repairs, and delay replacing 5,000 damaged street lamp fixtures, though burned-out bulbs will still be replaced. New nighttime parking meters will be installed in the midtown theater district and thousands of other meters will be adjusted for higher rates.
Grass-cutting and nonessential cleaning will be halted on most highways, except for roadways that most tourists and business travelers see driving in from Kennedy International and La Guardia Airports like the Grand Central Parkway, Long Island Expressway or Van Wyck Expressway. "It's kind of a heartbreaker," Mr. Riccio said. "It will get visibly dirtier out there on the highways."
But some fiscal experts, inside government and out, say those cuts are only the beginning. Deeper service reductions in the city's parks, libraries, museums and cultural institutions and its schools are to begin in July.
Even more cuts may be needed, both to deal with a laggard city economy and a state budget proposed by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo that would cut more than $400 million in aid to the city. Some experts say that before the current tribulations end, the city may be drastically and permanently reshaped.
"The economic base here can no longer support the current level of services," said Allen J. Proctor, executive director of the state's Financial Control Board. "You need to preserve those services that are necessary to live and do business in the city, and cut or eliminate others."
Mr. Proctor and others have noted that despite the steep cuts for city parks and libraries, other agencies -- the Fire and Police Departments and to a lesser extent the city's Human Resources Administration -- have been spared many deep and painful cuts.
Many smaller city agencies, like the Board of Elections and City Clerk's office, would continue to grow under Mr. Dinkins's budget. In fact, with most school job cuts postponed until next year, the number of workers on the city payroll is likely to rise this year.
"The decision makers in the city need to hear from the people that certain things -- education and libraries -- cannot be cut because we can't retrieve what is lost" said Representative Major R. Owens, a Democrat who represents part of Brooklyn in Congress. "We've got to wage war. We have to fight the assumption that the city and state are poor. The money is there; it is being wasted."
Some analysts see the service cuts as part of a political scheme to mobilize public opposition to budget cuts and support for larger tax increases.
"I do believe the libraries are being held hostage," said Henry J. Stern, a former Parks Commissioner who is the president of the Citizens Union, a nonprofit group. "It is part of a strategy to overcome the Council's reluctance to increase taxes. The administration talks layoffs, but they want taxes."
 
'Where the Dollars Are'
 Marc V. Shaw, director of the City Council finance division, said that once the Mayor decided to protect social services, health services and the police from deep cutbacks, he had little choice but to cut where he did. "That is where the dollars are," he said.
While Mayor Dinkins still hopes to avert most of the layoffs called for in his preliminary budget, the Brooklyn Public Library was forced to lay off 77 clerks and librarians on Thursday. The layoffs were needed to manage a 10 percent cut in aid this year and an additional 8.3 percent cut for next year, said a library spokesman, Donald Kaplan.
The New York Public Library's main research library on Fifth Avenue will open later and close earlier, making it more difficult for working people to use it, said Mimi Koren, associate manager of public relations. The system's 82 branch libraries will provide a total of 58 fewer days of service each week.
Councilwoman Ronnie M. Eldridge of Manhattan found the library cuts particularly galling. Last year, she said, she enlisted Council support to add $50,000 to the city's library subsidy so the Riverside branch library, at Amsterdam Avenue and 69th Street, could open on Saturdays. "Now," she said, "it is closing on Tuesdays."

HEADLINE: Plan to Limit Deposit Insurance Is Defended

 BODY:
The Treasury Department's plan to curtail deposit insurance at the nation's banks was described yesterday by Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady as an attempt "to make the system safe for savers, but yet to make sure the taxpayer does not have to pay enormous bills when banks fail."
The Treasury proposal, details of which were disclosed on Saturday, will be formally announced on Tuesday. It would limit the number of federally insured accounts that one person could have at a single institution. Under the proposal, each person would be limited to one $100,000 account at a single institution, as well as one $100,000 retirement account. 
 "Don't worry," Mr. Brady said in an interview on the ABC television program "Business World." "Savers are going to be presented with plenty of opportunity to put their money in places that they consider absolutely safe."
 
Response to Criticism
 After a series of meetings, and after hearing strong criticism recently from many bankers on a plan for sharper restrictions, senior officials at the White House and the Treasury Department agreed on Saturday about how to limit the coverage.
People could still have multiple accounts of $100,000 at different institutions, each covered by the Government's deposit insurance.
The plan needs the approval of Congress.
The Treasury is also contemplating a second, more stringent part of the plan. It would call for a $100,000 insurance limit on each individual regardless of how many different banks the money is kept in.
The Treasury proposed that such a systemwide limit be phased in after five years, after a study on the costs of adminstering such a program is conducted by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.
 
'A Good Approach'
 "This seems to be a good approach," said Representative Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of Brooklyn, a member of the House Banking Committee. "Insured deposits have to be limited in one way or another." Telephone calls to members of the Senate Banking Committee last night were not answered.
If it is approved by Congress, the Treasury's proposed limit on accounts at a single institution would be phased in over a year, Bush Administration officials say. The curb is intended to encourage large depositors to open accounts at different banks.
The Treasury plan will also eliminate the insurance protection provided to pension funds and other institutional investors that are able to get insurance for their huge deposits by breaking them into accounts of $100,000 or less.
The proposed limitations on deposit insurance come at a difficult time for the nation's banks. The deposit insurance fund administered by the F.D.I.C. and financed through premiums paid by banks has been drained by numerous bank failures, a process likely to continue during the recession.
 
Skepticism From Bankers
 Some bankers contacted yesterday were skeptical of the impact of the proposed changes.
Richard H. Deihl, chairman and chief executive of H. F. Ahmanson & Company, a savings and loan association in Irwindale, Calif., said the limits on institutional depositors were more significant than the curbs on individuals' deposit insurance. He called the proposed changes in the deposit insurance "window dressing," adding, "They are attacking the wrong enemy."
Richard D. Parsons, chairman of the Dime Savings Bank of New York, said the limits on individuals' insurance would be a difficult administrative task.
"This thing they are talking about creating is a nightmare," he said. "I am not sure that it is going to be practical at an operational level."
 
Cost-Benefit Analysis
 Regulators concluded last week that a systemwide limit of $100,000 an individual might cost as much as $1 billion to enforce.
"We wanted to make sure that the benefits offset the costs," said an Administration official who spoke on the condition that he would not be identified.
The official said there was very poor data on the impact of the proposed restriction or more severe limitations.
"It has been very, very difficult to determine how much can be saved by limiting the coverage," he said.
The official added that less than 6 percent of the nation's households have more than $100,000 in the nation's insured banks, savings associations and credit unions.
 
Diversification Encouraged
 In its plan, the Administration will also propose the elimination of laws going back to the Great Depression that prohibit the mergers of investment banks and commercial banks and also sharply limit interstate banking. It will propose the repeal of a law that bars industrial enterprises from owning commercial banks.
Administration officials say these changes will permit banks to diversify and become more profitable, and thus fewer will have to rely on assistance from the bank insurance fund. They also hope that such measures will make banks more attractive to investors.
The plan also substantially modifies the current policy of rescuing all depositors, no matter how large, at banks that officials consider too big to fail, by placing the decision primarily in the hands of the Treasury department and the Federal Reserve Board, instead of the F.D.I.C.
The too-big-to-fail policy, which has been strongly criticized by lawmakers who say it is unevenly applied, was most recently invoked last month with the failure of the Bank of New England and two affiliated banks. The F.D.I.C. has estimated that those three failures will ultimately cost the bank insurance fund at least $2.3 billion, which would make it one of the most expensive bailouts in history.

HEADLINE: Poland Asks West to Cancel Most of Its Big Foreign Debt

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DAVOS, Switzerland, Feb. 3

 BODY:
Asserting that Poland deserves favorable treatment because it is a pioneer in moving toward a market economy, Poland's new Prime Minister called on Western creditors today to forgive 80 percent of his nation's $46 billion in foreign debt.
In his first major speech before a Western audience, Prime Minister Jan Krzysztof Bielecki also promised to speed up Poland's already-rapid transition to capitalism, saying he hoped to privatize thousands of small businesses and hundreds of industrial enterprises in the next few months. 
 Speaking in this Swiss ski resort at the World Economic Forum, which brings together government and corporate officials from more than 50 countries, Mr. Bielecki pledged to remove obstacles to foreign investment, but he said his nation's huge debt was certain to slow growth and investment.
"This debt is a major destabilizing influence," he said. "It badly affects the climate for investment, particularly for foreign investment."
The 39-year-old Prime Minister welcomed a decision in principle by the Group of Seven industrial nations two weeks ago to reduce Poland's debt. But he said he was dissatisfied with the 40 percent reduction figure mentioned by the Finance Minister of France, Pierre Beregovoy.
The extent of the reduction is a matter of intense negotiation. Mr. Bielecki thanked the United States for leading the fight among industrial nations to cut Poland's debt.
Officials close to the negotiations said France was the main opponent of debt reduction of more than 40 percent. French officials say this would create a troubling precedent, since Western nations have agreed on a 33 percent debt-reduction ceiling for poor African countries.
In an interview today, Mr. Bielecki asserted that if Western officials followed their policy of giving debt relief on a case-by-case basis, Poland deserved special treatment.
"Poland is a unique example for Central and Eastern Europe, especially for the Soviet Union, that it is possible to make the transition from one system to another," he said in fluent English.
Mr. Bielecki, who is gray-haired and bearded and who ran a business consulting firm before President Lech Walesa named him Prime Minister, added that Poland also led the way in establishing a new political order in Eastern Europe.
 
Aiming for March
 Mr. Bielicki said it was extremely important to have a debt-reduction agreement by late March, when a moratorium allowing Poland to suspend debt payments is scheduled to end.
Polish officials say $30.9 billion of their country's foreign debt is owed to Western governments, principally to Germany. Another $10.6 billion is owed to commercial banks and $2.4 billion is owed to the Soviet Union and other members of the old Soviet trading bloc. The other debt is to miscellaneous creditors.
Jeffrey Sachs, a Harvard University professor who has advised Poland on its economic changes, said in an interview here that few if any countries deserve more favorable treatment on debt relief than Poland.
Professor Sachs said that Poland's economic problems and debt burden were huge. To cure the economic woes left by Communism, Poland began a program of shock therapy a year ago that involved eliminating most subsidies to industry and consumers, eliminating the Government's budget deficit and slashing the growth of the money supply.
 
Suport for Entrepreneurship
 Mr. Bielecki was one of the main speakers at the weeklong forum here, and his speech today was in many ways an ode to entrepreneurship.
"Our intention is to move to a market economy as fast as possible," he said. "That is the only way of giving hope to the young."
He said that one difference between his economic policies and those of his predecessor, Tadeusz Mazowiecki, was that he would put far more emphasis on the privatization of shops, restaurants and other small businesses. These moves, he said, are essential for creating a middle class, which "will be the natural supporter of economic change."
He said he had no plans to expand Poland's safety net for the one million unemployed, saying they would be encouraged to start businesses and find jobs themselves. "We have to unleash Poland's natural entrepreneurial spirit," he said.
Mr. Bielecki also outlined an extensive program to privatize large companies and create a sense of efficiency-minded ownership by distributing vouchers to the public for buying stock and by setting up mutual funds and other institutional investors.
The Prime Minister said he hoped that Poland would be accepted into the European Community by the end of the century.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Poland's new Prime Minister, Jan Krzysztof Bielecki, has urged that 80 percent of his country's debt to the West be forgiven. (Associated Press) (pg. D2)

HEADLINE: Frohnmayer Approves Environmental Project

BYLINE: By BARBARA GAMAREKIAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3

 BODY:
The chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts has announced that he has changed his mind and will approve a $10,000 grant to an artist for an environmental project.
The grant to the artist, Mel Chin, had been recommended by both the endowment's grant-making panel and by the National Council for the Arts, but the chairman, John E. Frohnmayer, said in November that he would overrule the two groups. 
 Unlike other grants that have roiled the endowment for the past year and a half, Mr. Chin's proposal does not involve sexuality or nudity. Instead, he proposes to collaborate with a Department of Agriculture research agronomist on a project using plants that absorb toxic metals to clean a waste site.
Mr. Frohnmayer's reversal was made known on Saturday at a meeting of the National Council for the Arts, which is appointed by the President to advise the endowment, as it returned to its customary low profile this weekend to discuss council policy and review almost 1,000 grant recommendations.
 
Respite From the Turmoil
 Over the past 18 months the council's quarterly meetings have been the scenes of emotional debate as members wrestled with how they could insure the future of the arts agency and comply with legislative restrictions on Federal financing of the arts.
But this two-day gathering was more a time for philosophical reflection and inquiry, as 18 council members discussed new Congressional requirements and approved $27 million worth of grants in the fields of arts education, design, visual arts, folk arts, music, dance, theater, museum and media arts.
At its last meeting, panel members expressed disappointment that Mr. Frohnmayer had not consulted with them before rejecting their recommendation of Mr. Chin's project. In reversing his decision, the chairman said that he originally felt the application "didn't adequately articulate what the project was about," and had asked that it be resubmitted.
"It's important that an application be written in a way that clearly articulates artistic merit and how that artistic merit is going to be accessible to the public," he said.
 
The Dwindling Pie
 In his opening remarks on Friday, Mr. Frohnmayer also spoke of the "severe disconnects in art funding around the country" and pointed to sharp cuts in arts support by many states during the current recession.
Ed Dickey, the endowment's director of states programs, told of recommended cuts of 40 percent in Texas, 56 percent in New York and 75 percent in Virginia and Massachusetts.
"Every one of those dollars represents human aspirations and goals," said a council member, the theater director Lloyd Richards. "The artistry of this country is being affected in a very major way."
Another council member, Roy M. Goodman, the Republican State Senator from Manhattan, said, "We must dispel the illusion that there is a Federal offset for this lost money."
 
Larger Share to the States
 He was referring to the fact that when Congress voted in October to extend the life of the arts endowment for three years, it increased the amount of money the endowment gives to the states to distribute to 27.5 percent from 20 percent. This has meant a decrease of nearly $12 million in grants the endowment itself can award to artists and arts organizations. In fiscal 1992, that figure will rise to 32 percent.
As the council heard reports from representatives of state councils from Ohio, Arizona and South Carolina against the Government's shift of more money to states, council members pressed them to lobby Congress to reverse the redistribution. "You have the political clout to reverse it," said Wendy Luers, a council member. "We don't."
The most provocative discussion was prompted by the painter Helen Frankenthaler after a presentation by the panel on visual arts programs when she questioned whether the demand for cultural diversity and social consciousness in grant giving was subverting the criteria for artistic excellence.
 
The Question of Quality
 "There's a sameness throughout," she said. "What happened to art that isn't video or performance art? Part of our responsibility is to make culture the loftiest ideal for the nation and this other thrust has lost sight of what used to be a major concern."
Roger Mandle, the deputy director of the National Gallery of Art, argued the two were "not mutually exclusive" and during the 40-minute discussion other panel members such as the composer David Baker and the choreographer Arthur Mitchell weighed into what many panelists later described as the most stimulating exchange the council has experienced in months.
"You don't like this work, you disagree with their version of quality and that is O.K.," Harvey Lichtenstein, the president of the Brooklyn Academy of Music, told Miss Frankenthaler, "but I object to the fact that you denigrate the work of these artists and say it is not really quality work when we have a panel and people of stature who agree these artists should get grants."

HEADLINE: Frank Rose, U. of Alabama Chief During Racial Turmoil, Dies at 70

BYLINE: By PETER B. FLINT

 BODY:
Frank Anthony Rose, the president of the University of Alabama from 1958 to 1969, the era when it was peacefully desegregated, died Friday at Georgetown University Hospital in Washington. He was 70 years old and had homes in Washington and Lexington, Ky.
He died of cancer and pneumonia, a family spokesman said. 
 With tact and diplomacy, Dr. Rose acted as the middleman in the June 1963 confrontation between Gov. George C. Wallace and the Justice Department of the Kennedy Administration. The university president, who described himself as neither a segregationist nor an integrationist but a realist, had vowed to help insure obedience to the laws and peace on the campus.
So when the Alabama Governor stood defiantly in front of a campus door and raised a hand against federalized troops, but stepped aside moments later, two black students were enrolled without further incident.
 
Raised Faculty Pay and Morale
 In his 11-year tenure at the university, Dr. Rose increased the faculty and its pay and morale, raised tens of million of dollars in research funds, tightened academic standards, expanded the graduate departments and helped build football teams that won national championships.
A 6-foot-2-inch Mississippian, he excelled as an administrator, fund-raiser and university spokesman rather than as an academician, and was popular with business leaders and politicians. When accused of stressing sports over scholarship, he replied simply, "Character is not built by a losing team."
Dr. Rose left Alabama in 1969 for Washington, where he founded and headed a not-for-profit consulting concern, University Associates, with clients that included black colleges. The company later merged with Cassidy & Associates, a public affairs concern, and he remained a senior consultant.
Frank Anthony Rose was born in Meridian, Miss., on Oct. 16, 1920. His father died when he was 10, and early on he picked cotton at 50 cents a day and later plowed fields and drove soft-drink trucks to earn money to go to Transylvania College in Lexington, Ky., where he earned bachelor's degrees in philosophy and divinity and was elected to Phi Beta Kappa.
 
A College President at 31
 He taught at the college while preaching as an ordained minister in the Disciples of Christ. At the age of 31, he became president of Transylvania, serving for seven years until he accepted the presidency at Alabama. He was awarded honorary doctorates by more than a dozen universities.
Over the years, Dr. Rose held many advisory posts with groups like the Salk Institute for Biological Studies; the White House committee on education and minority affairs, and the governing boards of Georgetown University and its medical center, the Mount Sinai Medical Center and the Christian Church Foundation.
Surviving are his wife of 48 years, Tommye; two daughters, Susan Dabny of Lexington and Elizabeth Rose of Pensacola, Fla.; two sons, Frank Jr., of Mobile, Ala., and Julian, of Dallas; a brother, Ramon, of Dallas, and eight grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Helping Hostile Cultures Touch

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN

 BODY:
Richard Sennett is a man who likes to ramble, both intellectually and on foot. In his new book, "The Conscience of the Eye: The Design and Social Life of Cities," the widely published and much-debated New York University sociologist takes the reader on several walks through New York City, commenting along the way on the lack of community, the separation of misery and wealth, and the absence of "a telling moment of talking or touching or connection."
Speaking at his home in Greenwich Village the other day, Mr. Sennett pursued the point. "Americans are particularly good at flight," he said. He had in mind the flight to the suburbs, the resistance to racial integration, the retreat from those who are socially or economically different, the campaign in higher education for cultural separatism, and other evasions that Americans have contrived to avoid the challenge and promise of a genuinely multi-cultural society. 
 These practices, said Mr. Sennett, who is 48 years old, have led to disharmony at home and the tendency "to measure the reality of the world by what we know immediately," a short-sightedness he regards as "disaster for us."
"The Conscience of the Eye" is Mr. Sennett's sixth work of nonfiction (he has also written three novels), and it seems as certain to be as provocative as its predecessors, which include "The Fall of Public Man" (1977) and "Authority" (1980).
 
Profiting From Differences
 In the past, Kenneth Keniston, the Yale professor of psychology who is one of Mr. Sennett's champions, praised him for exhibiting "a refreshing willingness to deal with contemporary American society on its own terms rather than in strained analogies to 19th-century capitalism or to 20th-century colonialism."
On the other hand, the critic Anatole Broyard, who generally admired Mr. Sennett's work, once called him down for being "sometimes lyrical instead of empirical," and J. H. Plumb, the Cambridge University historian, witheringly deplored "The Fall of Public Man" as being filled with "too much fashionable intellectual jargon, too little depth of thought."
"What I'm trying to get at in this book," Mr. Sennett said of "The Conscience of the Eye," "is the way you create a culture in which strangers can live together and profit from their differences. We can't go backward in time. We're an international society. Here in New York, 40 percent of the people who live in the city were not born in the United States. In that way, New York is a microcosm of the world. I tried to make all this very local and particular in terms of New York in the book, but I think the problem is a national one and indeed will become a European problem when the national borders open up in 1992."
 
'No Place to Hide Anymore'
 Mr. Sennett's descriptions of his strolls through the city are accompanied by a discussion of ideas about urban life from a variety of esoteric thinkers: the Renaissance clockmaker Isaak Haprecht and the 17th-century geographer Hickeringill, to name just two. He sweeps back and forth through cultural history and the contemporary scene, using as intellectual springboards such disparate matters as how the development of iron cannonballs affected the growth of cities, how recognition scenes in Dickens and Flaubert express contrasting kinds relationships between strangers, and how a Balanchine ballet and Mark Rothko's chapel in Houston inspire the kind of "turning outward" essential to meaningful city life.
All the while, he is pressing his thesis that the design of modern cities is an expression of the "fear of exposure." In place of that, he argues, the city must come to exemplify what Baudelaire called "the willingness to lose oneself in the world's confusions," in the author's paraphrase.
Asked whether he considered his thesis utopian, Mr. Sennett said: "There's no place to hide anymore. You can't hide in the suburbs because the problems of the city have now caught up with them. Furthermore, when you hide from other people, you deprive yourself of some of the essential experiences that you need to be a human being. The effect of hiding shows up in your failures to cope with the world."
"If we were a province, we could have an individualist culture," he continued, "but we are a superpower. What I think this book tries to do is identify a cultural necessity. The problem of sharing territory in the city reflects that larger necessity: how to share our differences."
 
The New Tribalism
 "Probably what we'll see in the next 20 years is that about 40 percent of the American economy will be foreign-owned," he continued. "That means we're being internationalized, like it or not. There's no way to go back to the world of Ronald Reagan, to a willfully simple society. The thing that bothers me is that I don't think our cultural ideas -- I mean the idea that there's shelter, the idea that culture is something uniform rather than made of mixed parts -- accord with the economic and political realities that we have to deal with."
"Furthermore," he said, "a lot of what we say about multi-culturalism is really a new form of tribalism. Especially on the left, people say, 'We're different from you, so leave us alone.' And that, to me, is more America, more cultural separatism. Teaching multi-culturalism is not just teaching about different cultures, but teaching about where cultures connect. My book tries to imagine how hostile cultures can touch rather than withdraw from each other. And what I would like to see us do in city planning is think about how you bring cultural differences together."
"For me," he said, "this is a kind of hopeful book. I wanted to think about New York not as a sinkhole of poverty and racial conflict, but as a city whose problems are symbolic of all cities. How can people who don't share much share the same territory?"
 
In Arendt and Baldwin
 Mr. Sennett said he considers himself a protege of the political philosopher Hannah Arendt, who died in 1975.
"I met Arendt when I was a student at the University of Chicago," he recalled, "when I came up to her after a class in the history of art and explained that I would have to withdraw from the course. I had my cello with me, and she liked that and convinced me not to withdraw. Then she flunked me. That's how we became friends."
In "The Conscience of the Eye" Mr. Sennett praises Arendt for having recognized impersonality as a positive value, that being a clue to his vision of the future. "She was truly color-blind," he wrote, "as she became in a way blind to religion and to social class."
But the individual who pointed the way to the future most provocatively for Mr. Sennett was the novelist and essayist James Baldwin. "Baldwin's voice," he writes in "The Conscience of the Eye," "is that of someone who has learned how to speak to strangers, not in the polite tones of 18th-century civility, but instead more forcefully and directly." In Mr. Sennett's view, it is this "harsher" tone, exemplified by Baldwin's 1962 essay "The Fire Next Time," that will be the saving grace of the city of the future.

SECTION: Section A; Page 17; Column 3; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 1712 words

HEADLINE: Limited War, Maximum Advantage

BYLINE: By Zbigniew Brzezinski; Zbigniew Brzezinski was national security
adviser in the Carter Administration.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The U.S., the recent victor in the 45-year-long cold war, has just become involved in a regional war. The outcome of that war might well determine whether the U.S. will enjoy the fruits of its global victory. Indeed, the outcome may decide whether the U.S. will be able to shape "the new world order," of which President Bush has spoken so often.
 Had the gulf crisis been resolved peacefully, with Iraq coerced into withdrawing from Kuwait by sanctions applied by the international community, a giant step toward a new world order indeed would have been taken. The rule of law would have been asserted through a collective but nonviolent response. 
But perhaps that was impossible. Even at the very last minute prior to the Jan. 15 deadline, Saddam Hussein spurned a French offer of a compromise (contrary to those, myself included, who thought that he would accept). Moreover, U.S. diplomacy during the crisis often conveyed the impression of being dedicated to the prevention of a diplomatic solution. It is regrettable, for example, that the American-Soviet statement of Jan. 29 was not issued exactly two weeks earlier. Thus we will never know if a nonviolent policy could have worked.
 The recourse to arms means that the ultimate military victory will be largely America's doing. But the parameters and the trajectory of war are inherently unpredictable. War triggers unforeseeable military dynamics and sets off massive political shocks, creating new problems as well as new opportunities.
 Hence, even as the guns still speak, it is not too early to focus on the twin challenges arising out of Mr. Bush's decision to go to war. First, what must be done to minimize the negative costs of the use of force? Second, what can be done to maximize the political benefits of an eventual U.S. military victory?
 Much depends on who exercises strategic control over the conduct of the war. Mr. Hussein's strategy is clear: to prolong and widen the conflict, transforming it into an American-Israeli war against the Arabs. The U.S., therefore, should seek to avoid a bloody ground war, fought for the goal of a total victory over Iraq. We should strive to limit our war aims to those set by the U.N. -- the restoration of Kuwait.
 The pursuit of the more limited aim should enable us to rely on a protracted air campaign designed to isolate Iraqi forces in Kuwait, to erode Iraqi military power and to inflict punishment on Iraqi industrial assets, while softening up the Iraqi defenses in Kuwait. And we should consider our mission accomplished if the Iraqis withdraw from Kuwait or if their forces there, surrounded and beleaguered, surrender.
 To be sure, Mr. Hussein may choose even then to continue to fight from the hinterland. But there is no point seeking to install a new regime in Baghdad. It would be better to subject his remaining forces -- deprived of any offensive capabilities -- to an enduring air harassment and punishment.
 This would leave Saddam Hussein humiliated, politically and militarily defeated on the issue of Kuwait, and with the country's industrial-military facilities in ruins. It would represent the second massive successive failure for his war policies, for his war with Iran produced nothing but suffering for the Iraqis. His political future would be very much in doubt.
 It is also important to remind ourselves that America's capacity to conduct a foreign policy that is responsive to our wider interests depends very much on our ability to avoid becoming deeply entangled as a protagonist in the Middle Eastern problems. The longer the war lasts -- especially if it becomes a ground war deep in Iraq -- the higher the regional and international costs for America.
 These costs can be broadly described as involving the following:
 A rise in regional instability and an intensification in Arab hatred for the U.S. Such feelings could be compounded by a global wave of sympathy for Iraq, which might increasingly be perceived -- particularly in the third world -- as the underdog. Ominous indications of this are surfacing in Egypt and elsewhere.
 Large-scale social disruptions in Iraq, but perhaps in the adjoining countries as well, caused in part by massive migrations of refugees, displaced persons and the homeless. The human suffering will be proportionate to the intensity and duration of the conflict. The transition from war to peace could also prove elusive, and the war could even spread.
 Protracted absorption of American foreign policy by the Persian Gulf and Middle East issue, to the exclusion of other important matters. America could become a bogged-down regional protagonist rather than the region's external mediator or arbiter. Moreover, cynical Europeans, convinced that all of history is derived from either perfidy or conspiracy, are already beginning to whisper about American-Soviet collusion: a free hand for America in the Persian Gulf in exchange for a free Soviet hand to crush the Baltic states. There was, in any case, the appearance of sacrifice of principle in the U.S. solicitation of Chinese and Syrian support for the action against Iraq.
 A decline in domestic support for military action and a rise in bitter domestic divisions. Large casualties will certainly undermine public support for the war. The sense of relief generated by America's victory in the cold war could easily degenerate into ugly recriminations, intensified perhaps by domestic economic difficulties.
 It follows that, even as we wage a controlled war and not a total one, the President should take the lead in articulating an agenda for America that looks beyond this regional war and responds also to the opportunities inherent in our recent victory in the global cold war. He should do so regarding three central issues that deserve national attention.
 First, the President should make more explicit America's longer range role in the Middle East. He should recommit America to a sustained and energetic effort to create a security framework for the region, one which truly takes into account the security needs of all parties. An Israeli-Arab peace settlement has become a necessity, and its attainment must become an explicit objective of American foreign policy, to be sought with the same degree of Presidential commitment with which we rebuffed Mr. Hussein's original aggression.
 An important component of any peace settlement has to be a wide-ranging economic recovery program, designed not only to undo the ravages of war in Iraq and Lebanon but to promote some degree of redistribution of wealth within the region. Otherwise, the spirit of vengeance and intransigence will dominate the Middle East to an even greater extent than ever, and with America now part of the problem and not the solution.
 Second, America must refocus its attention on what is happening in the post-Communist and the still-Communist world. Events there are likely to be more decisive for our future history than the tragic events in the Persian Gulf.
 Nevertheless, the Administration appears to cling to its preoccupation with Mikhail Gorbachev, while appearing to be much less concerned than the Europeans with either the fate of the Baltic countries or the growing difficulties of the post-Communist transition in Eastern European. It could not even bring itself to link the postponement of the summit meeting to the Soviet mistreatment of the Lithuanians and Latvians. There are also some ominous parallels here to the situation that prevailed in 1956 -- when the Anglo-French invasion of Suez diverted attention from Moscow's crushing of the Hungarians.
 Fortunately, the analogy to 1956 falls short in one important respect: This time, genuine political life exists in the Soviet Union. Accordingly, the U.S. should relate more directly to the democratic forces within the Soviet Union, especially the non-Communist governments of several of the non-Russian republics. And it should make some gestures of support, particularly for such political leaders as Boris Yeltsin. It should also place on the international agenda such matters as the Soviet suppression of the Baltic states. All this may temporarily worsen relations with Mr. Gorbachev but, in the long run, will promote democracy where it truly counts.
 Moreover, more of an effort needs to be made to address the conceptual problems in the transition to democracy. Internal tensions in Eastern Europe are likely to mount in the course of 1991, and there is a growing sense that the West, and especially America, are insufficiently responsive to the social and economic costs that the pursuit of freedom entails.
 Poland, Czechoslovakia and Hungry are all watching with amazement as America plows tens of billions of dollars into the Persian Gulf war or as rewards for countries that support the American position in that war. Without a more deliberate American, European and Japanese engagement in Eastern Europe's complex transition from totalitarianism to democracy, it is quite likely that the democratic experiment will run into increasing difficulties. Ultimately, it could even fail.
 Third, the time has come for a post-cold war program of domestic renewal of America's socio-economic structure. Even a cursory comparison of many aspects of American life -- from education to roads and bridges, not to speak of crime and social injustice -- with the more advanced countries of Europe yields depressing conclusions. America's victory in the cold war was not without painful social costs.
 It is tragic that the Administration might end up spending as much as $50 billion on a regional war, with perhaps another $10 billion to $20 billion in payoffs to Israel, Egypt, Turkey and others -- and yet is seemingly unable to initiate a comprehensive and ambitious effort to respond to our domestic shortcomings.
 As the war progresses and passions mount, Mr. Bush will be under increasing pressure to shift from limited to total war aims. It would be a bitter historical irony if America thereby were to lose sight of its wider and longerrange interests. The victor in the cold war, instead of shaping a new world order, would thus become the entangled victim of an endless regional conundrum.
