SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1516 words

HEADLINE: Business Groups Fight Laws In California on Wage Scales

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 4

 BODY:
Several communities in the San Francisco Bay area have enacted what labor lawyers say are the nation's first local laws that specify the wages to be paid to employees of private businesses.
Alarmed business groups, fearing that such laws will become a nationwide trend, are seeking to have them struck down in court. That action has set the stage for a highly emotional battle between the business groups and labor unions, which support the laws and stand to benefit from them. 
 The ordinances require that workers on private construction projects be paid what is called the prevailing wage. That wage, determined by a state agency, is usually close to union wages.
Prevailing-wage laws have been applied to Federal and some state public works projects, starting with the Federal Davis-Bacon Act in 1931. But the ordinances in the Bay Area are the first in the nation to cover private construction projects.
The difference in wages can be striking. A study commissioned by construction unions showed that on one project nonunion workers were paid an average of $12.39 an hour, including benefits, while the average prevailing wage would have been $27.97. And in an affidavit filed in one of the lawsuits challenging the laws, the president of a company that provides maintenance and repair service for industry said that under prevailing wages he would have to pay $25.03 an hour, including benefits, to workers who now receive $11.37.
Supporters of the laws argue that they prevent businesses from using low-paid, poorly trained workers who pose a workplace safety hazard and do construction of poor quality.
"If someone thinks that all you do is hire someone off the street and they know what they are doing, that's not the way it works," said Robert Gilmore, business manager for the Building and Construction Trades Council in San Mateo County, which is immediately south of San Francisco.
Often, he and other supporters say, such workers are brought in from other parts of the country in migrations reminiscent of "The Grapes of Wrath," overloading local schools and hospitals and hurting the local economy.
Union officials concede that the laws help the unions. While the ordinances do not require union labor, the fact that high wages must be paid removes a big incentive for private businesses to use nonunion workers.
 
Business Groups' Argument
 Business groups argue that the laws, in addition to raising their labor costs, represent an unwarranted and unconstitutional intrusion into private businesses by local governments.
They fear that the ordinances might become an important new tool for labor unions, which can enlist the help of sympathetic local politicians to insure more employment for union workers.
"It's really a use by the A.F.L.-C.I.O. of the political process to attempt to force what they cannot gain through collective bargaining," said Rosemary M. Collyer, a Washington lawyer representing the United States Chamber of Commerce, a business lobbying group.
 
Size of Projects a Factor
 Prevailing-wage laws affecting private projects have been passed in the last two years by San Mateo County and by three cities in that county -- South San Francisco, San Bruno and Belmont. These laws apply to residential, commercial and industrial construction projects above $250,000, although residential developments of four homes or less are exempted. In August, Contra Costa County, across the bay from San Francisco passed a law that applies to industrial construction projects of $500,000 or more.
Now, other communities in California are considering such ordinances, and business groups fear the laws will spread to other states. In Dade County, in Florida, a prevailing-wage law took effect in January that applies only to public projects but that business groups see as an unfavorable precedent.
"It looked like it was beginning to snowball and we needed to take it on," said Willie Washington, manager of human resources for the California Manufacturers Association, a lobbying group.
 
Court Challenges
 The association, along with two business groups in Contra Costa County, filed suit in state court against the Contra Costa ordinance, arguing that the state minimum-wage law prohibited localities from regulating wages. The Chamber of Commerce group has filed a suit in Federal District Court in San Francisco against the same ordinance.
The San Mateo, San Bruno and South San Francisco ordinances are being challenged in court by the Golden Gate Chapter of the Associated Builders and Contractors Inc., a trade group representing mainly nonunionized building contractors.
The business groups argue that there is no evidence that lower-paid workers have more accidents or do shoddier work. They also say the laws are pre-empted by Federal laws, like the National Labor Relations Act, that specify terms for collective bargaining and worker benefits.
 
Lobbying Group's Statement
 "The ordinance would not only frustrate collective bargaining; it would emasculate it," the Chamber of Commerce group said in papers filed in the case. "By dictating wage levels and employer payments for health benefits, welfare benefits, pensions, travel time, vacation, subsistence pay and apprenticeship contributions, the ordinance will nullify the terms of any contrary collective bargaining agreements."
The Shell Oil Company and the Unocal Corporation, both of which have refineries in Contra Costa County that are affected by the ordinance, say that the law would cause widespread confusion by forcing them to pay their employees two different wages. Their workers, who are represented by the Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers International Union, would get their usual wage when they were running the refinery and the prevailing wage when they were doing maintenance or construction work.
In its suit, the building contractors' association asserts that by placing unreasonable restrictions on developers, the laws represent an unconstitutional taking of property without just compensation.
Supporters of the laws argue that local government has a legitimate claim to such regulation. "Our basic position is that protection of health and safety and protection of the quality of construction are traditional areas of local regulation," said Thomas R. Adams, a San Mateo lawyer representing the construction unions.
Mr. Adams said prevailing-wage laws were appearing now because localities in California, and to some extent in the rest of the nation, were asserting greater control over local development. These controls include requiring developers to provide amenities like parks and child care centers in their projects.
 
Round Won by Law's Supporters
 While the Federal cases have not yet been decided, the unions have won a round in state court. In November, a Superior Court judge, James J. Marchiano, upheld the Contra Costa ordinance, saying state law does not specifically bar a locality from passing wage laws.
The Contra Costa ordinance has attracted the most attention because unlike San Mateo, Contra Costa has many large industrial plants including a steel mill, refineries, petrochemical plants and pulp and paper companies. The plants' owners -- among them Chevron, Dow Chemical and Gaylord Container -- have considerable political and economic influence.
Despite that, the companies were powerless to derail the ordinance, which was pushed through by local unions that capitalized on a public furor incited by USS-Posco Industries, one of the large companies.
In 1987, USS-Posco, a joint venture of the USX Corporation and the Pohang Iron and Steel Company of South Korea, began a $400 million renovation of an aging steel mill near the city of Pittsburg, Calif., using a nonunion contractor.
 
Deaths on the Job Fuel Campaign
 Confronted with one of the largest nonunion projects in the state's history, unions began a fierce campaign. When two construction workers died on the job, the unions quickly charged that the project was using untrained workers, resulting in unsafe conditions.
Another factor also played into the hands of the unions. The contractor, a joint venture whose main partner was BE& K Construction of Birmingham, Ala., brought in hundreds of workers from other parts of the country, who sometimes lived in their cars and whose families crowded local schools and hospitals.
"It was kind of like 'The Grapes of Wrath' of the construction industry," said Greg Feere, business manager and secretary-treasurer of the Contra Costa Building and Construction Trades Council, an umbrella group of construction-related unions.
John R. Gibson, director of modernization for USS-Posco, said the construction work was of high quality and that it was only speculation that the fatal accidents would not have happened had higher-paid workers been used. He said the nonunion contractor had been chosen because it bid about $50 million less than the lowest union contractor.
"Had we not made this decision, I'm not sure we would have had a project," he said.

HEADLINE: Europe Has Its Share Of Airline Problems

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Feb. 4

 BODY:
Airlines in the United States are not the only ones reeling from the Persian Gulf war. Uncertainty and a fear of terrorism generated by the conflict have also severely depressed the business of European airlines, which like American carriers had already been hit hard when fuel prices soared last year after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait.
Slowing economies in Europe, especially in Britain and Sweden, have also hurt the airline business. All told, major European airlines are reporting that the number of passengers has dropped 10 to 30 percent, and they have been cutting domestic and international service accordingly. 
 According to the 21-member Association of European Airlines, international flights within Europe were only 35 percent full in the last week of January. Lufthansa's planes have been flying 40 percent full on average since the war broke out, down from 60 percent. Late last month, London's two biggest airports, Heathrow and Gatwick, reported passenger traffic down 24 and 19 percent, respectively, from a year earlier.
Some carriers, including Scandinavian Airlines System and Air France, have announced plans to delay or cancel plane orders, although Air France said it made the decision before the war broke out. S.A.S. has also announced plans to reduce employment by 3,500, or 15.9 percent, by the end of 1992.
Olympic Airways, owned by the Greek Government, said it would have difficulty staying in business if the industry remained depressed for long. "For the time being, we are surviving, but who knows about the future," said Mark Xenakis, Olympic's assistant director general. He said Olympic had lost $67 million since the gulf crisis began in early August.
Besides Olympic, other airlines that might have trouble surviving in their current form include Alitalia of Italy, Sabena of Belgium and Iberia of Spain, said Richard Whitaker, editor of Airline Business, a trade magazine based in Sutton, England.
The European airlines' troubles have raised questions about whether the European Community will slow its program aimed at increasing competition and reducing state subsidies. "That's the big unknown today," said Andrew Chambers, a London-based analyst at Nomura Research Institute Europe Ltd.
Most of the major European carriers are either completely or partly state-owned, and many were struggling even before the gulf crisis. These include Alitalia, Sabena, Iberia, Air France and, to a lesser extent, Lufthansa of Germany.
While the 21 carriers in the Association of European Airlines earned a total of $1.1 billion in 1989, the group undoubtedly suffered an operating loss in 1990, its first since 1981, said David Henderson, the association's manager of statistical information.
Mr. Whitaker wondered how many governments would be willing to continue to pour money into their national carriers. If the losses become too great, "it may change people's minds as to whether every country should have a flag carrier," he said.
The Belgian Government has already indicated its intention to reduce its stake in Sabena S.A., parent of Sabena Belgian World Airlines, to 26 percent from about 54 percent. The Government wants the company to find outside investors.
 
Sabena Deal Collapsed
 A deal that would have given British Airways and KLM Royal Dutch Airlines each a 20 percent stake in the Sabena airline fell apart in December. At that time, Sabena said it expected its airline to lose as much as five billion Belgian francs ($158.3 million) in 1990.
Industry executives and analysts say that if the difficulties persist, some airlines will urge the European Commission, the community's executive branch, to ease its opposition to state subsidies and to permit big carriers to cooperate in ways that might seem anti-competitive.
The community has already taken steps to allow more competition in fares, but some industry executives would undoubtedly like to see delays on other planned actions. These include changes in the system for allocating landing and takeoff rights that could take rights away from big carriers, and opening international and domestic markets to much more competition.
"We don't think there will be any substantial delays or changes" in the deregulation program, said David Burnside, a spokesman for British Airways, which has generally been one of the strongest industry supporters of deregulation.
Carel Paauwe, the Amsterdam-based head of the transportation practice of McKinsey & Company, the management consulting firm, said the pace of deregulation would not slow very much unless the downturn dragged on and threatened the survival of some big airlines. "If one or two were really in danger of going under, then I think governments would have second thoughts," he said.
 
Hiring of Pilots Is an Issue
 Airlines would like to see cuts in airport fees, which are much higher in Europe than in the United States. They have also urged the commission to delay communitywide limits on how many hours pilots can fly and to make it easier for a carrier in one country to hire pilots in other nations where salaries are lower, said Stephen Wheatcroft, a London-based industry consultant and former executive at British Airways.
The major European carriers that have been the most profitable are British Airways, which has been investor-owned since 1987; KLM, which is 38 percent owned by the Netherlands, and Scandinavian Airlines System, which is half-owned by the Governments of Sweden, Denmark and Norway. But after being stung by the leap in fuel prices and the plunge in the number of passengers, analysts think that even the relatively efficient airlines are operating in the red.
British Airways, Europe's biggest carrier, said it expects to report a loss for the second half of its current fiscal year (the six months that end March 31). In reaction to the sharp downturn in business, it has cut its global service by 10.5 percent on average. The airline had previously announced it was abandoning service between Britain and the Irish Republic, beginning in March.
 
Talk of Layoffs
 Before the war broke out, British Airways had announced plans to cut costs by at least 100 million ($197.7 million) by the end of 1991. While it originally said these plans would not involve large layoffs, reports in British newspapers say the airline now has contingency plans to lay off up to 5,000 workers, or 10 percent of its work force. A spokesman would neither confirm nor deny those figures. The spokesman said no layoffs were imminent but the airline might have to resort to such action.
British Airways has told employees they can take up to three months of unpaid leave. To encourage that, it has offered to give free tickets to employees and their families to anywhere the airline flies if the employee takes at least one month off.
The airline has delayed until spring its plans to order planes to replace its fleet of 25 Lockheed Tristar and McDonnell Douglas DC-10 jetliners. It had planned to place the order by the end of last year.
Scandinavian Airlines System aims to cut its costs by three billion kronor ($540.1 million) by the end of 1992. S.A.S., which says the number of passengers has fallen by 20 to 40 percent, depending on the route, is cutting its flights by about 15 percent, said John Herbert, an S.A.S. spokesman. S.A.S. executives have said the airline probably broke even in 1990.
KLM Royal Dutch Airlines said last week that it would drastically cut service to European and United States destinations. The carrier will cut its capacity within Europe by 20 percent by canceling and combining flights and using smaller aircraft. Nine of KLM's 49 destinations in the United States are being dropped.
 
Cutbacks at Air France
 Air France has cut service in Europe but would not say by how much. In the week of Jan. 15-21, the week the Iraq war started, its traffic was down 16 percent from a year earlier. Even before the war, Air France had imposed a freeze on most hiring and announced plans to reduce or eliminate service on unprofitable routes.
The company, which also owns two smaller French carriers, Air Inter and Union des Transports Ariens, has delayed by one year the delivery of seven long-range Airbus 340's, which it was supposed to receive in the 1994-96 period. It has also delayed the delivery of six other planes it has options to buy and canceled options on seven other planes.
Lufthansa has cut 120 of its 1,000 or so flights to destinations in Europe, mainly within Germany, until at least Feb. 27. While Lufthansa is not contemplating layoffs, it is talking with worker representatives about reducing overtime, encouraging employees to take leftover vacation now and moving up training. Lufthansa executives say the airline will report a small profit for 1990 as a whole because traffic rose sharply in November and December as a result of German reunification.

HEADLINE: Accounting Board Staff Cut

 BODY:
The Financial Accounting Foundation said yesterday that it would shut its two-member Washington office and dismiss four employees at its Norwalk, Conn., headquarters because of cost pressures.
"It is a move made strictly for reasons of economy," said Joseph LaGambina, the foundation's executive vice president, who estimates that the moves will save about $225,000 a year. Though the cuts will not solve the $1.4 million deficit projected for 1991, the foundation has "no plans at this time to make further personnel reductions," he said.
The foundation, which relies heavily on contributions from companies and accounting firms for its financing, runs the Financial Accounting Standards Board and the Government Accounting Standards Board. The two groups make most of the accounting rules for the private sector and for state and local government, respectively.
On Jan. 24, Mr. LaGambina disclosed that the foundation expected to report its third consecutive deficit once its 1990 results became final and that the organization would run deficits through 1995 unless its trustees acted to reverse those trends.
Mr. LaGambina said the foundation expected to cover the Washington scene from Connecticut.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Oil Lower in Light Trading; Crude for March at $21.14

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Oil prices slipped in light trading yesterday as the market continued to show restraint about war in the Persian Gulf and to react primarily to issues of supply and demand.
"Prices just kind of drifted lower," said Peter C. Beutel, an oil analyst at the Pegasus Econometric Group Inc. in Hoboken, N.J. 
 Crude oil for delivery in March settled at $21.14 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange, down 20 cents from Friday.
"Continuing high levels of Saudi and OPEC production and exports are putting the markets on a bit of the defensive," Mr. Beutel said. He also cited a "lack of shocking news" about the war or other world events for the market's moderation.
"People are continuing to move away from the psychological factors, and back to supply and demand," he said.
In London, North Sea Brent blend crude settled at $19.77 a barrel, down 5 cents a barrel, on the International Petroleum Exchange.
Mr. Beutel said the prices for March delivery of heating oil and natural gas slumped as unseasonably warm weather covered much of the central and Northeast portions of the nation.
Heating oil for March fell 0.48 cent, to 61.72 cents a gallon, although the price rose for contracts for delivery in May and later months.

HEADLINE: THE FEDERAL BUDGET: Government Risk;
To Insure S.& L. and Bank Deposits, $88 Billion

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4

 BODY:
A leading element in the $281 billion deficit that the Bush Administration projected today in the budget for the 1992 fiscal year is the $88 billion that planners say may be needed for the insurance that protects depositors in banks and savings and loan associations.
And given the poor state of the economy, what budget experts find even more worrisome is the far greater cost that could result if there was severe trouble in a variety of Federal programs that provide insurance, housing aid, financial assistance and other credit to farmers, veterans, students and many other categories of Americans. 
 Indeed, a large section of the budget issued today was devoted to discussion of the Government's "underwriting risks."
That section notes that among other things, the amount of Federal credit, credit assistance and insurance totaled $6.2 trillion at the end of the last calendar year, an increase of 8 percent from a year earlier and 113 percent from a decade earlier. With the decline of the nation's economy, and with credit remaining tight in many regions, the Government has become increasingly exposed to the risk of large losses from defaults in these programs.
"About half of all non-Federal borrowing," the budget says, "is assisted by Federal credit programs, Government-sponsored enterprises or Federal deposit insurance."
 
Savings and Loan Outlook
 For the savings and loan industry, the Administration has asked Congress to approve $76.1 billion for the 1992 fiscal year, on top of $84.6 billion that has already been spent since the Federal bailout of the industry began in 1989. Of the $76.1 billion to be spent next year, the Government hopes to recover about $47 billion when the assets of failed savings and loan associations now in Government hands are sold.
For banks, the White House estimates that "at least" $25 billion in increased contributions will be needed over the next five years to insure the solvency of the fund that protects deposits. The budget sent to Congress today forecasts that without the start-up of an increase in these contributions, which to this point have come entirely from the banking industry, the bank insurance fund managed by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation will be in the red by next year.
The Administration continues to hope that the industry can keep financing the fund alone and that a taxpayer bailout can be averted. Government officials have been meeting with bankers to come up with a plan that would completely rely on industry money, but no such plan has yet emerged.
"Reform is urgent," the budget says. Such reform will be proposed on Tuesday, when the Treasury Department announces its long-awaited recommendations for overhauling the banking system. The proposed changes, previously reported, would permit the merger of investment banks and commercial banks, eliminate restrictions on interstate banking and allow industrial enterprises to own banks.

HEADLINE: Spanish Town Is Largely Unmoved by B-52's

DATELINE: MORON DE LA FRONTERA, Spain, Feb. 2

 BODY:
The dark, bristling tails of 15 giant B-52's look strangely out of place against a backdrop of olive groves, green wheat fields and scattered cows. And except when the long-range bombers roar down the runway, the entire area is wrapped in silence.
But the isolation of the Moron air base, 250 miles southwest of Madrid and 15 miles from the nearest town, is apparently one reason why it was chosen by the United States and Spain as a staging post for B-52 bombing missions against Iraq. 
 Although the bombers have reportedly been flying out of here for at least 12 days, it was only three days ago that news of the operation broke in the Spanish press. And the Government still refuses to acknowledge Spain's distant role in the Persian Gulf war.
Reporters are banned from entering the huge air base, which was built here with American money in the 1950's, but a quiet country road comes within half a mile of the runway. At one point, a B-52 took off, the sound of its engine echoing for minutes as it seemed to head east toward the gulf.
The noise of the bombers does not reach the nearby town of Moron de la Frontera, but the increased militaryactivity at the base was soon reported back by the 30 or so locals who work there. They say that the number of military workers at the base has jumped from around 400 to 3,000.
While the presence of the B-52's in Spain produced headlines in Madrid, it has stirred little interest here. "We live mostly with our backs to it," Paco Guardado, the town's Deputy Mayor, said of the base. "We're not linked economically." In contrast, large antiwar demonstrations took place this weekend outside the Torrejon air base near Madrid and the Rota Naval Base on the southern coast, both of which have been used to provide logistical supportfor American forces in the gulf.
Although the United Left coalition is the only party to oppose the drive to evict Iraq from Kuwait, public opinion in Spain is strongly critical of the Government's decision to send three warships to the gulf region to help enforce the trade embargo against Iraq.
The Popular Party, the main conservative opposition party, has also attacked the Government for not making public its decision to allow B-52's to carry out raids on Iraq from here.
In Moron de la Frontera, some residents are beginning to recall the anti-American feelings stirred by the construction of the base over 30 years ago. The complaint then, though, was not political, but rather about the rowdiness of American soldiers who would visit the town.
The town's indirect involvement inthe gulf war, on the other hand, is stirring concerns about Spain's relations with the Arab world, not least because Moron de la Frontera, as a frontier town between Christian Spain and the Muslims who held southern Spain until 1492, became a symbol of coexistence between the two cultures and religions. "There is less sympathy toward the Americans than toward the Arabs today," said Julian Velez, a literature professor.
Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez, however, has shown no sign of wavering in his decision to allow the B-52's to fly from here. News of the bombing raids prompted the Madrid daily El Mundo to headline an editorial: "They have deceived us. We are at war." But citing "security and efficiency," the Government continued to refuse to discuss the issue publicly.

HEADLINE: Cuomo and Florio Paths Converging on Budgets

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Feb. 4

 BODY:
A year ago, Gov. Jim Florio of New Jersey and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York seemed to be the two faces of Democratic politics.
Mr. Florio was seen as the bold one, jamming sweeping tax increases through a reluctant State Legislature and revamping aid to education. He seemed to act first and worry about the political fallout later. 
 Mr. Cuomo, in contrast, was the careful one. He treated the state's fiscal problems gingerly, searching for ways to avoid both spending cuts and dramatic tax increases. At all times, he seemed keenly aware of the political pitfalls he was facing.
But having traveled in opposite directions for the last year, Mr. Cuomo and Mr. Florio today find themselves, somewhat surprisingly, moving closer together. Last week, when the two Governors presented bad-news budgets to their legislatures for the next fiscal year, some of the similarities between the plans were striking.
 
'In This Soup Together'
 Both Mr. Cuomo and Mr. Florio tried to extract substantial savings from state unions. Both sought to sell off state assets to muster much-needed cash. And both stressed the need for streamlining state government and making its operations more efficient in recessionary times.
"To a certain degree, they're both in this soup together now," said George Sternlieb, professor emeritus of urban and regional planning at Rutgers University.
To be sure, the differences between Mr. Cuomo's situation and Mr. Florio's are still stark. New York is facing a budget gap that, by Mr. Cuomo's estimates, totals $6 billion, or more than 20 percent of the tax revenues the state expects to collect.
This gap between expected revenues and spending plans, partly a result of the recession afflicting the entire Northeast, is also a result of policies pursued by Mr. Cuomo during his eight years in office. Last year, for example, the Governor used more than $1.5 billion in "one shot" revenues, including reserve funds, to balance his budget. These "one shots" filled a significant portion of the budget gap for the current fiscal year; somehow they must all be replaced for next year.
New Jersey is facing far less dire fiscal problems; its budget gap for the coming fiscal year is estimated at $800 million, or roughly 6 percent of the state's total revenues. The relatively modest size of the shortfall is largely a result of the enormous tax increases that Mr. Florio imposed last year. These included higher sales taxes and a sharp rise in income-tax rates for wealthier taxpayers.
 
Similar Forces at Work
 "As a straight budget matter, Florio's going to have a much easier go, because he got a head start," said Paul Dickstein, a former budget director of New York City.
Yet despite the fiscal differences, similar political forces are at work in the Empire and Garden States, and they have pulled Mr. Cuomo and Mr. Florio in similar directions.
"Florio and Cuomo started from different positions," said Steven D. Gold, of the Center for the Study of the States at the State University of New York. "But now we've had a convergence of the two states' tax systems. Right now, both Governors have proposed very serious budget cuts, including large numbers of layoffs."
As a result of the tax increases imposed by Mr. Florio last year, New Jersey, which historically was a low-tax state, has taken substantial steps toward becoming a high-tax state. New York has long had a higher tax burden than the average state, and it has stayed roughly even.
In both states, November's election was widely interpreted as a signal of voters' antipathy toward high taxes. This year, new taxes are regarded on both sides of the Hudson as a political anathema.
Mr. Florio, whose popularity has reached almost record lows, proposed no new taxes in the budget he announced last week, and it is widely agreed that new taxes are politically off limits for New Jersey officials this year.
Mr. Cuomo, fresh from his third gubernatorial victory in November, is not as politically vulnerable as Mr. Florio. In his budget presentation last week, he proposed a 10-cents-a-gallon increase in the gasoline tax and a delay in an income-tax cut scheduled for later this year. But while these tax proposals are substantial, totaling more than $1 billion, their size is dwarfed by the state's tremendous fiscal problems.
Both Governors proposed substantial spending cuts last week. And one of the prime targets was state workers, who are increasingly being portrayed as the enemy of government efficiency.
In New Jersey, Mr. Florio not only proposed laying off 2,400 state workers, but also recommended that the state renege on salary increases already included in current state contracts.
 
'New Kind of Democrat'
 In New York, Mr. Cuomo proposed laying off 7,000 workers, and set aside no money for raises for state workers whose contracts expire in March.
"I think what you're seeing is a new kind of Democrat who casts himself much more as a man of business who is not afraid to stand up to unions," Professor Sternlieb said.
Looking for ways to drum up cash without taxes, Mr. Cuomo and Mr. Florio last week both proposed elaborate schemes for selling off state assets. Mr. Cuomo wants to sell Aqueduct race track to the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey for $208 million. Mr. Florio would like to unload some state roads onto the New Jersey Turnpike Authority in return for a payment of $400 million.
Improved efficiency has become a popular slogan in this time of shrinking government resources, and it was invoked frequently in Trenton and Albany last week. Mr. Florio proposed merging 19 state departments into 16. Mr. Cuomo proposed eliminating dozens of offices and commissions.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
U.S., Allies Join in Buying The Dollar

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve and the central banks of the United States' major economic allies bought dollars in the foreign exchange market yesterday in an apparent effort to support the weakening currency and to signal that economic cooperation among the allies was still in force.
But the exact motivation for the concerted dollar buying was not completely clear. Instead of a primary concern about the dollar, the intervention could have been aimed at weakening the German mark and easing the downward pressure also being exerted on European currencies in the European Monetary System following the increase in German interest rates last week. 
 Or both goals could have figured in the intervention decision, possibly reflecting the first glimmer of a consensus that a continued decline of the dollar and rise of the mark is not good for the long-term health of the world economy.
 
'Restore Credibility'
 Traders were agreed, however, that the dollar buying by 10 central banks, including most European central banks, was an effort to offset the belief among many traders that the United States and its allies were having trouble cooperating economically. This belief was enhanced by the rate increase by Germany's central bank, the Bundesbank, on Thursday, a decision that ran against America's economic interest and that of Germany's allies in the European Community.
"I think they were trying to restore credibility to the Group of Seven," said James T. McGroarty, senior vice president of Greenwich Capital markets in Greenwich, Conn., referring to the United States and its six main economic allies, Japan, Germany, Britain, France, Italy and Canada. Joining in the intervention were Belgium, Spain and the Netherlands,
The dollar, which had fallen at the beginning of trading, rallied some after several rounds of dollar buying yesterday, but did not make up the losses. Its course from here will depend on how much longer central banks keep buying dollars and selling marks and what happens to interest rates. Some traders said the dollar buying would have to continue for some time to have any major impact on the dollar and other currencies.
In late trading yesterday, the dollar was at 1.4629 marks, a new post-1948 low but up from the 1.4570 level at which traders said the intervention began. The dollar closed at 1.4680 marks Friday, the previous low for the dollar. Against the yen, the dollar closed at 130.58, up from its daily low of 130.30 but down from 131.50 on Friday.
Some traders and economists said the dollar buying was aimed at preventing a sharp fall of the dollar after the Bundesbank raised two of its key interest rates a half a percentage point Thursday and the Federal Reserve cut its discount rate and moved to push down its Federal funds rate, the rate banks charge for overnight loans, by a similar half a percentage point Friday. It was the first round of major intervention since the central banks moved to stop a dollar rally last March.
Combined, both interest rate moves should weaken the dollar by making it less attractive for foreign investors. Since beginning to fall last summer on the expectations of lower interest rates in the United States, the dollar has already set several new record lows against the German mark and the Swiss franc and moved closer to post-World War II lows against other currencies.
But traders also pointed out that the dollar had not fallen very much on Friday or much more yesterday, when the intervention started.
This fact led some analysts, like Nicholas Sargen, director of bond research for Salomon Brothers in New York, to conclude that the aim of the move was to ease tensions in the European Monetary System, in which nine currencies are basically linked to the mark in set trading ranges.
Because of the strictures of the system, a rise in German rates combined with weakening currencies would make it very difficult for countries like France, England and Italy to lower their interest rates to stimulate their economies. For this reason, French officials, who want to lower rates, have been pushing for cooperation for a stronger dollar.
Mr. Sargen said that if the Bank of Japan, which was closed when the dollar intervention began yesterday, joins the dollar buying, he would think the aim of the effort might be broader.
In this case, the concerted and coordinated intervention shows that the United States and its allies finally may be focusing on some common reasons for stopping the decline of the dollar and the rise of the mark. Such a convergence of purpose, if it emerges, would be similar to the consensus that was finally reached in 1985 and led to the coordinated effort to knock the dollar from its then record highs in an effort to trim the United States trade deficit by encouraging foreign purchases of United States goods.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Rally Continues in Treasury Issues

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities moved higher and interest rates dipped again yesterday, continuing the big rally on Friday. Interest rates on the three-month and six-month securities auctioned yesterday fell to their lowest levels in nearly three years.
A drop in the value of the dollar, which fell to new lows against the German mark despite concerted efforts by major central banks to prop it up, had no visible impact in the credit markets. 
 Despite the firm tone, dealers expressed some caution about the Treasury refunding auctions, especially the $11 billion sale on Thursday of new 30-year bonds.
"The market is in excellent shape, but right now prices are the richest they have been in over a year and we are facing the biggest auctions ever," one government bond trader said.
"It all comes down to distribution," the trader added. "If the Street ends up owning a lot of this paper, especially the bond, the market will go down. And I think that some accounts will balk at buying bonds with a yield of just 8 percent."
While worries linger about the market's ability to absorb longer-term securities, demand for short-term Treasury bills was strong at yesterday's weekly auction.
Three-month bills were sold at an average discount rate of 5.97 percent, down sharply from the 6.22 percent average rate a week ago. It is the lowest rate on a three-month bill since the auction of April 25, 1988.
Bids on the new six-month bills produced an average discount rate of 5.94 percent, down from an average rate of 6.28 percent last week. It is the lowest rate on a new six-month bill since the sale on March 14, 1988.
The $34.5 billion refunding auctions begin today, with the sale of $12.5 billion worth of new three-year Treasury notes. On Wednesday, $11 billion of new 10-year notes are expected to be sold.
In when-issued trading late yesterday, the 3-year notes were offered at a price to yield 7.00 percent. The 10-year notes were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 7.82 percent. And the 30-year bonds were offered at a price to yield 8.01 percent.
The extremely weak employment data released on Friday, coupled with moves by the Federal Reserve Board shortly after to cut both the discount rate and the overnight Federal funds rate, virtually insured success for the refunding auctions.
But money managers said that bond yields might have to back up a bit to attract bids.
"A lot of money managers have been sitting on the sidelines, due to the war," said James Kochan, chief of fixed-income money management at R. W. Baird & Company in Milwaukee. "I think you will see very good support for the refunding if yields back up. And I don't think it will take much of a retreat to generate support for these issues."
Analysts said the Federal Reserve appeared to confirm that it has moved its target for the Federal funds rate to 6.25 percent, from 6.75 percent.
Yesterday, the Fed drained reserves from the banking system at a time when the funds rate was trading at 6 3/16 percent.
"I looked at the transaction as confirmation they are at 6.25 percent," said Michael J. Moran, chief economist at Daiwa Securities America Inc.
 
Dow's Rise a Concern
 The rise of one-tenth of a point in January unemployment, to 6.2 percent, re-emphasized the problems facing the economy, but some credit market participants said the stock market's recent rise -- the Dow Jones industrial average rose another 41.59 points yesterday -- was a source of concern. If the downturn is as pronounced as many in the bond market believe, stock prices should be going down, not up, they said.
Elliot Platt, chief economist at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, said there were sound reasons why the stock and bond markets were rallying simultaneously.
"If we are in a mild recession, I don't think it is inappropriate for both markets to be moving together," he said. "Like the bond market, the stock market had been very much undervalued because of the Mideast crisis. And both markets are looking at better inflation prospects."
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 3/4 percent 30-year bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 107 30/32 late yesterday, up more than 1/2 point, or more than $5 for each $1,000 face amount of securities, to yield 8.04 percent, down from 8.08 percent late Friday.
Among note issues, the 8 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 104 10/ 32, up 10/32, to yield 7.85 percent. And the 7 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 3/8, up 1/32, to yield 6.79 percent.
Issuance of new corporate debt was heavy again yesterday, following up on Friday's hectic pace, when 17 companies priced issues.
Among the issuers yesterday was the Union Camp Corporation, which offered $125 million worth of 20-year bonds through an underwriting syndicate led by the First Boston Corporation.
The 9 1/4 percent securities, which mature on Feb. 1, 2021, were priced at $100, or par, 1.22 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 3/4 percent 30-year bonds of 2020.
The securities are rated A-1 by Moody's Investors Service and A-plus by Standard & Poor's.
The McKesson Corporation offered $100 million worth of seven-year notes. The 8 5/8 percent notes, which mature on Feb. 1, 1998, were priced at $99.50 to yield 8.721 percent, one percentage point above the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7 7/8 percent seven-year notes at the time of pricing. Morgan Stanley & Company acted as lead manager for the underwriting. The securities are rated A-2 by Moody's and A-plus by Standard & Poor's.
In the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds, traders said that prices of most issues rose by 1/4 point to 1/2 point.
A late announcement that the General Motors Corporation had slashed its dividend had little impact on prices of outstanding General Motors securities, the traders said.
In the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds, prices of most widely quoted issues rose by about 1/4 point, according to market participants.
Following are the results of yesterday's auction of three-month and six-month Treasury bills:

HEADLINE: Bond Rating For New York Holds Steady

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
In a sign of confidence in New York City's plans for confronting its fiscal problems, the Standard & Poor's Corporation yesterday removed its "credit watch" on the city's bonds and reaffirmed the city's A- bond rating, which had been in jeopardy since last fall.
But Standard & Poor's, one of the nation's major credit-rating agencies, warned that the city still faced deep economic problems and said the bond rating could yet fall if the Dinkins administration should choose to balance its budgets with a combination of bond refinancing and wage deferrals, which would produce cash now while costing money later. 
 "If that happens, the rating will go down," said Hyman Grossman, a managing director of the rating agency. "The city understands that."
The city has already negotiated wage deferrals with some workers, and has discussed the possibility of refinancing bonds, though warily.
But so far, Mr. Grossman said Mayor David N. Dinkins and other city officials "are in the process of meeting the challenges in the fiscal-balance question in a fairly reasonable fashion" that justified maintaining the current rating.
Mr. Grossman said that "there are very few gimmicks" in the administration's plans to close a budget gap of $500 million for the fiscal year that ends June 30 and more than $2 billion for the following year.
City officials expressed pleasure and relief, since a lowered bond rating would force them to pay more in interest on the money they borrow for long-term projects. The city has been planning a regular bond sale of more than $1 billion for sometime this month, and city officials said the sale would proceed soon. "I think it's great," said First Deputy Mayor Norman Steisel. "We're pleased to be recognized for the fiscal prudence we have repeatedly demonstrated."
Standard & Poor's had placed the city on the credit watch Oct. 9, after a tumultuous week of fiscal news, in which Mr. Dinkins announced a 5.5 percent wage settlement with teachers, a major anticrime plan and, finally, the need to lay off as many as 15,000 city workers. Since then, the city has updated its budget, cutting services to cope with growing shortfalls, proposing hundreds of millions of dollars in new taxes and holding scores of meetings with the financial community in an effort to keep the bond rating stable.
Though the city has won that battle for the moment, it is facing more problems because of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's proposal to cut at least $400 million in state aid.
Mr. Grossman said his agency uses the "credit watch" as a temporary classification for periods from three to six months, while deciding whether to change the rating. He said it had affirmed the rating now as part of its annual review. The other major credit agency, Moody's Investors Service, has not changed its A rating on New York City's bonds.
Standard & Poor's decision to affirm the current rating was a major reward for Mr. Dinkins's efforts, but its warnings for the future were equally clear.
"We're certainly not out of the woods," said the city's Budget Director, Philip R. Michael. "We know that there's a lot of work in front of us."
Mr. Grossman said the rating agency was willing to accept the possibility of wage deferrals that might be needed to finance the city's labor settlements. But he said it could not tolerate the combined effects of such deferrals and major bond refinancings that could defer borrowing costs into the future.
Mr. Michael and Mr. Steisel said they were aware of Standard & Poor's concerns about bond-refinancing deals under discussion that could produce one-time cash infusions but longer-term costs. Several proposals have been under discussion for some time, but Mr. Michael said the city would approach such a transaction very cautiously.

HEADLINE: THE FEDERAL BUDGET: Proposals;
Winners and Losers: How Bush's Plan Would Affect Domestic Spending

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4

 BODY:
Here are President Bush's budget proposals for major domestic programs in the 1992 fiscal year:
 
Health
The President proposes spending of $525 billion, up 8 percent from the level in the 1991 fiscal year. Adjusted for inflation, the increase would be 3 percent. (Other increases listed here are not adjusted to account for inflation.) 
 Health and human service programs account for more than a third of the entire Federal budget, mostly because they finance Social Security, Medicare and Medicaid. The proposal reflects a cut of at least $23 billion in Medicare, which pays for the health care of 33 million elderly and disabled Americans.
Programs to prevent disease received the most attention in this year's proposals. Increases will be sought for breast cancer screening, immunization for measles and other childhood diseases, infant mortality prevention in the cities where it is highest, screening for lead poisoning, prevention of tuberculosis, and prevention of sexually transmitted diseases other than AIDS. For AIDS, almost no extra money will be sought in 1992.
 
Agriculture
Although the overall farm spending request is being held almost flat, around $55 billion, the Administration seeks a substantial increase for the food stamp program, the largest component of the agriculture budget.
The 1992 food stamp proposal is $19.7 billion, an increase of $1.4 billion over the 1991 estimate. But with the latest increases in unemployment, even that may be too low. The Administration says it may ask for $200 million to $1.5 billion more; agriculture officials say the decision will be determined by economic circumstances later in the year. The maximum food stamp benefit for a family of four is expected to reach $370 a month, an increase of $18 over the maximum benefit in 1991.
Another major change in the farm budget is a sharp increase in projected spending for export subsidies to fight those of the European Community, which is selling commodities at discounts to get rid of growing food stocks. The budget seeks $1.2 billion in the 1992 fiscal year for the Export Enhancement Program, about $300 million more than projected spending in 1991 and nearly four times what was spent in 1990.
 
Transportation
With a proposed increase of 6 percent over its 1991 budget, to $33.6 billion, the Department of Transportation is seeking its largest increase in spending authority since 1985. Highway spending would rise 4 percent and urban mass transit spending 3 percent.
The Administration wants to broaden the scope of its highway program while shifting some of the costs to the states. Under the budget plan, the Federal Government would maintain an interconnected system of "national highways," 150,000 miles of roads of the greatest significance, including the 43,000-mile Interstate system. Other national highways would be selected after consulting with the states. The idea is to bring those roads up to the standards of the Interstate system.
The department's budget also includes $485 million for Amtrak. This is the first time in seven years that the department has requested an increase for the federally subsidized passenger rail service.
The Federal Aviation Administration would receive $4.5 billion, a 10 percent increase. The new money would permit the hiring of 450 new air traffic controllers and 100 aviation safety inspectors, among other personnel.
 
Education
The Administration proposes spending $29.6 billion for the Education Department, an increase of $2.5 billion, or about 9 percent, over the fiscal year 1991. Most of the new spending would be part of a coming legislative proposal that could be modified by the newly named Secretary of Education, Lamar Alexander, who awaits Senate confirmation.
One closely watched proposal would set aside $200 million for grants to local school districts and states that provide parents with a choice of schools for their children, including private and parochial schools.
The department also proposed changing the structure of the Federal education scholarships known as Pell Grants to direct them more toward students from poorer families. The maximum grant would increase to $4,200 for students whose families earn less than $20,000 a year; families making more would qualify for lower sums.
 
Cities and States
Total proposed spending by the Department of Housing and Urban Development is down slightly from the 1991 level, to $25.6 billion from $27 billion. Housing Secretary Jack F. Kemp said the decrease did not signal less emphasis on public housing, but rather a cut in planned spending for programs like mortgage insurance.
Mr. Kemp said the budget for new housing programs would actually increase, from $15.3 billion to $17.5 billion. Much of the new money would be used to help public housing tenants buy their homes, he said, adding that H.U.D. was also asking for $918 million extra in its 1991 budget for that purpose.
The Administration plans to reduce the Community Development Block Grant program by $300 million, from $3.2 billion, and to channel the grants through the states rather than giving them directly to the cities. Officials of cities have expressed dismay at that idea.
 
Energy
The Administration requested $18.6 billion for the Department of Energy, $900 million more than this year's level.
Programs to improve technical research and education would receive considerably more money. Funds for fundamental scientific research would increase more than 15 percent, to $2.67 billion from $2.31 billion. Much of the increase would go to the Superconducting Supercollider, a giant particle accelerator to be built in Texas. Spending on it would increase from $242.9 million to $533.7 million.
Almost half the Energy Department's budget, $8.1 billion, would go toward the system of production factories, laboratories and testing sites for nuclear weapons. For the first time in decades, the budget for producing nuclear warheads would shrink, to $2.71 billion from $2.88 billion. Similar cuts are proposed in the manufacture of nuclear materials for bombs, dropping the budget in that program to $1.87 billion from $1.95 billion.
 
Space
The Bush Administration continued its support for the space program by seeking $14.7 billion for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, an increase of $1.2 billion that would include starting a new family of rockets to lift heavy payloads.
NASA and the Air Force would be authorized to spend $175 million each to develop a new launching system by the end of the decade. The rocket system, which would take over some of the work of the space shuttle and the current generation of disposable rockets, would eventually cost about $10 billion.
The Administration also proposes almost $2 billion to continue development of a space station. Congress has ordered that the station be redesigned and scaled down before its first elements are put into orbit in 1995. The budget also includes almost $1 billion, a 24 percent increase, for NASA's "Mission to Planet Earth," part of an effort by several agencies to study global environmental change.
 
Environment
Environmental programs fared relatively well in the President's proposal, with the Environmental Protection Agency's operating budget rising from $2.1 billion in the fiscal year 1991 to $2.33 billion in 1992.
The plan would provide extra funds for the E.P.A. to carry out the far-reaching amendments to the Clean Air Act passed by Congress last year. The Administration also wants to spend more money to protect ecological systems like the Great Lakes and coastal areas, and to expand its scientific research, particularly into the causes and effects of global warming.
The Interior Department's budget would provide more money for protection and rehabilitation of national wildlife refuges and national parks, with emphasis on preserving Civil War battlegrounds. In all, the department's proposed outlays in 1992 are $8.7 billion, up from an estimated $8.5 billion in 1991.
 
Justice
The Justice Department is seeking a budget of $10.6 billion, a 14 percent increase over 1991. A significant part would go to enforcement of laws on drug trafficking and white-collar crime, notably prosecution of fraud in connection with the savings and loan industry.
Deputy Attorney General William P. Barr said part of the department's drug strategy was to place more resources in smaller cities and rural areas, which he said had not been given enough attention.
The task force of Federal agencies trying to break sophisticated international trafficking organizations would receive an increase of 20 percent, from this year's level of $335 million.
The department is seeking $1.74 billion to operate the nation's prisons. The Federal prison population, which was 25,000 in 1981, is now about 60,000 and is expected to rise to 100,000 by 1995.
 
Arts and Humanities
The Administration proposes to spend $833 million for activities that contribute to "preserving America's heritage." This is an increase of $65 million, or 8.5 percent, over 1991.
Proposed increases include 15.5 percent for the National Gallery of Art and 14.8 percent for the Smithsonian Institution. The only Federal agency whose proposed budget remains unchanged is the National Endowment for the Arts, at $174 million. The President proposes that the National Endowment for the Humanities receive $178 million, an increase of nearly 5 percent, with a special emphasis on the agency's educational programs.
In the past the arts endowment has received more money than the humanities endowment, but the gap has narrowed in recent years. This is the first time the Administration has offered a larger budget for humanities.
The budget request of $357 million for the Smithsonian includes $16.3 million for the new National Museum of the American Indian.
 
Labor
Amid signs of a deepening recession, the Labor Department has requested a $178 million increase for the administration of the unemployment insurance program. The department is also asking Congress for $100 million more in the current fiscal year to run the unemployment benefits program nationwide. Under current budget rules, that $100 million increase would have to be offset by cuts in other domestic programs. The benefits paid to the unemployed are financed by state taxes, but the program's administrative costs are the responsibility of the Federal Government.
 
Research
The Administration is proposing to spend $71.3 billion for research and development, an 8 percent increase, with the greatest amount, more than $42 billion, going to military research. The $71 billion is divided among the budgets of a number of departments, including Defense, Energy and Health and Human Services.
The National Science Foundation, which devotes 70 percent of its budget to nonmedical basic research at colleges and universities, would get a 13 percent increase, to $1.9 billion. The basic research budget of the National Institutes of Health would be increased 6 percent, to $4.6 billion.

HEADLINE: A Proposal To Limit F.D.I.C.

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4

 BODY:
In an apparent slap at the nation's senior banking regulator, L. William Seidman, the Bush Administration will recommend that his agency lose its authority to supervise banks, senior Government officials said today.
The recommendation would strip the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation of its role as a regulator of the nation's more than 12,000 banks, but the agency would continue to insure deposits. The recommendation is scheduled to be announced on Tuesday, when the Treasury Department discloses the details of its long-awaited proposal to Congress to overhaul the banking system. 
 It has already been disclosed that the proposed legislation will include a plan that permits the mergers of investment banks and commercial banks, eliminates barriers to interstate banking, alllows industrial enterprises to own banks and imposes some limitations on bank insurance coverage.
 
Political Strength
 Mr. Seidman's strong standing on Capitol Hill as head of the F.D.I.C. was acknowledged less than two years ago when he was named the chairman of the Resolution Trust Corporation, putting him in charge of the day-to-day administration of the bailout of the savings and loan industry. He continues to enjoy strong support in Congress, which may doom the Administration's proposal to reduce the F.D.I.C.'s power.
Last summer, long-simmering disagreements between Mr. Seidman and some senior officials at the White House led to a move to try to put pressure on him to retire before his term expires in October of this year. Mr. Seidman has said he intends to leave before the end of his term but he has never set a departure date.
The tart-tongued Mr. Seidman had particularly upset the White House chief of staff, John H. Sununu, when he ridiculed a proposal to have bank customers pay insurance premiums based on the size of their accounts. Mr. Seidman called the idea a reverse-toaster theory, alluding to some banks' practice of giving gifts to new customers.
As chairman of the F.D.I.C., Mr. Seidman has authority over more than 12,000 banks, although the largest ones also fall under the scrutiny of the Federal Reserve Board, which regulates bank holding companies, and the Comptroller of the Currency, which regulates nationally chartered institutions.
The F.D.I.C. is, however, the sole Federal regulator of about 7,500 state-chartered banks. Under the Treasury Department's plan, the supervision of state-chartered banks receiving Federal insurance coverage would be shifted to the Federal Reserve Board. And the Fed and the Comptroller would share authority over bank holding companies, depending upon whether their subsidiaries are state or federally chartered.
Mr. Seidman said in an interview this evening that he did not want to comment about the proposal until he had a chance to study it. He has long argued for a single independent regulator of the nation's banks and savings and loans.
"If what they are proposing is an insurance agency that has no power to protect the insurance fund, then they're asking for trouble," he said. "But I don't think they are trying to personalize their policy to fit any feelings they may have about me."
 
A Clash Is Expected
 Some industry experts said a battle between Mr. Seidman and the Administration was virtually assured.
"I'd be amazed if Seidman doesn't fight this," said Kenneth Guenther of the Independent Bankers Association, which represents community banks.
The Treasury Department is expected to say on Tuesday that the measure is not intended as a slight to Mr. Seidman but is an effort to reduce the redundant layers of regulation.
 
A Limited Role
 Under the Treasury's proposal, the F.D.I.C. would be relegated to administering the deposit insurance program and protecting its fund from losses. It would have access to the confidential bank reports prepared by examiners and would be able to investigate banks if it received permission from other regulators working under the Treasury Department.
The Treasury Department's plan also calls for the creation of a Federal Banking Agency from the merger of the Comptroller's office and another agency, the Office of Thrift Supervision, which was created by the 1989 bailout legislation to regulate savings associations. The new entity would be a division of the Treasury Department.
In effect, the proposal would have two regulators of banks and savings and loans: the new agency within Treasury and the Federal Reserve.
Most of the ideas presented in the regulatory reorganization to be proposed on Tuesday were initially suggested in 1984 by a task force on the regulation of financial services that was led by George Bush, who was then the Vice President.
 
A Surprise Move
 Mr. Seidman continues to exert considerable influence in Washington, and the decision to try to take away much of his authority comes as something of a surprise.
Last week he scored an important victory when he persuaded Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady not to propose severe restrictions on deposit insurance, which now covers all accounts up to $100,000.
Administration officials had told industry representatives that they were preparing to recommend that coverage be limited to one account per individual of up to $100,000 systemwide, in addition to a second retirement account of up to the same amount. The proposal was opposed by Mr. Seidman, who said it would drive money away from many banks, particularly smaller ones.
Late last week, the F.D.I.C. sent a study to the Treasury Department that estimated that enforcing such a proposal could cost as much as $1 billion annually.
 
Limiting Coverage
 The report was described by Treasury officials as a major factor in persuading Mr. Brady to abandon the strict limitations in favor of a proposal to limit insurance to one account of $100,000, plus one retirement account, at each bank where a depositor has money.
The Administration's plan will call for the elimination of a loophole in the current restrictions that allows an individual to get coverage of more than $100,000 at a single bank by using various types of joint accounts.
Mr. Seidman has been on the defensive in recent weeks, as both the White House and the Congressional Budget Office have issued reports estimating that the F.D.I.C. fund that insures bank deposits will be insolvent within the next two years. Last week, he took issue with those forecasts, predicting that the fund would remain solvent, assuming the recession is mild.

HEADLINE: Productivity Flat Over All In 4th Quarter

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4

 BODY:
The productivity of America's non-farm workers was practically unchanged for the fourth quarter, growing at an annual rate of one-tenth of 1 percent, but for the year it fell eight-tenths of 1 percent, the worst decline since 1982, the Government said today. Coupled with the 1989 drop of seven-tenths of 1 percent, it was the first back-to-back reversal in a decade. These figures are not seasonally adjusted.
Labor costs continued to rise as the tumbling economy forced businesses to trim working hours drastically in the final months of 1990, the Labor Department report showed. 
 "What we have here is the worst of both possible worlds -- the economy was sinking into recession at the same time labor costs were accelerating," said David Jones, an economist with Aubrey G. Lanston & Company.
 
Link to Standard of Living
 Increasing productivity, or getting more worker output per hour on the job, is considered vital to increasing the nation's standard of living without inflation.
But the latest figures, Mr. Jones said, show that the United States is continuing to lose its competitive edge in international markets and threaten a long-term reduction in living standards "unless one of two things happens -- either we sharply improve the quality of our labor force through education, or sharply improve savings and investment in new plants and equipment."
Allen Sinai, chief economist at the Boston Company, said: "Our ability to produce more goods and services does determine the pie that's available to us. That pie grew very slowly in 1990 and is going to shrink in 1991."
 
Hours Cut 2.7% in 4th Quarter
 The report showed that during the final three months of 1990, the nation's businesses trimmed the working hours of their employees at an annual rate of 2.7 percent -- the largest falloff since the depths of the 1981-82 recession.
It was the second quarterly decline in the number of hours worked, a normal consequence of recession as businesses trim payrolls.
In the manufacturing sector, productivity declined at an annual rate of 2.4 percent in the October-December period -- the largest drop since 1981. Meanwhile, factories trimmed their hours by 6.4 percent.
The decline in manufacturing hours was the steepest since the final quarter of 1982, when hours fell 8.6 percent, the Government said.
For all of 1990, manufacturing productivity increased 3.0 percent and hours worked fell 2.1 percent, the report said.
Meanwhile, unit labor costs, a key gauge of future price inflation, rose 4.3 percent for the year, well above the 3.9 percent increase of 1989. Hourly labor costs rose 3.5 percent for the year, also above the 3.2 percent increase of 1989.

HEADLINE: THE FEDERAL BUDGET: News Analysis
Tactics and Numbers;
A Budget Intended to Counter an Image Of a White House That Courts the Rich

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4

 BODY:
In the budget they sent to Congress today, President Bush and his advisers tried to neutralize the strongest political point the Democrats have developed in the Bush Presidency: the argument that this Administration favors the rich at the expense of the poor and the middle class.
Mr. Bush reintroduced his pet proposal to cut the tax on capital gains, a measure that would mostly benefit affluent taxpayers. 
 But in an attempt to knock the Democrats off stride, the President offered several modest proposals to limit the Government subsidies that well-to-do people receive through Medicare, student aid, farm price supports, school lunches and payments to veterans' survivors.
In some instances the money, no more than a few billion dollars a year, would be redirected to the poor; in other cases the proposals would represent overall cuts in programs.
Democrats gained considerable advantage in last fall's budget negotiations by maintaining that a cut in the capital gains tax would result in a windfall for the wealthy. The portrait of the President as a patron of fat cats seemed to take hold to an unusual degree, and Mr. Bush's popularity fell sharply.
 
A Clear Political Goal
 Richard G. Darman, director of the Office of Management and Budget, made no secret of the Administration's political goal in a television interview Sunday on the NBC News program "Meet the Press."
"It will be somewhat ironic," Mr. Darman said, "if the Democrats, who are expressing concerns about fairness, are reluctant to reduce the subsidies for the wealthiest Americans."
At a news conference today, Mr. Darman conceded that the proposals reducing subsidies to the well-to-do were "relatively modest," noting that they were worth "only a small number of billions" of dollars.
"We thought, nonetheless, it would be valuable to get this issue of principle on the public agenda," Mr. Darman said, "to start the debate, to get at least a toehold here, and then, over time, presumably one could target even better on the poor."
Democrats expressed skepticism about the proposals and the motives, and the chances of enactment of any of them seemed slight given the Democratic majorities in the House and the Senate. Representative Leon E. Panetta of California, chairman of the House Budget Committee, accused the President of "wanting to target the wealthy elderly who are ill," while helping others with his cut in the capital gains tax.
 
The Main Proposals
 These are Mr. Bush's main proposals to limit Government subsidies received by upper-income Americans:
*Single Medicare beneficiaries with annual incomes above $125,000 and couples with incomes of more that $150,000 would have to pay $63.60 per person more each month in premiums for insurance against doctors' bills and outpatient expenses. The monthly premium is now scheduled to be $31.80 a month next year. About 500,000 beneficiares out of a total of 33 million would be affected.
*Grants and loans to college students would be somewhat redirected so that a larger proportion would go to those from families with incomes of less than $10,000 a year, and the separate loan program for students studying to be health professionals would be rewritten so that only low-income students would be eligible.
*Farmers with nonfarm incomes above $125,000 would no longer be entitled to crop support payments.
*The rules for subsidized school lunches for elementary and high school students would be changed so that those from poor families would get more of a subsidy and those from well-off families would get less.
*The benefits paid to survivors of military personnel who die in the service or as a result of a service-connected injury or illness would be standardized at the level now paid to the survivors of staff sergeants. Under current law, the higher a person's rank the more benefits his survivors receive.
Poor families would get higher subsidies under changes in the student loan and school lunch programs, but changes in the other programs, while limiting subsidies to those with higher incomes, would not improve the benefits to the poor.
The President's capital gains proposal will probably stay on the shelf for most of this year. Mr. Bush virtually guaranteed that when he announced in his State of the Union Message last week that he had asked Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, to head a group to study how to calculate the cost and benefits of such a tax cut.
 
The 'Fairness' Issue
 No deadline was given for the group to report its findings. But whatever the Greenspan group says, Democrats will surely resume their attacks around the "fairness" issue if Mr. Bush tries once again to push the capital gains issue in earnest.
Economists disagree over whether a lower capital gains tax -- the tax on profits from investments -- raises or lowers revenue and whether it helps the overall economy. But they agree that most of the direct benefits go to the wealthiest taxpayers, since they hold most of the investments.
The Congressional Joint Tax Committee has calculated that about two-thirds of the benefits of a lower capital gains tax would go to taxpayers with incomes above $200,000, and about four-fifths to those with incomes above $100,000. The average tax bill of someone with an income of more than $200,000 would be cut by $15,000.
The Administration's two other main tax proposals -- tax-free savings accounts and penalty-free withdrawals from individual retirement accounts to make the down payment on a first home -- would not be of much benefit to poor families.
But the proposals could put the Democrats on the defensive if they ever came to a vote. Still, given the nature of the Democratic Congress, the chances are remote that the measures will ever reach the stage where votes must be cast.

HEADLINE: Hills Department Stores Files for Chapter 11 Bankruptcy

BYLINE: By ISADORE BARMASH

 BODY:
Hills Department Stores Inc., the nation's fifth-largest discount retailer, filed for protection from its creditors yesterday after failing to gain approval from banks and bondholders for a refinancing plan.
Hills, which is based in Canton, Mass., and some of its affiliates made the filing under the Chapter 11 provisions of the Bankruptcy Code in the United States Bankruptcy Court for the Southern District of New York. 
 Hills operates more than 200 stores in 14 states, mostly in the Midwest, selling apparel and houshold items. It listed assets and liabilities of about $1 billion each as of Dec. 31, 1990.
The company is profitable on an operating basis but has been struggling to meet debt and interest obligations and has reported losses over the last year. Since 1989, it has undergone a $425 million refinancing, the signing of a $325 million working capital agreement and the acquisition of 33 Gold Circle discount stores in Ohio and New York from Federated Department Stores Inc.
 
Blocked by Creditors
 John C. Brouillard, Hills's president and chief operating officer, said in a telephone interview yesterday that the company had been unable to convince its creditors on a refinancing plan.
"We put forth a number of proposals but they had to meet the requirements of various types of creditors, and that's where we got bogged down," he said. He added that the company was also hurt by the weakened economy, strong price competition in electronics and appliances and disappointing sales at the Gold Circle stores.
"Our sales in those stores were under our plan," Mr. Brouillard said. "They catered to different customers in different markets from us, and we had difficulty adapting to that." As to competition, he added, "The economy was much more difficult than any competition we encountered."
Hills said yesterday that Chemical Bank had agreed to provide $250 million in "debtor in possession" financing. Under such financing, the lender becomes a creditor with high priority for repayment.
Mr. Brouillard said he believed that the loan would cover the company's current operating cash needs and that it would take the focus off the financial restructuring.
Last Nov. 26, Hills reported a 6 percent rise in sales, to $1.5 billion, in the nine months ended Nov. 3 over the corresponding period in 1989. But the company's losses grew to $36.1 million in the period, from a loss of $22.4 million in the comparable nine months of 1989.
That announcement coincided with the resignation of Stephen A. Goldberger as chairman, president and chief executive officer and the promotion to president of Mr. Brouillard, who had been executive vice president and chief financial officer.
Last month, Hills said it would close 28 of its 214 stores and would take a $125 million write-off in the fourth quarter, which ended last month. Yesterday, Mr. Brouillard said the final quarter would probably show an operating profit, but that there would still be a net loss compared with the quarter a year earlier.
 
Banks Owed Millions
 Hills's largest unsecured financial creditors and the sums they are owed are: the Bankers Trust Company, New York, $110 million; the State Street Bank and Trust Company, Boston, $91.9 million, as trustee under 14 1/8 percent senior subordinated debentures, and $51.2 million as trustee under 14 5/8 percent subordinated debentures; the Fleet National Bank, Providence, R.I., $86.6 million, as trustee under 13 1/2 percent senior notes, and the Westinghouse Credit Corporation, Pittsburgh, $50 million.
The two largest unsecured merchandise creditors are the Handleman Company, a supplier of recorded music and books in Troy, Mich., $7.1 million, and Hasbro Inc., a toy maker in Pawtucket, R.I., $3.26 million.
Hills's shares dropped 12.5 cents each, to 62.5 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday..
The Hills Chapter 11 filing followed a similar action last April by Ames Department Stores Inc., the country's fourth-largest discounter behind the K Mart Corporation, Wal-Mart Stores Inc. and the Target Stores of the Dayton Hudson Corporation. Ames took on high debt and encountered financial difficulties when it purchased 300 Zayre discount stores and found that many were performing under expectations. But Ames recently reported that it had a profitable December.
