HEADLINE: G.M. Cuts Dividend Almost 50%

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Feb. 4

 BODY:
The General Motors Corporation, citing war and a weak economy, slashed its dividend nearly in half today and announced cost-cutting measures, including reductions in its salaried work force and its capital spending plans.
G.M., the nation's largest car maker, was the first of the Big Three to trim its quarterly payout, dropping it by 46 percent, to 40 cents a share from 75 cents, but analysts predict that Ford and Chrysler will soon follow suit. 
 The domestic auto makers have faced slumping sales for more than a year. But recent falling sales caused by the war, coupled with the need to spend aggressively on new vehicles, have made money tight for all of them.
G.M.'s move is expected to save it about $840 million annually. The company pays about $2 billion a year to holders of its common stock.
 
Stock Down to $35.25
 G.M.'s announcement, after a board meeting in New York, came shortly after the New York Stock Exchange closed. Its shares slipped 87.5 cents each, to $35.25, on a day when many market averages surged to their highest levels so far this year.
Credit rating agencies have warned that they may downgrade the Big Three's debt securities, making it more expensive to borrow money, unless they conserve resources.
"For G.M. to be doing this with interest rates and oil prices on the way down, the company is saying, We're still not competitive with the imports, and this isn't going to be a short recession and business as usual when Saddam Hussein is defeated," said Ronald A. Glantz, an automotive analyst for Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. in San Francisco.
 
Car Sales Off 21.2%
 For the first 20 days of January, G.M. car sales were off 21.2 percent, and some analysts expect G.M. later this month to post a loss of as much as $1.4 billion for the fourth quarter, which would be its biggest operating loss ever.
Robert C. Stempel, G.M.'s chairman, said directors remained confident of the company's "underlying financial strength and future prospects." But he said directors "felt it was imperative at this time to recognize the economic impact that the turmoil in the Middle East and the recession have had on consumer confidence, and on the highly competitive automotive markets, particularly in North America."
Mr. Stempel, stressing the need for General Motors to be more competitive, said he still expected the national economy to start recovering "sometime in 1991," But he said, "We cannot rely on an eventual economic turnaround alone to secure an adequate financial return for our stockholders over the longer term."
 
'Extremely Difficult'
 It was the first time G.M. had reduced a cash dividend since the second quarter of 1980, and only the third time in 35 years; Mr. Stempel called the latest cut "an extremely difficult decision."
G.M. also raised the dividend on its class E shares, representing the Electronic Data Systems Corporation subsidiary, to 16 cents a share from 14 cents; the auto maker retained the 18-cent-a-share dividend on its class H shares, representing its Hughes Aircraft and Delco Electronics unit.
For G.M.'s salaried automotive work force, totaling about 100,000 in North America, Mr. Stempel also had bad news. The company said it planned to cut 15,000 jobs during the next three years -- 6,000 this year and 9,000 in 1992 and 1993.
General Motors said it would try to accomplish the reductions through attrition and retirements "to the greatest extent possible" but did not rule out stronger measures like buyouts or dismissals.
Since 1986, G.M. has reduced its white-collar work force from about 133,000 to its current level.
Another part of G.M.'s cost-saving program will be substantial price reductions on components and materials that the company will be seeking from its suppliers. Robert T. O'Connell, the chief financial officer, said G.M. wanted by 1993 to cut $2 billion annually from component and material expenses that he estimated were $25 billion to $35 billion.
Mr. O'Connell said G.M. would provide engineering expertise to suppliers to help them reduce costs, and thus lower prices. But eventually the auto maker is seeking to deal with fewer suppliers on a longer-term basis, he said.
Harvey Heinbach, an analyst for Merrill Lynch & Company in New York, said, "Before they go out and ask for cuts from suppliers and employes, they are asking shareholders to share in the suffering."
 
Executives to Be Affected
 G.M. executives will not escape either. The company said it would not pay "incentive compensation in the form of restricted stock units" in 1990, the annual bonus that in some cases may exceed regular salary, "except in a few cases where modest awards were made to recognize outstanding results at selected subsidiary units." Mr. O'Connell said the exceptions did not include top executives. G.M. is also trimming its contributions to white-collar stock savings plans.
For the next four years, capital spending will be lowered by about $500 million a year, to about $7 billion annually, G.M. said. But the company said it would try to maintain its outlays on engineering expenses "in recognition of the importance of implementing G.M.'s aggressive forward product program."
But Mr. O'Connell conceded that some "minor programs" might be canceled. In the current year, G.M. plans to introduce nine new car and six new truck models.
 
Seeking More Efficiency
 While General Motors has been closing factories for several years to increase capacity utilization, no shutdowns are anticipated that have not been announced, Mr. O'Connell said. But G.M. will try to utilize its plants 100 percent, he said, and will seek to become more efficient, through such efforts as three-shift operations, an idea being tried in Europe. "We're discussing it with the union and we hope to get there," he said.
Mr. Stempel said G.M. had conducted "an intense review" of business practices and would pursue certain modern manufacturing techniques more aggressively. Among the highest priorities, he said, are "design for manufacture," which reduces cost and raises quality by designing parts that are easier to handle and assemble.

Ford Outsold in Europe

 
DETROIT, Feb. 4 (AP) -- For the first time, the General Motors Corporation has outsold the Ford Motor Company in Europe for a full year. G.M. said last week that it sold 1.56 million cars in Europe last year, and Ford said it sold 1.51 million. Some of Ford's problems involved the bumpy European introduction of the new Escort model, hampered by a seven-week strike at Ford of Europe's Halewood assembly plant in England.

HEADLINE: More Banks Cut Prime

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Several more American banks cut their prime lending rates by half a percentage point, to 9 percent, yesterday. They include Chase Manhattan Bank, Manufacturers Hanover Trust, Chemical Bank, Bank of New York and Mellon Bank. On Friday several banks, including Citibank, cut their prime to 9 percent minutes after the Federal Reserve dropped its discount rate to 6 percent, from 6 1/2 percent. The discount rate is the interest the Fed charges to member banks. When the rate is lowered, so are the banks' cost of funds, enabling them to trim the interest they charge.

HEADLINE: AMERICAN REVIVAL IN MANUFACTURING SEEN IN U.S. REPORT

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
In the last recession, America's aging industrial heartland was widely considered to be incapable of saving itself. But a Government report issued yesterday suggests that the Rust Belt has staged a renaissance on the factory floor.
Thanks to a wrenching contraction in payrolls and plants, manufacturing productivity -- the measure of output per hours worked -- climbed at a record rate from 1979 to 1990. Industrial productivity growth, which trailed that of the United States' trading partners in the 1970's, rebounded to equal their pace in the 1980's. 
 What is more, factories making everything from chemicals to computers now account for a robust 23.3 percent of the nation's gross national product, or the total cost of goods and services sold. According to the Commerce Department report, that figure is up from 20 percent in 1982, the post-World War II low, and matches the level of output achieved in the 1960's when American factories hummed at a feverish clip.
 
Economists' Differing Views
 "I am not surprised at what Commerce found," said Robert Lawrence, an economist at the Brookings Institution, who has argued that the United States manufacturing base had been revitalized in the late 1980's. "Fears of de-industrialization were overblown."
But Lawrence Mishel, research director of the Economic Policy Institute in Washington, who is regarded as the economist most responsible for getting the Government to conduct the remeasurement of manufacturing output, said yesterday: "I expected manufacturing's share to have shrunk. These partial revisions have rewritten history, but not as much as I expected. It is still my view that we have a competitiveness problem."
The implications of the Commerce Department report together with an analysis of factory productivity by the Bureau of Labor Statistics are that the nation's industrial base is better able to compete globally and participate fully in a rebound from recession.
Additionally, some analysts suggested that manufacturing never needed to be sheltered with costly subsidies or import protection. Indeed, one of the most striking occurrences in the last half of the 1980's was that the United States' share of exports by industrial countries rebounded. That share is now larger than it was in 1980, the previous peak year.
 
Implication for Trade Deficit
 The change is crucial because most economists agree that the best measure of competitiveness is how well a country's products perform in world markets. It also suggests that the dollar does not have to fall a great deal more for imports to decline and exports to rise and correct the chronic trade deficit.
The Government's report, which will be published in the latest issue of the Commerce Department's Survey of Current Business, remeasured the amount of goods turned out by United States factories during the last decade. It was undertaken in response to a long-simmering debate among some of the nation's leading economists. As the Reagan Administration heralded the recovery in the last half of the 1980's, some Democratic economists insisted that the Government's methods for measuring output yielded inflated results and misleading statistics about factory worker productivity.
Separately yesterday, the Government reported that overall productivity was flat for the fourth quarter of 1990 and down for the full year. Factory productivity, however, dipped in the fourth quarter but was up sharply for the year.
 
Previous Peak Reached in 1966
 The Commerce Department report showed that manufacturing shrank more in the early 1980's than had been estimated at the time but roared back to a level that matched the previous peak, reached in 1966.
A related report by the Bureau of Labor Statistics showed that manufacturing productivity grew at a 3.6 percent rate during the 1980's, almost three times as fast as in the 1970's.
The Commerce report reflects a growing consensus among many economists that the long-term problem in the nation's economy is not dilapidated, inefficient factories but productivity growth among the white-collar serivce sector. Eight out of 10 United States workers are employed outside manufacturing, and stagnant productivity growth in those fields has lowered overall output. White-collar productivity was flat in the last decade..
 
Two Million Fewer Jobs
 Between 1979 and 1989, industrial production rose by more than a third, but the factory work force shrank. There are 19 million manfuacturing workers now, versus 21 million in 1979 before the two back-to-back recessions of the early 1980's.
The stable output share and shrinking employment share reflect the fact that United States factories staged an almost unbelievable productivity revival. United States industrial productivity was dragging along at 1.4 percent of the gross national product in the 1970's, or about a third of the pace at which United States' trading partners were recording gains in hourly worker efficiencies. Now, it is growing at 3.6 percent a year, just as fast as the average pace of United States trading partners.
Michael J. Boskin, the chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, said: "With advances in productvity, flexibility of our market economy and proper economic policies, our economy will come out of recession with sustained growth in the 90's. On balance, manufacturing will do well."
One conclusion from the report is that United States manufacturing is more resilient than many people had thought.
In the 1980's, some economists argued that America's manufacturing base was crumbling. The Reagan Administration pointed to data showing that while there were many fewer workers in factories, manufacturing still held the same share of gross national product that it did in the 1960's -- around 21 percent to 23 percent. They insisted that factory efficiency was growing at a post-World War II record.
 
Challenge by Economists
 Those economists who believed that the nation's industrial base was weakening argued that the Government's statistical techniques for calculating output were overstating the share of G.N.P. produced by the manufacturing sector.
Yesterday's report, the culmination of a two-and-a-half-year effort to come up with better estimates, showed that manufacturing's share of G.N.P. fell from 1979 to 1982, to its post-World War II low, and had not fully recovered by 1987. But by 1988, the share of G.N.P. matched that of 1979, and by 1990 exceeded it.
Further, manufacturing productivity grew even faster than earlier data showed, according to Labor Department calculations. Factory efficiency raced ahead 3.6 percent a year during the last decade, about as fast as the average of United States' trading partners, including Japan, Canada and Western Europe. In the 1970's, by contrast, United States factory productivity grew at only one-third the rate of the nation's biggest trading partners.

HEADLINE: Dow Soars in Heavy Trading to Gain 41.59

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
Stocks rose strongly yesterday in hectic trading, with the Dow Jones industrials and other leading averages scoring new highs for the year. One of the nation's most influential Wall Street investment houses said the six-month bear market had ended.
"I think the bear market is over," Steven G. Einhorn, a partner and co-chairman of the investment policy committee of Goldman, Sachs & Company, said in an interview. Only a week ago, Mr. Einhorn had said, "The bear is still growling, but more softly." 
 The Dow surged yesterday by 41.59 points, to 2,772.28. Trading volume soared to 250.8 million shares -- its highest since 318.9 million on Jan. 17, the first trading session after the start of allied air strikes on Iraq.
 
Other Measures Advance
 Showing that the rise was far-reaching, the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose the equivalent of 42 Dow points. The smaller Nasdaq stocks, though, jumped 46.5 Dow points, while the American Stock Exchange's market value index of small stocks rose the equivalent of 35.
Mr. Einhorn said that up to now his position was that the market had seen its lows and was not dropping further, just flattening out.
"We now think there's more upside than downside," he said.
Mr. Einhorn urged clients to get out of the market before its collapse in October 1987 and correctly turned bearish again early last year. But he also urged higher cash positions in 1988 and again in the first two months of 1989, thus missing market upturns in both periods.
He said Goldman, Sachs had notified all its clients and branches around the world yesterday that the stock market "will deliver a pleasant return of 12 to 15 percent over the next 12 months."
Asked what the market responded to yesterday, he replied, "There's an ongoing conviction that the Fed will continue to ease" monetary policy, "bringing about lower interest rates and some recovery in economic activity beginning in the summer months."
The Fed touched off heavy trading on Friday after cutting interest rates.
Goldman, Sachs "likes the growth stocks," Mr. Einhorn said, mentioning Merck, Bristol-Myers Squibb, Philip Morris, Abbott Labs, Colgate and Conagra.
 
154 New Highs
 On the Big Board, 1,362 stocks rose and only 359 fell. An impressive 154 stocks -- including Compaq Computer -- reached new highs while only 8 fell to new lows.
The market took off almost from the opening bell. Birinyi Associates said program trading added barely 6.5 points to the Dow, meaning that practically all of the volume came from institutions and individuals.
Short-sellers, who hope to profit by selling borrowed stock and replacing it with shares bought later for less, were forced to jump in now to avoid losing money as stocks continued upward. This in turn pushed stocks even further ahead.
In one example, Wells Fargo, the big West Coast banking concern, jumped 6 3/8, to 69 3/8, in heavy trading. Many bank stocks rose in the wake of declining interest rates, but Campbell Chaney, who watches Wells Fargo for Sutro & Company in San Francisco, said: "A lot is short covering. Wells Fargo was everybody's favorite stock to short."
Mr. Chaney said short covering also helped lift Security Pacific, First Interstate, Citicorp and several others.
Security Pacific rose 2 7/8, to 25; First Interstate 1 1/2, to 32 1/8, and Citicorp 1 3/8, to 15, with 3.6 million shares changing hands.
From Mr. Einhorn's list, Merck rose 2 3/8, to 94 1/2, after a new high of 94 3/4; Bristol-Myers 1 1/4, to 70, after a new high of 70 1/4; Philip Morris 1 1/4, to 58 1/8, after a new high of 58 1/4; Abbott Labs 1/8, to 43 1/8; Colgate 1 7/8, to 72 1/2, and Conagra 1/8, to 39, after a new high of 39 5/8.
Warren E. Buffett, the Omaha billionaire, had a good day. Berkshire Hathaway, his main investment vehicle, rose 225 a share, to 7,800. In addition to a large investment in Wells Fargo, it owns big pieces of Capital Cities/ABC, which rose 4, to 470; Geico, up 2, to 167; Coca-Cola, up 1, to 482; Washington Post, up 6,to 228, and Salomon, up 7/8, to $23 3/4.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Chip Estimate Cut By NEC Officials

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: TOKYO, Feb. 4

 BODY:
The NEC Corporation, one of Japan's top makers of computers and semiconductors, lowered its estimate for production of its most sophisticated computer chips because of weak demand. NEC officials said the company had expected production of four-megabit dynamic random access memory chips to reach about four million a month by this summer. But they said output was now expected to hover around three million a month.
Company executives explained that an economic slowdown in the United States and Europe had chilled the demand for computers and other advanced electronic products using four-megabit chips, the most sophisticated now available on the market.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
The Rust Belt has staged a renaissance on the factory floor, a Government report suggests. Thanks to a wrenching contraction in payrolls and plants, manufacturing productivity climbed to a postwar record between 1979 and 1989. [Page A1.] Overall productivity of non-farm workers was flat in the latest quarter. [D8.]
The Administration will recommend that the F.D.I.C. lose its authority to supervise banks, officials said today. The move would apparently be a slap at Seidman. [D1.]
Business groups are challenging laws that specify the wages to be paid to employees of private businesses. The laws have been enacted by several communities in California. [D1.]
President Bush sent Congress a $1.45 trillion budget request that admittedly understates the war's cost, includes no new measures to combat the recession and seeks to redistribute some subsidies that go to the affluent. [A1.] A leading element in the budget deficit is $88 billion for bank and savings and loan insurance. [A19.]
California farmers had their water turned off by a state water project just as spring planting was to begin. [A1.]
S.&P. removed its "credit watch" on New York City's bonds and reaffirmed the city's existing bond rating. [B1.]
Expanding public access to information about environmental and consumer hazards, New York State's judiciary adopted rules that prohibit court records from being sealed in most cases. [B1.]
 
COMPANIES
G.M. slashed its dividend nearly in half and announced cost-cutting measures, including reductions in its salaried work force and its capital spending plans. [D1.]
McCabe & Company is New York's newest small ad agency, and the industry's biggest mystery. [D1.]
Hills Department Stores filed for bankruptcy protection after failing to gain approval for a financing plan. [D2.]
Citicorp agreed to sell to Fiserve several businesses that provide data processing services to banks and other institutions. [D2.]
Coca-Cola's earnings dropped 61.1 percent because of one-time gains a year earlier. Operating earnings rose 27.1 percent. [D5.]
Capital Cities/ABC said its profits fell 13.5 percent, citing weak advertising demand and higher program costs. [D15.]

HEADLINE: 'Africa Centered' School Plan Is Rooted in 60's Struggles

BYLINE: By M. A. FARBER

 BODY:
For all its currency, the conflict over the proposal to start a small "Africa centered" high school mainly for black boys in New York City has a past that is as old as the Ocean Hill-Brownsville school wars of the late 1960's and the move prompted by that upheaval toward community control of the schools.
It is rooted in years of thought and action about the quality of education for urban minorities, especially blacks, and even about who should provide it. 
 On both sides are people who have proved to be genuinely interested in raising the academic accomplishments and self-esteem of youths who are without skills, often without hope, and some of whom are a danger to themselves and to others.
But in this case, where symbol counts as much as substance and where there hasbeen considerable confusion and misstatement, there is little agreement on how to achieve a desirable end.
Just a few weeks after most of the seven members of the Board of Education publicly endorsed the concept for what has been called the Ujaama Institute, several have privately backtracked, board officials say. The proposal is facing considerable revision amid criticism from integrationists and civil libertarians who say they fear the experimental school would foster racial separation. Ujamaa (pronounced you-JAH-ma) is a Swahili word sometimes translated as family.
A spokesman for Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez said the proposal would be reworked over a period of months by a Medgar Evers College faculty member, assisted by "two or three experts in multicultural education."
"In no way would the school be restrictedto one gender or one race," the spokesman, James S. Vlasto, said in an interview. He said the future role of the proposal's developer, Basir Mchawi, a former high school teacher who is an employee of the Chancellor's office, "is to be determined."
Mr. Mchawi (pronounced ma-CHOW-ee), a graduate of New York University who taught communications briefly at Rutgers University and Empire State College, came to write the Ujamaa proposal after two decades in a changing educational environmentin which many of the city's public schools in effect became segregated.
His career in the public schools began in the late 1960's at Intermediate School 201 in East Harlem, when that school -- like others in the Ocean Hill-Brownsville section of Brooklyn -- was a demonstration project for community control financed by the Ford Foundation. For five years in the early 1970's, Mr. Mchawi taught at Junior High School 275 in Brownsville.
In 1976 he resigned to become a teacher at Uhuru Sasa, one of a handful of accredited private schools started by black cultural nationalists after occasionally violent confrontations in the Ocean Hill-Brownsville project, some of which precipitated a prolonged, citywide teachers' strike. Uhuru Sasa, in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, was founded by Leslie Campbell, who now calls himself Jitu Weusi. He is a former Ocean Hill teacher who, in the midst of the community-control battle, was denounced for reading a poem on the radio that was widely regarded as anti-Semitic.
Uhuru Sasa, which closed in the mid-1980's for what Mr. Weusi says was chiefly a lack of financial support, was, by many accounts, an exciting school, stressing pride in the students' African heritage. Like Shule Ya Mapinduzi, a nearby private school that Mr. Mchawi helped run, Uhuru Sasa had a profound impact on Mr. Mchawi, and he began to think of it as an educational model.
In 1986, Mr. Mchawi rejoined the public-school system as an English teacher at Boys and Girls High School in Brooklyn, where he was described last week by the principal, Frank Mickens, as a "good, satisfactory" teacher.
But two years later, under circumstances that are not entirely clear, Mr. Mchawi left the classroom to become an assistant to Richard R. Green, who had just arrived from Minnesota to become the new schools chancellor.
 
A Meeting Leads To a 'Cabinet' Job
 Carol Gibson, who was executive assistant to Mr. Green, said the Chancellor met Mr. Mchawi at a community meeting at Boys and Girls High School in early 1988 and was "impressed with how articulate Basir was."
"Richard liked to have classroom teachers in his cabinet," Ms. Gibson said. "Richard marched to his own drummer. And he was impressed with those who spoke out."
Others say that Robert (Sonny) Carson, a Brooklyn community organizer whose son and niece attended Boys and Girls High School, pressed for Mr. Mchawi's appointment at Board of Education headquarters. Mr. Carson, who is often at the forefront of racially charged issues and who helped start the continuing boycott of two Korean groceries in Brooklyn, denies a hand in Mr. Mchawi's appointment.
"There was a series of meetings with Green, with community people of different views, and at one of the meetings Green asked Basir if he would be his assistant," Mr. Carson said last week. "We were all surprised."
Mr. Carson says he has not been in touch with Mr. Mchawi since then; Mr. Mchawi says Mr. Carson is an acquaintance but not someone with whom he has ever had a working relationship.
But in his recent book "The Closest of Strangers," Jim Sleeper, an editorial writer for New York Newsday, says Mr. Carson "enlisted the support" of Mr. Mchawi, apparently in late 1988, when Mr. Carson wanted to oust Lester McDowell as principal of Public School 262 in Brooklyn, a school then in turmoil. Mr. Mchawi declined to be interviewed for this article.
 
Parent Complains Of Racial Emphasis
 According to senior school officials, Mr. Mchawi worked as a "troubleshooter" at board headquarters and helped on such projects as the "corridor school program," supported by the Aaron Diamond Foundation, to improve links between elementary and middle schools.
In April 1989 a Brooklyn parent, Norbert A. Pierre, complained to Mr. Green that Mr. Mchawi, speaking as the Chancellor's "representative," had told a community forum that "I work for the Board of Mis-education, and I mean that."
"Don't think that because there are two black men in the Chancellor's office that the revolution has started," the parent quoted Mr. Mchawi. "It hasn't. Nothing's changed."
Mr. Pierre wrote to Mr. Green that while Mr. Mchawi explained how he had been "enlightened through the writings of Malcolm X" and had brought along a rap group -- which had sung about voter registration -- as an example of "positive youth," the Chancellor's aide "undermined confidence in our schools" and "apparently sought to polarize us along racial lines."
Mr. Mchawi should be removed, Mr. Pierre suggested.
Mr. Pierre received a form reply to his letter. Ms. Gibson said that to her knowledge Chancellor Green was never "disenchanted with Basir." She described Mr. Mchawi as "very committed to students, believing in self-esteem as the cornerstone of developing your capacity."
Nonetheless when Mr. Fernandez arrived from Miami in late 1989 to become Chancellor, he asked for Mr. Mchawi's resignation, along with hundreds of similar requests in the school hierarchy. Mr. Mchawi was offered a number of teaching assignments, according to Mr. Vlasto, that did not "pan out." Last April, Mr. Vlasto said, Mr. Mchawi was reassigned to Boys and Girls High School, but did not return there. He came up with his proposal for the Ujamaa Institute.
The idea for the high school drew not only on Mr. Mchawi's experience, but also on the writings of Jawanza Kunjufu, the Chicago author of "Countering the Conspiracy to Destroy Black Boys."
Also influencing the Ujamaa concept were the "Seven Principles" of Maulana Karenga, a California professor who, in the 1960's, was known as Ron Karenga. He was the leader of a militant black group in Los Angeles known as US, for United Slaves.
 
Curriculum Is Seen As 'Africa Centered'
 The principles for the Ujamaa Institute, Mr. Mchawi wrote, were "synthesized from traditional African values and the contemporary needs of the African-American people" and would sustain what he called a "value-based education." He listed the principles as unity, self-determination, collective work and responsibility, cooperative economics, purpose, creativity and faith.
Mr. Mchawi's proposal envisioned an academically rigorous but innovative "alternative" school staffed mainly by black men who would serve as both role models and teachers. He saw it as a school that would adhere to state educational regulations but would have a "definite emphasis" in its curriculum and activities on an "Africa centered," rather than "Western civilization," perspective.
The school, with about 300 to 400 "volunteer" students, would be in a converted building in Brooklyn, presumably with Mr. Mchawi as its director. An undated draft -- perhaps not the first -- of Mr. Mchawi's proposal says the school would be "nondiscriminatory" and would include girls, as well as "Latino males."
However, Lee Blake, chief education aide to Mayor David N. Dinkins, recalls that when she saw the proposal last fall, girls were not included and she told Mr. Mchawi that under those circumstances the school could not qualify for state or Federal aid.
For "political momentum," Mr. Mchawi turned in the spring of 1990 to Roger L. Green, a Brooklyn Assemblyman who had been chairman of the Black and Puerto Rican Caucus in Albany and who was a protege of Assemblyman Al Vann of Brooklyn. Mr. Vann, with whom Mr. Mchawi also spoke, was head of the African-American Teachers Association during the Ocean Hill-Brownsville school battles.
Assemblyman Green, a former public-school teacher, had his own reasons, some highly personal, for listening carefully to Mr. Mchawi, whom he knew, he said, from "the struggle around decentralization" of the schools. After seeing gang members at a high school during a visit in the fall of 1989 -- "it made my hair stand up on my neck," he said last week -- Mr. Green took some of the members to his home to meet with education officials and community leaders.
"It was clear these kids were engulfed with a tremendous level of alienation," Mr. Green recalled.
In late 1989 and early 1990, Assemblyman Green and some educators convened a series of workshops to find ways of "reclaiming and empowering" youths who were dropping out of school and getting into trouble. He was also worried about his teen-age son, Khalid, who had been assaulted three times and stabbed, the last time in the hand.
"That only reinforced my belief that we needed to begin the process of new educational models," Mr. Green said.
 
'A Convergence Of Interests'
When Mr. Mchawi approached him, seeking support for the Ujamaa Institute, Mr. Green immediately saw "a convergence of interests."
He said he wrote last May to Chancellor Fernandez on behalf of Mr. Mchawi's concept, although Mr. Fernandez's office says it has no record of receiving the letter and Mr. Green's office cannot locate its copy. In July Mr. Fernandez gave Mr. Mchawi, now a $60,000-a-year associate on the staff of the chief executive for instruction, approval to develop the Ujamaa proposal.
Last fall Mr. Mchawi asked the Aaron Diamond Foundation for a planning grant and was supported by Amina Abdur-Rahman, deputy chancellor for external programs and community affairs, who wrote to the foundation's executive director, Vincent McGee.
"We are quite interested in this project," she wrote to Mr. Gee on Oct. 15, noting that it could produce "instructional methodology that might be more effective with black and/or Hispanic male students."
Three days after Ms. Abdur-Rahman's letter, The New York Post said in an article that Mr. Fernandez was considering "a controversial program that would set up special public schools exclusively for young black students." Since then, more heat than light has been shed on the Ujamaa proposal.
Mr. Fernandez -- who had seemed to distance himself from the proposal when it was likened in the fall to a similar Milwaukee plan -- shortly thereafter embraced the Ujamaa idea, or at least his version of it. In a Dec. 13 memorandum to members of the Board of Education, Mr. Fernandez made no mention of Ujamaa's "Africa centered" character, portraying the proposed school as the kind of "multicultural" education favored by the board, his administration and the Mayor's office.
Last month, after a presentation by Assemblyman Green and others, most members of the board waxed enthusiastic over Ujamaa.
But cries of "racism," "separatism" and "sexism" by civil liberties and civil rights organizations, as well as educators like Dr. Kenneth B. Clark, the psychiatrist, who said the proposal would have been "deeply resented if proposed by an education commission of a Southern state," appear to have dampened the ardor of a number of board members.
Mr. Mchawi had originally hoped to see Ujamaa open this month. Now it is problematic whether it will open this year -- or at all.

HEADLINE: Drought Forces Cutoff of Water To Vast Farmlands in California

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 4

 BODY:
The huge water project built a generation ago to protect the fast-growing state against drought cut off all water to farmers today as a result of the worst drought in California history.
While not entirely unexpected, the move is a brutal blow to California's agricultural industry, the nation's largest, with economic conquences far worse than the December freeze. 
 "The freeze was nothing compared to this," said Donald W. Marquez, an engineer with the Kern County Water Agency in Bakersfield, the largest purchaser of state water. "We are looking at losses of billions of dollars in Kern County alone."
The action, by the State Department of Water Resources, the independent agency that operates the project, came as farmers were preparing for their spring planting and irrigation of major crops like cotton and as the lettuce crop was half grown. In anticipation of the cutoff, many had shelved plans to grow alfalfa, cotton and other crops that require much water.
The California State Water Project, a system of dams, reservoirs, aqueducts and canals, provides about 9 percent of the water used annually in California, but nearly all the water used in major farm regions of the Central Valley, the fertile, 300-mile-long plain that fills the central part of the state.
While many farmers and water agencies are trying to find alternative supplies, from wells and transfers from other areas, officials say there is little prospect of replacing more than a fraction of the lost supplies.
Whatever could be found would be used mostly to save permanent crops like almond and fruit trees, rather than producing a marketable harvest, they said.
Farm leaders said today's action was almost certain to raise prices nationwide for cotton and some fruits and vegetables.
Of the 9 million acres of irrigated farmland in the state, 600,000 depend on the water project. The cutoff affects thousands of farms stretching from the San Joaquin Delta south along the western half of the Central Valley. Other regions are served by the larger Federal Central Valley Project, which has also said it expects to cut its deliveries by 65 percent.
The state project has also provided about half the water used by the the Metropolitan Water District of Southern California, which serves urban dwellers and industry in Southern California. In all, 19 million people, two-thirds of the state's population, get some or all of their water from the State Water Project.
In normal years, the project delivers 2 million to 2.5 million acre-feet of water from Northern California through the huge California Aqueduct. An acre-foot is about 326,000 gallons, roughly enough to supply two households for a year. About half the water goes to farms.
In December, the state notified agricultural users to expect only 35 percent of their requests. That assumed good precipitation in January, but that month proved dry.
State water officials said today that with reservoirs down to a third of normal or less, they were forced to cut off the farms to preserve essential water in case next year is dry, too. About 85 percent of the water in California is used by farmers, who produce half the fruits and vegetables in the United States and who are almost totally dependent on irrigation using piped-in water.
Nearly all the water comes from snow and rain in the winter. The dry season begins in April, and little precipitation can be expected until November. Therefore, barring unusually heavy precipitation in the next two months, it appears unlikely that deliveries can be restored before next year.
 
No Signs of Relief
 The fierce drought in West, now in its fifth year, is showing no sign of letup. The snowpack in the Sierra Nevada, which normally provides the spring runoff that feeds the aqueducts supplying California farms and cities with water, stood at only about 13 percent of normal by last week.
State officials said today that there was only a 50-50 chance that the project could deliver the supplies, already cut in half, that were promised urban residents this year.
This is certain to accelerate rationing in major cities, including Los Angeles, where Mayor Tom Bradley called on residents on Friday to reduce water use by 15 percent from 1986 levels or face stiff penalties on their bills.
The cutoff for farmers appeared to presage even broader restrictions on water use expected to be ordered when the State Water Resources Control Board, a powerful agency that controls rights to surface water statewide, meets Thursday in Sacramento. On Friday Gov. Pete Wilson created a task force to advise him on what steps to take, including a possible declaration of a state emergency.
In a letter to the local water agencies that buy the project's water, David N. Kennedy, director of the Department of Water Resources, said the agency would review its capacity to deliver more water during the rest of the rainy season, but he held out little hope in light of the "bleak" situation. He urged all contractors to emphasize conservation and efficiency.
It is hard to predict the full effects of today's action on farms and industries dependent on them.
"This has scared the socks off of everybody," said Fred L. Starrh, a Kern County farmer who canceled his cotton crop and laid off 40 workers even before today's announcement. He said he hoped to get enough water from other sources just to save his 265 acres of almond trees.
Cotton, which accounts for about one-third of the acreage in the six main counties of the Central Valley, is expected to be hit hardest.
"We're sick about it," Cathy Merlo, spokeswoman for Calcot, the state's largest cotton cooperative, told The Associated Press. She said the cooperative expected acreage to drop by 30 percent.
Bob Vice, president of the California Farm Bureau Federation, the largest agricultural organization in the state, said in a statement that the suspension of water deliveries would create much hardship.
 
'The Losses Will Be Large'
 "The financial effect of this action is unknown," he said, "but we know that the losses will be large and the potential exists that consumers will see the result in the marketplace." He urged renewed efforts to develop more water sources, a step resisted by environmentalists.
The principal engineer for the Department of Water Resources, Donald R. Long, said his agency was trying to buy water from other water systems to help keep fruit trees and grapevines from drying up and to supply cities facing health and safety emergencies.
The drought began in 1987. There has been some speculation that California might be undergoing a permanent climatological change, which would radically alter its economy. But water experts point to historical data showing repeated cycles of rain and drought, although no drought as protracted as this one. "It's got to rain some time," Mr. Long said.

HEADLINE: HORSE RACING NOTEBOOK;
Filly-Colt Showdown Likely in Triple Crown

BYLINE: By JOSEPH DURSO

 BODY:
Is another legendary battle of the sexes taking shape in racing's Triple Crown classics?
Could be. 
 In this corner, you have the champion 2-year-old colt of 1990, Fly So Free, who wasted no time making his 1991 debut a smashing one Saturday when he snatched the Hutcheson Stakes at Gulfstream Park in the final 60 yards. He is 5 of 7 in his career, and rolling.
In the far corner, the champion 2-year-old filly of 1990, Meadow Star, undefeated in seven starts last year, gathering her oats this year and primed for more.
Both are now 3-year-olds; both are eligible for the racing classics; both are in Florida, perhaps embarked on a collision course. And remember, only three fillies have ever won the Kentucky Derby: Regret in 1915, Genuine Risk in 1980 and Winning Colors in 1988.
Many others might have tried, but their owners and trainers decided to keep them competing against fillies and not subject them to the rigors of competing with colts, who tend to be bigger and tougher.
Guess what? The man who trained Genuine Risk in 1980 was Leroy Jolley. The man who trains Meadow Star, a decade later: Leroy Jolley.
But that doesn't necessarily mean he is spoiling for another battle of the sexes. In fact, it's generally believed he did not particularly want Genuine Risk to challenge the colts but was overruled by Bert Firestone, the filly's owner. And now Jolley says the dye has not yet been cast on Meadow Star, either by himself or by the owner, Carl Icahn, the financier.
"She's thrived here and couldn't be doing better," Jolley said the other day from the Payson Park training complex near Indiantown, Fla. "She'll have two races against fillies before we decide whether she'll tackle the colts and point for the Derby."
Jolley is projecting her debut around March 1. But by then, Fly So Free may have added a notch to his belt. His trainer, Scotty Schulhofer, said the colt would roll again Feb. 23 in the Fountain of Youth Stakes at Gulfstream (at a mile and a sixteenth) and yet again on March 16 in the Florida Derby (at a mile and an eighth). The Kentucky Derby will be run May 4 (at a mile and a quarter).
Why wouldn't they run a filly against anybody if she was unbeaten and unmatched in her class?
Because there are plenty of prizes and bankrolls for fillies who beat other fillies. And the greatest of fillies in our time, Ruffian, competed only once against a colt: in the match race in 1975 against Foolish Pleasure, the colt who had won the Kentucky Derby.
But we will never know how she would have fared. Her right foreleg snapped in the backstretch at Belmont Park, and she did not survive. Ask Leroy Jolley about colts and fillies and tragedy at the races: He was the trainer of Foolish Pleasure.
 
Aqueduct Hangs Tough

Yes, Virginia, there is an Aqueduct race track, and it probably will continue to delight the hearts of railbirds.
Just for how long, though, that is the question. Gov. Mario Cuomo, who is trying to trim New York's budget, proposed last week that the state sell the track to the Port Authority, which reportedly would like to expand Kennedy Airport, the track's neighbor in south Queens.
If so, the state would gain $100 million but lose one of its two major downstate tracks. Could Belmont house, feed and race all those horses by itself?
"Nothing is imminent," said Gerard McKeon, president of the New York Racing Association, which operates Belmont, Aqueduct and Saratoga. "Talks have been conducted on and off with the Port Authority for several months, but nothing is final or even imminent.
"Before the sale of Aqueduct could be concluded, many serious problems must be solved. Among them are the modification of Belmont Park to allow for a longer racing season; the replacement of Aqueduct's 500 stalls and training facilities; the shortening of the New York metropolitan racing season; the restructuring of the marketing of racing within the state, the protection of racing opportunities for horsemen and the preservation of the state's revenue stream from parimutuel wagering."
He means that Belmont Park would have to be expanded to carry the load of horses and its season would have to be lengthened to give the horses something to do. Belmont operates from May into November (except for the Saratoga season in August); Aqueduct runs through the winter into May.
These things could be worked out, and probably will be. Then the main problem will be financial: Fewer races mean fewer bets and fewer dollars for the state, both at the track and through its Offtrack Betting system. And the whole idea was to add money, in the first place.
 
War, Recession and Football

The racing industry has been reporting a drop in attendance and betting because of the war in the Middle East and the recession. And, said Glenn Mathis of the New York Racing Association, things at Aqueduct got noticeably slower some weekend afternoons in January for another reason.
"The Giants," he reported. "We were down on the Sundays when they were in the playoffs. People just stayed home and watched TV."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Fly So Free, right, with Jose Santos aboard, about to cross the finish line ahead of To Freedom, ridden by Chris Antley, to win the Hutcheson Stakes on Saturday at Gulfstream Park. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: In a Warming World, Who Comes Out Ahead?

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS

 BODY:
IN a finding fraught with sensitive political implications, some scientists say that if global warming takes its expected course, some parts of the world could come out winners, even while many others reap disaster.
A few regions, mainly in colder climes, may well benefit, according to computer models of climate change. The computer models merely simulate global climate change and are still being refined. They are therefore a rough guide to what may happen to various regions as the world warms, not an exact forecast. 
 For many other regions, including North America, the computer models predict both pluses and minuses whose overall balance cannot yet be assessed. But for developing countries, scientists say, the general picture is negative: most are more vulnerable to climate change and less able to adapt to it than are the industrialized nations of the cooler latitudes.
The question of whether some countries might gain from global warming has been bubbling just beneath the surface of discussions about climate change.
Some politicians and environmentalists have been reluctant to confront the issue for fear it might disrupt efforts to forge an international agreement to head off global warming from gases being produced by human activity. Others, including some scientists, assert that while there might be some temporary winners, there will be none over the long run, especially if global warming is severe and if it occurs as rapidly as scientists predict. Not least, they say, the natural ecosystems that undergird human life everywhere would not be able to adjust fast enough to escape catastrophe.
The winners-losers issue is becoming more prominent just as delegates met yesterday at Chantilly, Va., outside Washington, in the first of several sessions to negotiate a treaty limiting the emission of "greenhouse" gases, which trap the sun's heat in the atmosphere. Scientists predict that these gases will heat the earth's surface by an 2 to 5 degrees Fahrenheit over the next century unless checked.
Some experts note that if any countries gain from global warming, they will probably be the ones that now emit most greenhouse gases, primarily carbon dioxide, methane and chlorofluorocarbons.
 
Threat to Island Nations
 "In the long run, there are good reasons to believe that those who are responsible are the winners," said Dr. Klaus Meyer-Abich, a physicist and philosopher at Germany's Science Center of Rhine-Westphalia and at the University of Essen. He has served as an expert adviser on climate change to the German parliament and has extensively studied the question of climatic winners and losers.
Whether industrialized countries enjoy absolute gains or not, they stand to increase their already huge overall economic advantage over the third world.
Countries that see themselves as undoubted losers include small island nations that fear a major rise in sea level and more frequent and severe tropical storms, both of which are expected to result from global warming. These nations have formed the Alliance of Small Island States to press their case for stringent controls on greenhouse gas emissions.
They are preparing to demand that the industrialized countries cut their own emissions and also help the island nations adapt to climate change, said Naresh Singh of Castries, St. Lucia, the executive director of the Caribbean Environmental Health Institute, an umbrella organization for 16 English-speaking Caribbean countries. Mr. Singh is a delegate to the Chantilly meeting.
If the level of the oceans rises by more than two feet by the year 2100, as climate experts predict, low-lying nations like the Maldives and some Pacific islands could be inundated. Other places at high risk include Bangladesh, Thailand, Indonesia, Egypt, coastal China, Louisiana and the southern coast of the North Sea, according to a recent assessment by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, a body set up by the United Nations to advise the treaty negotiators and their governments.
In general, populations most vulnerable to global warming "are in developing countries, in the lower income groups, residents of coastal lowlands and islands, populations in semi-arid grasslands and the urban poor in squatter settlements, slums and shantytowns, especially in megacities," says a report by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change.
People living in third-world slums are judged more vulnerable because their existence, already precarious, could be made even more so by disrupted food supplies.
Developing countries are more vulnerable because they are more dependent on agriculture, forests and other natural resources for economic health, said Dr. Dennis Tirpak, director of the Environmental Protection Agency's global climate change division, a member of the American negotiating team at Chantilly.
Agriculture in much of the third world is especially susceptible to drought. Global warming is expected to intensify drought in wide areas, and also to cause severe damage to forests and grasslands. On top of this, many third world populations already live on the margins of subsistence, and lack the resources to cope with climatic disruption.
Apart from these broad outlines, the effects of warming appear mixed and quite complicated.
"In some places the climate will get better and in some it will get worse," said Dr. Michael H. Glantz of the National Center for Atmospheric Research in Boulder, Colo. But beyond that, he said, much remains unknown. Dr. Glantz, a social scientist, heads a group that studies the impact of climate change on societies and has been trying to encourage discussion and inquiry on winners and losers for some time. Last year he organized an international conference in Malta on assessing winners and losers.
 The conference concluded, "There will be advantaged and disadvantaged countries, regions within countries, sectors and populations."
"The identity of those advantaged and disadvantaged will change over time," it said. "There are serious obstacles to their identification."
Dr. Tirpak explained: "It's not a case where you can simply pick a date and have one set of countries that will win forevermore and another that will lose. It is not a very easy thing to characterize."
The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, nevertheless, has tentatively identified potential gainers and losers. The identification is based on results of mathematical simulations of how the earth's climate would behave under global warming, and is therefore uncertain.
"We should not take these studies literally, as a prognosis that every detail will just come as it is written now," Dr. Meyer-Abich said. But he said the general pattern "will not be changed very much" as more is learned.
 
Effects on Agriculture
 The relative advantages and disadvantages are perhaps most tellingly reflected in the effects of warming on agriculture. This will occur in forms like shifting rainfall patterns, drier soil, increased evaporation of surface water, increased loss of water by crops and reduced snowpacks in the mountains, resulting in lessened runoff in the spring.
But warming would also bring more rainfall to some areas and more warmth and longer growing seasons to regions that are now too cool for maximum agricultural production.
The following examples of possible gains and losses are not all-inclusive, but suggest the variety and range of changes expected:
Northern Europe would become a winner, according to the intergovernmental panel's analysis. Northern Scandinavia "stands to gain more from global warming than perhaps any other region of the world" because it would become warmer and wetter, the panel's report said. The grasslands that feed Iceland's sheep would become more than twice as productive as they are now.
Yields of grass and potatoes would increase in much of Ireland, Britain, the Low Countries and Denmark. A temperature increase of more than 2 degrees would improve the agricultural potential of much of the European part of the Soviet Union. But substantial decreases in productivity could occur in Southern Europe. A warming of 2 to 7 degrees would enable cultivated areas to creep 500 feet to 2,000 feet closer to the summit of the Alps. Northern Japan, including Hokkaido and the northern part of Honshu, would enjoy increased yields of rice, corn and soybeans.
By contrast, drier soils would disrupt food production in regions like Northwest and West Africa, the horn of Africa, southern Africa, western Saudi Arabia, Southeast Asia, Mexico, Central America and parts of eastern Brazil.
 
Prospects for North America
 For North America, the overall climate picture is mixed. Large parts of the northern United States and Canada would enjoy a pleasanter climate and attract more inhabitants, Dr. Meyer-Abich wrote in a recent review. In Europe, too, he said, these "privileged regions" would be extended farther to the north.
Agricultural production in the United States would also shift northward, according to a study by the Environmental Protection Agency, with Minnesota, Wisconsin and northern Michigan being gainers. But 10 to 50 percent of all agricultural acreage in the South might have to be abandoned. Production would probably decrease in the Corn Belt. Drier soil would cut yields of spring wheat in Canada, although there would be a small increase near the northern limit of current production. Yields of corn, barley, soybeans and hay would decline in all of Canada but northern Ontario.
A rise in sea level could inundate coastal wetlands, damaging or destroying spawning grounds that sustain commercial fisheries. Beachfront communities would have to invest billions of dollars in coastal protection, and some settled areas on the coast would probably be inundated.
Northern cities would be spared considerable expense in heating costs, snow removal and road maintenance. But air-conditioning bills would soar in the South and ski resorts could be in deep trouble.
In one sense, national borders are the wrong framework in which to consider global climate change.
"Looking at it on the nation-state level may not be appropriate," said Dan McGraw, a professor of international environmental law at the University of Colorado. "If significant climate change occurs, it's going to be a lot of individuals in the world who are disadvantaged. At one level, it doesn't matter so much which country they're in."
But when it comes to negotiating the treaties to moderate climate change, it is nations that do the negotiating. On that level, Mr. McGraw said, he has detected a reluctance to discuss winners and losers.
"Some folks feel that any discussion of the question will tend to polarize the possible participants in any sort of international solution," he said. The fear, he said, may be that "as countries start focusing on whether they are likely to be a winner or loser, that will influence whether they cooperate."
Temporary advantage aside, all nations are interdependent in the long run, note observers like William Nitze, a former State Department official who coordinated Government policy on global warming until last September. If the third world suffers, the industrialized countries suffer as well, he said, noting: "Developing countries are a tremendous market for us. We have a large stake in their long-term future prosperity."
Senator Al Gore, a Tennessee Democrat who favors strong action to combat global warming, contends that talk of winners and losers "is just another cop-out that people use for not dealing with this threat."
He cited the prospect of waves of "environmental refugees," fleeing ravaged third world economies or low-lying areas and causing "enormous destabilizing pressures" for industrialized countries.
 
Worldwide Refugee Problem
 The number of refugees could amount to 100 million, said Dr. Michael Oppenheimer, a senior scientist and expert on global warming at the Environmental Defense Fund, a research and advocacy group. The pressure they may bring on the rest of the world "is enough in itself to make people who think they're going to be winners take notice and reassess," he said.
He concedes that if the world warms by only a degree or two over the next century, then "without question, some people could be labeled winners." But with an eight degree warming, the upper limit predicted by some computer simulations, "the world would be so different at those higher levels that it is very difficult to argue that any significant number of people will find it beneficial," he said. "There will be radical change, in other words."
Scientists predict that the rate of climatic change would be faster than at any other time in the last 10,000 years. "If it happened infinitely slowly," Dr. Oppenheimer said, "society could adjust. In a fast-changing world, there are no winners."

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
Looking to Grow Rich, And Be Happy, in Texas

BYLINE: By MICHIKO KAKUTANI

 BODY:
Small Fortunes Two Guys in Pursuit
Of the American Dream
By Edward Zuckerman
296 pages. Viking. $19.95.
 The "Two Guys in Pursuit of the American Dream" that the journalist Edward Zuckerman profiles in his new book are both Texans and they are both entrepreneurs. Both come from modest backgrounds and both dream of using their business skills to invent new lives for themselves. There, however, the similarities apparently end. 
 Pete Binion, as Mr. Zuckerman notes, is "a Texan of the old school." Having grown up on a succession of small Texas farms, he enlisted in the Marines in the late 1960's, went to Vietnam and returned home to study animal husbandry and become a rodeo rider. Now, happily married with three children, he has sunk all his family's money into a ranch, where he hopes to breed Senepol cattle.
 Pete believes that he can introduce the Senepol, an obscure breed developed on the Caribbean island of St. Croix, to Texas and that one day it will rival such long-established breeds as the longhorn and the Brahman. He also plans to use his knowledge of animal science to start a company named Universal Embryonics. (He rejected the name World Embryonics as too limited.) The company, he believes, will operate on the cutting edge of cattle reproduction technology, bringing combined benefits, in Mr. Zuckerman's words, to "world agriculture and Pete Binion and his family."
Mr. Zuckerman's other subject, Jim Teal, has dreams that are considerably less visionary. He simply wants to make a lot of money and have a good time. As described by Mr. Zuckerman, Jim comes across as an obnoxious good old boy. His idea of a good time is golf with topless models or a wild party in his yellow RV.He is not above trying to collect insurance money by goading a drunken driver into running into his car.
 If Jim lacks conventional scruples, however, he's also a hard-working hustler. At age 18, he was a dollar-an-hour chicken breader at a Kentucky Fried Chicken; by 30, he was the owner of a Wendy's hamburger franchise and he had more than a million dollars in Wendy's stock. Since then, he has run a male stripper bar and a hot-tub business, which faltered amid the growing fears about herpes and AIDS. When Mr. Zuckerman first meets Jim, he has started a T-shirt business featuring shirts emblazoned with popular comic-strip characters like Skyler the Bird and Bill the Cat.
 Cutting back and forth in alternating chapters between Jim's story and Pete's story, Mr. Zuckerman creates a compelling and often very funny portrait of these two Texas businessmen, with whom he spent two and a half years. Observant yet nonjudgmental, he is able to give the reader a vivid sense of these two men's lives, as well as an understanding of how their stories fit and don't fit the traditional Horatio Alger mold. He demonstrates how luck and timing and judgment can make or break a small business, how circumstances beyond one's control can exert a profound -- and often devastating -- influence on individual lives. We see how American's suspicion of red meat and cholesterol can have a direct effect on ranchers like Pete Binion and how recession and bank failures can affect a struggling businessman like Jim Teal.
 In addition, Mr. Zuckerman gives the reader a colorful picture of contemporary Texas as glimpsed through the lives of his two heroes and some of those they encounter. He takes us to football games and golf courses, to shopping malls and trade fairs, to barbecues and dances, and he introduces us to a motley group of people, including a woman who persuades her wealthy husband to buy some cattle because she likes their color, a man who specializes in armadillo cartoons and a cowboy who dreams of owning a house with three walls of hard-cover books and a picture window.
 Unfortunately, neither Jim nor Pete prosper with their businesses. Pete is unable to find buyers for his Senepol cattle. He loses his ranch and eventually goes bankrupt. Jim and his partner also go out of business. After years of driving around in limousines, he begins living on his unemployment benefits of $217 a week.
 Both, however, remain incurable optimists. Last seen by Mr. Zuckerman, they are busy working on the second acts in their lives. Jim thinks there is money to be made in getting Federal and city funds to help subsidize mobile home parks for the homeless; Pete has returned to school to prepare for a new career in hazardous-waste management. He writes Mr. Zuckerman that he and his "family, pets and friends are healthy and doing well." He is relieved that he no longer has to worry about a failing business. "Life is a joy," he writes, "I'm living in heaven."

HEADLINE: U.S. Accepts Greenhouse Target

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHANTILLY, Va., Feb. 4

 BODY:
The Bush Administration today opened an international conference on global warming with the declaration that the United States will stabilize its overall production of the gases that have been linked to rising world temperatures.
According to the Administration's plan, introduced in a 22-page "action agenda" prepared by the White House, the United States will hold down the production of gases thought to cause the earth's warming to roughly 2.3 billion tons annually by the year 2000, the same amount produced in 1987. 
 The Administration also said for the first time in an international setting that it believed global warming was a problem.
The White House is proposing no new steps to hold down carbon dioxide or other gases, however, saying it believes that measures already taken will put a cap on greenhouse gases. Environmentalists compare this position unfavorably with that of European nations, which have agreed to cut back carbon dioxide emissions.
"The old White House position was this isn't a problem and we're not going to do anything about it anyway," said Dr. Michael Oppenheimer, an atmospheric physicist at the Environmental Defense Fund in New York. "The new position is yes, this a problem, but we're still not going to do anything about it."
 
Need to Act Now
 Michael Deland, chairman of the White House Council on Environmental Quality, told delegates to the international conference today, "Despite huge uncertainty, the potential threat for climate change justifies taking action now," said .
The Administration's plan and Mr. Deland's call to action came today at the first session of an international meeting to begin work on a treaty to curb emissions of carbon dioxide and several other gases that trap heat in the atmosphere, like the glass panes of a greenhouse.
The 10-day meeting, which attracted delegates from 130 nations, is the first of 5 scheduled to culminate in Rio de Janeiro in June 1992 with the signing of a treaty to take new economic, environmental and scientific steps to curb the warming.
 
Relief and Derision
 Mr. Deland's remarks and the White House proposal were greeted today with a mixture of relief and derision. Leaders of American environmental groups and some delegates said they indicated a new willingness by the Bush Administration to pursue strategies to reduce the threat of global warming. Other Administration officials, notably William K. Reilly, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, have voiced alarm over threatened global warming, but until now the White House position was that the threat had not been proved.
The critics of the Administration also noted that the White House proposals appeared to be more of a public relations move because they did not commit the United States to take any actions to reduce carbon dioxide, the most important of the gases involving in global warming. In fact, under the proposal, the production of carbon dioxide would rise by the year 2000 to 1.5 billion tons a year from 1.3 billion tons in 1987.
Three-quarters of the roughly five billion tons of carbon dioxide released into the atmosphere from human activity is produced by the industrialized countries, and the United States is responsible for nearly a quarter of the total.
 
Cut in Chlorofluorocarbons
 The increase in production of carbon dioxide, according to the Bush Administration's plan, would be offset by a reduction in the production of chlorofluorocarbons, a chemical used as a coolant and linked to the destruction of the atmospheric ozone shield. Almost four years ago in Montreal, the United States and other industrialized countries agreed to cut the production of chlorofluorocarbons by 50 percent. Last summer, the same nations agreed to phase out the chemical's production by the turn of the century.
Dr. Oppenheimer of the Environmental Defense Fund said: "This plan does not commit the United States to anything painful that hasn't been done already. But what is important is that we have a specific plan that the Administration says it's committed to. It's conceptually important that for the first time they are accepting targets. It is significant from a political perspective."
Before the conference ends on Feb. 14, delegates are scheduled to designate the members of three or four committees that will draft specific recommendations for reducing the threat of global warming. The committees are expected to consider proposals to reduce greenhouse gases and to preserve forests, which absorb carbon dioxide; ways to help less developed nations conform to a treaty, and the proposed legal text of the treaty.
The United States has proposed that a fourth committee be formed to provide the other committees with the latest research data on global warming.
Officials of other nations, especially the Europeans, oppose the proposal, saying that the best source of data is the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, 300 of the world's leading climate experts, organized by the United Nations to provide such research data.
 
National Energy Guide
 As part of its new plan for stabilizing the production of the gases that are linked to the changing climate, the White House today said that it was relying on aspects of its long-awaited national energy strategy. Conserving energy would reduce the production of such gases, the White House said.
Among the proposals outlined today was a plan by the White House to press for new standards to make appliances more efficient. Such standards could reduce the consumption of energy 7 to 8 percent by the turn of the century, and 15 percent by the year 2010. Large appliances, the White House said, account for more than two-thirds of the energy used in homes.
The White House also wants to increase its program to train engineers who can audit and improve the consumption patterns of more than 350,000 industrial plants in the United States.
The Federal Government will also be pressed to come up with new programs to reduce the consumption of energy for lighting. A quarter of the Government's energy consumption is for lighting offices, factories, military bases, and other installations, according to the White House. Improving lighting could reduce the production of the gases linked to the greenhouse effect by an amount equivalent to 1.4 million metric tons of carbon.

HEADLINE: Budget Deceit, Punctured;
And This Deficit Is No Demon

 BODY:
The Federal deficit for fiscal 1991 will exceed $300 billion, and next year's won't be much lower. These are chilling facts, enough to make critics belittle last year's budget accord and fear for the health of the economy. 
 The criticism and fear are unwarranted. The deficits projected for this year and next are swollen by factors like war and recession, surely serious but also temporary. They do not threaten the long-term health of the economy. What does matter is the structural deficit, which results from ongoing Federal programs.
By this measure, the budget projections released yesterday by the White House -- like earlier projections from the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office -- show the structural deficit heading steadily downward. That's sound; to cut more during a recession would be reckless.
Much of the fear concerning $300 billion deficits arises from misunderstanding. Much of that astronomical figure is for the war, the bailout of savings and loan institutions and the recession, when tax revenues fall and welfare costs rise. But each of these factors is temporary and poses no grave threat. During recessions, corporate borrowing falls off and is not threatened by an extra $50 billion or so of Federal borrowing. And when the Treasury borrows $100 billion to replenish the bank accounts at insolvent S.& L.'s, the money is put right back into the capital market for corporations to borrow.
Even as the actual deficit continues to rise, the structural deficit continues to fall, primarily because of last fall's $500 billion deficit reduction package. Once the economy recovers in 1995, the Administration's new budget projects the deficit falling to near zero. The Congressional Budget Office thinks it will be more like $100 billion. But even that figure would be less than 1 percent of gross national product for the first time in two decades.
The $500 billion deficit reduction package met Congress's duty to control borrowing for recurring Federal programs. As long as it doesn't renege on the accord, the economy will be well served.

SECTION: Section A; Page 22; Column 1; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: Budget Deceit, Punctured;
But Defense Still Stands Alone

 BODY:
On the surface, Budget Day in Washington yesterday seemed bland, even boring. In truth it was a remarkable occasion, because for once, the Government avoided its annual plunge into the solemnly ridiculous.
In the usual gavotte, the White House piously presents rosy estimates that make the projected deficit look deceptively small, lessening the need to cut programs or raise taxes. Last year, for instance, Michael Boskin, the President's chief economic adviser, estimated that the 1991 deficit would be $100 billion. In fact, it turned out to be over $300 billion. 
 This year is different: no tricks, no exaggeration. Yesterday Mr. Boskin fearlessly projected the 1992 deficit at $280 billion. Why the newfound candor? Because the budget law passed last fall eliminated any incentive for the White House or Congress to dissemble or deceive. The candor is wholeheartedly welcome. Defense spending remains unwisely shielded from debate, but in other respects the new process opens the way for honest fights over issues that matter.
 Until this year, the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings law required Congress to meet yearly targets for the Federal deficit. That produced an irresistible incentive to pretend the deficit was smaller than it really was. Last year the trickery ballooned beyond disguise, and Congress changed the law. It created a pay-as-you-go regime. If it passes a law that adds to spending or cuts taxes, it must make offsetting changes. But the Government is allowed to tolerate any deficit increase that is not caused by explicit Congressional act.
Thus Mr. Boskin did not need to disguise next year's huge, and growing, deficit because it is caused by external factors: the war, the recession, the cost of the savings and loan bailout and the decision last fall to hold down the first year of deficit cuts to protect a fragile economy.
The new law makes good economic sense. Cutting spending or raising taxes would be lethal in recession. And the recession, like war and the S.& L. bailout, is temporary. These needs do not create a permanent drain.
There is another reason that budget negotiations will now be less shrill. Congress set separate spending ceilings for the military, foreign assistance and domestic discretionary programs. That eliminates a whole dimension of debate. The law contemplates shifting money within each category, but does not allow shifting money between categories -- from the military, say, to education.
By so doing, Congress unwisely ducked the budget issue that counts most: how to apportion between defense and other spending. That glaring mistake aside, the new law insures a clearer budget and a wiser debate.

SECTION: Section A; Page 23; Column 1; Editorial Desk
