HEADLINE: OBSERVER;
Jumbo Was a Humbug

BYLINE: By Russell Baker

 BODY:
Here's a big development in soap, and big developments in soap must be important for America because if somebody asked, "What does America mean to you?" you wouldn't list very many other items ahead of soap, would you?
 The flag and baseball, yes. Maybe Abraham Lincoln. Those are tops. But after that, soap is right up there, and don't tell me you'd put family and motherhood ahead of soap. Thousands of families, many of them containing mothers, give up in divorce every day. Divorce or no divorce, nobody gives up soap. 
 Without soap there would be no soap opera. Clothing would not be twice as clean and white clothing would not be twice as white. Scalps would not be magically freed of unsightly dandruff without painful scraping which, in severe cases, might require shaving the head bald.
 Without soap, what would Presidential candidates be sold like by political technicians? Ever since President Eisenhower's ad agency boasted it had "sold him like soap," that's how all Presidential candidates have been sold. Like soap. Not all sold well, but neither do all soaps.
 So here is the new soap thing: "downsizing," it's called in American Newspeak. Those gigantic boxes of laundry soap you haul home from the grocery -- it turns out they don't have to be gigantic, after all. They never did. So the soap people are going to make them small.
 Apparently the detergent folks were fluffing up their detergents with filler like sodium carbonate, which has no soap power whatever. They wanted to justify a bigger box so customers would think they were getting more for their money.
 Theirs was the old traditional marketing theory that America was a big country full of big people who wanted big consumer goods. The theory's ultimate product may have been the giant family-size car: 300 horsepower, eight cylinders, eight miles per gallon.
 I once had such a car and loved it because it could be packed for a Maine vacation with wife and husband, three adolescent children, one grandmother, a 10-gallon aquarium tank, two cats and supporting cat-litter box, a three-week luggage supply for everyone, and four collapsible lawn chairs.
 Even then it still had a few feet of empty, unusable space between its bumpers and serious automotive organs front and back. This had been thrown in, like the detergent industry's sodium carbonate, to give me a sense of getting more for my money.
 Germany, Japan and the oil cartel wiped out this car by selling Americans on the dubious principle that less is more. As a result I eventually faced a nasty dilemma: Give up family vacations? Or tell grandmother and the children to tuck the aquarium and cats under arm and start hitchhiking toward Maine?
 The giant family-size car was done in by nasty economics, but that isn't the case with the jumbo detergent box. Sure, shrinking the thing until it's not much bigger than a box of steel-wool scouring pads will free some shelf space for supermarkets, but the soap people say that reducing packaging responds to rising environmental concerns.
 In short, if the public is passionately persuaded that less is more, maybe business will follow. It's said you don't lose any soap power from the small boxes, just the filler. With the smaller package, you use a lot less per laundry. Anyhow, that's the soap industry's story.
 Soap being one of the quintessentials of America, does this shrinkage portend a new age of smallness? It hasn't dawned on supermarket coffee shelves. Most coffee companies have surreptitiously reduced their standard marketing unit from one pound to 12 ounces without shrinking the familiar pound-sized container to a smaller, less-is-more, 12-ounce can.
 In this case perhaps coffee tycoons fear that the more which would result from the less would consist only in complaints about the 25 percent price increase.
 Evidence of romance with shrinkage is rampant, however, in the electronic-appliance industry. For instance, the compact disk, which is smaller than the old phonograph record, reproduces music better than music has ever been reproduced before, provided the music to be reproduced is not on your old phonograph records, in which case it is useless.
 Something similar has happened to personal computers. Old ones worked with 5.25-inch floppy disks. Disk size for new ones has been shrunk to 3.5 inches. The machines using 3.5 disks are superior, unless you need to work on your old 5.25 disks, in which case they are useless.
 Could this be a new law of developing technology: Useless is better?

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: But Are There Enough Jobs for the Poor?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your series on poverty in America ("The Missing Agenda: Poverty and Policy," Jan. 27, 28, 29), while hitting most of the issues, missed the biggest one: Are there enough jobs for the poor?
If the number of low-income welfare recipients, unemployed and "discouraged workers" is less than the supply of available jobs, then either the conventional conservative solution (increase motivation by cutting benefits) or the conventional liberal solution (remove barriers to entry such as racial discrimination and lack of job training) may be sound public policy.
If, on the other hand, the number of those whom we expect to work substantially exceeds the supply of available jobs, then neither motivation nor the removal of barriers will do much good. Most of the poor will remain poor -- because there will literally be too few jobs for them to fill.
We don't have a lot of data as to how the number of persons expected to work compares to the supply of unfilled jobs, but such data as do exist all point to the same conclusion: The supply of officially unemployed workers alone exceeds the supply of unfilled jobs.
National studies by Katherine Abraham and Harry Holzer show that -- depending on the official unemployment rate -- the number of officially unemployed consistently exceeds the number of unfilled jobs by ratios ranging from 10:1 to 3:1. When welfare recipients and "discouraged workers" are thrown into the mix, the ratios get worse. In Milwaukee, a forthcoming study by the Social Development Commission will show that, since 1987, the sum of welfare recipients plus unemployed plus discouraged workers has exceeded the estimated supply of unfilled jobs by ratios ranging from 10:1 to 6:1. And this when the official jobless rate was generally below both state and national averages.
As I suggest in my recent book, "The Prisoners of Welfare: Liberating America's Poor from Unemployment and Low Wages," while any individual's poverty in the United States may be the result of inadequate motivation or frustrating barriers to entry, aggregate poverty in this country is the result of two simple shortcomings of the labor market: too few jobs, and too many jobs that pay wages too low.
To eliminate poverty, therefore, it is necessary to correct for these two basic labor market deficiencies. Empowering the poor -- as that concept is defined by Housing Secretary Jack Kemp, i.e., letting the poor choose to enroll in any school, buy public housing units, etc. -- however meritorious, will not work, because empowerment neither creates millions of new extra jobs nor augments the earnings provided by the low-wage jobs at the bottom of the wage structure. More or better social services won't work either, for the same reasons: No new jobs are created and wages are not augmented.
Welfare reform generally won't work either, and again for largely the same reasons. Reform usually does not expand the supply of jobs, and it usually does not function to supplement low wages. To the extent that some welfare reform initiatives do achieve these goals, they suffer from two fundamental flaws. First, welfare reform's efforts to create jobs (by "workfare" or other means) or bolster wages (by letting benefits remain in place after recipients get employment) terminate at some fixed point in time. Second, and worse, welfare reform's attempts to
create jobs or bolster wages help only the relatively small percentage of poor who get welfare in the first place. Welfare reform by its very nature does not help the vast majority of poor -- who aren't on welfare -- to get jobs or augment earnings.
The poor will benefit, of course, from any general expansion of employment in the economy -- the last solution mentioned in your series. It is universally acknowledged, however, that the poor benefit in only a limited way when employment expands across the board. Too many of the new jobs are taken by non-poor competitors (such as teen-agers, college students, second-earners, and the elderly), who always enter and advance quickly in the queue for "untargeted" new jobs when more jobs are created on a general scale. One can hardly begrudge these competitors: while not officially poor, many are far from well-off. They need the money too.
In the final analysis, there are only two practical methods of ending poverty in the United States. Give the poor money -- so much money that they get out of poverty. Or get the poor into jobs -- and then make sure the jobs they then take or already hold (for most poor adults work in the first place) yield an "earnings-related income," consisting of wages and earnings supplements, higher than the poverty line. Only these two approaches correct for the basic problem: the economy's shortage of jobs and its plethora of low-wage jobs.
The first solution, whether it be called the Guaranteed Annual Income or the Negative Income Tax or something else, fell from grace over a decade ago. And for good reason. The poor don't want free money: they want jobs. And the rest of us don't want to give the poor free money: we expect the overwhelming majority of them, who are fit for work, to perform work to earn a living, just like us.
The second solution -- basically, a combination of a revived Civilian Conservation Corps and an expanded Earned Income Tax Credit -- thus emerges as the only practical, justifiable and politically acceptable solution to poverty in the United States. I add politically acceptable with care. Public opinion poll after public opinion poll has confirmed that the great majority of Americans believe that the unemployed poor should be offered community service employment if they cannot secure jobs in the private sector.
A revived C.C.C., an expanded E.I.T.C., and some help (based on ability to pay) with the high cost of child and health care -- financed by eliminating Aid to Families With Dependent Children, Food Stamps, half of Medicaid, and most every other Federal program that deals with the symptoms of poverty -- is the combination of public policies that the United States needs to transform its missing agenda into its rediscovery of justice.
 
DAVID R. RIEMER
Director of Administration
City of Milwaukee
Milwaukee, Jan. 31, 1991

HEADLINE: Employers Favor Student 'Warranty'

 BODY:
To the Editor:
We commend Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez's proposal to provide a warranty of employability to high school students. As "A 'Guarantee' for Graduates" (editorial, Jan. 15) points out, New York City employers complain that many graduates often lack the skills and the basic performance standards of the workplace.
In December 1989 we recommended to Mayor David N. Dinkins a strategy for economic growth in the 1990's. That strategy called for a variety of initiatives, including the creation of a curricular work experience program in the city's high schools that would lead to a certificate of employability, testifying that the graduates are ready for the workplace.
An information-intensive economy can be supported only by a work force with strong language, computation, problem-solving, communication and interpersonal skills. A certificate of employability could be a major step toward bridging the skills gap among thousands of unemployed youth in our city and the demands of a modern economy.
 
RONALD K. SHELP
Pres., New York City Partnership
New York, Jan. 23, 1991

HEADLINE: Europe Has Its Share Of Airline Problems

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Feb. 4

 BODY:
Airlines in the United States are not the only ones reeling from the Persian Gulf war. Uncertainty and a fear of terrorism generated by the conflict have also severely depressed the business of European airlines, which like American carriers had already been hit hard when fuel prices soared last year after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait.
Slowing economies in Europe, especially in Britain and Sweden, have also hurt the airline business. All told, major European airlines are reporting that the number of passengers has dropped 10 to 30 percent, and they have been cutting domestic and international service accordingly. 
 According to the 21-member Association of European Airlines, international flights within Europe were only 35 percent full in the last week of January. Lufthansa's planes have been flying 40 percent full on average since the war broke out, down from 60 percent. Late last month, London's two biggest airports, Heathrow and Gatwick, reported passenger traffic down 24 and 19 percent, respectively, from a year earlier.
Some carriers, including Scandinavian Airlines System and Air France, have announced plans to delay or cancel plane orders, although Air France said it made the decision before the war broke out. S.A.S. has also announced plans to reduce employment by 3,500, or 15.9 percent, by the end of 1992.
Olympic Airways, owned by the Greek Government, said it would have difficulty staying in business if the industry remained depressed for long. "For the time being, we are surviving, but who knows about the future," said Mark Xenakis, Olympic's assistant director general. He said Olympic had lost $67 million since the gulf crisis began in early August.
Besides Olympic, other airlines that might have trouble surviving in their current form include Alitalia of Italy, Sabena of Belgium and Iberia of Spain, said Richard Whitaker, editor of Airline Business, a trade magazine based in Sutton, England.
The European airlines' troubles have raised questions about whether the European Community will slow its program aimed at increasing competition and reducing state subsidies. "That's the big unknown today," said Andrew Chambers, a London-based analyst at Nomura Research Institute Europe Ltd.
Most of the major European carriers are either completely or partly state-owned, and many were struggling even before the gulf crisis. These include Alitalia, Sabena, Iberia, Air France and, to a lesser extent, Lufthansa of Germany.
While the 21 carriers in the Association of European Airlines earned a total of $1.1 billion in 1989, the group undoubtedly suffered an operating loss in 1990, its first since 1981, said David Henderson, the association's manager of statistical information.
Mr. Whitaker wondered how many governments would be willing to continue to pour money into their national carriers. If the losses become too great, "it may change people's minds as to whether every country should have a flag carrier," he said.
The Belgian Government has already indicated its intention to reduce its stake in Sabena S.A., parent of Sabena Belgian World Airlines, to 26 percent from about 54 percent. The Government wants the company to find outside investors.
 
Sabena Deal Collapsed
 A deal that would have given British Airways and KLM Royal Dutch Airlines each a 20 percent stake in the Sabena airline fell apart in December. At that time, Sabena said it expected its airline to lose as much as five billion Belgian francs ($158.3 million) in 1990.
Industry executives and analysts say that if the difficulties persist, some airlines will urge the European Commission, the community's executive branch, to ease its opposition to state subsidies and to permit big carriers to cooperate in ways that might seem anti-competitive.
The community has already taken steps to allow more competition in fares, but some industry executives would undoubtedly like to see delays on other planned actions. These include changes in the system for allocating landing and takeoff rights that could take rights away from big carriers, and opening international and domestic markets to much more competition.
"We don't think there will be any substantial delays or changes" in the deregulation program, said David Burnside, a spokesman for British Airways, which has generally been one of the strongest industry supporters of deregulation.
Carel Paauwe, the Amsterdam-based head of the transportation practice of McKinsey & Company, the management consulting firm, said the pace of deregulation would not slow very much unless the downturn dragged on and threatened the survival of some big airlines. "If one or two were really in danger of going under, then I think governments would have second thoughts," he said.
 
Hiring of Pilots Is an Issue
 Airlines would like to see cuts in airport fees, which are much higher in Europe than in the United States. They have also urged the commission to delay communitywide limits on how many hours pilots can fly and to make it easier for a carrier in one country to hire pilots in other nations where salaries are lower, said Stephen Wheatcroft, a London-based industry consultant and former executive at British Airways.
The major European carriers that have been the most profitable are British Airways, which has been investor-owned since 1987; KLM, which is 38 percent owned by the Netherlands, and Scandinavian Airlines System, which is half-owned by the Governments of Sweden, Denmark and Norway. But after being stung by the leap in fuel prices and the plunge in the number of passengers, analysts think that even the relatively efficient airlines are operating in the red.
British Airways, Europe's biggest carrier, said it expects to report a loss for the second half of its current fiscal year (the six months that end March 31). In reaction to the sharp downturn in business, it has cut its global service by 10.5 percent on average. The airline had previously announced it was abandoning service between Britain and the Irish Republic, beginning in March.
 
Talk of Layoffs
 Before the war broke out, British Airways had announced plans to cut costs by at least 100 million ($197.7 million) by the end of 1991. While it originally said these plans would not involve large layoffs, reports in British newspapers say the airline now has contingency plans to lay off up to 5,000 workers, or 10 percent of its work force. A spokesman would neither confirm nor deny those figures. The spokesman said no layoffs were imminent but the airline might have to resort to such action.
British Airways has told employees they can take up to three months of unpaid leave. To encourage that, it has offered to give free tickets to employees and their families to anywhere the airline flies if the employee takes at least one month off.
The airline has delayed until spring its plans to order planes to replace its fleet of 25 Lockheed Tristar and McDonnell Douglas DC-10 jetliners. It had planned to place the order by the end of last year.
Scandinavian Airlines System aims to cut its costs by three billion kronor ($540.1 million) by the end of 1992. S.A.S., which says the number of passengers has fallen by 20 to 40 percent, depending on the route, is cutting its flights by about 15 percent, said John Herbert, an S.A.S. spokesman. S.A.S. executives have said the airline probably broke even in 1990.
KLM Royal Dutch Airlines said last week that it would drastically cut service to European and United States destinations. The carrier will cut its capacity within Europe by 20 percent by canceling and combining flights and using smaller aircraft. Nine of KLM's 49 destinations in the United States are being dropped.
 
Cutbacks at Air France
 Air France has cut service in Europe but would not say by how much. In the week of Jan. 15-21, the week the Iraq war started, its traffic was down 16 percent from a year earlier. Even before the war, Air France had imposed a freeze on most hiring and announced plans to reduce or eliminate service on unprofitable routes.
The company, which also owns two smaller French carriers, Air Inter and Union des Transports Ariens, has delayed by one year the delivery of seven long-range Airbus 340's, which it was supposed to receive in the 1994-96 period. It has also delayed the delivery of six other planes it has options to buy and canceled options on seven other planes.
Lufthansa has cut 120 of its 1,000 or so flights to destinations in Europe, mainly within Germany, until at least Feb. 27. While Lufthansa is not contemplating layoffs, it is talking with worker representatives about reducing overtime, encouraging employees to take leftover vacation now and moving up training. Lufthansa executives say the airline will report a small profit for 1990 as a whole because traffic rose sharply in November and December as a result of German reunification.

CORRECTION-DATE: February 6, 1991, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day yesterday about the impact of the Persian Gulf war on European airlines misstated the number of United States cities served by KLM Royal Dutch Airlines and the number of flights from those cities that it has canceled. The line serves 8 cities in the United States and has canceled 5 of its 49 flights from them.

HEADLINE: THE FEDERAL BUDGET: The Overview;
PRESIDENT SUBMITS SPENDING PACKAGE TIED TO OPTIMISM

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4

 BODY:
President Bush today sent Congress a 1992 budget request of $1.45 trillion that admittedly understates the cost of the Persian Gulf war, offers no measures to combat the recession and seeks to redistribute some Federal subsidies that now go to the most affluent.
The President's budget, for the fiscal year that begins next Oct. 1, tries to pull together the strands of his domestic policy into a semblance of a coherent whole, proposing selective increases in money for education, children's health care, highways and scientific research. 
 It also reflects the most comprehensive effort yet to reshape the American military in the face of international political changes, although some significant questions were left unanswered in Mr. Bush's request for the Pentagon. [Page A18.]
 
Growth in Benefits Lamented
 The director of the Office of Management and Budget, Richard G. Darman, echoed remarks made by a predecessor a decade ago as he lamented "explosive growth" in Federal benefit payments to individuals. Mr. Bush's budget would cut $46.6 billion from the projected total of such spending over the next five years, including $25 billion from Medicare and $3.5 billion from veterans' benefits. Mr. Darman's words, in a statement accompanying Mr. Bush's proposals, were reminiscent of those made by David A. Stockman, the first budget director in the Reagan Administration.
Indeed, perhaps the most politically explosive elements of the budget are proposals to curtail benefits that middle- and upper-income families receive through Medicare, farm price supports, the school lunch program and Pell Grants for college students.
The intitial reaction from some leading Congressional Democrats was cool, but they did not reject Mr. Bush's proposals out of hand.
"It's pretty much what we expected," said Representative Leon E. Panetta of California, chairman of the House Budget Committee. Senator Jim Sasser of Tennessee, chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, said Mr. Bush was recycling "hoary old mossback proposals," including Medicare cuts, that had been repeatedly rejected.
 
Byrd and Nunn Comment
 But Senate Robert C. Byrd, chairman of the Appropriations Committee, expressed satisfaction that Mr. Bush was finally showing interest in programs that Mr. Byrd has championed for years. By investing in selected health, education, transportation and research programs, the Bush budget would "start to reverse the trends of past years," said Mr. Byrd, a West Virginia Democrat.
And Senator Sam Nunn, the Georgia Democrat who heads the Armed Services Committee, said Mr. Bush's military budget, which would be 1 percent lower than this year's spending, was generally "the right way to proceed," in view of a diminished threat from the Soviet Union.
As the Congressional debate over the budget proceeds in the months ahead, perhaps the biggest fights will deal with the President's proposals to slash benefits to relatively well-off Americans. For instance, for elderly people with incomes over $125,000 a year, Medicare premiums, set at $31.80 a month next year under current law, would nearly triple, and the Agriculture Department would stop paying crop subsidies to farmers who have non-farm income of more than $125,000.
About 550,000 of the 33 million Medicare beneficiaries have annual incomes over $125,000. Raising their premiums would save the Government $1.2 billion over five years, the Administration estimated. In recent years, the Government has paid crop subsidies to more than 10,000 people with at least $125,000 of income from sources unrelated to agriculture. The Government says it could save $396 million over five years by eliminating such payments.
 
Focus on College Aid
 Mr. Bush, like President Ronald Reagan before him, said he wanted to "reduce governmental subsidies for those who are not in need." In some cases, the savings would be redistributed to low-income people, as Mr. Bush tries to seize the "fairness" issue from Democrats.
Thus, for example, the maximum Pell Grant, now $2,400, would be increased next year to $3,700, and the rules would be revised so that most of the aid goes to "students from the lowest-income families," meaning those with incomes of less than $10,000 a year.
But the benefits that affluent people lose under Mr. Bush's proposals would be dwarfed by the benefits that some of them receive from his proposal to cut the Federal tax on profits from investments. As a result of this proposal, the capital gains tax would be capped at rates that would depend on the length of time that the sold assets had been held. The lowest rate, for assets held at least three years, would be 19.6 percent.
Robert Greenstein, director of the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a research group that favors the strengthening of welfare programs, said, "Large new benefits would be conferred on the wealthiest Americans, primarily through a capital gains tax cut, while no additional support whatsoever is provided to workers who are unemployed and cannot find new jobs."
 
Optimistic on Recession
 Mr. Bush said there was no need for new spending to stimulate the economy because the recession would be over by midyear. Mr. Bush proposed no additional benefits for the unemployed. Indeed, he proposed to eliminate Federal benefits paid to workers who lose their jobs as a result of competition from imports.
Mr. Bush said he foresaw deficits of $318 billion this year and $281 billion next year, far higher than the record of $221 billion set in 1986. Those numbers are almost certainly too optimistic; in addition to its assumption about the recession, Mr. Bush's budget, by his own admission, understates the cost of the Persian Gulf war.
Because the war began after the appropriations bills for the 1991 fiscal year were enacted, it was not until today, with the release of the 1992 budget, that the Administration started taking account of the costs. The budget assumes $8.2 billion for such costs in the current fiscal year and $4.6 billion in 1992.
The war is estimated to cost at least $500 million a day, which far exceeds the budget's assumptions. But Mr. Darman said that foreign contributions are $51 billion to date and that the Administration would send Congress a supplemental request for more money in a few months.
 
Many Programs Are Targets
 Mr. Bush's budget would end 238 domestic programs and 64 military programs, saving $4.6 billion and $7 billion, respectively.
Mr. Bush's military budget envisions a slow, steady decline in Pentagon spending. Mr. Bush would halt the Army's Bradley Fighting Vehicle, the Navy's Trident ballistic missile submarine and the Air Force F-16 fighter jet.
But the President seeks a 58 percent increase in the space-based missile defense system known as "Star Wars," to $4.6 billion next year, a request quickly derided as unrealistic by Democrats.
Interest payments on the Federal debt eat up $206.3 billion, or more than 14 percent of all Federal spending in Mr. Bush's budget for 1992. Federal debt held by the public soared from $785 billion in 1981, when Mr. Reagan took office, to $2.7 trillion this year and will reach nearly $3 trillion next year, Mr. Bush reported.
 
Children's Health Issues
 Mr. Bush said his budget emphasizes investment in preventive health programs, especially those for children. Spending on the Special Supplemental Food Program for Women, Infants and Children, or WIC, would rise $223 million, to $2.6 billion next year from $2.4 billion this year.
The President's budget contains some apparent contradictions. While increasing the overall budget of the Education Department, Mr. Bush said he wants to slash Federal grants to public libraries, to $35 million from $84 million this year.
While boasting that his budget would increase spending on selected programs for children like Head Start, Mr. Bush proposes to cut funds for foster care by 16 percent.
Mr. Bush proposes to spend a total of $83 billion over the next five years to build and repair highways and bridges. Annual outlays would rise steadily, from $14.4 billion in 1992 to $17.9 billion in 1996.
Mr. Bush's economic forecast, showing economic growth of nine-tenths of 1 percent this year, after adjustment for inflation, was similar to estimates by private forecasters. But Mr. Darman, like many of his predecessors, offered an optimistic projection of the deficit, saying it would drop to $2.9 billion in 1995.

CORRECTION-DATE: February 9, 1991, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday summarizing the Bush Administration's domestic spending proposals for the 1992 fiscal year misstated the amount of an increase in spending for the Federal Aviation Administration. Spending would rise 14 percent, to $9.3 billion,not 10 percent, to $4.5 billion. The article also referred incorrectly to a spending proposal for Amtrak. That Administration request, for $485 million, is the first request in seven years for any funds for the passenger rail service, not the first in seven years for an increase.

HEADLINE: THE DOCTOR'S WORLD;
Editor of Journal Envisions New Directions and Lighter Tone

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE K. ALTMAN, M.D.

 BODY:
ON July 1, Dr. Jerome P. Kassirer, a 58-year-old expert in kidney disorders, will become editor of The New England Journal of Medicine and one of the world's most powerful doctors.
For a physician like Dr. Kassirer with a rich background in medical editing and a flair for writing, the prospect of editing a journal that has long been an acknowledged leader in scientific research and opinion would surely seem appealing. 
 Yet six weeks ago, Dr. Kassirer said he would have dismissed as "crazy" any notion that he wanted the job. Indeed, when the journal issued a call for applicants for the post a few months ago, he was uninterested.
But colleagues, including his wife, Sheridan, a hospital administrator, told him he would be a good candidate for the job. And last week the once reluctant candidate said he was "thrilled" to succeed the retiring editor, Dr. Arnold S. Relman, who is 68.
By choosing which research papers to publish and which to reject, the editor can help shape medical practice and strongly influence grants for future research projects and for academic promotions. In recent decades, the journal has emphasized economic and social issues involving health care, and the editor's power to write and select editorials can influence political agendas.
Dr. Relman, for instance, wrote editorials criticizing the medical-industrial complex, medical practiceand social and economic issues that drew praise from many. But they also angered organized medicine, including members of the Massachusetts Medical Society, the journal's owner. By refusing to publish papers if the findings have been previously publicized, the journal has left many researchers unwilling to discuss their work ahead of time. This policy has been criticized for causing delays in applying new treatments and possibly deaths.
Although he said he was "not a power seeker," Dr. Kassirer acknowledged in an interview that his seat was one of the most visible and hottest in medicine and that journal editors had enormous power because of their role as stewards of medical knowledge.
Dr. Kassirer said that he had been assured of independence from the medical society and that he intended to speak out on various issues after learning his new job. His first task will be to take a fresh look at every page of the journal and its policies.
"Medical journals shouldn't be static " he said. "They should change. What directions we'll go in are up for grabs."
 Founded in Boston in 1812, The New England Journal of Medicine describes itself as the oldest continually published medical journal in the world. Dr. Kassirer will be its 38th editor.
He told the committee that selected him that he hoped to lighten the tone of the journal and improve its readability. An experienced medical columnist, he writes in a chatty style with a light touch and has a knack for catchier headlines than those in most scientific journals.
Although he will be editing a journal for doctors, one eye will be on the public. "Increasingly the general public are the readers of the journal," he said, because reports of new advances affect medical practice and health policy and the contents are transmitted to the public through news organizations.
The medical society said it chose Dr. Kassirer after a worldwide search. Yet, like all previous searches, the latest came back for an editor who had worked in Boston.
There, Dr. Kassirer is associate physician-in-chief of the New England Medical Center. For 32 years, he has also taught and done research at Tufts University School of Medicine. His team has pioneered in developing mathematical methods to analyze the way doctors make decisions about diagnosing and treating patients, particularly those with difficult problems.
He has long advocated the idea that doctors should help patients participate in decisions about their own care, saying doctors must not abdicate their responsibility in informing patients about the medical facts in their cases.
In his research, Dr. Kassirer has fed chunks of data to clinicians who are asked to think aloud as they try to solve a clinical problem. The researchers record the doctors' comments and later trace the thought processes.
Dr. Kassirer has been a critic of the teaching and practice that leads doctors to order excessive numbers of costly and sometimes dangerous tests in a stubborn quest for diagnostic certainty that often outweighs common sense. He has called for further study to determine how much, if any, quality would be lost if the number of tests was cut.
Many tests are carried out merely to confirm a diagnosis that is virtually certain, and there is need to weed out tests and procedures that are ineffective or superfluous, Dr. Kassirer said. He traces part of the problem to medical textbooks that he says "are rife with absolutes."
For six years, Dr. Kassirer has written a popular column on clinical decision making for Hospital Practice, which HP Publishing Company publishes in New York City. In one column he analyzed how a doctor made the right diagnosis for the wrong reasons. In another, he described how a doctor made the wrong diagnosis, ordered the wrong tests and prescribed the wrong treatment.
Dr. Kassirer has also helped edit a section of Kidney International, a monthly specialty journal published by Springer-Verlag in New York City. He said that he had learned "how poorly many supposedly distinguished researchers and clinicians write" and that "many times I have had to take their papers apart and put them back together again."
 Although he did not intend to become a medical journalist, he said he has had ideal training for his new job.
"If I had to ask myself 15 years ago what would I do to best prepare myself to be editor of The New England Journal of Medicine, I would have done what I did," he said. "But I would never have dreamed that any of that would have led me there."
Dr. Kassirer regularly reads Science and Annals of Internal Medicine as closely as The New England Journal of Medicine. As he began to focus on the nature of the scientific journalism world he was about to enter, Dr. Kassirer said he was dismayed to read an article in Science last week about the increasingly fierce competition among such journals as Nature, Cell and Science to be the first to publish major results.
"In trying to make themselves look the best, the journals overlooked the real reason for doing research, which is to advance science and medicine," Dr. Kassirer said, adding that he "would not have wanted to be one of the editors" cited.
Dr. Kassirer has been an official of the American College of Physicians in Philadelphia but said he never joined the American Medical Association.
"Systemic reforms are needed" in controlling the costs of medical care, making access to care more equitable and reducing the bureaucracy that has built up around health care, he said. But he expressed strong reservations about a Government-run national health insurance plan.
"The Government doesn't always do things particularly well, and since national health insurance involves the Government I am not convinced that would be the best way to go," he said.
With 220,000 subscribers, The New England Journal of Medicine says it has the largest paid circulation of any medical journal. Its profits have soared in recent years. But Dr. Kassirer said the Massachusetts Medical Society cited only the quality of the journal and not its economics as a criterion for renewing his contract when it expires in three years. But he said he would consider a fall in circulation a personal failure.

HEADLINE: Gorbachev to Disregard Lithuanian Vote

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: VILNIUS, Lithuania, Feb. 5

 BODY:
President Mikhail S. Gorbachev decreed today that a plebiscite on Lithuanian independence scheduled for Saturday is "without legal foundation," once again challenging the Baltic republic's efforts to break free of the Soviet Union.
"With this poll, the Lithuanian leaders are trying to generate support for their separatist aim," the Soviet press agency Tass said, quoting from the presidential decree. 
 Most Lithuanian officials in the Parliament building, which has been barricaded against Soviet troops since they attacked Lithuanian sites last month, interpreted Mr. Gorbachev's statement as an advance signal that Moscow will not recognize the outcome of the vote, which is expected to be an overwhelming endorsement of independence. They noted that the decree carried no explicit threat, and that Mr. Gorbachev's phrasing was short of declaring the vote illegal.
The Lithuanian President, Vytautas Landsbergis, denounced Mr. Gorbachev's decree as "impermissible political interference in the affairs of the sovereign Lithuanian state."
In a statement issued by his press office, Mr. Landsbergis said, "The decree of the U.S.S.R. President on the Lithuanian citizens' nationwide poll reflects an old tradition of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, according to which law and government derive not from the will of the people expressed by free votes, but are formed by the decree of autocratic rulers."
 
A Proposition Simply Worded
 The sole question Lithuanians will be asked to answer on Saturday is whether they support Lithuania's becoming "an independent democratic republic." Mr. Landsbergis' government has termed called the plebiscite a "public opinion poll," evidently to distinguish it from a more binding referendum.
The question is expected to get an overwhelming "yes" from people of Lithuanian heritage, who account for akmost 80 percent of the republic's population. The response of people of Russian and Polish heritage, who account for much of the rest of the population, is less certain.
Mr. Gorbachev's decree invalidating the Lithuanian plebiscite joined an increasing arsenal that the Kremlin has mobilized to fight a Lithuanian move to leave the Soviet Union. The most dramatic of these were the tanks used by the Soviet Army to storm the television tower on Jan. 12, with the loss of 14 lives. The central Government has also imposed an economic blockade against Lithuania for five months, and has tried a variety of lesser measures and intimidations.
Mr. Gorbachev's latest sally came as Moscow appeared to be floating some conciliatory signals on Lithuania. Last week, the Soviet President appointed a standing commission to negotiate with the Lithuanians, which is expected to arrive in Vilnius on Friday. The Lithuanian authorities, however, say they have yet to receive formal notification of the delegation, and has suggested that the announcement was intended more to placate Western critics.
Other conciliatory signs have included an announcement that the Committee of National Salvation, in whose name Soviet tanks rolled, has been disbanded, and the suspension of nighttime military patrols on Vilnius streets.
 
Stamps Undelivered
 In addition, the Minister of Posts and Telecommunication, Kostas Birulis, said Moscow had agreed to recognize Lithuanian postage stamps -- of which the first batch, printed in Leipzig, Germany, was confiscated at the Lithuanian border.
Mr. Birulis also said that officials from the national radio and television board in Moscow had sounded him out about lifting the military occupation of the Vilnius television tower in exchange for a guarantee of two hours' air time for pro-Moscow programs.
The conciliatory gestures were viewed to some degree as a recognition in the Kremlin that the military raid had done serious damage to Moscow's standing abroad, and in the Soviet Union had only served to fan Lithuanian nationalism, rally support for the Lithuanians' cause in other republics and further undermine Mr. Gorbachev's fading political stature.

HEADLINE: U.S. to Close Nuclear Sub Base in Scotland in '92

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Feb. 5

 BODY:
The United States nuclear submarine base at Holy Loch, Scotland, which opened despite strong antiwar protests and British Government misgivings in the early 1960's, will close sometime next year, Defense Secretary Tom King told the House of Commons today.
As eight-engine American B-52 aircraft began flying today into the Royal Air Force base at Fairford, England, to carry out raids against Iraq, Mr. King also said the American F-111 aircraft based in Britain of the type that bombed targets in Libya in 1986 wouldbe replaced beginning in 1992 by a smaller number of more advanced American nuclear-capable F-15E's. 
 The moves made clear that despite the war in the Persian Gulf, the end of the cold war with the Soviet Union still means significant military cutbacks in American and British forces.
A Scottish Labor Party Member of Parliament, Brian Wilson, who took part in the protests against the Holy Loch base when it was set up, said: "I have always been opposed to the American presence there, and I would view their withdrawal with unmitigated enthusiasm. There would obviously be a period of economic adjustment, butthat is going to come some time, and better sooner than later."
Secret British Cabinet papers made public last month showed that Prime Minister Harold Macmillan had tried and failed to persuade President Dwight D. Eisenhower to site the submarine base further away from Glasgow, where 755,000 people now live.
"It would surely be a mistake to put down what will become a major nuclear target so near to the third largest and the most overcrowded city in this country," Mr. Macmillan wrote in a letter to the President in June 1960, when the United States was proposing to locate the base at Gare Loch, about 10miles east of where it eventually was.
The British proposed a much further north and more isolated site at Loch Linnhe, near Fort William, but the United States rejected it as being too far from social amenities and posed unacceptable navigation problems. Britain also tried in vain to get the United States to agree to some form of partial British control over the base and the nuclear weapons that would be carried aboard the submarines, according to the Cabinet papers.
President Eisenhower made little concession, but finally wrote to Mr. Macmillan on Oct. 27, 1960, "In the event of an emergency, such as increased tension or the threat of war, the U.S. will take every possible step to consult with Britain and other allies," according to the British archives. Prime Minister Macmillan announcedthe plan to open the base at Holy Loch on Nov. 1, and the first Polaris submarine sailed in on March 8, 1961.
The announcement that the base would be closed was welcomed today by groups supporting owners of Scottish fishing vessels that have mysteriously vanished without trace in the area, reportedly after submarines running beneath the surface snagged their fishing nets and dragged them under.
Mr. King said the United States Navy would no longer need the base at Holy Loch by the end of this year because it was replacing the obsolete Poseidon missile submarines that used it for repairs and service with bigger Trident boats, four of which are also being bought by the British Navy.
Holy Loch now houses 2,000 American personnel, 1,600 dependents, and employs about 150 Scottish workers.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Surprising Profits Of Futures Funds

BYLINE: By H. J. Maidenberg

 BODY:
SPECULATORS in commodity futures are a curious lot. They make contracts either to buy goods they do not want or to sell goods they have no intention of delivering.
In either case, the overwhelming majority of individual speculators in commodity futures share a common experience: despite the large profit potential in their highly leveraged trading, they lose money. The leverage results because the initial cash outlay required to buy or sell a futures contract is less than 10 percent. 
 Despite these dismal odds, many futures speculators are reluctant to invest in commodity funds because the record of those funds is even more abysmal than the experiences of individuals.
While all this is hardly news to the commodity trading fraternity, many people have been surprised by the uncommonly large profits many publicly offered commodity funds made last year.
Based on the Norwood Index, the most respected measure of such funds' performance, the 135 publicly offered funds produced an aggregate profit of 17.7 percent in 1990, compared with a loss of 5 percent in 1989. In dollar terms, 1990 ended with a gain of $395 million on total equity of $3 billion. There are many other commodity funds, however; the Norwood Index surveys only those that agree to full disclosure of operating results.
"The results for 1990 have been astounding, given the past track record of commodity funds," said Daniel B. Stark, who heads a research firm bearing his name in Palatine, Ill. Mr. Stark now monitors the Norwood Index, which was createdyears ago as a research project by Jay Klopfenstein, who still heads the Norwood Securities Corporation of Chicago, a brokerage house that has never been involved in commodity trading.
Mr. Stark attributed the gains to profits that most funds made from trading currency futures in a year when the dollar was under pressure. "From our study of the trading records, it also seems that the trend followers did quite well," he said.
The big trend in futures in 1990, one that has continued this year, was the steady erosion of prices of both farm and industrial commodities, because of the growing worldwide recession. As the recession became pronounced last fall, interest rates began to decline steadily, which continues to benefit the followers of the trend in financial futures.
In any case, the profits of the monitored funds in 1990 stand in sharp contrast to the results of past years. For many years, transaction costs and other expenses chewed up whatever profits the funds made. The best shareholders could hope for was the common practice of dissolving a fund once it lost 50 percent of its assets, distributing what was left to shareholders.
The poor overall performance of commodity funds, as compared with stock mutual funds, has led many in the industry to experiment with all kinds of trading practices. Perhaps the most successful to date has been that developed through trial and error by the Commodities CorporationU.S.A. of Princeton, N.J., in 1969.
As a result, Robert G. Easton, president and chief executive of the Commodities Corporation, expects the management of commodity funds to undergo a complete change in coming years as more funds and managed accounts emulate his company's system.
"The basic problem was just as apparent in 1969 as it is now," Mr. Easton said. "Those who trade commodity futures, as well as those who invest in funds, have the cards stacked against them. Why? For one, the average futures broker depends on commissions for the bulk of his income." Another, more recent problem, he said, is that research departments have been cut back, "the first casualty of the brokerage industry's drive to cut overhead at a time of shrinking profits."
The founders of the Commodities Corporation, who include Paul Samuelson, the Nobel laureate in economics who is still active in the company, believed that a different breed of futures broker had to be developed, along with a new set of trading controls and practices.
The Commodities Corporation, for example, uses more than 160 independent traders to trade futures for its public funds, which are distributed through various brokerage houses. It also manages the accounts of wealthy individual speculators, and it services insurance companies, pension funds and other institutions that increasingly hedge their investments in the futures market.
"We don't care if the trader we use operates from a yacht on the French Riviera or from a cabin in Alaska or from the floor of one of the commodity exchanges," said Barry I. Bregman, vice president-human resources of the Commodities Corporation. "All we are interested in is the trading profits -- not commissions -- they produce for our various funds and clients."

HEADLINE: Orders to Factories Showed No Change in December

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5

 BODY:
Despite huge purchases of military goods and commercial aircraft, the overall level of orders to factories was unchanged in December, helping depress the increase for all of 1990 to a meager 1.4 percent, the Government reported today.
Some analysts said the report, which showed the worst performance in four years, was an indication that the recession may not be as mild as predicted. 
 "The economy very clearly is in trouble," said Robert Brusca, an economist with Nikko Securities Company in New York. "This is going to be a very typical-to-severe recession."
 
Job Losses Cited
 Elliott Platt, an economist at the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation, agreed that the recession "may be more severe than we originally thought," in light of the recent data, including a huge loss of jobs in January.
The Commerce Department reported today that orders for durable and nondurable goods totaled $235.6 billion in December. For the year, orders edged up 1.4 percent, to $2.9 trillion, the smallest gain since 1986, when orders fell 1.2 percent.
The report also said orders plunged a revised 5.8 percent in November, the largest drop since a 7 percent decline in December 1974. The November decline was first estimated at 5.9 percent.
December figures reported earlier by the Labor Department showed that factory payrolls fell by 33,000 that month, bringing to nearly 600,000 the number of manufacturing jobs lost since December 1989. Last week, in its report for January, the Labor Department said the unemployment rate had climbed to 6.2 percent, the highest since 1987, and that another 69,000 factory jobs had been lost.
The Commerce Department report today said orders for durable goods -- expensive items expected to last more than three years -- advanced 3.4 percent, to $120.3 billion, even slower than the 4.4 percent gain first reported last week. But that failed to make up for a 10.1 percent drop a month earlier.
The report said that the increase was concentrated in military and commercial aircraft orders and that excluding those categories, orders fell 4.7 percent in December.
 
'Erratic Movements'
 The overall durable goods increase was offset by a 3.4 percent decline in nondurable goods, to $115.3 billion. The decline, the second consecutive monthly drop, reflected "erratic movements in the petroleum, chemicals and tobacco industries," the department said.
In the durables category, the transportation sector posted a 13.6 percent gain, to $32 billion, after falling 25.3 percent in November. Military orders and commercial aircraft bookings more than offset a large decline in motor vehicle orders. But excluding transportation, orders fell 1.9 percent.
Military orders were up 59.8 percent, to $8.4 billion. Analysts attributed it to the military buildup in the Persian Gulf. Excluding the military sector, factory orders fell 1.4 percent. Military orders had fallen 26.9 percent in November.
Orders for electrical machinery increased 12.6 percent, to $20.8 billion, rebounding from a 7.2 percent loss a month earlier. Most of the gain was attributed to communications equipment. But nonelectrical machinery orders fell 6.9 percent, to $20.6 billion. The decline was the third straight drop, including a fall of five-tenths of 1 percent in November.

HEADLINE: As Many Fall, Project's Survivors Struggle On

SERIES: Life in The Towers: Home In a Hard Place - Last of three articles.

BYLINE: By DON TERRY

 BODY:
On a crisp winter afternoon, a half-dozen middle-aged black men huddled around a chess table in the shadow of the Martin Luther King Jr. Towers in Harlem.
The men grew up together in the project. Back then they didn't play much chess. When they were teen-agers, they called themselves the 115th Street Boys or the Imperial Knights, a rumble-ready gang of lean, tough youths from the ghetto. 
 Thirty years later, still hanging out together in the project when work and family allow, they call themselves the Survivors.
 
'So Many Brothers Never Made It'
 Many of their friends and dreams died young long, long ago. But these men -- Vic, Walt, Rog and the other "brothers" -- have made it through the hard times, the gang fights, the closed factories and the bitter disappointments that have fallen on them and theirs like a harsh rain.
"I'm lucky to be alive," said Victor Buford, a 48-year-old former boxer who fought for as little as $50 a night before things really got bad. "So many brothers never made it. I'm a survivor."
King Towers, in the words of Walter Drayton, another regular at the chess table, "is full of survivors." Like many of New York's working-poor neighborhoods, these three city blocks framed by Fifth and Lenox Avenues, 112th and 115th Streets, are a place of considerable permanence and continuity amid adversity, where the average tenant spends 21 years and many stay for generations.
Some of these survivors have moved up to the middle class and away; they have fulfilled the promise of the projects but still return. Others are growing old at King Towers and lack the money, the hope or even the inclination to live anywhere else. Others still dream of escape.
To talk to them all is to talk of life in a hard place, getting harder. The surrounding neighborhood has been punched and kicked by crime, homelessness and numbing poverty for years. Now the blows are beginning to pile up, staggering even the most traditionally stable sections of Harlem, including King Towers.
"Growing up, there were black-owned stores in the neighborhood," Mr. Buford said. "We had role models, people to look up to. That's all gone now. The community has been dismantled. Drugs are killing us."
"So many politicians have their hands in the till," said Roger Shepherd, a 37-year-old kitchen aide at a state hospital. "Cops, too. Now they want to blame the poor for New York falling. It's crazy."
Still, they are survivors.
"Why do we stay?" asked Mr. Drayton, who is 42. "Did you hear that, Victor? He wants to know why we stay. We stay because this is home. This is where we were raised and where we raised our kids. This is where we know everybody and everybody knows us.
"And, there ain't nowhere else to go. The system has us in a jar with the lid on tight."
In King Towers, home is both castle and prison.
 
Hard Times
Hold Onto a Job With Both Hands
A few days later, a gypsy cab pulled into King Towers. In Harlem, yellow cabs are like buffalo -- rare.
The driver jumped out and helped a frail old woman climb slowly down to the street. He carried her grocery bags to the sidewalk and then called out to a young woman walking along the street with a child.
"Will you help her inside her house?" the driver asked.
"No," the woman said. "Why don't you?"
"I can't leave my car out here," he said. "I hope you drop dead."
The cabby drove off, leaving the old woman looking scared on the curb. Then Mr. Shepherd, who had been standing nearby, stepped forward and carried the woman's bags to her apartment.
"I never come out this late," the woman said.
It was 5 P.M.
 
'Relieve the Pressure'
 Mr. Shepherd grew up in King Towers. He and Mr. Buford are cousins. And though he now lives in the Bronx, he stops by the project almost every day to see his friends and his family.
"Times are real hard," Mr. Shepherd said. "The job I have now, I'm holding onto with both hands."
Mr. Shepherd walked slowly around the project and paused in front of the Two Way Market, a grocery and liquor store on 115th Street.
"They got as many liquor stores around here as churches," he said. "When you got so much tension you got to do something to relieve the pressure. That's where the liquor stores come in."
He continued walking toward the corner of 115th and Lenox Avenue, a popular hangout for the project's young people, some of them waiting to buy or sell drugs.
"They," Mr. Shepherd said, meaning the government, "want us to settle for a little piece of nothing, like the Indians on the reservation. They got us fighting and killing each other for crumbs."
He sighed deeply. "In a way, the ones in jail are like political prisoners because they refused to settle for less."
 
The Success
Come Back To Give Back
Charles Williams, a 40-year-old administrator at Harlem Hospital, spent most of his first 25 years in King Towers. He earned a master's degree in social work and a ticket out of the projects.
But while he lives in the Bronx now, he has not forgotten his roots. He holds onto them tightly, proudly, sadly. He is president of the advisory board of the King Towers community center. "This will always be home," he said.
Mr. Williams is constantly on the telephone trying to convince other former residents "who have made it" -- police officers, teachers, a Federal drug agent -- to return and become role models for the development's young people, many of whom are being pushed and dragged by circumstance and misguided choice toward a life and premature death in the streets.
"Those of us who have made it must come back and give back to the community," he said. "Basically, we've got to change what's happening in King Towers, the way we treat each other."
Four nights after Christmas, the Survivors held a reunion dance in a recreation center a few blocks from King Towers.
"None of us have ever left each other," said Robert J. Truesdale, a member of the 115th Street Boys who grew up to serve in Vietnam, move to the Riverdale section of the Bronx, work as an area manager for Paine Webber and send his daughter to Princeton.
"A lot of us got killed over the years, but the rest of us make a point to get together," Mr. Truesdale said. "We've been best men at each other's weddings, godfathers to each other's children. We've been there for each other. I can remember a time when we had holes in our pockets. There are a lot of guys in here making $60,000 a year now. We've been to hell and back."
They have also been to too many funerals to remember.
 
3 Funerals in One Week
 During one week in November, they gathered to bury three men from King Towers, all in their mid-40's. One man overdosed on drugs; another died of cirrhosis. No one at the dance knew what had killed the third man.
"The streets are eating up everybody," said Richard Finney, 42.
Mr. Buford, one of the organizers of the reunion dance, was himself almost devoured by the streets.
He had tried his fortunes as a fighter after returning home from the Army in the mid-60's. But he was lucky to make more than $100 a fight, while some of his friends were "getting rich selling drugs."
"I started dealing, and that was my downfall," he said. "I had money, clothes, women. But you lose your soul being a drug dealer." Not only did he sell drugs, he used them and became heavily addicted. It took him five or six tries to kick his habit.
 
'I've Helped Destroy My People'
 "Then I said to myself and the Almighty, 'Thank God, I'm still alive,' " he said. "I said, 'I know I've helped destroy my people and I'm sorry.'
"I feel God kept me alive to do something more than that -- to help my people, especially these young brothers on the corner."
Mr. Buford and the other Survivors are hoping to raise enough money to buy a building and turn it into a community center.
"We want to help these young kids coming up," Mr. Drayton said. "Unless the men of the community stand up and give these kids some direction, we're finished. We're in a war, fighting for our youth."
"There are so many talented people here," Mr. Buford added. "But that talent isn't brought out because everybody is struggling. The pace is very fast. Kids grow up too fast. They don't have time for a childhood. I think it's designed to have our young people on the street. If you kill the youth, you kill a generation."
The city's Housing Authority already operates a youth center at King Towers, but it is underfinanced and understaffed. After paying staff salaries, the center can spend about $1,400 a year.
The center's director, Dianne Henderson, insists that "I'm pretty good with money." In her few months at King Towers, she has been searching for volunteers and role models to run recreational, educational and cultural programs. So far, many have promised to help, but few have stepped forward.
Ms. Henderson has found that talk is as cheap as a Saturday night special.
 
The Pioneer
'My Son Died Instantly'
For 40 years, Louise Vails has watched the ebb and flow of life at King Towers from a window of her first-floor apartment. She and her husband raised 10 children in the project, including their youngest, Nelson, who went on to win a silver medal for cycling in the 1984 Olympics.
"He made all of America feel proud that year," Mrs. Vails said. A framed photograph of her son standing between Ronald and Nancy Reagan hangs on her living-room wall.
Mrs. Vails was eight months pregnant with Nelson when one of her children, 18-year-old Albert, was killed on the stoop of her building. He was returning home from his job at a purse factory when a young man came up behind him and shot him in the head. They had had a dispute at a party a few days before.
"My son died instantly," Mrs. Vails said. "I never thought about moving. It was just one of those things. It could have happened anywhere."
Mrs. Vails, who is 72 years old, is both a survivor and a pioneer.
 
On Welfare, Then Off
 When she and her family moved into the project in 1951, only 2 of the 10 rust-colored high-rise buildings were completed, and the development was known as the Stephen Foster Houses. The name was changed shortly after the 1968 assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.
Her husband, Robert, drove a cab and worked in a hospital laundry room. He died in 1986. Mrs. Vails was a nurse's aide for 22 years. For a short time in the early 50's, while only Mr. Vails was working, the family received some welfare assistance. But "we got off of it as soon as I started working," Mrs. Vails said.
"Everything around here is, I'd say, 100 percent better than in the past 20 years," she said. "A lot of the young fellas who used to do bad things have grown up. They got married. They have families. They have jobs. Even the grounds are cleaner.
"The only reason people I know move out of the projects is to buy a house. But other than that, I never heard no one say the projects was bad. I myself wouldn't live anywhere else. Two of my children were born here."
One of Mrs. Vails's sons is a retired cowboy, another an Army recruiter. One daughter is a head nurse at a hospital in San Francisco; another is a secretary at a college. She has a son who is a printer, another who is a supervisor at a drug-rehabilitation center and another who is a retired correction officer. She has 19 grandchildren and 7 great-grandchildren.
"There is a lot of good in these projects that people don't hear about," she said. "You got good and bad people everywhere. There are bad people in the Waldorf.
"My children didn't have the best of everything, but we gave them the best we could. It's not where you live; it's how you bring your children up. This apartment isn't a mansion, but it's a home full of love."
 
The Future?
'These Kids Aren't Listening'
There is a lot of talk at King Towers about the young people and their future. More often than not, one way or another, it is mixed with talk about drugs.
At the chess table one day, a sad-faced man named George Brown spoke in a voice just above a whisper.
"These kids aren't listening to us," he said. "We ain't selling no drugs, so we ain't no role models."
He looked away from his friends. His voice was laced with shame.
"My son said to me, 'Dad, I'll be glad when you get a job.' He's 12 years old. That hurt me. I'm trying."
So is Michael Smalls. It was 11:30 in the morning, and Mr. Smalls, a husky man of 35 with a pair of dark glasses perched on the end of his nose, was doing what he does most mornings, afternoons and nights: hanging out in front of his building in King Towers.
"Another one of my friends got killed last night," said Mr. Smalls, who is unemployed and trying to get a job with the Housing Authority. "I'm out here trying to put together the bits and pieces."
A young man approached, his baseball cap pulled down against a brisk wind.
"Did you hear about Kenny?" Mr. Smalls asked the man.
"Yeah, I heard he got killed," the man said. "He got shot in the back of the head on 126th Street."
 
'This Is My Reward'
 Mr. Smalls said his friend Kenny had been involved with drugs for years but had a good heart and a family that loved him.
"I wish we could make people take a chill pill and stop all this killing," he said. "I hate it around here. I guess it's really a self-pity thing.
"I had the talent to play myself out of here with basketball, but I messed up in school. This is my reward."
In a sixth-floor hallway a few buildings away, a man lay sprawled in the dim afternoon light.
"He's a crackhead," a neighbor explained. "That's where he sleeps during the day. His mother lives there. She puts him out in the morning when she goes to work and lets him back in when she comes home at night.
"She's afraid he'll sell everything in the apartment for crack. A crackhead will do anything for a dime."
 
Epilogue
'I Call It A Development'
Marguerite Ryner, the vice president of the tenant association, has raised three children and mourned two husbands in her 36 years in King Towers. By now, most of her long-time friends and neighbors have either moved out or been chased out.
Mrs. Ryner, though, wears her ambivalence about King Towers like a gas mask, putting it on and taking it off, depending on the assaults of the day. One day she is disillusioned and bitter, ready to move out with the dawn. The next, she is determined and firm about staying and fighting to "make King Towers a decent place to live again."
"I don't like to call it the projects," she explained. "I call it a development, because that's what we're doing, developing this place into a community."
Mrs. Ryner was standing in the hallway just outside her apartment on the 10th floor of her building on Fifth Avenue. She is extremely proud of this hallway: Six years ago, she and a group of neighbors painted a mural over every inch of its institutional, off-white walls. They covered the walls in dark reds, browns and yellows. They painted pictures of karate fighters, couples eating dinner, flowers and comic-book superheroes.
But what they really painted was a declaration: This is our home.
Mrs. Ryner tapped the floor with her cane and ran her other hand over the mural. "We've got to do it over again," she said sadly. 'As you can see, the graffiti people have been here."
 
What Life Has Become
 Mrs. Ryner, who is 65 years old, moved into the development in 1954, the year it was completed. She had been living in one room of a boarding house with her husband, a railroad cook. Their family was growing. They needed more space. She has three grown children, two daughters and a son.
"The development was beautiful," Mrs. Ryner said. "Everybody got along. We kept our development clean. No graffiti. No robbing. No stealing. No drugs."
Mrs. Ryner shook her head at what life has become at King Towers.
"This drug nonsense doesn't stem from the poor people, the lower-echelon group," she said. "This stems from above. The Federal Government sanctioned Noriega. In order to clear out this drug situation, you got to clear out the Federal Government in Washington."
Even a walk to the corner newsstand can be dangerous. One early morning when she was out walking her dog, Christmas, Mrs. Ryner saw a 35-year-old man she had known all his life shooting at another man across the street.
When the man saw her, he yanked the gun behind his back and said, "Mrs. Ryner, I didn't mean for you to see that."
"I still love it here," Mrs. Ryner said, frowning at the memory of those early-morning gunshots. "But I don't love it enough to stay here and be miserable. Working people have a heck of time trying to survive."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
2d Day of Buying by Fed Moderates the Dollar's Drop

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar declined moderately against major foreign currencies yesterday, with a second day of dollar-buying by the Federal Reserve protecting the United States currency from a steeper fall, traders said.
Gold prices also posted moderate losses in New York, where bullion fell by $2.20 a troy ounce, to $366.40, on the Commodity Exchange. The Republic National Bank earlier quoted a late bid of $365.65 an ounce, down $2.45 from late Monday's quote. 
 The dollar headed lower in early trading, threatening to extend further the sharp losses it had suffered since Friday's grim jobless report prompted the Federal Reserve to lower the discount rate, a key lending rate. Several major banks have since lowered their prime rates.
The dollar, like all currencies, is supported by higher interest rates.
 
3 Buying Forays
 In a concerted and coordinated effort to soften the dollar's slide, the Fed and major allies bought dollars on Monday, helping to lift the currency somewhat off its daily lows. And yesterday, the Fed entered foreign exchange markets three times to buy dollars against the German mark, traders said.
Each time, the dollar, which was threatening to touch another new low against the mark, staged a moderate advance before declining again.
Traders said that without the Fed intervention yesterday, the dollar may have slipped even lower than the historic low of 1.456 German marks reached Monday in New York. Instead, the dollar recorded a trading low of 1.4565 marks in New York.
By day's end in New York, the currency closed at 1.4577 marks, down from late Monday's 1.4629 marks. Earlier, in Europe, the dollar finished at 1.4635 marks.
The Fed's solo attempts yesterday to shore up the dollar were not considered as effective as the coordinated intervention on Monday, which included dollar-buying by the Bank of England and the German Bundesbank.
The dollar also fell yesterday against most other major currencies in moderately active European trading.
In Tokyo, the dollar fell to a closing 130.05 Japanese yen, from 131.28 yen at Monday's close. Later, in London, it fell to 129.66 yen. In New York, the dollar closed at 129.48 yen, down from late Monday's 130.58 yen.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.984, from $1.9777 late Monday. In New York, sterling strengthened to $1.992, from late Monday's $1.9810.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday's prices, included: 1.243 Swiss francs, down from 1.251; 4.9625 French francs, down from 4.981; 1,095.75 Italian lire, down from 1,100.5, and 1.1583 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1596.

HEADLINE: COMPANY EARNINGS;
Goodrich's Earnings Off By 48 Percent

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
The B. F. Goodrich Company, a producer of plastic resins, specialty chemicals and aerospace components, said yesterday that its net income fell nearly 48 percent in the fourth quarter, as sales from some specialty chemical products were hurt by higher costs for petrochemical-based raw materials.
Goodrich said that its net income dropped to $14.1 million, or 47 cents a share, from $27 million, or 98 cents a share, in the fourth quarter of 1989. Sales for the quarter were up slightly, to $575.8 million, from $573.7 million in the period a year earlier. 
 The company, which is based in Akron, Ohio, said that its net income for all of last year dropped nearly 21 percent, to $136.3 million, or $4.95 a share, from $172.4 million, or $6.27 a share, in 1989. Sales for the year were up slightly, to $2.43 billion, from $2.42 billion in 1989.
 
PVC Sales Drop
 Goodrich is North America's largest producer of polyvinyl chloride, or PVC, plastics, which are widely used in pipes and tubing. The company said that it had reached record levels in specialty chemicals and areospace products but PVC sales for the quarter were down, to $256 million, from $265 million in the period last year, and profits from PVC plastics have deteriorated as a result of growing industry capacity.
"The economic slowdown in the United States and Canada negatively affected several important operations during the quarter," said John D. Ong, Goodrich's chairman. "The specialty chemicals and aerospace businesses will continue to expand," he said, adding that even if the plastics business improves the other areas will become the most significant contributors to the company's earnings.
The company said that its earnings were affected by higher crude oil prices, which have pushed up the costs of propane and ethylene, two chemicals used to make plastic products.
 
Growing Aerospace Business
 Goodrich, which sold its tire business in 1988, has moved to decrease its dependence on its plastics business. In the fourth quarter, the company acquired Hercules Inc.'s aircraft and electronics group, which will increase the company's aerospace sales by about 40 percent.
Most analysts said the results were in line with expectations.
On the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, Goodrich's stock was down $1.25, closing at $42.

HEADLINE: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
$138 Million in Bonds Priced By M.A.C. in a Refunding

 BODY:
The Municipal Assistance Corporation for the City of New York yesterday priced $138 million in bonds to refund other debt sold when interest rates were higher.
Goldman, Sachs & Company, lead manager for the underwriting group, said the offering went well and initial indications were that the bonds were well received by retail and institutional investors.
The maximum yield offered is 6.90 percent for an issue due in 2008, while yields on the short-term serial bonds range from 5.30 percent in 1992 to 6.10 percent in 1996, to 6.65 percent in 2001 and 6.80 percent in 2003.
The refunding bonds are rated A by Moody's Investors Service, A by the Standard & Poor's Corporation, and AA by Fitch Investors Service Inc. Traders outside the underwriting group said the sale of these bonds could give a good indication of how well the credit markets would respond if the corporation should have to borrow again on the city's behalf.
