HEADLINE: Canada to Join U.S. and Mexico in Talks on Free Trade

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5

 BODY:
The United States, Canada and Mexico announced today that they would open talks, probably starting this summer, to create a North American free trade zone that would be one of the world's largest open markets,with 360 million consumers and annual output of $6 trillion.
The announcement, which was widely anticipated, means that Canada, with which the United States has a two-year-old free trade pact, will join as a full participant in talks at which the United States and Mexico intend to try to reduce trade barriers at the Rio Grande. 
 The negotiations are likely to be highly contentious in all three countries, where many domestic industries share a fear of greater competition and are expected to try to preserve tariff walls.
 
Far-Reaching Idea
 The official announcements were upbeat. President Bush said at a news conference before a joint communique was issued in the three capitals that he had spoken with President Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico and Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada, who said the pact would link the three economies "in bold and far-reaching ways."
The United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, said in an interview that she thought the three-way negotiations might be concluded by the end of this year.
Among the opposition in the United States, the A.F.L.-C.I.O., worried about a flood of low-wage Mexican products affecting not only imports but also wage levels, has made its opposition to fighting the pact its No. 1 legislative goal.
 
Environmental Concerns
 American environmental groups are also urging that the Bush Administration seek greater commitments from the Salinas administration on improving air and water standards before any agreement is concluded.
But multinational business organizations, which could enjoy greater economies of scale from a market even larger than that of the 12-nation European Community, are ready to back the talks.
Should the Mexican pact follow what was negotiated after 18 months of often bitter talks with Canada in the late 1980's, tariffs and other barriers would be progressively cut over a 10-year transition period.
The Canadian-American pact has pleased the industries and Governments of both countries so much that tariff-cutting schedules for a number of industry sectors are being accelerated. But that pact still remains highly controversial in Canada, where a number of groups say it has aggravated plant closings in the current recession.
 
Benefits for Canada
 A study published today by the Royal Bank of Canada found that the pact had not contributed to the current difficulties experienced by some industries in Canada and that it might have moderated the impact of the recession through higher levels of investment.
By March 1, the Bush Administration is expected to ask Congress for a two-year extension of so-called fast-track authority to permit Congress to approve the agreement without amendments.
Such authority, which expires May 31, is considered essential for the trade pact to go forward.
The negotiations are not expected to begin until this summer to give the two Congressional committees charged with overseeing trade matters time to register any possible dissent.
 
Expected Fight in Congress
 But the fight in Congress is expected to be more over the Administration's request to seek the fast-track authority, which it would use both for the Mexico negotiations and for the now stalled global trade talks known as the Uruguay Round.
Separately, the chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, Lloyd Bentsen, Democrat of Texas, released a report by the International Trade Commission, a Federal agency that analyzes trade issues for the Government, that concluded that a free trade agreement with Mexico would benefit the United States economy over all.
But it said the benefits were likely to be small at least over the next few years because of the relatively small size of the Mexican economy and because a sizable share of United States imports from Mexico already enters the United States duty free. 

 	 	 		--------------------	 		 	 	
 
Caution in Canada
 TORONTO, Feb. 5 (Special to The New York Times) -- Canada's Trade Minister said today that while the Government saw little risk to Canada's manufacturing industries from the agreement to hold free-trade negotiations among the United States, Mexico and Canada, Canada reserved the right to pull out of the talks if they took a turn that threatened Canadian interests.
John Crosbie, the Canadian Trade Minister, told reporters in Ottawa after the agreement was announced that official projections suggested Canadian industries could hold their own against low-wage plants in Mexico. Because Canadian industries are increasingly shifting to high-technology production, Mr. Crosbie said, their real competition in Canada's domestic market came from Japan and Western Europe, not Mexico.
During the preliminary discussions, Canadian labor unions made it clear they would oppose any broadening of the free trade pact between Canada and the United States, dating from Jan. 1, 1989, to include Mexico. Shirley Carr, president of the Canadian Labor Congress, the country's biggest labor organization, said today that Canada had already lost 200,000 jobs from the two-nation pact.
Although Mexico is Canada's largest trading partner in Latin America, two-way trade between the countries in 1990 totaled less than $2.2 billion, compared with more than $150 billion in trade between Canada and the United States.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Concorde Flights Will Be Reduced

BYLINE: REUTERS

DATELINE: LONDON, Feb. 5

 BODY:
British Airways P.L.C. will cut the number of trans-Atlantic flights by the supersonic Concorde airliner starting on Thursday. Daily runs between New York and London will be reduced from two to one, and the three weekly trips to Washington will be suspended, the company said.
"Airline services continue to be affected by the downturn in business traffic as a consequence of the gulf war and the economic recession," a company official said. He said the company had also taken other steps to trim costs, including freezing recruitment, encouraging staff to take one-month unpaid leaves while the war lasts, and cutting advertising.

HEADLINE: U.S. Sales Of Vehicles Drop 31.5%

BYLINE: By PAUL C. JUDGE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Feb. 5

 BODY:
Sales of American-made vehicles dropped 31.5 percent in late January, closing a month of drastic sales declines for auto makers buffeted by war and a weak economy.
The latest drop is a stark reminder that domestic and foreign auto makers confront the most serious slump in demand for cars and trucks in the United States since the last recession ended in 1982. Since August, consumer confidence has been stuck at its lowest level in a decade, according to recent surveys conducted by the University of Michigan.
 
'Prospects Are too Uncertain'
"Rather than telling us that car price discounts aren't big enough or that interest rates are too high, people are saying their economic prospects are too uncertain," said Richard T. Curtin, the director of the survey. "A lot of consumers have put off even looking for new cars and trucks." 
 The 10 leading manufacturers sold 185,049 domestically produced cars in the January 21-31 period, a decline of 27.9 percent. Sales of pickups, mini-vans and four-wheel drive vehicles were down 37.4 percent, to 97,263.
Seasonally adjusted, cars sold at an annual rate of 5.4 million, well behind the sales rate of 7.4 million in the same period last year. There were 10 selling days in the period this year, and 9 last year.
 
Pace of Sales Slows
 The pace of sales has slowed considerably in recent weeks; during the last 60 days, cars sold at an annual rate of 6.3 million.
For the month, car sales including imports were down by 25.2 percent, and light truck sales plunged 32.8 percent.
Sales of imported cars and trucks also suffered in January, declining by 28.6 percent, compared with a drop of 29.3 percent for the Big Three domestic auto makers. The seven Japanese manufacturers with plants in the United States posted a sales drop of 9.3 percent in January.
The poor prospects for a quick recovery and the pressing need to conserve cash spurred General Motors on Monday to cut its dividend nearly in half and announce cost-cutting plans, including a 15 percent reduction in its salaried work force.
Analysts say the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation will cut their dividends as well. And the Big Three shut down 24 car and truck assembly plants this week, temporarily idling more than 62,000 workers because of a shortage of dealer orders.
 
Difficult Year Ahead
 "It's clear that 1991 is going to be a difficult year for all manufacturers," said J.B. Fitzpatrick, G.M. vice president for marketing.
G.M. sold 79,116 domestically produced cars in late January, a drop of 30.4 percent. G.M.'s light truck sales were down 40.7 percent, to 33,004 vehicles.
Ford sold 44,933 cars, a drop of 35.1 percent, while Ford's light truck sales dropped 33.5 percent, to 31,219 vehicles.
Chrysler sold 29,966 cars, a drop of 1.7 percent. The figure is based on estimates provided by Ward's Automotive Reports, an industry newsletter. Sales of Chrysler's mini-vans, Jeeps and pickups fell by 43 percent, to 28,067 vehicles.
 
Chrysler Under Fire
 Chrysler's profitable mini-vans came under fire last week, when Consumer Reports warned that faulty transmissions made them unreliable. Chrysler's chairman, Lee A. Iacocca, asked dealers this week to counter the criticism with an all-out sales and service drive to keep customers from fleeing. Mr. Iacocca acknowledged that the impact of the article could be disastrous for Chrysler.
Dealers report that many buyers still visiting showrooms are taking a harder line in negotiating the price of a new vehicle. That has meant lower profits on each sale for the dealers, and more legwork for customers, who are shopping broadly for new cars and trucks and comparing more models and brands before committing themselves.
"Most people are more frugal in what they buy now," said Frank DeBartolo, sales manager at Celozzi-Ettelson Chevrolet in Elmhurst, Illinois. "It's not that they are buying cheaper cars, but they are negotiating harder. In normal times, a customer might wind up paying $200 more than he wanted to pay. Now he negotiates harder to cut $100 here or there."
 
Toyota Sales Drop
 Toyota Motor Corporation sold 10,249 domestically produced cars in late January, down 18.7 percent. Honda Motor Company's car sales fell 52.6 percent, to 10,263 vehicles. Nissan Motor Company sold 3,650 cars made in the United States, a gain of 27.2 percent, and sold 4,034 light trucks, a gain of 15.8 percent.
For the month of January, Toyota's imported car and truck sales fell 7.8 percent, Nissan's sales of imported vehicles declined 34.7 percent, and Honda's sales of imported cars were down 11.3 percent.
The major European importers suffered, too. Volkswagen posted a decline of 18.9 percent in sales of its cars in the United States. Mercedes was down 27.4 percent, while Volvo's sales fell by 40.6 percent.
In terms of United States market share, the big losers in January were Ford, Chrysler and Mitsubishi. Ford dropped to 20.9 percent of the car and truck market, from 24.3 percent last year. Chrysler's share fell to 14.1 percent, from 15.7 percent last year. And Mitsubishi's share declined to 1.5 percent, from 2.3 percent last January.
General Motors increased its market share to 35.5 percent, from 34.7 percent last year. Toyota raised its share to 7.7 percent of the vehicle market, from 6.4 percent last year. And Nissan rose to 4.4 percent, from 3.6 percent.

HEADLINE: THE FEDERAL BUDGET: THE OVERVIEW;
Darman Greeted Politely in Cautious Foray to Hill

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5

 BODY:
Chastened by his brawl with Congress last year, President Bush's budget director appeared on Capitol Hill today for the first time since then, gave a low-key, polite defense of the President's 1992 budget, confessed earlier errors and charmed at least a few senators who had been put off by his cocky self-assurance in the past.
Testifying at a hearing of the Senate Budget Committee, the official, Richard G. Darman, did not win support for all the proposals in the budget, which the President delivered to Congress on Monday. But he was applauded for giving a candid assessment of policy options and realistic estimates of the deficit for both this year and next. 
 The budget director was "clearly not as contentious and not as defensive" as in the past, said Senator Jim Sasser of Tennessee, the Democrat who serves as chairman of the Budget Committee. "The Administration honestly estimated the amount of the deficit this year, a staggering $318 billion, so he doesn't have to defend an unrealistic rosy scenario, as he did last year."
 
View From a Farm State
 Senator J. James Exon said that he did not agree with all Mr. Bush's proposals but that this was "as honest a budget presentation as we've ever had."
Mr. Exon, a Democrat from the farm state of Nebraska, said he could live with Mr. Bush's proposal to halt crop subsidy payments to farmers who have nonfarm income of more than $125,000 a year. The idea seems to be "not only fair but workable," he said.
Another farm state Senator, Charles E. Grassley, Republican of Iowa, said he too was willing to consider "putting a lid on farm susbidies," because he believes that they should be directed more to people who truly need such assistance.
Mr. Darman also made peace with Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, a leader of conservatives who denounced the Administration for accepting tax increases as part of last fall's landmark budget agreement, which provided the framework for deficit reduction over five years.
 
Sununu's Remarks Recalled
 John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff, said at the time that Mr. Lott was "an insignificant figure" in budget negotiations, and that the Mississippi Republican could "find something wrong" with any proposal.
Today, in a gesture of conciliation, Mr. Darman welcomed Mr. Lott to the Budget Committee, which he is joining this year, and offered him sympathy for having to do the thankless work of writing a budget and for "having to deal with me -- I know how difficult a burden that can be."
Mr. Darman gave details of foreign contributions to the cost of United States military operations in the Persian Gulf, including pledges of $9.7 billion last year and $41.8 billion in the first quarter of this year. Among the chief contributors, he said, Saudi Arabia has pledged a total of $16.8 billion, Kuwait $16 billion, Japan $10.7 billion and Germany $6.6 billion.
The budget director said he was confident that these countries would meet their commitments, although he acknowledged that so far the United States had received less than $8 billion. At the White House today, Mr. Bush said the war might cost the United States no more than $15 billion if other countries made contributions as promised.
 
Questions on Benefits
 Turning to the domestic side of Mr. Bush's budget, Mr. Darman acknowledged that the Administration was proposing $46.6 billion of cutbacks in Medicare and other benefit programs over five years, beyond what was required by last fall's budget agreement.
Under intense questioning from Democrats, Mr. Darman conceded that the Administration might find a little more money to run the unemployment insurance program during the current recession. Because of inadequate funds to administer the program, jobless workers have had to wait as long as seven weeks to get the insurance benefits to which they are legally entitled.
Senator Exon pressed Mr. Darman to admit that he was in error when he estimated in January 1990 that the Federal budget deficit would be $63 billion in the current fiscal year, about one-fifth of the $318 billion now estimated. "If your point is that I was wrong, you are right," Mr. Darman said.
If Mr. Darman and some lawmakers are less combative this year, the reason may be the budget agreement of last year. As a result of that deal, which placed caps on each of three broad categories of discretionary spending, the focus now is not on how much should be spent but on how to spend what is available, and savings in the military budget are no longer available to expand social welfare programs.
 
'Honesty of the Numbers'
 Senator Timothy E. Wirth, Democrat of Colorado, told Mr. Darman, "I appreciate the honesty of the numbers" in the President's new budget. He also commended Mr. Darman for proposing a 13 percent increase in Federal support for scientific research and development, to $75.6 billion next year.
The atmosphere of amity may not last long. Mr. Bush's proposals to slash Medicare payments to urban teaching hospitals and to triple Medicare premiums for elderly people with incomes of more than $125,000 a year elicited no visible support on Capitol Hill.
Representative Pete Stark, the California Democrat who heads the House Ways and Means Subcommittee on Health, said that Mr. Bush's proposal to slice an additional $25 billion from Medicare over the next five years "breaks faith with the budget deal" approved last year. That agreement reduced Medicare payments to doctors and hospitals by $32 billion over five years and required beneficiaries to pay a total of $10 billion in additional premiums over the same period.
Representative Henry A. Waxman, who has led many successful efforts to expand Medicaid coverage of low-income women and children, was even harsher in judging the President's budget.
"It doesn't do anything to help the states meet the burden of Medicaid spending or the millions of poor people who can't get Medicaid services," said Mr. Waxman, a California Democrat who is chairman of the the House Energy and Commerce Subcommittee on Health. .
Mr. Waxman also complained that the Administration was not seeking enough money to deal with the AIDS epidemic. Under Mr. Bush's 1992 budget, the Public Health Service would get $1.95 billion for research, prevention and treatment activities related to the disease, an increase of $65 million over spending this year.

HEADLINE: THE FEDERAL BUDGET: NEW YORK;
Dinkins and Other Officials Assail Bush's Budget Over Spending Cuts

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5

 BODY:
New York City and state officials and a Brooklyn Congressman reacted today with varying degrees of scorn and disappointment over President Bush's budget.
Mayor David N. Dinkins of New York said in a statement issued by the city's lobbying office here that the proposed budget would cost New York $100 million in transit aid alone, and many millions more in health care, housing, community improvement and community-based services to the poor. 
 He said that the budget would deal "a crushing blow" to health care, housing, education and transportation.
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's chief Washington lobbyist, Brad C. Johnson, said the President's proposal to funnel block grant aid to cities through the states threatened to pit cities and states against each other in pursuit of Federal dollars. This, he said, amounted to a "diversion" that distracted attention from what he termed the Bush Administration's failure to deal with a declining economy.
 
Cuts in Medicare Assailed
 And Representative Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of Brooklyn, said the budget's effect on job training would be "stagnant at best," and called its impact on energy assistance "short sighted" and the cuts in Medicare "devastating."
Mayor Dinkins, perhaps the harshest critic of the budget, said, "The President's failure to offer any clear domestic policy is bitter medicine for state and local governments, which must continue to bear the burden of Draconian budget cuts and rapidly growing social problems."
The Mayor also accused Mr. Bush of treating mass transit as "expendable" and of giving short shrift to housing, day care and services for low-income families, the homeless and the elderly.
Judy Chesser, the Mayor's representative in Washington, said city officials were wary of the President's plan to funnel Community Development Block Grants through the state, rather than channeling the money directly to the cities. The grants amount to $2.9 billion nationally and $183 million for New York City. "We're concerned," she said, "whether the cities will ever get the money through the state."
Mr. Johnson said that the concerns of cities were "justified," but added that guidelines could be drafted to make sure the money gets to the areas of greatest need.
He also said the plan to channel grants through the states occupied "the attention of the governors when the real problems are the recession, universal access to health care and quality education."

HEADLINE: WAR IN THE GULF: THE WHITE HOUSE;
Excerpts From Talk By Bush on Gulf War

BYLINE: REUTERS

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from President Bush's news conference at the White House today:
 
OPENING STATEMENT
This morning I spoke with President Salinas and Prime Minister Mulroney of Canada, and together we intend to pursue a trilateral free-trade agreement that would link our three economies in bold and far-reaching ways. A successful conclusion of the free-trade agreement will expand market opportunities, increase prosperity, and help our three countries meet the economic challenges of the future. A free-trade area encompassing all three countries would create a North American market of 360 million people with annual production of more than $6 trillion. This agreement would be a dramatic first step toward the realization of a hemispheric free-trade zone stretching from Point Barrow in Alaska to the Straits of Magellan.
I've informed the Congress of this decision and notified them of my intent to use the fast-track procedure for this North American free-trade zone. . . .
I am very pleased at the generally constructive reception that our budget is receiving, and in particular am pleased at the positive receptions that the governors gave yesterday concerning our budget proposal for transferring $15 billion worth of Government programs to the states, fully funded, I might add.

 	 	 		. . .	 		 	 	This morning, I also spoke with President Ozal of Turkey regarding the coalition efforts in the Persian Gulf. We're nearing the end of the third week of Operation Desert Storm, almost 21 -- 21 days to the hour. And I'm pleased to report that we remain on course, and on schedule.
U.S. and coalition forces continue to perform their assigned missions with great professionalism, and thankfully, with only modest casualties on our side. And I'd like to emphasize that we are going to extraordinary, and I would venture to say, unprecedented length, to avoid damage to civilians and holy places.
 
Unchanged Goals in Gulf
 We do not seek Iraq's destruction, nor do we seek to punish the Iraqi people for the decisions and policies of their leaders. In addition, we are doing everything possible and with great success to minimize collateral damage, despite the fact that Saddam is now relocating some military functions, such as command and control headquarters, in civilian areas such as schools.
I would also emphasize that our goals have not changed. We continue to seek Iraq's full compliance with the 12 relevant United Nations Security Council resolutions. And our soldiers have performed with courage and bravery that should make all Americans proud.
And I believe our country is giving them the support that they need and deserve.
As we move into the fourth week of this conflict, I ask all Americans to continue their prayers for our valiant men and women in the gulf. And let me just end with this. I asked Dick Cheney, the Secretary of Defense, and General Powell, to travel to Saudi Arabia late this week to meet directly with Norm Schwarzkopf and his staff. The purpose of this trip, which will be a short one, will be for them to get a firsthand status report. And I would then look forward to their returning here quickly and meeting with me and my other senior advisers.
 
QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS
Q. Mr. President, your new budget contains relatively little money for the Persian Gulf war, which some analysts say could cost as high as $1 billion a day if it goes into a ground conflict. If the war goes on for months, how will you pay for it with an economy that's in a recession and a deficit that's combing past $300 billion?
A. Well, I think that in the budget some $15 billion is included, and I think what people that are concerned about this have realized is that we are getting significant support committed from overseas. And I'm confident that what we have in there will take care of it. There will be testimony on this up on the Hill. But we're talking about having commitments of close to -- I think it's $50 billion or $51 billion from others. Added to the $15 billion that we have budgeted, that's $66 billion and we believe it should be sufficient.
Q. Would you, under any circumstances, consider a surtax to pay for the war if it goes on?
A. Too hypothetical, but I can see no reason for a war surtax. I don't think it's necessary and I've heard very little call for that, as a matter of fact, because I think people realize that these cost estimates are pretty accurate.

 	 	 		. . .	 		 	 	
 
Ground-War Decision
 Q. Mr. President, does the Cheney-Powell visit over there signal that a decision is at hand on the commencement of a ground war?
A. No, it doesn't signal that.
 
Anti-U.S. Sentiment
 Q. Let me follow by asking you, there is a perceptible increase in anti-American sentiment in the streets of a number of capitals in the Middle East. Does this add to the pressure on you to wrap this war up and get it over with?
A. No, it doesn't. Because what we overlook when we see the demonstrations on the television is the fact that there's strong support in many Arab countries. And I'm staying in very close touch with our coalition partners, and I'm always encouraged when I talk to them about the support in their countries and in other parts of the Arab world for what we're doing.
Yes, it's divided. And yes, we've seen -- I've seen the demonstrations in Amman. I've seen some of the demonstrations in the Mahgreb. But I don't -- to get back to your question, they will not influence my decision-making on the timing involved, say for the use of ground forces.

 	 	 		. . .	 		 	 	
 
Iran's Peace Proposal
 Q. Both the White House and the State Department were cool, even indifferent, to the Iranian peace initiative. Why so? Why would you not encourage an initiative which called for the full withdrawal from Kuwait?
A. Well, I don't that there was an initial -- I don't think that there is an Iranian proposal, John. I have not seen it. I just hung up talking to Ozal -- President Ozal of Turkey, and he doesn't think there is a specific Iranian proposal, because -- and I think the reason is that people realize that this man has to comply with these resolutions without equivocation, that he has to go forward, no concession, no compromise, and do what the world has called on him to do. And at that point, then, there can be some cessation of hostilities.
But I have not seen a specific five-point program out of Teheran.

 	 	 		. . .	 		 	 	
 
Saddam Hussein's Fate
 Q. The problem seems to be, sir, an impression is being given that you will be disappointed if the war ends with Saddam Hussein still in power.
A. Well, I see. No, I don't think that's the case. But the war will not end with Saddam Hussein standing with his view that he will not withdraw from Kuwait. . . .
There's nothing to negotiate about. There's nothing to be conciliatory about, when you have a person who is steadfast in his refusal to comply with the fundamental purpose, and that is to get him out of Kuwait. But we haven't shifted our objectives on this.
Now, would I weep? Would I mourn, if somehow the -- Saddam Hussein did not remain as -- as head of his country? I thought Prime Minister Major spoke very well about it, spoke very convincingly about it, and he reflected my view that there would be no sorrow if he's not there. . . .
In fact it would be a lot easier to see a successful conclusion because I don't believe anybody other than Saddam Hussein is want to -- is going to want to continue to submit, to subject his army to the pounding they are taking, or his people to the pounding that is going on. . . .
Q. Mr. President, back on the planning of this ground offensive, you said last week at Fort Stewart, Ga., and again here today that the United States and its allies and not Saddam Hussein would determine that. Three weeks into the war, what are the prospects for avoiding ground warfare in [inaudible] in the gulf?
A. Well, I'd -- I think one of the things that I look forward to hearing from General Powell and Dick Cheney is the answer to that question as to -- and I guess you could rephrase it and say would air power alone get the job done. And I -- my own view is I'm somewhat skeptical that it would, but I'm very interested to hear from our Secretary of Defense and the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs.

 	 	 		. . .	 		 	 	
 
Hussein's Strategy
 Q. You just mentioned the pounding that these Iraqi troops are taking, and I wondered how you have approached the decision where you obviously, if you continue this aerial bombardment like this, run the chance of slaughtering, literally, tens of thousands of Iraqi troops. A two-part question is, first, do you make any conclusion -- draw any conclusion that Saddam is either out of control of that decision or lost his senses?
A. On what decision?
Q. On allowing the United States basically to pound his troops who are virtually defenseless from the air?
A. I'm not sure he has the full -- I've never known for fact certain how much he's told. You mentioned Khafji. The question was raised. I don't know whether -- how much information he has about what happened there in spite of the full coverage that takes place. But let me be very clear. What concerns me are the lives of our troops. What concerns me are the lives of our coalition forces, the Saudi and the Qatar forces that went into Khafji, very courageously, and my first worries are about them and Saddam Hussein should be concerned about the Iraqi forces. But how concerned he is I don't know cause when you shove people into the people, pushing them from behind, to be defeated, clearly and surely, or when you send your airplanes up and the score is totally one-sided -- in fact every engagement in the air the Iraqi planes and pilots have gone down -- you have to wonder how he looks at -- at what you're asking about, how he feels about that.
But here's a man that used chemical weapons on his own people, here's a man that gassed the Kurds, here's a man who has no hesitancy to throw, recklessly throw city-busting Scuds, population-killing Scuds into Israel or into Saudi Arabia. Here's a man that brutally parades prisoners of war, here's a man that has launched environmental terrorism. I can't figure out what he's thinking and neither do the coalition partners with whom I am in touch. Neither can they figure it out.

 	 	 		. . .	 		 	 	
 
P.O.W.'s Fate
 Q. Mr. President, I'm wondering if you can tell us the latest you've heard from the International Red Cross or anyone else that's trying to find out the fate of the P.O.W.'s -- the personnel who are missing there?
A. So far all I've heard is a frustrating silence of his willingness to permit people to do what should be done, and that is to inspect and talk to the people involved. That's all I've heard.
 
 
 
Kinship With Pilots
 Q. Sir, as a follow up. Do you, following your experience in World War II, feel any personal kinship with the pilots who were shot down?
A. Well, it doesn't have anything to do with my experience, particularly, many, many years ago. It has a lot to do with the fact that they are courageous Americans and the answer to your question is yes. I feel -- and I feel very strongly about it, and I had a chance to say that to some of the spouses, and -- but it's not some kind of a psychological tie-in to the fact that 50 years ago I was flying airplanes. It's the fact that -- just -- you see that, and you see these prisoners paraded, and it just turns my stomach. It just says something about the brutality of this person, and that's what really motivates me.

 	 	 		. . .	 		 	 	
 
Use of Chemical Arms
 Q. Mr. President, Saddam Hussein has not yet used chemical weapons on the battlefield, but some analysts believe that may be something that we would face in the future. Have you made a decision on what the U.S. response would be if he does turn to chemical weapons? Have you ruled out the idea that the United States might in turn use weapons of mass destruction?
A. Well, I think it's better to never say what option you may be considering or may or may not do. But yes, he has used chemical weapons on his own people, so the only way -- I would like to take the opportunity, in responding to your question to say he ought to think very carefully about doing that. Very, very carefully. And I will leave that up to a very fuzzy interpretation because I would like to have every possible chance that he decides not to do this.
You talk about turning world opinion further against this brutal man. That would do it. But how we will respond or something, I would wait for recommendations and I would not discuss options ahead of time one way or another.
Q. I understand that you're not going to tell us what you would do, but have you in your own mind made a decision on what you would do in ----
A. No.
 
Stance on the Draft
Q. Mr. President, can you say with a 100 percent Presidential guarantee that you will not reinstate the draft?
A. I have absolutely no intention of reinstating the draft.

 	 	 		. . .	 		 	 	
 
Ground War's Timing
 Q. There seems to be an increasing feeling on the Hill, among Republicans as well as Democrats, that we should wait longer, some say even up until June. What's the downside of waiting that long and continuing to pound away?
A. Well, I would simply say that we want to let this be determined by people that understand the military plan and that are prepared to implement it.
And I remember before Jan. 16 there was the same feeling -- please let the sanctions work. I mean I can understand the feeling on the Hill. I can understand those who say, let air power do it alone.
But I'm going to make these calls. These are the responsibilities of the Commander in Chief, that kind of decision, and I will make that decision after full consultation with these -- the chief out there and the two main military people upon whom I depend here, Secretary of Defense and Chairman of the Chiefs.
So it's -- I'm not trying to say it's not -- wouldn't be a difficult decision. But I am saying, one, I'm prepared to make it, and two, I have total confidence that this decision will not be recommended to me unless these people that I just mentioned know that it's the right thing to do.

HEADLINE: Bank Plan's Gains Are All Long Term

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5

 BODY:
The broad changes in the banking system proposed today by the Bush Administration would not solve the nation's current economic woes, but they could have important long-term benefits for the economy.
 It will take Congress at least a year to deal with such comprehensive legislation and even longer for new laws to go into effect. If the recession is not over and the scarcity of credit is not more or less resolved by then, the economy will be so sick that it will need much stronger medicine than changes in the banking laws. 
 But the Administration argues that measures to make the banks more secure and more profitable would ultimately strengthen the economy, and economists generally agree that the proposals released today would indeed make the financial system healthier.
"A weak banking system hurts the economy, particularly during difficult economic times," Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said at a news conference this morning. "Weak banks are forced to pull back just when their good customers need them most. Businesses must be able to count on banks in bad times as well as good times."
 
Changing Circumstances
 No one disputes that the existing banking laws, enacted mostly during the Depression, are anachronistic. In the decades since the laws were put on the books, credit cards, computers, automated teller machines, money market mutual funds and variable interest rates have changed banking the way air-conditioning changed life in the Sun Belt and jet engines changed overseas travel.
The question, of course, is how to change the outmoded laws. In Congress, that will depend as much on lobbying and regional interests as it does on what is best for the economy.
The most urgent goal for the Administration and Congress is to strengthen the banks' deposit insurance system. The economy could not tolerate a flood of bank failures, and taxpayers would not tolerate another bailout like the costly one involving the savings and loan associations. Congress may not approve today's proposal to limit the number of insured accounts a depositor can hold or the method of financing that the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation is expected to offer in the next few weeks. But most experts expect that the deposit-insurance question will be resolved in some way this year.
For long-run economic growth, the most significant proposal today probably was the one to allow banks to open branches nationwide.
The measure has been sharply attacked by lobbyists for small community banks, who fear being swallowed up by the giants from New York, Chicago and San Francisco. Representative Henry B. Gonzalez, the populist Democrat from Texas who heads the House Banking Committee, indicated today that he was solidly on the side of the small bankers. But among economists, the idea of nationwide banking has widespread support.
Weak, poorly capitalized small banks would indeed be endangered, economists say, but their survival is problematic anyway, and strong community banks would flourish.
"Sure, it increases the competition to local bankers," said Verne S. Atwater, a professor of finance at the Pace University Graduate School of Business. "But most of them ought to be able to compete successfully because they know their customers and local conditions better."
 
Big Savings Potential
 Mr. Brady said he had been told by banking consultants that the efficiencies involved, like banks in several states being connected by a single computer network, would save the industry $5 billion to $10 billion a year, a hefty sum considering that the total profits of American banks last year was about $20 billion.
Banks would be able to lend this additional money many times over. In theory, it would be invested, and the entire economy would grow.
Interstate banking, now prohibited in many states and restricted in others, would also make the larger banks less likely to pull in their reins during bad times and thus be a further drag on an already slow economy. "Branching would allow a bank that had losses in the Northeast real estate market, for example, to have a counterbalance with a stronger geographic region," said Richard J. Herring, a professor of finance at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania.
 
International Competition
 Allowing banks into new lines of business like securities, mutual funds and insurance is important mainly because it would allow American banks to be more internationally competitive. That is especially important because of the investment opportunities with the economic unification of Europe next year.
Banks in Europe are allowed to engage in a full range of businesses. The Europeans are telling Americans that if they want to operate banks in Europe, then Europeans must be allowed to operate here with the same opportunities for business diversity they have at home.
What Congress will want to know is whether the Administration's proposals would help or harm consumers and small businesses. They have much more lobbying strength than do the large banks that would be the direct beneficiaries of the new laws.
Some small-business executives are already making waves, saying that they prefer dealing with their familiar local bankers, bond underwriters and insurance agents and not with some faceless international conglomerate. The Administration and its supporters respond that the new laws would give everyone a wider range of services and opportunities.
On the first day out of the gate, the Administration seems to be on sound footing economically with its banking proposals. But the political race is going to be long and arduous.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Economic Analysis

HEADLINE: Dow Up 16.09, to 2,788.37 in Heavy Trading

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
Stock prices kept rising yesterday in exceptionally heavy trading as money managers and individuals alike jumped into the market.
Over-the-counter stocks continued to lead the parade, although dozens of small stocks on both the New York and American exchanges also made impressive new gains. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average, which jumped 41.59 points on Monday, rose 16.09 more yesterday, to 2,788.37.
Trading soared to 290.6 million shares, the highest since the day after the allied attacks against Iraq and the fifth consecutive session over 200 million.
The hefty volume -- coupled with declining interest rates -- gave investment houses a lift. Morgan Stanley, for example, jumped 3 1/8, to 65 1/2.
The Nasdaq composite index, bolstered by strong technology and financial stocks, jumped the equivalent of 48 Dow points. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks advanced 23 Dow points.
In a measure of the market's breadth, 1,151 Big Board stocks moved ahead while 517 fell, for a ratio of more than 2 to 1.
Pointing to what he called "the breadth stampede," Ronald J. Hill, investment strategist for Brown Brothers Harriman, said, "We've now got confirmation of the bull market."
For the last 10 days, he explained, the ratio of advances to declines has been above 1.95 to 1. Such a 10-day streak has occurred only 14 times in a little more than 40 years, and each time the market has jumped 10 percent before "a meaningful correction."
"The broad market far exceeded the Dow," said Dennis E. Jarrett, market analyst for Kidder, Peabody & Company. He attributed the Dow's relative weakness to the decline in General Motors after its surprise dividend cut late Monday.
 
Heavy Market Activity
 Commenting on the heavy market activity, he said: "You have a buying panic -- fear of missing the upside. It has to be cash coming off the sidelines."
Asked what investors were buying, he replied, "When you have 1,151 issues up, it's across the board."
Noting that the Dow had jumped an astounding 280 points since the attack on Iraq, one trader said some investors had pulled back when the index rose during the day beyond 2,800, to 2,805.20. But Mr. Jarrett argued that 2,800 is "nothing significant, just a round number." Even so, he said, yesterday was the fifth day of 1,000 or more advancing Big Board stocks and "some traders were itching to take profits."
Precisely how much money is flowing into the stock market is difficult to gauge but seemed to be running into the hundreds of millions of dollars.
The Investment Company Institute, which reports monthly the amount of cash available to buy stock, said less than a week ago that $29.6 billion was available as of Nov. 30, but that by Dec. 31 the amount had dropped to $28 billion, suggesting that $1.6 billion had moved into the market in December.
Since the outlook for the economy has improved considerably since then, the movement of cash into the market since December should have been strong.
Indata, a weekly service of Gordon, Haskett & Company in Stamford, Conn., said its 1,200 clients held nearly $12 billion in cash for investment in stock as of Jan. 25, or about $57 million less than the week before.
 
Money Waiting for Investment
 By either measure a huge amount of money is still waiting for investment.
In yet another sign that investors are skittish, General Motors ended the day on the New York Stock Exchange on Monday at 37 3/8, up 1 1/4, but subsequently fell 2 1/4, to 35 1/4, after announcing it was slashing the dividend.
Instinet, the after-hours electronic trading service, said 260,000 G.M. shares traded between Monday evening and yesterday morning before the market opened, with the price gradually dropping to 35 5/8.
Scott F. Merlis, auto analyst for Morgan Stanley, said he had upgraded G.M. and Ford to "buys" because lower interest rates and oil prices were positive for car sales.
G.M. fell 1/4, to 35. It was the second-most-active stock, with 5.1 million shares changing hands. Ford Motor fell 1/4, to 29 3/8, on 1.8 million shares, while Chrysler rose 1/4, to 12 5/8.
Wells Fargo, which rose 6 3/8 Monday, fell 3/8, to 69, but climbed as high as 72 5/8. Robert Albertson, bank analyst for Goldman, Sachs, said that yesterday's second day of strength in financial stocks "says this is going to be more than a flash in the pan" for the group.

HEADLINE: WAR IN THE GULF: WAR SHORTAGES;
Iraq Suspending Fuel Sales, As Raids Widen Shortages

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan, Feb. 5

 BODY:
Iraq announced the suspension of all fuel sales today, bringing further deprivation to a wintry land suffering from shortages of food, water, electricity and gasoline after allied bombers have hammered its refineries and distribution networks.
The Baghdad radio offered no explanation for the suspension, which, it said today, went into effect Monday and would remain "until further notice." The announcement gave Iraqis no time to stockpile the fuels they need for transportion, cooking and heat. 
 "For organizational purposes," the radio said, the authorities would "suspend the provision of fuel to citizens as of 4th February until further notice."
The decison meant a halt in the supply of cooking gas, gasoline and fuel oil, used for heating homes in this season when overnight temperatures drop below freezing. It seemed a clear acknowledgement of significant disruption after more than two weeks of sustained bombing.
 
Allies Hit Oil Refineries
 Western spokesmen have said allied bombs have destroyed 80 percent of Iraq's pre-war oil-refining capability of around 500,000 barrels per day, forcing the authorities to choose between civilian and military priorities.
Western diplomats in Amman said the United States and its allies were seeking to weaken Iraq's will to fight and to demoralize the country's 17 million people.
According to news reports and comments by travelers from Baghdad, Iraq has already been forced to ration drinking water, and gasoline sales to private citizens had been limited to 7 gallons every 15 days. Travelers have also spoken of rationing coupons for food, and electric power is severed in many places.
Refugees from Iraq have reported seeing allied air attacks on oil refineries throughout the country -- in Basra, Baghdad and Kirkuk -- suggesting that Iraq needs to channel its stocks of refined products to the military.
 
Civilian Casualties Reported
 In a letter to Iraqi newspapers, Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz said 108 civilians had been killed and 249 wounded in air raids on residential areas between Jan. 26 and Sunday. The figures brought to 428 dead and 650 wounded Iraq's estimate of the number of civilian casualties in the war.
Amid the growing hardships, the Baghdad radio seemed to increase the volume of its already strident invective against the United States and its allies massed in Saudi Arabia.
"Let George Bush and other scoundrels taking part in this aggression learn that our reckoning with them will be harsh and our vengeance crushing," the radio declared. It reported 373 allied air attacks on "peaceful civilian women and children, commercial businesses and homes" and claimed the downing of four allied airplanes.
Other accounts also suggested widespread bombing. The Iranian press agency reported overnight bombing of the southern Iraqi towns of Fao, Basra, Abul Khasib and Zuhair. Jordanian officials said allied air strikes had been reported again Monday on a highway in western Iraq that has been pounded by warplanes trying to keep Iraq from launching missiles toward Israel.
 
Jordan Rebuts the U.S.
 Today, Jordan formally denied Washington's assertions that its fuel supply trucks from Baghdad were mingling with military supply convoys on the highway.
The American assertions, made Monday by the State Department spokeswoman, Margaret D. Tutwiler, were the latest in a series that have persuaded some Jordanians that Washington wants to destabilize Jordan or punish it for tilting toward Baghdad in the gulf crisis.
Iraq is now Jordan's only supplier of crude oil, which is brought in tanker trucks from Baghdad. Allied air attacks on the highway, Jordanian officials said today, have killed 8 Jordanian truck drivers and crippled more than 30 trucks. Last week, Foreign Minister Taher el-Masri accused the coalition of deliberately aiming at Jordanian civilian traffic on the highway.
Information Minister Ibrahim Izzedine told reporters today, "We can categorically deny that our nationals involve themselves in any military activities in Iraq."
 
U.S. Embassy Staff Is Cut
 The United States has also surprised Jordanians by ordering its embassy staff here reduced further and by urging Americans to leave the country as soon as possible. Washington has not explained the move. It has also challenged what Jordan calls the "tacit agreement" by which it breaks United Nations sanctions on Iraq with its oil imports. Mr. Izzedine said Jordan was negotiating to buy oil from Syria.
United States officials here declined to comment on the widespread perception of American hostility toward Jordan, which has deepened an already profound anti-Americanism among a population, more than half Palestinian, that sympathizes with Iraq.
West European diplomats suggested that the anti-American climate may have persuaded the United States that it is only a matter of time before its officials or installations here become the target of terrorist assault.

 	 	 		--------------------	 		 	 	
 
Iraq Assails U.N. Chief
 UNITED NATIONS, Feb. 5 (Special to The New York Times) -- Iraq has attacked Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar again for not opposing the bombing of Iraq.
As the letter was made public, officials said the World Health Organization and the United Nations Childrens Fund were planning to send a joint mission to Baghdad next week carrying medicines and other medical supplies.
The new Iraqi letter, addressed to Mr. Perez de Cuellar and received Monday, was signed by Foreign Minister Aziz. It accuses the Secretary General of "keeping silent" about "crimes against Iraqi citizens."
Mr. Perez de Cuellar has on several occasions expressed concern over damage to civilian targets and loss of life, most recently over reports that Jordanian truck drivers had been bombed by allied warplanes in Iraq.
In a letter last month, Iraq also criticized the Secretary General for doing nothing about the raids.

HEADLINE: COMPANY EARNINGS;
Polaroid Earnings Rise

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 5

 BODY:
The Polaroid Corporation said today that its fourth-quarter earnings rose 18 percent, but the company warned that its profits will be squeezed this year by the recession and investments in new products. Polaroid's net income for the quarter was $55 million, or 90 cents a share, compared with $46.5 million, or 72 cents a share in the 1989 period. Sales rose 11 percent, to $596.2 million, from $538.1 million. The company said its results were bolstered by strong overseas sales of instant cameras and conventional film.

HEADLINE: Drought May Alter Face Of California as It Spurs Showdown Over Water

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 5

 BODY:
Once it seemed that there would always be plenty of water for Fred Starrh to irrigate the rich soil in Kern County on the western slopes of California's Central Valley. Come February, he would normally plow and irrigate for the cotton crop and water the alfalfa.
But the state system of dams and reservoirs on which he has long depended cut off water to him and thousands of other farmers on Monday as drought tightened its grip on California. So he will not be growing any cotton, and maybe only one crop of alfalfa. 
 "This is the worst in 40 years we've been farming," he said recently on his farm in Shafter in Kern County. "To just come up all of a sudden and say you are not going to get any water -- I never thought we'd end up like this."
 
Another Threatened Cut
 In Sacramento today, Federal officials said the drought might force them to cut water to growers from the other main water project in the state, the federally owned Central Valley Project, by up to 75 percent.
Critics of the water policy say that it is just as well that farmers like Mr. Starrh are being forced to stop growing crops like cotton and alfalfa. For years, they maintain, the economics of farming and the low rates charged for water have led farmers to waste water on high water-demanding crops of comparatively low value. Some of the crops, like rice and cotton, are subsidized by the Federal Government.
Farmers use 85 percent of all available water in California. Over the last two generations California built vast water projects to channel water from the mountains and streams of northern California to create the nation's largest farm industry in the Central Valley and huge sprawling cities in arid Southern California. For a long time, it seemed that there was enough water for both.
 
Titanic Political Struggle
 But the drought, now in its fifth year and the worst in the state's history, and relentless population growth are forcing a titanic political struggle that could well change the face of the largest state. Officials in major cities, now imposing unpopular rationing on urban dwellers, are looking for ways to divert water from farms to cities.
The water rights of the farmers were established decades ago when agriculture was the dominant industry of the state, and even as the population growth shifted the economic power to industrialized cities, the farmers retained their water rights. State officials have said there is only a 50-50 chance that they will be able to deliver half of the amount of water that urban and industrial users are expecting.
Alfalfa alone, which is sold mainly as hay for cattle and horses and requires more water per acre than any major crop except rice, uses more water than the combined household needs of 30 million Californians each year. Last year, more than 20 percent of farmland was planted with alfalfa, which used 16 percent of all available water. Cotton took another 16 percent of acreage and 8 percent of the water.
"A lot of these crops are low value," said John Krautkraemer, a lawyer with the Environmental Defense Fund in Oakland, which has been arguing for economic incentives to encourage farmers to sell some of their water rights to urban users. "This would not be taking place if we did not have subsidies or water rights that were decided a long time ago. If alfalfa is really that valuable to farmers, then they should be willing to pay more for water. It makes sense when you have a valuable resource like water not to be giving it away."
 
Farmers Defend Their Crops
 Farm interests defend the growing of hay, which brought receipts of $869 million to farmers in 1989. It is essential to the states's $2 billion dairy industry, second only to Wisconsin's, said Mary-Ann Warmerdam, director of natural resources for the 83,000-member California Farm Bureau Federation. It would not be economical to import hay from distant states, she said, adding that alfalfa, as a nitrogen-fixing legume, was an important rotational crop that replenished soil.
"Strangely enough, cows who eat hay make milk for kids in Los Angeles," said Mr. Starrh, who usually grows 2,900 acres of alfalfa. "I don't think we're growing something the public doesn't want."
Nowhere are these issues more pointed than here in Kern County, one of the nation's richest farm areas, with 856,059 irrigated acres of grapes, cotton, almonds, carrots, potatos, sugar beats and alfalfa among the crops.
The chief supplier of water here is the Kern County Water Agency, the second largest user of water from the state's system of dams and reservoirs, known as the State Water Project. Last year it took 21 percent of all the project's water, which was 557,000 acre-feet. This year, the agency expects to see its allotment cut to about 35,000 acre-feet. An acre-foot is about 326,000 gallons, enough to supply two average households for a year.
This spells economic calamity for the county, according to the agency, which estimates total direct revenue losses will be $4.1 billion. That includes $1.6 billion in lost income, with 7,700 farm workers and 3,900 people in support industries put of work.
Skeptics dispute these dire forecasts, saying that farm output has not declined during the first four years of drought, despite substantial cutbacks in water, because farmers have managed to find substitute supplies, mainly by drilling for water.
 
Lack of Underground Water
 But that is not an option for many, including Mr. Starrh, who like most of his neighbors is entirely dependent on the state water because there is no water under the ground. In addition to alfalfa and cotton, he grows almonds on his farm, 23 miles west of his home here. The hilly land sits just above the mighty aqueduct that carries water south to Los Angeles, but this year he cannot have a drop of it.
Normally, he hires up to 100 men to help move the heavy irrigation lines through the crops. But what little work there is now is done by his two sons, Fred Jr. and Larry, and two sons-in-law, Jay Kroeker and Mike Brown. Even before Monday's cutoff by the state, Mr. Starrh had decided to abandon his cotton crop and to cut back his alfalfa harvest to just one cutting instead of seven.
In the past, he paid the local water district $75 an acre-foot for his water, and spent another $17 an acre-foot to pump it. Thus water accounted for 40 percent of his cost of raising alfalfa and 30 percent for cotton.
The farmers who depend on water from the Central Valley Project, who are mainly along the eastern half of the Central Valley, pay only about $15 an acre-foot for water.
"California is reaping what it has sewn," Mr. Starrh said. "There has been no new water development for 15 years and the state has grown from 20 million to 30 million people. Now they come to agriculture and say, 'You do something to get more water for these people.' "
But others believe the drought will accelerate a transformation in California that will be every bit as powerful and wrenching as that wrought by the first irrigation projects decades ago, when wheat farmers were driven out by cotton and rice and vegetable growers and by the thrist of Los Angeles and other spreading cities.
"The days of super-rich Federal subsidies for water and crops is coming to an end," said Assemblyman Phillip Isenberg, a Democrat from Sacramento, who a member of the State Assembly's Water, Parks and Wildlife Committee. The time has come, said, for urban users to offer to help farmers financially to convert to more efficient irrigation and new crops in exchange for some of their water rights.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A California reservoir system has cut off water to thousands of farmers as the state's drought deepens. Fred Starrh, right, walking near an irrigation pipe in his alfalfa field with his son Larry. Mr. Starrh won't be growing any cotton this year and may have only one crop of alfalfa. (Scott Robinson for The New York Times)

The changes in the banking system would not solve the nation's current economic woes, but they could have important long-term benefits. Economic Analysis. [D6.]

HEADLINE: U.S. Acts to End Monopolies In New York Trash Hauling

BYLINE: By ALLAN R. GOLD

 BODY:
The United States Justice Department is negotiating to sell commercial garbage-collection routes in New York City to some of the nation's biggest waste-disposal companies, a move that could open the way to more competition in a business widely viewed as controlled by organized crime.
To encourage entrants into the market, the city would consider buying back the routes if the original purchasers wished to sell because of intimidation, the city's Consumer Affairs Commissioner said yesterday. The Justice Department confiscated the routes from private haulers who did not pay criminal fines for illegal dumping. 
 For years, Government officials and local businesses have dreamed of infusing more competition into the city's private garbage-hauling industry and of wresting it from the hands of organized crime.
City officials say restricted competition has raised the cost of doing business in New York City, where commercial enterprises must contract with private haulers to remove trash.
What has made other haulers reluctant to enter the New York market is fear that their equipment will be damaged and employees harmed by entrenched haulers, some controlled by organized crime, government officials say.
 
Many Earlier Investigations
 The private hauling industry has been a subject of many largely unproductive Federal, state and city investigations into charges of racketeering and anti-competitive criminal behavior.
The biggest garbage-hauling companies have long sought a piece of the lucrative New York market, estimated by city officials at $1 billion a year. But "this is a very, very vicious situation," an industry executive said.
The Justice Department has scheduled a meeting on Feb. 20 with several companies, including Browning-Ferris Industries of Houston and Laidlaw Inc. of Burlington, Ontario, said Mark Green, the Consumer Affairs Commissioner, whose department licenses private haulers.
The meeting was confirmed by Marc Holloway, a court-appointed monitor of the seized garbage companies. He is with the accounting firm of Deloitte & Touche.
Mark Hellerer, chief of the major crimes unit for the United States Attorney in Manhattan, said he could neither confirm nor deny the scheduling of the meeting, but he said the routes were for sale.
The Justice Department took over the routes when it confiscated assets of four private-hauling companies whose two owners were sentenced to prison in October for illegal dumping on Staten Island. The companies have more than 2,000 customers in Brooklyn, Queens, Manhattan and on Staten Island, putting them among the city's bigger operators.
The owners -- Angelo Paccione, 51 years old, and Anthony Vulpis, 39, who are serving 12-year terms -- failed to pay $22 million in fines. The Government is trying to recover the amount by selling the hauling companies, now operated by a trustee appointed by Judge Constance Baker Motley in Federal Court.
 
Department Licenses Haulers
 Laidlaw, a publicly held Canadian company that operates a waste-disposal subsidiary in many states, cannot confirm negotiations with the Justice Department, said a spokesman, T. A .G. Watson. Telephone calls to Browning-Ferris were not returned.
New York City has about 450 private garbage-hauling companies, ranging in size from one-truck operations to fleets with dozens of trucks. The Department of Consumer Affairs licenses the haulers and sets the rate they can charge the city's 250,000 businesses. Haulers own the garbage routes, which are regularly bought and sold. The city's Sanitation Department is responsible for picking up residential garbage.
"The private carting industry in New York City does not govern itself by the rules of the marketplace, but by the restraint of trade characterized by cartels," the Consumer Affairs Department said recently in a public statement. It said "carters violate the rules of economics by not competitively bidding for business."
"Instead, according to law-enforcement authorities, customers and routes are divided among haulers in the industry," the statement said.
Businesses that solicit competitive bids for removing their waste "nearly invariably" find that other haulers will not bid for new customers, the department said. Both businesses that try to switch haulers and new haulers who try to enter the market have faced threats, Commissioner Green said.
Ronald Goldstock, director of the New York State Organized Crime Task Force, said his agency had been trying to increase competition by encouraging the bigger national companies to enter the New York market.
 
'Violence Wouldn't Pay Off'
 To address concerns of intimidation by entrenched haulers, the city may become the hauler "of last resort" for the routes up for sale and buy them back from a company that wanted to get out, Commissioner Green said. Such a pledge "would be sufficient to deter any violence, since it would mean that violence wouldn't pay off for the intimidating carter," he said.
If the city became the hauler of last resort, the Sanitation Department would be responsible for pickups.
A spokesman for private haulers said they did not do business through intimidation. "It's a myth," said Salvatore Spinelli, a lawyer for the Council of Trade Waste Associations, which represents many private haulers. "There are customers that change carters, and nothing has happened to them."
The reason why bigger companies are not interested in New York City is lagging profitability, Mr. Spinelli said. "The collection end is no longer as glamorous or profitable as it had been 20 years ago," he said. In addition, he said, the bigger companies are put off by the "tough market."
"Can you imagine these Harvard business types dealing with the merchants on 14th Street?" he said.

HEADLINE: Proposal Has Supporters, But Many Raise Objections

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
The Treasury's proposal to overhaul the banking system was applauded yesterday by executives of some of the nation's largest banks, but it provoked objections from competing financial companies and from smaller banks.
Although the latest Treasury suggestions have the backing of the President, bankers remain cautious because many earlier efforts to change the banking laws have failed. A key issue in the minds of many bankers is whether heavy losses in the federally guaranteed deposit insurance program will be seen as a reason to control banks more tightly rather than grant them the power to enter new businesses. 
 "If we bankers are going to bear the burden of financing Federal deposit insurance, it is important that we get some quid pro quo in the form of changes in regulations that allow us to compete in the modern world," said John Rau, president of LaSalle National Bank in Chicago. "I'm worried that the people in Congress will want us to shoulder the losses of the F.D.I.C. but then say it is too risky to let banks broaden their activities."
 
'Sound, Sensible Package'
 Richard L. Huber, vice chairman of the Continental Bank Corporation in Chicago, said, "The Treasury has presented a sound, sensible package, but I would not bet a great deal of my personal money on it becoming law."
Patrick Forte, director of the Association of Financial Services Holding Companies, a group that represents large banking and other financial companies, was more optimistic about prospects for the plan. "Legislators in Washington are not particularly proud of the mess we are in," he said, "and I think this package will become law."
He said the most likely amendments would preserve more of the regulatory powers of state authorities and reduce the Treasury's oversight of banks.
Many Treasury proposals, like allowing a full range of securities sales and trading, conveying more power to sell insurance products, and developing a nationwide network of branches, have long been strongly backed by large banks. The chairmen of Citicorp, Chase Manhattan and J. P. Morgan all issued statements yesterday supporting the proposals.
 
2 Groups Speak Up
 But among smaller banks, and at firms whose businesses would become more open to competition from banks, the Treasury proposal was criticized. The small banks that make up the Independent Bankers Association of America, for example, do not like the idea of allowing nationwide branches. And the Securities Industry Association, which represents Wall Street firms, again warned that bank activities financed with insured deposits should be kept separate from securities trading.
Some of the strongest complaints of bankers concerned a proposal to limit a customer's insured deposits at a single bank to $100,000 for ordinary accounts and to $100,000 for an Individual Retirement Account.
Thomas E. Hales, chief executive of the Union State Bank in Nanuet, N.Y., warned that the proposal "is going to kill the small banks." "Even before this gets to Congress," he said, large depositors at small banks will begin shifting funds to Treasury securities or to larger banks, "which will still be perceived as too big to fail."
Jeffrey Gerhart, president of the First National Bank of Newman Grove, Neb., also said deposit insurance limits should not be narrowed. "People want to put their money where they live and feel safe about it."
Edward Yingling, the top lobbyist for the American Bankers Association, said he expected the Treasury proposals to be supported by banks of all sizes. "We are getting rid of the idea that some banks are too big to fail," he said.
 
Opposition From Insurers
 The Treasury sugggested that Federal prohibitions on the sale of insurance by banks be removed and that states be allowed to set rules for such sales.
Insurance agents, who have long fought to prevent banks from entering their business, are sure to fight the Treasury proposal. Banks have long sought a bigger piece of the brokerage fees and commissions paid to insurance agents for property and casualty insurance, which amounted to more than $23 billion in 1989, saying it is a low-risk business that is a natural extension of banking activities. Life insurance products like annuities are also incresingly attractive to banks, because they are an alternative to ordinary savings accounts or certificates of deposit.
The Treasury proposal to allow industrial companies to own banks drew criticism even before the Treasury study was issued.
E. Gerald Corrigan, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, said late last week that he doubted whether Federal regulators could keep a tight rein on potentially abusive practices if a banking company was controlled by a nonfinancial corporation, and questioned the accuracy of claims that the banking industry needs access to the capital of these companies.
