HEADLINE: Administration Presents Its Plan For Broad Overhaul of Banking

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5

 BODY:
The Bush Administration today formally presented its plan for the most sweeping overhaul of the nation's banking system since the Great Depression.
The proposal, the broad outlines of which had been widely known here for weeks, offers the nation's commercial banking system a competitive landscape unrestrained by many of the barriers and regulations that were installed by the Government after the national banking crisis in the 1930's. 
 The most important elements of the plan would allow commercial and investment banks to merge and would push down the barriers to interstate banking. It would also permit industrial companies to own banks.
 
A Search for Security
 The Administration's aim, which reflects both political and regulatory realities, is to brace the nation's banking system by offering it new avenues for profits that would ultimately enhance the safety and the security of the system and in the long run benefit the economy. [Page D6.]
But in a bow to the likely barrage of opposition from the insurance and real estate lobbies, the Administration stopped short of recommending that Congress allow banks to engage in the real estate business through direct investment. Also, the plan would permit insurance ventures only if a banking company's home state allows banks to sell insurance.
In a news conference, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said today that the Adminstration had two main goals: to strengthen a banking system that is under stress and to make banks more competitive internationally.
"We must modernize our banking laws to deal with the reality of the marketplace," he said, emphasizing the point several times during the news conference. "We now have one United States bank in the top 30 internationally. Twenty years ago, we had 9 banks in the top 30."
The proposal represents only the starting process for months of debate in Congress. The plan received a tepid, and in some instances hostile, response from some lawmakers today. Several of them warned that the Administration's plan harked back to the Reagan Administration's ill-fated effort to help the savings and loan industry in the early 1980's by allowing savings institutions to plunge into previously forbidden ventures.
For months, officials have stressed the need to address the shakiness of the banking system. Heightening the urgency, reports in recent days by both the White House and the Congressional Budget Office said the fund that insures bank deposits might need a taxpayer bailout within two years. Today's plan did not specifically address how to shore up the deposit insurance fund.
These are the major features of the Administration's plan:
*Industrial companies would be permitted to own banks, but in such arrangements insured deposits would be held in a separate affiliate to prevent their use in speculative ventures.
*Banks would be able to open branches in other states without restrictions, to buy banks in other states, to sell mutual funds and to enter investment banking activities like underwriting corporate securities..
*Banks would be permitted to sell insurance if that is allowed in the states where they operate or are chartered. Sixteen states now permit banks to sell insurance.
*The regulation of banks and savings and loans, which is now shared by four agencies, would be consolidated. The Federal Reserve Board would regulate state-chartered banks; a new agency under the Treasury Department, called the Federal Banking Agency, would oversee nationally chartered banks and savings associations.
*Loopholes in the laws on deposit insurance would be closed. An individual could have only two insured accounts in any one bank: a regular account, with insurance coverage limited to $100,000, and a retirement account, also with a limit of $100,000. Large depositors could still get broader coverage by having accounts at more than one bank.
*There would be a continuation of the policy of protecting all deposits, no matter how large, at those banks considered "too big to fail." Enforcement would be taken out of the hands of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and shared between the Treasury Department and the Federal Reserve.
The plan, which had been supported by large banks but worried smaller institutions, rewards financially strong banks by giving them the authority to enter into new businesses, like investment banking.The amount of capital, or long-term investment, that a bank has is the criterion for determining financial strength, and those institutions that are deemed poorly capitalized would be put under tighter control of the Government.
Mr. Brady said in an interview that he had initially been reluctant to endorse industrial ownership of banks, but that he was now convinced that adequate safeguards could be established to prevent a financial services conglomerate from squandering insured deposits.
In exchange for the right to own a bank, the industrial company would come under increased supervision from Washington. Regulators would have the authority to order a reduction in the parent company's dividends or the outright sale of some or all of its ownership in the bank if it is unable to comply with Federal standards on its financial health.
Under the plan, commercial banks would be permitted to lend to affiliated investment banks or other businesses, but only if the transaction meets the bank's usual standards and the loan is fully collateralized.
The main targets of the proposal are laws that were intended to curb speculative excesses that led to the collapse of the banking industry in the 1930's. These include the McFadden Act of 1927, which sharply limited interstate banking; the Glass-Steagall Act of 1933, which restricted the mergers of investment banks and commercial banks, and the Bank Holding Act of 1956, which prevented industrial companies from owning banks.
Over the years, there has been some erosion of these barriers. The Federal Reserve Board last September took a significant bite out of the Glass-Steagall restrictions when it gave permission to J. P. Morgan & Company to engage in securities underwriting, although with numerous limitations. Since then, three other banks have received similar permission. But the Federal Reserve does not have the authority to remove many of the remaining barriers.
For more than two decades, politicians have sought to overhaul the banking system. Indeed, many of today's proposals, particularly those aimed at changing the structure of the regulatory agencies, were recommended by a task force in 1984 that was headed by George Bush when he was Vice President. For the most part, that report had negligible impact on Congress.
 
Some Reasons for Worry
 But Treasury officials are hoping that today's plan stands a greater chance of passage because of the rapidly declining health of many of the nation's banks and the increasing concerns that taxpayers' money may be needed to bail out the industry.
One of the most urgent aspects of the plan, the reorganization of the fund that insures banks, is still being formulated by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and bankers. Mr. Brady insisted again today that taxpayer money would not be needed to rescue the insurance fund.
The chairman of the House Banking Committee, Henry B. Gonzalez, a Texas Democrat, indicated that he would oppose many elements of the proposal, including those aspects that give banks broader powers and change the regulatory structure.
"This is the same 'cart before the horse' mentality which plagued the deregulation of the savings and loan industry in the early 1980's," Mr. Gonzalez said. "Let's set the speed limits and train the policemen before we open a new super-expressway for financial institutions."
 
Matter of Priorities
 The chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, Donald W. Riegle Jr., Democrat of Michigan, said Congress would probably first address the issue of the health of the bank insurance fund before it turned to overhauling the banking structure.
"Interstate banking is an issue whose time has probably come," Mr. Riegle said. "But we have to be addressing the most urgent concerns first."
John D. Dingell, a Michigan Democrat who is the chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, said he would oppose the measure.
"Wall Street is a dry hole today, and even in the best of times it is an extremely risky business," Mr. Dingell said. "Allowing weak banks into the securities field or into insurance, which has solvency problems, will simply compound the problems of both."
 
Considering the Opposition
 Treasury officials said this week that they had sought to tailor the plan to remove much of the potential opposition, even if such changes would make the proposal fall short of their ideal.
In an interview in his office on Monday, Mr. Brady said he had decided early on not to challenge too many industries and interest groups for fear that it would doom the legislation.
"Don't wreck your chances of getting the three or four most important things done," Mr. Brady said he had told his staff. "Instead, leave that for a later day."
He said one provision of the plan, regarding the ability of banks to sell insurance, was strongly influenced by his days as a Senator from New Jersey when he saw the power of the insurance industry. In 1982, he introduced an amendment that would have expanded the power of banks to sell insurance. The proposal received virtually no support, and Mr. Brady had to quickly withdraw it.
The plan's drafters also decided to propose that banks be prohibited from making direct investments in real estate out of concern that otherwise the real estate lobby would seriously threaten passage of the plan.
 
A Much-Disputed Issue
 Perhaps the most politically charged issue is the limitations that would be imposed on insurance of bank deposits.
Late last week, senior Treasury officials were telling members of Congress that the Administration was going to recommend that an individual be allowed to have no more than two $100,000 insured accounts in the entire banking system.
But after facing a groundswell of complaints from bankers, who argued that such restrictions would lead to bank runs, the Treasury Department retreated from that position. Instead, it recommended that the limits be imposed on a per-bank basis instead of systemwide.
But the plan kept a proposal to limit the protection of institutional investors, like pension funds and securities firms, that break huge deposits into amounts of $100,000 to obtain complete insurance coverage. Under the Tresury plan, such deposits would no longer be protected.
Mr. Brady said the Treasury Department had initially considered creating one super-regulatory body that would supervise all banks and savings associations. But that idea was scrapped when the department concluded that it did not want to give up its authority to an independent regulator and that Congress would be unlikely to approve any plan in which all regulators would be part of the Administration.
"We split the baby down the middle," Mr. Brady said. "We wound up with a proposal that does a good part of what's needed, but doesn't go all the way and shake up the system when it can least afford it."

HEADLINE: High-Tech Takes On Truffles

BYLINE: By DENA KLEIMAN

DATELINE: CAHORS, France

 BODY:
DARIUS, an unusually well-mannered Labrador, has had a productive life here in the Quercy region of south-central France. At this time of year, he scratched around the earth, picked up the scent of truffles and found them for his master, in exchange for cookies.
But now Darius, along with the rest of the dogs -- and trained pigs -- that work the fields of France may be out of a job. 
 As scientists unlock the secrets around the prized black Perigord truffle, they are revolutionizing the way that truffle is grown, where it is found and even how it may be defined. They are also developing technology that could make it possible to hunt truffles with a machine.
"We don't have it yet, but we will," said Jacques Pebeyre, one of France's largest truffle merchants, who has helped finance the research for such a device.
This is one of the more dramatic new ventures under way in the hunt for the lusty black truffle -- Tuber melanosporum -- which is currently at the height of its harvest here in France and elsewhere. The ventures, including a synthetic that offers a chemical replica of the truffle's aroma, are raising questions about the truffle industry and where it is headed.
"Can you imagine a machine to find truffles?," said Richard Tarlov, director of product development for Balducci 's in New York, which is selling fresh black truffles these days for $1.25 a gram or $560 a pound. "It takes the soul out of the hunt. To me, it takes away from the aura of the item."
Truffle production has been on the decline in France and elsewhere for decades. At the turn of the century an estimated 1,000 tons were produced in France, but the average yield today is only about 50 tons.
But world demand for the pungent fungus -- which grows underground, looks like a piece of coal, smells not unlike old socks and has sold, retail, for as much as $650 a pound -- remains high, and incentives to increase production are strong.
While truffles represent only a small piece of the economy of the Query region, they are nevertheless a $50 million- to $100 million-a-year business.
Any changes in the industry could have a significant effect not only on the individuals who hunt them and the entrepreneurs who distribute them worldwide, but also on the gourmet shops and retail shops that sell truffles directly to consumers.
Because the truffle is a fungus that grows in the root systems of oak and hazelnut trees, much of the research revolves around developing special techniques of irrigation, fertilization and temperature control to enhance its growth.
Truffles sprout on the roots of trees, but eventually separate from the roots and grow in the earth on their own. It is known is that truffles require a temperate climate, an alkaline soil and a rather eccentric pattern of rainfall. Underground, they are undetectable to the human nose.
Truffles first develop in late March but are not ready for harvest until November to early April. Trees once had to be at least 20 years old before their roots produced truffles, but modern techniques have made it possible to harvest truffles from trees as young as four years. Truffle scientists say a tree can produce truffles until it is about 60. The hope is that as an increasing number of newly planted trees reach maturity, the harvest of truffles will soar.
"We are interested in anything that will enhance truffle production," said Paul Bonnet, a truffle producer in Carpentras, who recently started a clearinghouse for scientific information involving truffle research.
But these changes continue to meet with resistance in the Quercy region, where pigs and dogs still dig and root in the fields, and farmers hawk their bounty at a weekly truffle market. Some people suspect the precision of science when it comes to something as mysterious as the truffle. Others fear that all this objectivity will jeopardize the romance and lore intrinsic to truffles.
"People here don't want to talk about yield per acre," said Michel Kulifag, a biologist on the faculty of Paul Sabatie University in Toulouse and a truffle consultant. "They prefer that truffles remain mysterious." Dr. Kulifag said he had explained the optimum conditions for the truffle and specified irrigation schedules to the farmers, but many ignored them.
"It's anathema to say that truffles can be grown like corn," said Pierre Sourzat, a specialist in truffles on the faculty of the Lycee Agricole in Cahors. He also says that one day it may be possible to do so.
Meanwhile, Mr. Pebeyre, whose family has been selling truffles since 1897, finds himself in a nettlesome situation. He is a staunch promoter of the authentic black Perigord truffle and has spent tens of thousands of dollars on trying to find out all there is to know about the fungus. Not long ago scientists at Paul Sabatie University who worked under his financing told him they had just unmasked the 15 chemical compounds that make up the truffle's haunting aroma. Then they explained that they could manufacture a synthetic equivalent.
"That was the worst day of my life," Mr. Pebeyre said, adding that he told them not to produce the substance. But after they told him that they felt compelled to publish their results and that if he would not do the manufacturing someone else would, he gave them the go-ahead.
He now holds the patent for the process and has started marketing the synthetic substance, infused in safflower oil for use in omelets and salads. A small tin -- enough for about eight omelets -- is about $6. At the moment it is available only to chefs in France, but Mr. Pebeyre says he hopes to make it available to a wider market soon.
On a recent afternoon truffle hunt, Darius the Labrador stopped in his tracks: his master had surreptitiously poured synthetic-truffle liquid on the ground. Darius pawed madly at the earth, to find nothing. That led scientists to envision a machine that could hunt truffles. The machine, under study by chemists at Paul Sabatie, would be a kind of electronic nose or Geiger counter that would scan the earth for the chemical compounds that create the truffle's aroma. Pigs and dogs are thought to miss up to 80 percent of the truffles they hunt. The industry, Mr. Pebeyre said, envisions a machine small enough to carry on the shoulder and inexpensive enough to compare with the upkeep of a dog.
But new technology is not the only force shaping the truffle market or fueling fears about its future. Many people in the industry say the reputation of the black truffle itself is being eroded, largely because of public misunderstanding and fraud.
The public is frequently confused, people in the industry say, between the real black Perigord truffle and the much inferior "summer truffle."
The black Perigord truffle, which actually is more common in other parts of France, Italy and Spain than to Perigord, is a winter truffle and can only be bought fresh at this time of year. The summer truffle, Tuber aestivum, is black outside but white inside, has comparatively little flavor, costs about a tenth the price of a black truffles and can be bought fresh only in summer.
In the past several months the French Government has accused several major distributors of dying summer truffles black; dying truffles without disclosing the fact is illegal.
Confusion can arise when truffles are bought canned. If consumers simply ask for "truffles" without specifying which kind, they may not receive the authentic all-black variety.
Leon Pinto, president of La Compagnie Gourmand in Washington, which produces truffles in Europe and imports them to the United States, said there is a market for dyed summer truffles among caterers and others "who would like to feature truffles on their menu but don't have the money for the real stuff." Mr. Pinto said the summer truffle is inferior and gives the Perigord variety a bad name.
"It's definitely misleading," said Mr. Pinto, adding that until the name truffle is internationally regulated and applies only to Tuber melanosporum, spotting fakes will be difficult.
While the clamor over truffle fraud builds, just about every afternoon, the south-central French farmers, wicker basket in hand, trusty dog or pig in tow, try their luck.
Recently Pierre La Rinaudie, 63 years old, showed up in Mr. Pebeyre's office here in Cahors with one large truffle and two small pieces that he had just unearthed. The treasures were covered with dirt.
Mr. La Rinaudie said he had been walking along the highway with his dog when he found the prize. Mr. Pebeyre, who usually deals in deliveries of several hundred pounds at a clip, nevertheless inspected the bounty, placed it on the scale, and pronounced the truffles "good." Then he handed over 220 francs, the equivalent of about $44. Not bad change for an afternoon stroll.
Mr. La Rinaudie said he had never heard of a machine that could find truffles. It didn't seem to interest him much. But then, he confided, he never eats truffles.

HEADLINE: Review/Fashion;
Honest, Earthy Clothes for Men

BYLINE: By WOODY HOCHSWENDER

 BODY:
WHEN designers make more clothes for the woods than for the nightclub, something is up. Burliness, honesty, naturalness and integrity -- these are the qualities American men's wear designers celebrated in their fall showings last week.
The new ideals were embodied in the reverse chic of a plaid hunter's jacket, the zippered workingman's sweater or the salesman's reversible balmacaan raincoat. In men's fashion, the predatory elegance of the white-collar criminal has had its day. 
 Amid the uncertainty of war and recession, quiet, quality clothes are the thing. Preening is probably out, although Robert Forsythe, the Perry Ellis designer, made a case for it with cashmere tuxedos, in bright colors, and Joseph Abboud slipped elaborately embroidered vests under his evening jackets.
Isaac Mizrahi , whose instinct for the fabulous injected some life into men's wear last year, said recently that henceforth he would design only the kind of men's clothes he would wear himself. This is a bit like Attila the Hun saying, "Don't do anything I wouldn't do."
But Mr. Mizrahi, who is fond of gold lame sport jackets in his personal wardrobe, has toned down his act without sacrificing style. His fall collection is very carefully tailored in the English way -- trim shoulders and a suppressed waist -- and very plaid, from its Shetland sport jackets in bold plaids to cashmere-blend blazers in Royal Stewart tartans.
His full-cut camel's hair polo coats, in brown or camel, are as classic as a weekend in Newport. A traditional double-breasted banker's pinstripe gray suit was in a knit fabric (such suits are nearly always woven). By making his knitwear in tailored shapes, Mr. Mizrahi achieves the feel of a sweater but the look of a suit. He has very quickly gotten into the men's wear groove.
The show for Basco (an acronym for Barneys All-American Sportswear Company ) borrowed its theme from southern Italy to portray its version of honest, humble clothes. The lights came up on a group of models sitting on old wooden crates. Not playing dominoes exactly, but that kind of thing. These faux Sicilian homeboys were dressed in relaxed layers: a polo sweater under a cardigan or workman's sweater with patches, charcoal wool or leather jackets, topped by wool caps. Jackets in microfiber -- a velvety polyester -- hooded sweatshirts in wool and track pants in stretch twill combined street looks with better fabrics.
The Basco designer, Lance Karesh, is fluent in men's wear idioms that range from thrift-shop-style Ivy League jackets to workman's clothing, and this translates into clothes not terribly expensive but with a strong element of style.
One designer who is not afraid to be offbeat, but who can produce fine-tailored garments, is Sabato Russo . His workroom above the Strand Bookstore on Lower Broadway is on the same floor as the tailoring factory that makes his clothes. For fall, Mr. Russo showed a complete line of suits, most of which are in untraditional fabrics like alpaca, microfiber and satin gabardine.
While most of his silhouettes were classic, he also experimented with a modified Nehru cut, which he calls a "band collar" jacket, in both overcoats and business suits. Mr. Russo, who designed the men's wear for the Spike Lee film "Mo' Better Blues," makes clothes that have the modishness to suit a musician but are calm enough to be worn for business.
Several designers sought inspiration from workingman and woodsman contexts for their collections. Bill Robinson made zippered suits out of garbadine-twill mechanic's clothes and turned the shadow-plaid hunting coat into a sport jacket.
Mr. Robinson also tightened up his tailored silhouettes and continued to expand on his amazing range of colors for men, from a "leaf mousse" sweater to a "cadmium" corduroy suit.
One thing to note about men's fashion shows: they always seem to want to wrap you up in extra sweaters. At last week's Joseph Abboud show, there were "twin sets" for men and the inevitable sweaters wrapped around the waists and necks on sheepish male models.
Mr. Abboud, who has been named men's wear designer of the year two years in a row by the Council of Fashion Designers of America, is a creative traditionalist. For example, the trousers for his tuxedos were cuffed. For his tailored clothing, the shades were olive, the shapes classic.
But most of Mr. Abboud's show was devoted to rugged outdoors, like something a James Fenimore Cooper character would wear, including shearling-lined wool coats, distressed leather shearlings and hunter's plaid jackets.
The models, with their plaid jackets, lambswool hooded sweatshirts and houndstooth-check wool caps looked less like the urban homeboys of recent seasons and more like Natty Bumppo out for a lark.

HEADLINE: FOOTBALL;
It's Official: Big East to Play Football

BYLINE: By MALCOLM MORAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Feb. 5

 BODY:
After decades of futile discussions in which independent Eastern colleges were unable to form a football alliance, eight universities came together this morning to compete under a banner that changed the college sports marketplace in the 1980's.
Syracuse, Boston College and Pittsburgh, which had maintained football independence while competing in other sports within the Big East Conference, and Miami, the league's newest full-time member, will join with four other schools to participate in a Big East football league. Conference play will begin this fall on a limited basis, and the four additional schools -- Rutgers, Temple, West Virginia and Virginia Tech -- will compete in the Big East only in football. 
 The eight-team football league aspires to the same marketing and competitive triumphs that men's basketball programs began to realize when the Big East Conference was founded nearly 12 years ago.
 
Troubling Climate
 The difference between the discussions that have made this idea a success and the longtime frustrations that preceded them is the troubling climate within the industry.
"People want to make it work," said Fred Gruninger, the Rutgers athletic director. "There was no question in my mind that independents have become an endangered species."
"You don't want to get shut out," said William Flynn, the Boston College athletic director emeritus. "If you're not in a league, what independents are there? You just have no one to play."
 
Contract Is Investigated
 The universities sought a sense of security to help endure one of the most volatile periods in the history of college athletics.
The College Football Association's television agreement is under investigation by the Federal Trade Commission. Conference affiliations have been uncertain since Penn State was accepted last year to join the Big Ten. The bowl-game structure is vulnerable to proposals for a national playoff. And the decision of Sunkist this week to end its sponsorship of the Fiesta Bowl is the latest example of economic instability threatening the foundations of the sport.
The eight schools have responded because of a proven formula. The sight of a Big East emblem on a football and a helmet might seem out of place in the winter of 1991, but the machinery that helped transform Seton Hall and Connecticut from floundering basketball programs into nationally ranked championship contenders is already working to achieve the same sort of success in football.
 
Basketball Is Unaffected
 "I believe that by the end of 1991," said Mike Tranghese, the conference commissioner, "people will be sick and tired of hearing about us."
The new football arrangement will not have any effect on the basketball league, which Tranghese said would remain at nine teams.
Each football program has agreed to play at least five conference opponents no later than the 1995 season, although a Big East champion will be declared next fall, based on criteria not yet been determined.
The league's television network plans to syndicate a game of the week next season, in addition to seeking national network and cable appearances to be arranged under the C.F.A. agreement. A finance committee will oversee a revenue-sharing plan.
 
A Standard of Success
 The beginning of the Big East football league, symbolically if unofficially, came with Miami's decision last month to wear the conference emblem on its jerseys during its penalty-marred Cotton Bowl victory over Texas. Miami provides the league a standard of success represented by three unofficial national championships in the last eight years. Syracuse and West Virginia also played bowl games in recent seasons with the prospect of earning the top rank in the news-agency polls.
But most significant, the Big East football league will be able to claim at least 25 percent of the television households in the nation, and 5 of the top 16 markets, in the negotiations that will define its future.
"It gives us another dimension to what we are individually," said Jake Crouthamel, the Syracuse athletic director. "It gives us a forum to express ourselves as one. It gives us an opportunity to have access to things. Information. Keeping on top of situations. We had to do that individually before. Now we do it collectively."

HEADLINE: Everyone but Oil Companies Is for Cleaner Gas;
What Is Spilled

 BODY:
To the Editor:
While in Alaska following the Exxon Valdez spill two years ago, I heard oil referred to as the lifeblood of the United States economy. That image has more than one troubling implication when applied to two front-page headlines on Jan. 27: "Oil Spill, Growing Rapidly, Heads for Vital Saudi Sites" and "Hickel Wants Alaska to Go Prospecting Again."
An oil spill is never a purely accidental act. The Exxon Valdez was not accidentally carrying oil to a country accidentally craving it. No more or less accidental than the slick spreading over the Persian Gulf or a United States soldier losing blood as a result of a combat wound. Each is an extension of our national thirst for oil.
Gov. Walter J. Hickel of Alaska called in his State of the State address last week for oil drilling in North America's largest wildlife preserve, the Arctic National Wildlife Preserve. He also proposed an expansion of big state-funded projects, to be financed by a projected $2 billion surplus from Alaska's windfall from higher oil prices.
You quote him as saying, "Our goose that laid the golden egg, the North Slope oil, is running out, so we've got to build more geese." Unfortunately, it is too late to rebuild the casualties of our dependence on oil: the real geese and sea otters of Alaska, the oil-soaked cormorants of the Persian Gulf.
We must remember the troubling costs of continued dependence on foreign and domestic oil as lifeblood; for ourselves, our soldiers and the planet. The call on the Bush Administration to formulate a realistic energy policy for an oil-thirsty country must be loud and clear, and the debates in Congress and the Alaskan legislature over the future of the Arctic refuge should be taken as seriously as the debate over war.
 
DAVID CONOVER
Arlington, Mass., Jan. 27, 1991

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Rodman & Renshaw Names a New President

BYLINE: By DANIEL F. CUFF

 BODY:
Rodman & Renshaw Capital Group Inc., a financial services concern in Chicago that has been expanding for two and a half years, yesterday named Norman E. Mains president and chief operating officer.
Mr. Mains, who is 47, is currently executive vice president of Bateman Eichler, Hill Richards, an investment firm in Los Angeles. He succeeds Howard B. Silverman, 52, who resigned Jan. 22 after about a year in the post. 
 Rodman & Renshaw's chairman and chief executive, Kurt B. Karmin, worked with Mr. Mains at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the Wall Street investment firm that collapsed last year. Indeed, Rodman & Renshaw has hired several people from Drexel, Mr. Karmin said.
He said the company had grown to about $90 million in annual revenues, from about $30 million, during his two-and-a-half-year tenure and had expanded from a regional firm to one with offices in London and Vienna. The company has a fixed-income business and a commodities department, which Mr. Karmin said was started two years ago and now provides 25 percent of revenues.
Mr. Karmin said Mr. Mains would fit in because his background was in both fixed-income investments and in commodities. "He's one of the few people who understand the fixed-income business, the securities business and the commodities business," Mr. Karmin said. "To find a chief operating officer who can pitch in in all of these businesses is rare."
Mr. Mains said Rodman & Renshaw, with its feet in both securities and commodities and with retail and institutional accounts, "is in good shape for the 1990's in what is a relatively hostile environment for securities firms."
Mr. Mains has been at Bateman Eichler for two and a half years and has been responsible for its research, institutional sales, money management and public finance division as well as being its chief economist.
Before that, he was based in Chicago for six years as first vice president and director of research of Drexel's institutional financial futures and options division.
The Drexel post followed seven years with the Federal Reserve Board in Washington, where Mr. Mains was a senior economist and served under Arthur F. Burns, G. William Miller and Paul A. Volcker. He started his career as an economist for the Investment Company Institute, the mutual fund trade association.
He is a graduate of the University of Colorado, where he received bachelor's and master's of arts degrees. He received a Ph.D. from the University of Warwick in England.

HEADLINE: Real Estate;
Swedes Join Foreign Rush To Build Hotels in Atlanta

BYLINE: By Ford Risley

DATELINE: ATLANTA

 BODY:
A SWEDISH developer has begun construction of a luxury hotel here, its first project in the United States and one that will add to the city's growing inventory of foreign-owned hotels.
A privately owned development company based in Stockholm, Gullstedt Gruppen, is building a 50-story mixed-use tower that will include a 250-room luxury hotel as well as apartments and office space. 
 The $90 million GLG Tower, named for the company's United States subsidiary, GLG Center Inc., is being built in Midtown, the name that has been given to Atlanta's cultural district. In recent years, Midtown has been the site of increasing office construction. The project is expected to be completed late next year.
Gullstedt Gruppen is solely owned by G. Lars Gullstedt. The company's largest project to date is a 70-acre office and industrial park outside Stockholm, said Hans Tiveus, president of the company.
The hotel will occupy the first 19 floors of the 590,000-square-foot building, Mr. Tiveus said. It will be topped by five floors of office suites and 26 floors of apartments, with the office floors sandwiched between the hotel and the apartments. The project is being financed by Gotabanken, a Swedish bank.
The hotel will be operated by Occidental Hotels, a Spanish company that runs 22 hotels, primarily in Europe and the Caribbean, and will be known as the Occidental Hotel. Occidental's only other United States hotel is the Hotel Riverparc in Miami.
The Occidental is the latest foreign-owned luxury hotel to be built in Atlanta, which has long been dominated by the Hyatt, the Ritz-Carlton and the Western. Rates for the Occidental have not been set, but they are expected to be competitive with those of other prime hotels here.
The Hotel Niko, a joint development of the Japan Development Group and the Prudential Property Group, opened in October. The $80 million project has 440 rooms and rates average $135 a night.
The Swissotel, a $63 million joint development of Swissair and Ackerman & Company, an Atlanta developer, opened in January. The hotel's 358 rooms have an average rate of $145 a night.
A German-owned chain, the Penta Hotel Group, bought an existing Atlanta hotel last year and renovated it. The hotel has 504 rooms with average rates of $100 a night.
Atlanta has attracted hotel developers and investors from foreign countries because of its strong economy and the city's growing popularity as an international destination, said Henry B. Staley, vice president of Landauer Associates Inc., which tracks the hotel industry.
Nevertheless, the addition of so many rooms will probably keep the occupancy rate of luxury hotels at depressed levels for the next few years, Mr. Staley said.
The city's prime hotels had an average occupancy rate of 65.6 percent in 1990, largely unchanged from the year before, according to a survey by Landauer. But with the new rooms and a general economic slowdown, the rate will probably decline this year, he said.
"It's going to take a few years to absorb these rooms," Mr. Staley said. "In the long term, the hotels will be fine. But in the early years of those properties it's going to be tough going."
The Hotel Niko's occupancy rate is currently about 40 percent, said Yasuhiko Hando, the project manager. The rate has been steadily increasing since the hotel opened, however, and executives expect it to rise to 65 percent by the end of the year, he said.
The Swissotel has not been open long enough to gauge the response to it, but officials recognize that rooms will initially be slow to fill, said Janis Cannon, director of marketing. Still, she said, the company is encouraged that more than $2.5 million worth of business has already been reserved.
The Niko and Swissotel are both in Buckhead, a retail and office district north of downtown Atlanta. Buckhead already has several luxury hotels, among them the Ritz-Carlton.
In contrast, Midtown, which is between the Buckhead district and downtown, has fewer luxury hotels, which should give the Occidental Hotel an advantage in the higher-rate market, Mr. Tiveus said. He said he expected the Occidental to benefit from the recent growth of Midtown. I.B.M., A.T.&T. and BellSouth are among the companies that have opened large new offices in Midtown.
Mr. Tiveus said Gullstedt Gruppen had chosen Atlanta for its initial United States project because of the strong development climate and the fact that 60 Swedish businesses already had offices in the city.
GLG Tower was designed by Rabun Hatch & Associates of Atlanta. The rose-colored granite building will have a large arched facade and twin spires.
In addition to the tower site, Gullstedt Gruppen recently acquired three other parcels of land in Midtown, among them a 13-acre tract.
Mr. Tiveus would not comment on the company's plans for the other sites. But he noted that changes in Swedish tax laws last year had made it easier to invest outside the country.

SECTION: Section A; Page 12; Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 671 words

HEADLINE: Germany Says It Seeks to Curb Its Arms Exporters

BYLINE: By STEPHEN KINZER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BONN, Feb. 6

 BODY:
The Government of Chancellor Helmut Kohl announced today that it would seek new sanctions against illegal arms exporters, as a result of the growing scandal over German arms exports to Iraq.
Under the proposals, the minimum prison term for those convicted of violating a trade embargo imposed by the United Nations would be increased from six months to one year, with maximum sentences up to 10 years. 
 In addition, an official statemet said, falsifying export reports would "be generally punished as a criminaloffense." The statement also said a export control office would be created in the Office for Trade and Industry.
The proposals are a reaction to intense public pressure for tighter control of weapons exports. Politicians of every stripe have begun calling for new and tighter export controls.
Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher has promised a Government crackdown on German "merchants of death," and Economics Minister Jurgen Mollemann says he is determined to close "the last loopholes" in German export laws.
Germany is the world's fifth largest arms exporter. Income from the sale ofweapons abroad accounts for about 5 percent of Germany's export earnings.
According to press reports that have been confirmed by the Government, German companies may have helped Iraq improve its Scud missiles and extend their range. Iraq has launched Scuds against Israel and Saudi Arabia since the Persian Gulf war began.
After the first Scud attacks, Israel accused Germany of "almost criminal laxity" in its export policies.
Press reports have also charged that German companies built poison gas plants in Iraq and provided precision timers and other sophisticated equipment to the Iraqi military."The murderers are among us," Peter Glotz, a prominent Social Democratic member of Parliament, said in a recent interview. "They sow death and they bring shame to Germany."
Much of the arms business between Germany and Iraq was conducted in the 1980's, when Western nations including the United States favored Iraq because of its hostility to Iran. Now that President Saddam Hussein has been widely branded as an international outlaw, those who supplied him with arms are coming under sharp criticism.
Government officials say at least nine German companies are under investigation on suspicion of violating export laws. Various government agencies, as well as several groups in Parliament, are preparing legal initiatives.
Some specialists who have beenworking for years to limit German arms exports, however, said today that they were uncertain whether the sudden interest from Bonn would produce substantial results.
"Every time there is a scandal, politicians start talking about changing the laws," said Kerstin Meinhardt, an investigator at the Documentation Center, a research and political action group based in the central city of Idstein. "It's an attempt to appease people. But the whole process gets dragged out over months, and when people have finally calmed down, we are told that the issue has either died in committee or that Parliament could not reach an agreement."
Ms. Meinhardt suggested that if the German authorities were serious about regulating exporters, they could do so under existing law.
 A coalition of consumer groups in Bonn has announced plans for a nationwide consumer boycott of German companies that have helped arm Iraq. Organizers say targets include about a dozen companies, including giants such as Siemens and Daimler-Benz.
German companies are not the only ones implicated in arms sales to Iraq. American and French corporations have sold sophisticated equipment to Iraq. British companies reportedly built army barracks and a military command center in Baghdad, while Belgian and Yugoslav concerns are said to have built reinforced underground hangars for Iraqi warplanes.
German officials could not say whether companies that may have built military installations in Iraq are providing information to the allies about what they had built and where.

HEADLINE: Poor Mothers on Their Own Prompt Gifts to the Neediest

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ

 BODY:
"I hope this can help another woman who has had to struggle against great odds."
This request accompanied a $750 contribution to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, and the donor, Rhoda Selvin, noted that the gift was in celebration of her victory in a 15-year sex discrimination suit. 
 Ms. Selvin, an assistant vice provost of undergraduate studies at the State University of New York at Stony Brook, said yesterday that last year she received 10 years of back pay from the state university system and that she wished to share it with the Neediest Cases. Since her youth, it has been an annual practice for her to donate to the fund, but this time she more than tripled her previous gift and asked that it be used to help a woman.
"It seemed to be a fitting request," she said. "There are certainly many who need the help."
 
Aiding Seven Charities
 Over the last decade, women have become an increasing percentage of those who live under the poverty line. It is a problem that has concerned many who contribute to the Neediest Cases, and a number of gifts have been designated for single mothers.
The proceeds from the Neediest Cases are distributed to seven charities to aid the sick and the poor. The New York Times pays for the campaign's overhead. Money from the fund has provided a range of services for the elderly, disabled children and unemployed and homeless people, among others.
But while the fund helps a variety of people, a number of donors wrote that they worried most about young women struggling to raise children on their own.
Hope Cobb of Princeton, N.J., sent $350 for single mothers and wrote, "I know from my own experience how difficult this situation is, even if your financial situation is reasonably good." She said that she had been a single mother of two children and that it had been very trying, even without financial difficulties.
A $120 gift from Elizabeth Lipman of Brooklyn was also intended for a single mother. "I am grateful that my husband and I can share the responsibilities of having two children, and I feel for women, especially poor women, who must try to care for their children alone."
There was also $50 from Caroline A. Westerfield of Yorktown Heights, N.Y., who asked that the money be used to give a poor teen-age mother some diapers and baby formula.
One donor, Cindy Coopersmith, of New City, N.Y., wrote that the problems of single mothers are sometimes complicated by a history of physical and sexual abuse. "As a woman who was herself abused, I hope I can offer some small measure of comfort to someone who is trying to climb out of the pit of despair and depression that are the consequences of abuse," she wrote.
This was Ms. Coopersmith's first donation to the Neediest Cases, and she said it was inspired by the recent birth of her granddaughter.
"I know the $25 I give can't do much, but I hope it encourages another woman to stand on her own two feet," she said. "I hope that it makes her realize that someone cares."

HEADLINE: Hostility Toward Arabs and Jews Is Found on Rise

BYLINE: By DAVID JOHNSTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6

 BODY:
Crimes of hate against Arabs and Jews rose to record levels in 1990, Arab-American and Jewish organizations said in separate reports today.
Arab-American leaders said ethnic animosities against Arabs in the United States had been aggravated by events like the tensions in the Persian Gulf that led to war in January. 
 Jewish leaders cited a complicated mixture of factors, including a worsening economy, anti-Israel attitudes by some Americans and a loosening of social restraints on expressions of hatred, exemplified by the verbal assaults of the comedian Andrew Dice Clay and the graphically violent lyrics of musical groups like 2 Live Crew.
The reports catalogued thousands of acts against Arabs and Jews, from the murder of Rabbi Meir Kahane in New York last November to the gunshots fired into the car of a Palestinian family in Kansas City last September.
The groups issuing the reports were the American-Arab Anti-Discrimination Committee, the largest Arab-American rights organization in the United States, and the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith, a human rights organization established to combat anti-Semitism.
 
'Sharp Level of Public Hostility'
 The American-Arab Anti-Discrimination Committee, said that it had logged fewer than five anti-Arab incidents before Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2 but more than 40 complaints by the end of the year.
"The crisis in the Persian Gulf produced a sharp level of public hostility toward Arabs and and Arab-Americans," the report said.
Albert Mokhiber, president of the group, said no clear patterns of harassment have emerged to explain which Arab-Americans are likely to be victimized. "It is as though Arabs are put into one bag and shaken up and one is picked out to be targeted," he said.
The group also released an updated summary of anti-Arab acts since January. It said it logged nearly 60 incidents, including threatening phone calls, assaults and an arson fire at a restaurant in Michigan owned by an Arab-American.
The Federal Bureau of Investigation has acknowledged that it is investigating about 30 civil rights complaints involving Arab-Americans filed since last August. The number of active criminal investigations by the bureau is much smaller than the number of complaints to the anti-discrimination committee, which keeps track of many anti-Arab incidents that may not be considered a Federal crime.
 In its report, the Anti-Defamation League said that its nationwide survey of incidents against Jews rose for the fourth straight year, to 1,685. The report noted a "particularly troubling" increase of bias-related incidents on college campuses.
"Anti-Semitic and racist attacks are particularly troubling when they occur in a university environment devoted to respect for diverse ideas, people and cultures," said Abraham H. Foxman, the league's national director.
The audit, conducted annually since 1979, said there were 927 incidents of anti-Jewish vandalism and 758 acts of harrassment, threats or assaults against Jews or Jewish institutions. The total represented an 18 percent increase over the 1989 total of 1,432 incidents.
On college campuses, the league reported a total of 95 incidents at 56 institutions in 1990 as against 69 incidents at 54 campuses in 1989. The acts were directed against Jewish students and faculty members as well as places of Jewish activity, like Jewish fraternities and sororities.
The report also noted a decrease in one category, anti-Semitic attacks attributed to neo-Nazi skinheads, which declined by 27 percent. The report said that agressive law-enforcement efforts were responsible for discouraging such incidents.
In explaining the reason for the record level of anti-Semitic acts, the report cited "a coarsening of public expression and popular culture" and said this had combined with a deteriorating economy, which has traditionally heightened social frictions.
Grace Flores-Hughes, the director of the Justice Department's Community Relations Service, said today that the department had detected similar patterns of hate violence, in part through such mechanisms as the hate-crime telephone hotline, which was established year to encourage the reporting of hate crimes. Other officials said the department was investigating about 2,000 complaints of civil rights abuses, including an undetermined number of hate crimes against Arabs and Jews.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
The Dollar Is Down Again Despite Central Bank Efforts

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar slid to a postwar low against the German mark and a 10-year low against the British pound yesterday, despite attempts by central banks of leading industrial nations to support the currency.
The dollar's fall in recent days has been prompted by the belief that the Federal Reserve will lower interest rates even further to stimulate the economy. Lower domestic rates tend to decrease the value of the dollar since dollar-denominated investments earn less interest than investments made in nations with higher interest rates. 
 The Fed on Friday cut its discount rate, the interest it charges on loans to banks, and the action prompted many large banks to reduce their prime lending rate.
Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said yesterday that he would like to see interest rates fall further.
The Fed's action contrasts sharply with recent moves by the central bank of Germany, the Bundesbank, to raise its interest rates, making the mark more attractive. The interest paid on six-month government securities in Germany is about 2.5 percentage points higher than the comparable United States Treasury note.
Central banks from a number of nations, including the Fed, bought dollars yesterday by selling marks, but that did little to brake the dollar's slide, currency traders said.
The dollar stood at 1.4483 marks in domestic trading at late afternoon, a new postwar low, down from 1.4577 marks on Tuesday. The previous low of 1.4560 marks was set on Monday.
The pound strengthened against the dollar, crossing the $2 level in a rate not seen since 1981. One pound cost $2.0035 in New York yesterday, up from $1.9920 late on Tuesday.
Against the Japanese currency, the dollar fell in New York to 128.13 yen, its lowest level in many months, from 129.48 yen on Tuesday.
On the future direction of the dollar, one trader said he did not think the dollar's fall had been broken.
"The interest-rate differentials will continue to widen, and that will continue to cause the dollar to drop further," said John McCarthy, the chief currency dealer at Algemene Bank Nederland in New York.
But Lawrence A. Kudlow, the chief economist at Bear, Stearns & Company, said he was not overly concerned by the dollar's decline. The American stock and bond markets "have been rallying very strongly despite the drop in the dollar," he said, "and the reason for that is lower domestic inflation expectations and lower interest rates,"
He said, however, that the situation that prompted the dollar's fall showed the need for better coordination of interest rate policies of the leading industrial nations.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with those of late on Tuesday, included: 1.2316 Swiss francs, down from 1.2430; 4.9325 French francs, down from 4.9625; 1,088.50 Italian lire, down from 1,095.75, and 1.1575 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1583.
Gold prices, meanwhile, fell. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold fetched $362.90 an ounce, down $3.50 from Tuesday.

HEADLINE: Welfare Suit Could Hurt Cuomo Budget

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Feb. 6

 BODY:
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's proposed budget does not plan for the possibility that a judge will order the state to increase its welfare grant this year, a ruling that could add hundreds of millions of dollars to New York's $6 billion budget gap.
A trial in the case, Jiggetts v. Grinker, is to begin on March 4 in State Supreme Court in Manhattan. It will determine whether the state's shelter allowance, a component of the welfare grant, is sufficient to prevent homelessness, as is required by state law. 
 The judge, Karla Moskowitz, seemed to signal her inclination in the case when she granted a preliminary injunction in 1988 and wrote that the shelter allowance in New York City was "totally inadequate."
But despite a 1990 Court of Appeals decision affirming Justice Moskowitz's authority to determine the adequacy of the shelter allowance, the Cuomo administration chose not to deal with the issue in its budget for the 1992 fiscal year.
 
Assumptions for Revenue
 The lack of contingency planning for the court ruling reflects one of several risky assumptions that could upset the fragile balance of Mr. Cuomo's $29.15 billion budget, even if the Governor is able to sidestep the many political mines planted in the Legislature.
The budget's revenue forecasts are based on projections that national economic growth will resume after mid-year and that the war in the Persian Gulf will end "within the next six months or so."
It includes no money for raises for state employees in a year when the state must negotiate new contracts with its largest public employee unions. And it relies on $875 million in Medicaid cuts that may be difficult to achieve because the recession is expanding the state's caseload.
The Jiggetts case poses an immediate threat, and Matthew Diller, the Legal Aid Society lawyer representing the welfare recipients who filed the lawsuit, said the Governor had opted for a budgetary stalling tactic by refusing to address it.
 
Cuomo Sees Few Options
 "Trying to prove that $312 is an inadequate rent subsidy for a family of four in New York City is like proving that the sky is blue," he said. "But we'll have this trial, and when they lose they'll appeal and delay it longer."
Mr. Cuomo's press secretary, Anne W. Crowley, said the fiscal reality of the state's budget shortfall left the Governor with few options.
"The alternative would have been to set aside money for a case that we have not conceded when the money is needed for other programs, particularly in these difficult fiscal times," she said.
The potential cost of losing the Jiggetts case is uncertain, but state officials have made rough calculations.
If Justice Moskowitz orders the state to pay 100 percent of the rents currently being paid by the state's 1.3 million welfare recipients, the increase could add between $90 million and $140 million to the state's $3 billion annual welfare expenditures, according to a Cuomo administration source. If she ordered the state to pay average fair-market rents, the cost could be twice as high.
 
30 Welfare Recipients
 A 1935 law says the shelter allowance "shall be adequate" to provide for the proper upbringing of children, but it provides little definition of adequacy. The Court of Appeals ruled that assistance levels have to be high enough to keep families with dependent children from becoming homeless.
The Jiggetts case was filed in 1987 by 30 welfare recipients in New York City, including Barbara Jiggetts, who faced eviction because their shelter allowances did not cover their rents. Many were forced to pay rent with a part of their welfare grant that is intended for food and clothing.
The shelter allowance, which varies by county and by family size, has been raised by the Legislature twice since 1975. But a recent study by the State Communities Aid Association shows that it remains far below average fair-market rents in both urban and rural counties.
The study showed, for instance, that the full welfare grant of $577 for a family of three in New York City, which includes a basic grant, the shelter allowance and two energy grants, would barely cover the city's average fair-market rent of $504, which was calculated by the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development. The situation is analogous in Suffolk and Westchester Counties, where lawsuits similar to the Jiggetts case have been filed.
One alternative that has been discussed by the Cuomo administration is consolidating the components of the welfare grant into a single payment. But administration officials and social service advocates agree that such a move could be viewed as a cynical legal maneuver unless it was accompanied by a significant increase in the size of the grant.
"You would probably make the lawsuit moot because there wouldn't be a shelter allowance," said one Cuomo aide. "But you wouldn't do anything to help the people out there unless you consolidate it and do an increase."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Pilots at Northwest To Weigh Concessions

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: EAGAN, Minn., Feb. 6

 BODY:
The pilots for Northwest Airlines have agreed to negotiate contract concessions because of the carrier's worsening financial condition.
The move by the 5,600-member union came on Tuesday, a day after union officials met with Northwest's chairman, Alfred A. Checchi, and chief executive, John Dasburg, for more than three hours. 
 "Obviously, we realize the company is bleeding," said Peter Dodge, chairman of the Air Line Pilots Association's 17-member master executive council at Northwest. The council voted unanimously to provide relief.
Possible areas for concessions include reductions in pay, pensions and benefits and relaxation of work rules.
Neither the comany nor union officials would discuss the extent of the airline's financial problems.
A Northwest spokeswoman said the carrier suffered from the same problems as the whole industry: a sluggish economy, high fuel prices and reduced air travel because of the Persian Gulf war.
"Things are worse than we want to believe they are in terms of cash flow," said Bruce Retrum, secretary-treasurer of Local 2747 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, which represents the airline's 8,600 flight attendants.
Last week, Northwest and the flight attendants' union agreed to a leave-of-absence program that would reduce payroll expenses for the next two months. Mr. Retrum said about 400 flight attendants had signed up.
"We're trying to get people off the payroll on a temporary and voluntary basis," Mr. Retrum said. "Push is going to come to shove if we don't."
Leaders of Northwest's 26,000-member machinists' union also said they were working with the company to trim costs.
